And Mr Boffin.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Strict system here; eh, my lad?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, as he was booked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the boy. \xe2\x80\x98I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t get on without it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBy which he probably meant that his mind would have been shattered to\r\npieces without this fiction of an occupation. Wearing in his solitary\r\nconfinement no fetters that he could polish, and being provided with no\r\ndrinking-cup that he could carve, he had fallen on the device of ringing\r\nalphabetical changes into the two volumes in question, or of entering\r\nvast numbers of persons out of the Directory as transacting business\r\nwith Mr Lightwood. It was the more necessary for his spirits, because,\r\nbeing of a sensitive temperament, he was apt to consider it personally\r\ndisgraceful to himself that his master had no clients.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How long have you been in the law, now?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mr Boffin, with a\r\npounce, in his usual inquisitive way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve been in the law, now, sir, about three years.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Must have been as good as born in it!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, with admiration.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you like it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t mind it much,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Young Blight, heaving a sigh, as if its\r\nbitterness were past.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What wages do you get?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Half what I could wish,\xe2\x80\x99 replied young Blight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s the whole that you could wish?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Fifteen shillings a week,\xe2\x80\x99 said the boy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98About how long might it take you now, at a average rate of going, to be\r\na Judge?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mr Boffin, after surveying his small stature in silence.\r\n\r\nThe boy answered that he had not yet quite worked out that little\r\ncalculation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing to prevent your going in for it?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr\r\nBoffin.\r\n\r\nThe boy virtually replied that as he had the honour to be a Briton who\r\nnever never never, there was nothing to prevent his going in for it. Yet\r\nhe seemed inclined to suspect that there might be something to prevent\r\nhis coming out with it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Would a couple of pound help you up at all?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mr Boffin.\r\n\r\nOn this head, young Blight had no doubt whatever, so Mr Boffin made him\r\na present of that sum of money, and thanked him for his attention to his\r\n(Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s) affairs; which, he added, were now, he believed, as good\r\nas settled.\r\n\r\nThen Mr Boffin, with his stick at his ear, like a Familiar Spirit\r\nexplaining the office to him, sat staring at a little bookcase of Law\r\nPractice and Law Reports, and at a window, and at an empty blue bag, and\r\nat a stick of sealing-wax, and a pen, and a box of wafers, and an apple,\r\nand a writing-pad--all very dusty--and at a number of inky smears\r\nand blots, and at an imperfectly-disguised gun-case pretending to be\r\nsomething legal, and at an iron box labelled HARMON ESTATE, until Mr\r\nLightwood appeared.\r\n\r\nMr Lightwood explained that he came from the proctor\xe2\x80\x99s, with whom he had\r\nbeen engaged in transacting Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s affairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And they seem to have taken a deal out of you!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, with\r\ncommiseration.\r\n\r\nMr Lightwood, without explaining that his weariness was chronic,\r\nproceeded with his exposition that, all forms of law having been at\r\nlength complied with, will of Harmon deceased having been proved, death\r\nof Harmon next inheriting having been proved, &c., and so forth, Court\r\nof Chancery having been moved, &c. and so forth, he, Mr Lightwood, had\r\nnow the gratification, honour, and happiness, again &c. and so forth, of\r\ncongratulating Mr Boffin on coming into possession as residuary legatee,\r\nof upwards of one hundred thousand pounds, standing in the books of the\r\nGovernor and Company of the Bank of England, again &c. and so forth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And what is particularly eligible in the property Mr Boffin, is, that\r\nit involves no trouble. There are no estates to manage, no rents to\r\nreturn so much per cent upon in bad times (which is an extremely dear\r\nway of getting your name into the newspapers), no voters to become\r\nparboiled in hot water with, no agents to take the cream off the\r\nmilk before it comes to table. You could put the whole in a cash-box\r\nto-morrow morning, and take it with you to--say, to the Rocky Mountains.\r\nInasmuch as every man,\xe2\x80\x99 concluded Mr Lightwood, with an indolent smile,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98appears to be under a fatal spell which obliges him, sooner or later,\r\nto mention the Rocky Mountains in a tone of extreme familiarity to some\r\nother man, I hope you\xe2\x80\x99ll excuse my pressing you into the service of that\r\ngigantic range of geographical bores.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWithout following this last remark very closely, Mr Boffin cast his\r\nperplexed gaze first at the ceiling, and then at the carpet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 he remarked, \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what to say about it, I am sure. I\r\nwas a\xe2\x80\x99most as well as I was. It\xe2\x80\x99s a great lot to take care of.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear Mr Boffin, then DON\xe2\x80\x99T take care of it!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Eh?\xe2\x80\x99 said that gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Speaking now,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mortimer, \xe2\x80\x98with the irresponsible imbecility\r\nof a private individual, and not with the profundity of a professional\r\nadviser, I should say that if the circumstance of its being too much,\r\nweighs upon your mind, you have the haven of consolation open to you\r\nthat you can easily make it less. And if you should be apprehensive of\r\nthe trouble of doing so, there is the further haven of consolation that\r\nany number of people will take the trouble off your hands.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well! I don\xe2\x80\x99t quite see it,\xe2\x80\x99 retorted Mr Boffin, still perplexed.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s not satisfactory, you know, what you\xe2\x80\x99re a-saying.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is Anything satisfactory, Mr Boffin?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mortimer, raising his\r\neyebrows.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I used to find it so,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Mr Boffin, with a wistful look. \xe2\x80\x98While\r\nI was foreman at the Bower--afore it WAS the Bower--I considered the\r\nbusiness very satisfactory. The old man was a awful Tartar (saying\r\nit, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure, without disrespect to his memory) but the business was\r\na pleasant one to look after, from before daylight to past dark. It\xe2\x80\x99s\r\na\xe2\x80\x99most a pity,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, rubbing his ear, \xe2\x80\x98that he ever went and\r\nmade so much money. It would have been better for him if he hadn\xe2\x80\x99t so\r\ngiven himself up to it. You may depend upon it,\xe2\x80\x99 making the discovery\r\nall of a sudden, \xe2\x80\x98that HE found it a great lot to take care of!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Lightwood coughed, not convinced.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And speaking of satisfactory,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98why, Lord save\r\nus! when we come to take it to pieces, bit by bit, where\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nsatisfactoriness of the money as yet? When the old man does right the\r\npoor boy after all, the poor boy gets no good of it. He gets made away\r\nwith, at the moment when he\xe2\x80\x99s lifting (as one may say) the cup and\r\nsarser to his lips. Mr Lightwood, I will now name to you, that on behalf\r\nof the poor dear boy, me and Mrs Boffin have stood out against the old\r\nman times out of number, till he has called us every name he could lay\r\nhis tongue to. I have seen him, after Mrs Boffin has given him her mind\r\nrespecting the claims of the nat\xe2\x80\x99ral affections, catch off Mrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbonnet (she wore, in general, a black straw, perched as a matter of\r\nconvenience on the top of her head), and send it spinning across\r\nthe yard. I have indeed. And once, when he did this in a manner that\r\namounted to personal, I should have given him a rattler for himself, if\r\nMrs Boffin hadn\xe2\x80\x99t thrown herself betwixt us, and received flush on the\r\ntemple. Which dropped her, Mr Lightwood. Dropped her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Lightwood murmured \xe2\x80\x98Equal honour--Mrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s head and heart.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You understand; I name this,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98to show you, now the\r\naffairs are wound up, that me and Mrs Boffin have ever stood as we were\r\nin Christian honour bound, the children\xe2\x80\x99s friend. Me and Mrs Boffin\r\nstood the poor girl\xe2\x80\x99s friend; me and Mrs Boffin stood the poor boy\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfriend; me and Mrs Boffin up and faced the old man when we momently\r\nexpected to be turned out for our pains. As to Mrs Boffin,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr\r\nBoffin lowering his voice, \xe2\x80\x98she mightn\xe2\x80\x99t wish it mentioned now she\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nFashionable, but she went so far as to tell him, in my presence, he was\r\na flinty-hearted rascal.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Lightwood murmured \xe2\x80\x98Vigorous Saxon spirit--Mrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nancestors--bowmen--Agincourt and Cressy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The last time me and Mrs Boffin saw the poor boy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin,\r\nwarming (as fat usually does) with a tendency to melt, \xe2\x80\x98he was a child\r\nof seven year old. For when he came back to make intercession for his\r\nsister, me and Mrs Boffin were away overlooking a country contract which\r\nwas to be sifted before carted, and he was come and gone in a single\r\nhour. I say he was a child of seven year old. He was going away, all\r\nalone and forlorn, to that foreign school, and he come into our place,\r\nsituate up the yard of the present Bower, to have a warm at our fire.\r\nThere was his little scanty travelling clothes upon him. There was his\r\nlittle scanty box outside in the shivering wind, which I was going to\r\ncarry for him down to the steamboat, as the old man wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t hear of\r\nallowing a sixpence coach-money. Mrs Boffin, then quite a young woman\r\nand pictur of a full-blown rose, stands him by her, kneels down at the\r\nfire, warms her two open hands, and falls to rubbing his cheeks; but\r\nseeing the tears come into the child\xe2\x80\x99s eyes, the tears come fast into\r\nher own, and she holds him round the neck, like as if she was protecting\r\nhim, and cries to me, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d give the wide wide world, I would, to run\r\naway with him!\xe2\x80\x9d I don\xe2\x80\x99t say but what it cut me, and but what it at the\r\nsame time heightened my feelings of admiration for Mrs Boffin. The poor\r\nchild clings to her for awhile, as she clings to him, and then, when\r\nthe old man calls, he says \xe2\x80\x9cI must go! God bless you!\xe2\x80\x9d and for a moment\r\nrests his heart against her bosom, and looks up at both of us, as if it\r\nwas in pain--in agony. Such a look! I went aboard with him (I gave him\r\nfirst what little treat I thought he\xe2\x80\x99d like), and I left him when he had\r\nfallen asleep in his berth, and I came back to Mrs Boffin. But tell\r\nher what I would of how I had left him, it all went for nothing, for,\r\naccording to her thoughts, he never changed that look that he had looked\r\nup at us two. But it did one piece of good. Mrs Boffin and me had no\r\nchild of our own, and had sometimes wished that how we had one. But not\r\nnow. \xe2\x80\x9cWe might both of us die,\xe2\x80\x9d says Mrs Boffin, \xe2\x80\x9cand other eyes might\r\nsee that lonely look in our child.\xe2\x80\x9d So of a night, when it was very\r\ncold, or when the wind roared, or the rain dripped heavy, she would\r\nwake sobbing, and call out in a fluster, \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you see the poor child\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nface? O shelter the poor child!\xe2\x80\x9d--till in course of years it gently wore\r\nout, as many things do.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear Mr Boffin, everything wears to rags,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mortimer, with a\r\nlight laugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I won\xe2\x80\x99t go so far as to say everything,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mr Boffin, on whom\r\nhis manner seemed to grate, \xe2\x80\x98because there\xe2\x80\x99s some things that I never\r\nfound among the dust. Well, sir. So Mrs Boffin and me grow older and\r\nolder in the old man\xe2\x80\x99s service, living and working pretty hard in it,\r\ntill the old man is discovered dead in his bed. Then Mrs Boffin and me\r\nseal up his box, always standing on the table at the side of his bed,\r\nand having frequently heerd tell of the Temple as a spot where lawyer\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndust is contracted for, I come down here in search of a lawyer to\r\nadvise, and I see your young man up at this present elevation, chopping\r\nat the flies on the window-sill with his penknife, and I give him a Hoy!\r\nnot then having the pleasure of your acquaintance, and by that\r\nmeans come to gain the honour. Then you, and the gentleman in the\r\nuncomfortable neck-cloth under the little archway in Saint Paul\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nChurchyard--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Doctors\xe2\x80\x99 Commons,\xe2\x80\x99 observed Lightwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I understood it was another name,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, pausing, \xe2\x80\x98but you\r\nknow best. Then you and Doctor Scommons, you go to work, and you do the\r\nthing that\xe2\x80\x99s proper, and you and Doctor S. take steps for finding out\r\nthe poor boy, and at last you do find out the poor boy, and me and Mrs\r\nBoffin often exchange the observation, \xe2\x80\x9cWe shall see him again,\r\nunder happy circumstances.\xe2\x80\x9d But it was never to be; and the want of\r\nsatisfactoriness is, that after all the money never gets to him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But it gets,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Lightwood, with a languid inclination of the\r\nhead, \xe2\x80\x98into excellent hands.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It gets into the hands of me and Mrs Boffin only this very day and\r\nhour, and that\xe2\x80\x99s what I am working round to, having waited for this day\r\nand hour a\xe2\x80\x99 purpose. Mr Lightwood, here has been a wicked cruel\r\nmurder. By that murder me and Mrs Boffin mysteriously profit. For the\r\napprehension and conviction of the murderer, we offer a reward of one\r\ntithe of the property--a reward of Ten Thousand Pound.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Boffin, it\xe2\x80\x99s too much.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Lightwood, me and Mrs Boffin have fixed the sum together, and we\r\nstand to it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But let me represent to you,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Lightwood, \xe2\x80\x98speaking now with\r\nprofessional profundity, and not with individual imbecility, that the\r\noffer of such an immense reward is a temptation to forced suspicion,\r\nforced construction of circumstances, strained accusation, a whole\r\ntool-box of edged tools.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, a little staggered, \xe2\x80\x98that\xe2\x80\x99s the sum we put o\xe2\x80\x99\r\none side for the purpose. Whether it shall be openly declared in the new\r\nnotices that must now be put about in our names--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In your name, Mr Boffin; in your name.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very well; in my name, which is the same as Mrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s, and means\r\nboth of us, is to be considered in drawing \xe2\x80\x98em up. But this is the first\r\ninstruction that I, as the owner of the property, give to my lawyer on\r\ncoming into it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your lawyer, Mr Boffin,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Lightwood, making a very short\r\nnote of it with a very rusty pen, \xe2\x80\x98has the gratification of taking the\r\ninstruction. There is another?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There is just one other, and no more. Make me as compact a little will\r\nas can be reconciled with tightness, leaving the whole of the property\r\nto \xe2\x80\x9cmy beloved wife, Henerietty Boffin, sole executrix\xe2\x80\x9d. Make it as\r\nshort as you can, using those words; but make it tight.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAt some loss to fathom Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s notions of a tight will, Lightwood\r\nfelt his way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I beg your pardon, but professional profundity must be exact. When you\r\nsay tight--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I mean tight,\xe2\x80\x99 Mr Boffin explained.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Exactly so. And nothing can be more laudable. But is the tightness to\r\nbind Mrs Boffin to any and what conditions?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bind Mrs Boffin?\xe2\x80\x99 interposed her husband. \xe2\x80\x98No! What are you thinking\r\nof! What I want is, to make it all hers so tight as that her hold of it\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t be loosed.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hers freely, to do what she likes with? Hers absolutely?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Absolutely?\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Mr Boffin, with a short sturdy laugh. \xe2\x80\x98Hah! I\r\nshould think so! It would be handsome in me to begin to bind Mrs Boffin\r\nat this time of day!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSo that instruction, too, was taken by Mr Lightwood; and Mr Lightwood,\r\nhaving taken it, was in the act of showing Mr Boffin out, when Mr Eugene\r\nWrayburn almost jostled him in the door-way. Consequently Mr Lightwood\r\nsaid, in his cool manner, \xe2\x80\x98Let me make you two known to one another,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nand further signified that Mr Wrayburn was counsel learned in the\r\nlaw, and that, partly in the way of business and partly in the way of\r\npleasure, he had imparted to Mr Wrayburn some of the interesting facts\r\nof Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s biography.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Delighted,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene--though he didn\xe2\x80\x99t look so--\xe2\x80\x98to know Mr Boffin.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thankee, sir, thankee,\xe2\x80\x99 returned that gentleman. \xe2\x80\x98And how do YOU like\r\nthe law?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A--not particularly,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Eugene.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Too dry for you, eh? Well, I suppose it wants some years of sticking\r\nto, before you master it. But there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing like work. Look at the\r\nbees.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I beg your pardon,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Eugene, with a reluctant smile, \xe2\x80\x98but will\r\nyou excuse my mentioning that I always protest against being referred to\r\nthe bees?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I object on principle,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, \xe2\x80\x98as a biped--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As a what?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mr Boffin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As a two-footed creature;--I object on principle, as a two-footed\r\ncreature, to being constantly referred to insects and four-footed\r\ncreatures. I object to being required to model my proceedings according\r\nto the proceedings of the bee, or the dog, or the spider, or the camel.\r\nI fully admit that the camel, for instance, is an excessively temperate\r\nperson; but he has several stomachs to entertain himself with, and I\r\nhave only one. Besides, I am not fitted up with a convenient cool cellar\r\nto keep my drink in.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I said, you know,\xe2\x80\x99 urged Mr Boffin, rather at a loss for an answer,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98the bee.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Exactly. And may I represent to you that it\xe2\x80\x99s injudicious to say the\r\nbee? For the whole case is assumed. Conceding for a moment that there is\r\nany analogy between a bee, and a man in a shirt and pantaloons (which\r\nI deny), and that it is settled that the man is to learn from the bee\r\n(which I also deny), the question still remains, what is he to learn?\r\nTo imitate? Or to avoid? When your friends the bees worry themselves to\r\nthat highly fluttered extent about their sovereign, and become perfectly\r\ndistracted touching the slightest monarchical movement, are we men to\r\nlearn the greatness of Tuft-hunting, or the littleness of the\r\nCourt Circular? I am not clear, Mr Boffin, but that the hive may be\r\nsatirical.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98At all events, they work,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ye-es,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Eugene, disparagingly, \xe2\x80\x98they work; but don\xe2\x80\x99t you think\r\nthey overdo it? They work so much more than they need--they make so much\r\nmore than they can eat--they are so incessantly boring and buzzing at\r\ntheir one idea till Death comes upon them--that don\xe2\x80\x99t you think they\r\noverdo it? And are human labourers to have no holidays, because of the\r\nbees? And am I never to have change of air, because the bees don\xe2\x80\x99t? Mr\r\nBoffin, I think honey excellent at breakfast; but, regarded in the light\r\nof my conventional schoolmaster and moralist, I protest against the\r\ntyrannical humbug of your friend the bee. With the highest respect for\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thankee,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98Morning, morning!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBut, the worthy Mr Boffin jogged away with a comfortless impression he\r\ncould have dispensed with, that there was a deal of unsatisfactoriness\r\nin the world, besides what he had recalled as appertaining to the Harmon\r\nproperty. And he was still jogging along Fleet Street in this condition\r\nof mind, when he became aware that he was closely tracked and observed\r\nby a man of genteel appearance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now then?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, stopping short, with his meditations brought\r\nto an abrupt check, \xe2\x80\x98what\xe2\x80\x99s the next article?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I beg your pardon, Mr Boffin.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My name too, eh? How did you come by it? I don\xe2\x80\x99t know you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, sir, you don\xe2\x80\x99t know me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Boffin looked full at the man, and the man looked full at him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, after a glance at the pavement, as if it were made\r\nof faces and he were trying to match the man\xe2\x80\x99s, \xe2\x80\x98I DON\xe2\x80\x99T know you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am nobody,\xe2\x80\x99 said the stranger, \xe2\x80\x98and not likely to be known; but Mr\r\nBoffin\xe2\x80\x99s wealth--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh! that\xe2\x80\x99s got about already, has it?\xe2\x80\x99 muttered Mr Boffin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98--And his romantic manner of acquiring it, make him conspicuous. You\r\nwere pointed out to me the other day.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98I should say I was a disappintment to you when\r\nI WAS pinted out, if your politeness would allow you to confess it, for\r\nI am well aware I am not much to look at. What might you want with me?\r\nNot in the law, are you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No information to give, for a reward?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere may have been a momentary mantling in the face of the man as he\r\nmade the last answer, but it passed directly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If I don\xe2\x80\x99t mistake, you have followed me from my lawyer\xe2\x80\x99s and tried\r\nto fix my attention. Say out! Have you? Or haven\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x99 demanded Mr\r\nBoffin, rather angry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why have you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If you will allow me to walk beside you, Mr Boffin, I will tell you.\r\nWould you object to turn aside into this place--I think it is called\r\nClifford\xe2\x80\x99s Inn--where we can hear one another better than in the roaring\r\nstreet?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n[\xe2\x80\x98Now,\xe2\x80\x99 thought Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98if he proposes a game at skittles, or meets\r\na country gentleman just come into property, or produces any article\r\nof jewellery he has found, I\xe2\x80\x99ll knock him down!\xe2\x80\x99 With this discreet\r\nreflection, and carrying his stick in his arms much as Punch carries\r\nhis, Mr Boffin turned into Clifford\xe2\x80\x99s Inn aforesaid.)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Boffin, I happened to be in Chancery Lane this morning, when I saw\r\nyou going along before me. I took the liberty of following you, trying\r\nto make up my mind to speak to you, till you went into your lawyer\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\nThen I waited outside till you came out.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n[\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t quite sound like skittles, nor yet country gentleman, nor yet\r\njewellery,\xe2\x80\x99 thought Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98but there\xe2\x80\x99s no knowing.\xe2\x80\x99)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am afraid my object is a bold one, I am afraid it has little of the\r\nusual practical world about it, but I venture it. If you ask me, or if\r\nyou ask yourself--which is more likely--what emboldens me, I answer, I\r\nhave been strongly assured, that you are a man of rectitude and plain\r\ndealing, with the soundest of sound hearts, and that you are blessed in\r\na wife distinguished by the same qualities.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your information is true of Mrs Boffin, anyhow,\xe2\x80\x99 was Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nanswer, as he surveyed his new friend again. There was something\r\nrepressed in the strange man\xe2\x80\x99s manner, and he walked with his eyes\r\non the ground--though conscious, for all that, of Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nobservation--and he spoke in a subdued voice. But his words came easily,\r\nand his voice was agreeable in tone, albeit constrained.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When I add, I can discern for myself what the general tongue says of\r\nyou--that you are quite unspoiled by Fortune, and not uplifted--I trust\r\nyou will not, as a man of an open nature, suspect that I mean to flatter\r\nyou, but will believe that all I mean is to excuse myself, these being\r\nmy only excuses for my present intrusion.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n[\xe2\x80\x98How much?\xe2\x80\x99 thought Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98It must be coming to money. How much?\xe2\x80\x99)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You will probably change your manner of living, Mr Boffin, in your\r\nchanged circumstances. You will probably keep a larger house, have many\r\nmatters to arrange, and be beset by numbers of correspondents. If you\r\nwould try me as your Secretary--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As WHAT?\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mr Boffin, with his eyes wide open.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your Secretary.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, under his breath, \xe2\x80\x98that\xe2\x80\x99s a queer thing!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Or,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued the stranger, wondering at Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s wonder, \xe2\x80\x98if you\r\nwould try me as your man of business under any name, I know you would\r\nfind me faithful and grateful, and I hope you would find me useful. You\r\nmay naturally think that my immediate object is money. Not so, for\r\nI would willingly serve you a year--two years--any term you might\r\nappoint--before that should begin to be a consideration between us.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where do you come from?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mr Boffin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I come,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the other, meeting his eye, \xe2\x80\x98from many countries.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBoffin\xe2\x80\x99s acquaintances with the names and situations of foreign lands\r\nbeing limited in extent and somewhat confused in quality, he shaped his\r\nnext question on an elastic model.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98From--any particular place?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have been in many places.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What have you been?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mr Boffin.\r\n\r\nHere again he made no great advance, for the reply was, \xe2\x80\x98I have been a\r\nstudent and a traveller.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But if it ain\xe2\x80\x99t a liberty to plump it out,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98what do\r\nyou do for your living?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have mentioned,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the other, with another look at him, and\r\na smile, \xe2\x80\x98what I aspire to do. I have been superseded as to some slight\r\nintentions I had, and I may say that I have now to begin life.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nNot very well knowing how to get rid of this applicant, and feeling the\r\nmore embarrassed because his manner and appearance claimed a delicacy\r\nin which the worthy Mr Boffin feared he himself might be deficient, that\r\ngentleman glanced into the mouldy little plantation or cat-preserve, of\r\nClifford\xe2\x80\x99s Inn, as it was that day, in search of a suggestion. Sparrows\r\nwere there, cats were there, dry-rot and wet-rot were there, but it was\r\nnot otherwise a suggestive spot.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98All this time,\xe2\x80\x99 said the stranger, producing a little pocket-book and\r\ntaking out a card, \xe2\x80\x98I have not mentioned my name. My name is Rokesmith.\r\nI lodge at one Mr Wilfer\xe2\x80\x99s, at Holloway.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Boffin stared again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Father of Miss Bella Wilfer?\xe2\x80\x99 said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My landlord has a daughter named Bella. Yes; no doubt.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nNow, this name had been more or less in Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts all the\r\nmorning, and for days before; therefore he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s singular, too!\xe2\x80\x99 unconsciously staring again, past all bounds of\r\ngood manners, with the card in his hand. \xe2\x80\x98Though, by-the-bye, I suppose\r\nit was one of that family that pinted me out?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No. I have never been in the streets with one of them.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Heard me talked of among \xe2\x80\x98em, though?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No. I occupy my own rooms, and have held scarcely any communication\r\nwith them.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Odder and odder!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98Well, sir, to tell you the truth, I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t know what to say to you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Say nothing,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mr Rokesmith; \xe2\x80\x98allow me to call on you in a few\r\ndays. I am not so unconscionable as to think it likely that you would\r\naccept me on trust at first sight, and take me out of the very street.\r\nLet me come to you for your further opinion, at your leisure.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s fair, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t object,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin; \xe2\x80\x98but it must be on\r\ncondition that it\xe2\x80\x99s fully understood that I no more know that I shall\r\never be in want of any gentleman as Secretary--it WAS Secretary you\r\nsaid; wasn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAgain Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s eyes opened wide, and he stared at the applicant from\r\nhead to foot, repeating \xe2\x80\x98Queer!--You\xe2\x80\x99re sure it was Secretary? Are you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am sure I said so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n--\xe2\x80\x98As Secretary,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Mr Boffin, meditating upon the word; \xe2\x80\x98I no\r\nmore know that I may ever want a Secretary, or what not, than I do that\r\nI shall ever be in want of the man in the moon. Me and Mrs Boffin have\r\nnot even settled that we shall make any change in our way of life. Mrs\r\nBoffin\xe2\x80\x99s inclinations certainly do tend towards Fashion; but, being\r\nalready set up in a fashionable way at the Bower, she may not make\r\nfurther alterations. However, sir, as you don\xe2\x80\x99t press yourself, I wish\r\nto meet you so far as saying, by all means call at the Bower if you\r\nlike. Call in the course of a week or two. At the same time, I consider\r\nthat I ought to name, in addition to what I have already named, that I\r\nhave in my employment a literary man--WITH a wooden leg--as I have no\r\nthoughts of parting from.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I regret to hear I am in some sort anticipated,\xe2\x80\x99 Mr Rokesmith answered,\r\nevidently having heard it with surprise; \xe2\x80\x98but perhaps other duties might\r\narise?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You see,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mr Boffin, with a confidential sense of dignity, \xe2\x80\x98as\r\nto my literary man\xe2\x80\x99s duties, they\xe2\x80\x99re clear. Professionally he declines\r\nand he falls, and as a friend he drops into poetry.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWithout observing that these duties seemed by no means clear to Mr\r\nRokesmith\xe2\x80\x99s astonished comprehension, Mr Boffin went on:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And now, sir, I\xe2\x80\x99ll wish you good-day. You can call at the Bower any\r\ntime in a week or two. It\xe2\x80\x99s not above a mile or so from you, and your\r\nlandlord can direct you to it. But as he may not know it by its new\r\nname of Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s Bower, say, when you inquire of him, it\xe2\x80\x99s Harmon\xe2\x80\x99s;\r\nwill you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Harmoon\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Mr Rokesmith, seeming to have caught the sound\r\nimperfectly, \xe2\x80\x98Harmarn\xe2\x80\x99s. How do you spell it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, as to the spelling of it,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mr Boffin, with great presence\r\nof mind, \xe2\x80\x98that\xe2\x80\x99s YOUR look out. Harmon\xe2\x80\x99s is all you\xe2\x80\x99ve got to say to\r\nHIM. Morning, morning, morning!\xe2\x80\x99 And so departed, without looking back.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 9\r\n\r\nMR AND MRS BOFFIN IN CONSULTATION\r\n\r\n\r\nBetaking himself straight homeward, Mr Boffin, without further let or\r\nhindrance, arrived at the Bower, and gave Mrs Boffin (in a walking dress\r\nof black velvet and feathers, like a mourning coach-horse) an account of\r\nall he had said and done since breakfast.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This brings us round, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 he then pursued, \xe2\x80\x98to the question\r\nwe left unfinished: namely, whether there\xe2\x80\x99s to be any new go-in for\r\nFashion.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you what I want, Noddy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Boffin, smoothing her\r\ndress with an air of immense enjoyment, \xe2\x80\x98I want Society.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Fashionable Society, my dear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mrs Boffin, laughing with the glee of a child. \xe2\x80\x98Yes! It\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nno good my being kept here like Wax-Work; is it now?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98People have to pay to see Wax-Work, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 returned her husband,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98whereas (though you\xe2\x80\x99d be cheap at the same money) the neighbours is\r\nwelcome to see YOU for nothing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But it don\xe2\x80\x99t answer,\xe2\x80\x99 said the cheerful Mrs Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98When we worked\r\nlike the neighbours, we suited one another. Now we have left work off;\r\nwe have left off suiting one another.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What, do you think of beginning work again?\xe2\x80\x99 Mr Boffin hinted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Out of the question! We have come into a great fortune, and we must do\r\nwhat\xe2\x80\x99s right by our fortune; we must act up to it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Boffin, who had a deep respect for his wife\xe2\x80\x99s intuitive wisdom,\r\nreplied, though rather pensively: \xe2\x80\x98I suppose we must.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s never been acted up to yet, and, consequently, no good has come of\r\nit,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Boffin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98True, to the present time,\xe2\x80\x99 Mr Boffin assented, with his former\r\npensiveness, as he took his seat upon his settle. \xe2\x80\x98I hope good may be\r\ncoming of it in the future time. Towards which, what\xe2\x80\x99s your views, old\r\nlady?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs Boffin, a smiling creature, broad of figure and simple of nature,\r\nwith her hands folded in her lap, and with buxom creases in her throat,\r\nproceeded to expound her views.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I say, a good house in a good neighbourhood, good things about us,\r\ngood living, and good society. I say, live like our means, without\r\nextravagance, and be happy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. I say be happy, too,\xe2\x80\x99 assented the still pensive Mr Boffin.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lor-a-mussy!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mrs Boffin, laughing and clapping her hands,\r\nand gaily rocking herself to and fro, \xe2\x80\x98when I think of me in a light\r\nyellow chariot and pair, with silver boxes to the wheels--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh! you was thinking of that, was you, my dear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes!\xe2\x80\x99 cried the delighted creature. \xe2\x80\x98And with a footman up behind, with\r\na bar across, to keep his legs from being poled! And with a coachman\r\nup in front, sinking down into a seat big enough for three of him, all\r\ncovered with upholstery in green and white! And with two bay horses\r\ntossing their heads and stepping higher than they trot long-ways! And\r\nwith you and me leaning back inside, as grand as ninepence! Oh-h-h-h My!\r\nHa ha ha ha ha!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs Boffin clapped her hands again, rocked herself again, beat her feet\r\nupon the floor, and wiped the tears of laughter from her eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And what, my old lady,\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mr Boffin, when he also had\r\nsympathetically laughed: \xe2\x80\x98what\xe2\x80\x99s your views on the subject of the\r\nBower?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Shut it up. Don\xe2\x80\x99t part with it, but put somebody in it, to keep it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Any other views?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Noddy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Boffin, coming from her fashionable sofa to his side\r\non the plain settle, and hooking her comfortable arm through his,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Next I think--and I really have been thinking early and late--of the\r\ndisappointed girl; her that was so cruelly disappointed, you know, both\r\nof her husband and his riches. Don\xe2\x80\x99t you think we might do something for\r\nher? Have her to live with us? Or something of that sort?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ne-ver once thought of the way of doing it!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mr Boffin, smiting\r\nthe table in his admiration. \xe2\x80\x98What a thinking steam-ingein this old lady\r\nis. And she don\xe2\x80\x99t know how she does it. Neither does the ingein!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs Boffin pulled his nearest ear, in acknowledgment of this piece of\r\nphilosophy, and then said, gradually toning down to a motherly strain:\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Last, and not least, I have taken a fancy. You remember dear little\r\nJohn Harmon, before he went to school? Over yonder across the yard, at\r\nour fire? Now that he is past all benefit of the money, and it\xe2\x80\x99s come to\r\nus, I should like to find some orphan child, and take the boy and adopt\r\nhim and give him John\xe2\x80\x99s name, and provide for him. Somehow, it would\r\nmake me easier, I fancy. Say it\xe2\x80\x99s only a whim--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I don\xe2\x80\x99t say so,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed her husband.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, but deary, if you did--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should be a Beast if I did,\xe2\x80\x99 her husband interposed again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s as much as to say you agree? Good and kind of you, and like you,\r\ndeary! And don\xe2\x80\x99t you begin to find it pleasant now,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Boffin,\r\nonce more radiant in her comely way from head to foot, and once more\r\nsmoothing her dress with immense enjoyment, \xe2\x80\x98don\xe2\x80\x99t you begin to find\r\nit pleasant already, to think that a child will be made brighter, and\r\nbetter, and happier, because of that poor sad child that day? And isn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nit pleasant to know that the good will be done with the poor sad child\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nown money?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes; and it\xe2\x80\x99s pleasant to know that you are Mrs Boffin,\xe2\x80\x99 said her\r\nhusband, \xe2\x80\x98and it\xe2\x80\x99s been a pleasant thing to know this many and many a\r\nyear!\xe2\x80\x99 It was ruin to Mrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s aspirations, but, having so spoken,\r\nthey sat side by side, a hopelessly Unfashionable pair.\r\n\r\nThese two ignorant and unpolished people had guided themselves so far on\r\nin their journey of life, by a religious sense of duty and desire to do\r\nright. Ten thousand weaknesses and absurdities might have been detected\r\nin the breasts of both; ten thousand vanities additional, possibly, in\r\nthe breast of the woman. But the hard wrathful and sordid nature that\r\nhad wrung as much work out of them as could be got in their best days,\r\nfor as little money as could be paid to hurry on their worst, had never\r\nbeen so warped but that it knew their moral straightness and respected\r\nit. In its own despite, in a constant conflict with itself and them, it\r\nhad done so. And this is the eternal law. For, Evil often stops short at\r\nitself and dies with the doer of it; but Good, never.\r\n\r\nThrough his most inveterate purposes, the dead Jailer of Harmony Jail\r\nhad known these two faithful servants to be honest and true. While he\r\nraged at them and reviled them for opposing him with the speech of the\r\nhonest and true, it had scratched his stony heart, and he had perceived\r\nthe powerlessness of all his wealth to buy them if he had addressed\r\nhimself to the attempt. So, even while he was their griping taskmaster\r\nand never gave them a good word, he had written their names down in his\r\nwill. So, even while it was his daily declaration that he mistrusted all\r\nmankind--and sorely indeed he did mistrust all who bore any resemblance\r\nto himself--he was as certain that these two people, surviving him,\r\nwould be trustworthy in all things from the greatest to the least, as he\r\nwas that he must surely die.\r\n\r\nMr and Mrs Boffin, sitting side by side, with Fashion withdrawn to an\r\nimmeasurable distance, fell to discussing how they could best find their\r\norphan. Mrs Boffin suggested advertisement in the newspapers, requesting\r\norphans answering annexed description to apply at the Bower on a certain\r\nday; but Mr Boffin wisely apprehending obstruction of the neighbouring\r\nthoroughfares by orphan swarms, this course was negatived. Mrs Boffin\r\nnext suggested application to their clergyman for a likely orphan. Mr\r\nBoffin thinking better of this scheme, they resolved to call upon the\r\nreverend gentleman at once, and to take the same opportunity of making\r\nacquaintance with Miss Bella Wilfer. In order that these visits might be\r\nvisits of state, Mrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s equipage was ordered out.\r\n\r\nThis consisted of a long hammer-headed old horse, formerly used in the\r\nbusiness, attached to a four-wheeled chaise of the same period, which\r\nhad long been exclusively used by the Harmony Jail poultry as the\r\nfavourite laying-place of several discreet hens. An unwonted application\r\nof corn to the horse, and of paint and varnish to the carriage, when\r\nboth fell in as a part of the Boffin legacy, had made what Mr Boffin\r\nconsidered a neat turn-out of the whole; and a driver being added, in\r\nthe person of a long hammer-headed young man who was a very good match\r\nfor the horse, left nothing to be desired. He, too, had been formerly\r\nused in the business, but was now entombed by an honest jobbing tailor\r\nof the district in a perfect Sepulchre of coat and gaiters, sealed with\r\nponderous buttons.\r\n\r\nBehind this domestic, Mr and Mrs Boffin took their seats in the back\r\ncompartment of the vehicle: which was sufficiently commodious, but had\r\nan undignified and alarming tendency, in getting over a rough crossing,\r\nto hiccup itself away from the front compartment. On their being\r\ndescried emerging from the gates of the Bower, the neighbourhood turned\r\nout at door and window to salute the Boffins. Among those who were ever\r\nand again left behind, staring after the equipage, were many youthful\r\nspirits, who hailed it in stentorian tones with such congratulations as\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nod-dy Bof-fin!\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Bof-fin\xe2\x80\x99s mon-ey!\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Down with the dust, Bof-fin!\xe2\x80\x99 and\r\nother similar compliments. These, the hammer-headed young man took in\r\nsuch ill part that he often impaired the majesty of the progress by\r\npulling up short, and making as though he would alight to exterminate\r\nthe offenders; a purpose from which he only allowed himself to be\r\ndissuaded after long and lively arguments with his employers.\r\n\r\nAt length the Bower district was left behind, and the peaceful dwelling\r\nof the Reverend Frank Milvey was gained. The Reverend Frank Milvey\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nabode was a very modest abode, because his income was a very modest\r\nincome. He was officially accessible to every blundering old woman who\r\nhad incoherence to bestow upon him, and readily received the Boffins.\r\nHe was quite a young man, expensively educated and wretchedly paid, with\r\nquite a young wife and half a dozen quite young children. He was under\r\nthe necessity of teaching and translating from the classics, to eke out\r\nhis scanty means, yet was generally expected to have more time to spare\r\nthan the idlest person in the parish, and more money than the richest.\r\nHe accepted the needless inequalities and inconsistencies of his life,\r\nwith a kind of conventional submission that was almost slavish; and any\r\ndaring layman who would have adjusted such burdens as his, more decently\r\nand graciously, would have had small help from him.\r\n\r\nWith a ready patient face and manner, and yet with a latent smile that\r\nshowed a quick enough observation of Mrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s dress, Mr Milvey, in\r\nhis little book-room--charged with sounds and cries as though the six\r\nchildren above were coming down through the ceiling, and the roasting\r\nleg of mutton below were coming up through the floor--listened to Mrs\r\nBoffin\xe2\x80\x99s statement of her want of an orphan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Milvey, \xe2\x80\x98that you have never had a child of your own,\r\nMr and Mrs Boffin?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nNever.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But, like the Kings and Queens in the Fairy Tales, I suppose you have\r\nwished for one?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIn a general way, yes.\r\n\r\nMr Milvey smiled again, as he remarked to himself \xe2\x80\x98Those kings and\r\nqueens were always wishing for children.\xe2\x80\x99 It occurring to him, perhaps,\r\nthat if they had been Curates, their wishes might have tended in the\r\nopposite direction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think,\xe2\x80\x99 he pursued, \xe2\x80\x98we had better take Mrs Milvey into our Council.\r\nShe is indispensable to me. If you please, I\xe2\x80\x99ll call her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSo, Mr Milvey called, \xe2\x80\x98Margaretta, my dear!\xe2\x80\x99 and Mrs Milvey came down.\r\nA pretty, bright little woman, something worn by anxiety, who had\r\nrepressed many pretty tastes and bright fancies, and substituted in\r\ntheir stead, schools, soup, flannel, coals, and all the week-day cares\r\nand Sunday coughs of a large population, young and old. As gallantly had\r\nMr Milvey repressed much in himself that naturally belonged to his old\r\nstudies and old fellow-students, and taken up among the poor and their\r\nchildren with the hard crumbs of life.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr and Mrs Boffin, my dear, whose good fortune you have heard of.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs Milvey, with the most unaffected grace in the world, congratulated\r\nthem, and was glad to see them. Yet her engaging face, being an open as\r\nwell as a perceptive one, was not without her husband\xe2\x80\x99s latent smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mrs Boffin wishes to adopt a little boy, my dear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs Milvey, looking rather alarmed, her husband added:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98An orphan, my dear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Milvey, reassured for her own little boys.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And I was thinking, Margaretta, that perhaps old Mrs Goody\xe2\x80\x99s grandchild\r\nmight answer the purpose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh my DEAR Frank! I DON\xe2\x80\x99T think that would do!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh NO!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe smiling Mrs Boffin, feeling it incumbent on her to take part in the\r\nconversation, and being charmed with the emphatic little wife and her\r\nready interest, here offered her acknowledgments and inquired what there\r\nwas against him?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I DON\xe2\x80\x99T think,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Milvey, glancing at the Reverend Frank, \xe2\x80\x98--and\r\nI believe my husband will agree with me when he considers it again--that\r\nyou could possibly keep that orphan clean from snuff. Because his\r\ngrandmother takes so MANY ounces, and drops it over him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But he would not be living with his grandmother then, Margaretta,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nMr Milvey.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, Frank, but it would be impossible to keep her from Mrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhouse; and the MORE there was to eat and drink there, the oftener she\r\nwould go. And she IS an inconvenient woman. I HOPE it\xe2\x80\x99s not uncharitable\r\nto remember that last Christmas Eve she drank eleven cups of tea, and\r\ngrumbled all the time. And she is NOT a grateful woman, Frank. You\r\nrecollect her addressing a crowd outside this house, about her wrongs,\r\nwhen, one night after we had gone to bed, she brought back the petticoat\r\nof new flannel that had been given her, because it was too short.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s true,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Milvey. \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t think that would do. Would\r\nlittle Harrison--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, FRANK!\xe2\x80\x99 remonstrated his emphatic wife.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He has no grandmother, my dear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, but I DON\xe2\x80\x99T think Mrs Boffin would like an orphan who squints so\r\nMUCH.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s true again,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Milvey, becoming haggard with perplexity.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If a little girl would do--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But, my DEAR Frank, Mrs Boffin wants a boy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s true again,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Milvey. \xe2\x80\x98Tom Bocker is a nice boy\xe2\x80\x99\r\n(thoughtfully).\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I DOUBT, Frank,\xe2\x80\x99 Mrs Milvey hinted, after a little hesitation, \xe2\x80\x98if\r\nMrs Boffin wants an orphan QUITE nineteen, who drives a cart and waters\r\nthe roads.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Milvey referred the point to Mrs Boffin in a look; on that smiling\r\nlady\xe2\x80\x99s shaking her black velvet bonnet and bows, he remarked, in lower\r\nspirits, \xe2\x80\x98that\xe2\x80\x99s true again.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am sure,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Boffin, concerned at giving so much trouble, \xe2\x80\x98that\r\nif I had known you would have taken so much pains, sir--and you too, ma\xe2\x80\x99\r\nam--I don\xe2\x80\x99t think I would have come.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98PRAY don\xe2\x80\x99t say that!\xe2\x80\x99 urged Mrs Milvey.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, don\xe2\x80\x99t say that,\xe2\x80\x99 assented Mr Milvey, \xe2\x80\x98because we are so much\r\nobliged to you for giving us the preference.\xe2\x80\x99 Which Mrs Milvey\r\nconfirmed; and really the kind, conscientious couple spoke, as if they\r\nkept some profitable orphan warehouse and were personally patronized.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But it is a responsible trust,\xe2\x80\x99 added Mr Milvey, \xe2\x80\x98and difficult to\r\ndischarge. At the same time, we are naturally very unwilling to lose the\r\nchance you so kindly give us, and if you could afford us a day or two\r\nto look about us,--you know, Margaretta, we might carefully examine the\r\nworkhouse, and the Infant School, and your District.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To be SURE!\xe2\x80\x99 said the emphatic little wife.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We have orphans, I know,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued Mr Milvey, quite with the air as if\r\nhe might have added, \xe2\x80\x98in stock,\xe2\x80\x99 and quite as anxiously as if there were\r\ngreat competition in the business and he were afraid of losing an order,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98over at the clay-pits; but they are employed by relations or friends,\r\nand I am afraid it would come at last to a transaction in the way of\r\nbarter. And even if you exchanged blankets for the child--or books\r\nand firing--it would be impossible to prevent their being turned into\r\nliquor.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAccordingly, it was resolved that Mr and Mrs Milvey should search for\r\nan orphan likely to suit, and as free as possible from the foregoing\r\nobjections, and should communicate again with Mrs Boffin. Then, Mr\r\nBoffin took the liberty of mentioning to Mr Milvey that if Mr Milvey\r\nwould do him the kindness to be perpetually his banker to the extent\r\nof \xe2\x80\x98a twenty-pound note or so,\xe2\x80\x99 to be expended without any reference\r\nto him, he would be heartily obliged. At this, both Mr Milvey and Mrs\r\nMilvey were quite as much pleased as if they had no wants of their own,\r\nbut only knew what poverty was, in the persons of other people; and\r\nso the interview terminated with satisfaction and good opinion on all\r\nsides.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, old lady,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, as they resumed their seats behind the\r\nhammer-headed horse and man: \xe2\x80\x98having made a very agreeable visit there,\r\nwe\xe2\x80\x99ll try Wilfer\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt appeared, on their drawing up at the family gate, that to try\r\nWilfer\xe2\x80\x99s was a thing more easily projected than done, on account of the\r\nextreme difficulty of getting into that establishment; three pulls\r\nat the bell producing no external result; though each was attended\r\nby audible sounds of scampering and rushing within. At the fourth\r\ntug--vindictively administered by the hammer-headed young man--Miss\r\nLavinia appeared, emerging from the house in an accidental manner, with\r\na bonnet and parasol, as designing to take a contemplative walk. The\r\nyoung lady was astonished to find visitors at the gate, and expressed\r\nher feelings in appropriate action.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here\xe2\x80\x99s Mr and Mrs Boffin!\xe2\x80\x99 growled the hammer-headed young man through\r\nthe bars of the gate, and at the same time shaking it, as if he were on\r\nview in a Menagerie; \xe2\x80\x98they\xe2\x80\x99ve been here half an hour.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who did you say?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Miss Lavinia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr and Mrs BOFFIN\xe2\x80\x99 returned the young man, rising into a roar.\r\n\r\nMiss Lavinia tripped up the steps to the house-door, tripped down the\r\nsteps with the key, tripped across the little garden, and opened the\r\ngate. \xe2\x80\x98Please to walk in,\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Lavinia, haughtily. \xe2\x80\x98Our servant is\r\nout.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr and Mrs Boffin complying, and pausing in the little hall until Miss\r\nLavinia came up to show them where to go next, perceived three pairs of\r\nlistening legs upon the stairs above. Mrs Wilfer\xe2\x80\x99s legs, Miss Bella\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlegs, Mr George Sampson\xe2\x80\x99s legs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr and Mrs Boffin, I think?\xe2\x80\x99 said Lavinia, in a warning voice. Strained\r\nattention on the part of Mrs Wilfer\xe2\x80\x99s legs, of Miss Bella\xe2\x80\x99s legs, of Mr\r\nGeorge Sampson\xe2\x80\x99s legs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, Miss.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If you\xe2\x80\x99ll step this way--down these stairs--I\xe2\x80\x99ll let Ma know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\nExcited flight of Mrs Wilfer\xe2\x80\x99s legs, of Miss Bella\xe2\x80\x99s legs, of Mr George\r\nSampson\xe2\x80\x99s legs.\r\n\r\nAfter waiting some quarter of an hour alone in the family sitting-room,\r\nwhich presented traces of having been so hastily arranged after a meal,\r\nthat one might have doubted whether it was made tidy for visitors,\r\nor cleared for blindman\xe2\x80\x99s buff, Mr and Mrs Boffin became aware of the\r\nentrance of Mrs Wilfer, majestically faint, and with a condescending\r\nstitch in her side: which was her company manner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pardon me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Wilfer, after the first salutations, and as soon\r\nas she had adjusted the handkerchief under her chin, and waved her\r\ngloved hands, \xe2\x80\x98to what am I indebted for this honour?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To make short of it, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98perhaps you may be\r\nacquainted with the names of me and Mrs Boffin, as having come into a\r\ncertain property.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have heard, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mrs Wilfer, with a dignified bend of her\r\nhead, \xe2\x80\x98of such being the case.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And I dare say, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued Mr Boffin, while Mrs Boffin added\r\nconfirmatory nods and smiles, \xe2\x80\x98you are not very much inclined to take\r\nkindly to us?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pardon me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Wilfer. \xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x99Twere unjust to visit upon Mr and Mrs\r\nBoffin, a calamity which was doubtless a dispensation.\xe2\x80\x99 These words\r\nwere rendered the more effective by a serenely heroic expression of\r\nsuffering.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s fairly meant, I am sure,\xe2\x80\x99 because there\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nalways a straight way to everything. Consequently, we make this call\r\nto say, that we shall be glad to have the honour and pleasure of your\r\ndaughter\xe2\x80\x99s acquaintance, and that we shall be rejoiced if your daughter\r\nwill come to consider our house in the light of her home equally with\r\nthis. In short, we want to cheer your daughter, and to give her\r\nthe opportunity of sharing such pleasures as we are a going to take\r\nourselves. We want to brisk her up, and brisk her about, and give her a\r\nchange.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s it!\xe2\x80\x99 said the open-hearted Mrs Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98Lor! Let\xe2\x80\x99s be\r\ncomfortable.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs Wilfer bent her head in a distant manner to her lady visitor, and\r\nwith majestic monotony replied to the gentleman:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pardon me. I have several daughters. Which of my daughters am I to\r\nunderstand is thus favoured by the kind intentions of Mr Boffin and his\r\nlady?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you see?\xe2\x80\x99 the ever-smiling Mrs Boffin put in. \xe2\x80\x98Naturally, Miss\r\nBella, you know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh-h!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Wilfer, with a severely unconvinced look. \xe2\x80\x98My daughter\r\nBella is accessible and shall speak for herself.\xe2\x80\x99 Then opening the door\r\na little way, simultaneously with a sound of scuttling outside it,\r\nthe good lady made the proclamation, \xe2\x80\x98Send Miss Bella to me!\xe2\x80\x99 which\r\nproclamation, though grandly formal, and one might almost say heraldic,\r\nto hear, was in fact enunciated with her maternal eyes reproachfully\r\nglaring on that young lady in the flesh--and in so much of it that she\r\nwas retiring with difficulty into the small closet under the stairs,\r\napprehensive of the emergence of Mr and Mrs Boffin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The avocations of R.
