And come again soon. Good\r\nnight!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nCharming to see Mr and Mrs Lammle taking leave so gracefully, and going\r\ndown the stairs so lovingly and sweetly. Not quite so charming to see\r\ntheir smiling faces fall and brood as they dropped moodily into separate\r\ncorners of their little carriage. But to be sure that was a sight behind\r\nthe scenes, which nobody saw, and which nobody was meant to see.\r\n\r\nCertain big, heavy vehicles, built on the model of the Podsnap plate,\r\ntook away the heavy articles of guests weighing ever so much; and the\r\nless valuable articles got away after their various manners; and the\r\nPodsnap plate was put to bed. As Mr Podsnap stood with his back to the\r\ndrawing-room fire, pulling up his shirtcollar, like a veritable cock\r\nof the walk literally pluming himself in the midst of his possessions,\r\nnothing would have astonished him more than an intimation that Miss\r\nPodsnap, or any other young person properly born and bred, could not be\r\nexactly put away like the plate, brought out like the plate, polished\r\nlike the plate, counted, weighed, and valued like the plate. That such\r\na young person could possibly have a morbid vacancy in the heart for\r\nanything younger than the plate, or less monotonous than the plate;\r\nor that such a young person\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts could try to scale the region\r\nbounded on the north, south, east, and west, by the plate; was a\r\nmonstrous imagination which he would on the spot have flourished into\r\nspace. This perhaps in some sort arose from Mr Podsnap\xe2\x80\x99s blushing young\r\nperson being, so to speak, all cheek; whereas there is a possibility\r\nthat there may be young persons of a rather more complex organization.\r\n\r\nIf Mr Podsnap, pulling up his shirt-collar, could only have heard\r\nhimself called \xe2\x80\x98that fellow\xe2\x80\x99 in a certain short dialogue, which passed\r\nbetween Mr and Mrs Lammle in their opposite corners of their little\r\ncarriage, rolling home!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sophronia, are you awake?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Am I likely to be asleep, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very likely, I should think, after that fellow\xe2\x80\x99s company. Attend to\r\nwhat I am going to say.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have attended to what you have already said, have I not? What else\r\nhave I been doing all to-night.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Attend, I tell you,\xe2\x80\x99 (in a raised voice) \xe2\x80\x98to what I am going to say.\r\nKeep close to that idiot girl. Keep her under your thumb. You have her\r\nfast, and you are not to let her go. Do you hear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hear you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I foresee there is money to be made out of this, besides taking that\r\nfellow down a peg. We owe each other money, you know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs Lammle winced a little at the reminder, but only enough to shake her\r\nscents and essences anew into the atmosphere of the little carriage, as\r\nshe settled herself afresh in her own dark corner.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 12\r\n\r\nTHE SWEAT OF AN HONEST MAN\xe2\x80\x99S BROW\r\n\r\n\r\nMr Mortimer Lightwood and Mr Eugene Wrayburn took a coffee-house dinner\r\ntogether in Mr Lightwood\xe2\x80\x99s office. They had newly agreed to set up a\r\njoint establishment together. They had taken a bachelor cottage near\r\nHampton, on the brink of the Thames, with a lawn, and a boat-house; and\r\nall things fitting, and were to float with the stream through the summer\r\nand the Long Vacation.\r\n\r\nIt was not summer yet, but spring; and it was not gentle spring\r\nethereally mild, as in Thomson\xe2\x80\x99s Seasons, but nipping spring with an\r\neasterly wind, as in Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s, Jackson\xe2\x80\x99s, Dickson\xe2\x80\x99s, Smith\xe2\x80\x99s, and\r\nJones\xe2\x80\x99s Seasons. The grating wind sawed rather than blew; and as it\r\nsawed, the sawdust whirled about the sawpit. Every street was a sawpit,\r\nand there were no top-sawyers; every passenger was an under-sawyer, with\r\nthe sawdust blinding him and choking him.\r\n\r\nThat mysterious paper currency which circulates in London when the\r\nwind blows, gyrated here and there and everywhere. Whence can it come,\r\nwhither can it go? It hangs on every bush, flutters in every tree, is\r\ncaught flying by the electric wires, haunts every enclosure, drinks at\r\nevery pump, cowers at every grating, shudders upon every plot of grass,\r\nseeks rest in vain behind the legions of iron rails. In Paris, where\r\nnothing is wasted, costly and luxurious city though it be, but where\r\nwonderful human ants creep out of holes and pick up every scrap, there\r\nis no such thing. There, it blows nothing but dust. There, sharp eyes\r\nand sharp stomachs reap even the east wind, and get something out of it.\r\n\r\nThe wind sawed, and the sawdust whirled. The shrubs wrung their many\r\nhands, bemoaning that they had been over-persuaded by the sun to bud;\r\nthe young leaves pined; the sparrows repented of their early marriages,\r\nlike men and women; the colours of the rainbow were discernible, not\r\nin floral spring, but in the faces of the people whom it nibbled and\r\npinched. And ever the wind sawed, and the sawdust whirled.\r\n\r\nWhen the spring evenings are too long and light to shut out, and such\r\nweather is rife, the city which Mr Podsnap so explanatorily called\r\nLondon, Londres, London, is at its worst. Such a black shrill city,\r\ncombining the qualities of a smoky house and a scolding wife; such a\r\ngritty city; such a hopeless city, with no rent in the leaden canopy of\r\nits sky; such a beleaguered city, invested by the great Marsh Forces of\r\nEssex and Kent. So the two old schoolfellows felt it to be, as, their\r\ndinner done, they turned towards the fire to smoke. Young Blight was\r\ngone, the coffee-house waiter was gone, the plates and dishes were gone,\r\nthe wine was going--but not in the same direction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The wind sounds up here,\xe2\x80\x99 quoth Eugene, stirring the fire, \xe2\x80\x98as if we\r\nwere keeping a lighthouse. I wish we were.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you think it would bore us?\xe2\x80\x99 Lightwood asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not more than any other place. And there would be no Circuit to go. But\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s a selfish consideration, personal to me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And no clients to come,\xe2\x80\x99 added Lightwood. \xe2\x80\x98Not that that\xe2\x80\x99s a selfish\r\nconsideration at all personal to ME.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If we were on an isolated rock in a stormy sea,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, smoking\r\nwith his eyes on the fire, \xe2\x80\x98Lady Tippins couldn\xe2\x80\x99t put off to visit us,\r\nor, better still, might put off and get swamped. People couldn\xe2\x80\x99t ask one\r\nto wedding breakfasts. There would be no Precedents to hammer at,\r\nexcept the plain-sailing Precedent of keeping the light up. It would be\r\nexciting to look out for wrecks.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But otherwise,\xe2\x80\x99 suggested Lightwood, \xe2\x80\x98there might be a degree of\r\nsameness in the life.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have thought of that also,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, as if he really had been\r\nconsidering the subject in its various bearings with an eye to the\r\nbusiness; \xe2\x80\x98but it would be a defined and limited monotony. It would\r\nnot extend beyond two people. Now, it\xe2\x80\x99s a question with me, Mortimer,\r\nwhether a monotony defined with that precision and limited to that\r\nextent, might not be more endurable than the unlimited monotony of one\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfellow-creatures.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs Lightwood laughed and passed the wine, he remarked, \xe2\x80\x98We shall have an\r\nopportunity, in our boating summer, of trying the question.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98An imperfect one,\xe2\x80\x99 Eugene acquiesced, with a sigh, \xe2\x80\x98but so we shall. I\r\nhope we may not prove too much for one another.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, regarding your respected father,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lightwood, bringing him\r\nto a subject they had expressly appointed to discuss: always the most\r\nslippery eel of eels of subjects to lay hold of.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, regarding my respected father,\xe2\x80\x99 assented Eugene, settling himself\r\nin his arm-chair. \xe2\x80\x98I would rather have approached my respected father by\r\ncandlelight, as a theme requiring a little artificial brilliancy; but we\r\nwill take him by twilight, enlivened with a glow of Wallsend.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe stirred the fire again as he spoke, and having made it blaze,\r\nresumed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My respected father has found, down in the parental neighbourhood, a\r\nwife for his not-generally-respected son.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98With some money, of course?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98With some money, of course, or he would not have found her. My\r\nrespected father--let me shorten the dutiful tautology by substituting\r\nin future M. R. F., which sounds military, and rather like the Duke of\r\nWellington.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What an absurd fellow you are, Eugene!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not at all, I assure you. M. R. F. having always in the clearest manner\r\nprovided (as he calls it) for his children by pre-arranging from the\r\nhour of the birth of each, and sometimes from an earlier period, what\r\nthe devoted little victim\xe2\x80\x99s calling and course in life should be, M. R.\r\nF. pre-arranged for myself that I was to be the barrister I am (with\r\nthe slight addition of an enormous practice, which has not accrued), and\r\nalso the married man I am not.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The first you have often told me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The first I have often told you. Considering myself sufficiently\r\nincongruous on my legal eminence, I have until now suppressed my\r\ndomestic destiny. You know M. R. F., but not as well as I do. If you\r\nknew him as well as I do, he would amuse you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Filially spoken, Eugene!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Perfectly so, believe me; and with every sentiment of affectionate\r\ndeference towards M. R. F. But if he amuses me, I can\xe2\x80\x99t help it. When my\r\neldest brother was born, of course the rest of us knew (I mean the rest\r\nof us would have known, if we had been in existence) that he was heir\r\nto the Family Embarrassments--we call it before the company the Family\r\nEstate. But when my second brother was going to be born by-and-by,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthis,\xe2\x80\x9d says M. R. F., \xe2\x80\x9cis a little pillar of the church.\xe2\x80\x9d Was born,\r\nand became a pillar of the church; a very shaky one. My third brother\r\nappeared, considerably in advance of his engagement to my mother; but\r\nM. R. F., not at all put out by surprise, instantly declared him\r\na Circumnavigator. Was pitch-forked into the Navy, but has not\r\ncircumnavigated. I announced myself and was disposed of with the highly\r\nsatisfactory results embodied before you. When my younger brother was\r\nhalf an hour old, it was settled by M. R. F. that he should have a\r\nmechanical genius. And so on. Therefore I say that M. R. F. amuses me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Touching the lady, Eugene.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There M. R. F. ceases to be amusing, because my intentions are opposed\r\nto touching the lady.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you know her?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not in the least.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hadn\xe2\x80\x99t you better see her?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear Mortimer, you have studied my character. Could I possibly go\r\ndown there, labelled \xe2\x80\x9cELIGIBLE. ON VIEW,\xe2\x80\x9d and meet the lady, similarly\r\nlabelled? Anything to carry out M. R. F.\xe2\x80\x99s arrangements, I am sure, with\r\nthe greatest pleasure--except matrimony. Could I possibly support it? I,\r\nso soon bored, so constantly, so fatally?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But you are not a consistent fellow, Eugene.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In susceptibility to boredom,\xe2\x80\x99 returned that worthy, \xe2\x80\x98I assure you I am\r\nthe most consistent of mankind.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, it was but now that you were dwelling in the advantages of a\r\nmonotony of two.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In a lighthouse. Do me the justice to remember the condition. In a\r\nlighthouse.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMortimer laughed again, and Eugene, having laughed too for the first\r\ntime, as if he found himself on reflection rather entertaining, relapsed\r\ninto his usual gloom, and drowsily said, as he enjoyed his cigar, \xe2\x80\x98No,\r\nthere is no help for it; one of the prophetic deliveries of M. R. F.\r\nmust for ever remain unfulfilled. With every disposition to oblige him,\r\nhe must submit to a failure.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt had grown darker as they talked, and the wind was sawing and the\r\nsawdust was whirling outside paler windows. The underlying churchyard\r\nwas already settling into deep dim shade, and the shade was creeping up\r\nto the housetops among which they sat. \xe2\x80\x98As if,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, \xe2\x80\x98as if the\r\nchurchyard ghosts were rising.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe had walked to the window with his cigar in his mouth, to exalt its\r\nflavour by comparing the fireside with the outside, when he stopped\r\nmidway on his return to his arm-chair, and said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Apparently one of the ghosts has lost its way, and dropped in to be\r\ndirected. Look at this phantom!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLightwood, whose back was towards the door, turned his head, and there,\r\nin the darkness of the entry, stood a something in the likeness of a\r\nman: to whom he addressed the not irrelevant inquiry, \xe2\x80\x98Who the devil are\r\nyou?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I ask your pardons, Governors,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the ghost, in a hoarse\r\ndouble-barrelled whisper, \xe2\x80\x98but might either on you be Lawyer Lightwood?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you mean by not knocking at the door?\xe2\x80\x99 demanded Mortimer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I ask your pardons, Governors,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the ghost, as before, \xe2\x80\x98but\r\nprobable you was not aware your door stood open.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you want?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHereunto the ghost again hoarsely replied, in its double-barrelled\r\nmanner, \xe2\x80\x98I ask your pardons, Governors, but might one on you be Lawyer\r\nLightwood?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98One of us is,\xe2\x80\x99 said the owner of that name.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98All right, Governors Both,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the ghost, carefully closing the\r\nroom door; \xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x99tickler business.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMortimer lighted the candles. They showed the visitor to be an\r\nill-looking visitor with a squinting leer, who, as he spoke, fumbled\r\nat an old sodden fur cap, formless and mangey, that looked like a furry\r\nanimal, dog or cat, puppy or kitten, drowned and decaying.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mortimer, \xe2\x80\x98what is it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Governors Both,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the man, in what he meant to be a wheedling\r\ntone, \xe2\x80\x98which on you might be Lawyer Lightwood?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lawyer Lightwood,\xe2\x80\x99 ducking at him with a servile air, \xe2\x80\x98I am a man as\r\ngets my living, and as seeks to get my living, by the sweat of my brow.\r\nNot to risk being done out of the sweat of my brow, by any chances, I\r\nshould wish afore going further to be swore in.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am not a swearer in of people, man.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe visitor, clearly anything but reliant on this assurance, doggedly\r\nmuttered \xe2\x80\x98Alfred David.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is that your name?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Lightwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My name?\xe2\x80\x99 returned the man. \xe2\x80\x98No; I want to take a Alfred David.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n(Which Eugene, smoking and contemplating him, interpreted as meaning\r\nAffidavit.)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I tell you, my good fellow,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lightwood, with his indolent laugh,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98that I have nothing to do with swearing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He can swear AT you,\xe2\x80\x99 Eugene explained; \xe2\x80\x98and so can I. But we can\xe2\x80\x99t do\r\nmore for you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMuch discomfited by this information, the visitor turned the drowned\r\ndog or cat, puppy or kitten, about and about, and looked from one of\r\nthe Governors Both to the other of the Governors Both, while he deeply\r\nconsidered within himself. At length he decided:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then I must be took down.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Lightwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man. \xe2\x80\x98In pen and ink.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98First, let us know what your business is about.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s about,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man, taking a step forward, dropping his hoarse\r\nvoice, and shading it with his hand, \xe2\x80\x98it\xe2\x80\x99s about from five to ten\r\nthousand pound reward. That\xe2\x80\x99s what it\xe2\x80\x99s about. It\xe2\x80\x99s about Murder. That\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwhat it\xe2\x80\x99s about.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come nearer the table. Sit down. Will you have a glass of wine?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, I will,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man; \xe2\x80\x98and I don\xe2\x80\x99t deceive you, Governors.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt was given him. Making a stiff arm to the elbow, he poured the wine\r\ninto his mouth, tilted it into his right cheek, as saying, \xe2\x80\x98What do you\r\nthink of it?\xe2\x80\x99 tilted it into his left cheek, as saying, \xe2\x80\x98What do YOU\r\nthink of it?\xe2\x80\x99 jerked it into his stomach, as saying, \xe2\x80\x98What do YOU think\r\nof it?\xe2\x80\x99 To conclude, smacked his lips, as if all three replied, \xe2\x80\x98We\r\nthink well of it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Will you have another?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, I will,\xe2\x80\x99 he repeated, \xe2\x80\x98and I don\xe2\x80\x99t deceive you, Governors.\xe2\x80\x99 And\r\nalso repeated the other proceedings.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now,\xe2\x80\x99 began Lightwood, \xe2\x80\x98what\xe2\x80\x99s your name?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, there you\xe2\x80\x99re rather fast, Lawyer Lightwood,\xe2\x80\x99 he replied, in a\r\nremonstrant manner. \xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you see, Lawyer Lightwood? There you\xe2\x80\x99re a\r\nlittle bit fast. I\xe2\x80\x99m going to earn from five to ten thousand pound by\r\nthe sweat of my brow; and as a poor man doing justice to the sweat of my\r\nbrow, is it likely I can afford to part with so much as my name without\r\nits being took down?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDeferring to the man\xe2\x80\x99s sense of the binding powers of pen and ink and\r\npaper, Lightwood nodded acceptance of Eugene\xe2\x80\x99s nodded proposal to take\r\nthose spells in hand. Eugene, bringing them to the table, sat down as\r\nclerk or notary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lightwood, \xe2\x80\x98what\xe2\x80\x99s your name?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBut further precaution was still due to the sweat of this honest\r\nfellow\xe2\x80\x99s brow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should wish, Lawyer Lightwood,\xe2\x80\x99 he stipulated, \xe2\x80\x98to have that T\xe2\x80\x99other\r\nGovernor as my witness that what I said I said. Consequent, will the\r\nT\xe2\x80\x99other Governor be so good as chuck me his name and where he lives?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nEugene, cigar in mouth and pen in hand, tossed him his card. After\r\nspelling it out slowly, the man made it into a little roll, and tied it\r\nup in an end of his neckerchief still more slowly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lightwood, for the third time, \xe2\x80\x98if you have quite completed\r\nyour various preparations, my friend, and have fully ascertained that\r\nyour spirits are cool and not in any way hurried, what\xe2\x80\x99s your name?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Roger Riderhood.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dwelling-place?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lime\xe2\x80\x99us Hole.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Calling or occupation?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nNot quite so glib with this answer as with the previous two, Mr\r\nRiderhood gave in the definition, \xe2\x80\x98Waterside character.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Anything against you?\xe2\x80\x99 Eugene quietly put in, as he wrote.\r\n\r\nRather baulked, Mr Riderhood evasively remarked, with an innocent air,\r\nthat he believed the T\xe2\x80\x99other Governor had asked him summa\xe2\x80\x99t.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ever in trouble?\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Once.\xe2\x80\x99 (Might happen to any man, Mr Riderhood added incidentally.)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98On suspicion of--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of seaman\xe2\x80\x99s pocket,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Riderhood. \xe2\x80\x98Whereby I was in reality the\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s best friend, and tried to take care of him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98With the sweat of your brow?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Eugene.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Till it poured down like rain,\xe2\x80\x99 said Roger Riderhood.\r\n\r\nEugene leaned back in his chair, and smoked with his eyes negligently\r\nturned on the informer, and his pen ready to reduce him to more writing.\r\nLightwood also smoked, with his eyes negligently turned on the informer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now let me be took down again,\xe2\x80\x99 said Riderhood, when he had turned the\r\ndrowned cap over and under, and had brushed it the wrong way (if it had\r\na right way) with his sleeve. \xe2\x80\x98I give information that the man that done\r\nthe Harmon Murder is Gaffer Hexam, the man that found the body. The hand\r\nof Jesse Hexam, commonly called Gaffer on the river and along shore, is\r\nthe hand that done that deed. His hand and no other.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe two friends glanced at one another with more serious faces than they\r\nhad shown yet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Tell us on what grounds you make this accusation,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mortimer\r\nLightwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98On the grounds,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Riderhood, wiping his face with his sleeve,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98that I was Gaffer\xe2\x80\x99s pardner, and suspected of him many a long day and\r\nmany a dark night. On the grounds that I knowed his ways. On the grounds\r\nthat I broke the pardnership because I see the danger; which I warn you\r\nhis daughter may tell you another story about that, for anythink I can\r\nsay, but you know what it\xe2\x80\x99ll be worth, for she\xe2\x80\x99d tell you lies, the\r\nworld round and the heavens broad, to save her father. I had once very nigh\r\ngot it off to Miss Abbey Potterson which keeps the Six Jolly\r\nFellowships--there is the \xe2\x80\x98ouse, it won\xe2\x80\x99t run away,--there lives the\r\nlady, she ain\xe2\x80\x99t likely to be struck dead afore you get there--ask\r\nher!--but I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t do it. Two-and-twenty last October. And then I put it to\r\nmyself, \xe2\x80\x9cRegarding the money. This night!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAfter another silence, broken only by the fall of the ashes in the\r\ngrate, which attracted the informer\xe2\x80\x99s attention as if it were the\r\nchinking of money, Mortimer Lightwood leaned over his friend, and said\r\nin a whisper:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose I must go with this fellow to our imperturbable friend at the\r\npolice-station.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, \xe2\x80\x98there is no help for it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you believe him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I believe him to be a thorough rascal. While extinguishing the candles,\r\nLightwood, quite as a matter of course took up the glass from which that\r\nhonest gentleman had drunk, and coolly tossed it under the grate, where\r\nit fell shivering into fragments.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, if you will take the lead,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lightwood, \xe2\x80\x98Mr Wrayburn and I\r\nwill follow. You know where to go, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose I do, Lawyer Lightwood.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Take the lead, then.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe waterside character pulled his drowned cap over his ears with both\r\nhands, and making himself more round-shouldered than nature had made\r\nhim, by the sullen and persistent slouch with which he went, went\r\ndown the stairs, round by the Temple Church, across the Temple into\r\nWhitefriars, and so on by the waterside streets.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Look at his hang-dog air,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lightwood, following.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It strikes me rather as a hang-MAN air,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Eugene. \xe2\x80\x98He has\r\nundeniable intentions that way.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey said little else as they followed. He went on before them as an\r\nugly Fate might have done, and they kept him in view, and would have\r\nbeen glad enough to lose sight of him. But on he went before them,\r\nalways at the same distance, and the same rate. Aslant against the hard\r\nimplacable weather and the rough wind, he was no more to be driven back\r\nthan hurried forward, but held on like an advancing Destiny. There came,\r\nwhen they were about midway on their journey, a heavy rush of hail,\r\nwhich in a few minutes pelted the streets clear, and whitened them. It\r\nmade no difference to him. A man\xe2\x80\x99s life being to be taken and the price\r\nof it got, the hailstones to arrest the purpose must lie larger and\r\ndeeper than those. He crashed through them, leaving marks in the\r\nfast-melting slush that were mere shapeless holes; one might have\r\nfancied, following, that the very fashion of humanity had departed from\r\nhis feet.\r\n\r\nThe blast went by, and the moon contended with the fast-flying clouds,\r\nand the wild disorder reigning up there made the pitiful little tumults\r\nin the streets of no account. It was not that the wind swept all\r\nthe brawlers into places of shelter, as it had swept the hail still\r\nlingering in heaps wherever there was refuge for it; but that it seemed\r\nas if the streets were absorbed by the sky, and the night were all in\r\nthe air.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If he has had time to think of it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, \xe2\x80\x98he has not had time to\r\nthink better of it--or differently of it, if that\xe2\x80\x99s better. There is no\r\nsign of drawing back in him; and as I recollect this place, we must be\r\nclose upon the corner where we alighted that night.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIn fact, a few abrupt turns brought them to the river side, where they\r\nhad slipped about among the stones, and where they now slipped more; the\r\nwind coming against them in slants and flaws, across the tide and the\r\nwindings of the river, in a furious way. With that habit of getting\r\nunder the lee of any shelter which waterside characters acquire, the\r\nwaterside character at present in question led the way to the leeside of\r\nthe Six Jolly Fellowship Porters before he spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Look round here, Lawyer Lightwood, at them red curtains. It\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nFellowships, the \xe2\x80\x98ouse as I told you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t run away. And has it run\r\naway?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nNot showing himself much impressed by this remarkable confirmation of\r\nthe informer\xe2\x80\x99s evidence, Lightwood inquired what other business they had\r\nthere?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wished you to see the Fellowships for yourself, Lawyer Lightwood,\r\nthat you might judge whether I\xe2\x80\x99m a liar; and now I\xe2\x80\x99ll see Gaffer\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwindow for myself, that we may know whether he\xe2\x80\x99s at home.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith that, he crept away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He\xe2\x80\x99ll come back, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x99 murmured Lightwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ay! and go through with it,\xe2\x80\x99 murmured Eugene.\r\n\r\nHe came back after a very short interval indeed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Gaffer\xe2\x80\x99s out, and his boat\xe2\x80\x99s out. His daughter\xe2\x80\x99s at home, sitting\r\na-looking at the fire. But there\xe2\x80\x99s some supper getting ready, so\r\nGaffer\xe2\x80\x99s expected. I can find what move he\xe2\x80\x99s upon, easy enough,\r\npresently.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThen he beckoned and led the way again, and they came to the\r\npolice-station, still as clean and cool and steady as before, saving\r\nthat the flame of its lamp--being but a lamp-flame, and only attached to\r\nthe Force as an outsider--flickered in the wind.\r\n\r\nAlso, within doors, Mr Inspector was at his studies as of yore.\r\nHe recognized the friends the instant they reappeared, but their\r\nreappearance had no effect on his composure. Not even the circumstance\r\nthat Riderhood was their conductor moved him, otherwise than that as he\r\ntook a dip of ink he seemed, by a settlement of his chin in his stock,\r\nto propound to that personage, without looking at him, the question,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What have YOU been up to, last?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMortimer Lightwood asked him, would he be so good as look at those\r\nnotes? Handing him Eugene\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\nHaving read the first few lines, Mr Inspector mounted to that (for him)\r\nextraordinary pitch of emotion that he said, \xe2\x80\x98Does either of you two\r\ngentlemen happen to have a pinch of snuff about him?\xe2\x80\x99 Finding that\r\nneither had, he did quite as well without it, and read on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have you heard these read?\xe2\x80\x99 he then demanded of the honest man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 said Riderhood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then you had better hear them.\xe2\x80\x99 And so read them aloud, in an official\r\nmanner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are these notes correct, now, as to the information you bring here and\r\nthe evidence you mean to give?\xe2\x80\x99 he asked, when he had finished reading.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They are. They are as correct,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mr Riderhood, \xe2\x80\x98as I am. I\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t say more than that for \xe2\x80\x98em.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll take this man myself, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector to Lightwood. Then\r\nto Riderhood, \xe2\x80\x98Is he at home? Where is he? What\xe2\x80\x99s he doing? You have\r\nmade it your business to know all about him, no doubt.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nRiderhood said what he did know, and promised to find out in a few\r\nminutes what he didn\xe2\x80\x99t know.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stop,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector; \xe2\x80\x98not till I tell you: We mustn\xe2\x80\x99t look like\r\nbusiness. Would you two gentlemen object to making a pretence of taking\r\na glass of something in my company at the Fellowships? Well-conducted\r\nhouse, and highly respectable landlady.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey replied that they would be happy to substitute a reality for the\r\npretence, which, in the main, appeared to be as one with Mr Inspector\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmeaning.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very good,\xe2\x80\x99 said he, taking his hat from its peg, and putting a pair of\r\nhandcuffs in his pocket as if they were his gloves. \xe2\x80\x98Reserve!\xe2\x80\x99 Reserve\r\nsaluted. \xe2\x80\x98You know where to find me?\xe2\x80\x99 Reserve again saluted. \xe2\x80\x98Riderhood,\r\nwhen you have found out concerning his coming home, come round to the\r\nwindow of Cosy, tap twice at it, and wait for me. Now, gentlemen.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs the three went out together, and Riderhood slouched off from under\r\nthe trembling lamp his separate way, Lightwood asked the officer what he\r\nthought of this?\r\n\r\nMr Inspector replied, with due generality and reticence, that it was\r\nalways more likely that a man had done a bad thing than that he hadn\xe2\x80\x99t.\r\nThat he himself had several times \xe2\x80\x98reckoned up\xe2\x80\x99 Gaffer, but had never\r\nbeen able to bring him to a satisfactory criminal total. That if this\r\nstory was true, it was only in part true. That the two men, very shy\r\ncharacters, would have been jointly and pretty equally \xe2\x80\x98in it;\xe2\x80\x99 but that\r\nthis man had \xe2\x80\x98spotted\xe2\x80\x99 the other, to save himself and get the money.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And I think,\xe2\x80\x99 added Mr Inspector, in conclusion, \xe2\x80\x98that if all goes\r\nwell with him, he\xe2\x80\x99s in a tolerable way of getting it. But as this is the\r\nFellowships, gentlemen, where the lights are, I recommend dropping\r\nthe subject. You can\xe2\x80\x99t do better than be interested in some lime works\r\nanywhere down about Northfleet, and doubtful whether some of your lime\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t get into bad company as it comes up in barges.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You hear Eugene?\xe2\x80\x99 said Lightwood, over his shoulder. \xe2\x80\x98You are deeply\r\ninterested in lime.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Without lime,\xe2\x80\x99 returned that unmoved barrister-at-law, \xe2\x80\x98my existence\r\nwould be unilluminated by a ray of hope.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 13\r\n\r\nTRACKING THE BIRD OF PREY\r\n\r\n\r\nThe two lime merchants, with their escort, entered the dominions of\r\nMiss Abbey Potterson, to whom their escort (presenting them and their\r\npretended business over the half-door of the bar, in a confidential\r\nway) preferred his figurative request that \xe2\x80\x98a mouthful of fire\xe2\x80\x99 might\r\nbe lighted in Cosy. Always well disposed to assist the constituted\r\nauthorities, Miss Abbey bade Bob Gliddery attend the gentlemen to\r\nthat retreat, and promptly enliven it with fire and gaslight. Of this\r\ncommission the bare-armed Bob, leading the way with a flaming wisp of\r\npaper, so speedily acquitted himself, that Cosy seemed to leap out of a\r\ndark sleep and embrace them warmly, the moment they passed the lintels\r\nof its hospitable door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They burn sherry very well here,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector, as a piece of\r\nlocal intelligence. \xe2\x80\x98Perhaps you gentlemen might like a bottle?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe answer being By all means, Bob Gliddery received his instructions\r\nfrom Mr Inspector, and departed in a becoming state of alacrity\r\nengendered by reverence for the majesty of the law.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s a certain fact,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector, \xe2\x80\x98that this man we have\r\nreceived our information from,\xe2\x80\x99 indicating Riderhood with his thumb over\r\nhis shoulder, \xe2\x80\x98has for some time past given the other man a bad name\r\narising out of your lime barges, and that the other man has been avoided\r\nin consequence. I don\xe2\x80\x99t say what it means or proves, but it\xe2\x80\x99s a certain\r\nfact. I had it first from one of the opposite sex of my acquaintance,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nvaguely indicating Miss Abbey with his thumb over his shoulder, \xe2\x80\x98down\r\naway at a distance, over yonder.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThen probably Mr Inspector was not quite unprepared for their visit that\r\nevening? Lightwood hinted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well you see,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector, \xe2\x80\x98it was a question of making a move.\r\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s of no use moving if you don\xe2\x80\x99t know what your move is. You had\r\nbetter by far keep still. In the matter of this lime, I certainly had\r\nan idea that it might lie betwixt the two men; I always had that idea.\r\nStill I was forced to wait for a start, and I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t so lucky as to get\r\na start. This man that we have received our information from, has got\r\na start, and if he don\xe2\x80\x99t meet with a check he may make the running and\r\ncome in first. There may turn out to be something considerable for him\r\nthat comes in second, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t mention who may or who may not try\r\nfor that place. There\xe2\x80\x99s duty to do, and I shall do it, under any\r\ncircumstances; to the best of my judgment and ability.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Speaking as a shipper of lime--\xe2\x80\x99 began Eugene.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Which no man has a better right to do than yourself, you know,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr\r\nInspector.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope not,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene; \xe2\x80\x98my father having been a shipper of lime\r\nbefore me, and my grandfather before him--in fact we having been a\r\nfamily immersed to the crowns of our heads in lime during several\r\ngenerations--I beg to observe that if this missing lime could be got\r\nhold of without any young female relative of any distinguished gentleman\r\nengaged in the lime trade (which I cherish next to my life) being\r\npresent, I think it might be a more agreeable proceeding to the\r\nassisting bystanders, that is to say, lime-burners.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I also,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lightwood, pushing his friend aside with a laugh, \xe2\x80\x98should\r\nmuch prefer that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It shall be done, gentlemen, if it can be done conveniently,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nMr Inspector, with coolness. \xe2\x80\x98There is no wish on my part to cause any\r\ndistress in that quarter. Indeed, I am sorry for that quarter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There was a boy in that quarter,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Eugene. \xe2\x80\x98He is still there?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector. \xe2\x80\x98He has quitted those works. He is otherwise\r\ndisposed of.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Will she be left alone then?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Eugene.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She will be left,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector, \xe2\x80\x98alone.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBob\xe2\x80\x99s reappearance with a steaming jug broke off the conversation. But\r\nalthough the jug steamed forth a delicious perfume, its contents had not\r\nreceived that last happy touch which the surpassing finish of the Six\r\nJolly Fellowship Porters imparted on such momentous occasions. Bob\r\ncarried in his left hand one of those iron models of sugar-loaf hats,\r\nbefore mentioned, into which he emptied the jug, and the pointed end of\r\nwhich he thrust deep down into the fire, so leaving it for a few moments\r\nwhile he disappeared and reappeared with three bright drinking-glasses.\r\nPlacing these on the table and bending over the fire, meritoriously\r\nsensible of the trying nature of his duty, he watched the wreaths of\r\nsteam, until at the special instant of projection he caught up the iron\r\nvessel and gave it one delicate twirl, causing it to send forth one\r\ngentle hiss. Then he restored the contents to the jug; held over the\r\nsteam of the jug, each of the three bright glasses in succession;\r\nfinally filled them all, and with a clear conscience awaited the\r\napplause of his fellow-creatures.\r\n\r\nIt was bestowed (Mr Inspector having proposed as an appropriate\r\nsentiment \xe2\x80\x98The lime trade!\xe2\x80\x99) and Bob withdrew to report the\r\ncommendations of the guests to Miss Abbey in the bar. It may be here\r\nin confidence admitted that, the room being close shut in his absence,\r\nthere had not appeared to be the slightest reason for the elaborate\r\nmaintenance of this same lime fiction. Only it had been regarded by Mr\r\nInspector as so uncommonly satisfactory, and so fraught with mysterious\r\nvirtues, that neither of his clients had presumed to question it.\r\n\r\nTwo taps were now heard on the outside of the window. Mr Inspector,\r\nhastily fortifying himself with another glass, strolled out with a\r\nnoiseless foot and an unoccupied countenance. As one might go to survey\r\nthe weather and the general aspect of the heavenly bodies.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is becoming grim, Mortimer,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, in a low voice. \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nlike this.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nor I\xe2\x80\x99 said Lightwood. \xe2\x80\x98Shall we go?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Being here, let us stay. You ought to see it out, and I won\xe2\x80\x99t leave\r\nyou. Besides, that lonely girl with the dark hair runs in my head. It\r\nwas little more than a glimpse we had of her that last time, and yet\r\nI almost see her waiting by the fire to-night. Do you feel like a dark\r\ncombination of traitor and pickpocket when you think of that girl?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Rather,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Lightwood. \xe2\x80\x98Do you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very much so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nTheir escort strolled back again, and reported. Divested of its various\r\nlime-lights and shadows, his report went to the effect that Gaffer was\r\naway in his boat, supposed to be on his old look-out; that he had been\r\nexpected last high-water; that having missed it for some reason or\r\nother, he was not, according to his usual habits at night, to be counted\r\non before next high-water, or it might be an hour or so later; that his\r\ndaughter, surveyed through the window, would seem to be so expecting\r\nhim, for the supper was not cooking, but set out ready to be cooked;\r\nthat it would be high-water at about one, and that it was now barely\r\nten; that there was nothing to be done but watch and wait; that the\r\ninformer was keeping watch at the instant of that present reporting, but\r\nthat two heads were better than one (especially when the second was\r\nMr Inspector\xe2\x80\x99s); and that the reporter meant to share the watch. And\r\nforasmuch as crouching under the lee of a hauled-up boat on a night when\r\nit blew cold and strong, and when the weather was varied with blasts of\r\nhail at times, might be wearisome to amateurs, the reporter closed with\r\nthe recommendation that the two gentlemen should remain, for a while at\r\nany rate, in their present quarters, which were weather-tight and warm.\r\n\r\nThey were not inclined to dispute this recommendation, but they wanted\r\nto know where they could join the watchers when so disposed. Rather than\r\ntrust to a verbal description of the place, which might mislead, Eugene\r\n(with a less weighty sense of personal trouble on him than he usually\r\nhad) would go out with Mr Inspector, note the spot, and come back.\r\n\r\nOn the shelving bank of the river, among the slimy stones of a\r\ncauseway--not the special causeway of the Six Jolly Fellowships, which\r\nhad a landing-place of its own, but another, a little removed, and\r\nvery near to the old windmill which was the denounced man\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndwelling-place--were a few boats; some, moored and already beginning to\r\nfloat; others, hauled up above the reach of the tide. Under one of these\r\nlatter, Eugene\xe2\x80\x99s companion disappeared. And when Eugene had observed its\r\nposition with reference to the other boats, and had made sure that he\r\ncould not miss it, he turned his eyes upon the building where, as he had\r\nbeen told, the lonely girl with the dark hair sat by the fire.\r\n\r\nHe could see the light of the fire shining through the window. Perhaps\r\nit drew him on to look in. Perhaps he had come out with the express\r\nintention. That part of the bank having rank grass growing on it, there\r\nwas no difficulty in getting close, without any noise of footsteps: it\r\nwas but to scramble up a ragged face of pretty hard mud some three or\r\nfour feet high and come upon the grass and to the window. He came to the\r\nwindow by that means.\r\n\r\nShe had no other light than the light of the fire. The unkindled lamp\r\nstood on the table. She sat on the ground, looking at the brazier, with\r\nher face leaning on her hand. There was a kind of film or flicker on\r\nher face, which at first he took to be the fitful firelight; but, on a\r\nsecond look, he saw that she was weeping. A sad and solitary spectacle,\r\nas shown him by the rising and the falling of the fire.\r\n\r\nIt was a little window of but four pieces of glass, and was not\r\ncurtained; he chose it because the larger window near it was. It showed\r\nhim the room, and the bills upon the wall respecting the drowned people\r\nstarting out and receding by turns. But he glanced slightly at them,\r\nthough he looked long and steadily at her. A deep rich piece of colour,\r\nwith the brown flush of her cheek and the shining lustre of her hair,\r\nthough sad and solitary, weeping by the rising and the falling of the\r\nfire.\r\n\r\nShe started up. He had been so very still that he felt sure it was not\r\nhe who had disturbed her, so merely withdrew from the window and stood\r\nnear it in the shadow of the wall. She opened the door, and said in an\r\nalarmed tone, \xe2\x80\x98Father, was that you calling me?\xe2\x80\x99 And again, \xe2\x80\x98Father!\xe2\x80\x99\r\nAnd once again, after listening, \xe2\x80\x98Father! I thought I heard you call me\r\ntwice before!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nNo response. As she re-entered at the door, he dropped over the bank and\r\nmade his way back, among the ooze and near the hiding-place, to Mortimer\r\nLightwood: to whom he told what he had seen of the girl, and how this\r\nwas becoming very grim indeed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If the real man feels as guilty as I do,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, \xe2\x80\x98he is\r\nremarkably uncomfortable.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Influence of secrecy,\xe2\x80\x99 suggested Lightwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am not at all obliged to it for making me Guy Fawkes in the vault and\r\na Sneak in the area both at once,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene. \xe2\x80\x98Give me some more of\r\nthat stuff.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLightwood helped him to some more of that stuff, but it had been\r\ncooling, and didn\xe2\x80\x99t answer now.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pooh,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, spitting it out among the ashes. \xe2\x80\x98Tastes like the\r\nwash of the river.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you so familiar with the flavour of the wash of the river?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I seem to be to-night. I feel as if I had been half drowned, and\r\nswallowing a gallon of it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Influence of locality,\xe2\x80\x99 suggested Lightwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are mighty learned to-night, you and your influences,\xe2\x80\x99 returned\r\nEugene. \xe2\x80\x98How long shall we stay here?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How long do you think?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If I could choose, I should say a minute,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Eugene, \xe2\x80\x98for the\r\nJolly Fellowship Porters are not the jolliest dogs I have known. But\r\nI suppose we are best here until they turn us out with the other\r\nsuspicious characters, at midnight.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThereupon he stirred the fire, and sat down on one side of it. It struck\r\neleven, and he made believe to compose himself patiently. But gradually\r\nhe took the fidgets in one leg, and then in the other leg, and then in\r\none arm, and then in the other arm, and then in his chin, and then in\r\nhis back, and then in his forehead, and then in his hair, and then in\r\nhis nose; and then he stretched himself recumbent on two chairs, and\r\ngroaned; and then he started up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Invisible insects of diabolical activity swarm in this place. I am\r\ntickled and twitched all over. Mentally, I have now committed a burglary\r\nunder the meanest circumstances, and the myrmidons of justice are at my\r\nheels.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am quite as bad,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lightwood, sitting up facing him, with a\r\ntumbled head; after going through some wonderful evolutions, in which\r\nhis head had been the lowest part of him. \xe2\x80\x98This restlessness began with\r\nme, long ago. All the time you were out, I felt like Gulliver with the\r\nLilliputians firing upon him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It won\xe2\x80\x99t do, Mortimer. We must get into the air; we must join our dear\r\nfriend and brother, Riderhood. And let us tranquillize ourselves by\r\nmaking a compact. Next time (with a view to our peace of mind) we\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\ncommit the crime, instead of taking the criminal. You swear it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sworn! Let Tippins look to it. Her life\xe2\x80\x99s in danger.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMortimer rang the bell to pay the score, and Bob appeared to transact\r\nthat business with him: whom Eugene, in his careless extravagance, asked\r\nif he would like a situation in the lime-trade?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thankee sir, no sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bob. \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve a good sitiwation here, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If you change your mind at any time,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Eugene, \xe2\x80\x98come to me at\r\nmy works, and you\xe2\x80\x99ll always find an opening in the lime-kiln.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thankee sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bob.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is my partner,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, \xe2\x80\x98who keeps the books and attends to\r\nthe wages. A fair day\xe2\x80\x99s wages for a fair day\xe2\x80\x99s work is ever my partner\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmotto.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And a very good \xe2\x80\x98un it is, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bob, receiving his fee, and\r\ndrawing a bow out of his head with his right hand, very much as he would\r\nhave drawn a pint of beer out of the beer engine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Eugene,\xe2\x80\x99 Mortimer apostrophized him, laughing quite heartily when they\r\nwere alone again, \xe2\x80\x98how CAN you be so ridiculous?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am in a ridiculous humour,\xe2\x80\x99 quoth Eugene; \xe2\x80\x98I am a ridiculous fellow.\r\nEverything is ridiculous. Come along!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt passed into Mortimer Lightwood\xe2\x80\x99s mind that a change of some sort,\r\nbest expressed perhaps as an intensification of all that was wildest and\r\nmost negligent and reckless in his friend, had come upon him in the last\r\nhalf-hour or so. Thoroughly used to him as he was, he found something\r\nnew and strained in him that was for the moment perplexing. This passed\r\ninto his mind, and passed out again; but he remembered it afterwards.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s where she sits, you see,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, when they were standing\r\nunder the bank, roared and riven at by the wind. \xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s the light of\r\nher fire.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll take a peep through the window,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mortimer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, don\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x99 Eugene caught him by the arm. \xe2\x80\x98Best, not make a show of\r\nher. Come to our honest friend.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe led him to the post of watch, and they both dropped down and crept\r\nunder the lee of the boat; a better shelter than it had seemed before,\r\nbeing directly contrasted with the blowing wind and the bare night.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Inspector at home?\xe2\x80\x99 whispered Eugene.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here I am, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And our friend of the perspiring brow is at the far corner there? Good.\r\nAnything happened?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98His daughter has been out, thinking she heard him calling, unless it\r\nwas a sign to him to keep out of the way. It might have been.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It might have been Rule Britannia,\xe2\x80\x99 muttered Eugene, \xe2\x80\x98but it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t.\r\nMortimer!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here!\xe2\x80\x99 (On the other side of Mr Inspector.)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Two burglaries now, and a forgery!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith this indication of his depressed state of mind, Eugene fell silent.\r\n\r\nThey were all silent for a long while. As it got to be flood-tide, and\r\nthe water came nearer to them, noises on the river became more frequent,\r\nand they listened more. To the turning of steam-paddles, to the clinking\r\nof iron chain, to the creaking of blocks, to the measured working\r\nof oars, to the occasional violent barking of some passing dog on\r\nshipboard, who seemed to scent them lying in their hiding-place. The\r\nnight was not so dark but that, besides the lights at bows and mastheads\r\ngliding to and fro, they could discern some shadowy bulk attached; and\r\nnow and then a ghostly lighter with a large dark sail, like a warning\r\narm, would start up very near them, pass on, and vanish. At this time\r\nof their watch, the water close to them would be often agitated by some\r\nimpulsion given it from a distance. Often they believed this beat and\r\nplash to be the boat they lay in wait for, running in ashore; and again\r\nand again they would have started up, but for the immobility with which\r\nthe informer, well used to the river, kept quiet in his place.\r\n\r\nThe wind carried away the striking of the great multitude of city\r\nchurch clocks, for those lay to leeward of them; but there were bells to\r\nwindward that told them of its being One--Two--Three. Without that aid\r\nthey would have known how the night wore, by the falling of the tide,\r\nrecorded in the appearance of an ever-widening black wet strip of shore,\r\nand the emergence of the paved causeway from the river, foot by foot.\r\n\r\nAs the time so passed, this slinking business became a more and more\r\nprecarious one. It would seem as if the man had had some intimation of\r\nwhat was in hand against him, or had taken fright? His movements might\r\nhave been planned to gain for him, in getting beyond their reach, twelve\r\nhours\xe2\x80\x99 advantage? The honest man who had expended the sweat of his brow\r\nbecame uneasy, and began to complain with bitterness of the proneness of\r\nmankind to cheat him--him invested with the dignity of Labour!\r\n\r\nTheir retreat was so chosen that while they could watch the river, they\r\ncould watch the house. No one had passed in or out, since the daughter\r\nthought she heard the father calling. No one could pass in or out\r\nwithout being seen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But it will be light at five,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector, \xe2\x80\x98and then WE shall be\r\nseen.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Look here,\xe2\x80\x99 said Riderhood, \xe2\x80\x98what do you say to this? He may have\r\nbeen lurking in and out, and just holding his own betwixt two or three\r\nbridges, for hours back.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you make of that?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector. Stoical, but\r\ncontradictory.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He may be doing so at this present time.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you make of that?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My boat\xe2\x80\x99s among them boats here at the cause\xe2\x80\x99ay.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And what do you make of your boat?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What if I put off in her and take a look round? I know his ways, and\r\nthe likely nooks he favours. I know where he\xe2\x80\x99d be at such a time of the\r\ntide, and where he\xe2\x80\x99d be at such another time. Ain\xe2\x80\x99t I been his pardner?\r\nNone of you need show. None of you need stir. I can shove her off\r\nwithout help; and as to me being seen, I\xe2\x80\x99m about at all times.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You might have given a worse opinion,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector, after brief\r\nconsideration. \xe2\x80\x98Try it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stop a bit. Let\xe2\x80\x99s work it out. If I want you, I\xe2\x80\x99ll drop round under the\r\nFellowships and tip you a whistle.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If I might so far presume as to offer a suggestion to my honourable and\r\ngallant friend, whose knowledge of naval matters far be it from me to\r\nimpeach,\xe2\x80\x99 Eugene struck in with great deliberation, \xe2\x80\x98it would be, that\r\nto tip a whistle is to advertise mystery and invite speculation.\r\nMy honourable and gallant friend will, I trust, excuse me, as an\r\nindependent member, for throwing out a remark which I feel to be due to\r\nthis house and the country.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Was that the T\xe2\x80\x99other Governor, or Lawyer Lightwood?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Riderhood.\r\nFor, they spoke as they crouched or lay, without seeing one another\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfaces.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In reply to the question put by my honourable and gallant friend,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Eugene, who was lying on his back with his hat on his face, as an\r\nattitude highly expressive of watchfulness, \xe2\x80\x98I can have no hesitation in\r\nreplying (it not being inconsistent with the public service) that those\r\naccents were the accents of the T\xe2\x80\x99other Governor.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99ve tolerable good eyes, ain\xe2\x80\x99t you, Governor? You\xe2\x80\x99ve all tolerable\r\ngood eyes, ain\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x99 demanded the informer.\r\n\r\nAll.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then if I row up under the Fellowship and lay there, no need to\r\nwhistle. You\xe2\x80\x99ll make out that there\xe2\x80\x99s a speck of something or another\r\nthere, and you\xe2\x80\x99ll know it\xe2\x80\x99s me, and you\xe2\x80\x99ll come down that cause\xe2\x80\x99ay to\r\nme. Understood all?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nUnderstood all.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Off she goes then!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIn a moment, with the wind cutting keenly at him sideways, he was\r\nstaggering down to his boat; in a few moments he was clear, and creeping\r\nup the river under their own shore.\r\n\r\nEugene had raised himself on his elbow to look into the darkness after\r\nhim. \xe2\x80\x98I wish the boat of my honourable and gallant friend,\xe2\x80\x99 he murmured,\r\nlying down again and speaking into his hat, \xe2\x80\x98may be endowed\r\nwith philanthropy enough to turn bottom-upward and extinguish\r\nhim!--Mortimer.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My honourable friend.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Three burglaries, two forgeries, and a midnight assassination.\xe2\x80\x99 Yet\r\nin spite of having those weights on his conscience, Eugene was somewhat\r\nenlivened by the late slight change in the circumstances of affairs. So\r\nwere his two companions. Its being a change was everything. The suspense\r\nseemed to have taken a new lease, and to have begun afresh from a recent\r\ndate. There was something additional to look for. They were all three\r\nmore sharply on the alert, and less deadened by the miserable influences\r\nof the place and time.\r\n\r\nMore than an hour had passed, and they were even dozing, when one of the\r\nthree--each said it was he, and he had NOT dozed--made out Riderhood\r\nin his boat at the spot agreed on. They sprang up, came out from their\r\nshelter, and went down to him. When he saw them coming, he dropped\r\nalongside the causeway; so that they, standing on the causeway, could\r\nspeak with him in whispers, under the shadowy mass of the Six Jolly\r\nFellowship Porters fast asleep.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Blest if I can make it out!\xe2\x80\x99 said he, staring at them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Make what out? Have you seen him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What HAVE you seen?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Lightwood. For, he was staring at them in\r\nthe strangest way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen his boat.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not empty?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, empty. And what\xe2\x80\x99s more,--adrift. And what\xe2\x80\x99s more,--with one scull\r\ngone. And what\xe2\x80\x99s more,--with t\xe2\x80\x99other scull jammed in the thowels and\r\nbroke short off. And what\xe2\x80\x99s more,--the boat\xe2\x80\x99s drove tight by the tide\r\n\xe2\x80\x98atwixt two tiers of barges. And what\xe2\x80\x99s more,--he\xe2\x80\x99s in luck again, by\r\nGeorge if he ain\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 14\r\n\r\nTHE BIRD OF PREY BROUGHT DOWN\r\n\r\n\r\nCold on the shore, in the raw cold of that leaden crisis in the\r\nfour-and-twenty hours when the vital force of all the noblest and\r\nprettiest things that live is at its lowest, the three watchers looked\r\neach at the blank faces of the other two, and all at the blank face of\r\nRiderhood in his boat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Gaffer\xe2\x80\x99s boat, Gaffer in luck again, and yet no Gaffer!\xe2\x80\x99 So spake\r\nRiderhood, staring disconsolate.\r\n\r\nAs if with one accord, they all turned their eyes towards the light of\r\nthe fire shining through the window. It was fainter and duller. Perhaps\r\nfire, like the higher animal and vegetable life it helps to sustain, has\r\nits greatest tendency towards death, when the night is dying and the day\r\nis not yet born.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If it was me that had the law of this here job in hand,\xe2\x80\x99 growled\r\nRiderhood with a threatening shake of his head, \xe2\x80\x98blest if I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t lay\r\nhold of HER, at any rate!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ay, but it is not you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene. With something so suddenly fierce\r\nin him that the informer returned submissively; \xe2\x80\x98Well, well, well,\r\nt\xe2\x80\x99other governor, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t say it was. A man may speak.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And vermin may be silent,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene. \xe2\x80\x98Hold your tongue, you\r\nwater-rat!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAstonished by his friend\xe2\x80\x99s unusual heat, Lightwood stared too, and then\r\nsaid: \xe2\x80\x98What can have become of this man?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Can\xe2\x80\x99t imagine. Unless he dived overboard.\xe2\x80\x99 The informer wiped his\r\nbrow ruefully as he said it, sitting in his boat and always staring\r\ndisconsolate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did you make his boat fast?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She\xe2\x80\x99s fast enough till the tide runs back. I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t make her faster\r\nthan she is. Come aboard of mine, and see for your own-selves.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere was a little backwardness in complying, for the freight looked too\r\nmuch for the boat; but on Riderhood\xe2\x80\x99s protesting \xe2\x80\x98that he had had half a\r\ndozen, dead and alive, in her afore now, and she was nothing deep in the\r\nwater nor down in the stern even then, to speak of;\xe2\x80\x99 they carefully took\r\ntheir places, and trimmed the crazy thing. While they were doing so,\r\nRiderhood still sat staring disconsolate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98All right. Give way!\xe2\x80\x99 said Lightwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Give way, by George!\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Riderhood, before shoving off. \xe2\x80\x98If he\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ngone and made off any how Lawyer Lightwood, it\xe2\x80\x99s enough to make me give\r\nway in a different manner. But he always WAS a cheat, con-found him!\r\nHe always was a infernal cheat, was Gaffer. Nothing straightfor\xe2\x80\x99ard,\r\nnothing on the square. So mean, so underhanded. Never going through with\r\na thing, nor carrying it out like a man!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hallo! Steady!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Eugene (he had recovered immediately on\r\nembarking), as they bumped heavily against a pile; and then in a lower\r\nvoice reversed his late apostrophe by remarking [\xe2\x80\x98I wish the boat of my\r\nhonourable and gallant friend may be endowed with philanthropy enough\r\nnot to turn bottom-upward and extinguish us!) Steady, steady! Sit close,\r\nMortimer. Here\xe2\x80\x99s the hail again. See how it flies, like a troop of wild\r\ncats, at Mr Riderhood\xe2\x80\x99s eyes!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIndeed he had the full benefit of it, and it so mauled him, though he\r\nbent his head low and tried to present nothing but the mangy cap to it,\r\nthat he dropped under the lee of a tier of shipping, and they lay there\r\nuntil it was over. The squall had come up, like a spiteful messenger\r\nbefore the morning; there followed in its wake a ragged tear of light\r\nwhich ripped the dark clouds until they showed a great grey hole of day.\r\n\r\nThey were all shivering, and everything about them seemed to be\r\nshivering; the river itself; craft, rigging, sails, such early smoke as\r\nthere yet was on the shore. Black with wet, and altered to the eye by\r\nwhite patches of hail and sleet, the huddled buildings looked lower\r\nthan usual, as if they were cowering, and had shrunk with the cold. Very\r\nlittle life was to be seen on either bank, windows and doors were shut,\r\nand the staring black and white letters upon wharves and warehouses\r\n\xe2\x80\x98looked,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene to Mortimer, \xe2\x80\x98like inscriptions over the graves of\r\ndead businesses.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs they glided slowly on, keeping under the shore and sneaking in and\r\nout among the shipping by back-alleys of water, in a pilfering way\r\nthat seemed to be their boatman\xe2\x80\x99s normal manner of progression, all\r\nthe objects among which they crept were so huge in contrast with their\r\nwretched boat, as to threaten to crush it. Not a ship\xe2\x80\x99s hull, with its\r\nrusty iron links of cable run out of hawse-holes long discoloured with\r\nthe iron\xe2\x80\x99s rusty tears, but seemed to be there with a fell intention.\r\nNot a figure-head but had the menacing look of bursting forward to run\r\nthem down. Not a sluice gate, or a painted scale upon a post or wall,\r\nshowing the depth of water, but seemed to hint, like the dreadfully\r\nfacetious Wolf in bed in Grandmamma\xe2\x80\x99s cottage, \xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s to drown YOU in,\r\nmy dears!\xe2\x80\x99 Not a lumbering black barge, with its cracked and blistered\r\nside impending over them, but seemed to suck at the river with a\r\nthirst for sucking them under. And everything so vaunted the spoiling\r\ninfluences of water--discoloured copper, rotten wood, honey-combed\r\nstone, green dank deposit--that the after-consequences of being crushed,\r\nsucked under, and drawn down, looked as ugly to the imagination as the\r\nmain event.\r\n\r\nSome half-hour of this work, and Riderhood unshipped his sculls, stood\r\nholding on to a barge, and hand over hand long-wise along the barge\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nside gradually worked his boat under her head into a secret little\r\nnook of scummy water. And driven into that nook, and wedged as he had\r\ndescribed, was Gaffer\xe2\x80\x99s boat; that boat with the stain still in it,\r\nbearing some resemblance to a muffled human form.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now tell me I\xe2\x80\x99m a liar!\xe2\x80\x99 said the honest man.\r\n\r\n[\xe2\x80\x98With a morbid expectation,\xe2\x80\x99 murmured Eugene to Lightwood, \xe2\x80\x98that\r\nsomebody is always going to tell him the truth.\xe2\x80\x99)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is Hexam\xe2\x80\x99s boat,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector. \xe2\x80\x98I know her well.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Look at the broken scull. Look at the t\xe2\x80\x99other scull gone. NOW tell me I\r\nam a liar!\xe2\x80\x99 said the honest man.\r\n\r\nMr Inspector stepped into the boat. Eugene and Mortimer looked on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And see now!\xe2\x80\x99 added Riderhood, creeping aft, and showing a stretched\r\nrope made fast there and towing overboard. \xe2\x80\x98Didn\xe2\x80\x99t I tell you he was in\r\nluck again?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Haul in,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Easy to say haul in,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Riderhood. \xe2\x80\x98Not so easy done. His luck\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ngot fouled under the keels of the barges. I tried to haul in last time,\r\nbut I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t. See how taut the line is!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I must have it up,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector. \xe2\x80\x98I am going to take this boat\r\nashore, and his luck along with it. Try easy now.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe tried easy now; but the luck resisted; wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t come.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I mean to have it, and the boat too,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector, playing the\r\nline.\r\n\r\nBut still the luck resisted; wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t come.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Take care,\xe2\x80\x99 said Riderhood. \xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99ll disfigure. Or pull asunder\r\nperhaps.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am not going to do either, not even to your Grandmother,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr\r\nInspector; \xe2\x80\x98but I mean to have it. Come!\xe2\x80\x99 he added, at once persuasively\r\nand with authority to the hidden object in the water, as he played the\r\nline again; \xe2\x80\x98it\xe2\x80\x99s no good this sort of game, you know. You MUST come up.\r\nI mean to have you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere was so much virtue in this distinctly and decidedly meaning to\r\nhave it, that it yielded a little, even while the line was played.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I told you so,\xe2\x80\x99 quoth Mr Inspector, pulling off his outer coat, and\r\nleaning well over the stern with a will. \xe2\x80\x98Come!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt was an awful sort of fishing, but it no more disconcerted Mr\r\nInspector than if he had been fishing in a punt on a summer evening by\r\nsome soothing weir high up the peaceful river. After certain minutes,\r\nand a few directions to the rest to \xe2\x80\x98ease her a little for\xe2\x80\x99ard,\xe2\x80\x99 and\r\n\xe2\x80\x98now ease her a trifle aft,\xe2\x80\x99 and the like, he said composedly, \xe2\x80\x98All\r\nclear!\xe2\x80\x99 and the line and the boat came free together.\r\n\r\nAccepting Lightwood\xe2\x80\x99s proffered hand to help him up, he then put on his\r\ncoat, and said to Riderhood, \xe2\x80\x98Hand me over those spare sculls of yours,\r\nand I\xe2\x80\x99ll pull this in to the nearest stairs. Go ahead you, and keep out\r\nin pretty open water, that I mayn\xe2\x80\x99t get fouled again.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHis directions were obeyed, and they pulled ashore directly; two in one\r\nboat, two in the other.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector, again to Riderhood, when they were all on the\r\nslushy stones; \xe2\x80\x98you have had more practice in this than I have had, and\r\nought to be a better workman at it. Undo the tow-rope, and we\xe2\x80\x99ll help\r\nyou haul in.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nRiderhood got into the boat accordingly. It appeared as if he had\r\nscarcely had a moment\xe2\x80\x99s time to touch the rope or look over the stern,\r\nwhen he came scrambling back, as pale as the morning, and gasped out:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98By the Lord, he\xe2\x80\x99s done me!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you mean?\xe2\x80\x99 they all demanded.\r\n\r\nHe pointed behind him at the boat, and gasped to that degree that he\r\ndropped upon the stones to get his breath.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Gaffer\xe2\x80\x99s done me. It\xe2\x80\x99s Gaffer!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey ran to the rope, leaving him gasping there. Soon, the form of the\r\nbird of prey, dead some hours, lay stretched upon the shore, with a new\r\nblast storming at it and clotting the wet hair with hail-stones.\r\n\r\nFather, was that you calling me? Father! I thought I heard you call me\r\ntwice before! Words never to be answered, those, upon the earth-side\r\nof the grave. The wind sweeps jeeringly over Father, whips him with the\r\nfrayed ends of his dress and his jagged hair, tries to turn him where he\r\nlies stark on his back, and force his face towards the rising sun, that\r\nhe may be shamed the more. A lull, and the wind is secret and prying\r\nwith him; lifts and lets falls a rag; hides palpitating under another\r\nrag; runs nimbly through his hair and beard. Then, in a rush, it cruelly\r\ntaunts him. Father, was that you calling me? Was it you, the voiceless\r\nand the dead? Was it you, thus buffeted as you lie here in a heap? Was\r\nit you, thus baptized unto Death, with these flying impurities now flung\r\nupon your face? Why not speak, Father? Soaking into this filthy ground\r\nas you lie here, is your own shape. Did you never see such a shape\r\nsoaked into your boat? Speak, Father. Speak to us, the winds, the only\r\nlisteners left you!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now see,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector, after mature deliberation: kneeling on one\r\nknee beside the body, when they had stood looking down on the drowned\r\nman, as he had many a time looked down on many another man: \xe2\x80\x98the way of\r\nit was this. Of course you gentlemen hardly failed to observe that he\r\nwas towing by the neck and arms.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey had helped to release the rope, and of course not.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And you will have observed before, and you will observe now, that this\r\nknot, which was drawn chock-tight round his neck by the strain of his\r\nown arms, is a slip-knot\xe2\x80\x99: holding it up for demonstration.\r\n\r\nPlain enough.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Likewise you will have observed how he had run the other end of this\r\nrope to his boat.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt had the curves and indentations in it still, where it had been twined\r\nand bound.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now see,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector, \xe2\x80\x98see how it works round upon him. It\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nwild tempestuous evening when this man that was,\xe2\x80\x99 stooping to wipe\r\nsome hailstones out of his hair with an end of his own drowned jacket,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98--there! Now he\xe2\x80\x99s more like himself; though he\xe2\x80\x99s badly bruised,--when\r\nthis man that was, rows out upon the river on his usual lay. He carries\r\nwith him this coil of rope. He always carries with him this coil of\r\nrope. It\xe2\x80\x99s as well known to me as he was himself. Sometimes it lay in\r\nthe bottom of his boat. Sometimes he hung it loose round his neck.\r\nHe was a light-dresser was this man;--you see?\xe2\x80\x99 lifting the loose\r\nneckerchief over his breast, and taking the opportunity of wiping the\r\ndead lips with it--\xe2\x80\x98and when it was wet, or freezing, or blew cold, he\r\nwould hang this coil of line round his neck. Last evening he does this.\r\nWorse for him! He dodges about in his boat, does this man, till he gets\r\nchilled. His hands,\xe2\x80\x99 taking up one of them, which dropped like a leaden\r\nweight, \xe2\x80\x98get numbed. He sees some object that\xe2\x80\x99s in his way of business,\r\nfloating. He makes ready to secure that object. He unwinds the end of\r\nhis coil that he wants to take some turns on in his boat, and he takes\r\nturns enough on it to secure that it shan\xe2\x80\x99t run out. He makes it too\r\nsecure, as it happens. He is a little longer about this than usual, his\r\nhands being numbed. His object drifts up, before he is quite ready for\r\nit. He catches at it, thinks he\xe2\x80\x99ll make sure of the contents of the\r\npockets anyhow, in case he should be parted from it, bends right over\r\nthe stern, and in one of these heavy squalls, or in the cross-swell of\r\ntwo steamers, or in not being quite prepared, or through all or most or\r\nsome, gets a lurch, overbalances and goes head-foremost overboard. Now\r\nsee! He can swim, can this man, and instantly he strikes out. But in\r\nsuch striking-out he tangles his arms, pulls strong on the slip-knot,\r\nand it runs home. The object he had expected to take in tow, floats by,\r\nand his own boat tows him dead, to where we found him, all entangled\r\nin his own line. You\xe2\x80\x99ll ask me how I make out about the pockets? First,\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you more; there was silver in \xe2\x80\x98em. How do I make that out?\r\nSimple and satisfactory. Because he\xe2\x80\x99s got it here.\xe2\x80\x99 The lecturer held up\r\nthe tightly clenched right hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What is to be done with the remains?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Lightwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t object to standing by him half a minute, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 was\r\nthe reply, \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll find the nearest of our men to come and take charge of\r\nhim;--I still call it HIM, you see,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector, looking back as\r\nhe went, with a philosophical smile upon the force of habit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Eugene,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lightwood and was about to add \xe2\x80\x98we may wait at a little\r\ndistance,\xe2\x80\x99 when turning his head he found that no Eugene was there.\r\n\r\nHe raised his voice and called \xe2\x80\x98Eugene! Holloa!\xe2\x80\x99 But no Eugene replied.\r\n\r\nIt was broad daylight now, and he looked about. But no Eugene was in all\r\nthe view.\r\n\r\nMr Inspector speedily returning down the wooden stairs, with a police\r\nconstable, Lightwood asked him if he had seen his friend leave them? Mr\r\nInspector could not exactly say that he had seen him go, but had noticed\r\nthat he was restless.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Singular and entertaining combination, sir, your friend.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wish it had not been a part of his singular entertaining combination\r\nto give me the slip under these dreary circumstances at this time of the\r\nmorning,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lightwood. \xe2\x80\x98Can we get anything hot to drink?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWe could, and we did. In a public-house kitchen with a large fire. We\r\ngot hot brandy and water, and it revived us wonderfully. Mr Inspector\r\nhaving to Mr Riderhood announced his official intention of \xe2\x80\x98keeping\r\nhis eye upon him\xe2\x80\x99, stood him in a corner of the fireplace, like a wet\r\numbrella, and took no further outward and visible notice of that honest\r\nman, except ordering a separate service of brandy and water for him:\r\napparently out of the public funds.\r\n\r\nAs Mortimer Lightwood sat before the blazing fire, conscious of drinking\r\nbrandy and water then and there in his sleep, and yet at one and the\r\nsame time drinking burnt sherry at the Six Jolly Fellowships, and\r\nlying under the boat on the river shore, and sitting in the boat that\r\nRiderhood rowed, and listening to the lecture recently concluded, and\r\nhaving to dine in the Temple with an unknown man, who described himself\r\nas M. H. F. Eugene Gaffer Harmon, and said he lived at Hailstorm,--as\r\nhe passed through these curious vicissitudes of fatigue and slumber,\r\narranged upon the scale of a dozen hours to the second, he became aware\r\nof answering aloud a communication of pressing importance that had\r\nnever been made to him, and then turned it into a cough on beholding\r\nMr Inspector. For, he felt, with some natural indignation, that that\r\nfunctionary might otherwise suspect him of having closed his eyes, or\r\nwandered in his attention.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here just before us, you see,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I see,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lightwood, with dignity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And had hot brandy and water too, you see,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector, \xe2\x80\x98and\r\nthen cut off at a great rate.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who?\xe2\x80\x99 said Lightwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your friend, you know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know,\xe2\x80\x99 he replied, again with dignity.\r\n\r\nAfter hearing, in a mist through which Mr Inspector loomed vague and\r\nlarge, that the officer took upon himself to prepare the dead man\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndaughter for what had befallen in the night, and generally that he took\r\neverything upon himself, Mortimer Lightwood stumbled in his sleep to\r\na cab-stand, called a cab, and had entered the army and committed a\r\ncapital military offence and been tried by court martial and found\r\nguilty and had arranged his affairs and been marched out to be shot,\r\nbefore the door banged.\r\n\r\nHard work rowing the cab through the City to the Temple, for a cup of\r\nfrom five to ten thousand pounds value, given by Mr Boffin; and hard\r\nwork holding forth at that immeasurable length to Eugene (when he had\r\nbeen rescued with a rope from the running pavement) for making off in\r\nthat extraordinary manner! But he offered such ample apologies, and was\r\nso very penitent, that when Lightwood got out of the cab, he gave\r\nthe driver a particular charge to be careful of him. Which the driver\r\n(knowing there was no other fare left inside) stared at prodigiously.\r\n\r\nIn short, the night\xe2\x80\x99s work had so exhausted and worn out this actor in\r\nit, that he had become a mere somnambulist.
