Come, come, Mr Riah, we know the arts of your\r\npeople\xe2\x80\x9d--my people!--\xe2\x80\x9cIf the money is to be lent, fetch it, fetch it; if\r\nit is not to be lent, keep it and say so.\xe2\x80\x9d They never believe me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98THAT\xe2\x80\x99S all right,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fascination Fledgeby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They say, \xe2\x80\x9cWe know, Mr Riah, we know. We have but to look at you, and\r\nwe know.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, a good \xe2\x80\x98un are you for the post,\xe2\x80\x99 thought Fledgeby, \xe2\x80\x98and a good \xe2\x80\x98un\r\nwas I to mark you out for it! I may be slow, but I am precious sure.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nNot a syllable of this reflection shaped itself in any scrap of Mr\r\nFledgeby\xe2\x80\x99s breath, lest it should tend to put his servant\xe2\x80\x99s price up.\r\nBut looking at the old man as he stood quiet with his head bowed and his\r\neyes cast down, he felt that to relinquish an inch of his baldness,\r\nan inch of his grey hair, an inch of his coat-skirt, an inch of his\r\nhat-brim, an inch of his walking-staff, would be to relinquish hundreds\r\nof pounds.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Look here, Riah,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby, mollified by these self-approving\r\nconsiderations. \xe2\x80\x98I want to go a little more into buying-up queer bills.\r\nLook out in that direction.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir, it shall be done.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Casting my eye over the accounts, I find that branch of business pays\r\npretty fairly, and I am game for extending it. I like to know people\xe2\x80\x99s\r\naffairs likewise. So look out.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir, I will, promptly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Put it about in the right quarters, that you\xe2\x80\x99ll buy queer bills by the\r\nlump--by the pound weight if that\xe2\x80\x99s all--supposing you see your way to a\r\nfair chance on looking over the parcel. And there\xe2\x80\x99s one thing more. Come\r\nto me with the books for periodical inspection as usual, at eight on\r\nMonday morning.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nRiah drew some folding tablets from his breast and noted it down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s all I wanted to say at the present time,\xe2\x80\x99 continued Fledgeby in\r\na grudging vein, as he got off the stool, \xe2\x80\x98except that I wish you\xe2\x80\x99d take\r\nthe air where you can hear the bell, or the knocker, either one of the\r\ntwo or both. By-the-by how DO you take the air at the top of the house?\r\nDo you stick your head out of a chimney-pot?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir, there are leads there, and I have made a little garden there.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To bury your money in, you old dodger?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A thumbnail\xe2\x80\x99s space of garden would hold the treasure I bury, master,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Riah. \xe2\x80\x98Twelve shillings a week, even when they are an old man\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwages, bury themselves.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should like to know what you really are worth,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Fledgeby,\r\nwith whom his growing rich on that stipend and gratitude was a very\r\nconvenient fiction. \xe2\x80\x98But come! Let\xe2\x80\x99s have a look at your garden on the\r\ntiles, before I go!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe old man took a step back, and hesitated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Truly, sir, I have company there.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have you, by George!\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby; \xe2\x80\x98I suppose you happen to know\r\nwhose premises these are?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir, they are yours, and I am your servant in them.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh! I thought you might have overlooked that,\xe2\x80\x99 retorted Fledgeby, with\r\nhis eyes on Riah\xe2\x80\x99s beard as he felt for his own; \xe2\x80\x98having company on my\r\npremises, you know!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come up and see the guests, sir. I hope for your admission that they\r\ncan do no harm.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPassing him with a courteous reverence, specially unlike any action that\r\nMr Fledgeby could for his life have imparted to his own head and hands,\r\nthe old man began to ascend the stairs. As he toiled on before, with his\r\npalm upon the stair-rail, and his long black skirt, a very gaberdine,\r\noverhanging each successive step, he might have been the leader in some\r\npilgrimage of devotional ascent to a prophet\xe2\x80\x99s tomb. Not troubled by any\r\nsuch weak imagining, Fascination Fledgeby merely speculated on the time\r\nof life at which his beard had begun, and thought once more what a good\r\n\xe2\x80\x98un he was for the part.\r\n\r\nSome final wooden steps conducted them, stooping under a low penthouse\r\nroof, to the house-top. Riah stood still, and, turning to his master,\r\npointed out his guests.\r\n\r\nLizzie Hexam and Jenny Wren. For whom, perhaps with some old instinct of\r\nhis race, the gentle Jew had spread a carpet. Seated on it, against\r\nno more romantic object than a blackened chimney-stack over which some\r\nbumble creeper had been trained, they both pored over one book; both\r\nwith attentive faces; Jenny with the sharper; Lizzie with the more\r\nperplexed. Another little book or two were lying near, and a common\r\nbasket of common fruit, and another basket full of strings of beads and\r\ntinsel scraps. A few boxes of humble flowers and evergreens completed\r\nthe garden; and the encompassing wilderness of dowager old chimneys\r\ntwirled their cowls and fluttered their smoke, rather as if they were\r\nbridling, and fanning themselves, and looking on in a state of airy\r\nsurprise.\r\n\r\nTaking her eyes off the book, to test her memory of something in it,\r\nLizzie was the first to see herself observed. As she rose, Miss Wren\r\nlikewise became conscious, and said, irreverently addressing the great\r\nchief of the premises: \xe2\x80\x98Whoever you are, I can\xe2\x80\x99t get up, because my\r\nback\xe2\x80\x99s bad and my legs are queer.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is my master,\xe2\x80\x99 said Riah, stepping forward.\r\n\r\n[\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t look like anybody\xe2\x80\x99s master,\xe2\x80\x99 observed Miss Wren to herself, with\r\na hitch of her chin and eyes.)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued the old man, \xe2\x80\x98is a little dressmaker for little\r\npeople. Explain to the master, Jenny.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dolls; that\xe2\x80\x99s all,\xe2\x80\x99 said Jenny, shortly. \xe2\x80\x98Very difficult to fit too,\r\nbecause their figures are so uncertain. You never know where to expect\r\ntheir waists.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Her friend,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed the old man, motioning towards Lizzie; \xe2\x80\x98and as\r\nindustrious as virtuous. But that they both are. They are busy early and\r\nlate, sir, early and late; and in bye-times, as on this holiday, they go\r\nto book-learning.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not much good to be got out of that,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Fledgeby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Depends upon the person!\xe2\x80\x99 quoth Miss Wren, snapping him up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I made acquaintance with my guests, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued the Jew, with an\r\nevident purpose of drawing out the dressmaker, \xe2\x80\x98through their coming\r\nhere to buy of our damage and waste for Miss Jenny\xe2\x80\x99s millinery. Our\r\nwaste goes into the best of company, sir, on her rosy-cheeked little\r\ncustomers. They wear it in their hair, and on their ball-dresses, and\r\neven (so she tells me) are presented at Court with it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah!\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby, on whose intelligence this doll-fancy made rather\r\nstrong demands; \xe2\x80\x98she\xe2\x80\x99s been buying that basketful to-day, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose she has,\xe2\x80\x99 Miss Jenny interposed; \xe2\x80\x98and paying for it too, most\r\nlikely!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Let\xe2\x80\x99s have a look at it,\xe2\x80\x99 said the suspicious chief. Riah handed it to\r\nhim. \xe2\x80\x98How much for this now?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Two precious silver shillings,\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Wren.\r\n\r\nRiah confirmed her with two nods, as Fledgeby looked to him. A nod for\r\neach shilling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby, poking into the contents of the basket with his\r\nforefinger, \xe2\x80\x98the price is not so bad. You have got good measure, Miss\r\nWhat-is-it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Try Jenny,\xe2\x80\x99 suggested that young lady with great calmness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have got good measure, Miss Jenny; but the price is not so\r\nbad.--And you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby, turning to the other visitor, \xe2\x80\x98do you buy\r\nanything here, miss?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nor sell anything neither, miss?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLooking askew at the questioner, Jenny stole her hand up to her\r\nfriend\xe2\x80\x99s, and drew her friend down, so that she bent beside her on her\r\nknee.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We are thankful to come here for rest, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Jenny. \xe2\x80\x98You see, you\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t know what the rest of this place is to us; does he, Lizzie? It\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nthe quiet, and the air.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The quiet!\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Fledgeby, with a contemptuous turn of his head\r\ntowards the City\xe2\x80\x99s roar. \xe2\x80\x98And the air!\xe2\x80\x99 with a \xe2\x80\x98Poof!\xe2\x80\x99 at the smoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah!\xe2\x80\x99 said Jenny. \xe2\x80\x98But it\xe2\x80\x99s so high. And you see the clouds rushing\r\non above the narrow streets, not minding them, and you see the golden\r\narrows pointing at the mountains in the sky from which the wind comes,\r\nand you feel as if you were dead.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe little creature looked above her, holding up her slight transparent\r\nhand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How do you feel when you are dead?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Fledgeby, much perplexed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, so tranquil!\xe2\x80\x99 cried the little creature, smiling. \xe2\x80\x98Oh, so peaceful\r\nand so thankful! And you hear the people who are alive, crying, and\r\nworking, and calling to one another down in the close dark streets, and\r\nyou seem to pity them so! And such a chain has fallen from you, and such\r\na strange good sorrowful happiness comes upon you!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHer eyes fell on the old man, who, with his hands folded, quietly looked\r\non.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why it was only just now,\xe2\x80\x99 said the little creature, pointing at him,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98that I fancied I saw him come out of his grave! He toiled out at\r\nthat low door so bent and worn, and then he took his breath and stood\r\nupright, and looked all round him at the sky, and the wind blew upon\r\nhim, and his life down in the dark was over!--Till he was called back\r\nto life,\xe2\x80\x99 she added, looking round at Fledgeby with that lower look of\r\nsharpness. \xe2\x80\x98Why did you call him back?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He was long enough coming, anyhow,\xe2\x80\x99 grumbled Fledgeby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But you are not dead, you know,\xe2\x80\x99 said Jenny Wren. \xe2\x80\x98Get down to life!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Fledgeby seemed to think it rather a good suggestion, and with a nod\r\nturned round. As Riah followed to attend him down the stairs, the little\r\ncreature called out to the Jew in a silvery tone, \xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t be long gone.\r\nCome back, and be dead!\xe2\x80\x99 And still as they went down they heard the\r\nlittle sweet voice, more and more faintly, half calling and half\r\nsinging, \xe2\x80\x98Come back and be dead, Come back and be dead!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWhen they got down into the entry, Fledgeby, pausing under the shadow of\r\nthe broad old hat, and mechanically poising the staff, said to the old\r\nman:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s a handsome girl, that one in her senses.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And as good as handsome,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Riah.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98At all events,\xe2\x80\x99 observed Fledgeby, with a dry whistle, \xe2\x80\x98I hope she\r\nain\xe2\x80\x99t bad enough to put any chap up to the fastenings, and get the\r\npremises broken open. You look out. Keep your weather eye awake and\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t make any more acquaintances, however handsome. Of course you\r\nalways keep my name to yourself?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir, assuredly I do.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If they ask it, say it\xe2\x80\x99s Pubsey, or say it\xe2\x80\x99s Co, or say it\xe2\x80\x99s anything\r\nyou like, but what it is.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHis grateful servant--in whose race gratitude is deep, strong, and\r\nenduring--bowed his head, and actually did now put the hem of his coat\r\nto his lips: though so lightly that the wearer knew nothing of it.\r\n\r\nThus, Fascination Fledgeby went his way, exulting in the artful\r\ncleverness with which he had turned his thumb down on a Jew, and the old\r\nman went his different way up-stairs. As he mounted, the call or song\r\nbegan to sound in his ears again, and, looking above, he saw the face\r\nof the little creature looking down out of a Glory of her long bright\r\nradiant hair, and musically repeating to him, like a vision:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come up and be dead! Come up and be dead!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 6\r\n\r\nA RIDDLE WITHOUT AN ANSWER\r\n\r\n\r\nAgain Mr Mortimer Lightwood and Mr Eugene Wrayburn sat together in the\r\nTemple. This evening, however, they were not together in the place of\r\nbusiness of the eminent solicitor, but in another dismal set of\r\nchambers facing it on the same second-floor; on whose dungeon-like black\r\nouter-door appeared the legend:\r\n\r\n\t\tPRIVATE\r\n\r\n\t\tMR EUGENE WRAYBURN\r\n\r\n\t\tMR MORTIMER LIGHTWOOD\r\n\r\n\t\t(Mr Lightwood\xe2\x80\x99s Offices opposite.)\r\n\r\nAppearances indicated that this establishment was a very recent\r\ninstitution. The white letters of the inscription were extremely white\r\nand extremely strong to the sense of smell, the complexion of the\r\ntables and chairs was (like Lady Tippins\xe2\x80\x99s) a little too blooming to\r\nbe believed in, and the carpets and floorcloth seemed to rush at the\r\nbeholder\xe2\x80\x99s face in the unusual prominency of their patterns. But the\r\nTemple, accustomed to tone down both the still life and the human life\r\nthat has much to do with it, would soon get the better of all that.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well!\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, on one side of the fire, \xe2\x80\x98I feel tolerably\r\ncomfortable. I hope the upholsterer may do the same.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t he?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Lightwood, from the other side of the fire.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To be sure,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued Eugene, reflecting, \xe2\x80\x98he is not in the secret of\r\nour pecuniary affairs, so perhaps he may be in an easy frame of mind.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We shall pay him,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mortimer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Shall we, really?\xe2\x80\x99 returned Eugene, indolently surprised. \xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nsay so!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I mean to pay him, Eugene, for my part,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mortimer, in a slightly\r\ninjured tone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! I mean to pay him too,\xe2\x80\x99 retorted Eugene. \xe2\x80\x98But then I mean so much\r\nthat I--that I don\xe2\x80\x99t mean.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t mean?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So much that I only mean and shall always only mean and nothing more,\r\nmy dear Mortimer. It\xe2\x80\x99s the same thing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHis friend, lying back in his easy chair, watched him lying back in his\r\neasy chair, as he stretched out his legs on the hearth-rug, and said,\r\nwith the amused look that Eugene Wrayburn could always awaken in him\r\nwithout seeming to try or care:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Anyhow, your vagaries have increased the bill.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Calls the domestic virtues vagaries!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Eugene, raising his\r\neyes to the ceiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This very complete little kitchen of ours,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mortimer, \xe2\x80\x98in which\r\nnothing will ever be cooked--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear, dear Mortimer,\xe2\x80\x99 returned his friend, lazily lifting his head\r\na little to look at him, \xe2\x80\x98how often have I pointed out to you that its\r\nmoral influence is the important thing?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Its moral influence on this fellow!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Lightwood, laughing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do me the favour,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, getting out of his chair with much\r\ngravity, \xe2\x80\x98to come and inspect that feature of our establishment which\r\nyou rashly disparage.\xe2\x80\x99 With that, taking up a candle, he conducted\r\nhis chum into the fourth room of the set of chambers--a little narrow\r\nroom--which was very completely and neatly fitted as a kitchen. \xe2\x80\x98See!\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Eugene, \xe2\x80\x98miniature flour-barrel, rolling-pin, spice-box, shelf of\r\nbrown jars, chopping-board, coffee-mill, dresser elegantly furnished\r\nwith crockery, saucepans and pans, roasting jack, a charming kettle, an\r\narmoury of dish-covers. The moral influence of these objects, in forming\r\nthe domestic virtues, may have an immense influence upon me; not upon\r\nyou, for you are a hopeless case, but upon me. In fact, I have an idea\r\nthat I feel the domestic virtues already forming. Do me the favour to\r\nstep into my bedroom. Secretaire, you see, and abstruse set of solid\r\nmahogany pigeon-holes, one for every letter of the alphabet. To what use\r\ndo I devote them? I receive a bill--say from Jones. I docket it neatly\r\nat the secretaire, JONES, and I put it into pigeonhole J. It\xe2\x80\x99s the next\r\nthing to a receipt and is quite as satisfactory to ME. And I very much\r\nwish, Mortimer,\xe2\x80\x99 sitting on his bed, with the air of a philosopher\r\nlecturing a disciple, \xe2\x80\x98that my example might induce YOU to cultivate\r\nhabits of punctuality and method; and, by means of the moral influences\r\nwith which I have surrounded you, to encourage the formation of the\r\ndomestic virtues.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMortimer laughed again, with his usual commentaries of \xe2\x80\x98How CAN you be\r\nso ridiculous, Eugene!\xe2\x80\x99 and \xe2\x80\x98What an absurd fellow you are!\xe2\x80\x99 but when\r\nhis laugh was out, there was something serious, if not anxious, in his\r\nface. Despite that pernicious assumption of lassitude and indifference,\r\nwhich had become his second nature, he was strongly attached to his\r\nfriend. He had founded himself upon Eugene when they were yet boys at\r\nschool; and at this hour imitated him no less, admired him no less,\r\nloved him no less, than in those departed days.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Eugene,\xe2\x80\x99 said he, \xe2\x80\x98if I could find you in earnest for a minute, I would\r\ntry to say an earnest word to you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98An earnest word?\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Eugene. \xe2\x80\x98The moral influences are beginning\r\nto work. Say on.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, I will,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the other, \xe2\x80\x98though you are not earnest yet.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In this desire for earnestness,\xe2\x80\x99 murmured Eugene, with the air of one\r\nwho was meditating deeply, \xe2\x80\x98I trace the happy influences of the little\r\nflour-barrel and the coffee-mill. Gratifying.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Eugene,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed Mortimer, disregarding the light interruption, and\r\nlaying a hand upon Eugene\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder, as he, Mortimer, stood before him\r\nseated on his bed, \xe2\x80\x98you are withholding something from me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nEugene looked at him, but said nothing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98All this past summer, you have been withholding something from me.\r\nBefore we entered on our boating vacation, you were as bent upon it as I\r\nhave seen you upon anything since we first rowed together. But you cared\r\nvery little for it when it came, often found it a tie and a drag upon\r\nyou, and were constantly away. Now it was well enough half-a-dozen\r\ntimes, a dozen times, twenty times, to say to me in your own odd manner,\r\nwhich I know so well and like so much, that your disappearances were\r\nprecautions against our boring one another; but of course after a short\r\nwhile I began to know that they covered something. I don\xe2\x80\x99t ask what it\r\nis, as you have not told me; but the fact is so. Say, is it not?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I give you my word of honour, Mortimer,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Eugene, after a\r\nserious pause of a few moments, \xe2\x80\x98that I don\xe2\x80\x99t know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t know, Eugene?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Upon my soul, don\xe2\x80\x99t know. I know less about myself than about most\r\npeople in the world, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have some design in your mind?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have I? I don\xe2\x80\x99t think I have.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98At any rate, you have some subject of interest there which used not to\r\nbe there?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I really can\xe2\x80\x99t say,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Eugene, shaking his head blankly, after\r\npausing again to reconsider. \xe2\x80\x98At times I have thought yes; at other\r\ntimes I have thought no. Now, I have been inclined to pursue such a\r\nsubject; now I have felt that it was absurd, and that it tired and\r\nembarrassed me. Absolutely, I can\xe2\x80\x99t say. Frankly and faithfully, I would\r\nif I could.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSo replying, he clapped a hand, in his turn, on his friend\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder,\r\nas he rose from his seat upon the bed, and said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You must take your friend as he is. You know what I am, my dear\r\nMortimer. You know how dreadfully susceptible I am to boredom. You know\r\nthat when I became enough of a man to find myself an embodied conundrum,\r\nI bored myself to the last degree by trying to find out what I meant.\r\nYou know that at length I gave it up, and declined to guess any more.\r\nThen how can I possibly give you the answer that I have not discovered?\r\nThe old nursery form runs, \xe2\x80\x9cRiddle-me-riddle-me-ree, p\xe2\x80\x99raps you can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ntell me what this may be?\xe2\x80\x9d My reply runs, \xe2\x80\x9cNo. Upon my life, I can\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSo much of what was fantastically true to his own knowledge of this\r\nutterly careless Eugene, mingled with the answer, that Mortimer could\r\nnot receive it as a mere evasion. Besides, it was given with an engaging\r\nair of openness, and of special exemption of the one friend he valued,\r\nfrom his reckless indifference.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come, dear boy!\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene. \xe2\x80\x98Let us try the effect of smoking. If it\r\nenlightens me at all on this question, I will impart unreservedly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey returned to the room they had come from, and, finding it heated,\r\nopened a window. Having lighted their cigars, they leaned out of this\r\nwindow, smoking, and looking down at the moonlight, as it shone into the\r\ncourt below.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No enlightenment,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed Eugene, after certain minutes of silence. \xe2\x80\x98I\r\nfeel sincerely apologetic, my dear Mortimer, but nothing comes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If nothing comes,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mortimer, \xe2\x80\x98nothing can come from it. So\r\nI shall hope that this may hold good throughout, and that there may be\r\nnothing on foot. Nothing injurious to you, Eugene, or--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nEugene stayed him for a moment with his hand on his arm, while he took a\r\npiece of earth from an old flowerpot on the window-sill and dexterously\r\nshot it at a little point of light opposite; having done which to his\r\nsatisfaction, he said, \xe2\x80\x98Or?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Or injurious to any one else.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, taking another little piece of earth, and shooting\r\nit with great precision at the former mark, \xe2\x80\x98how injurious to any one\r\nelse?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, taking, as he said the word, another shot, \xe2\x80\x98to whom\r\nelse?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nChecking himself with another piece of earth in his hand, Eugene looked\r\nat his friend inquiringly and a little suspiciously. There was no\r\nconcealed or half-expressed meaning in his face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Two belated wanderers in the mazes of the law,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, attracted\r\nby the sound of footsteps, and glancing down as he spoke, \xe2\x80\x98stray into\r\nthe court. They examine the door-posts of number one, seeking the name\r\nthey want. Not finding it at number one, they come to number two. On the\r\nhat of wanderer number two, the shorter one, I drop this pellet. Hitting\r\nhim on the hat, I smoke serenely, and become absorbed in contemplation\r\nof the sky.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBoth the wanderers looked up towards the window; but, after\r\ninterchanging a mutter or two, soon applied themselves to the door-posts\r\nbelow. There they seemed to discover what they wanted, for they\r\ndisappeared from view by entering at the doorway. \xe2\x80\x98When they emerge,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Eugene, \xe2\x80\x98you shall see me bring them both down\xe2\x80\x99; and so prepared\r\ntwo pellets for the purpose.\r\n\r\nHe had not reckoned on their seeking his name, or Lightwood\xe2\x80\x99s. But\r\neither the one or the other would seem to be in question, for now there\r\ncame a knock at the door. \xe2\x80\x98I am on duty to-night,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mortimer, \xe2\x80\x98stay\r\nyou where you are, Eugene.\xe2\x80\x99 Requiring no persuasion, he stayed there,\r\nsmoking quietly, and not at all curious to know who knocked, until\r\nMortimer spoke to him from within the room, and touched him. Then,\r\ndrawing in his head, he found the visitors to be young Charley Hexam\r\nand the schoolmaster; both standing facing him, and both recognized at a\r\nglance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You recollect this young fellow, Eugene?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mortimer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Let me look at him,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Wrayburn, coolly. \xe2\x80\x98Oh, yes, yes. I\r\nrecollect him!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe had not been about to repeat that former action of taking him by the\r\nchin, but the boy had suspected him of it, and had thrown up his arm\r\nwith an angry start. Laughingly, Wrayburn looked to Lightwood for an\r\nexplanation of this odd visit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He says he has something to say.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Surely it must be to you, Mortimer.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So I thought, but he says no. He says it is to you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, I do say so,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed the boy. \xe2\x80\x98And I mean to say what I want\r\nto say, too, Mr Eugene Wrayburn!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPassing him with his eyes as if there were nothing where he stood,\r\nEugene looked on to Bradley Headstone. With consummate indolence, he\r\nturned to Mortimer, inquiring: \xe2\x80\x98And who may this other person be?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am Charles Hexam\xe2\x80\x99s friend,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bradley; \xe2\x80\x98I am Charles Hexam\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nschoolmaster.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My good sir, you should teach your pupils better manners,\xe2\x80\x99 returned\r\nEugene.\r\n\r\nComposedly smoking, he leaned an elbow on the chimneypiece, at the side\r\nof the fire, and looked at the schoolmaster. It was a cruel look, in its\r\ncold disdain of him, as a creature of no worth. The schoolmaster looked\r\nat him, and that, too, was a cruel look, though of the different kind,\r\nthat it had a raging jealousy and fiery wrath in it.\r\n\r\nVery remarkably, neither Eugene Wrayburn nor Bradley Headstone looked at\r\nall at the boy. Through the ensuing dialogue, those two, no matter\r\nwho spoke, or whom was addressed, looked at each other. There was some\r\nsecret, sure perception between them, which set them against one another\r\nin all ways.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In some high respects, Mr Eugene Wrayburn,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bradley, answering\r\nhim with pale and quivering lips, \xe2\x80\x98the natural feelings of my pupils are\r\nstronger than my teaching.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In most respects, I dare say,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Eugene, enjoying his cigar,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98though whether high or low is of no importance. You have my name very\r\ncorrectly. Pray what is yours?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It cannot concern you much to know, but--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98True,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Eugene, striking sharply and cutting him short at his\r\nmistake, \xe2\x80\x98it does not concern me at all to know. I can say Schoolmaster,\r\nwhich is a most respectable title. You are right, Schoolmaster.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt was not the dullest part of this goad in its galling of Bradley\r\nHeadstone, that he had made it himself in a moment of incautious anger.\r\nHe tried to set his lips so as to prevent their quivering, but they\r\nquivered fast.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Eugene Wrayburn,\xe2\x80\x99 said the boy, \xe2\x80\x98I want a word with you. I have\r\nwanted it so much, that we have looked out your address in the book, and\r\nwe have been to your office, and we have come from your office here.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have given yourself much trouble, Schoolmaster,\xe2\x80\x99 observed\r\nEugene, blowing the feathery ash from his cigar. \xe2\x80\x98I hope it may prove\r\nremunerative.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And I am glad to speak,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued the boy, \xe2\x80\x98in presence of Mr Lightwood,\r\nbecause it was through Mr Lightwood that you ever saw my sister.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nFor a mere moment, Wrayburn turned his eyes aside from the schoolmaster\r\nto note the effect of the last word on Mortimer, who, standing on the\r\nopposite side of the fire, as soon as the word was spoken, turned his\r\nface towards the fire and looked down into it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Similarly, it was through Mr Lightwood that you ever saw her again, for\r\nyou were with him on the night when my father was found, and so I found\r\nyou with her on the next day. Since then, you have seen my sister often.\r\nYou have seen my sister oftener and oftener. And I want to know why?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Was this worth while, Schoolmaster?\xe2\x80\x99 murmured Eugene, with the air of\r\na disinterested adviser. \xe2\x80\x98So much trouble for nothing? You should know\r\nbest, but I think not.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know, Mr Wrayburn,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Bradley, with his passion rising,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98why you address me--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you? said Eugene. \xe2\x80\x98Then I won\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe said it so tauntingly in his perfect placidity, that the respectable\r\nright-hand clutching the respectable hair-guard of the respectable watch\r\ncould have wound it round his throat and strangled him with it. Not\r\nanother word did Eugene deem it worth while to utter, but stood leaning\r\nhis head upon his hand, smoking, and looking imperturbably at the\r\nchafing Bradley Headstone with his clutching right-hand, until Bradley\r\nwas wellnigh mad.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Wrayburn,\xe2\x80\x99 proceeded the boy, \xe2\x80\x98we not only know this that I have\r\ncharged upon you, but we know more. It has not yet come to my sister\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nknowledge that we have found it out, but we have. We had a plan, Mr\r\nHeadstone and I, for my sister\xe2\x80\x99s education, and for its being advised\r\nand overlooked by Mr Headstone, who is a much more competent authority,\r\nwhatever you may pretend to think, as you smoke, than you could produce,\r\nif you tried. Then, what do we find? What do we find, Mr Lightwood? Why,\r\nwe find that my sister is already being taught, without our knowing\r\nit. We find that while my sister gives an unwilling and cold ear to our\r\nschemes for her advantage--I, her brother, and Mr Headstone, the most\r\ncompetent authority, as his certificates would easily prove, that could\r\nbe produced--she is wilfully and willingly profiting by other schemes.\r\nAy, and taking pains, too, for I know what such pains are. And so does\r\nMr Headstone! Well! Somebody pays for this, is a thought that naturally\r\noccurs to us; who pays? We apply ourselves to find out, Mr Lightwood,\r\nand we find that your friend, this Mr Eugene Wrayburn, here, pays. Then\r\nI ask him what right has he to do it, and what does he mean by it, and\r\nhow comes he to be taking such a liberty without my consent, when I\r\nam raising myself in the scale of society by my own exertions and Mr\r\nHeadstone\xe2\x80\x99s aid, and have no right to have any darkness cast upon my\r\nprospects, or any imputation upon my respectability, through my sister?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe boyish weakness of this speech, combined with its great selfishness,\r\nmade it a poor one indeed. And yet Bradley Headstone, used to the little\r\naudience of a school, and unused to the larger ways of men, showed a\r\nkind of exultation in it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now I tell Mr Eugene Wrayburn,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued the boy, forced into the use\r\nof the third person by the hopelessness of addressing him in the first,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98that I object to his having any acquaintance at all with my sister, and\r\nthat I request him to drop it altogether. He is not to take it into his\r\nhead that I am afraid of my sister\xe2\x80\x99s caring for HIM--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n(As the boy sneered, the Master sneered, and Eugene blew off the\r\nfeathery ash again.)\r\n\r\n--\xe2\x80\x98But I object to it, and that\xe2\x80\x99s enough. I am more important to my\r\nsister than he thinks. As I raise myself, I intend to raise her;\r\nshe knows that, and she has to look to me for her prospects. Now I\r\nunderstand all this very well, and so does Mr Headstone. My sister is an\r\nexcellent girl, but she has some romantic notions; not about such things\r\nas your Mr Eugene Wrayburns, but about the death of my father and other\r\nmatters of that sort. Mr Wrayburn encourages those notions to make\r\nhimself of importance, and so she thinks she ought to be grateful to\r\nhim, and perhaps even likes to be. Now I don\xe2\x80\x99t choose her to be grateful\r\nto him, or to be grateful to anybody but me, except Mr Headstone. And\r\nI tell Mr Wrayburn that if he don\xe2\x80\x99t take heed of what I say, it will be\r\nworse for her. Let him turn that over in his memory, and make sure of\r\nit. Worse for her!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nA pause ensued, in which the schoolmaster looked very awkward.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98May I suggest, Schoolmaster,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, removing his fast-waning\r\ncigar from his lips to glance at it, \xe2\x80\x98that you can now take your pupil\r\naway.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And Mr Lightwood,\xe2\x80\x99 added the boy, with a burning face, under the\r\nflaming aggravation of getting no sort of answer or attention, \xe2\x80\x98I hope\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ll take notice of what I have said to your friend, and of what\r\nyour friend has heard me say, word by word, whatever he pretends to the\r\ncontrary. You are bound to take notice of it, Mr Lightwood, for, as I\r\nhave already mentioned, you first brought your friend into my sister\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncompany, and but for you we never should have seen him. Lord knows none\r\nof us ever wanted him, any more than any of us will ever miss him. Now\r\nMr Headstone, as Mr Eugene Wrayburn has been obliged to hear what I had\r\nto say, and couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help himself, and as I have said it out to the last\r\nword, we have done all we wanted to do, and may go.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Go down-stairs, and leave me a moment, Hexam,\xe2\x80\x99 he returned. The boy\r\ncomplying with an indignant look and as much noise as he could make,\r\nswung out of the room; and Lightwood went to the window, and leaned\r\nthere, looking out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You think me of no more value than the dirt under your feet,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nBradley to Eugene, speaking in a carefully weighed and measured tone, or\r\nhe could not have spoken at all.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I assure you, Schoolmaster,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Eugene, \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t think about you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s not true,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the other; \xe2\x80\x98you know better.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s coarse,\xe2\x80\x99 Eugene retorted; \xe2\x80\x98but you DON\xe2\x80\x99T know better.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Wrayburn, at least I know very well that it would be idle to set\r\nmyself against you in insolent words or overbearing manners. That lad\r\nwho has just gone out could put you to shame in half-a-dozen branches of\r\nknowledge in half an hour, but you can throw him aside like an inferior.\r\nYou can do as much by me, I have no doubt, beforehand.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Possibly,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Eugene.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I am more than a lad,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bradley, with his clutching hand, \xe2\x80\x98and\r\nI WILL be heard, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As a schoolmaster,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, \xe2\x80\x98you are always being heard. That\r\nought to content you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But it does not content me,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the other, white with passion. \xe2\x80\x98Do\r\nyou suppose that a man, in forming himself for the duties I discharge,\r\nand in watching and repressing himself daily to discharge them well,\r\ndismisses a man\xe2\x80\x99s nature?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, \xe2\x80\x98judging from what I see as I look at you,\r\nto be rather too passionate for a good schoolmaster.\xe2\x80\x99 As he spoke, he\r\ntossed away the end of his cigar.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Passionate with you, sir, I admit I am. Passionate with you, sir, I\r\nrespect myself for being. But I have not Devils for my pupils.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98For your Teachers, I should rather say,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Eugene.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Wrayburn.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Schoolmaster.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir, my name is Bradley Headstone.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As you justly said, my good sir, your name cannot concern me. Now, what\r\nmore?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This more. And let me remind you that the door is standing open, and your\r\nyoung friend waiting for you on the stairs.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When I accompanied that youth here, sir, I did so with the purpose of\r\nadding, as a man whom you should not be permitted to put aside, in case\r\nyou put him aside as a boy, that his instinct is correct and right.\xe2\x80\x99\r\nThus Bradley Headstone, with great effort and difficulty.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is that all?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Eugene.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said the other, flushed and fierce. \xe2\x80\x98I strongly support him\r\nin his disapproval of your visits to his sister, and in his objection to\r\nyour officiousness--and worse--in what you have taken upon yourself to\r\ndo for her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is THAT all?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Eugene.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, sir. I determined to tell you that you are not justified in these\r\nproceedings, and that they are injurious to his sister.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you her schoolmaster as well as her brother\xe2\x80\x99s?--Or perhaps you\r\nwould like to be?\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene.\r\n\r\nIt was a stab that the blood followed, in its rush to Bradley\r\nHeadstone\xe2\x80\x99s face, as swiftly as if it had been dealt with a dagger.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you mean by that?\xe2\x80\x99 was as much as he could utter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A natural ambition enough,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, coolly. \xe2\x80\x98Far be it from me\r\nto say otherwise. The sister who is something too much upon your lips,\r\nperhaps--is so very different from all the associations to which she had\r\nbeen used, and from all the low obscure people about her, that it is a\r\nvery natural ambition.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you throw my obscurity in my teeth, Mr Wrayburn?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That can hardly be, for I know nothing concerning it, Schoolmaster, and\r\nseek to know nothing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You reproach me with my origin,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bradley Headstone; \xe2\x80\x98you cast\r\ninsinuations at my bringing-up. But I tell you, sir, I have worked my\r\nway onward, out of both and in spite of both, and have a right to be\r\nconsidered a better man than you, with better reasons for being proud.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How I can reproach you with what is not within my knowledge, or how\r\nI can cast stones that were never in my hand, is a problem for the\r\ningenuity of a schoolmaster to prove,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Eugene. \xe2\x80\x98Is THAT all?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, sir. If you suppose that boy--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who really will be tired of waiting,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, politely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If you suppose that boy to be friendless, Mr Wrayburn, you deceive\r\nyourself. I am his friend, and you shall find me so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And you will find HIM on the stairs,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Eugene.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You may have promised yourself, sir, that you could do what you\r\nchose here, because you had to deal with a mere boy, inexperienced,\r\nfriendless, and unassisted. But I give you warning that this mean\r\ncalculation is wrong. You have to do with a man also. You have to do\r\nwith me. I will support him, and, if need be, require reparation for\r\nhim. My hand and heart are in this cause, and are open to him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And--quite a coincidence--the door is open,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Eugene.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I scorn your shifty evasions, and I scorn you,\xe2\x80\x99 said the schoolmaster.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In the meanness of your nature you revile me with the meanness of my\r\nbirth. I hold you in contempt for it. But if you don\xe2\x80\x99t profit by this\r\nvisit, and act accordingly, you will find me as bitterly in earnest\r\nagainst you as I could be if I deemed you worth a second thought on my\r\nown account.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith a consciously bad grace and stiff manner, as Wrayburn looked so\r\neasily and calmly on, he went out with these words, and the heavy door\r\nclosed like a furnace-door upon his red and white heats of rage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A curious monomaniac,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene. \xe2\x80\x98The man seems to believe that\r\neverybody was acquainted with his mother!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMortimer Lightwood being still at the window, to which he had in\r\ndelicacy withdrawn, Eugene called to him, and he fell to slowly pacing\r\nthe room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear fellow,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, as he lighted another cigar, \xe2\x80\x98I fear my\r\nunexpected visitors have been troublesome. If as a set-off (excuse the\r\nlegal phrase from a barrister-at-law) you would like to ask Tippins to\r\ntea, I pledge myself to make love to her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Eugene, Eugene, Eugene,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mortimer, still pacing the room, \xe2\x80\x98I am\r\nsorry for this. And to think that I have been so blind!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How blind, dear boy?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired his unmoved friend.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What were your words that night at the river-side public-house?\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nLightwood, stopping. \xe2\x80\x98What was it that you asked me? Did I feel like a\r\ndark combination of traitor and pickpocket when I thought of that girl?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I seem to remember the expression,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How do YOU feel when you think of her just now?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHis friend made no direct reply, but observed, after a few whiffs of his\r\ncigar, \xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t mistake the situation. There is no better girl in all this\r\nLondon than Lizzie Hexam. There is no better among my people at home; no\r\nbetter among your people.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Granted. What follows?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, looking after him dubiously as he paced away to\r\nthe other end of the room, \xe2\x80\x98you put me again upon guessing the riddle\r\nthat I have given up.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Eugene, do you design to capture and desert this girl?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear fellow, no.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you design to marry her?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear fellow, no.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you design to pursue her?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear fellow, I don\xe2\x80\x99t design anything. I have no design whatever.\r\nI am incapable of designs. If I conceived a design, I should speedily\r\nabandon it, exhausted by the operation.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh Eugene, Eugene!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear Mortimer, not that tone of melancholy reproach, I entreat. What\r\ncan I do more than tell you all I know, and acknowledge my ignorance\r\nof all I don\xe2\x80\x99t know! How does that little old song go, which, under\r\npretence of being cheerful, is by far the most lugubrious I ever heard\r\nin my life?\r\n\r\n     \xe2\x80\x9cAway with melancholy,\r\n     Nor doleful changes ring\r\n     On life and human folly,\r\n     But merrily merrily sing\r\n                              Fal la!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDon\xe2\x80\x99t let us sing Fal la, my dear Mortimer (which is comparatively\r\nunmeaning), but let us sing that we give up guessing the riddle\r\naltogether.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you in communication with this girl, Eugene, and is what these\r\npeople say true?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I concede both admissions to my honourable and learned friend.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then what is to come of it? What are you doing? Where are you going?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear Mortimer, one would think the schoolmaster had left behind him\r\na catechizing infection. You are ruffled by the want of another cigar.\r\nTake one of these, I entreat. Light it at mine, which is in perfect\r\norder. So! Now do me the justice to observe that I am doing all I can\r\ntowards self-improvement, and that you have a light thrown on those\r\nhousehold implements which, when you only saw them as in a glass darkly,\r\nyou were hastily--I must say hastily--inclined to depreciate. Sensible\r\nof my deficiencies, I have surrounded myself with moral influences\r\nexpressly meant to promote the formation of the domestic virtues.\r\nTo those influences, and to the improving society of my friend from\r\nboyhood, commend me with your best wishes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, Eugene!\xe2\x80\x99 said Lightwood, affectionately, now standing near him,\r\nso that they both stood in one little cloud of smoke; \xe2\x80\x98I would that you\r\nanswered my three questions! What is to come of it? What are you doing?\r\nWhere are you going?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And my dear Mortimer,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Eugene, lightly fanning away the smoke\r\nwith his hand for the better exposition of his frankness of face and\r\nmanner, \xe2\x80\x98believe me, I would answer them instantly if I could. But\r\nto enable me to do so, I must first have found out the troublesome\r\nconundrum long abandoned. Here it is. Eugene Wrayburn.\xe2\x80\x99 Tapping his\r\nforehead and breast. \xe2\x80\x98Riddle-me, riddle-me-ree, perhaps you can\xe2\x80\x99t tell\r\nme what this may be?--No, upon my life I can\xe2\x80\x99t. I give it up!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 7\r\n\r\nIN WHICH A FRIENDLY MOVE IS ORIGINATED\r\n\r\n\r\nThe arrangement between Mr Boffin and his literary man, Mr Silas Wegg,\r\nso far altered with the altered habits of Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s life, as that\r\nthe Roman Empire usually declined in the morning and in the eminently\r\naristocratic family mansion, rather than in the evening, as of yore,\r\nand in Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s Bower. There were occasions, however, when Mr Boffin,\r\nseeking a brief refuge from the blandishments of fashion, would present\r\nhimself at the Bower after dark, to anticipate the next sallying\r\nforth of Wegg, and would there, on the old settle, pursue the downward\r\nfortunes of those enervated and corrupted masters of the world who were\r\nby this time on their last legs. If Wegg had been worse paid for his\r\noffice, or better qualified to discharge it, he would have considered\r\nthese visits complimentary and agreeable; but, holding the position of\r\na handsomely-remunerated humbug, he resented them. This was quite\r\naccording to rule, for the incompetent servant, by whomsoever employed,\r\nis always against his employer. Even those born governors, noble and\r\nright honourable creatures, who have been the most imbecile in high\r\nplaces, have uniformly shown themselves the most opposed (sometimes in\r\nbelying distrust, sometimes in vapid insolence) to THEIR employer. What\r\nis in such wise true of the public master and servant, is equally true\r\nof the private master and servant all the world over.\r\n\r\nWhen Mr Silas Wegg did at last obtain free access to \xe2\x80\x98Our House\xe2\x80\x99, as he\r\nhad been wont to call the mansion outside which he had sat shelterless\r\nso long, and when he did at last find it in all particulars as different\r\nfrom his mental plans of it as according to the nature of things it\r\nwell could be, that far-seeing and far-reaching character, by way of\r\nasserting himself and making out a case for compensation, affected to\r\nfall into a melancholy strain of musing over the mournful past; as if\r\nthe house and he had had a fall in life together.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And this, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 Silas would say to his patron, sadly nodding his head\r\nand musing, \xe2\x80\x98was once Our House! This, sir, is the building from which I\r\nhave so often seen those great creatures, Miss Elizabeth, Master\r\nGeorge, Aunt Jane, and Uncle Parker\xe2\x80\x99--whose very names were of his own\r\ninventing--\xe2\x80\x98pass and repass! And has it come to this, indeed! Ah dear\r\nme, dear me!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSo tender were his lamentations, that the kindly Mr Boffin was quite\r\nsorry for him, and almost felt mistrustful that in buying the house he\r\nhad done him an irreparable injury.\r\n\r\nTwo or three diplomatic interviews, the result of great subtlety on Mr\r\nWegg\xe2\x80\x99s part, but assuming the mask of careless yielding to a fortuitous\r\ncombination of circumstances impelling him towards Clerkenwell, had\r\nenabled him to complete his bargain with Mr Venus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bring me round to the Bower,\xe2\x80\x99 said Silas, when the bargain was closed,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98next Saturday evening, and if a sociable glass of old Jamaikey warm\r\nshould meet your views, I am not the man to begrudge it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are aware of my being poor company, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr Venus, \xe2\x80\x98but be\r\nit so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt being so, here is Saturday evening come, and here is Mr Venus come,\r\nand ringing at the Bower-gate.\r\n\r\nMr Wegg opens the gate, descries a sort of brown paper truncheon under\r\nMr Venus\xe2\x80\x99s arm, and remarks, in a dry tone: \xe2\x80\x98Oh! I thought perhaps you\r\nmight have come in a cab.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, Mr Wegg,\xe2\x80\x99 replies Venus. \xe2\x80\x98I am not above a parcel.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Above a parcel! No!\xe2\x80\x99 says Wegg, with some dissatisfaction. But does not\r\nopenly growl, \xe2\x80\x98a certain sort of parcel might be above you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here is your purchase, Mr Wegg,\xe2\x80\x99 says Venus, politely handing it over,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98and I am glad to restore it to the source from whence it--flowed.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thankee,\xe2\x80\x99 says Wegg. \xe2\x80\x98Now this affair is concluded, I may mention to\r\nyou in a friendly way that I\xe2\x80\x99ve my doubts whether, if I had consulted a\r\nlawyer, you could have kept this article back from me. I only throw it\r\nout as a legal point.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you think so, Mr Wegg? I bought you in open contract.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You can\xe2\x80\x99t buy human flesh and blood in this country, sir; not alive,\r\nyou can\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99 says Wegg, shaking his head. \xe2\x80\x98Then query, bone?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As a legal point?\xe2\x80\x99 asks Venus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As a legal point.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am not competent to speak upon that, Mr Wegg,\xe2\x80\x99 says Venus, reddening\r\nand growing something louder; \xe2\x80\x98but upon a point of fact I think myself\r\ncompetent to speak; and as a point of fact I would have seen you--will\r\nyou allow me to say, further?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t say more than further, if I was you,\xe2\x80\x99 Mr Wegg suggests,\r\npacifically.\r\n\r\n--\xe2\x80\x98Before I\xe2\x80\x99d have given that packet into your hand without being paid\r\nmy price for it. I don\xe2\x80\x99t pretend to know how the point of law may stand,\r\nbut I\xe2\x80\x99m thoroughly confident upon the point of fact.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs Mr Venus is irritable (no doubt owing to his disappointment in love),\r\nand as it is not the cue of Mr Wegg to have him out of temper, the\r\nlatter gentleman soothingly remarks, \xe2\x80\x98I only put it as a little case; I\r\nonly put it ha\xe2\x80\x99porthetically.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then I\xe2\x80\x99d rather, Mr Wegg, you put it another time, penn\xe2\x80\x99orth-etically,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nis Mr Venus\xe2\x80\x99s retort, \xe2\x80\x98for I tell you candidly I don\xe2\x80\x99t like your little\r\ncases.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nArrived by this time in Mr Wegg\xe2\x80\x99s sitting-room, made bright on the\r\nchilly evening by gaslight and fire, Mr Venus softens and compliments\r\nhim on his abode; profiting by the occasion to remind Wegg that he\r\n(Venus) told him he had got into a good thing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Tolerable,\xe2\x80\x99 Wegg rejoins. \xe2\x80\x98But bear in mind, Mr Venus, that there\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nno gold without its alloy. Mix for yourself and take a seat in the\r\nchimbley-corner. Will you perform upon a pipe, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am but an indifferent performer, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 returns the other; \xe2\x80\x98but I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\naccompany you with a whiff or two at intervals.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSo, Mr Venus mixes, and Wegg mixes; and Mr Venus lights and puffs, and\r\nWegg lights and puffs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And there\xe2\x80\x99s alloy even in this metal of yours, Mr Wegg, you was\r\nremarking?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mystery,\xe2\x80\x99 returns Wegg. \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t like it, Mr Venus. I don\xe2\x80\x99t like to\r\nhave the life knocked out of former inhabitants of this house, in the\r\ngloomy dark, and not know who did it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Might you have any suspicions, Mr Wegg?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 returns that gentleman. \xe2\x80\x98I know who profits by it. But I\xe2\x80\x99ve no\r\nsuspicions.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHaving said which, Mr Wegg smokes and looks at the fire with a most\r\ndetermined expression of Charity; as if he had caught that cardinal\r\nvirtue by the skirts as she felt it her painful duty to depart from him,\r\nand held her by main force.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Similarly,\xe2\x80\x99 resumes Wegg, \xe2\x80\x98I have observations as I can offer upon\r\ncertain points and parties; but I make no objections, Mr Venus. Here\r\nis an immense fortune drops from the clouds upon a person that shall be\r\nnameless. Here is a weekly allowance, with a certain weight of coals,\r\ndrops from the clouds upon me. Which of us is the better man? Not the\r\nperson that shall be nameless. That\xe2\x80\x99s an observation of mine, but I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t make it an objection. I take my allowance and my certain weight of\r\ncoals. He takes his fortune. That\xe2\x80\x99s the way it works.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It would be a good thing for me, if I could see things in the calm\r\nlight you do, Mr Wegg.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Again look here,\xe2\x80\x99 pursues Silas, with an oratorical flourish of his\r\npipe and his wooden leg: the latter having an undignified tendency\r\nto tilt him back in his chair; \xe2\x80\x98here\xe2\x80\x99s another observation, Mr Venus,\r\nunaccompanied with an objection. Him that shall be nameless is liable to\r\nbe talked over. He gets talked over. Him that shall be nameless, having\r\nme at his right hand, naturally looking to be promoted higher, and you\r\nmay perhaps say meriting to be promoted higher--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n(Mr Venus murmurs that he does say so.)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98--Him that shall be nameless, under such circumstances passes me by,\r\nand puts a talking-over stranger above my head. Which of us two is the\r\nbetter man? Which of us two can repeat most poetry? Which of us two has,\r\nin the service of him that shall be nameless, tackled the Romans, both\r\ncivil and military, till he has got as husky as if he\xe2\x80\x99d been weaned and\r\never since brought up on sawdust? Not the talking-over stranger. Yet the\r\nhouse is as free to him as if it was his, and he has his room, and is\r\nput upon a footing, and draws about a thousand a year. I am banished to\r\nthe Bower, to be found in it like a piece of furniture whenever wanted.\r\nMerit, therefore, don\xe2\x80\x99t win. That\xe2\x80\x99s the way it works. I observe it,\r\nbecause I can\xe2\x80\x99t help observing it, being accustomed to take a powerful\r\nsight of notice; but I don\xe2\x80\x99t object. Ever here before, Mr Venus?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not inside the gate, Mr Wegg.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99ve been as far as the gate then, Mr Venus?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, Mr Wegg, and peeped in from curiosity.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did you see anything?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing but the dust-yard.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Wegg rolls his eyes all round the room, in that ever unsatisfied\r\nquest of his, and then rolls his eyes all round Mr Venus; as if\r\nsuspicious of his having something about him to be found out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And yet, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 he pursues, \xe2\x80\x98being acquainted with old Mr Harmon, one\r\nwould have thought it might have been polite in you, too, to give him a\r\ncall. And you\xe2\x80\x99re naturally of a polite disposition, you are.\xe2\x80\x99 This last\r\nclause as a softening compliment to Mr Venus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is true, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replies Venus, winking his weak eyes, and running\r\nhis fingers through his dusty shock of hair, \xe2\x80\x98that I was so, before a\r\ncertain observation soured me. You understand to what I allude, Mr Wegg?\r\nTo a certain written statement respecting not wishing to be regarded in\r\na certain light. Since that, all is fled, save gall.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not all,\xe2\x80\x99 says Mr Wegg, in a tone of sentimental condolence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 returns Venus, \xe2\x80\x98all! The world may deem it harsh, but I\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nquite as soon pitch into my best friend as not. Indeed, I\xe2\x80\x99d sooner!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nInvoluntarily making a pass with his wooden leg to guard himself as Mr\r\nVenus springs up in the emphasis of this unsociable declaration, Mr Wegg\r\ntilts over on his back, chair and all, and is rescued by that harmless\r\nmisanthrope, in a disjointed state and ruefully rubbing his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, you lost your balance, Mr Wegg,\xe2\x80\x99 says Venus, handing him his pipe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And about time to do it,\xe2\x80\x99 grumbles Silas, \xe2\x80\x98when a man\xe2\x80\x99s visitors,\r\nwithout a word of notice, conduct themselves with the sudden wiciousness\r\nof Jacks-in-boxes! Don\xe2\x80\x99t come flying out of your chair like that, Mr\r\nVenus!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I ask your pardon, Mr Wegg. I am so soured.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, but hang it,\xe2\x80\x99 says Wegg argumentatively, \xe2\x80\x98a well-governed mind can\r\nbe soured sitting! And as to being regarded in lights, there\xe2\x80\x99s bumpey\r\nlights as well as bony. IN which,\xe2\x80\x99 again rubbing his head, \xe2\x80\x98I object to\r\nregard myself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll bear it in memory, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If you\xe2\x80\x99ll be so good.\xe2\x80\x99 Mr Wegg slowly subdues his ironical tone and his\r\nlingering irritation, and resumes his pipe. \xe2\x80\x98We were talking of old Mr\r\nHarmon being a friend of yours.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not a friend, Mr Wegg. Only known to speak to, and to have a little\r\ndeal with now and then. A very inquisitive character, Mr Wegg, regarding\r\nwhat was found in the dust. As inquisitive as secret.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! You found him secret?\xe2\x80\x99 returns Wegg, with a greedy relish.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He had always the look of it, and the manner of it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah!\xe2\x80\x99 with another roll of his eyes. \xe2\x80\x98As to what was found in the dust\r\nnow. Did you ever hear him mention how he found it, my dear friend?\r\nLiving on the mysterious premises, one would like to know. For instance,\r\nwhere he found things? Or, for instance, how he set about it? Whether\r\nhe began at the top of the mounds, or whether he began at the bottom.\r\nWhether he prodded\xe2\x80\x99; Mr Wegg\xe2\x80\x99s pantomime is skilful and expressive here;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98or whether he scooped? Should you say scooped, my dear Mr Venus; or\r\nshould you as a man--say prodded?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should say neither, Mr Wegg.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As a fellow-man, Mr Venus--mix again--why neither?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Because I suppose, sir, that what was found, was found in the sorting\r\nand sifting. All the mounds are sorted and sifted?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You shall see \xe2\x80\x98em and pass your opinion. Mix again.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nOn each occasion of his saying \xe2\x80\x98mix again\xe2\x80\x99, Mr Wegg, with a hop on\r\nhis wooden leg, hitches his chair a little nearer; more as if he were\r\nproposing that himself and Mr Venus should mix again, than that they\r\nshould replenish their glasses.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Living (as I said before) on the mysterious premises,\xe2\x80\x99 says Wegg when\r\nthe other has acted on his hospitable entreaty, \xe2\x80\x98one likes to know.\r\nWould you be inclined to say now--as a brother--that he ever hid things\r\nin the dust, as well as found \xe2\x80\x98em?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Wegg, on the whole I should say he might.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Wegg claps on his spectacles, and admiringly surveys Mr Venus from\r\nhead to foot.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As a mortal equally with myself, whose hand I take in mine for the\r\nfirst time this day, having unaccountably overlooked that act so full of\r\nboundless confidence binding a fellow-creetur TO a fellow creetur,\xe2\x80\x99 says\r\nWegg, holding Mr Venus\xe2\x80\x99s palm out, flat and ready for smiting, and now\r\nsmiting it; \xe2\x80\x98as such--and no other--for I scorn all lowlier ties betwixt\r\nmyself and the man walking with his face erect that alone I call my\r\nTwin--regarded and regarding in this trustful bond--what do you think he\r\nmight have hid?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is but a supposition, Mr Wegg.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As a Being with his hand upon his heart,\xe2\x80\x99 cries Wegg; and the\r\napostrophe is not the less impressive for the Being\xe2\x80\x99s hand being\r\nactually upon his rum and water; \xe2\x80\x98put your supposition into language,\r\nand bring it out, Mr Venus!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He was the species of old gentleman, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 slowly returns that\r\npractical anatomist, after drinking, \xe2\x80\x98that I should judge likely to\r\ntake such opportunities as this place offered, of stowing away money,\r\nvaluables, maybe papers.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As one that was ever an ornament to human life,\xe2\x80\x99 says Mr Wegg, again\r\nholding out Mr Venus\xe2\x80\x99s palm as if he were going to tell his fortune by\r\nchiromancy, and holding his own up ready for smiting it when the time\r\nshould come; \xe2\x80\x98as one that the poet might have had his eye on, in writing\r\nthe national naval words:\r\n\r\n     Helm a-weather, now lay her close,\r\n            Yard arm and yard arm she lies;\r\n     Again, cried I, Mr Venus, give her t\xe2\x80\x99other dose,\r\n            Man shrouds and grapple, sir, or she flies!\r\n\r\n--that is to say, regarded in the light of true British Oak, for such\r\nyou are explain, Mr Venus, the expression \xe2\x80\x9cpapers\xe2\x80\x9d!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Seeing that the old gentleman was generally cutting off some near\r\nrelation, or blocking out some natural affection,\xe2\x80\x99 Mr Venus rejoins, \xe2\x80\x98he\r\nmost likely made a good many wills and codicils.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe palm of Silas Wegg descends with a sounding smack upon the palm\r\nof Venus, and Wegg lavishly exclaims, \xe2\x80\x98Twin in opinion equally with\r\nfeeling! Mix a little more!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHaving now hitched his wooden leg and his chair close in front of Mr\r\nVenus, Mr Wegg rapidly mixes for both, gives his visitor his glass,\r\ntouches its rim with the rim of his own, puts his own to his lips, puts\r\nit down, and spreading his hands on his visitor\xe2\x80\x99s knees thus addresses\r\nhim:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Venus. It ain\xe2\x80\x99t that I object to being passed over for a stranger,\r\nthough I regard the stranger as a more than doubtful customer. It ain\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nfor the sake of making money, though money is ever welcome. It ain\xe2\x80\x99t for\r\nmyself, though I am not so haughty as to be above doing myself a good\r\nturn. It\xe2\x80\x99s for the cause of the right.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Venus, passively winking his weak eyes both at once, demands: \xe2\x80\x98What\r\nis, Mr Wegg?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The friendly move, sir, that I now propose. You see the move, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Till you have pointed it out, Mr Wegg, I can\xe2\x80\x99t say whether I do or\r\nnot.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If there IS anything to be found on these premises, let us find it\r\ntogether. Let us make the friendly move of agreeing to look for it\r\ntogether. Let us make the friendly move of agreeing to share the\r\nprofits of it equally betwixt us. In the cause of the right.\xe2\x80\x99 Thus Silas\r\nassuming a noble air.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then,\xe2\x80\x99 says Mr Venus, looking up, after meditating with his hair held\r\nin his hands, as if he could only fix his attention by fixing his head;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98if anything was to be unburied from under the dust, it would be kept a\r\nsecret by you and me? Would that be it, Mr Wegg?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That would depend upon what it was, Mr Venus. Say it was money, or\r\nplate, or jewellery, it would be as much ours as anybody else\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Venus rubs an eyebrow, interrogatively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In the cause of the right it would. Because it would be unknowingly\r\nsold with the mounds else, and the buyer would get what he was never\r\nmeant to have, and never bought. And what would that be, Mr Venus, but\r\nthe cause of the wrong?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Say it was papers,\xe2\x80\x99 Mr Venus propounds.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98According to what they contained we should offer to dispose of \xe2\x80\x98em to\r\nthe parties most interested,\xe2\x80\x99 replies Wegg, promptly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In the cause of the right, Mr Wegg?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Always so, Mr Venus. If the parties should use them in the cause of the\r\nwrong, that would be their act and deed. Mr Venus. I have an opinion of\r\nyou, sir, to which it is not easy to give mouth. Since I called upon you\r\nthat evening when you were, as I may say, floating your powerful mind in\r\ntea, I have felt that you required to be roused with an object. In this\r\nfriendly move, sir, you will have a glorious object to rouse you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Wegg then goes on to enlarge upon what throughout has been uppermost\r\nin his crafty mind:--the qualifications of Mr Venus for such a search.\r\nHe expatiates on Mr Venus\xe2\x80\x99s patient habits and delicate manipulation; on\r\nhis skill in piecing little things together; on his knowledge of various\r\ntissues and textures; on the likelihood of small indications leading him\r\non to the discovery of great concealments. \xe2\x80\x98While as to myself,\xe2\x80\x99 says\r\nWegg, \xe2\x80\x98I am not good at it. Whether I gave myself up to prodding,\r\nor whether I gave myself up to scooping, I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t do it with that\r\ndelicate touch so as not to show that I was disturbing the mounds.\r\nQuite different with YOU, going to work (as YOU would) in the light of\r\na fellow-man, holily pledged in a friendly move to his brother man.\xe2\x80\x99 Mr\r\nWegg next modestly remarks on the want of adaptation in a wooden leg\r\nto ladders and such like airy perches, and also hints at an inherent\r\ntendency in that timber fiction, when called into action for the\r\npurposes of a promenade on an ashey slope, to stick itself into the\r\nyielding foothold, and peg its owner to one spot. Then, leaving this\r\npart of the subject, he remarks on the special phenomenon that before\r\nhis installation in the Bower, it was from Mr Venus that he first heard\r\nof the legend of hidden wealth in the Mounds: \xe2\x80\x98which\xe2\x80\x99, he observes with\r\na vaguely pious air, \xe2\x80\x98was surely never meant for nothing.\xe2\x80\x99 Lastly,\r\nhe returns to the cause of the right, gloomily foreshadowing the\r\npossibility of something being unearthed to criminate Mr Boffin (of whom\r\nhe once more candidly admits it cannot be denied that he profits by a\r\nmurder), and anticipating his denunciation by the friendly movers to\r\navenging justice. And this, Mr Wegg expressly points out, not at all for\r\nthe sake of the reward--though it would be a want of principle not to\r\ntake it.\r\n\r\nTo all this, Mr Venus, with his shock of dusty hair cocked after the\r\nmanner of a terrier\xe2\x80\x99s ears, attends profoundly. When Mr Wegg, having\r\nfinished, opens his arms wide, as if to show Mr Venus how bare his\r\nbreast is, and then folds them pending a reply, Mr Venus winks at him\r\nwith both eyes some little time before speaking.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I see you have tried it by yourself, Mr Wegg,\xe2\x80\x99 he says when he does\r\nspeak. \xe2\x80\x98You have found out the difficulties by experience.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, it can hardly be said that I have tried it,\xe2\x80\x99 replies Wegg, a little\r\ndashed by the hint. \xe2\x80\x98I have just skimmed it. Skimmed it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And found nothing besides the difficulties?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWegg shakes his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I scarcely know what to say to this, Mr Wegg,\xe2\x80\x99 observes Venus, after\r\nruminating for a while.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Say yes,\xe2\x80\x99 Wegg naturally urges.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t soured, my answer would be no. But being soured, Mr Wegg,\r\nand driven to reckless madness and desperation, I suppose it\xe2\x80\x99s Yes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWegg joyfully reproduces the two glasses, repeats the ceremony of\r\nclinking their rims, and inwardly drinks with great heartiness to the\r\nhealth and success in life of the young lady who has reduced Mr Venus to\r\nhis present convenient state of mind.\r\n\r\nThe articles of the friendly move are then severally recited and agreed\r\nupon. They are but secrecy, fidelity, and perseverance. The Bower to\r\nbe always free of access to Mr Venus for his researches, and every\r\nprecaution to be taken against their attracting observation in the\r\nneighbourhood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s a footstep!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaims Venus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where?\xe2\x80\x99 cries Wegg, starting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Outside. St!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey are in the act of ratifying the treaty of friendly move, by shaking\r\nhands upon it. They softly break off, light their pipes which have gone\r\nout, and lean back in their chairs. No doubt, a footstep. It approaches\r\nthe window, and a hand taps at the glass. \xe2\x80\x98Come in!\xe2\x80\x99 calls Wegg; meaning\r\ncome round by the door. But the heavy old-fashioned sash is slowly\r\nraised, and a head slowly looks in out of the dark background of night.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pray is Mr Silas Wegg here? Oh! I see him!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe friendly movers might not have been quite at their ease, even\r\nthough the visitor had entered in the usual manner. But, leaning on the\r\nbreast-high window, and staring in out of the darkness, they find the\r\nvisitor extremely embarrassing. Especially Mr Venus: who removes his\r\npipe, draws back his head, and stares at the starer, as if it were his\r\nown Hindoo baby come to fetch him home.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good evening, Mr Wegg. The yard gate-lock should be looked to, if you\r\nplease; it don\xe2\x80\x99t catch.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is it Mr Rokesmith?\xe2\x80\x99 falters Wegg.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is Mr Rokesmith. Don\xe2\x80\x99t let me disturb you. I am not coming in. I\r\nhave only a message for you, which I undertook to deliver on my way home\r\nto my lodgings. I was in two minds about coming beyond the gate without\r\nringing: not knowing but you might have a dog about.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wish I had,\xe2\x80\x99 mutters Wegg, with his back turned as he rose from his\r\nchair. \xe2\x80\x98St! Hush! The talking-over stranger, Mr Venus.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is that any one I know?\xe2\x80\x99 inquires the staring Secretary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, Mr Rokesmith. Friend of mine. Passing the evening with me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh! I beg his pardon. Mr Boffin wishes you to know that he does not\r\nexpect you to stay at home any evening, on the chance of his coming. It\r\nhas occurred to him that he may, without intending it, have been a tie\r\nupon you. In future, if he should come without notice, he will take his\r\nchance of finding you, and it will be all the same to him if he does\r\nnot. I undertook to tell you on my way. That\xe2\x80\x99s all.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith that, and \xe2\x80\x98Good night,\xe2\x80\x99 the Secretary lowers the window, and\r\ndisappears. They listen, and hear his footsteps go back to the gate, and\r\nhear the gate close after him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And for that individual, Mr Venus,\xe2\x80\x99 remarks Wegg, when he is fully\r\ngone, \xe2\x80\x98I have been passed over! Let me ask you what you think of him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nApparently, Mr Venus does not know what to think of him, for he makes\r\nsundry efforts to reply, without delivering himself of any other\r\narticulate utterance than that he has \xe2\x80\x98a singular look\xe2\x80\x99.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A double look, you mean, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoins Wegg, playing bitterly upon the\r\nword. \xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s HIS look. Any amount of singular look for me, but not a\r\ndouble look! That\xe2\x80\x99s an under-handed mind, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you say there\xe2\x80\x99s something against him?\xe2\x80\x99 Venus asks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Something against him?\xe2\x80\x99 repeats Wegg. \xe2\x80\x98Something? What would the relief\r\nbe to my feelings--as a fellow-man--if I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the slave of truth, and\r\ndidn\xe2\x80\x99t feel myself compelled to answer, Everything!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSee into what wonderful maudlin refuges, featherless ostriches plunge\r\ntheir heads! It is such unspeakable moral compensation to Wegg, to be\r\novercome by the consideration that Mr Rokesmith has an underhanded mind!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98On this starlight night, Mr Venus,\xe2\x80\x99 he remarks, when he is showing that\r\nfriendly mover out across the yard, and both are something the worse\r\nfor mixing again and again: \xe2\x80\x98on this starlight night to think that\r\ntalking-over strangers, and underhanded minds, can go walking home under\r\nthe sky, as if they was all square!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The spectacle of those orbs,\xe2\x80\x99 says Mr Venus, gazing upward with his hat\r\ntumbling off; \xe2\x80\x98brings heavy on me her crushing words that she did not\r\nwish to regard herself nor yet to be regarded in that--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know! I know! You needn\xe2\x80\x99t repeat \xe2\x80\x98em,\xe2\x80\x99 says Wegg, pressing his hand.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But think how those stars steady me in the cause of the right against\r\nsome that shall be nameless. It isn\xe2\x80\x99t that I bear malice. But see how\r\nthey glisten with old remembrances! Old remembrances of what, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Venus begins drearily replying, \xe2\x80\x98Of her words, in her own\r\nhandwriting, that she does not wish to regard herself, nor yet--\xe2\x80\x99 when\r\nSilas cuts him short with dignity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, sir! Remembrances of Our House, of Master George, of Aunt Jane, of\r\nUncle Parker, all laid waste! All offered up sacrifices to the minion of\r\nfortune and the worm of the hour!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 8\r\n\r\nIN WHICH AN INNOCENT ELOPEMENT OCCURS\r\n\r\n\r\nThe minion of fortune and the worm of the hour, or in less cutting\r\nlanguage, Nicodemus Boffin, Esquire, the Golden Dustman, had become\r\nas much at home in his eminently aristocratic family mansion as he\r\nwas likely ever to be. He could not but feel that, like an eminently\r\naristocratic family cheese, it was much too large for his wants, and\r\nbred an infinite amount of parasites; but he was content to regard this\r\ndrawback on his property as a sort of perpetual Legacy Duty. He felt the\r\nmore resigned to it, forasmuch as Mrs Boffin enjoyed herself completely,\r\nand Miss Bella was delighted.\r\n\r\nThat young lady was, no doubt, an acquisition to the Boffins. She\r\nwas far too pretty to be unattractive anywhere, and far too quick of\r\nperception to be below the tone of her new career. Whether it improved\r\nher heart might be a matter of taste that was open to question; but as\r\ntouching another matter of taste, its improvement of her appearance and\r\nmanner, there could be no question whatever.\r\n\r\nAnd thus it soon came about that Miss Bella began to set Mrs Boffin\r\nright; and even further, that Miss Bella began to feel ill at ease, and\r\nas it were responsible, when she saw Mrs Boffin going wrong.
