Not that so\r\nsweet a disposition and so sound a nature could ever go very wrong even\r\namong the great visiting authorities who agreed that the Boffins were\r\n\xe2\x80\x98charmingly vulgar\xe2\x80\x99 (which for certain was not their own case in saying\r\nso), but that when she made a slip on the social ice on which all the\r\nchildren of Podsnappery, with genteel souls to be saved, are required to\r\nskate in circles, or to slide in long rows, she inevitably tripped Miss\r\nBella up (so that young lady felt), and caused her to experience great\r\nconfusion under the glances of the more skilful performers engaged in\r\nthose ice-exercises.\r\n\r\nAt Miss Bella\xe2\x80\x99s time of life it was not to be expected that she should\r\nexamine herself very closely on the congruity or stability of her\r\nposition in Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s house. And as she had never been sparing of\r\ncomplaints of her old home when she had no other to compare it with,\r\nso there was no novelty of ingratitude or disdain in her very much\r\npreferring her new one.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98An invaluable man is Rokesmith,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, after some two or\r\nthree months. \xe2\x80\x98But I can\xe2\x80\x99t quite make him out.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nNeither could Bella, so she found the subject rather interesting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He takes more care of my affairs, morning, noon, and night,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr\r\nBoffin, \xe2\x80\x98than fifty other men put together either could or would; and\r\nyet he has ways of his own that are like tying a scaffolding-pole right\r\nacross the road, and bringing me up short when I am almost a-walking arm\r\nin arm with him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98May I ask how so, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Bella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98he won\xe2\x80\x99t meet any company here, but\r\nyou. When we have visitors, I should wish him to have his regular place\r\nat the table like ourselves; but no, he won\xe2\x80\x99t take it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If he considers himself above it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Bella, with an airy toss\r\nof her head, \xe2\x80\x98I should leave him alone.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It ain\xe2\x80\x99t that, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr Boffin, thinking it over. \xe2\x80\x98He don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nconsider himself above it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Perhaps he considers himself beneath it,\xe2\x80\x99 suggested Bella. \xe2\x80\x98If so, he\r\nought to know best.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, my dear; nor it ain\xe2\x80\x99t that, neither. No,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Mr Boffin, with\r\na shake of his head, after again thinking it over; \xe2\x80\x98Rokesmith\xe2\x80\x99s a modest\r\nman, but he don\xe2\x80\x99t consider himself beneath it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then what does he consider, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Bella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dashed if I know!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98It seemed at first as if it\r\nwas only Lightwood that he objected to meet. And now it seems to be\r\neverybody, except you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nOho! thought Miss Bella. \xe2\x80\x98In--deed! That\xe2\x80\x99s it, is it!\xe2\x80\x99 For Mr Mortimer\r\nLightwood had dined there two or three times, and she had met him\r\nelsewhere, and he had shown her some attention. \xe2\x80\x98Rather cool in a\r\nSecretary--and Pa\xe2\x80\x99s lodger--to make me the subject of his jealousy!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThat Pa\xe2\x80\x99s daughter should be so contemptuous of Pa\xe2\x80\x99s lodger was odd;\r\nbut there were odder anomalies than that in the mind of the spoilt girl:\r\nspoilt first by poverty, and then by wealth. Be it this history\xe2\x80\x99s part,\r\nhowever, to leave them to unravel themselves.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A little too much, I think,\xe2\x80\x99 Miss Bella reflected scornfully, \xe2\x80\x98to\r\nhave Pa\xe2\x80\x99s lodger laying claim to me, and keeping eligible people off!\r\nA little too much, indeed, to have the opportunities opened to me by Mr\r\nand Mrs Boffin, appropriated by a mere Secretary and Pa\xe2\x80\x99s lodger!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nYet it was not so very long ago that Bella had been fluttered by the\r\ndiscovery that this same Secretary and lodger seem to like her. Ah! but\r\nthe eminently aristocratic mansion and Mrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s dressmaker had not\r\ncome into play then.\r\n\r\nIn spite of his seemingly retiring manners a very intrusive person, this\r\nSecretary and lodger, in Miss Bella\xe2\x80\x99s opinion. Always a light in his\r\noffice-room when we came home from the play or Opera, and he always at\r\nthe carriage-door to hand us out. Always a provoking radiance too on\r\nMrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s face, and an abominably cheerful reception of him, as if it\r\nwere possible seriously to approve what the man had in his mind!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You never charge me, Miss Wilfer,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Secretary, encountering her\r\nby chance alone in the great drawing-room, \xe2\x80\x98with commissions for home.\r\nI shall always be happy to execute any commands you may have in that\r\ndirection.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pray what may you mean, Mr Rokesmith?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Miss Bella, with\r\nlanguidly drooping eyelids.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98By home? I mean your father\xe2\x80\x99s house at Holloway.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe coloured under the retort--so skilfully thrust, that the words\r\nseemed to be merely a plain answer, given in plain good faith--and said,\r\nrather more emphatically and sharply:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What commissions and commands are you speaking of?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Only little words of remembrance as I assume you sent somehow or\r\nother,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the Secretary with his former air. \xe2\x80\x98It would be a\r\npleasure to me if you would make me the bearer of them. As you know, I\r\ncome and go between the two houses every day.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You needn\xe2\x80\x99t remind me of that, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe was too quick in this petulant sally against \xe2\x80\x98Pa\xe2\x80\x99s lodger\xe2\x80\x99; and she\r\nfelt that she had been so when she met his quiet look.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They don\xe2\x80\x99t send many--what was your expression?--words of remembrance\r\nto me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, making haste to take refuge in ill-usage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They frequently ask me about you, and I give them such slight\r\nintelligence as I can.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope it\xe2\x80\x99s truly given,\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Bella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope you cannot doubt it, for it would be very much against you, if\r\nyou could.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, I do not doubt it. I deserve the reproach, which is very just\r\nindeed. I beg your pardon, Mr Rokesmith.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should beg you not to do so, but that it shows you to such admirable\r\nadvantage,\xe2\x80\x99 he replied with earnestness. \xe2\x80\x98Forgive me; I could not help\r\nsaying that. To return to what I have digressed from, let me add that\r\nperhaps they think I report them to you, deliver little messages, and\r\nthe like. But I forbear to trouble you, as you never ask me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am going, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, looking at him as if he had reproved her,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98to see them tomorrow.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is that,\xe2\x80\x99 he asked, hesitating, \xe2\x80\x98said to me, or to them?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To which you please.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To both? Shall I make it a message?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You can if you like, Mr Rokesmith. Message or no message, I am going to\r\nsee them tomorrow.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then I will tell them so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe lingered a moment, as though to give her the opportunity of\r\nprolonging the conversation if she wished. As she remained silent, he\r\nleft her. Two incidents of the little interview were felt by Miss Bella\r\nherself, when alone again, to be very curious. The first was, that he\r\nunquestionably left her with a penitent air upon her, and a penitent\r\nfeeling in her heart. The second was, that she had not an intention or\r\na thought of going home, until she had announced it to him as a settled\r\ndesign.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What can I mean by it, or what can he mean by it?\xe2\x80\x99 was her mental\r\ninquiry: \xe2\x80\x98He has no right to any power over me, and how do I come to\r\nmind him when I don\xe2\x80\x99t care for him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs Boffin, insisting that Bella should make tomorrow\xe2\x80\x99s expedition\r\nin the chariot, she went home in great grandeur. Mrs Wilfer and Miss\r\nLavinia had speculated much on the probabilities and improbabilities of\r\nher coming in this gorgeous state, and, on beholding the chariot from\r\nthe window at which they were secreted to look out for it, agreed\r\nthat it must be detained at the door as long as possible, for the\r\nmortification and confusion of the neighbours. Then they repaired to\r\nthe usual family room, to receive Miss Bella with a becoming show of\r\nindifference.\r\n\r\nThe family room looked very small and very mean, and the downward\r\nstaircase by which it was attained looked very narrow and very crooked.\r\nThe little house and all its arrangements were a poor contrast to the\r\neminently aristocratic dwelling. \xe2\x80\x98I can hardly believe,\xe2\x80\x99 thought Bella,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98that I ever did endure life in this place!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nGloomy majesty on the part of Mrs Wilfer, and native pertness on the\r\npart of Lavvy, did not mend the matter. Bella really stood in natural\r\nneed of a little help, and she got none.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Wilfer, presenting a cheek to be kissed, as sympathetic\r\nand responsive as the back of the bowl of a spoon, \xe2\x80\x98is quite an honour!\r\nYou will probably find your sister Lavvy grown, Bella.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ma,\xe2\x80\x99 Miss Lavinia interposed, \xe2\x80\x98there can be no objection to your being\r\naggravating, because Bella richly deserves it; but I really must request\r\nthat you will not drag in such ridiculous nonsense as my having grown\r\nwhen I am past the growing age.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I grew, myself,\xe2\x80\x99 Mrs Wilfer sternly proclaimed, \xe2\x80\x98after I was married.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very well, Ma,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Lavvy, \xe2\x80\x98then I think you had much better have\r\nleft it alone.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe lofty glare with which the majestic woman received this answer,\r\nmight have embarrassed a less pert opponent, but it had no effect upon\r\nLavinia: who, leaving her parent to the enjoyment of any amount of\r\nglaring at she might deem desirable under the circumstances, accosted\r\nher sister, undismayed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose you won\xe2\x80\x99t consider yourself quite disgraced, Bella, if I give\r\nyou a kiss? Well! And how do you do, Bella? And how are your Boffins?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Peace!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mrs Wilfer. \xe2\x80\x98Hold! I will not suffer this tone of\r\nlevity.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My goodness me! How are your Spoffins, then?\xe2\x80\x99 said Lavvy, \xe2\x80\x98since Ma so\r\nvery much objects to your Boffins.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Impertinent girl! Minx!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Wilfer, with dread severity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t care whether I am a Minx, or a Sphinx,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Lavinia,\r\ncoolly, tossing her head; \xe2\x80\x98it\xe2\x80\x99s exactly the same thing to me, and I\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nevery bit as soon be one as the other; but I know this--I\xe2\x80\x99ll not grow\r\nafter I\xe2\x80\x99m married!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You will not? YOU will not?\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Mrs Wilfer, solemnly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, Ma, I will not. Nothing shall induce me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs Wilfer, having waved her gloves, became loftily pathetic.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But it was to be expected;\xe2\x80\x99 thus she spake. \xe2\x80\x98A child of mine deserts me\r\nfor the proud and prosperous, and another child of mine despises me. It\r\nis quite fitting.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ma,\xe2\x80\x99 Bella struck in, \xe2\x80\x98Mr and Mrs Boffin are prosperous, no doubt; but\r\nyou have no right to say they are proud. You must know very well that\r\nthey are not.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In short, Ma,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lavvy, bouncing over to the enemy without a word\r\nof notice, \xe2\x80\x98you must know very well--or if you don\xe2\x80\x99t, more shame for\r\nyou!--that Mr and Mrs Boffin are just absolute perfection.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Truly,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mrs Wilfer, courteously receiving the deserter, \xe2\x80\x98it\r\nwould seem that we are required to think so. And this, Lavinia, is\r\nmy reason for objecting to a tone of levity. Mrs Boffin (of whose\r\nphysiognomy I can never speak with the composure I would desire to\r\npreserve), and your mother, are not on terms of intimacy. It is not\r\nfor a moment to be supposed that she and her husband dare to presume to\r\nspeak of this family as the Wilfers. I cannot therefore condescend to\r\nspeak of them as the Boffins. No; for such a tone--call it familiarity,\r\nlevity, equality, or what you will--would imply those social\r\ninterchanges which do not exist. Do I render myself intelligible?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWithout taking the least notice of this inquiry, albeit delivered in an\r\nimposing and forensic manner, Lavinia reminded her sister, \xe2\x80\x98After all,\r\nyou know, Bella, you haven\xe2\x80\x99t told us how your Whatshisnames are.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to speak of them here,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Bella, suppressing\r\nindignation, and tapping her foot on the floor. \xe2\x80\x98They are much too kind\r\nand too good to be drawn into these discussions.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why put it so?\xe2\x80\x99 demanded Mrs Wilfer, with biting sarcasm. \xe2\x80\x98Why adopt a\r\ncircuitous form of speech? It is polite and it is obliging; but why do\r\nit? Why not openly say that they are much too kind and too good for US?\r\nWe understand the allusion. Why disguise the phrase?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ma,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, with one beat of her foot, \xe2\x80\x98you are enough to drive a\r\nsaint mad, and so is Lavvy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Unfortunate Lavvy!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mrs Wilfer, in a tone of commiseration. \xe2\x80\x98She\r\nalways comes for it. My poor child!\xe2\x80\x99 But Lavvy, with the suddenness of\r\nher former desertion, now bounced over to the other enemy: very sharply\r\nremarking, \xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t patronize ME, Ma, because I can take care of myself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I only wonder,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed Mrs Wilfer, directing her observations to her\r\nelder daughter, as safer on the whole than her utterly unmanageable\r\nyounger, \xe2\x80\x98that you found time and inclination to tear yourself from\r\nMr and Mrs Boffin, and come to see us at all. I only wonder that our\r\nclaims, contending against the superior claims of Mr and Mrs Boffin,\r\nhad any weight. I feel I ought to be thankful for gaining so much, in\r\ncompetition with Mr and Mrs Boffin.\xe2\x80\x99 (The good lady bitterly emphasized\r\nthe first letter of the word Boffin, as if it represented her chief\r\nobjection to the owners of that name, and as if she could have born\r\nDoffin, Moffin, or Poffin much better.)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ma,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, angrily, \xe2\x80\x98you force me to say that I am truly sorry I\r\ndid come home, and that I never will come home again, except when poor\r\ndear Pa is here. For, Pa is too magnanimous to feel envy and spite\r\ntowards my generous friends, and Pa is delicate enough and gentle enough\r\nto remember the sort of little claim they thought I had upon them and\r\nthe unusually trying position in which, through no act of my own, I had\r\nbeen placed. And I always did love poor dear Pa better than all the rest\r\nof you put together, and I always do and I always shall!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHere Bella, deriving no comfort from her charming bonnet and her elegant\r\ndress, burst into tears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think, R.W.,\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mrs Wilfer, lifting up her eyes and\r\napostrophising the air, \xe2\x80\x98that if you were present, it would be a\r\ntrial to your feelings to hear your wife and the mother of your family\r\ndepreciated in your name. But Fate has spared you this, R.W., whatever\r\nit may have thought proper to inflict upon her!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHere Mrs Wilfer burst into tears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hate the Boffins!\xe2\x80\x99 protested Miss Lavinia. \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t care who objects\r\nto their being called the Boffins. I WILL call \xe2\x80\x98em the Boffins. The\r\nBoffins, the Boffins, the Boffins! And I say they are mischief-making\r\nBoffins, and I say the Boffins have set Bella against me, and I tell the\r\nBoffins to their faces:\xe2\x80\x99 which was not strictly the fact, but the\r\nyoung lady was excited: \xe2\x80\x98that they are detestable Boffins, disreputable\r\nBoffins, odious Boffins, beastly Boffins. There!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHere Miss Lavinia burst into tears.\r\n\r\nThe front garden-gate clanked, and the Secretary was seen coming at a\r\nbrisk pace up the steps. \xe2\x80\x98Leave Me to open the door to him,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs\r\nWilfer, rising with stately resignation as she shook her head and dried\r\nher eyes; \xe2\x80\x98we have at present no stipendiary girl to do so. We have\r\nnothing to conceal. If he sees these traces of emotion on our cheeks,\r\nlet him construe them as he may.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith those words she stalked out. In a few moments she stalked in again,\r\nproclaiming in her heraldic manner, \xe2\x80\x98Mr Rokesmith is the bearer of a\r\npacket for Miss Bella Wilfer.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Rokesmith followed close upon his name, and of course saw what was\r\namiss. But he discreetly affected to see nothing, and addressed Miss\r\nBella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Boffin intended to have placed this in the carriage for you\r\nthis morning. He wished you to have it, as a little keepsake he had\r\nprepared--it is only a purse, Miss Wilfer--but as he was disappointed in\r\nhis fancy, I volunteered to come after you with it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella took it in her hand, and thanked him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We have been quarrelling here a little, Mr Rokesmith, but not more than\r\nwe used; you know our agreeable ways among ourselves. You find me just\r\ngoing. Good-bye, mamma. Good-bye, Lavvy!\xe2\x80\x99 and with a kiss for each Miss\r\nBella turned to the door. The Secretary would have attended her, but\r\nMrs Wilfer advancing and saying with dignity, \xe2\x80\x98Pardon me! Permit me to\r\nassert my natural right to escort my child to the equipage which is\r\nin waiting for her,\xe2\x80\x99 he begged pardon and gave place. It was a very\r\nmagnificent spectacle indeed, to see Mrs Wilfer throw open the\r\nhouse-door, and loudly demand with extended gloves, \xe2\x80\x98The male domestic\r\nof Mrs Boffin!\xe2\x80\x99 To whom presenting himself, she delivered the brief but\r\nmajestic charge, \xe2\x80\x98Miss Wilfer. Coming out!\xe2\x80\x99 and so delivered her over,\r\nlike a female Lieutenant of the Tower relinquishing a State Prisoner.\r\nThe effect of this ceremonial was for some quarter of an hour afterwards\r\nperfectly paralyzing on the neighbours, and was much enhanced by the\r\nworthy lady airing herself for that term in a kind of splendidly serene\r\ntrance on the top step.\r\n\r\nWhen Bella was seated in the carriage, she opened the little packet in\r\nher hand. It contained a pretty purse, and the purse contained a bank\r\nnote for fifty pounds. \xe2\x80\x98This shall be a joyful surprise for poor dear\r\nPa,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, \xe2\x80\x98and I\xe2\x80\x99ll take it myself into the City!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs she was uninformed respecting the exact locality of the place of\r\nbusiness of Chicksey Veneering and Stobbles, but knew it to be near\r\nMincing Lane, she directed herself to be driven to the corner of that\r\ndarksome spot. Thence she despatched \xe2\x80\x98the male domestic of Mrs Boffin,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nin search of the counting-house of Chicksey Veneering and Stobbles, with\r\na message importing that if R. Wilfer could come out, there was a lady\r\nwaiting who would be glad to speak with him. The delivery of these\r\nmysterious words from the mouth of a footman caused so great an\r\nexcitement in the counting-house, that a youthful scout was instantly\r\nappointed to follow Rumty, observe the lady, and come in with his\r\nreport. Nor was the agitation by any means diminished, when the scout\r\nrushed back with the intelligence that the lady was \xe2\x80\x98a slap-up gal in a\r\nbang-up chariot.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nRumty himself, with his pen behind his ear under his rusty hat, arrived\r\nat the carriage-door in a breathless condition, and had been fairly\r\nlugged into the vehicle by his cravat and embraced almost unto choking,\r\nbefore he recognized his daughter. \xe2\x80\x98My dear child!\xe2\x80\x99 he then panted,\r\nincoherently. \xe2\x80\x98Good gracious me! What a lovely woman you are! I thought\r\nyou had been unkind and forgotten your mother and sister.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have just been to see them, Pa dear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh! and how--how did you find your mother?\xe2\x80\x99 asked R. W., dubiously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very disagreeable, Pa, and so was Lavvy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They are sometimes a little liable to it,\xe2\x80\x99 observed the patient cherub;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98but I hope you made allowances, Bella, my dear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No. I was disagreeable too, Pa; we were all of us disagreeable\r\ntogether. But I want you to come and dine with me somewhere, Pa.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, my dear, I have already partaken of a--if one might mention such\r\nan article in this superb chariot--of a--Saveloy,\xe2\x80\x99 replied R. Wilfer,\r\nmodestly dropping his voice on the word, as he eyed the canary-coloured\r\nfittings.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh! That\xe2\x80\x99s nothing, Pa!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Truly, it ain\xe2\x80\x99t as much as one could sometimes wish it to be, my\r\ndear,\xe2\x80\x99 he admitted, drawing his hand across his mouth. \xe2\x80\x98Still, when\r\ncircumstances over which you have no control, interpose obstacles\r\nbetween yourself and Small Germans, you can\xe2\x80\x99t do better than bring a\r\ncontented mind to hear on\xe2\x80\x99--again dropping his voice in deference to the\r\nchariot--\xe2\x80\x98Saveloys!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You poor good Pa! Pa, do, I beg and pray, get leave for the rest of the\r\nday, and come and pass it with me!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, my dear, I\xe2\x80\x99ll cut back and ask for leave.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But before you cut back,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, who had already taken him by the\r\nchin, pulled his hat off, and begun to stick up his hair in her old way,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98do say that you are sure I am giddy and inconsiderate, but have never\r\nreally slighted you, Pa.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear, I say it with all my heart. And might I likewise observe,\xe2\x80\x99 her\r\nfather delicately hinted, with a glance out at window, \xe2\x80\x98that perhaps\r\nit might be calculated to attract attention, having one\xe2\x80\x99s hair publicly\r\ndone by a lovely woman in an elegant turn-out in Fenchurch Street?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella laughed and put on his hat again. But when his boyish figure\r\nbobbed away, its shabbiness and cheerful patience smote the tears out\r\nof her eyes. \xe2\x80\x98I hate that Secretary for thinking it of me,\xe2\x80\x99 she said to\r\nherself, \xe2\x80\x98and yet it seems half true!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBack came her father, more like a boy than ever, in his release from\r\nschool. \xe2\x80\x98All right, my dear. Leave given at once. Really very handsomely\r\ndone!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now where can we find some quiet place, Pa, in which I can wait for you\r\nwhile you go on an errand for me, if I send the carriage away?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt demanded cogitation. \xe2\x80\x98You see, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 he explained, \xe2\x80\x98you really\r\nhave become such a very lovely woman, that it ought to be a very quiet\r\nplace.\xe2\x80\x99 At length he suggested, \xe2\x80\x98Near the garden up by the Trinity House\r\non Tower Hill.\xe2\x80\x99 So, they were driven there, and Bella dismissed the\r\nchariot; sending a pencilled note by it to Mrs Boffin, that she was with\r\nher father.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, Pa, attend to what I am going to say, and promise and vow to be\r\nobedient.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I promise and vow, my dear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You ask no questions. You take this purse; you go to the nearest place\r\nwhere they keep everything of the very very best, ready made; you buy\r\nand put on, the most beautiful suit of clothes, the most beautiful hat,\r\nand the most beautiful pair of bright boots (patent leather, Pa, mind!)\r\nthat are to be got for money; and you come back to me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But, my dear Bella--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Take care, Pa!\xe2\x80\x99 pointing her forefinger at him, merrily. \xe2\x80\x98You have\r\npromised and vowed. It\xe2\x80\x99s perjury, you know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere was water in the foolish little fellow\xe2\x80\x99s eyes, but she kissed them\r\ndry (though her own were wet), and he bobbed away again. After half an\r\nhour, he came back, so brilliantly transformed, that Bella was obliged\r\nto walk round him in ecstatic admiration twenty times, before she could\r\ndraw her arm through his, and delightedly squeeze it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, Pa,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, hugging him close, \xe2\x80\x98take this lovely woman out to\r\ndinner.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where shall we go, my dear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Greenwich!\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, valiantly. \xe2\x80\x98And be sure you treat this lovely\r\nwoman with everything of the best.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWhile they were going along to take boat, \xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you wish, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid R. W., timidly, \xe2\x80\x98that your mother was here?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, I don\xe2\x80\x99t, Pa, for I like to have you all to myself to-day. I was\r\nalways your little favourite at home, and you were always mine. We have\r\nrun away together often, before now; haven\xe2\x80\x99t we, Pa?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, to be sure we have! Many a Sunday when your mother was--was a\r\nlittle liable to it,\xe2\x80\x99 repeating his former delicate expression after\r\npausing to cough.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, and I am afraid I was seldom or never as good as I ought to have\r\nbeen, Pa. I made you carry me, over and over again, when you should\r\nhave made me walk; and I often drove you in harness, when you would much\r\nrather have sat down and read your news-paper: didn\xe2\x80\x99t I?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sometimes, sometimes. But Lor, what a child you were! What a companion\r\nyou were!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Companion? That\xe2\x80\x99s just what I want to be to-day, Pa.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are safe to succeed, my love. Your brothers and sisters have all\r\nin their turns been companions to me, to a certain extent, but only to a\r\ncertain extent. Your mother has, throughout life, been a companion that\r\nany man might--might look up to--and--and commit the sayings of, to\r\nmemory--and--form himself upon--if he--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If he liked the model?\xe2\x80\x99 suggested Bella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We-ell, ye-es,\xe2\x80\x99 he returned, thinking about it, not quite satisfied\r\nwith the phrase: \xe2\x80\x98or perhaps I might say, if it was in him. Supposing,\r\nfor instance, that a man wanted to be always marching, he would find\r\nyour mother an inestimable companion. But if he had any taste for\r\nwalking, or should wish at any time to break into a trot, he might\r\nsometimes find it a little difficult to keep step with your mother.\r\nOr take it this way, Bella,\xe2\x80\x99 he added, after a moment\xe2\x80\x99s reflection;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Supposing that a man had to go through life, we won\xe2\x80\x99t say with a\r\ncompanion, but we\xe2\x80\x99ll say to a tune. Very good. Supposing that the tune\r\nallotted to him was the Dead March in Saul. Well. It would be a very\r\nsuitable tune for particular occasions--none better--but it would\r\nbe difficult to keep time with in the ordinary run of domestic\r\ntransactions. For instance, if he took his supper after a hard day, to\r\nthe Dead March in Saul, his food might be likely to sit heavy on him.\r\nOr, if he was at any time inclined to relieve his mind by singing a\r\ncomic song or dancing a hornpipe, and was obliged to do it to the Dead\r\nMarch in Saul, he might find himself put out in the execution of his\r\nlively intentions.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Poor Pa!\xe2\x80\x99 thought Bella, as she hung upon his arm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, what I will say for you, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 the cherub pursued mildly and\r\nwithout a notion of complaining, \xe2\x80\x98is, that you are so adaptable. So\r\nadaptable.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Indeed I am afraid I have shown a wretched temper, Pa. I am afraid\r\nI have been very complaining, and very capricious. I seldom or never\r\nthought of it before. But when I sat in the carriage just now and saw\r\nyou coming along the pavement, I reproached myself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not at all, my dear. Don\xe2\x80\x99t speak of such a thing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nA happy and a chatty man was Pa in his new clothes that day. Take it\r\nfor all in all, it was perhaps the happiest day he had ever known in his\r\nlife; not even excepting that on which his heroic partner had approached\r\nthe nuptial altar to the tune of the Dead March in Saul.\r\n\r\nThe little expedition down the river was delightful, and the little\r\nroom overlooking the river into which they were shown for dinner was\r\ndelightful. Everything was delightful. The park was delightful, the\r\npunch was delightful, the dishes of fish were delightful, the wine\r\nwas delightful. Bella was more delightful than any other item in the\r\nfestival; drawing Pa out in the gayest manner; making a point of always\r\nmentioning herself as the lovely woman; stimulating Pa to order things,\r\nby declaring that the lovely woman insisted on being treated with them;\r\nand in short causing Pa to be quite enraptured with the consideration\r\nthat he WAS the Pa of such a charming daughter.\r\n\r\nAnd then, as they sat looking at the ships and steamboats making their\r\nway to the sea with the tide that was running down, the lovely woman\r\nimagined all sorts of voyages for herself and Pa. Now, Pa, in the\r\ncharacter of owner of a lumbering square-sailed collier, was tacking\r\naway to Newcastle, to fetch black diamonds to make his fortune with;\r\nnow, Pa was going to China in that handsome threemasted ship, to bring\r\nhome opium, with which he would for ever cut out Chicksey Veneering\r\nand Stobbles, and to bring home silks and shawls without end for the\r\ndecoration of his charming daughter. Now, John Harmon\xe2\x80\x99s disastrous fate\r\nwas all a dream, and he had come home and found the lovely woman just\r\nthe article for him, and the lovely woman had found him just the article\r\nfor her, and they were going away on a trip, in their gallant bark,\r\nto look after their vines, with streamers flying at all points, a band\r\nplaying on deck and Pa established in the great cabin. Now, John Harmon\r\nwas consigned to his grave again, and a merchant of immense wealth\r\n(name unknown) had courted and married the lovely woman, and he was\r\nso enormously rich that everything you saw upon the river sailing or\r\nsteaming belonged to him, and he kept a perfect fleet of yachts for\r\npleasure, and that little impudent yacht which you saw over there, with\r\nthe great white sail, was called The Bella, in honour of his wife, and\r\nshe held her state aboard when it pleased her, like a modern Cleopatra.\r\nAnon, there would embark in that troop-ship when she got to Gravesend, a\r\nmighty general, of large property (name also unknown), who wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nhear of going to victory without his wife, and whose wife was the lovely\r\nwoman, and she was destined to become the idol of all the red coats and\r\nblue jackets alow and aloft. And then again: you saw that ship being\r\ntowed out by a steam-tug? Well! where did you suppose she was going to?\r\nShe was going among the coral reefs and cocoa-nuts and all that sort of\r\nthing, and she was chartered for a fortunate individual of the name\r\nof Pa (himself on board, and much respected by all hands), and she\r\nwas going, for his sole profit and advantage, to fetch a cargo of\r\nsweet-smelling woods, the most beautiful that ever were seen, and the\r\nmost profitable that ever were heard of; and her cargo would be a great\r\nfortune, as indeed it ought to be: the lovely woman who had purchased\r\nher and fitted her expressly for this voyage, being married to an Indian\r\nPrince, who was a Something-or-Other, and who wore Cashmere shawls all\r\nover himself and diamonds and emeralds blazing in his turban, and was\r\nbeautifully coffee-coloured and excessively devoted, though a little too\r\njealous. Thus Bella ran on merrily, in a manner perfectly enchanting to\r\nPa, who was as willing to put his head into the Sultan\xe2\x80\x99s tub of water as\r\nthe beggar-boys below the window were to put THEIR heads in the mud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Pa after dinner, \xe2\x80\x98we may come to the\r\nconclusion at home, that we have lost you for good?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella shook her head. Didn\xe2\x80\x99t know. Couldn\xe2\x80\x99t say. All she was able to\r\nreport was, that she was most handsomely supplied with everything she\r\ncould possibly want, and that whenever she hinted at leaving Mr and Mrs\r\nBoffin, they wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t hear of it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And now, Pa,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued Bella, \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll make a confession to you. I am the\r\nmost mercenary little wretch that ever lived in the world.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should hardly have thought it of you, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 returned her father,\r\nfirst glancing at himself; and then at the dessert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I understand what you mean, Pa, but it\xe2\x80\x99s not that. It\xe2\x80\x99s not that I care\r\nfor money to keep as money, but I do care so much for what it will buy!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Really I think most of us do,\xe2\x80\x99 returned R. W.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But not to the dreadful extent that I do, Pa. O-o!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Bella,\r\nscrewing the exclamation out of herself with a twist of her dimpled\r\nchin. \xe2\x80\x98I AM so mercenary!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith a wistful glance R. W. said, in default of having anything better\r\nto say: \xe2\x80\x98About when did you begin to feel it coming on, my dear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s it, Pa. That\xe2\x80\x99s the terrible part of it. When I was at home, and\r\nonly knew what it was to be poor, I grumbled but didn\xe2\x80\x99t so much mind.\r\nWhen I was at home expecting to be rich, I thought vaguely of all the\r\ngreat things I would do. But when I had been disappointed of my splendid\r\nfortune, and came to see it from day to day in other hands, and to have\r\nbefore my eyes what it could really do, then I became the mercenary\r\nlittle wretch I am.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s your fancy, my dear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can assure you it\xe2\x80\x99s nothing of the sort, Pa!\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, nodding at\r\nhim, with her very pretty eyebrows raised as high as they would go, and\r\nlooking comically frightened. \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s a fact. I am always avariciously\r\nscheming.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lor! But how?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you, Pa. I don\xe2\x80\x99t mind telling YOU, because we have always\r\nbeen favourites of each other\xe2\x80\x99s, and because you are not like a Pa, but\r\nmore like a sort of a younger brother with a dear venerable chubbiness\r\non him. And besides,\xe2\x80\x99 added Bella, laughing as she pointed a rallying\r\nfinger at his face, \xe2\x80\x98because I have got you in my power. This is a\r\nsecret expedition. If ever you tell of me, I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell of you. I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell\r\nMa that you dined at Greenwich.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well; seriously, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 observed R. W., with some trepidation of\r\nmanner, \xe2\x80\x98it might be as well not to mention it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Aha!\xe2\x80\x99 laughed Bella. \xe2\x80\x98I knew you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t like it, sir! So you keep my\r\nconfidence, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll keep yours. But betray the lovely woman, and you\r\nshall find her a serpent. Now, you may give me a kiss, Pa, and I should\r\nlike to give your hair a turn, because it has been dreadfully neglected\r\nin my absence.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nR. W. submitted his head to the operator, and the operator went on\r\ntalking; at the same time putting separate locks of his hair through\r\na curious process of being smartly rolled over her two revolving\r\nforefingers, which were then suddenly pulled out of it in opposite\r\nlateral directions. On each of these occasions the patient winced and\r\nwinked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have made up my mind that I must have money, Pa. I feel that I can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nbeg it, borrow it, or steal it; and so I have resolved that I must marry\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nR. W. cast up his eyes towards her, as well as he could under the\r\noperating circumstances, and said in a tone of remonstrance, \xe2\x80\x98My de-ar\r\nBella!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have resolved, I say, Pa, that to get money I must marry money. In\r\nconsequence of which, I am always looking out for money to captivate.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My de-a-r Bella!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, Pa, that is the state of the case. If ever there was a mercenary\r\nplotter whose thoughts and designs were always in her mean occupation, I\r\nam the amiable creature. But I don\xe2\x80\x99t care. I hate and detest being\r\npoor, and I won\xe2\x80\x99t be poor if I can marry money. Now you are deliciously\r\nfluffy, Pa, and in a state to astonish the waiter and pay the bill.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But, my dear Bella, this is quite alarming at your age.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I told you so, Pa, but you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t believe it,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Bella, with a\r\npleasant childish gravity. \xe2\x80\x98Isn\xe2\x80\x99t it shocking?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It would be quite so, if you fully knew what you said, my dear, or\r\nmeant it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, Pa, I can only tell you that I mean nothing else. Talk to me of\r\nlove!\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, contemptuously: though her face and figure certainly\r\nrendered the subject no incongruous one. \xe2\x80\x98Talk to me of fiery dragons!\r\nBut talk to me of poverty and wealth, and there indeed we touch upon\r\nrealities.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My De-ar, this is becoming Awful--\xe2\x80\x99 her father was emphatically\r\nbeginning: when she stopped him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pa, tell me. Did you marry money?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You know I didn\xe2\x80\x99t, my dear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella hummed the Dead March in Saul, and said, after all it signified\r\nvery little! But seeing him look grave and downcast, she took him round\r\nthe neck and kissed him back to cheerfulness again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I didn\xe2\x80\x99t mean that last touch, Pa; it was only said in joke. Now mind!\r\nYou are not to tell of me, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll not tell of you. And more than that;\r\nI promise to have no secrets from you, Pa, and you may make certain\r\nthat, whatever mercenary things go on, I shall always tell you all about\r\nthem in strict confidence.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nFain to be satisfied with this concession from the lovely woman, R. W.\r\nrang the bell, and paid the bill. \xe2\x80\x98Now, all the rest of this, Pa,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nBella, rolling up the purse when they were alone again, hammering it\r\nsmall with her little fist on the table, and cramming it into one of the\r\npockets of his new waistcoat, \xe2\x80\x98is for you, to buy presents with for them\r\nat home, and to pay bills with, and to divide as you like, and spend\r\nexactly as you think proper. Last of all take notice, Pa, that it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nnot the fruit of any avaricious scheme. Perhaps if it was, your little\r\nmercenary wretch of a daughter wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t make so free with it!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAfter which, she tugged at his coat with both hands, and pulled him all\r\naskew in buttoning that garment over the precious waistcoat pocket, and\r\nthen tied her dimples into her bonnet-strings in a very knowing way, and\r\ntook him back to London. Arrived at Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s door, she set him with\r\nhis back against it, tenderly took him by the ears as convenient handles\r\nfor her purpose, and kissed him until he knocked muffled double knocks\r\nat the door with the back of his head. That done, she once more reminded\r\nhim of their compact and gaily parted from him.\r\n\r\nNot so gaily, however, but that tears filled her eyes as he went away\r\ndown the dark street. Not so gaily, but that she several times said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, poor little Pa! Ah, poor dear struggling shabby little Pa!\xe2\x80\x99\r\nbefore she took heart to knock at the door. Not so gaily, but that the\r\nbrilliant furniture seemed to stare her out of countenance as if it\r\ninsisted on being compared with the dingy furniture at home. Not so\r\ngaily, but that she fell into very low spirits sitting late in her own\r\nroom, and very heartily wept, as she wished, now that the deceased old\r\nJohn Harmon had never made a will about her, now that the deceased young\r\nJohn Harmon had lived to marry her. \xe2\x80\x98Contradictory things to wish,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nBella, \xe2\x80\x98but my life and fortunes are so contradictory altogether that\r\nwhat can I expect myself to be!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 9\r\n\r\nIN WHICH THE ORPHAN MAKES HIS WILL\r\n\r\n\r\nThe Secretary, working in the Dismal Swamp betimes next morning, was\r\ninformed that a youth waited in the hall who gave the name of Sloppy.\r\nThe footman who communicated this intelligence made a decent pause\r\nbefore uttering the name, to express that it was forced on his\r\nreluctance by the youth in question, and that if the youth had had\r\nthe good sense and good taste to inherit some other name it would have\r\nspared the feelings of him the bearer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mrs Boffin will be very well pleased,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Secretary in a\r\nperfectly composed way. \xe2\x80\x98Show him in.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Sloppy being introduced, remained close to the door: revealing\r\nin various parts of his form many surprising, confounding, and\r\nincomprehensible buttons.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am glad to see you,\xe2\x80\x99 said John Rokesmith, in a cheerful tone of\r\nwelcome. \xe2\x80\x98I have been expecting you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSloppy explained that he had meant to come before, but that the Orphan\r\n(of whom he made mention as Our Johnny) had been ailing, and he had\r\nwaited to report him well.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then he is well now?\xe2\x80\x99 said the Secretary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No he ain\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sloppy.\r\n\r\nMr Sloppy having shaken his head to a considerable extent, proceeded\r\nto remark that he thought Johnny \xe2\x80\x98must have took \xe2\x80\x98em from the Minders.\xe2\x80\x99\r\nBeing asked what he meant, he answered, them that come out upon him and\r\npartickler his chest. Being requested to explain himself, he stated that\r\nthere was some of \xe2\x80\x98em wot you couldn\xe2\x80\x99t kiver with a sixpence. Pressed to\r\nfall back upon a nominative case, he opined that they wos about as\r\nred as ever red could be. \xe2\x80\x98But as long as they strikes out\xe2\x80\x99ards, sir,\xe2\x80\x99\r\ncontinued Sloppy, \xe2\x80\x98they ain\xe2\x80\x99t so much. It\xe2\x80\x99s their striking in\xe2\x80\x99ards\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s to be kep off.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJohn Rokesmith hoped the child had had medical attendance? Oh yes, said\r\nSloppy, he had been took to the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s shop once. And what did the\r\ndoctor call it? Rokesmith asked him. After some perplexed reflection,\r\nSloppy answered, brightening, \xe2\x80\x98He called it something as wos wery\r\nlong for spots.\xe2\x80\x99 Rokesmith suggested measles. \xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sloppy with\r\nconfidence, \xe2\x80\x98ever so much longer than THEM, sir!\xe2\x80\x99 (Mr Sloppy was\r\nelevated by this fact, and seemed to consider that it reflected credit\r\non the poor little patient.)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mrs Boffin will be sorry to hear this,\xe2\x80\x99 said Rokesmith.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mrs Higden said so, sir, when she kep it from her, hoping as Our Johnny\r\nwould work round.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I hope he will?\xe2\x80\x99 said Rokesmith, with a quick turn upon the\r\nmessenger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope so,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Sloppy. \xe2\x80\x98It all depends on their striking\r\nin\xe2\x80\x99ards.\xe2\x80\x99 He then went on to say that whether Johnny had \xe2\x80\x98took \xe2\x80\x98em\xe2\x80\x99\r\nfrom the Minders, or whether the Minders had \xe2\x80\x98took \xe2\x80\x99em from Johnny,\r\nthe Minders had been sent home and had \xe2\x80\x98got \xe2\x80\x99em.\xe2\x80\x99 Furthermore, that Mrs\r\nHigden\xe2\x80\x99s days and nights being devoted to Our Johnny, who was never out\r\nof her lap, the whole of the mangling arrangements had devolved upon\r\nhimself, and he had had \xe2\x80\x98rayther a tight time\xe2\x80\x99. The ungainly piece of\r\nhonesty beamed and blushed as he said it, quite enraptured with the\r\nremembrance of having been serviceable.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Last night,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sloppy, \xe2\x80\x98when I was a-turning at the wheel pretty\r\nlate, the mangle seemed to go like Our Johnny\xe2\x80\x99s breathing. It begun\r\nbeautiful, then as it went out it shook a little and got unsteady, then\r\nas it took the turn to come home it had a rattle-like and lumbered a\r\nbit, then it come smooth, and so it went on till I scarce know\xe2\x80\x99d which\r\nwas mangle and which was Our Johnny. Nor Our Johnny, he scarce know\xe2\x80\x99d\r\neither, for sometimes when the mangle lumbers he says, \xe2\x80\x9cMe choking,\r\nGranny!\xe2\x80\x9d and Mrs Higden holds him up in her lap and says to me \xe2\x80\x9cBide a\r\nbit, Sloppy,\xe2\x80\x9d and we all stops together. And when Our Johnny gets his\r\nbreathing again, I turns again, and we all goes on together.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSloppy had gradually expanded with his description into a stare and a\r\nvacant grin. He now contracted, being silent, into a half-repressed gush\r\nof tears, and, under pretence of being heated, drew the under part of\r\nhis sleeve across his eyes with a singularly awkward, laborious, and\r\nroundabout smear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is unfortunate,\xe2\x80\x99 said Rokesmith. \xe2\x80\x98I must go and break it to Mrs\r\nBoffin. Stay you here, Sloppy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSloppy stayed there, staring at the pattern of the paper on the wall,\r\nuntil the Secretary and Mrs Boffin came back together. And with Mrs\r\nBoffin was a young lady (Miss Bella Wilfer by name) who was better worth\r\nstaring at, it occurred to Sloppy, than the best of wall-papering.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, my poor dear pretty little John Harmon!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mrs Boffin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes mum,\xe2\x80\x99 said the sympathetic Sloppy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t think he is in a very, very bad way, do you?\xe2\x80\x99 asked the\r\npleasant creature with her wholesome cordiality.\r\n\r\nPut upon his good faith, and finding it in collision with his\r\ninclinations, Sloppy threw back his head and uttered a mellifluous howl,\r\nrounded off with a sniff.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So bad as that!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mrs Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98And Betty Higden not to tell me of\r\nit sooner!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think she might have been mistrustful, mum,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Sloppy,\r\nhesitating.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of what, for Heaven\xe2\x80\x99s sake?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think she might have been mistrustful, mum,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Sloppy with\r\nsubmission, \xe2\x80\x98of standing in Our Johnny\xe2\x80\x99s light. There\xe2\x80\x99s so much trouble\r\nin illness, and so much expense, and she\xe2\x80\x99s seen such a lot of its being\r\nobjected to.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But she never can have thought,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98that I would grudge\r\nthe dear child anything?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No mum, but she might have thought (as a habit-like) of its standing\r\nin Johnny\xe2\x80\x99s light, and might have tried to bring him through it\r\nunbeknownst.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSloppy knew his ground well. To conceal herself in sickness, like a\r\nlower animal; to creep out of sight and coil herself away and die; had\r\nbecome this woman\xe2\x80\x99s instinct. To catch up in her arms the sick child who\r\nwas dear to her, and hide it as if it were a criminal, and keep off all\r\nministration but such as her own ignorant tenderness and patience could\r\nsupply, had become this woman\xe2\x80\x99s idea of maternal love, fidelity, and\r\nduty. The shameful accounts we read, every week in the Christian year,\r\nmy lords and gentlemen and honourable boards, the infamous records of\r\nsmall official inhumanity, do not pass by the people as they pass by\r\nus. And hence these irrational, blind, and obstinate prejudices, so\r\nastonishing to our magnificence, and having no more reason in them--God\r\nsave the Queen and Confound their politics--no, than smoke has in coming\r\nfrom fire!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s not a right place for the poor child to stay in,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Boffin.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Tell us, dear Mr Rokesmith, what to do for the best.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe had already thought what to do, and the consultation was very short.\r\nHe could pave the way, he said, in half an hour, and then they would go\r\ndown to Brentford. \xe2\x80\x98Pray take me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella. Therefore a carriage was\r\nordered, of capacity to take them all, and in the meantime Sloppy\r\nwas regaled, feasting alone in the Secretary\xe2\x80\x99s room, with a complete\r\nrealization of that fairy vision--meat, beer, vegetables, and pudding.\r\nIn consequence of which his buttons became more importunate of public\r\nnotice than before, with the exception of two or three about the region\r\nof the waistband, which modestly withdrew into a creasy retirement.\r\n\r\nPunctual to the time, appeared the carriage and the Secretary. He sat\r\non the box, and Mr Sloppy graced the rumble. So, to the Three Magpies as\r\nbefore: where Mrs Boffin and Miss Bella were handed out, and whence they\r\nall went on foot to Mrs Betty Higden\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\nBut, on the way down, they had stopped at a toy-shop, and had bought\r\nthat noble charger, a description of whose points and trappings had on\r\nthe last occasion conciliated the then worldly-minded orphan, and also a\r\nNoah\xe2\x80\x99s ark, and also a yellow bird with an artificial voice in him,\r\nand also a military doll so well dressed that if he had only been of\r\nlife-size his brother-officers in the Guards might never have found him\r\nout. Bearing these gifts, they raised the latch of Betty Higden\xe2\x80\x99s door,\r\nand saw her sitting in the dimmest and furthest corner with poor Johnny\r\nin her lap.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And how\xe2\x80\x99s my boy, Betty?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mrs Boffin, sitting down beside her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He\xe2\x80\x99s bad! He\xe2\x80\x99s bad!\xe2\x80\x99 said Betty. \xe2\x80\x98I begin to be afeerd he\xe2\x80\x99ll not be\r\nyours any more than mine. All others belonging to him have gone to\r\nthe Power and the Glory, and I have a mind that they\xe2\x80\x99re drawing him to\r\nthem--leading him away.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no, no,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Boffin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know why else he clenches his little hand as if it had hold of\r\na finger that I can\xe2\x80\x99t see. Look at it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Betty, opening the wrappers\r\nin which the flushed child lay, and showing his small right hand lying\r\nclosed upon his breast. \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s always so. It don\xe2\x80\x99t mind me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is he asleep?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, I think not. You\xe2\x80\x99re not asleep, my Johnny?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 said Johnny, with a quiet air of pity for himself; and without\r\nopening his eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here\xe2\x80\x99s the lady, Johnny. And the horse.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJohnny could bear the lady, with complete indifference, but not the\r\nhorse. Opening his heavy eyes, he slowly broke into a smile on beholding\r\nthat splendid phenomenon, and wanted to take it in his arms. As it was\r\nmuch too big, it was put upon a chair where he could hold it by the mane\r\nand contemplate it. Which he soon forgot to do.\r\n\r\nBut, Johnny murmuring something with his eyes closed, and Mrs Boffin\r\nnot knowing what, old Betty bent her ear to listen and took pains to\r\nunderstand. Being asked by her to repeat what he had said, he did so two\r\nor three times, and then it came out that he must have seen more than\r\nthey supposed when he looked up to see the horse, for the murmur was,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who is the boofer lady?\xe2\x80\x99 Now, the boofer, or beautiful, lady was Bella;\r\nand whereas this notice from the poor baby would have touched her of\r\nitself; it was rendered more pathetic by the late melting of her heart\r\nto her poor little father, and their joke about the lovely woman. So,\r\nBella\xe2\x80\x99s behaviour was very tender and very natural when she kneeled on\r\nthe brick floor to clasp the child, and when the child, with a child\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nadmiration of what is young and pretty, fondled the boofer lady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, my good dear Betty,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Boffin, hoping that she saw her\r\nopportunity, and laying her hand persuasively on her arm; \xe2\x80\x98we have come\r\nto remove Johnny from this cottage to where he can be taken better care\r\nof.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nInstantly, and before another word could be spoken, the old woman\r\nstarted up with blazing eyes, and rushed at the door with the sick\r\nchild.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stand away from me every one of ye!\xe2\x80\x99 she cried out wildly. \xe2\x80\x98I see what\r\nye mean now. Let me go my way, all of ye. I\xe2\x80\x99d sooner kill the Pretty,\r\nand kill myself!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stay, stay!\xe2\x80\x99 said Rokesmith, soothing her. \xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t understand.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I understand too well. I know too much about it, sir. I\xe2\x80\x99ve run from\r\nit too many a year. No! Never for me, nor for the child, while there\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwater enough in England to cover us!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe terror, the shame, the passion of horror and repugnance, firing the\r\nworn face and perfectly maddening it, would have been a quite terrible\r\nsight, if embodied in one old fellow-creature alone. Yet it \xe2\x80\x98crops\r\nup\xe2\x80\x99--as our slang goes--my lords and gentlemen and honourable boards, in\r\nother fellow-creatures, rather frequently!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s been chasing me all my life, but it shall never take me nor mine\r\nalive!\xe2\x80\x99 cried old Betty. \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve done with ye. I\xe2\x80\x99d have fastened door and\r\nwindow and starved out, afore I\xe2\x80\x99d ever have let ye in, if I had known\r\nwhat ye came for!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBut, catching sight of Mrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s wholesome face, she relented, and\r\ncrouching down by the door and bending over her burden to hush it, said\r\nhumbly: \xe2\x80\x98Maybe my fears has put me wrong. If they have so, tell me, and\r\nthe good Lord forgive me! I\xe2\x80\x99m quick to take this fright, I know, and my\r\nhead is summ\xe2\x80\x99at light with wearying and watching.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There, there, there!\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mrs Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98Come, come! Say no more of\r\nit, Betty. It was a mistake, a mistake. Any one of us might have made it\r\nin your place, and felt just as you do.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The Lord bless ye!\xe2\x80\x99 said the old woman, stretching out her hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, see, Betty,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued the sweet compassionate soul, holding the\r\nhand kindly, \xe2\x80\x98what I really did mean, and what I should have begun by\r\nsaying out, if I had only been a little wiser and handier. We want to\r\nmove Johnny to a place where there are none but children; a place set\r\nup on purpose for sick children; where the good doctors and nurses pass\r\ntheir lives with children, talk to none but children, touch none but\r\nchildren, comfort and cure none but children.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is there really such a place?\xe2\x80\x99 asked the old woman, with a gaze of\r\nwonder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, Betty, on my word, and you shall see it. If my home was a better\r\nplace for the dear boy, I\xe2\x80\x99d take him to it; but indeed indeed it\xe2\x80\x99s not.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You shall take him,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Betty, fervently kissing the comforting\r\nhand, \xe2\x80\x98where you will, my deary. I am not so hard, but that I believe\r\nyour face and voice, and I will, as long as I can see and hear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis victory gained, Rokesmith made haste to profit by it, for he saw\r\nhow woefully time had been lost. He despatched Sloppy to bring the\r\ncarriage to the door; caused the child to be carefully wrapped up; bade\r\nold Betty get her bonnet on; collected the toys, enabling the little\r\nfellow to comprehend that his treasures were to be transported with\r\nhim; and had all things prepared so easily that they were ready for\r\nthe carriage as soon as it appeared, and in a minute afterwards were\r\non their way. Sloppy they left behind, relieving his overcharged breast\r\nwith a paroxysm of mangling.\r\n\r\nAt the Children\xe2\x80\x99s Hospital, the gallant steed, the Noah\xe2\x80\x99s ark, yellow\r\nbird, and the officer in the Guards, were made as welcome as their\r\nchild-owner. But the doctor said aside to Rokesmith, \xe2\x80\x98This should have\r\nbeen days ago. Too late!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHowever, they were all carried up into a fresh airy room, and there\r\nJohnny came to himself, out of a sleep or a swoon or whatever it was,\r\nto find himself lying in a little quiet bed, with a little platform over\r\nhis breast, on which were already arranged, to give him heart and urge\r\nhim to cheer up, the Noah\xe2\x80\x99s ark, the noble steed, and the yellow bird;\r\nwith the officer in the Guards doing duty over the whole, quite as much\r\nto the satisfaction of his country as if he had been upon Parade. And at\r\nthe bed\xe2\x80\x99s head was a coloured picture beautiful to see, representing as\r\nit were another Johnny seated on the knee of some Angel surely who loved\r\nlittle children. And, marvellous fact, to lie and stare at: Johnny had\r\nbecome one of a little family, all in little quiet beds (except two\r\nplaying dominoes in little arm-chairs at a little table on the hearth):\r\nand on all the little beds were little platforms whereon were to be\r\nseen dolls\xe2\x80\x99 houses, woolly dogs with mechanical barks in them not very\r\ndissimilar from the artificial voice pervading the bowels of the yellow\r\nbird, tin armies, Moorish tumblers, wooden tea things, and the riches of\r\nthe earth.\r\n\r\nAs Johnny murmured something in his placid admiration, the ministering\r\nwomen at his bed\xe2\x80\x99s head asked him what he said. It seemed that he wanted\r\nto know whether all these were brothers and sisters of his? So they told\r\nhim yes. It seemed then, that he wanted to know whether God had brought\r\nthem all together there? So they told him yes again. They made out then,\r\nthat he wanted to know whether they would all get out of pain? So they\r\nanswered yes to that question likewise, and made him understand that the\r\nreply included himself.\r\n\r\nJohnny\xe2\x80\x99s powers of sustaining conversation were as yet so very\r\nimperfectly developed, even in a state of health, that in sickness they\r\nwere little more than monosyllabic. But, he had to be washed and tended,\r\nand remedies were applied, and though those offices were far, far more\r\nskilfully and lightly done than ever anything had been done for him in\r\nhis little life, so rough and short, they would have hurt and tired him\r\nbut for an amazing circumstance which laid hold of his attention. This\r\nwas no less than the appearance on his own little platform in pairs,\r\nof All Creation, on its way into his own particular ark: the elephant\r\nleading, and the fly, with a diffident sense of his size, politely\r\nbringing up the rear. A very little brother lying in the next bed with a\r\nbroken leg, was so enchanted by this spectacle that his delight exalted\r\nits enthralling interest; and so came rest and sleep.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I see you are not afraid to leave the dear child here, Betty,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nwhispered Mrs Boffin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, ma\xe2\x80\x99am. Most willingly, most thankfully, with all my heart and\r\nsoul.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSo, they kissed him, and left him there, and old Betty was to come back\r\nearly in the morning, and nobody but Rokesmith knew for certain how that\r\nthe doctor had said, \xe2\x80\x98This should have been days ago. Too late!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBut, Rokesmith knowing it, and knowing that his bearing it in mind would\r\nbe acceptable thereafter to that good woman who had been the only light\r\nin the childhood of desolate John Harmon dead and gone, resolved that\r\nlate at night he would go back to the bedside of John Harmon\xe2\x80\x99s namesake,\r\nand see how it fared with him.\r\n\r\nThe family whom God had brought together were not all asleep, but were\r\nall quiet. From bed to bed, a light womanly tread and a pleasant fresh\r\nface passed in the silence of the night. A little head would lift itself\r\nup into the softened light here and there, to be kissed as the face went\r\nby--for these little patients are very loving--and would then submit\r\nitself to be composed to rest again. The mite with the broken leg was\r\nrestless, and moaned; but after a while turned his face towards Johnny\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbed, to fortify himself with a view of the ark, and fell asleep. Over\r\nmost of the beds, the toys were yet grouped as the children had left\r\nthem when they last laid themselves down, and, in their innocent\r\ngrotesqueness and incongruity, they might have stood for the children\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndreams.\r\n\r\nThe doctor came in too, to see how it fared with Johnny. And he and\r\nRokesmith stood together, looking down with compassion on him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What is it, Johnny?\xe2\x80\x99 Rokesmith was the questioner, and put an arm round\r\nthe poor baby as he made a struggle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Him!\xe2\x80\x99 said the little fellow. \xe2\x80\x98Those!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe doctor was quick to understand children, and, taking the horse,\r\nthe ark, the yellow bird, and the man in the Guards, from Johnny\xe2\x80\x99s bed,\r\nsoftly placed them on that of his next neighbour, the mite with the\r\nbroken leg.\r\n\r\nWith a weary and yet a pleased smile, and with an action as if he\r\nstretched his little figure out to rest, the child heaved his body on\r\nthe sustaining arm, and seeking Rokesmith\xe2\x80\x99s face with his lips, said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A kiss for the boofer lady.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHaving now bequeathed all he had to dispose of, and arranged his affairs\r\nin this world, Johnny, thus speaking, left it.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 10\r\n\r\nA SUCCESSOR\r\n\r\n\r\nSome of the Reverend Frank Milvey\xe2\x80\x99s brethren had found themselves\r\nexceedingly uncomfortable in their minds, because they were required to\r\nbury the dead too hopefully. But, the Reverend Frank, inclining to the\r\nbelief that they were required to do one or two other things (say out of\r\nnine-and-thirty) calculated to trouble their consciences rather more if\r\nthey would think as much about them, held his peace.\r\n\r\nIndeed, the Reverend Frank Milvey was a forbearing man, who noticed many\r\nsad warps and blights in the vineyard wherein he worked, and did not\r\nprofess that they made him savagely wise. He only learned that the more\r\nhe himself knew, in his little limited human way, the better he could\r\ndistantly imagine what Omniscience might know.\r\n\r\nWherefore, if the Reverend Frank had had to read the words that troubled\r\nsome of his brethren, and profitably touched innumerable hearts, in\r\na worse case than Johnny\xe2\x80\x99s, he would have done so out of the pity and\r\nhumility of his soul. Reading them over Johnny, he thought of his own\r\nsix children, but not of his poverty, and read them with dimmed eyes.\r\nAnd very seriously did he and his bright little wife, who had been\r\nlistening, look down into the small grave and walk home arm-in-arm.\r\n\r\nThere was grief in the aristocratic house, and there was joy in the\r\nBower. Mr Wegg argued, if an orphan were wanted, was he not an orphan\r\nhimself; and could a better be desired? And why go beating about\r\nBrentford bushes, seeking orphans forsooth who had established no claims\r\nupon you and made no sacrifices for you, when here was an orphan ready\r\nto your hand who had given up in your cause, Miss Elizabeth, Master\r\nGeorge, Aunt Jane, and Uncle Parker?\r\n\r\nMr Wegg chuckled, consequently, when he heard the tidings. Nay, it was\r\nafterwards affirmed by a witness who shall at present be nameless,\r\nthat in the seclusion of the Bower he poked out his wooden leg, in the\r\nstage-ballet manner, and executed a taunting or triumphant pirouette on\r\nthe genuine leg remaining to him.\r\n\r\nJohn Rokesmith\xe2\x80\x99s manner towards Mrs Boffin at this time, was more the\r\nmanner of a young man towards a mother, than that of a Secretary towards\r\nhis employer\xe2\x80\x99s wife. It had always been marked by a subdued affectionate\r\ndeference that seemed to have sprung up on the very day of his\r\nengagement; whatever was odd in her dress or her ways had seemed to have\r\nno oddity for him; he had sometimes borne a quietly-amused face in her\r\ncompany, but still it had seemed as if the pleasure her genial temper\r\nand radiant nature yielded him, could have been quite as naturally\r\nexpressed in a tear as in a smile. The completeness of his sympathy with\r\nher fancy for having a little John Harmon to protect and rear, he\r\nhad shown in every act and word, and now that the kind fancy was\r\ndisappointed, he treated it with a manly tenderness and respect for\r\nwhich she could hardly thank him enough.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I do thank you, Mr Rokesmith,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98and I thank you\r\nmost kindly. You love children.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope everybody does.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They ought,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Boffin; \xe2\x80\x98but we don\xe2\x80\x99t all of us do what we ought,\r\ndo us?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJohn Rokesmith replied, \xe2\x80\x98Some among us supply the short-comings of the\r\nrest. You have loved children well, Mr Boffin has told me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not a bit better than he has, but that\xe2\x80\x99s his way; he puts all the good\r\nupon me. You speak rather sadly, Mr Rokesmith.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do I?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It sounds to me so. Were you one of many children?\xe2\x80\x99 He shook his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98An only child?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No there was another. Dead long ago.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Father or mother alive?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dead.\xe2\x80\x99--\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And the rest of your relations?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dead--if I ever had any living. I never heard of any.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAt this point of the dialogue Bella came in with a light step. She\r\npaused at the door a moment, hesitating whether to remain or retire;\r\nperplexed by finding that she was not observed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, don\xe2\x80\x99t mind an old lady\xe2\x80\x99s talk,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98but tell me. Are\r\nyou quite sure, Mr Rokesmith, that you have never had a disappointment\r\nin love?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Quite sure. Why do you ask me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, for this reason. Sometimes you have a kind of kept-down manner\r\nwith you, which is not like your age. You can\xe2\x80\x99t be thirty?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am not yet thirty.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDeeming it high time to make her presence known, Bella coughed here to\r\nattract attention, begged pardon, and said she would go, fearing that\r\nshe interrupted some matter of business.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, don\xe2\x80\x99t go,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Mrs Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98because we are coming to business,\r\ninstead of having begun it, and you belong to it as much now, my dear\r\nBella, as I do. But I want my Noddy to consult with us. Would somebody\r\nbe so good as find my Noddy for me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nRokesmith departed on that errand, and presently returned accompanied by\r\nMr Boffin at his jog-trot. Bella felt a little vague trepidation as to\r\nthe subject-matter of this same consultation, until Mrs Boffin announced\r\nit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, you come and sit by me, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said that worthy soul, taking\r\nher comfortable place on a large ottoman in the centre of the room,\r\nand drawing her arm through Bella\xe2\x80\x99s; \xe2\x80\x98and Noddy, you sit here, and Mr\r\nRokesmith you sit there. Now, you see, what I want to talk about, is\r\nthis. Mr and Mrs Milvey have sent me the kindest note possible (which\r\nMr Rokesmith just now read to me out aloud, for I ain\xe2\x80\x99t good at\r\nhandwritings), offering to find me another little child to name and\r\neducate and bring up. Well. This has set me thinking.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n[\xe2\x80\x98And she is a steam-ingein at it,\xe2\x80\x99 murmured Mr Boffin, in an admiring\r\nparenthesis, \xe2\x80\x98when she once begins. It mayn\xe2\x80\x99t be so easy to start her;\r\nbut once started, she\xe2\x80\x99s a ingein.\xe2\x80\x99)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98--This has set me thinking, I say,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Mrs Boffin, cordially\r\nbeaming under the influence of her husband\xe2\x80\x99s compliment, \xe2\x80\x98and I have\r\nthought two things. First of all, that I have grown timid of reviving\r\nJohn Harmon\xe2\x80\x99s name. It\xe2\x80\x99s an unfortunate name, and I fancy I should\r\nreproach myself if I gave it to another dear child, and it proved again\r\nunlucky.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, whether,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, gravely propounding a case for his\r\nSecretary\xe2\x80\x99s opinion; \xe2\x80\x98whether one might call that a superstition?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is a matter of feeling with Mrs Boffin,\xe2\x80\x99 said Rokesmith, gently.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The name has always been unfortunate. It has now this new unfortunate\r\nassociation connected with it. The name has died out. Why revive it?\r\nMight I ask Miss Wilfer what she thinks?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It has not been a fortunate name for me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, colouring--\xe2\x80\x98or\r\nat least it was not, until it led to my being here--but that is not the\r\npoint in my thoughts. As we had given the name to the poor child, and as\r\nthe poor child took so lovingly to me, I think I should feel jealous of\r\ncalling another child by it. I think I should feel as if the name had\r\nbecome endeared to me, and I had no right to use it so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And that\xe2\x80\x99s your opinion?\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Mr Boffin, observant of the\r\nSecretary\xe2\x80\x99s face and again addressing him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I say again, it is a matter of feeling,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the Secretary. \xe2\x80\x98I\r\nthink Miss Wilfer\xe2\x80\x99s feeling very womanly and pretty.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, give us your opinion, Noddy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Boffin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My opinion, old lady,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the Golden Dustman, \xe2\x80\x98is your opinion.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98we agree not to revive John Harmon\xe2\x80\x99s name, but\r\nto let it rest in the grave. It is, as Mr Rokesmith says, a matter of\r\nfeeling, but Lor how many matters ARE matters of feeling! Well; and so\r\nI come to the second thing I have thought of. You must know, Bella,\r\nmy dear, and Mr Rokesmith, that when I first named to my husband my\r\nthoughts of adopting a little orphan boy in remembrance of John Harmon,\r\nI further named to my husband that it was comforting to think that how\r\nthe poor boy would be benefited by John\xe2\x80\x99s own money, and protected from\r\nJohn\xe2\x80\x99s own forlornness.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hear, hear!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98So she did. Ancoar!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, not Ancoar, Noddy, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mrs Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98because I am\r\ngoing to say something else. I meant that, I am sure, as much as\r\nI still mean it. But this little death has made me ask myself the\r\nquestion, seriously, whether I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t too bent upon pleasing myself.\r\nElse why did I seek out so much for a pretty child, and a child quite to\r\nmy liking? Wanting to do good, why not do it for its own sake, and put\r\nmy tastes and likings by?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Perhaps,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella; and perhaps she said it with some little\r\nsensitiveness arising out of those old curious relations of hers towards\r\nthe murdered man; \xe2\x80\x98perhaps, in reviving the name, you would not have\r\nliked to give it to a less interesting child than the original. He\r\ninterested you very much.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mrs Boffin, giving her a squeeze, \xe2\x80\x98it\xe2\x80\x99s kind\r\nof you to find that reason out, and I hope it may have been so, and\r\nindeed to a certain extent I believe it was so, but I am afraid not to\r\nthe whole extent. However, that don\xe2\x80\x99t come in question now, because we\r\nhave done with the name.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Laid it up as a remembrance,\xe2\x80\x99 suggested Bella, musingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Much better said, my dear; laid it up as a remembrance. Well then; I\r\nhave been thinking if I take any orphan to provide for, let it not be\r\na pet and a plaything for me, but a creature to be helped for its own\r\nsake.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not pretty then?\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mrs Boffin, stoutly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nor prepossessing then?\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mrs Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98Not necessarily so. That\xe2\x80\x99s as it may happen.\r\nA well-disposed boy comes in my way who may be even a little wanting in\r\nsuch advantages for getting on in life, but is honest and industrious\r\nand requires a helping hand and deserves it. If I am very much in\r\nearnest and quite determined to be unselfish, let me take care of HIM.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHere the footman whose feelings had been hurt on the former occasion,\r\nappeared, and crossing to Rokesmith apologetically announced the\r\nobjectionable Sloppy.\r\n\r\nThe four members of Council looked at one another, and paused. \xe2\x80\x98Shall he\r\nbe brought here, ma\xe2\x80\x99am?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Rokesmith.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Boffin. Whereupon the footman disappeared, reappeared\r\npresenting Sloppy, and retired much disgusted.\r\n\r\nThe consideration of Mrs Boffin had clothed Mr Sloppy in a suit of\r\nblack, on which the tailor had received personal directions from\r\nRokesmith to expend the utmost cunning of his art, with a view to the\r\nconcealment of the cohering and sustaining buttons. But, so much\r\nmore powerful were the frailties of Sloppy\xe2\x80\x99s form than the strongest\r\nresources of tailoring science, that he now stood before the Council,\r\na perfect Argus in the way of buttons: shining and winking and gleaming\r\nand twinkling out of a hundred of those eyes of bright metal, at the\r\ndazzled spectators. The artistic taste of some unknown hatter had\r\nfurnished him with a hatband of wholesale capacity which was fluted\r\nbehind, from the crown of his hat to the brim, and terminated in a black\r\nbunch, from which the imagination shrunk discomfited and the reason\r\nrevolted. Some special powers with which his legs were endowed, had\r\nalready hitched up his glossy trousers at the ankles, and bagged them at\r\nthe knees; while similar gifts in his arms had raised his coat-sleeves\r\nfrom his wrists and accumulated them at his elbows. Thus set forth, with\r\nthe additional embellishments of a very little tail to his coat, and a\r\nyawning gulf at his waistband, Sloppy stood confessed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And how is Betty, my good fellow?\xe2\x80\x99 Mrs Boffin asked him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thankee, mum,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sloppy, \xe2\x80\x98she do pretty nicely, and sending her\r\ndooty and many thanks for the tea and all faviours and wishing to know\r\nthe family\xe2\x80\x99s healths.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have you just come, Sloppy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, mum.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then you have not had your dinner yet?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, mum. But I mean to it. For I ain\xe2\x80\x99t forgotten your handsome orders\r\nthat I was never to go away without having had a good \xe2\x80\x98un off of meat\r\nand beer and pudding--no: there was four of \xe2\x80\x98em, for I reckoned \xe2\x80\x98em\r\nup when I had \xe2\x80\x98em; meat one, beer two, vegetables three, and which was\r\nfour?--Why, pudding, HE was four!\xe2\x80\x99 Here Sloppy threw his head back,\r\nopened his mouth wide, and laughed rapturously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How are the two poor little Minders?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mrs Boffin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Striking right out, mum, and coming round beautiful.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs Boffin looked on the other three members of Council, and then said,\r\nbeckoning with her finger:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sloppy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, mum.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come forward, Sloppy. Should you like to dine here every day?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Off of all four on \xe2\x80\x98em, mum?
