O mum!\xe2\x80\x99 Sloppy\xe2\x80\x99s feelings obliged him to\r\nsqueeze his hat, and contract one leg at the knee.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. And should you like to be always taken care of here, if you were\r\nindustrious and deserving?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, mum!--But there\xe2\x80\x99s Mrs Higden,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sloppy, checking himself in his\r\nraptures, drawing back, and shaking his head with very serious meaning.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s Mrs Higden. Mrs Higden goes before all. None can ever be better\r\nfriends to me than Mrs Higden\xe2\x80\x99s been. And she must be turned for, must\r\nMrs Higden. Where would Mrs Higden be if she warn\xe2\x80\x99t turned for!\xe2\x80\x99 At the\r\nmere thought of Mrs Higden in this inconceivable affliction, Mr Sloppy\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncountenance became pale, and manifested the most distressful emotions.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are as right as right can be, Sloppy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Boffin \xe2\x80\x98and far be\r\nit from me to tell you otherwise. It shall be seen to. If Betty Higden\r\ncan be turned for all the same, you shall come here and be taken care of\r\nfor life, and be made able to keep her in other ways than the turning.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Even as to that, mum,\xe2\x80\x99 answered the ecstatic Sloppy, \xe2\x80\x98the turning might\r\nbe done in the night, don\xe2\x80\x99t you see? I could be here in the day, and\r\nturn in the night. I don\xe2\x80\x99t want no sleep, I don\xe2\x80\x99t. Or even if I any ways\r\nshould want a wink or two,\xe2\x80\x99 added Sloppy, after a moment\xe2\x80\x99s apologetic\r\nreflection, \xe2\x80\x98I could take \xe2\x80\x98em turning. I\xe2\x80\x99ve took \xe2\x80\x98em turning many a\r\ntime, and enjoyed \xe2\x80\x98em wonderful!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nOn the grateful impulse of the moment, Mr Sloppy kissed Mrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhand, and then detaching himself from that good creature that he might\r\nhave room enough for his feelings, threw back his head, opened his mouth\r\nwide, and uttered a dismal howl. It was creditable to his tenderness of\r\nheart, but suggested that he might on occasion give some offence to the\r\nneighbours: the rather, as the footman looked in, and begged pardon,\r\nfinding he was not wanted, but excused himself; on the ground \xe2\x80\x98that he\r\nthought it was Cats.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 11\r\n\r\nSOME AFFAIRS OF THE HEART\r\n\r\n\r\nLittle Miss Peecher, from her little official dwelling-house, with its\r\nlittle windows like the eyes in needles, and its little doors like the\r\ncovers of school-books, was very observant indeed of the object of her\r\nquiet affections. Love, though said to be afflicted with blindness, is\r\na vigilant watchman, and Miss Peecher kept him on double duty over Mr\r\nBradley Headstone. It was not that she was naturally given to playing\r\nthe spy--it was not that she was at all secret, plotting, or mean--it\r\nwas simply that she loved the irresponsive Bradley with all the\r\nprimitive and homely stock of love that had never been examined or\r\ncertificated out of her. If her faithful slate had had the latent\r\nqualities of sympathetic paper, and its pencil those of invisible ink,\r\nmany a little treatise calculated to astonish the pupils would have come\r\nbursting through the dry sums in school-time under the warming influence\r\nof Miss Peecher\xe2\x80\x99s bosom. For, oftentimes when school was not, and her\r\ncalm leisure and calm little house were her own, Miss Peecher would\r\ncommit to the confidential slate an imaginary description of how, upon\r\na balmy evening at dusk, two figures might have been observed in the\r\nmarket-garden ground round the corner, of whom one, being a manly form,\r\nbent over the other, being a womanly form of short stature and some\r\ncompactness, and breathed in a low voice the words, \xe2\x80\x98Emma Peecher, wilt\r\nthou be my own?\xe2\x80\x99 after which the womanly form\xe2\x80\x99s head reposed upon the\r\nmanly form\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder, and the nightingales tuned up. Though all unseen,\r\nand unsuspected by the pupils, Bradley Headstone even pervaded the\r\nschool exercises. Was Geography in question? He would come triumphantly\r\nflying out of Vesuvius and Aetna ahead of the lava, and would boil\r\nunharmed in the hot springs of Iceland, and would float majestically\r\ndown the Ganges and the Nile. Did History chronicle a king of men?\r\nBehold him in pepper-and-salt pantaloons, with his watch-guard round\r\nhis neck. Were copies to be written? In capital B\xe2\x80\x99s and H\xe2\x80\x99s most of the\r\ngirls under Miss Peecher\xe2\x80\x99s tuition were half a year ahead of every other\r\nletter in the alphabet. And Mental Arithmetic, administered by Miss\r\nPeecher, often devoted itself to providing Bradley Headstone with a\r\nwardrobe of fabulous extent: fourscore and four neck-ties at two and\r\nninepence-halfpenny, two gross of silver watches at four pounds fifteen\r\nand sixpence, seventy-four black hats at eighteen shillings; and many\r\nsimilar superfluities.\r\n\r\nThe vigilant watchman, using his daily opportunities of turning his eyes\r\nin Bradley\xe2\x80\x99s direction, soon apprized Miss Peecher that Bradley was more\r\npreoccupied than had been his wont, and more given to strolling about\r\nwith a downcast and reserved face, turning something difficult in his\r\nmind that was not in the scholastic syllabus. Putting this and that\r\ntogether--combining under the head \xe2\x80\x98this,\xe2\x80\x99 present appearances and the\r\nintimacy with Charley Hexam, and ranging under the head \xe2\x80\x98that\xe2\x80\x99 the\r\nvisit to his sister, the watchman reported to Miss Peecher his strong\r\nsuspicions that the sister was at the bottom of it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wonder,\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Peecher, as she sat making up her weekly report on\r\na half-holiday afternoon, \xe2\x80\x98what they call Hexam\xe2\x80\x99s sister?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMary Anne, at her needlework, attendant and attentive, held her arm up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, Mary Anne?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She is named Lizzie, ma\xe2\x80\x99am.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She can hardly be named Lizzie, I think, Mary Anne,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Miss\r\nPeecher, in a tunefully instructive voice. \xe2\x80\x98Is Lizzie a Christian name,\r\nMary Anne?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMary Anne laid down her work, rose, hooked herself behind, as being\r\nunder catechization, and replied: \xe2\x80\x98No, it is a corruption, Miss\r\nPeecher.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who gave her that name?\xe2\x80\x99 Miss Peecher was going on, from the mere force\r\nof habit, when she checked herself; on Mary Anne\xe2\x80\x99s evincing theological\r\nimpatience to strike in with her godfathers and her godmothers, and\r\nsaid: \xe2\x80\x98I mean of what name is it a corruption?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Elizabeth, or Eliza, Miss Peecher.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Right, Mary Anne. Whether there were any Lizzies in the early Christian\r\nChurch must be considered very doubtful, very doubtful.\xe2\x80\x99 Miss Peecher\r\nwas exceedingly sage here. \xe2\x80\x98Speaking correctly, we say, then, that\r\nHexam\xe2\x80\x99s sister is called Lizzie; not that she is named so. Do we not,\r\nMary Anne?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We do, Miss Peecher.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And where,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued Miss Peecher, complacent in her little transparent\r\nfiction of conducting the examination in a semiofficial manner for Mary\r\nAnne\xe2\x80\x99s benefit, not her own, \xe2\x80\x98where does this young woman, who is called\r\nbut not named Lizzie, live? Think, now, before answering.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In Church Street, Smith Square, by Mill Bank, ma\xe2\x80\x99am.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In Church Street, Smith Square, by Mill Bank,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Miss Peecher,\r\nas if possessed beforehand of the book in which it was written. Exactly\r\nso. And what occupation does this young woman pursue, Mary Anne? Take\r\ntime.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She has a place of trust at an outfitter\xe2\x80\x99s in the City, ma\xe2\x80\x99am.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh!\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Peecher, pondering on it; but smoothly added, in a\r\nconfirmatory tone, \xe2\x80\x98At an outfitter\xe2\x80\x99s in the City. Ye-es?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And Charley--\xe2\x80\x99 Mary Anne was proceeding, when Miss Peecher stared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I mean Hexam, Miss Peecher.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should think you did, Mary Anne. I am glad to hear you do. And\r\nHexam--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Says,\xe2\x80\x99 Mary Anne went on, \xe2\x80\x98that he is not pleased with his sister, and\r\nthat his sister won\xe2\x80\x99t be guided by his advice, and persists in being\r\nguided by somebody else\xe2\x80\x99s; and that--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Headstone coming across the garden!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Miss Peecher, with a\r\nflushed glance at the looking-glass. \xe2\x80\x98You have answered very well, Mary\r\nAnne. You are forming an excellent habit of arranging your thoughts\r\nclearly. That will do.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe discreet Mary Anne resumed her seat and her silence, and stitched,\r\nand stitched, and was stitching when the schoolmaster\xe2\x80\x99s shadow came in\r\nbefore him, announcing that he might be instantly expected.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good evening, Miss Peecher,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, pursuing the shadow, and taking\r\nits place.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good evening, Mr Headstone. Mary Anne, a chair.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bradley, seating himself in his constrained manner.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is but a flying visit. I have looked in, on my way, to ask a\r\nkindness of you as a neighbour.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did you say on your way, Mr Headstone?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Miss Peecher.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98On my way to--where I am going.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Church Street, Smith Square, by Mill Bank,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Miss Peecher, in\r\nher own thoughts.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Charley Hexam has gone to get a book or two he wants, and will probably\r\nbe back before me. As we leave my house empty, I took the liberty of\r\ntelling him I would leave the key here. Would you kindly allow me to do\r\nso?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly, Mr Headstone. Going for an evening walk, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Partly for a walk, and partly for--on business.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Business in Church Street, Smith Square, by Mill Bank,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Miss\r\nPeecher to herself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Having said which,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued Bradley, laying his door-key on the table,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I must be already going. There is nothing I can do for you, Miss\r\nPeecher?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you, Mr Headstone. In which direction?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In the direction of Westminster.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mill Bank,\xe2\x80\x99 Miss Peecher repeated in her own thoughts once again. \xe2\x80\x98No,\r\nthank you, Mr Headstone; I\xe2\x80\x99ll not trouble you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You couldn\xe2\x80\x99t trouble me,\xe2\x80\x99 said the schoolmaster.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah!\xe2\x80\x99 returned Miss Peecher, though not aloud; \xe2\x80\x98but you can trouble\r\nME!\xe2\x80\x99 And for all her quiet manner, and her quiet smile, she was full of\r\ntrouble as he went his way.\r\n\r\nShe was right touching his destination. He held as straight a course\r\nfor the house of the dolls\xe2\x80\x99 dressmaker as the wisdom of his ancestors,\r\nexemplified in the construction of the intervening streets, would let\r\nhim, and walked with a bent head hammering at one fixed idea. It had\r\nbeen an immoveable idea since he first set eyes upon her. It seemed to\r\nhim as if all that he could suppress in himself he had suppressed, as\r\nif all that he could restrain in himself he had restrained, and the time\r\nhad come--in a rush, in a moment--when the power of self-command had\r\ndeparted from him. Love at first sight is a trite expression quite\r\nsufficiently discussed; enough that in certain smouldering natures like\r\nthis man\xe2\x80\x99s, that passion leaps into a blaze, and makes such head as fire\r\ndoes in a rage of wind, when other passions, but for its mastery, could\r\nbe held in chains. As a multitude of weak, imitative natures are\r\nalways lying by, ready to go mad upon the next wrong idea that may be\r\nbroached--in these times, generally some form of tribute to Somebody\r\nfor something that never was done, or, if ever done, that was done by\r\nSomebody Else--so these less ordinary natures may lie by for years,\r\nready on the touch of an instant to burst into flame.\r\n\r\nThe schoolmaster went his way, brooding and brooding, and a sense of\r\nbeing vanquished in a struggle might have been pieced out of his worried\r\nface. Truly, in his breast there lingered a resentful shame to find\r\nhimself defeated by this passion for Charley Hexam\xe2\x80\x99s sister, though in\r\nthe very self-same moments he was concentrating himself upon the object\r\nof bringing the passion to a successful issue.\r\n\r\nHe appeared before the dolls\xe2\x80\x99 dressmaker, sitting alone at her work.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oho!\xe2\x80\x99 thought that sharp young personage, \xe2\x80\x98it\xe2\x80\x99s you, is it? I know your\r\ntricks and your manners, my friend!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hexam\xe2\x80\x99s sister,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bradley Headstone, \xe2\x80\x98is not come home yet?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are quite a conjuror,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Miss Wren.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I will wait, if you please, for I want to speak to her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you?\xe2\x80\x99 returned Miss Wren. \xe2\x80\x98Sit down. I hope it\xe2\x80\x99s mutual.\xe2\x80\x99 Bradley\r\nglanced distrustfully at the shrewd face again bending over the work,\r\nand said, trying to conquer doubt and hesitation:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope you don\xe2\x80\x99t imply that my visit will be unacceptable to Hexam\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsister?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There! Don\xe2\x80\x99t call her that. I can\xe2\x80\x99t bear you to call her that,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nreturned Miss Wren, snapping her fingers in a volley of impatient snaps,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98for I don\xe2\x80\x99t like Hexam.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Indeed?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No.\xe2\x80\x99 Miss Wren wrinkled her nose, to express dislike. \xe2\x80\x98Selfish. Thinks\r\nonly of himself. The way with all of you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The way with all of us? Then you don\xe2\x80\x99t like ME?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So-so,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Miss Wren, with a shrug and a laugh. \xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t know much\r\nabout you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I was not aware it was the way with all of us,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bradley,\r\nreturning to the accusation, a little injured. \xe2\x80\x98Won\xe2\x80\x99t you say, some of\r\nus?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Meaning,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the little creature, \xe2\x80\x98every one of you, but you.\r\nHah! Now look this lady in the face. This is Mrs Truth. The Honourable.\r\nFull-dressed.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBradley glanced at the doll she held up for his observation--which had\r\nbeen lying on its face on her bench, while with a needle and thread she\r\nfastened the dress on at the back--and looked from it to her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I stand the Honourable Mrs T. on my bench in this corner against the\r\nwall, where her blue eyes can shine upon you,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued Miss Wren, doing\r\nso, and making two little dabs at him in the air with her needle, as\r\nif she pricked him with it in his own eyes; \xe2\x80\x98and I defy you to tell me,\r\nwith Mrs T. for a witness, what you have come here for.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To see Hexam\xe2\x80\x99s sister.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t say so!\xe2\x80\x99 retorted Miss Wren, hitching her chin. \xe2\x80\x98But on whose\r\naccount?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Her own.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O Mrs T.!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Miss Wren. \xe2\x80\x98You hear him!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To reason with her,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued Bradley, half humouring what was present,\r\nand half angry with what was not present; \xe2\x80\x98for her own sake.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh Mrs T.!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed the dressmaker.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98For her own sake,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Bradley, warming, \xe2\x80\x98and for her brother\xe2\x80\x99s,\r\nand as a perfectly disinterested person.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Really, Mrs T.,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked the dressmaker, \xe2\x80\x98since it comes to this, we\r\nmust positively turn you with your face to the wall.\xe2\x80\x99 She had hardly\r\ndone so, when Lizzie Hexam arrived, and showed some surprise on seeing\r\nBradley Headstone there, and Jenny shaking her little fist at him close\r\nbefore her eyes, and the Honourable Mrs T. with her face to the wall.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here\xe2\x80\x99s a perfectly disinterested person, Lizzie dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said the knowing\r\nMiss Wren, \xe2\x80\x98come to talk with you, for your own sake and your brother\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\nThink of that. I am sure there ought to be no third party present at\r\nanything so very kind and so very serious; and so, if you\xe2\x80\x99ll remove the\r\nthird party upstairs, my dear, the third party will retire.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLizzie took the hand which the dolls\xe2\x80\x99 dressmaker held out to her for\r\nthe purpose of being supported away, but only looked at her with an\r\ninquiring smile, and made no other movement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The third party hobbles awfully, you know, when she\xe2\x80\x99s left to herself;\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Miss Wren, \xe2\x80\x98her back being so bad, and her legs so queer; so she\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t retire gracefully unless you help her, Lizzie.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She can do no better than stay where she is,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Lizzie,\r\nreleasing the hand, and laying her own lightly on Miss Jenny\xe2\x80\x99s curls.\r\nAnd then to Bradley: \xe2\x80\x98From Charley, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIn an irresolute way, and stealing a clumsy look at her, Bradley rose to\r\nplace a chair for her, and then returned to his own.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Strictly speaking,\xe2\x80\x99 said he, \xe2\x80\x98I come from Charley, because I left him\r\nonly a little while ago; but I am not commissioned by Charley. I come of\r\nmy own spontaneous act.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith her elbows on her bench, and her chin upon her hands, Miss Jenny\r\nWren sat looking at him with a watchful sidelong look. Lizzie, in her\r\ndifferent way, sat looking at him too.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The fact is,\xe2\x80\x99 began Bradley, with a mouth so dry that he had some\r\ndifficulty in articulating his words: the consciousness of which\r\nrendered his manner still more ungainly and undecided; \xe2\x80\x98the truth is,\r\nthat Charley, having no secrets from me (to the best of my belief), has\r\nconfided the whole of this matter to me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe came to a stop, and Lizzie asked: \xe2\x80\x98what matter, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I thought,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the schoolmaster, stealing another look at her,\r\nand seeming to try in vain to sustain it; for the look dropped as it\r\nlighted on her eyes, \xe2\x80\x98that it might be so superfluous as to be almost\r\nimpertinent, to enter upon a definition of it. My allusion was to this\r\nmatter of your having put aside your brother\xe2\x80\x99s plans for you, and\r\ngiven the preference to those of Mr--I believe the name is Mr Eugene\r\nWrayburn.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe made this point of not being certain of the name, with another uneasy\r\nlook at her, which dropped like the last.\r\n\r\nNothing being said on the other side, he had to begin again, and began\r\nwith new embarrassment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your brother\xe2\x80\x99s plans were communicated to me when he first had them in\r\nhis thoughts. In point of fact he spoke to me about them when I was\r\nlast here--when we were walking back together, and when I--when the\r\nimpression was fresh upon me of having seen his sister.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere might have been no meaning in it, but the little dressmaker here\r\nremoved one of her supporting hands from her chin, and musingly turned\r\nthe Honourable Mrs T. with her face to the company. That done, she fell\r\ninto her former attitude.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I approved of his idea,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bradley, with his uneasy look wandering\r\nto the doll, and unconsciously resting there longer than it had\r\nrested on Lizzie, \xe2\x80\x98both because your brother ought naturally to be the\r\noriginator of any such scheme, and because I hoped to be able to promote\r\nit. I should have had inexpressible pleasure, I should have taken\r\ninexpressible interest, in promoting it. Therefore I must acknowledge\r\nthat when your brother was disappointed, I too was disappointed. I wish\r\nto avoid reservation or concealment, and I fully acknowledge that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe appeared to have encouraged himself by having got so far. At all\r\nevents he went on with much greater firmness and force of emphasis:\r\nthough with a curious disposition to set his teeth, and with a curious\r\ntight-screwing movement of his right hand in the clenching palm of his\r\nleft, like the action of one who was being physically hurt, and was\r\nunwilling to cry out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am a man of strong feelings, and I have strongly felt this\r\ndisappointment. I do strongly feel it. I don\xe2\x80\x99t show what I feel; some\r\nof us are obliged habitually to keep it down. To keep it down. But to\r\nreturn to your brother. He has taken the matter so much to heart that\r\nhe has remonstrated (in my presence he remonstrated) with Mr Eugene\r\nWrayburn, if that be the name. He did so, quite ineffectually. As any\r\none not blinded to the real character of Mr--Mr Eugene Wrayburn--would\r\nreadily suppose.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe looked at Lizzie again, and held the look. And his face turned from\r\nburning red to white, and from white back to burning red, and so for the\r\ntime to lasting deadly white.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Finally, I resolved to come here alone, and appeal to you. I resolved\r\nto come here alone, and entreat you to retract the course you have\r\nchosen, and instead of confiding in a mere stranger--a person of most\r\ninsolent behaviour to your brother and others--to prefer your brother\r\nand your brother\xe2\x80\x99s friend.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLizzie Hexam had changed colour when those changes came over him, and\r\nher face now expressed some anger, more dislike, and even a touch of\r\nfear. But she answered him very steadily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I cannot doubt, Mr Headstone, that your visit is well meant. You have\r\nbeen so good a friend to Charley that I have no right to doubt it. I\r\nhave nothing to tell Charley, but that I accepted the help to which he\r\nso much objects before he made any plans for me; or certainly before I\r\nknew of any. It was considerately and delicately offered, and there were\r\nreasons that had weight with me which should be as dear to Charley as to\r\nme. I have no more to say to Charley on this subject.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHis lips trembled and stood apart, as he followed this repudiation of\r\nhimself; and limitation of her words to her brother.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should have told Charley, if he had come to me,\xe2\x80\x99 she resumed, as\r\nthough it were an after-thought, \xe2\x80\x98that Jenny and I find our teacher very\r\nable and very patient, and that she takes great pains with us. So much\r\nso, that we have said to her we hope in a very little while to be able\r\nto go on by ourselves. Charley knows about teachers, and I should also\r\nhave told him, for his satisfaction, that ours comes from an institution\r\nwhere teachers are regularly brought up.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should like to ask you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bradley Headstone, grinding his words\r\nslowly out, as though they came from a rusty mill; \xe2\x80\x98I should like to\r\nask you, if I may without offence, whether you would have objected--no;\r\nrather, I should like to say, if I may without offence, that I wish I\r\nhad had the opportunity of coming here with your brother and devoting my\r\npoor abilities and experience to your service.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you, Mr Headstone.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I fear,\xe2\x80\x99 he pursued, after a pause, furtively wrenching at the seat\r\nof his chair with one hand, as if he would have wrenched the chair to\r\npieces, and gloomily observing her while her eyes were cast down, \xe2\x80\x98that\r\nmy humble services would not have found much favour with you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe made no reply, and the poor stricken wretch sat contending with\r\nhimself in a heat of passion and torment. After a while he took out his\r\nhandkerchief and wiped his forehead and hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There is only one thing more I had to say, but it is the most\r\nimportant. There is a reason against this matter, there is a personal\r\nrelation concerned in this matter, not yet explained to you. It might--I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t say it would--it might--induce you to think differently. To\r\nproceed under the present circumstances is out of the question. Will you\r\nplease come to the understanding that there shall be another interview\r\non the subject?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98With Charley, Mr Headstone?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98With--well,\xe2\x80\x99 he answered, breaking off, \xe2\x80\x98yes! Say with him too.\r\nWill you please come to the understanding that there must be another\r\ninterview under more favourable circumstances, before the whole case can\r\nbe submitted?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lizzie, shaking her head, \xe2\x80\x98understand your meaning, Mr\r\nHeadstone.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Limit my meaning for the present,\xe2\x80\x99 he interrupted, \xe2\x80\x98to the whole case\r\nbeing submitted to you in another interview.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What case, Mr Headstone? What is wanting to it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You--you shall be informed in the other interview.\xe2\x80\x99 Then he said, as\r\nif in a burst of irrepressible despair, \xe2\x80\x98I--I leave it all incomplete!\r\nThere is a spell upon me, I think!\xe2\x80\x99 And then added, almost as if he\r\nasked for pity, \xe2\x80\x98Good-night!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe held out his hand. As she, with manifest hesitation, not to say\r\nreluctance, touched it, a strange tremble passed over him, and his face,\r\nso deadly white, was moved as by a stroke of pain. Then he was gone.\r\n\r\nThe dolls\xe2\x80\x99 dressmaker sat with her attitude unchanged, eyeing the door\r\nby which he had departed, until Lizzie pushed her bench aside and sat\r\ndown near her. Then, eyeing Lizzie as she had previously eyed Bradley\r\nand the door, Miss Wren chopped that very sudden and keen chop in which\r\nher jaws sometimes indulged, leaned back in her chair with folded arms,\r\nand thus expressed herself:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Humph! If he--I mean, of course, my dear, the party who is coming to\r\ncourt me when the time comes--should be THAT sort of man, he may spare\r\nhimself the trouble. HE wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t do to be trotted about and made useful.\r\nHe\xe2\x80\x99d take fire and blow up while he was about it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And so you would be rid of him,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lizzie, humouring her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not so easily,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Miss Wren. \xe2\x80\x98He wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t blow up alone. He\xe2\x80\x99d\r\ncarry me up with him. I know his tricks and his manners.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Would he want to hurt you, do you mean?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Lizzie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mightn\xe2\x80\x99t exactly want to do it, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Miss Wren; \xe2\x80\x98but a\r\nlot of gunpowder among lighted lucifer-matches in the next room might\r\nalmost as well be here.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He is a very strange man,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lizzie, thoughtfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wish he was so very strange a man as to be a total stranger,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nanswered the sharp little thing.\r\n\r\nIt being Lizzie\xe2\x80\x99s regular occupation when they were alone of an evening\r\nto brush out and smooth the long fair hair of the dolls\xe2\x80\x99 dressmaker, she\r\nunfastened a ribbon that kept it back while the little creature was at\r\nher work, and it fell in a beautiful shower over the poor shoulders that\r\nwere much in need of such adorning rain. \xe2\x80\x98Not now, Lizzie, dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nJenny; \xe2\x80\x98let us have a talk by the fire.\xe2\x80\x99 With those words, she in her\r\nturn loosened her friend\xe2\x80\x99s dark hair, and it dropped of its own weight\r\nover her bosom, in two rich masses. Pretending to compare the colours\r\nand admire the contrast, Jenny so managed a mere touch or two of her\r\nnimble hands, as that she herself laying a cheek on one of the dark\r\nfolds, seemed blinded by her own clustering curls to all but the fire,\r\nwhile the fine handsome face and brow of Lizzie were revealed without\r\nobstruction in the sombre light.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Let us have a talk,\xe2\x80\x99 said Jenny, \xe2\x80\x98about Mr Eugene Wrayburn.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSomething sparkled down among the fair hair resting on the dark hair;\r\nand if it were not a star--which it couldn\xe2\x80\x99t be--it was an eye; and\r\nif it were an eye, it was Jenny Wren\xe2\x80\x99s eye, bright and watchful as the\r\nbird\xe2\x80\x99s whose name she had taken.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why about Mr Wrayburn?\xe2\x80\x99 Lizzie asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98For no better reason than because I\xe2\x80\x99m in the humour. I wonder whether\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99s rich!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, not rich.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Poor?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think so, for a gentleman.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! To be sure! Yes, he\xe2\x80\x99s a gentleman. Not of our sort; is he?\xe2\x80\x99 A shake\r\nof the head, a thoughtful shake of the head, and the answer, softly\r\nspoken, \xe2\x80\x98Oh no, oh no!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe dolls\xe2\x80\x99 dressmaker had an arm round her friend\xe2\x80\x99s waist. Adjusting the\r\narm, she slyly took the opportunity of blowing at her own hair where\r\nit fell over her face; then the eye down there, under lighter shadows\r\nsparkled more brightly and appeared more watchful.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When He turns up, he shan\xe2\x80\x99t be a gentleman; I\xe2\x80\x99ll very soon send him\r\npacking, if he is. I wonder whether anybody has, Lizzie!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is very likely.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is it very likely? I wonder who!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is it not very likely that some lady has been taken by him, and that he\r\nmay love her dearly?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Perhaps. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know. What would you think of him, Lizzie, if you were\r\na lady?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I a lady!\xe2\x80\x99 she repeated, laughing. \xe2\x80\x98Such a fancy!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. But say: just as a fancy, and for instance.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I a lady! I, a poor girl who used to row poor father on the river. I,\r\nwho had rowed poor father out and home on the very night when I saw him\r\nfor the first time. I, who was made so timid by his looking at me, that\r\nI got up and went out!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n[\xe2\x80\x98He did look at you, even that night, though you were not a lady!\xe2\x80\x99\r\nthought Miss Wren.)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I a lady!\xe2\x80\x99 Lizzie went on in a low voice, with her eyes upon the fire.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I, with poor father\xe2\x80\x99s grave not even cleared of undeserved stain and\r\nshame, and he trying to clear it for me! I a lady!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Only as a fancy, and for instance,\xe2\x80\x99 urged Miss Wren.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Too much, Jenny, dear, too much! My fancy is not able to get that far.\xe2\x80\x99\r\nAs the low fire gleamed upon her, it showed her smiling, mournfully and\r\nabstractedly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I am in the humour, and I must be humoured, Lizzie, because after\r\nall I am a poor little thing, and have had a hard day with my bad child.\r\nLook in the fire, as I like to hear you tell how you used to do when you\r\nlived in that dreary old house that had once been a windmill. Look in\r\nthe--what was its name when you told fortunes with your brother that I\r\nDON\xe2\x80\x99T like?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The hollow down by the flare?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! That\xe2\x80\x99s the name! You can find a lady there, I know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98More easily than I can make one of such material as myself, Jenny.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe sparkling eye looked steadfastly up, as the musing face looked\r\nthoughtfully down. \xe2\x80\x98Well?\xe2\x80\x99 said the dolls\xe2\x80\x99 dressmaker, \xe2\x80\x98We have found\r\nour lady?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLizzie nodded, and asked, \xe2\x80\x98Shall she be rich?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She had better be, as he\xe2\x80\x99s poor.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She is very rich. Shall she be handsome?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Even you can be that, Lizzie, so she ought to be.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She is very handsome.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What does she say about him?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Miss Jenny, in a low voice:\r\nwatchful, through an intervening silence, of the face looking down at\r\nthe fire.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She is glad, glad, to be rich, that he may have the money. She is glad,\r\nglad, to be beautiful, that he may be proud of her. Her poor heart--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Eh? Her poor heart?\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Wren.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Her heart--is given him, with all its love and truth. She would\r\njoyfully die with him, or, better than that, die for him. She knows he\r\nhas failings, but she thinks they have grown up through his being like\r\none cast away, for the want of something to trust in, and care for, and\r\nthink well of. And she says, that lady rich and beautiful that I can\r\nnever come near, \xe2\x80\x9cOnly put me in that empty place, only try how little\r\nI mind myself, only prove what a world of things I will do and bear for\r\nyou, and I hope that you might even come to be much better than you are,\r\nthrough me who am so much worse, and hardly worth the thinking of beside\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs the face looking at the fire had become exalted and forgetful in the\r\nrapture of these words, the little creature, openly clearing away\r\nher fair hair with her disengaged hand, had gazed at it with earnest\r\nattention and something like alarm. Now that the speaker ceased, the\r\nlittle creature laid down her head again, and moaned, \xe2\x80\x98O me, O me, O\r\nme!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In pain, dear Jenny?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Lizzie, as if awakened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, but not the old pain. Lay me down, lay me down. Don\xe2\x80\x99t go out of\r\nmy sight to-night. Lock the door and keep close to me.\xe2\x80\x99 Then turning away\r\nher face, she said in a whisper to herself, \xe2\x80\x98My Lizzie, my poor Lizzie!\r\nO my blessed children, come back in the long bright slanting rows, and\r\ncome for her, not me. She wants help more than I, my blessed children!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe had stretched her hands up with that higher and better look, and\r\nnow she turned again, and folded them round Lizzie\xe2\x80\x99s neck, and rocked\r\nherself on Lizzie\xe2\x80\x99s breast.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 12\r\n\r\nMORE BIRDS OF PREY\r\n\r\n\r\nRogue Riderhood dwelt deep and dark in Limehouse Hole, among the\r\nriggers, and the mast, oar and block makers, and the boat-builders, and\r\nthe sail-lofts, as in a kind of ship\xe2\x80\x99s hold stored full of waterside\r\ncharacters, some no better than himself, some very much better, and\r\nnone much worse. The Hole, albeit in a general way not over nice in\r\nits choice of company, was rather shy in reference to the honour of\r\ncultivating the Rogue\xe2\x80\x99s acquaintance; more frequently giving him the\r\ncold shoulder than the warm hand, and seldom or never drinking with him\r\nunless at his own expense. A part of the Hole, indeed, contained so\r\nmuch public spirit and private virtue that not even this strong leverage\r\ncould move it to good fellowship with a tainted accuser. But, there may\r\nhave been the drawback on this magnanimous morality, that its exponents\r\nheld a true witness before Justice to be the next unneighbourly and\r\naccursed character to a false one.\r\n\r\nHad it not been for the daughter whom he often mentioned, Mr Riderhood\r\nmight have found the Hole a mere grave as to any means it would yield\r\nhim of getting a living. But Miss Pleasant Riderhood had some little\r\nposition and connection in Limehouse Hole. Upon the smallest of small\r\nscales, she was an unlicensed pawnbroker, keeping what was popularly\r\ncalled a Leaving Shop, by lending insignificant sums on insignificant\r\narticles of property deposited with her as security. In her\r\nfour-and-twentieth year of life, Pleasant was already in her fifth year\r\nof this way of trade. Her deceased mother had established the business,\r\nand on that parent\xe2\x80\x99s demise she had appropriated a secret capital of\r\nfifteen shillings to establishing herself in it; the existence of\r\nsuch capital in a pillow being the last intelligible confidential\r\ncommunication made to her by the departed, before succumbing to\r\ndropsical conditions of snuff and gin, incompatible equally with\r\ncoherence and existence.\r\n\r\nWhy christened Pleasant, the late Mrs Riderhood might possibly have\r\nbeen at some time able to explain, and possibly not. Her daughter had no\r\ninformation on that point. Pleasant she found herself, and she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nhelp it. She had not been consulted on the question, any more than on\r\nthe question of her coming into these terrestrial parts, to want a name.\r\nSimilarly, she found herself possessed of what is colloquially termed\r\na swivel eye (derived from her father), which she might perhaps have\r\ndeclined if her sentiments on the subject had been taken. She was not\r\notherwise positively ill-looking, though anxious, meagre, of a muddy\r\ncomplexion, and looking as old again as she really was.\r\n\r\nAs some dogs have it in the blood, or are trained, to worry certain\r\ncreatures to a certain point, so--not to make the comparison\r\ndisrespectfully--Pleasant Riderhood had it in the blood, or had been\r\ntrained, to regard seamen, within certain limits, as her prey. Show\r\nher a man in a blue jacket, and, figuratively speaking, she pinned him\r\ninstantly. Yet, all things considered, she was not of an evil mind or an\r\nunkindly disposition. For, observe how many things were to be considered\r\naccording to her own unfortunate experience. Show Pleasant Riderhood a\r\nWedding in the street, and she only saw two people taking out a regular\r\nlicence to quarrel and fight. Show her a Christening, and she saw a\r\nlittle heathen personage having a quite superfluous name bestowed upon\r\nit, inasmuch as it would be commonly addressed by some abusive epithet:\r\nwhich little personage was not in the least wanted by anybody, and would\r\nbe shoved and banged out of everybody\xe2\x80\x99s way, until it should grow\r\nbig enough to shove and bang. Show her a Funeral, and she saw an\r\nunremunerative ceremony in the nature of a black masquerade, conferring\r\na temporary gentility on the performers, at an immense expense, and\r\nrepresenting the only formal party ever given by the deceased. Show her\r\na live father, and she saw but a duplicate of her own father, who from\r\nher infancy had been taken with fits and starts of discharging his duty\r\nto her, which duty was always incorporated in the form of a fist or a\r\nleathern strap, and being discharged hurt her. All things considered,\r\ntherefore, Pleasant Riderhood was not so very, very bad. There was even\r\na touch of romance in her--of such romance as could creep into Limehouse\r\nHole--and maybe sometimes of a summer evening, when she stood with\r\nfolded arms at her shop-door, looking from the reeking street to the\r\nsky where the sun was setting, she may have had some vaporous visions\r\nof far-off islands in the southern seas or elsewhere (not being\r\ngeographically particular), where it would be good to roam with a\r\ncongenial partner among groves of bread-fruit, waiting for ships to be\r\nwafted from the hollow ports of civilization. For, sailors to be got the\r\nbetter of, were essential to Miss Pleasant\xe2\x80\x99s Eden.\r\n\r\nNot on a summer evening did she come to her little shop-door, when a\r\ncertain man standing over against the house on the opposite side of\r\nthe street took notice of her. That was on a cold shrewd windy evening,\r\nafter dark. Pleasant Riderhood shared with most of the lady inhabitants\r\nof the Hole, the peculiarity that her hair was a ragged knot, constantly\r\ncoming down behind, and that she never could enter upon any undertaking\r\nwithout first twisting it into place. At that particular moment, being\r\nnewly come to the threshold to take a look out of doors, she was winding\r\nherself up with both hands after this fashion. And so prevalent was the\r\nfashion, that on the occasion of a fight or other disturbance in the\r\nHole, the ladies would be seen flocking from all quarters universally\r\ntwisting their back-hair as they came along, and many of them, in the\r\nhurry of the moment, carrying their back-combs in their mouths.\r\n\r\nIt was a wretched little shop, with a roof that any man standing in it\r\ncould touch with his hand; little better than a cellar or cave, down\r\nthree steps. Yet in its ill-lighted window, among a flaring handkerchief\r\nor two, an old peacoat or so, a few valueless watches and compasses, a\r\njar of tobacco and two crossed pipes, a bottle of walnut ketchup, and\r\nsome horrible sweets these creature discomforts serving as a blind to\r\nthe main business of the Leaving Shop--was displayed the inscription\r\nSEAMAN\xe2\x80\x99S BOARDING-HOUSE.\r\n\r\nTaking notice of Pleasant Riderhood at the door, the man crossed so\r\nquickly that she was still winding herself up, when he stood close\r\nbefore her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is your father at home?\xe2\x80\x99 said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think he is,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Pleasant, dropping her arms; \xe2\x80\x98come in.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt was a tentative reply, the man having a seafaring appearance. Her\r\nfather was not at home, and Pleasant knew it. \xe2\x80\x98Take a seat by the fire,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nwere her hospitable words when she had got him in; \xe2\x80\x98men of your calling\r\nare always welcome here.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thankee,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man.\r\n\r\nHis manner was the manner of a sailor, and his hands were the hands of\r\na sailor, except that they were smooth. Pleasant had an eye for sailors,\r\nand she noticed the unused colour and texture of the hands, sunburnt\r\nthough they were, as sharply as she noticed their unmistakable looseness\r\nand suppleness, as he sat himself down with his left arm carelessly\r\nthrown across his left leg a little above the knee, and the right arm\r\nas carelessly thrown over the elbow of the wooden chair, with the hand\r\ncurved, half open and half shut, as if it had just let go a rope.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Might you be looking for a Boarding-House?\xe2\x80\x99 Pleasant inquired, taking\r\nher observant stand on one side of the fire.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t rightly know my plans yet,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You ain\xe2\x80\x99t looking for a Leaving Shop?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 assented Pleasant, \xe2\x80\x98you\xe2\x80\x99ve got too much of an outfit on you for\r\nthat. But if you should want either, this is both.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ay, ay!\xe2\x80\x99 said the man, glancing round the place. \xe2\x80\x98I know. I\xe2\x80\x99ve been\r\nhere before.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did you Leave anything when you were here before?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Pleasant, with\r\na view to principal and interest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No.\xe2\x80\x99 The man shook his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am pretty sure you never boarded here?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No.\xe2\x80\x99 The man again shook his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What DID you do here when you were here before?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Pleasant. \xe2\x80\x98For I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t remember you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s not at all likely you should. I remember the place well.\xe2\x80\x99 Looking very curiously\r\nround it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Might that have been long ago?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ay, a goodish bit ago. In taking stock of his\r\nfamiliarly worn rough-weather nautical clothes, piece by piece, she took\r\nstock of a formidable knife in a sheath at his waist ready to his hand,\r\nand of a whistle hanging round his neck, and of a short jagged knotted\r\nclub with a loaded head that peeped out of a pocket of his loose\r\nouter jacket or frock.
