He rejoined with another short\r\ndumb nod. Then he got up and stood with his arms folded, in front of\r\nthe fire, looking down into it occasionally, as she stood with her arms\r\nfolded, leaning against the side of the chimney-piece.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To wile away the time till your father comes,\xe2\x80\x99 he said,--\xe2\x80\x98pray is there\r\nmuch robbing and murdering of seamen about the water-side now?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 said Pleasant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Any?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Complaints of that sort are sometimes made, about Ratcliffe and Wapping\r\nand up that way. But who knows how many are true?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To be sure. And it don\xe2\x80\x99t seem necessary.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s what I say,\xe2\x80\x99 observed Pleasant. \xe2\x80\x98Where\xe2\x80\x99s the reason for it?\r\nBless the sailors, it ain\xe2\x80\x99t as if they ever could keep what they have,\r\nwithout it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re right. Their money may be soon got out of them, without\r\nviolence,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course it may,\xe2\x80\x99 said Pleasant; \xe2\x80\x98and then they ship again and get\r\nmore. And the best thing for \xe2\x80\x98em, too, to ship again as soon as ever\r\nthey can be brought to it. They\xe2\x80\x99re never so well off as when they\xe2\x80\x99re\r\nafloat.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you why I ask,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued the visitor, looking up from the\r\nfire. \xe2\x80\x98I was once beset that way myself, and left for dead.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No?\xe2\x80\x99 said Pleasant. \xe2\x80\x98Where did it happen?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It happened,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the man, with a ruminative air, as he drew his\r\nright hand across his chin, and dipped the other in the pocket of his\r\nrough outer coat, \xe2\x80\x98it happened somewhere about here as I reckon. I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nthink it can have been a mile from here.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Were you drunk?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Pleasant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I was muddled, but not with fair drinking. I had not been drinking, you\r\nunderstand. A mouthful did it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPleasant with a grave look shook her head; importing that she understood\r\nthe process, but decidedly disapproved.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Fair trade is one thing,\xe2\x80\x99 said she, \xe2\x80\x98but that\xe2\x80\x99s another. No one has a\r\nright to carry on with Jack in THAT way.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The sentiment does you credit,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the man, with a grim smile;\r\nand added, in a mutter, \xe2\x80\x98the more so, as I believe it\xe2\x80\x99s not your\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s.--Yes, I had a bad time of it, that time. I lost everything,\r\nand had a sharp struggle for my life, weak as I was.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did you get the parties punished?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Pleasant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A tremendous punishment followed,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man, more seriously; \xe2\x80\x98but\r\nit was not of my bringing about.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of whose, then?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Pleasant.\r\n\r\nThe man pointed upward with his forefinger, and, slowly recovering that\r\nhand, settled his chin in it again as he looked at the fire. Bringing\r\nher inherited eye to bear upon him, Pleasant Riderhood felt more\r\nand more uncomfortable, his manner was so mysterious, so stern, so\r\nself-possessed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Anyways,\xe2\x80\x99 said the damsel, \xe2\x80\x98I am glad punishment followed, and I say\r\nso. Fair trade with seafaring men gets a bad name through deeds of\r\nviolence. I am as much against deeds of violence being done to seafaring\r\nmen, as seafaring men can be themselves. I am of the same opinion as my\r\nmother was, when she was living. Fair trade, my mother used to say, but\r\nno robbery and no blows.\xe2\x80\x99 In the way of trade Miss Pleasant would have\r\ntaken--and indeed did take when she could--as much as thirty shillings\r\na week for board that would be dear at five, and likewise conducted the\r\nLeaving business upon correspondingly equitable principles; yet she had\r\nthat tenderness of conscience and those feelings of humanity, that the\r\nmoment her ideas of trade were overstepped, she became the seaman\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nchampion, even against her father whom she seldom otherwise resisted.\r\n\r\nBut, she was here interrupted by her father\xe2\x80\x99s voice exclaiming angrily,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, Poll Parrot!\xe2\x80\x99 and by her father\xe2\x80\x99s hat being heavily flung from his\r\nhand and striking her face. Accustomed to such occasional manifestations\r\nof his sense of parental duty, Pleasant merely wiped her face on her\r\nhair (which of course had tumbled down) before she twisted it up. This\r\nwas another common procedure on the part of the ladies of the Hole, when\r\nheated by verbal or fistic altercation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Blest if I believe such a Poll Parrot as you was ever learned to\r\nspeak!\xe2\x80\x99 growled Mr Riderhood, stooping to pick up his hat, and making\r\na feint at her with his head and right elbow; for he took the delicate\r\nsubject of robbing seamen in extraordinary dudgeon, and was out of\r\nhumour too. \xe2\x80\x98What are you Poll Parroting at now? Ain\xe2\x80\x99t you got nothing\r\nto do but fold your arms and stand a Poll Parroting all night?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Let her alone,\xe2\x80\x99 urged the man. \xe2\x80\x98She was only speaking to me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Let her alone too!\xe2\x80\x99 retorted Mr Riderhood, eyeing him all over. \xe2\x80\x98Do you\r\nknow she\xe2\x80\x99s my daughter?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And don\xe2\x80\x99t you know that I won\xe2\x80\x99t have no Poll Parroting on the part of\r\nmy daughter? No, nor yet that I won\xe2\x80\x99t take no Poll Parroting from no\r\nman? And who may YOU be, and what may YOU want?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How can I tell you until you are silent?\xe2\x80\x99 returned the other fiercely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Riderhood, quailing a little, \xe2\x80\x98I am willing to be silent\r\nfor the purpose of hearing. But don\xe2\x80\x99t Poll Parrot me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you thirsty, you?\xe2\x80\x99 the man asked, in the same fierce short way,\r\nafter returning his look.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why nat\xe2\x80\x99rally,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Riderhood, \xe2\x80\x98ain\xe2\x80\x99t I always thirsty!\xe2\x80\x99 (Indignant\r\nat the absurdity of the question.)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What will you drink?\xe2\x80\x99 demanded the man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sherry wine,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mr Riderhood, in the same sharp tone, \xe2\x80\x98if you\xe2\x80\x99re\r\ncapable of it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe man put his hand in his pocket, took out half a sovereign, and\r\nbegged the favour of Miss Pleasant that she would fetch a bottle. \xe2\x80\x98With\r\nthe cork undrawn,\xe2\x80\x99 he added, emphatically, looking at her father.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll take my Alfred David,\xe2\x80\x99 muttered Mr Riderhood, slowly relaxing into\r\na dark smile, \xe2\x80\x98that you know a move. Do I know YOU? N--n--no, I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nknow you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe man replied, \xe2\x80\x98No, you don\xe2\x80\x99t know me.\xe2\x80\x99 And so they stood looking at\r\none another surlily enough, until Pleasant came back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s small glasses on the shelf,\xe2\x80\x99 said Riderhood to his daughter.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Give me the one without a foot. I gets my living by the sweat of my\r\nbrow, and it\xe2\x80\x99s good enough for ME.\xe2\x80\x99 This had a modest self-denying\r\nappearance; but it soon turned out that as, by reason of the\r\nimpossibility of standing the glass upright while there was anything in\r\nit, it required to be emptied as soon as filled, Mr Riderhood managed to\r\ndrink in the proportion of three to one.\r\n\r\nWith his Fortunatus\xe2\x80\x99s goblet ready in his hand, Mr Riderhood sat down on\r\none side of the table before the fire, and the strange man on the other:\r\nPleasant occupying a stool between the latter and the fireside. The\r\nbackground, composed of handkerchiefs, coats, shirts, hats, and other\r\nold articles \xe2\x80\x98On Leaving,\xe2\x80\x99 had a general dim resemblance to human\r\nlisteners; especially where a shiny black sou\xe2\x80\x99wester suit and hat hung,\r\nlooking very like a clumsy mariner with his back to the company, who\r\nwas so curious to overhear, that he paused for the purpose with his\r\ncoat half pulled on, and his shoulders up to his ears in the uncompleted\r\naction.\r\n\r\nThe visitor first held the bottle against the light of the candle,\r\nand next examined the top of the cork. Satisfied that it had not been\r\ntampered with, he slowly took from his breastpocket a rusty clasp-knife,\r\nand, with a corkscrew in the handle, opened the wine. That done,\r\nhe looked at the cork, unscrewed it from the corkscrew, laid each\r\nseparately on the table, and, with the end of the sailor\xe2\x80\x99s knot of his\r\nneckerchief, dusted the inside of the neck of the bottle. All this with\r\ngreat deliberation.\r\n\r\nAt first Riderhood had sat with his footless glass extended at arm\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlength for filling, while the very deliberate stranger seemed absorbed\r\nin his preparations. But, gradually his arm reverted home to him, and\r\nhis glass was lowered and lowered until he rested it upside down upon\r\nthe table. By the same degrees his attention became concentrated on\r\nthe knife. And now, as the man held out the bottle to fill all round,\r\nRiderhood stood up, leaned over the table to look closer at the knife,\r\nand stared from it to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x99 asked the man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, I know that knife!\xe2\x80\x99 said Riderhood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, I dare say you do.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe motioned to him to hold up his glass, and filled it. Riderhood\r\nemptied it to the last drop and began again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That there knife--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stop,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man, composedly. \xe2\x80\x98I was going to drink to your\r\ndaughter. Your health, Miss Riderhood.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That knife was the knife of a seaman named George Radfoot.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That seaman was well beknown to me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He was.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s come to him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Death has come to him. Death came to him in an ugly shape. He looked,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid the man, \xe2\x80\x98very horrible after it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Arter what?\xe2\x80\x99 said Riderhood, with a frowning stare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98After he was killed.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Killed? Who killed him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nOnly answering with a shrug, the man filled the footless glass, and\r\nRiderhood emptied it: looking amazedly from his daughter to his visitor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t mean to tell a honest man--\xe2\x80\x99 he was recommencing with\r\nhis empty glass in his hand, when his eye became fascinated by the\r\nstranger\xe2\x80\x99s outer coat. He leaned across the table to see it nearer,\r\ntouched the sleeve, turned the cuff to look at the sleeve-lining (the\r\nman, in his perfect composure, offering not the least objection), and\r\nexclaimed, \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s my belief as this here coat was George Radfoot\xe2\x80\x99s too!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are right. He wore it the last time you ever saw him, and the last\r\ntime you ever will see him--in this world.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s my belief you mean to tell me to my face you killed him!\xe2\x80\x99\r\nexclaimed Riderhood; but, nevertheless, allowing his glass to be filled\r\nagain.\r\n\r\nThe man only answered with another shrug, and showed no symptom of\r\nconfusion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wish I may die if I know what to be up to with this chap!\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nRiderhood, after staring at him, and tossing his last glassful down his\r\nthroat. \xe2\x80\x98Let\xe2\x80\x99s know what to make of you. Say something plain.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I will,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the other, leaning forward across the table, and\r\nspeaking in a low impressive voice. \xe2\x80\x98What a liar you are!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe honest witness rose, and made as though he would fling his glass in\r\nthe man\xe2\x80\x99s face. The man not wincing, and merely shaking his forefinger\r\nhalf knowingly, half menacingly, the piece of honesty thought better of\r\nit and sat down again, putting the glass down too.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And when you went to that lawyer yonder in the Temple with that\r\ninvented story,\xe2\x80\x99 said the stranger, in an exasperatingly comfortable\r\nsort of confidence, \xe2\x80\x98you might have had your strong suspicions of a\r\nfriend of your own, you know. I think you had, you know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Me my suspicions? Of what friend?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Tell me again whose knife was this?\xe2\x80\x99 demanded the man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was possessed by, and was the property of--him as I have made\r\nmention on,\xe2\x80\x99 said Riderhood, stupidly evading the actual mention of the\r\nname.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Tell me again whose coat was this?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That there article of clothing likeways belonged to, and was wore\r\nby--him as I have made mention on,\xe2\x80\x99 was again the dull Old Bailey\r\nevasion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suspect that you gave him the credit of the deed, and of keeping\r\ncleverly out of the way. But there was small cleverness in HIS keeping\r\nout of the way. The cleverness would have been, to have got back for one\r\nsingle instant to the light of the sun.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Things is come to a pretty pass,\xe2\x80\x99 growled Mr Riderhood, rising to his\r\nfeet, goaded to stand at bay, \xe2\x80\x98when bullyers as is wearing dead men\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nclothes, and bullyers as is armed with dead men\xe2\x80\x99s knives, is to come\r\ninto the houses of honest live men, getting their livings by the sweats\r\nof their brows, and is to make these here sort of charges with no rhyme\r\nand no reason, neither the one nor yet the other! Why should I have had\r\nmy suspicions of him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Because you knew him,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the man; \xe2\x80\x98because you had been one with\r\nhim, and knew his real character under a fair outside; because on the\r\nnight which you had afterwards reason to believe to be the very night of\r\nthe murder, he came in here, within an hour of his having left his ship\r\nin the docks, and asked you in what lodgings he could find room. Was\r\nthere no stranger with him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll take my world-without-end everlasting Alfred David that you warn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nwith him,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Riderhood. \xe2\x80\x98You talk big, you do, but things look\r\npretty black against yourself, to my thinking. You charge again\xe2\x80\x99 me that\r\nGeorge Radfoot got lost sight of, and was no more thought of. What\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nthat for a sailor? Why there\xe2\x80\x99s fifty such, out of sight and out of\r\nmind, ten times as long as him--through entering in different names,\r\nre-shipping when the out\xe2\x80\x99ard voyage is made, and what not--a turning\r\nup to light every day about here, and no matter made of it. Ask my\r\ndaughter. You could go on Poll Parroting enough with her, when I warn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ncome in: Poll Parrot a little with her on this pint. You and your\r\nsuspicions of my suspicions of him! What are my suspicions of you? You\r\ntell me George Radfoot got killed. I ask you who done it and how you\r\nknow it. You carry his knife and you wear his coat. I ask you how you\r\ncome by \xe2\x80\x98em? Hand over that there bottle!\xe2\x80\x99 Here Mr Riderhood appeared\r\nto labour under a virtuous delusion that it was his own property. \xe2\x80\x98And\r\nyou,\xe2\x80\x99 he added, turning to his daughter, as he filled the footless\r\nglass, \xe2\x80\x98if it warn\xe2\x80\x99t wasting good sherry wine on you, I\xe2\x80\x99d chuck this at\r\nyou, for Poll Parroting with this man. It\xe2\x80\x99s along of Poll Parroting\r\nthat such like as him gets their suspicions, whereas I gets mine by\r\nargueyment, and being nat\xe2\x80\x99rally a honest man, and sweating away at the\r\nbrow as a honest man ought.\xe2\x80\x99 Here he filled the footless goblet again,\r\nand stood chewing one half of its contents and looking down into the\r\nother as he slowly rolled the wine about in the glass; while Pleasant,\r\nwhose sympathetic hair had come down on her being apostrophised,\r\nrearranged it, much in the style of the tail of a horse when proceeding\r\nto market to be sold.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well? Have you finished?\xe2\x80\x99 asked the strange man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 said Riderhood, \xe2\x80\x98I ain\xe2\x80\x99t. Far from it. Now then! I want to know\r\nhow George Radfoot come by his death, and how you come by his kit?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If you ever do know, you won\xe2\x80\x99t know now.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And next I want to know,\xe2\x80\x99 proceeded Riderhood \xe2\x80\x98whether you mean to\r\ncharge that what-you-may-call-it-murder--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Harmon murder, father,\xe2\x80\x99 suggested Pleasant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No Poll Parroting!\xe2\x80\x99 he vociferated, in return. \xe2\x80\x98Keep your mouth\r\nshut!--I want to know, you sir, whether you charge that there crime on\r\nGeorge Radfoot?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If you ever do know, you won\xe2\x80\x99t know now.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Perhaps you done it yourself?\xe2\x80\x99 said Riderhood, with a threatening\r\naction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I alone know,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the man, sternly shaking his head, \xe2\x80\x98the\r\nmysteries of that crime. I alone know that your trumped-up story cannot\r\npossibly be true. I alone know that it must be altogether false, and\r\nthat you must know it to be altogether false. I come here to-night to\r\ntell you so much of what I know, and no more.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Riderhood, with his crooked eye upon his visitor, meditated for some\r\nmoments, and then refilled his glass, and tipped the contents down his\r\nthroat in three tips.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Shut the shop-door!\xe2\x80\x99 he then said to his daughter, putting the glass\r\nsuddenly down. \xe2\x80\x98And turn the key and stand by it! If you know all this,\r\nyou sir,\xe2\x80\x99 getting, as he spoke, between the visitor and the door, \xe2\x80\x98why\r\nhan\xe2\x80\x99t you gone to Lawyer Lightwood?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That, also, is alone known to myself,\xe2\x80\x99 was the cool answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you know that, if you didn\xe2\x80\x99t do the deed, what you say you could\r\ntell is worth from five to ten thousand pound?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Riderhood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know it very well, and when I claim the money you shall share it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe honest man paused, and drew a little nearer to the visitor, and a\r\nlittle further from the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know it,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated the man, quietly, \xe2\x80\x98as well as I know that you and\r\nGeorge Radfoot were one together in more than one dark business; and as\r\nwell as I know that you, Roger Riderhood, conspired against an innocent\r\nman for blood-money; and as well as I know that I can--and that I swear\r\nI will!--give you up on both scores, and be the proof against you in my\r\nown person, if you defy me!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Father!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Pleasant, from the door. \xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t defy him! Give way to\r\nhim! Don\xe2\x80\x99t get into more trouble, father!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Will you leave off a Poll Parroting, I ask you?\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mr Riderhood,\r\nhalf beside himself between the two. Then, propitiatingly and\r\ncrawlingly: \xe2\x80\x98You sir! You han\xe2\x80\x99t said what you want of me. Is it fair, is\r\nit worthy of yourself, to talk of my defying you afore ever you say what\r\nyou want of me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t want much,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man. \xe2\x80\x98This accusation of yours must not be\r\nleft half made and half unmade. What was done for the blood-money must\r\nbe thoroughly undone.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well; but Shipmate--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t call me Shipmate,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Captain, then,\xe2\x80\x99 urged Mr Riderhood; \xe2\x80\x98there! You won\xe2\x80\x99t object to\r\nCaptain. It\xe2\x80\x99s a honourable title, and you fully look it. Captain! Ain\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nthe man dead? Now I ask you fair. Ain\xe2\x80\x99t Gaffer dead?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the other, with impatience, \xe2\x80\x98yes, he is dead. What\r\nthen?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Can words hurt a dead man, Captain? I only ask you fair.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They can hurt the memory of a dead man, and they can hurt his living\r\nchildren. How many children had this man?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Meaning Gaffer, Captain?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of whom else are we speaking?\xe2\x80\x99 returned the other, with a movement of\r\nhis foot, as if Rogue Riderhood were beginning to sneak before him in\r\nthe body as well as the spirit, and he spurned him off. \xe2\x80\x98I have heard\r\nof a daughter, and a son. I ask for information; I ask YOUR daughter; I\r\nprefer to speak to her. What children did Hexam leave?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPleasant, looking to her father for permission to reply, that honest man\r\nexclaimed with great bitterness:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why the devil don\xe2\x80\x99t you answer the Captain? You can Poll Parrot enough\r\nwhen you ain\xe2\x80\x99t wanted to Poll Parrot, you perwerse jade!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThus encouraged, Pleasant explained that there were only Lizzie, the\r\ndaughter in question, and the youth. Both very respectable, she added.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is dreadful that any stigma should attach to them,\xe2\x80\x99 said the\r\nvisitor, whom the consideration rendered so uneasy that he rose, and\r\npaced to and fro, muttering, \xe2\x80\x98Dreadful! Unforeseen? How could it be\r\nforeseen!\xe2\x80\x99 Then he stopped, and asked aloud: \xe2\x80\x98Where do they live?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPleasant further explained that only the daughter had resided with the\r\nfather at the time of his accidental death, and that she had immediately\r\nafterwards quitted the neighbourhood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know that,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man, \xe2\x80\x98for I have been to the place they dwelt\r\nin, at the time of the inquest. Could you quietly find out for me where\r\nshe lives now?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPleasant had no doubt she could do that. Within what time, did she\r\nthink? Within a day. The visitor said that was well, and he would return\r\nfor the information, relying on its being obtained. To this dialogue\r\nRiderhood had attended in silence, and he now obsequiously bespake the\r\nCaptain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Captain! Mentioning them unfort\xe2\x80\x99net words of mine respecting Gaffer,\r\nit is contrairily to be bore in mind that Gaffer always were a precious\r\nrascal, and that his line were a thieving line. Likeways when I went to\r\nthem two Governors, Lawyer Lightwood and the t\xe2\x80\x99other Governor, with\r\nmy information, I may have been a little over-eager for the cause of\r\njustice, or (to put it another way) a little over-stimilated by them\r\nfeelings which rouses a man up, when a pot of money is going about,\r\nto get his hand into that pot of money for his family\xe2\x80\x99s sake. Besides\r\nwhich, I think the wine of them two Governors was--I will not say\r\na hocussed wine, but fur from a wine as was elthy for the mind. And\r\nthere\xe2\x80\x99s another thing to be remembered, Captain. Did I stick to them\r\nwords when Gaffer was no more, and did I say bold to them two Governors,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGovernors both, wot I informed I still inform; wot was took down I hold\r\nto\xe2\x80\x9d? No. I says, frank and open--no shuffling, mind you, Captain!--\xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nmay have been mistook, I\xe2\x80\x99ve been a thinking of it, it mayn\xe2\x80\x99t have been\r\ntook down correct on this and that, and I won\xe2\x80\x99t swear to thick and thin,\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99d rayther forfeit your good opinions than do it.\xe2\x80\x9d And so far as\r\nI know,\xe2\x80\x99 concluded Mr Riderhood, by way of proof and evidence to\r\ncharacter, \xe2\x80\x98I HAVE actiwally forfeited the good opinions of several\r\npersons--even your own, Captain, if I understand your words--but I\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nsooner do it than be forswore. There; if that\xe2\x80\x99s conspiracy, call me\r\nconspirator.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You shall sign,\xe2\x80\x99 said the visitor, taking very little heed of this\r\noration, \xe2\x80\x98a statement that it was all utterly false, and the poor girl\r\nshall have it. I will bring it with me for your signature, when I come\r\nagain.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When might you be expected, Captain?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Riderhood, again\r\ndubiously getting between him and door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Quite soon enough for you. I shall not disappoint you; don\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\nafraid.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Might you be inclined to leave any name, Captain?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, not at all. I have no such intention.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cShall\xe2\x80\x9d is summ\xe2\x80\x99at of a hard word, Captain,\xe2\x80\x99 urged Riderhood, still\r\nfeebly dodging between him and the door, as he advanced. \xe2\x80\x98When you say a\r\nman \xe2\x80\x9cshall\xe2\x80\x9d sign this and that and t\xe2\x80\x99other, Captain, you order him about\r\nin a grand sort of a way. Don\xe2\x80\x99t it seem so to yourself?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe man stood still, and angrily fixed him with his eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Father, father!\xe2\x80\x99 entreated Pleasant, from the door, with her disengaged\r\nhand nervously trembling at her lips; \xe2\x80\x98don\xe2\x80\x99t! Don\xe2\x80\x99t get into trouble any\r\nmore!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hear me out, Captain, hear me out! All I was wishing to mention,\r\nCaptain, afore you took your departer,\xe2\x80\x99 said the sneaking Mr Riderhood,\r\nfalling out of his path, \xe2\x80\x98was, your handsome words relating to the\r\nreward.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When I claim it,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man, in a tone which seemed to leave some\r\nsuch words as \xe2\x80\x98you dog,\xe2\x80\x99 very distinctly understood, \xe2\x80\x98you shall share\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLooking stedfastly at Riderhood, he once more said in a low voice, this\r\ntime with a grim sort of admiration of him as a perfect piece of evil,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What a liar you are!\xe2\x80\x99 and, nodding his head twice or thrice over the\r\ncompliment, passed out of the shop. But, to Pleasant he said good-night\r\nkindly.\r\n\r\nThe honest man who gained his living by the sweat of his brow remained\r\nin a state akin to stupefaction, until the footless glass and the\r\nunfinished bottle conveyed themselves into his mind. From his mind he\r\nconveyed them into his hands, and so conveyed the last of the wine into\r\nhis stomach. When that was done, he awoke to a clear perception that\r\nPoll Parroting was solely chargeable with what had passed. Therefore,\r\nnot to be remiss in his duty as a father, he threw a pair of sea-boots\r\nat Pleasant, which she ducked to avoid, and then cried, poor thing,\r\nusing her hair for a pocket-handkerchief.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 13\r\n\r\nA SOLO AND A DUETT\r\n\r\n\r\nThe wind was blowing so hard when the visitor came out at the shop-door\r\ninto the darkness and dirt of Limehouse Hole, that it almost blew him\r\nin again. Doors were slamming violently, lamps were flickering or blown\r\nout, signs were rocking in their frames, the water of the kennels,\r\nwind-dispersed, flew about in drops like rain. Indifferent to the\r\nweather, and even preferring it to better weather for its clearance of\r\nthe streets, the man looked about him with a scrutinizing glance. \xe2\x80\x98Thus\r\nmuch I know,\xe2\x80\x99 he murmured. \xe2\x80\x98I have never been here since that night, and\r\nnever was here before that night, but thus much I recognize. I wonder\r\nwhich way did we take when we came out of that shop. We turned to the\r\nright as I have turned, but I can recall no more. Did we go by this\r\nalley? Or down that little lane?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe tried both, but both confused him equally, and he came straying\r\nback to the same spot. \xe2\x80\x98I remember there were poles pushed out of upper\r\nwindows on which clothes were drying, and I remember a low public-house,\r\nand the sound flowing down a narrow passage belonging to it of the\r\nscraping of a fiddle and the shuffling of feet. But here are all these\r\nthings in the lane, and here are all these things in the alley. And I\r\nhave nothing else in my mind but a wall, a dark doorway, a flight of\r\nstairs, and a room.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe tried a new direction, but made nothing of it; walls, dark doorways,\r\nflights of stairs and rooms, were too abundant. And, like most people so\r\npuzzled, he again and again described a circle, and found himself at\r\nthe point from which he had begun. \xe2\x80\x98This is like what I have read in\r\nnarratives of escape from prison,\xe2\x80\x99 said he, \xe2\x80\x98where the little track of\r\nthe fugitives in the night always seems to take the shape of the great\r\nround world, on which they wander; as if it were a secret law.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHere he ceased to be the oakum-headed, oakum-whiskered man on whom Miss\r\nPleasant Riderhood had looked, and, allowing for his being still wrapped\r\nin a nautical overcoat, became as like that same lost wanted Mr Julius\r\nHandford, as never man was like another in this world. In the breast of\r\nthe coat he stowed the bristling hair and whisker, in a moment, as the\r\nfavouring wind went with him down a solitary place that it had swept\r\nclear of passengers. Yet in that same moment he was the Secretary also,\r\nMr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s Secretary. For John Rokesmith, too, was as like that same\r\nlost wanted Mr Julius Handford as never man was like another in this\r\nworld.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have no clue to the scene of my death,\xe2\x80\x99 said he. \xe2\x80\x98Not that it matters\r\nnow. But having risked discovery by venturing here at all, I should have\r\nbeen glad to track some part of the way.\xe2\x80\x99 With which singular words he\r\nabandoned his search, came up out of Limehouse Hole, and took the way\r\npast Limehouse Church. At the great iron gate of the churchyard he\r\nstopped and looked in. He looked up at the high tower spectrally\r\nresisting the wind, and he looked round at the white tombstones, like\r\nenough to the dead in their winding-sheets, and he counted the nine\r\ntolls of the clock-bell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is a sensation not experienced by many mortals,\xe2\x80\x99 said he, \xe2\x80\x98to be\r\nlooking into a churchyard on a wild windy night, and to feel that I no\r\nmore hold a place among the living than these dead do, and even to know\r\nthat I lie buried somewhere else, as they lie buried here. Nothing uses\r\nme to it. A spirit that was once a man could hardly feel stranger or\r\nlonelier, going unrecognized among mankind, than I feel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But this is the fanciful side of the situation. It has a real side, so\r\ndifficult that, though I think of it every day, I never thoroughly think\r\nit out. Now, let me determine to think it out as I walk home. I know\r\nI evade it, as many men--perhaps most men--do evade thinking their way\r\nthrough their greatest perplexity. I will try to pin myself to mine.\r\nDon\xe2\x80\x99t evade it, John Harmon; don\xe2\x80\x99t evade it; think it out!\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When I came to England, attracted to the country with which I had none\r\nbut most miserable associations, by the accounts of my fine inheritance\r\nthat found me abroad, I came back, shrinking from my father\xe2\x80\x99s money,\r\nshrinking from my father\xe2\x80\x99s memory, mistrustful of being forced on a\r\nmercenary wife, mistrustful of my father\xe2\x80\x99s intention in thrusting that\r\nmarriage on me, mistrustful that I was already growing avaricious,\r\nmistrustful that I was slackening in gratitude to the two dear noble\r\nhonest friends who had made the only sunlight in my childish life or\r\nthat of my heartbroken sister. I came back, timid, divided in my mind,\r\nafraid of myself and everybody here, knowing of nothing but wretchedness\r\nthat my father\xe2\x80\x99s wealth had ever brought about. Now, stop, and so far\r\nthink it out, John Harmon. Is that so? That is exactly so.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98On board serving as third mate was George Radfoot. I knew nothing of\r\nhim. His name first became known to me about a week before we sailed,\r\nthrough my being accosted by one of the ship-agent\xe2\x80\x99s clerks as\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr Radfoot.\xe2\x80\x9d It was one day when I had gone aboard to look to my\r\npreparations, and the clerk, coming behind me as I stood on deck, tapped\r\nme on the shoulder, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cMr Rad-foot, look here,\xe2\x80\x9d referring to\r\nsome papers that he had in his hand. And my name first became known to\r\nRadfoot, through another clerk within a day or two, and while the ship\r\nwas yet in port, coming up behind him, tapping him on the shoulder and\r\nbeginning, \xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon, Mr Harmon--.\xe2\x80\x9d I believe we were alike\r\nin bulk and stature but not otherwise, and that we were not strikingly\r\nalike, even in those respects, when we were together and could be\r\ncompared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98However, a sociable word or two on these mistakes became an easy\r\nintroduction between us, and the weather was hot, and he helped me to a\r\ncool cabin on deck alongside his own, and his first school had been at\r\nBrussels as mine had been, and he had learnt French as I had learnt it,\r\nand he had a little history of himself to relate--God only knows how\r\nmuch of it true, and how much of it false--that had its likeness to\r\nmine. I had been a seaman too. So we got to be confidential together,\r\nand the more easily yet, because he and every one on board had known\r\nby general rumour what I was making the voyage to England for. By such\r\ndegrees and means, he came to the knowledge of my uneasiness of mind,\r\nand of its setting at that time in the direction of desiring to see and\r\nform some judgment of my allotted wife, before she could possibly know\r\nme for myself; also to try Mrs Boffin and give her a glad surprise. So\r\nthe plot was made out of our getting common sailors\xe2\x80\x99 dresses (as he was\r\nable to guide me about London), and throwing ourselves in Bella Wilfer\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nneighbourhood, and trying to put ourselves in her way, and doing\r\nwhatever chance might favour on the spot, and seeing what came of it. If\r\nnothing came of it, I should be no worse off, and there would merely\r\nbe a short delay in my presenting myself to Lightwood. I have all these\r\nfacts right? Yes. They are all accurately right.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98His advantage in all this was, that for a time I was to be lost. It\r\nmight be for a day or for two days, but I must be lost sight of on\r\nlanding, or there would be recognition, anticipation, and failure.\r\nTherefore, I disembarked with my valise in my hand--as Potterson\r\nthe steward and Mr Jacob Kibble my fellow-passenger afterwards\r\nremembered--and waited for him in the dark by that very Limehouse Church\r\nwhich is now behind me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As I had always shunned the port of London, I only knew the church\r\nthrough his pointing out its spire from on board. Perhaps I might\r\nrecall, if it were any good to try, the way by which I went to it alone\r\nfrom the river; but how we two went from it to Riderhood\xe2\x80\x99s shop, I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nknow--any more than I know what turns we took and doubles we made, after\r\nwe left it. The way was purposely confused, no doubt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But let me go on thinking the facts out, and avoid confusing them with\r\nmy speculations. Whether he took me by a straight way or a crooked way,\r\nwhat is that to the purpose now? Steady, John Harmon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When we stopped at Riderhood\xe2\x80\x99s, and he asked that scoundrel a question\r\nor two, purporting to refer only to the lodging-houses in which there\r\nwas accommodation for us, had I the least suspicion of him? None.\r\nCertainly none until afterwards when I held the clue. I think he must\r\nhave got from Riderhood in a paper, the drug, or whatever it was, that\r\nafterwards stupefied me, but I am far from sure. All I felt safe in\r\ncharging on him to-night, was old companionship in villainy between\r\nthem. Their undisguised intimacy, and the character I now know Riderhood\r\nto bear, made that not at all adventurous. But I am not clear about the\r\ndrug. Thinking out the circumstances on which I found my suspicion, they\r\nare only two. One: I remember his changing a small folded paper from one\r\npocket to another, after we came out, which he had not touched before.\r\nTwo: I now know Riderhood to have been previously taken up for being\r\nconcerned in the robbery of an unlucky seaman, to whom some such poison\r\nhad been given.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is my conviction that we cannot have gone a mile from that shop,\r\nbefore we came to the wall, the dark doorway, the flight of stairs, and\r\nthe room. The night was particularly dark and it rained hard. As I think\r\nthe circumstances back, I hear the rain splashing on the stone pavement\r\nof the passage, which was not under cover. The room overlooked the\r\nriver, or a dock, or a creek, and the tide was out. Being possessed of\r\nthe time down to that point, I know by the hour that it must have been\r\nabout low water; but while the coffee was getting ready, I drew back the\r\ncurtain (a dark-brown curtain), and, looking out, knew by the kind\r\nof reflection below, of the few neighbouring lights, that they were\r\nreflected in tidal mud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He had carried under his arm a canvas bag, containing a suit of his\r\nclothes. I had no change of outer clothes with me, as I was to buy\r\nslops. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are very wet, Mr Harmon,\xe2\x80\x9d--I can hear him saying--\xe2\x80\x9cand I am\r\nquite dry under this good waterproof coat. Put on these clothes of\r\nmine. You may find on trying them that they will answer your purpose\r\nto-morrow, as well as the slops you mean to buy, or better. While you\r\nchange, I\xe2\x80\x99ll hurry the hot coffee.\xe2\x80\x9d When he came back, I had his clothes\r\non, and there was a black man with him, wearing a linen jacket, like\r\na steward, who put the smoking coffee on the table in a tray and never\r\nlooked at me. I am so far literal and exact? Literal and exact, I am\r\ncertain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, I pass to sick and deranged impressions; they are so strong, that\r\nI rely upon them; but there are spaces between them that I know nothing\r\nabout, and they are not pervaded by any idea of time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I had drank some coffee, when to my sense of sight he began to swell\r\nimmensely, and something urged me to rush at him. We had a struggle near\r\nthe door. He got from me, through my not knowing where to strike, in the\r\nwhirling round of the room, and the flashing of flames of fire between\r\nus. I dropped down. Lying helpless on the ground, I was turned over by\r\na foot. I was dragged by the neck into a corner. I heard men speak\r\ntogether. I was turned over by other feet. I saw a figure like myself\r\nlying dressed in my clothes on a bed. What might have been, for anything\r\nI knew, a silence of days, weeks, months, years, was broken by a violent\r\nwrestling of men all over the room. The figure like myself was assailed,\r\nand my valise was in its hand. I was trodden upon and fallen over. I\r\nheard a noise of blows, and thought it was a wood-cutter cutting down\r\na tree. I could not have said that my name was John Harmon--I could not\r\nhave thought it--I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know it--but when I heard the blows, I thought\r\nof the wood-cutter and his axe, and had some dead idea that I was lying\r\nin a forest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is still correct? Still correct, with the exception that I cannot\r\npossibly express it to myself without using the word I. But it was not\r\nI. There was no such thing as I, within my knowledge.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was only after a downward slide through something like a tube, and\r\nthen a great noise and a sparkling and crackling as of fires, that the\r\nconsciousness came upon me, \xe2\x80\x9cThis is John Harmon drowning! John Harmon,\r\nstruggle for your life. John Harmon, call on Heaven and save yourself!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n I think I cried it out aloud in a great agony, and then a heavy horrid\r\nunintelligible something vanished, and it was I who was struggling there\r\nalone in the water.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I was very weak and faint, frightfully oppressed with drowsiness, and\r\ndriving fast with the tide. Looking over the black water, I saw the\r\nlights racing past me on the two banks of the river, as if they were\r\neager to be gone and leave me dying in the dark. The tide was running\r\ndown, but I knew nothing of up or down then. When, guiding myself safely\r\nwith Heaven\xe2\x80\x99s assistance before the fierce set of the water, I at last\r\ncaught at a boat moored, one of a tier of boats at a causeway, I was\r\nsucked under her, and came up, only just alive, on the other side.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Was I long in the water? Long enough to be chilled to the heart, but\r\nI don\xe2\x80\x99t know how long. Yet the cold was merciful, for it was the cold\r\nnight air and the rain that restored me from a swoon on the stones of\r\nthe causeway. They naturally supposed me to have toppled in, drunk, when\r\nI crept to the public-house it belonged to; for I had no notion where\r\nI was, and could not articulate--through the poison that had made me\r\ninsensible having affected my speech--and I supposed the night to be\r\nthe previous night, as it was still dark and raining. But I had lost\r\ntwenty-four hours.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have checked the calculation often, and it must have been two nights\r\nthat I lay recovering in that public-house. Let me see. Yes. I am sure\r\nit was while I lay in that bed there, that the thought entered my head\r\nof turning the danger I had passed through, to the account of being\r\nfor some time supposed to have disappeared mysteriously, and of proving\r\nBella. The dread of our being forced on one another, and perpetuating\r\nthe fate that seemed to have fallen on my father\xe2\x80\x99s riches--the fate that\r\nthey should lead to nothing but evil--was strong upon the moral timidity\r\nthat dates from my childhood with my poor sister.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As to this hour I cannot understand that side of the river where I\r\nrecovered the shore, being the opposite side to that on which I was\r\nensnared, I shall never understand it now. Even at this moment, while I\r\nleave the river behind me, going home, I cannot conceive that it rolls\r\nbetween me and that spot, or that the sea is where it is. But this is\r\nnot thinking it out; this is making a leap to the present time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I could not have done it, but for the fortune in the waterproof\r\nbelt round my body. Not a great fortune, forty and odd pounds for the\r\ninheritor of a hundred and odd thousand! But it was enough. Without it I\r\nmust have disclosed myself. Without it, I could never have gone to that\r\nExchequer Coffee House, or taken Mrs Wilfer\xe2\x80\x99s lodgings.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Some twelve days I lived at that hotel, before the night when I saw the\r\ncorpse of Radfoot at the Police Station. The inexpressible mental horror\r\nthat I laboured under, as one of the consequences of the poison, makes\r\nthe interval seem greatly longer, but I know it cannot have been longer.\r\nThat suffering has gradually weakened and weakened since, and has only\r\ncome upon me by starts, and I hope I am free from it now; but even now,\r\nI have sometimes to think, constrain myself, and stop before speaking,\r\nor I could not say the words I want to say.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Again I ramble away from thinking it out to the end. It is not so far\r\nto the end that I need be tempted to break off. Now, on straight!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I examined the newspapers every day for tidings that I was missing, but\r\nsaw none. Going out that night to walk (for I kept retired while it was\r\nlight), I found a crowd assembled round a placard posted at Whitehall.\r\nIt described myself, John Harmon, as found dead and mutilated in the\r\nriver under circumstances of strong suspicion, described my dress,\r\ndescribed the papers in my pockets, and stated where I was lying for\r\nrecognition. In a wild incautious way I hurried there, and there--with\r\nthe horror of the death I had escaped, before my eyes in its most\r\nappalling shape, added to the inconceivable horror tormenting me at\r\nthat time when the poisonous stuff was strongest on me--I perceived that\r\nRadfoot had been murdered by some unknown hands for the money for which\r\nhe would have murdered me, and that probably we had both been shot into\r\nthe river from the same dark place into the same dark tide, when the\r\nstream ran deep and strong.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That night I almost gave up my mystery, though I suspected no one,\r\ncould offer no information, knew absolutely nothing save that the\r\nmurdered man was not I, but Radfoot. Next day while I hesitated, and\r\nnext day while I hesitated, it seemed as if the whole country were\r\ndetermined to have me dead. The Inquest declared me dead, the Government\r\nproclaimed me dead; I could not listen at my fireside for five minutes\r\nto the outer noises, but it was borne into my ears that I was dead.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So John Harmon died, and Julius Handford disappeared, and John\r\nRokesmith was born. John Rokesmith\xe2\x80\x99s intent to-night has been to repair\r\na wrong that he could never have imagined possible, coming to his ears\r\nthrough the Lightwood talk related to him, and which he is bound by\r\nevery consideration to remedy. In that intent John Rokesmith will\r\npersevere, as his duty is.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, is it all thought out? All to this time? Nothing omitted? No,\r\nnothing. But beyond this time? To think it out through the future, is a\r\nharder though a much shorter task than to think it out through the past.\r\nJohn Harmon is dead. Should John Harmon come to life?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If yes, why? If no, why?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Take yes, first. To enlighten human Justice concerning the offence of\r\none far beyond it who may have a living mother. To enlighten it with the\r\nlights of a stone passage, a flight of stairs, a brown window-curtain,\r\nand a black man. To come into possession of my father\xe2\x80\x99s money, and with\r\nit sordidly to buy a beautiful creature whom I love--I cannot help it;\r\nreason has nothing to do with it; I love her against reason--but who\r\nwould as soon love me for my own sake, as she would love the beggar at\r\nthe corner. What a use for the money, and how worthy of its old misuses!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, take no. The reasons why John Harmon should not come to life.\r\nBecause he has passively allowed these dear old faithful friends to pass\r\ninto possession of the property. Because he sees them happy with it,\r\nmaking a good use of it, effacing the old rust and tarnish on the money.\r\nBecause they have virtually adopted Bella, and will provide for her.\r\nBecause there is affection enough in her nature, and warmth enough in\r\nher heart, to develop into something enduringly good, under favourable\r\nconditions. Because her faults have been intensified by her place in my\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s will, and she is already growing better. Because her marriage\r\nwith John Harmon, after what I have heard from her own lips, would be a\r\nshocking mockery, of which both she and I must always be conscious, and\r\nwhich would degrade her in her mind, and me in mine, and each of us in\r\nthe other\xe2\x80\x99s. Because if John Harmon comes to life and does not marry\r\nher, the property falls into the very hands that hold it now.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What would I have? Dead, I have found the true friends of my lifetime\r\nstill as true as tender and as faithful as when I was alive, and making\r\nmy memory an incentive to good actions done in my name. Dead, I have\r\nfound them when they might have slighted my name, and passed\r\ngreedily over my grave to ease and wealth, lingering by the way, like\r\nsingle-hearted children, to recall their love for me when I was a poor\r\nfrightened child. Dead, I have heard from the woman who would have been\r\nmy wife if I had lived, the revolting truth that I should have purchased\r\nher, caring nothing for me, as a Sultan buys a slave.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What would I have? If the dead could know, or do know, how the living\r\nuse them, who among the hosts of dead has found a more disinterested\r\nfidelity on earth than I? Is not that enough for me? If I had come back,\r\nthese noble creatures would have welcomed me, wept over me, given up\r\neverything to me with joy. I did not come back, and they have passed\r\nunspoiled into my place. Let them rest in it, and let Bella rest in\r\nhers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What course for me then? This. To live the same quiet Secretary life,\r\ncarefully avoiding chances of recognition, until they shall have become\r\nmore accustomed to their altered state, and until the great swarm of\r\nswindlers under many names shall have found newer prey. By that time,\r\nthe method I am establishing through all the affairs, and with which I\r\nwill every day take new pains to make them both familiar, will be, I may\r\nhope, a machine in such working order as that they can keep it going.\r\nI know I need but ask of their generosity, to have. When the right time\r\ncomes, I will ask no more than will replace me in my former path of\r\nlife, and John Rokesmith shall tread it as contentedly as he may. But\r\nJohn Harmon shall come back no more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That I may never, in the days to come afar off, have any weak misgiving\r\nthat Bella might, in any contingency, have taken me for my own sake if\r\nI had plainly asked her, I WILL plainly ask her: proving beyond all\r\nquestion what I already know too well. And now it is all thought out,\r\nfrom the beginning to the end, and my mind is easier.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\nSo deeply engaged had the living-dead man been, in thus communing with\r\nhimself, that he had regarded neither the wind nor the way, and had\r\nresisted the former instinctively as he had pursued the latter. But\r\nbeing now come into the City, where there was a coach-stand, he stood\r\nirresolute whether to go to his lodgings, or to go first to Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhouse. He decided to go round by the house, arguing, as he carried his\r\novercoat upon his arm, that it was less likely to attract notice if left\r\nthere, than if taken to Holloway: both Mrs Wilfer and Miss Lavinia being\r\nravenously curious touching every article of which the lodger stood\r\npossessed.\r\n\r\nArriving at the house, he found that Mr and Mrs Boffin were out, but\r\nthat Miss Wilfer was in the drawing-room. Miss Wilfer had remained at\r\nhome, in consequence of not feeling very well, and had inquired in the\r\nevening if Mr Rokesmith were in his room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Make my compliments to Miss Wilfer, and say I am here now.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMiss Wilfer\xe2\x80\x99s compliments came down in return, and, if it were not too\r\nmuch trouble, would Mr Rokesmith be so kind as to come up before he\r\nwent?\r\n\r\nIt was not too much trouble, and Mr Rokesmith came up.\r\n\r\nOh she looked very pretty, she looked very, very pretty! If the father\r\nof the late John Harmon had but left his money unconditionally to his\r\nson, and if his son had but lighted on this loveable girl for himself,\r\nand had the happiness to make her loving as well as loveable!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dear me! Are you not well, Mr Rokesmith?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, quite well. I was sorry to hear, when I came in, that YOU were\r\nnot.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A mere nothing. I had a headache--gone now--and was not quite fit for\r\na hot theatre, so I stayed at home. I asked you if you were not well,\r\nbecause you look so white.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do I? I have had a busy evening.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe was on a low ottoman before the fire, with a little shining jewel\r\nof a table, and her book and her work, beside her. Ah! what a different\r\nlife the late John Harmon\xe2\x80\x99s, if it had been his happy privilege to take\r\nhis place upon that ottoman, and draw his arm about that waist, and say,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope the time has been long without me? What a Home Goddess you look,\r\nmy darling!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBut, the present John Rokesmith, far removed from the late John Harmon,\r\nremained standing at a distance. A little distance in respect of space,\r\nbut a great distance in respect of separation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Rokesmith,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, taking up her work, and inspecting it all\r\nround the corners, \xe2\x80\x98I wanted to say something to you when I could have\r\nthe opportunity, as an explanation why I was rude to you the other day.\r\nYou have no right to think ill of me, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe sharp little way in which she darted a look at him, half sensitively\r\ninjured, and half pettishly, would have been very much admired by the\r\nlate John Harmon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t know how well I think of you, Miss Wilfer.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Truly, you must have a very high opinion of me, Mr Rokesmith, when you\r\nbelieve that in prosperity I neglect and forget my old home.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do I believe so?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You DID, sir, at any rate,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Bella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I took the liberty of reminding you of a little omission into which you\r\nhad fallen--insensibly and naturally fallen. It was no more than that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And I beg leave to ask you, Mr Rokesmith,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, \xe2\x80\x98why you took\r\nthat liberty?--I hope there is no offence in the phrase; it is your own,\r\nremember.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Because I am truly, deeply, profoundly interested in you, Miss Wilfer.\r\nBecause I wish to see you always at your best. Because I--shall I go\r\non?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Bella, with a burning face, \xe2\x80\x98you have said more than\r\nenough. I beg that you will NOT go on. If you have any generosity, any\r\nhonour, you will say no more.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe late John Harmon, looking at the proud face with the down-cast eyes,\r\nand at the quick breathing as it stirred the fall of bright brown hair\r\nover the beautiful neck, would probably have remained silent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wish to speak to you, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, \xe2\x80\x98once for all, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nknow how to do it. I have sat here all this evening, wishing to speak to\r\nyou, and determining to speak to you, and feeling that I must. I beg for\r\na moment\xe2\x80\x99s time.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe remained silent, and she remained with her face averted, sometimes\r\nmaking a slight movement as if she would turn and speak. At length she\r\ndid so.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You know how I am situated here, sir, and you know how I am situated\r\nat home. I must speak to you for myself, since there is no one about\r\nme whom I could ask to do so. It is not generous in you, it is not\r\nhonourable in you, to conduct yourself towards me as you do.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is it ungenerous or dishonourable to be devoted to you; fascinated by\r\nyou?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Preposterous!\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella.\r\n\r\nThe late John Harmon might have thought it rather a contemptuous and\r\nlofty word of repudiation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I now feel obliged to go on,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued the Secretary, \xe2\x80\x98though it were\r\nonly in self-explanation and self-defence. I hope, Miss Wilfer, that\r\nit is not unpardonable--even in me--to make an honest declaration of an\r\nhonest devotion to you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98An honest declaration!\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Bella, with emphasis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is it otherwise?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I must request, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, taking refuge in a touch of timely\r\nresentment, \xe2\x80\x98that I may not be questioned. You must excuse me if I\r\ndecline to be cross-examined.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, Miss Wilfer, this is hardly charitable. I ask you nothing but what\r\nyour own emphasis suggests. However, I waive even that question. But\r\nwhat I have declared, I take my stand by. I cannot recall the avowal of\r\nmy earnest and deep attachment to you, and I do not recall it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I reject it, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should be blind and deaf if I were not prepared for the reply.\r\nForgive my offence, for it carries its punishment with it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What punishment?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Bella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is my present endurance none? But excuse me; I did not mean to\r\ncross-examine you again.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You take advantage of a hasty word of mine,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella with a little\r\nsting of self-reproach, \xe2\x80\x98to make me seem--I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what. I spoke\r\nwithout consideration when I used it. If that was bad, I am sorry; but\r\nyou repeat it after consideration, and that seems to me to be at least\r\nno better. For the rest, I beg it may be understood, Mr Rokesmith, that\r\nthere is an end of this between us, now and for ever.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now and for ever,\xe2\x80\x99 he repeated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. I appeal to you, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 proceeded Bella with increasing spirit,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98not to pursue me. I appeal to you not to take advantage of your\r\nposition in this house to make my position in it distressing and\r\ndisagreeable. I appeal to you to discontinue your habit of making your\r\nmisplaced attentions as plain to Mrs Boffin as to me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have I done so?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should think you have,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Bella. \xe2\x80\x98In any case it is not your\r\nfault if you have not, Mr Rokesmith.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope you are wrong in that impression. I should be very sorry to\r\nhave justified it. I think I have not. For the future there is no\r\napprehension. It is all over.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am much relieved to hear it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella. \xe2\x80\x98I have far other views in\r\nlife, and why should you waste your own?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mine!\xe2\x80\x99 said the Secretary. \xe2\x80\x98My life!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHis curious tone caused Bella to glance at the curious smile with which\r\nhe said it. It was gone as he glanced back. \xe2\x80\x98Pardon me, Miss Wilfer,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nhe proceeded, when their eyes met; \xe2\x80\x98you have used some hard words, for\r\nwhich I do not doubt you have a justification in your mind, that I do\r\nnot understand. Ungenerous and dishonourable. In what?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I would rather not be asked,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, haughtily looking down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I would rather not ask, but the question is imposed upon me. Kindly\r\nexplain; or if not kindly, justly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, sir!\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, raising her eyes to his, after a little struggle\r\nto forbear, \xe2\x80\x98is it generous and honourable to use the power here which\r\nyour favour with Mr and Mrs Boffin and your ability in your place give\r\nyou, against me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Against you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is it generous and honourable to form a plan for gradually bringing\r\ntheir influence to bear upon a suit which I have shown you that I do not\r\nlike, and which I tell you that I utterly reject?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe late John Harmon could have borne a good deal, but he would have\r\nbeen cut to the heart by such a suspicion as this.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Would it be generous and honourable to step into your place--if you did\r\nso, for I don\xe2\x80\x99t know that you did, and I hope you did not--anticipating,\r\nor knowing beforehand, that I should come here, and designing to take me\r\nat this disadvantage?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This mean and cruel disadvantage,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Secretary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 assented Bella.\r\n\r\nThe Secretary kept silence for a little while; then merely said, \xe2\x80\x98You\r\nare wholly mistaken, Miss Wilfer; wonderfully mistaken. I cannot say,\r\nhowever, that it is your fault. If I deserve better things of you, you\r\ndo not know it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98At least, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 retorted Bella, with her old indignation rising, \xe2\x80\x98you\r\nknow the history of my being here at all. I have heard Mr Boffin say\r\nthat you are master of every line and word of that will, as you are\r\nmaster of all his affairs. And was it not enough that I should have been\r\nwilled away, like a horse, or a dog, or a bird; but must you too begin\r\nto dispose of me in your mind, and speculate in me, as soon as I had\r\nceased to be the talk and the laugh of the town? Am I for ever to be\r\nmade the property of strangers?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Believe me,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the Secretary, \xe2\x80\x98you are wonderfully mistaken.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should be glad to know it,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Bella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I doubt if you ever will. Good-night. Of course I shall be careful to\r\nconceal any traces of this interview from Mr and Mrs Boffin, as long as\r\nI remain here. Trust me, what you have complained of is at an end for\r\never.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am glad I have spoken, then, Mr Rokesmith. It has been painful and\r\ndifficult, but it is done. If I have hurt you, I hope you will forgive\r\nme. I am inexperienced and impetuous, and I have been a little spoilt;\r\nbut I really am not so bad as I dare say I appear, or as you think me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe quitted the room when Bella had said this, relenting in her wilful\r\ninconsistent way. Left alone, she threw herself back on her ottoman, and\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x98I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know the lovely woman was such a Dragon!\xe2\x80\x99 Then, she\r\ngot up and looked in the glass, and said to her image, \xe2\x80\x98You have been\r\npositively swelling your features, you little fool!\xe2\x80\x99 Then, she took an\r\nimpatient walk to the other end of the room and back, and said, \xe2\x80\x98I\r\nwish Pa was here to have a talk about an avaricious marriage; but he\r\nis better away, poor dear, for I know I should pull his hair if he WAS\r\nhere.\xe2\x80\x99 And then she threw her work away, and threw her book after\r\nit, and sat down and hummed a tune, and hummed it out of tune, and\r\nquarrelled with it.\r\n\r\nAnd John Rokesmith, what did he?\r\n\r\nHe went down to his room, and buried John Harmon many additional fathoms\r\ndeep. He took his hat, and walked out, and, as he went to Holloway or\r\nanywhere else--not at all minding where--heaped mounds upon mounds of\r\nearth over John Harmon\xe2\x80\x99s grave. His walking did not bring him home until\r\nthe dawn of day. And so busy had he been all night, piling and piling\r\nweights upon weights of earth above John Harmon\xe2\x80\x99s grave, that by that\r\ntime John Harmon lay buried under a whole Alpine range; and still the\r\nSexton Rokesmith accumulated mountains over him, lightening his labour\r\nwith the dirge, \xe2\x80\x98Cover him, crush him, keep him down!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 14\r\n\r\nSTRONG OF PURPOSE\r\n\r\n\r\nThe sexton-task of piling earth above John Harmon all night long, was\r\nnot conducive to sound sleep; but Rokesmith had some broken morning\r\nrest, and rose strengthened in his purpose. It was all over now. No\r\nghost should trouble Mr and Mrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s peace; invisible and voiceless,\r\nthe ghost should look on for a little while longer at the state of\r\nexistence out of which it had departed, and then should for ever cease\r\nto haunt the scenes in which it had no place.\r\n\r\nHe went over it all again. He had lapsed into the condition in which\r\nhe found himself, as many a man lapses into many a condition, without\r\nperceiving the accumulative power of its separate circumstances. When\r\nin the distrust engendered by his wretched childhood and the action for\r\nevil--never yet for good within his knowledge then--of his father and\r\nhis father\xe2\x80\x99s wealth on all within their influence, he conceived the idea\r\nof his first deception, it was meant to be harmless, it was to last\r\nbut a few hours or days, it was to involve in it only the girl so\r\ncapriciously forced upon him and upon whom he was so capriciously\r\nforced, and it was honestly meant well towards her. For, if he had\r\nfound her unhappy in the prospect of that marriage (through her heart\r\ninclining to another man or for any other cause), he would seriously\r\nhave said: \xe2\x80\x98This is another of the old perverted uses of the\r\nmisery-making money. I will let it go to my and my sister\xe2\x80\x99s only\r\nprotectors and friends.\xe2\x80\x99 When the snare into which he fell so\r\noutstripped his first intention as that he found himself placarded by\r\nthe police authorities upon the London walls for dead, he confusedly\r\naccepted the aid that fell upon him, without considering how firmly it\r\nmust seem to fix the Boffins in their accession to the fortune. When he\r\nsaw them, and knew them, and even from his vantage-ground of inspection\r\ncould find no flaw in them, he asked himself, \xe2\x80\x98And shall I come to life\r\nto dispossess such people as these?\xe2\x80\x99 There was no good to set against\r\nthe putting of them to that hard proof. He had heard from Bella\xe2\x80\x99s own\r\nlips when he stood tapping at the door on that night of his taking\r\nthe lodgings, that the marriage would have been on her part thoroughly\r\nmercenary. He had since tried her, in his own unknown person and\r\nsupposed station, and she not only rejected his advances but resented\r\nthem. Was it for him to have the shame of buying her, or the meanness of\r\npunishing her? Yet, by coming to life and accepting the condition of the\r\ninheritance, he must do the former; and by coming to life and rejecting\r\nit, he must do the latter.\r\n\r\nAnother consequence that he had never foreshadowed, was the implication\r\nof an innocent man in his supposed murder. He would obtain complete\r\nretraction from the accuser, and set the wrong right; but clearly the\r\nwrong could never have been done if he had never planned a deception.\r\nThen, whatever inconvenience or distress of mind the deception cost him,\r\nit was manful repentantly to accept as among its consequences, and make\r\nno complaint.\r\n\r\nThus John Rokesmith in the morning, and it buried John Harmon still many\r\nfathoms deeper than he had been buried in the night.\r\n\r\nGoing out earlier than he was accustomed to do, he encountered the\r\ncherub at the door. The cherub\xe2\x80\x99s way was for a certain space his way,\r\nand they walked together.\r\n\r\nIt was impossible not to notice the change in the cherub\xe2\x80\x99s appearance.\r\nThe cherub felt very conscious of it, and modestly remarked:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A present from my daughter Bella, Mr Rokesmith.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe words gave the Secretary a stroke of pleasure, for he remembered the\r\nfifty pounds, and he still loved the girl. No doubt it was very weak--it\r\nalways IS very weak, some authorities hold--but he loved the girl.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know whether you happen to have read many books of African\r\nTravel, Mr Rokesmith?\xe2\x80\x99 said R. W.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have read several.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, you know, there\xe2\x80\x99s usually a King George, or a King Boy, or a King\r\nSambo, or a King Bill, or Bull, or Rum, or Junk, or whatever name the\r\nsailors may have happened to give him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Rokesmith.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Anywhere. Anywhere in Africa, I mean. Pretty well everywhere, I may\r\nsay; for black kings are cheap--and I think\xe2\x80\x99--said R. W., with an\r\napologetic air, \xe2\x80\x98nasty\xe2\x80\x99.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am much of your opinion, Mr Wilfer. You were going to say--?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I was going to say, the king is generally dressed in a London hat only,\r\nor a Manchester pair of braces, or one epaulette, or an uniform coat\r\nwith his legs in the sleeves, or something of that kind.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Just so,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Secretary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In confidence, I assure you, Mr Rokesmith,\xe2\x80\x99 observed the cheerful\r\ncherub, \xe2\x80\x98that when more of my family were at home and to be provided\r\nfor, I used to remind myself immensely of that king. You have no idea,\r\nas a single man, of the difficulty I have had in wearing more than one\r\ngood article at a time.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can easily believe it, Mr Wilfer.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I only mention it,\xe2\x80\x99 said R. W. in the warmth of his heart, \xe2\x80\x98as a proof\r\nof the amiable, delicate, and considerate affection of my daughter\r\nBella. If she had been a little spoilt, I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have thought so very\r\nmuch of it, under the circumstances. But no, not a bit. And she is so\r\nvery pretty! I hope you agree with me in finding her very pretty, Mr\r\nRokesmith?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly I do. Every one must.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope so,\xe2\x80\x99 said the cherub. \xe2\x80\x98Indeed, I have no doubt of it. This is a\r\ngreat advancement for her in life, Mr Rokesmith. A great opening of her\r\nprospects?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Miss Wilfer could have no better friends than Mr and Mrs Boffin.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Impossible!\xe2\x80\x99 said the gratified cherub. \xe2\x80\x98Really I begin to think things\r\nare very well as they are. If Mr John Harmon had lived--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He is better dead,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Secretary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, I won\xe2\x80\x99t go so far as to say that,\xe2\x80\x99 urged the cherub, a little\r\nremonstrant against the very decisive and unpitying tone; \xe2\x80\x98but he\r\nmightn\xe2\x80\x99t have suited Bella, or Bella mightn\xe2\x80\x99t have suited him, or fifty\r\nthings, whereas now I hope she can choose for herself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Has she--as you place the confidence in me of speaking on the subject,\r\nyou will excuse my asking--has she--perhaps--chosen?\xe2\x80\x99 faltered the\r\nSecretary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh dear no!\xe2\x80\x99 returned R. W.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Young ladies sometimes,\xe2\x80\x99 Rokesmith hinted, \xe2\x80\x98choose without mentioning\r\ntheir choice to their fathers.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not in this case, Mr Rokesmith. Between my daughter Bella and me there\r\nis a regular league and covenant of confidence. It was ratified only the\r\nother day. The ratification dates from--these,\xe2\x80\x99 said the cherub,\r\ngiving a little pull at the lappels of his coat and the pockets of his\r\ntrousers. \xe2\x80\x98Oh no, she has not chosen. To be sure, young George Sampson,\r\nin the days when Mr John Harmon--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who I wish had never been born!\xe2\x80\x99 said the Secretary, with a gloomy\r\nbrow.\r\n\r\nR. W. looked at him with surprise, as thinking he had contracted an\r\nunaccountable spite against the poor deceased, and continued: \xe2\x80\x98In the\r\ndays when Mr John Harmon was being sought out, young George Sampson\r\ncertainly was hovering about Bella, and Bella let him hover. But it\r\nnever was seriously thought of, and it\xe2\x80\x99s still less than ever to be\r\nthought of now. For Bella is ambitious, Mr Rokesmith, and I think I may\r\npredict will marry fortune. This time, you see, she will have the person\r\nand the property before her together, and will be able to make her\r\nchoice with her eyes open. This is my road. I am very sorry to part\r\ncompany so soon. Good morning, sir!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe Secretary pursued his way, not very much elevated in spirits by this\r\nconversation, and, arriving at the Boffin mansion, found Betty Higden\r\nwaiting for him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should thank you kindly, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Betty, \xe2\x80\x98if I might make so bold\r\nas have a word or two wi\xe2\x80\x99 you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe should have as many words as she liked, he told her; and took her\r\ninto his room, and made her sit down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x99Tis concerning Sloppy, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Betty. \xe2\x80\x98And that\xe2\x80\x99s how I come here\r\nby myself. If I was young, it would all have to be gone through again,\r\nand the end would be a weary way off, don\xe2\x80\x99t you see? But never mind me;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98tis concerning Sloppy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And what about him, Betty?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x99Tis just this, sir. Now he can\xe2\x80\x99t. To give himself up\r\nto being put in the way of arning a good living and getting on, he must\r\ngive me up. Well; he won\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I respect him for it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Rokesmith.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98DO ye, sir? I don\xe2\x80\x99t know but what I do myself. And in the nod and in the firm set\r\nof her mouth, there was a vigour of purpose not to be doubted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come, come!\xe2\x80\x99 said the Secretary. \xe2\x80\x98We must talk about this. But it did\r\njust keep us on, the two together. Now that I\xe2\x80\x99m alone--with even Johnny\r\ngone--I\xe2\x80\x99d far sooner be upon my feet and tiring of myself out, than a\r\nsitting folding and folding by the fire. And I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you why. There\xe2\x80\x99s\r\na deadness steals over me at times, that the kind of life favours and I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t like. Now, I seem to have Johnny in my arms--now, his mother--now,\r\nhis mother\xe2\x80\x99s mother--now, I seem to be a child myself, a lying once\r\nagain in the arms of my own mother--then I get numbed, thought and\r\nsense, till I start out of my seat, afeerd that I\xe2\x80\x99m a growing like the\r\npoor old people that they brick up in the Unions, as you may sometimes\r\nsee when they let \xe2\x80\x98em out of the four walls to have a warm in the sun,\r\ncrawling quite scared about the streets. I was a nimble girl, and have\r\nalways been a active body, as I told your lady, first time ever I see\r\nher good face. I can still walk twenty mile if I am put to it. I\xe2\x80\x99d far\r\nbetter be a walking than a getting numbed and dreary. I\xe2\x80\x99m a good fair\r\nknitter, and can make many little things to sell. The loan from your\r\nlady and gentleman of twenty shillings to fit out a basket with, would\r\nbe a fortune for me. Trudging round the country and tiring of myself\r\nout, I shall keep the deadness off, and get my own bread by my own\r\nlabour. And what more can I want?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And this is your plan,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Secretary, \xe2\x80\x98for running away?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Show me a better! My deary, show me a better! Why, I know very well,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid old Betty Higden, \xe2\x80\x98and you know very well, that your lady and\r\ngentleman would set me up like a queen for the rest of my life, if so be\r\nthat we could make it right among us to have it so. But we can\xe2\x80\x99t make it\r\nright among us to have it so. I\xe2\x80\x99ve never took charity yet, nor yet has\r\nany one belonging to me. And it would be forsaking of myself indeed, and\r\nforsaking of my children dead and gone, and forsaking of their children\r\ndead and gone, to set up a contradiction now at last.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It might come to be justifiable and unavoidable at last,\xe2\x80\x99 the Secretary\r\ngently hinted, with a slight stress on the word.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope it never will! It ain\xe2\x80\x99t that I mean to give offence by being\r\nanyways proud,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old creature simply, \xe2\x80\x98but that I want to be of\r\na piece like, and helpful of myself right through to my death.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And to be sure,\xe2\x80\x99 added the Secretary, as a comfort for her, \xe2\x80\x98Sloppy\r\nwill be eagerly looking forward to his opportunity of being to you what\r\nyou have been to him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Trust him for that, sir!\xe2\x80\x99 said Betty, cheerfully. \xe2\x80\x98Though he had need\r\nto be something quick about it, for I\xe2\x80\x99m a getting to be an old one. She and her husband had worked too, and had brought\r\ntheir simple faith and honour clean out of dustheaps. If they owed a\r\nduty to Betty Higden, of a surety that duty must be done.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But, Betty,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Boffin, when she accompanied John Rokesmith back\r\nto his room, and shone upon her with the light of her radiant face,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98granted all else, I think I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t run away\xe2\x80\x99.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x99Twould come easier to Sloppy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Higden, shaking her head.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x99Twould come easier to me too. I know many parts of the country well. When\r\nnothing else was to be done, I have worked in many a market-garden afore\r\nnow, and in many a hop-garden too.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If I give my consent to your going, Betty--which Mr Rokesmith thinks I\r\nought to do--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBetty thanked him with a grateful curtsey.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98--We must not lose sight of you.
