And\r\nthis he will add; that Anastatia Veneering (who is instantly heard to\r\nweep) is formed on the same model as her old and chosen friend Sophronia\r\nLammle, in respect that she is devoted to the man who wooed and won her,\r\nand nobly discharges the duties of a wife.\r\n\r\nSeeing no better way out of it, Veneering here pulls up his oratorical\r\nPegasus extremely short, and plumps down, clean over his head, with:\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lammle, God bless you!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThen Lammle. Too much of him every way; pervadingly too much nose of a\r\ncoarse wrong shape, and his nose in his mind and his manners; too much\r\nsmile to be real; too much frown to be false; too many large teeth to be\r\nvisible at once without suggesting a bite. He thanks you, dear friends,\r\nfor your kindly greeting, and hopes to receive you--it may be on the\r\nnext of these delightful occasions--in a residence better suited to\r\nyour claims on the rites of hospitality. He will never forget that at\r\nVeneering\xe2\x80\x99s he first saw Sophronia. Sophronia will never forget that at\r\nVeneering\xe2\x80\x99s she first saw him. \xe2\x80\x98They spoke of it soon after they\r\nwere married, and agreed that they would never forget it. In fact, to\r\nVeneering they owe their union. They hope to show their sense of this\r\nsome day [\xe2\x80\x98No, no, from Veneering)--oh yes, yes, and let him rely\r\nupon it, they will if they can! His marriage with Sophronia was not a\r\nmarriage of interest on either side: she had her little fortune, he had\r\nhis little fortune: they joined their little fortunes: it was a marriage\r\nof pure inclination and suitability. Thank you! Sophronia and he are\r\nfond of the society of young people; but he is not sure that their house\r\nwould be a good house for young people proposing to remain single, since\r\nthe contemplation of its domestic bliss might induce them to change\r\ntheir minds. He will not apply this to any one present; certainly not\r\nto their darling little Georgiana. Again thank you! Neither, by-the-by,\r\nwill he apply it to his friend Fledgeby. He thanks Veneering for the\r\nfeeling manner in which he referred to their common friend Fledgeby, for\r\nhe holds that gentleman in the highest estimation. Thank you. In fact\r\n(returning unexpectedly to Fledgeby), the better you know him, the more\r\nyou find in him that you desire to know. Again thank you! In his dear\r\nSophronia\xe2\x80\x99s name and in his own, thank you!\r\n\r\nMrs Lammle has sat quite still, with her eyes cast down upon the\r\ntable-cloth. As Mr Lammle\xe2\x80\x99s address ends, Twemlow once more turns to her\r\ninvoluntarily, not cured yet of that often recurring impression that she\r\nis going to speak to him. This time she really is going to speak to him.\r\nVeneering is talking with his other next neighbour, and she speaks in a\r\nlow voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Twemlow.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe answers, \xe2\x80\x98I beg your pardon? Yes?\xe2\x80\x99 Still a little doubtful, because\r\nof her not looking at him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have the soul of a gentleman, and I know I may trust you. Will you\r\ngive me the opportunity of saying a few words to you when you come up\r\nstairs?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Assuredly. I shall be honoured.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t seem to do so, if you please, and don\xe2\x80\x99t think it inconsistent if\r\nmy manner should be more careless than my words. I may be watched.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIntensely astonished, Twemlow puts his hand to his forehead, and sinks\r\nback in his chair meditating. Mrs Lammle rises. All rise. The ladies go\r\nup stairs. The gentlemen soon saunter after them. Fledgeby has devoted\r\nthe interval to taking an observation of Boots\xe2\x80\x99s whiskers, Brewer\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwhiskers, and Lammle\xe2\x80\x99s whiskers, and considering which pattern of\r\nwhisker he would prefer to produce out of himself by friction, if the\r\nGenie of the cheek would only answer to his rubbing.\r\n\r\nIn the drawing-room, groups form as usual. Lightwood, Boots, and Brewer,\r\nflutter like moths around that yellow wax candle--guttering down,\r\nand with some hint of a winding-sheet in it--Lady Tippins. Outsiders\r\ncultivate Veneering, M P., and Mrs Veneering, W.M.P. Lammle stands with\r\nfolded arms, Mephistophelean in a corner, with Georgiana and Fledgeby.\r\nMrs Lammle, on a sofa by a table, invites Mr Twemlow\xe2\x80\x99s attention to a\r\nbook of portraits in her hand.\r\n\r\nMr Twemlow takes his station on a settee before her, and Mrs Lammle\r\nshows him a portrait.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have reason to be surprised,\xe2\x80\x99 she says softly, \xe2\x80\x98but I wish you\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t look so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDisturbed Twemlow, making an effort not to look so, looks much more so.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think, Mr Twemlow, you never saw that distant connexion of yours\r\nbefore to-day?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, never.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now that you do see him, you see what he is. You are not proud of him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To say the truth, Mrs Lammle, no.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If you knew more of him, you would be less inclined to acknowledge him.\r\nHere is another portrait. What do you think of it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nTwemlow has just presence of mind enough to say aloud: \xe2\x80\x98Very like!\r\nUncommonly like!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have noticed, perhaps, whom he favours with his attentions? You\r\nnotice where he is now, and how engaged?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. But Mr Lammle--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe darts a look at him which he cannot comprehend, and shows him\r\nanother portrait.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very good; is it not?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Charming!\xe2\x80\x99 says Twemlow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So like as to be almost a caricature?--Mr Twemlow, it is impossible\r\nto tell you what the struggle in my mind has been, before I could bring\r\nmyself to speak to you as I do now. It is only in the conviction that I\r\nmay trust you never to betray me, that I can proceed. Sincerely promise\r\nme that you never will betray my confidence--that you will respect it,\r\neven though you may no longer respect me,--and I shall be as satisfied\r\nas if you had sworn it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Madam, on the honour of a poor gentleman--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you. I can desire no more. Mr Twemlow, I implore you to save that\r\nchild!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That child?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Georgiana. She will be sacrificed. She will be inveigled and married\r\nto that connexion of yours. It is a partnership affair, a\r\nmoney-speculation. She has no strength of will or character to help\r\nherself and she is on the brink of being sold into wretchedness for\r\nlife.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Amazing! But what can I do to prevent it?\xe2\x80\x99 demands Twemlow, shocked and\r\nbewildered to the last degree.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here is another portrait. And not good, is it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAghast at the light manner of her throwing her head back to look at it\r\ncritically, Twemlow still dimly perceives the expediency of throwing his\r\nown head back, and does so. Though he no more sees the portrait than if\r\nit were in China.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Decidedly not good,\xe2\x80\x99 says Mrs Lammle. \xe2\x80\x98Stiff and exaggerated!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And ex--\xe2\x80\x99 But Twemlow, in his demolished state, cannot command the\r\nword, and trails off into \xe2\x80\x98--actly so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Twemlow, your word will have weight with her pompous, self-blinded\r\nfather. You know how much he makes of your family. Lose no time. Warn\r\nhim.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But warn him against whom?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Against me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBy great good fortune Twemlow receives a stimulant at this critical\r\ninstant. The stimulant is Lammle\xe2\x80\x99s voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sophronia, my dear, what portraits are you showing Twemlow?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Public characters, Alfred.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Show him the last of me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, Alfred.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe puts the book down, takes another book up, turns the leaves, and\r\npresents the portrait to Twemlow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That is the last of Mr Lammle. Do you think it good?--Warn her father\r\nagainst me. I deserve it, for I have been in the scheme from the first.\r\nIt is my husband\xe2\x80\x99s scheme, your connexion\xe2\x80\x99s, and mine. I tell you this,\r\nonly to show you the necessity of the poor little foolish affectionate\r\ncreature\xe2\x80\x99s being befriended and rescued. You will not repeat this to her\r\nfather. You will spare me so far, and spare my husband. For, though this\r\ncelebration of to-day is all a mockery, he is my husband, and we must\r\nlive.--Do you think it like?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nTwemlow, in a stunned condition, feigns to compare the portrait in his\r\nhand with the original looking towards him from his Mephistophelean\r\ncorner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very well indeed!\xe2\x80\x99 are at length the words which Twemlow with great\r\ndifficulty extracts from himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am glad you think so. On the whole, I myself consider it the best.\r\nThe others are so dark. Now here, for instance, is another of Mr\r\nLammle--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I don\xe2\x80\x99t understand; I don\xe2\x80\x99t see my way,\xe2\x80\x99 Twemlow stammers, as he\r\nfalters over the book with his glass at his eye. \xe2\x80\x98How warn her father,\r\nand not tell him? Tell him how much? Tell him how little? I--I--am\r\ngetting lost.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Tell him I am a match-maker; tell him I am an artful and designing\r\nwoman; tell him you are sure his daughter is best out of my house and my\r\ncompany. Tell him any such things of me; they will all be true. You know\r\nwhat a puffed-up man he is, and how easily you can cause his vanity to\r\ntake the alarm. Tell him as much as will give him the alarm and make\r\nhim careful of her, and spare me the rest. Mr Twemlow, I feel my sudden\r\ndegradation in your eyes; familiar as I am with my degradation in my own\r\neyes, I keenly feel the change that must have come upon me in yours,\r\nin these last few moments. But I trust to your good faith with me as\r\nimplicitly as when I began. If you knew how often I have tried to speak\r\nto you to-day, you would almost pity me. I want no new promise from you\r\non my own account, for I am satisfied, and I always shall be satisfied,\r\nwith the promise you have given me. I can venture to say no more, for\r\nI see that I am watched. If you would set my mind at rest with the\r\nassurance that you will interpose with the father and save this harmless\r\ngirl, close that book before you return it to me, and I shall know what\r\nyou mean, and deeply thank you in my heart.--Alfred, Mr Twemlow thinks\r\nthe last one the best, and quite agrees with you and me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAlfred advances. The groups break up. Lady Tippins rises to go, and Mrs\r\nVeneering follows her leader. For the moment, Mrs Lammle does not turn\r\nto them, but remains looking at Twemlow looking at Alfred\xe2\x80\x99s portrait\r\nthrough his eyeglass. The moment past, Twemlow drops his eyeglass at its\r\nribbon\xe2\x80\x99s length, rises, and closes the book with an emphasis which makes\r\nthat fragile nursling of the fairies, Tippins, start.\r\n\r\nThen good-bye and good-bye, and charming occasion worthy of the Golden\r\nAge, and more about the flitch of bacon, and the like of that; and\r\nTwemlow goes staggering across Piccadilly with his hand to his forehead,\r\nand is nearly run down by a flushed lettercart, and at last drops\r\nsafe in his easy-chair, innocent good gentleman, with his hand to his\r\nforehead still, and his head in a whirl.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBOOK THE THIRD -- A LONG LANE\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 1\r\n\r\nLODGERS IN QUEER STREET\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was a foggy day in London, and the fog was heavy and dark. Animate\r\nLondon, with smarting eyes and irritated lungs, was blinking, wheezing,\r\nand choking; inanimate London was a sooty spectre, divided in purpose\r\nbetween being visible and invisible, and so being wholly neither.\r\nGaslights flared in the shops with a haggard and unblest air, as knowing\r\nthemselves to be night-creatures that had no business abroad under the\r\nsun; while the sun itself when it was for a few moments dimly indicated\r\nthrough circling eddies of fog, showed as if it had gone out and were\r\ncollapsing flat and cold. Even in the surrounding country it was a foggy\r\nday, but there the fog was grey, whereas in London it was, at about\r\nthe boundary line, dark yellow, and a little within it brown, and then\r\nbrowner, and then browner, until at the heart of the City--which call\r\nSaint Mary Axe--it was rusty-black. From any point of the high ridge of\r\nland northward, it might have been discerned that the loftiest buildings\r\nmade an occasional struggle to get their heads above the foggy sea, and\r\nespecially that the great dome of Saint Paul\xe2\x80\x99s seemed to die hard; but\r\nthis was not perceivable in the streets at their feet, where the whole\r\nmetropolis was a heap of vapour charged with muffled sound of wheels,\r\nand enfolding a gigantic catarrh.\r\n\r\nAt nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock on such a morning, the place of business of Pubsey and\r\nCo. was not the liveliest object even in Saint Mary Axe--which is not a\r\nvery lively spot--with a sobbing gaslight in the counting-house window,\r\nand a burglarious stream of fog creeping in to strangle it through the\r\nkeyhole of the main door. But the light went out, and the main door\r\nopened, and Riah came forth with a bag under his arm.\r\n\r\nAlmost in the act of coming out at the door, Riah went into the fog, and\r\nwas lost to the eyes of Saint Mary Axe. But the eyes of this history\r\ncan follow him westward, by Cornhill, Cheapside, Fleet Street, and the\r\nStrand, to Piccadilly and the Albany. Thither he went at his grave and\r\nmeasured pace, staff in hand, skirt at heel; and more than one head,\r\nturning to look back at his venerable figure already lost in the mist,\r\nsupposed it to be some ordinary figure indistinctly seen, which fancy\r\nand the fog had worked into that passing likeness.\r\n\r\nArrived at the house in which his master\xe2\x80\x99s chambers were on the\r\nsecond floor, Riah proceeded up the stairs, and paused at Fascination\r\nFledgeby\xe2\x80\x99s door. Making free with neither bell nor knocker, he struck\r\nupon the door with the top of his staff, and, having listened, sat down\r\non the threshold. It was characteristic of his habitual submission,\r\nthat he sat down on the raw dark staircase, as many of his ancestors\r\nhad probably sat down in dungeons, taking what befell him as it might\r\nbefall.\r\n\r\nAfter a time, when he had grown so cold as to be fain to blow upon his\r\nfingers, he arose and knocked with his staff again, and listened again,\r\nand again sat down to wait. Thrice he repeated these actions before his\r\nlistening ears were greeted by the voice of Fledgeby, calling from his\r\nbed, \xe2\x80\x98Hold your row!--I\xe2\x80\x99ll come and open the door directly!\xe2\x80\x99 But, in\r\nlieu of coming directly, he fell into a sweet sleep for some quarter of\r\nan hour more, during which added interval Riah sat upon the stairs and\r\nwaited with perfect patience.\r\n\r\nAt length the door stood open, and Mr Fledgeby\xe2\x80\x99s retreating drapery\r\nplunged into bed again. Following it at a respectful distance, Riah\r\npassed into the bed-chamber, where a fire had been sometime lighted, and\r\nwas burning briskly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, what time of night do you mean to call it?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Fledgeby,\r\nturning away beneath the clothes, and presenting a comfortable rampart\r\nof shoulder to the chilled figure of the old man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir, it is full half-past ten in the morning.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The deuce it is! Then it must be precious foggy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very foggy, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And raw, then?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Chill and bitter,\xe2\x80\x99 said Riah, drawing out a handkerchief, and wiping\r\nthe moisture from his beard and long grey hair as he stood on the verge\r\nof the rug, with his eyes on the acceptable fire.\r\n\r\nWith a plunge of enjoyment, Fledgeby settled himself afresh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Any snow, or sleet, or slush, or anything of that sort?\xe2\x80\x99 he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, sir, no. Not quite so bad as that. The streets are pretty clean.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You needn\xe2\x80\x99t brag about it,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Fledgeby, disappointed in his\r\ndesire to heighten the contrast between his bed and the streets. \xe2\x80\x98But\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99re always bragging about something. Got the books there?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They are here, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98All right. I\xe2\x80\x99ll turn the general subject over in my mind for a minute\r\nor two, and while I\xe2\x80\x99m about it you can empty your bag and get ready for\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith another comfortable plunge, Mr Fledgeby fell asleep again. The old\r\nman, having obeyed his directions, sat down on the edge of a chair, and,\r\nfolding his hands before him, gradually yielded to the influence of the\r\nwarmth, and dozed. He was roused by Mr Fledgeby\xe2\x80\x99s appearing erect at\r\nthe foot of the bed, in Turkish slippers, rose-coloured Turkish trousers\r\n(got cheap from somebody who had cheated some other somebody out of\r\nthem), and a gown and cap to correspond. In that costume he would have\r\nleft nothing to be desired, if he had been further fitted out with a\r\nbottomless chair, a lantern, and a bunch of matches.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, old \xe2\x80\x98un!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Fascination, in his light raillery, \xe2\x80\x98what dodgery\r\nare you up to next, sitting there with your eyes shut? You ain\xe2\x80\x99t asleep.\r\nCatch a weasel at it, and catch a Jew!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Truly, sir, I fear I nodded,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not you!\xe2\x80\x99 returned Fledgeby, with a cunning look. \xe2\x80\x98A telling move with\r\na good many, I dare say, but it won\xe2\x80\x99t put ME off my guard. Not a bad\r\nnotion though, if you want to look indifferent in driving a bargain. Oh,\r\nyou are a dodger!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe old man shook his head, gently repudiating the imputation, and\r\nsuppressed a sigh, and moved to the table at which Mr Fledgeby was now\r\npouring out for himself a cup of steaming and fragrant coffee from a pot\r\nthat had stood ready on the hob. It was an edifying spectacle, the young\r\nman in his easy chair taking his coffee, and the old man with his grey\r\nhead bent, standing awaiting his pleasure.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now!\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby. \xe2\x80\x98Fork out your balance in hand, and prove by\r\nfigures how you make it out that it ain\xe2\x80\x99t more. First of all, light that\r\ncandle.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nRiah obeyed, and then taking a bag from his breast, and referring to\r\nthe sum in the accounts for which they made him responsible, told it out\r\nupon the table. Fledgeby told it again with great care, and rang every\r\nsovereign.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, taking one up to eye it closely, \xe2\x80\x98you haven\xe2\x80\x99t been\r\nlightening any of these; but it\xe2\x80\x99s a trade of your people\xe2\x80\x99s, you know.\r\nYOU understand what sweating a pound means, don\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Much as you do, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the old man, with his hands under\r\nopposite cuffs of his loose sleeves, as he stood at the table,\r\ndeferentially observant of the master\xe2\x80\x99s face. \xe2\x80\x98May I take the liberty to\r\nsay something?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You may,\xe2\x80\x99 Fledgeby graciously conceded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you not, sir--without intending it--of a surety without intending\r\nit--sometimes mingle the character I fairly earn in your employment,\r\nwith the character which it is your policy that I should bear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t find it worth my while to cut things so fine as to go into the\r\ninquiry,\xe2\x80\x99 Fascination coolly answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not in justice?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bother justice!\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not in generosity?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Jews and generosity!\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby. \xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s a good connexion! Bring\r\nout your vouchers, and don\xe2\x80\x99t talk Jerusalem palaver.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe vouchers were produced, and for the next half-hour Mr Fledgeby\r\nconcentrated his sublime attention on them. They and the accounts were\r\nall found correct, and the books and the papers resumed their places in\r\nthe bag.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Next,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby, \xe2\x80\x98concerning that bill-broking branch of the\r\nbusiness; the branch I like best. What queer bills are to be bought, and\r\nat what prices? You have got your list of what\xe2\x80\x99s in the market?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir, a long list,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Riah, taking out a pocket-book, and\r\nselecting from its contents a folded paper, which, being unfolded,\r\nbecame a sheet of foolscap covered with close writing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Whew!\xe2\x80\x99 whistled Fledgeby, as he took it in his hand. \xe2\x80\x98Queer Street is\r\nfull of lodgers just at present! These are to be disposed of in parcels;\r\nare they?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In parcels as set forth,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the old man, looking over his\r\nmaster\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder; \xe2\x80\x98or the lump.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Half the lump will be waste-paper, one knows beforehand,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nFledgeby. \xe2\x80\x98Can you get it at waste-paper price? That\xe2\x80\x99s the question.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nRiah shook his head, and Fledgeby cast his small eyes down the list.\r\nThey presently began to twinkle, and he no sooner became conscious of\r\ntheir twinkling, than he looked up over his shoulder at the grave face\r\nabove him, and moved to the chimney-piece. Making a desk of it, he stood\r\nthere with his back to the old man, warming his knees, perusing the list\r\nat his leisure, and often returning to some lines of it, as though\r\nthey were particularly interesting. At those times he glanced in the\r\nchimney-glass to see what note the old man took of him. He took none\r\nthat could be detected, but, aware of his employer\xe2\x80\x99s suspicions, stood\r\nwith his eyes on the ground.\r\n\r\nMr Fledgeby was thus amiably engaged when a step was heard at the outer\r\ndoor, and the door was heard to open hastily. \xe2\x80\x98Hark! That\xe2\x80\x99s your doing,\r\nyou Pump of Israel,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby; \xe2\x80\x98you can\xe2\x80\x99t have shut it.\xe2\x80\x99 Then the\r\nstep was heard within, and the voice of Mr Alfred Lammle called aloud,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you anywhere here, Fledgeby?\xe2\x80\x99 To which Fledgeby, after cautioning\r\nRiah in a low voice to take his cue as it should be given him, replied,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here I am!\xe2\x80\x99 and opened his bedroom door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come in!\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby. \xe2\x80\x98This gentleman is only Pubsey and Co. of\r\nSaint Mary Axe, that I am trying to make terms for an unfortunate friend\r\nwith in a matter of some dishonoured bills. But really Pubsey and Co.\r\nare so strict with their debtors, and so hard to move, that I seem to be\r\nwasting my time. Can\xe2\x80\x99t I make ANY terms with you on my friend\xe2\x80\x99s part, Mr\r\nRiah?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am but the representative of another, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the Jew in a low\r\nvoice. \xe2\x80\x98I do as I am bidden by my principal. It is not my capital that\r\nis invested in the business. It is not my profit that arises therefrom.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ha ha!\xe2\x80\x99 laughed Fledgeby. \xe2\x80\x98Lammle?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ha ha!\xe2\x80\x99 laughed Lammle. \xe2\x80\x98Yes. Of course. We know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Devilish good, ain\xe2\x80\x99t it, Lammle?\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby, unspeakably amused by\r\nhis hidden joke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Always the same, always the same!\xe2\x80\x99 said Lammle. \xe2\x80\x98Mr--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Riah, Pubsey and Co. Saint Mary Axe,\xe2\x80\x99 Fledgeby put in, as he wiped away\r\nthe tears that trickled from his eyes, so rare was his enjoyment of his\r\nsecret joke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Riah is bound to observe the invariable forms for such cases made\r\nand provided,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lammle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He is only the representative of another!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Fledgeby. \xe2\x80\x98Does as\r\nhe is told by his principal! Not his capital that\xe2\x80\x99s invested in the\r\nbusiness. Oh, that\xe2\x80\x99s good! Ha ha ha ha!\xe2\x80\x99 Mr Lammle joined in the laugh\r\nand looked knowing; and the more he did both, the more exquisite the\r\nsecret joke became for Mr Fledgeby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98However,\xe2\x80\x99 said that fascinating gentleman, wiping his eyes again, \xe2\x80\x98if\r\nwe go on in this way, we shall seem to be almost making game of Mr Riah,\r\nor of Pubsey and Co. Saint Mary Axe, or of somebody: which is far from\r\nour intention. Mr Riah, if you would have the kindness to step into the\r\nnext room for a few moments while I speak with Mr Lammle here, I should\r\nlike to try to make terms with you once again before you go.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe old man, who had never raised his eyes during the whole transaction\r\nof Mr Fledgeby\xe2\x80\x99s joke, silently bowed and passed out by the door which\r\nFledgeby opened for him. Having closed it on him, Fledgeby returned to\r\nLammle, standing with his back to the bedroom fire, with one hand under\r\nhis coat-skirts, and all his whiskers in the other.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Halloa!\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby. \xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s something wrong!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How do you know it?\xe2\x80\x99 demanded Lammle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Because you show it,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Fledgeby in unintentional rhyme.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well then; there is,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lammle; \xe2\x80\x98there IS something wrong; the whole\r\nthing\xe2\x80\x99s wrong.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I say!\xe2\x80\x99 remonstrated Fascination very slowly, and sitting down with his\r\nhands on his knees to stare at his glowering friend with his back to the\r\nfire.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I tell you, Fledgeby,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Lammle, with a sweep of his right arm,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98the whole thing\xe2\x80\x99s wrong. The game\xe2\x80\x99s up.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What game\xe2\x80\x99s up?\xe2\x80\x99 demanded Fledgeby, as slowly as before, and more\r\nsternly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98THE game. OUR game. Read that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nFledgeby took a note from his extended hand and read it aloud. \xe2\x80\x98Alfred\r\nLammle, Esquire. Sir: Allow Mrs Podsnap and myself to express our united\r\nsense of the polite attentions of Mrs Alfred Lammle and yourself towards\r\nour daughter, Georgiana. Allow us also, wholly to reject them for the\r\nfuture, and to communicate our final desire that the two families\r\nmay become entire strangers. I have the honour to be, Sir, your most\r\nobedient and very humble servant, JOHN PODSNAP.\xe2\x80\x99 Fledgeby looked at the\r\nthree blank sides of this note, quite as long and earnestly as at the\r\nfirst expressive side, and then looked at Lammle, who responded with\r\nanother extensive sweep of his right arm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Whose doing is this?\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Impossible to imagine,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lammle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Perhaps,\xe2\x80\x99 suggested Fledgeby, after reflecting with a very discontented\r\nbrow, \xe2\x80\x98somebody has been giving you a bad character.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Or you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lammle, with a deeper frown.\r\n\r\nMr Fledgeby appeared to be on the verge of some mutinous expressions,\r\nwhen his hand happened to touch his nose. A certain remembrance\r\nconnected with that feature operating as a timely warning, he took it\r\nthoughtfully between his thumb and forefinger, and pondered; Lammle\r\nmeanwhile eyeing him with furtive eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well!\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby. \xe2\x80\x98This won\xe2\x80\x99t improve with talking about. If we\r\never find out who did it, we\xe2\x80\x99ll mark that person. There\xe2\x80\x99s nothing more\r\nto be said, except that you undertook to do what circumstances prevent\r\nyour doing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And that you undertook to do what you might have done by this time, if\r\nyou had made a prompter use of circumstances,\xe2\x80\x99 snarled Lammle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hah! That,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Fledgeby, with his hands in the Turkish trousers,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98is matter of opinion.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Fledgeby,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lammle, in a bullying tone, \xe2\x80\x98am I to understand that\r\nyou in any way reflect upon me, or hint dissatisfaction with me, in this\r\naffair?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby; \xe2\x80\x98provided you have brought my promissory note in\r\nyour pocket, and now hand it over.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLammle produced it, not without reluctance. Fledgeby looked at it,\r\nidentified it, twisted it up, and threw it into the fire. They both\r\nlooked at it as it blazed, went out, and flew in feathery ash up the\r\nchimney.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98NOW, Mr Fledgeby,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lammle, as before; \xe2\x80\x98am I to understand that\r\nyou in any way reflect upon me, or hint dissatisfaction with me, in this\r\naffair?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Finally and unreservedly no?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Fledgeby, my hand.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Fledgeby took it, saying, \xe2\x80\x98And if we ever find out who did this,\r\nwe\xe2\x80\x99ll mark that person. And in the most friendly manner, let me mention\r\none thing more. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what your circumstances are, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nask. You have sustained a loss here. Many men are liable to be involved\r\nat times, and you may be, or you may not be. But whatever you do,\r\nLammle, don\xe2\x80\x99t--don\xe2\x80\x99t--don\xe2\x80\x99t, I beg of you--ever fall into the hands of\r\nPubsey and Co. in the next room, for they are grinders. Regular flayers\r\nand grinders, my dear Lammle,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Fledgeby with a peculiar relish,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98and they\xe2\x80\x99ll skin you by the inch, from the nape of your neck to the\r\nsole of your foot, and grind every inch of your skin to tooth-powder.\r\nYou have seen what Mr Riah is. Never fall into his hands, Lammle, I beg\r\nof you as a friend!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Lammle, disclosing some alarm at the solemnity of this affectionate\r\nadjuration, demanded why the devil he ever should fall into the hands of\r\nPubsey and Co.?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To confess the fact, I was made a little uneasy,\xe2\x80\x99 said the candid\r\nFledgeby, \xe2\x80\x98by the manner in which that Jew looked at you when he heard\r\nyour name. I didn\xe2\x80\x99t like his eye. But it may have been the heated\r\nfancy of a friend. Of course if you are sure that you have no personal\r\nsecurity out, which you may not be quite equal to meeting, and which can\r\nhave got into his hands, it must have been fancy. Still, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t like\r\nhis eye.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe brooding Lammle, with certain white dints coming and going in his\r\npalpitating nose, looked as if some tormenting imp were pinching it.\r\nFledgeby, watching him with a twitch in his mean face which did duty\r\nthere for a smile, looked very like the tormentor who was pinching.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I mustn\xe2\x80\x99t keep him waiting too long,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby, \xe2\x80\x98or he\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nrevenge it on my unfortunate friend. How\xe2\x80\x99s your very clever and\r\nagreeable wife? She knows we have broken down?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I showed her the letter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very much surprised?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Fledgeby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think she would have been more so,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Lammle, \xe2\x80\x98if there had\r\nbeen more go in YOU?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh!--She lays it upon me, then?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Fledgeby, I will not have my words misconstrued.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t break out, Lammle,\xe2\x80\x99 urged Fledgeby, in a submissive tone,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98because there\xe2\x80\x99s no occasion. I only asked a question. Then she don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nlay it upon me? To ask another question.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very good,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby, plainly seeing that she did. \xe2\x80\x98My compliments\r\nto her. Good-bye!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey shook hands, and Lammle strode out pondering. Fledgeby saw him\r\ninto the fog, and, returning to the fire and musing with his face to it,\r\nstretched the legs of the rose-coloured Turkish trousers wide apart, and\r\nmeditatively bent his knees, as if he were going down upon them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have a pair of whiskers, Lammle, which I never liked,\xe2\x80\x99 murmured\r\nFledgeby, \xe2\x80\x98and which money can\xe2\x80\x99t produce; you are boastful of your\r\nmanners and your conversation; you wanted to pull my nose, and you have\r\nlet me in for a failure, and your wife says I am the cause of it. I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nbowl you down. I will, though I have no whiskers,\xe2\x80\x99 here he rubbed the\r\nplaces where they were due, \xe2\x80\x98and no manners, and no conversation!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHaving thus relieved his noble mind, he collected the legs of the\r\nTurkish trousers, straightened himself on his knees, and called out\r\nto Riah in the next room, \xe2\x80\x98Halloa, you sir!\xe2\x80\x99 At sight of the old man\r\nre-entering with a gentleness monstrously in contrast with the character\r\nhe had given him, Mr Fledgeby was so tickled again, that he exclaimed,\r\nlaughing, \xe2\x80\x98Good! Good! Upon my soul it is uncommon good!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, old \xe2\x80\x98un,\xe2\x80\x99 proceeded Fledgeby, when he had had his laugh out,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98you\xe2\x80\x99ll buy up these lots that I mark with my pencil--there\xe2\x80\x99s a tick\r\nthere, and a tick there, and a tick there--and I wager two-pence you\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nafterwards go on squeezing those Christians like the Jew you are. Now,\r\nnext you\xe2\x80\x99ll want a cheque--or you\xe2\x80\x99ll say you want it, though you\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\ncapital enough somewhere, if one only knew where, but you\xe2\x80\x99d be peppered\r\nand salted and grilled on a gridiron before you\xe2\x80\x99d own to it--and that\r\ncheque I\xe2\x80\x99ll write.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWhen he had unlocked a drawer and taken a key from it to open another\r\ndrawer, in which was another key that opened another drawer, in which\r\nwas another key that opened another drawer, in which was the cheque\r\nbook; and when he had written the cheque; and when, reversing the key\r\nand drawer process, he had placed his cheque book in safety again; he\r\nbeckoned the old man, with the folded cheque, to come and take it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Old \xe2\x80\x98un,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby, when the Jew had put it in his pocketbook, and\r\nwas putting that in the breast of his outer garment; \xe2\x80\x98so much at present\r\nfor my affairs. Now a word about affairs that are not exactly mine.\r\nWhere is she?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith his hand not yet withdrawn from the breast of his garment, Riah\r\nstarted and paused.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oho!\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby. \xe2\x80\x98Didn\xe2\x80\x99t expect it! Where have you hidden her?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShowing that he was taken by surprise, the old man looked at his master\r\nwith some passing confusion, which the master highly enjoyed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is she in the house I pay rent and taxes for in Saint Mary Axe?\xe2\x80\x99\r\ndemanded Fledgeby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is she in your garden up atop of that house--gone up to be dead, or\r\nwhatever the game is?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Fledgeby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where is she then?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nRiah bent his eyes upon the ground, as if considering whether he could\r\nanswer the question without breach of faith, and then silently raised\r\nthem to Fledgeby\xe2\x80\x99s face, as if he could not.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come!\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby. \xe2\x80\x98I won\xe2\x80\x99t press that just now. But I want to know\r\nthis, and I will know this, mind you. What are you up to?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe old man, with an apologetic action of his head and hands, as not\r\ncomprehending the master\xe2\x80\x99s meaning, addressed to him a look of mute\r\ninquiry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You can\xe2\x80\x99t be a gallivanting dodger,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby. \xe2\x80\x98For you\xe2\x80\x99re a\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cregular pity the sorrows\xe2\x80\x9d, you know--if you DO know any Christian\r\nrhyme--\xe2\x80\x9cwhose trembling limbs have borne him to\xe2\x80\x9d--et cetrer. You\xe2\x80\x99re one\r\nof the Patriarchs; you\xe2\x80\x99re a shaky old card; and you can\xe2\x80\x99t be in love\r\nwith this Lizzie?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O, sir!\xe2\x80\x99 expostulated Riah. \xe2\x80\x98O, sir, sir, sir!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then why,\xe2\x80\x99 retorted Fledgeby, with some slight tinge of a blush, \xe2\x80\x98don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nyou out with your reason for having your spoon in the soup at all?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir, I will tell you the truth. But (your pardon for the stipulation)\r\nit is in sacred confidence; it is strictly upon honour.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Honour too!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Fledgeby, with a mocking lip. \xe2\x80\x98Honour among Jews.\r\nWell. Cut away.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is upon honour, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 the other still stipulated, with respectful\r\nfirmness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, certainly. Honour bright,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby.\r\n\r\nThe old man, never bidden to sit down, stood with an earnest hand laid\r\non the back of the young man\xe2\x80\x99s easy chair. The young man sat looking at\r\nthe fire with a face of listening curiosity, ready to check him off and\r\ncatch him tripping.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Cut away,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby. \xe2\x80\x98Start with your motive.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir, I have no motive but to help the helpless.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Fledgeby could only express the feelings to which this incredible\r\nstatement gave rise in his breast, by a prodigiously long derisive\r\nsniff.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How I came to know, and much to esteem and to respect, this damsel, I\r\nmentioned when you saw her in my poor garden on the house-top,\xe2\x80\x99 said the\r\nJew.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did you?\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby, distrustfully. \xe2\x80\x98Well. Perhaps you did,\r\nthough.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The better I knew her, the more interest I felt in her fortunes. They\r\ngathered to a crisis. I found her beset by a selfish and ungrateful\r\nbrother, beset by an unacceptable wooer, beset by the snares of a more\r\npowerful lover, beset by the wiles of her own heart.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She took to one of the chaps then?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir, it was only natural that she should incline towards him, for he\r\nhad many and great advantages. But he was not of her station, and to\r\nmarry her was not in his mind. Perils were closing round her, and the\r\ncircle was fast darkening, when I--being as you have said, sir, too\r\nold and broken to be suspected of any feeling for her but a\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s--stepped in, and counselled flight. I said, \xe2\x80\x9cMy daughter, there\r\nare times of moral danger when the hardest virtuous resolution to form\r\nis flight, and when the most heroic bravery is flight.\xe2\x80\x9d She answered,\r\nshe had had this in her thoughts; but whither to fly without help she\r\nknew not, and there were none to help her. I showed her there was one to\r\nhelp her, and it was I. And she is gone.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What did you do with her?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Fledgeby, feeling his cheek.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I placed her,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old man, \xe2\x80\x98at a distance;\xe2\x80\x99 with a grave smooth\r\noutward sweep from one another of his two open hands at arm\xe2\x80\x99s length;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98at a distance--among certain of our people, where her industry would\r\nserve her, and where she could hope to exercise it, unassailed from any\r\nquarter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nFledgeby\xe2\x80\x99s eyes had come from the fire to notice the action of his hands\r\nwhen he said \xe2\x80\x98at a distance.\xe2\x80\x99 Fledgeby now tried (very unsuccessfully)\r\nto imitate that action, as he shook his head and said, \xe2\x80\x98Placed her in\r\nthat direction, did you? Oh you circular old dodger!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith one hand across his breast and the other on the easy chair, Riah,\r\nwithout justifying himself, waited for further questioning. But, that it\r\nwas hopeless to question him on that one reserved point, Fledgeby, with\r\nhis small eyes too near together, saw full well.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lizzie,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby, looking at the fire again, and then looking up.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Humph, Lizzie. You didn\xe2\x80\x99t tell me the other name in your garden atop of\r\nthe house. I\xe2\x80\x99ll be more communicative with you. The other name\xe2\x80\x99s Hexam.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nRiah bent his head in assent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Look here, you sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby. \xe2\x80\x98I have a notion I know something\r\nof the inveigling chap, the powerful one. Has he anything to do with the\r\nlaw?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nominally, I believe it his calling.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I thought so. Name anything like Lightwood?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir, not at all like.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come, old \xe2\x80\x98un,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby, meeting his eyes with a wink, \xe2\x80\x98say the\r\nname.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wrayburn.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98By Jupiter!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Fledgeby. \xe2\x80\x98That one, is it? I thought it might be\r\nthe other, but I never dreamt of that one! I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t object to your\r\nbaulking either of the pair, dodger, for they are both conceited enough;\r\nbut that one is as cool a customer as ever I met with. Got a beard\r\nbesides, and presumes upon it. Well done, old \xe2\x80\x98un! Go on and prosper!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBrightened by this unexpected commendation, Riah asked were there more\r\ninstructions for him?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby, \xe2\x80\x98you may toddle now, Judah, and grope about on the\r\norders you have got.\xe2\x80\x99 Dismissed with those pleasing words, the old man\r\ntook his broad hat and staff, and left the great presence: more as if he\r\nwere some superior creature benignantly blessing Mr Fledgeby, than the\r\npoor dependent on whom he set his foot. Left alone, Mr Fledgeby locked\r\nhis outer door, and came back to his fire.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well done you!\xe2\x80\x99 said Fascination to himself. \xe2\x80\x98Slow, you may be; sure,\r\nyou are!\xe2\x80\x99 This he twice or thrice repeated with much complacency, as he\r\nagain dispersed the legs of the Turkish trousers and bent the knees.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A tidy shot that, I flatter myself,\xe2\x80\x99 he then soliloquised. \xe2\x80\x98And a Jew\r\nbrought down with it! Now, when I heard the story told at Lammle\xe2\x80\x99s, I\r\ndidn\xe2\x80\x99t make a jump at Riah. Not a hit of it; I got at him by degrees.\xe2\x80\x99\r\nHerein he was quite accurate; it being his habit, not to jump, or\r\nleap, or make an upward spring, at anything in life, but to crawl at\r\neverything.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I got at him,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued Fledgeby, feeling for his whisker, \xe2\x80\x98by degrees.\r\nIf your Lammles or your Lightwoods had got at him anyhow, they would\r\nhave asked him the question whether he hadn\xe2\x80\x99t something to do with that\r\ngal\xe2\x80\x99s disappearance. I knew a better way of going to work. Having got\r\nbehind the hedge, and put him in the light, I took a shot at him and\r\nbrought him down plump. Oh! It don\xe2\x80\x99t count for much, being a Jew, in a\r\nmatch against ME!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAnother dry twist in place of a smile, made his face crooked here.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As to Christians,\xe2\x80\x99 proceeded Fledgeby, \xe2\x80\x98look out, fellow-Christians,\r\nparticularly you that lodge in Queer Street! I have got the run of Queer\r\nStreet now, and you shall see some games there. To work a lot of power\r\nover you and you not know it, knowing as you think yourselves, would\r\nbe almost worth laying out money upon. But when it comes to squeezing a\r\nprofit out of you into the bargain, it\xe2\x80\x99s something like!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith this apostrophe Mr Fledgeby appropriately proceeded to divest\r\nhimself of his Turkish garments, and invest himself with Christian\r\nattire. Pending which operation, and his morning ablutions, and his\r\nanointing of himself with the last infallible preparation for the\r\nproduction of luxuriant and glossy hair upon the human countenance\r\n(quacks being the only sages he believed in besides usurers), the murky\r\nfog closed about him and shut him up in its sooty embrace. If it had\r\nnever let him out any more, the world would have had no irreparable\r\nloss, but could have easily replaced him from its stock on hand.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 2\r\n\r\nA RESPECTED FRIEND IN A NEW ASPECT\r\n\r\n\r\nIn the evening of this same foggy day when the yellow window-blind of\r\nPubsey and Co. was drawn down upon the day\xe2\x80\x99s work, Riah the Jew once\r\nmore came forth into Saint Mary Axe. But this time he carried no bag,\r\nand was not bound on his master\xe2\x80\x99s affairs. He passed over London Bridge,\r\nand returned to the Middlesex shore by that of Westminster, and so, ever\r\nwading through the fog, waded to the doorstep of the dolls\xe2\x80\x99 dressmaker.\r\n\r\nMiss Wren expected him. He could see her through the window by the light\r\nof her low fire--carefully banked up with damp cinders that it might\r\nlast the longer and waste the less when she was out--sitting waiting\r\nfor him in her bonnet. His tap at the glass roused her from the musing\r\nsolitude in which she sat, and she came to the door to open it; aiding\r\nher steps with a little crutch-stick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good evening, godmother!\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Jenny Wren.\r\n\r\nThe old man laughed, and gave her his arm to lean on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Won\xe2\x80\x99t you come in and warm yourself, godmother?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Miss Jenny Wren.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not if you are ready, Cinderella, my dear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Miss Wren, delighted. \xe2\x80\x98Now you ARE a clever old boy!\r\nIf we gave prizes at this establishment (but we only keep blanks), you\r\nshould have the first silver medal, for taking me up so quick.\xe2\x80\x99 As she\r\nspake thus, Miss Wren removed the key of the house-door from the keyhole\r\nand put it in her pocket, and then bustlingly closed the door, and tried\r\nit as they both stood on the step. Satisfied that her dwelling was safe,\r\nshe drew one hand through the old man\xe2\x80\x99s arm and prepared to ply her\r\ncrutch-stick with the other. But the key was an instrument of such\r\ngigantic proportions, that before they started Riah proposed to carry\r\nit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no, no! I\xe2\x80\x99ll carry it myself,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Miss Wren. \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m awfully\r\nlopsided, you know, and stowed down in my pocket it\xe2\x80\x99ll trim the ship. To\r\nlet you into a secret, godmother, I wear my pocket on my high side, o\xe2\x80\x99\r\npurpose.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith that they began their plodding through the fog.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, it was truly sharp of you, godmother,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed Miss Wren with\r\ngreat approbation, \xe2\x80\x98to understand me. But, you see, you ARE so like the\r\nfairy godmother in the bright little books! You look so unlike the rest\r\nof people, and so much as if you had changed yourself into that shape,\r\njust this moment, with some benevolent object. Boh!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Miss Jenny,\r\nputting her face close to the old man\xe2\x80\x99s. \xe2\x80\x98I can see your features,\r\ngodmother, behind the beard.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Does the fancy go to my changing other objects too, Jenny?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! That it does! If you\xe2\x80\x99d only borrow my stick and tap this piece of\r\npavement--this dirty stone that my foot taps--it would start up a coach\r\nand six. I say! Let\xe2\x80\x99s believe so!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98With all my heart,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the good old man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you what I must ask you to do, godmother. I must ask you\r\nto be so kind as give my child a tap, and change him altogether. O my\r\nchild has been such a bad, bad child of late! It worries me nearly\r\nout of my wits. Not done a stroke of work these ten days. Has had the\r\nhorrors, too, and fancied that four copper-coloured men in red wanted to\r\nthrow him into a fiery furnace.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But that\xe2\x80\x99s dangerous, Jenny.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dangerous, godmother? My child is always dangerous, more or less. He\r\nmight\xe2\x80\x99--here the little creature glanced back over her shoulder at the\r\nsky--\xe2\x80\x98be setting the house on fire at this present moment. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know\r\nwho would have a child, for my part! It\xe2\x80\x99s no use shaking him. I have\r\nshaken him till I have made myself giddy. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you mind your\r\nCommandments and honour your parent, you naughty old boy?\xe2\x80\x9d I said to him\r\nall the time. But he only whimpered and stared at me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What shall be changed, after him?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Riah in a compassionately\r\nplayful voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Upon my word, godmother, I am afraid I must be selfish next, and get\r\nyou to set me right in the back and the legs. It\xe2\x80\x99s a little thing to you\r\nwith your power, godmother, but it\xe2\x80\x99s a great deal to poor weak aching\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere was no querulous complaining in the words, but they were not the\r\nless touching for that.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And then?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, and then--YOU know, godmother. We\xe2\x80\x99ll both jump up into the coach\r\nand six and go to Lizzie. This reminds me, godmother, to ask you a\r\nserious question. You are as wise as wise can be (having been brought\r\nup by the fairies), and you can tell me this: Is it better to have had a\r\ngood thing and lost it, or never to have had it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Explain, god-daughter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I feel so much more solitary and helpless without Lizzie now, than I\r\nused to feel before I knew her.\xe2\x80\x99 (Tears were in her eyes as she said\r\nso.)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Some beloved companionship fades out of most lives, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said the\r\nJew,--\xe2\x80\x98that of a wife, and a fair daughter, and a son of promise, has\r\nfaded out of my own life--but the happiness was.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah!\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Wren thoughtfully, by no means convinced, and chopping\r\nthe exclamation with that sharp little hatchet of hers; \xe2\x80\x98then I tell you\r\nwhat change I think you had better begin with, godmother. You had better\r\nchange Is into Was and Was into Is, and keep them so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Would that suit your case? Would you not be always in pain then?\xe2\x80\x99 asked\r\nthe old man tenderly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Right!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Miss Wren with another chop. \xe2\x80\x98You have changed me\r\nwiser, godmother.--Not,\xe2\x80\x99 she added with the quaint hitch of her chin and\r\neyes, \xe2\x80\x98that you need be a very wonderful godmother to do that deed.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThus conversing, and having crossed Westminster Bridge, they traversed\r\nthe ground that Riah had lately traversed, and new ground likewise; for,\r\nwhen they had recrossed the Thames by way of London Bridge, they struck\r\ndown by the river and held their still foggier course that way.\r\n\r\nBut previously, as they were going along, Jenny twisted her venerable\r\nfriend aside to a brilliantly-lighted toy-shop window, and said: \xe2\x80\x98Now\r\nlook at \xe2\x80\x98em! All my work!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis referred to a dazzling semicircle of dolls in all the colours of\r\nthe rainbow, who were dressed for presentation at court, for going to\r\nballs, for going out driving, for going out on horseback, for going out\r\nwalking, for going to get married, for going to help other dolls to get\r\nmarried, for all the gay events of life.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pretty, pretty, pretty!\xe2\x80\x99 said the old man with a clap of his hands.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Most elegant taste!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Glad you like \xe2\x80\x98em,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Miss Wren, loftily. \xe2\x80\x98But the fun is,\r\ngodmother, how I make the great ladies try my dresses on. Though it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nthe hardest part of my business, and would be, even if my back were not\r\nbad and my legs queer.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe looked at her as not understanding what she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bless you, godmother,\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Wren, \xe2\x80\x98I have to scud about town at\r\nall hours. If it was only sitting at my bench, cutting out and sewing,\r\nit would be comparatively easy work; but it\xe2\x80\x99s the trying-on by the great\r\nladies that takes it out of me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How, the trying-on?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Riah.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What a mooney godmother you are, after all!\xe2\x80\x99 returned Miss Wren. \xe2\x80\x98Look\r\nhere. There\xe2\x80\x99s a Drawing Room, or a grand day in the Park, or a Show, or\r\na Fete, or what you like. Very well. I squeeze among the crowd, and I\r\nlook about me. When I see a great lady very suitable for my business, I\r\nsay \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll do, my dear!\xe2\x80\x9d and I take particular notice of her, and run\r\nhome and cut her out and baste her. Then another day, I come scudding\r\nback again to try on, and then I take particular notice of her again.\r\nSometimes she plainly seems to say, \xe2\x80\x98How that little creature is\r\nstaring!\xe2\x80\x99 and sometimes likes it and sometimes don\xe2\x80\x99t, but much more\r\noften yes than no. All the time I am only saying to myself, \xe2\x80\x9cI must\r\nhollow out a bit here; I must slope away there;\xe2\x80\x9d and I am making a\r\nperfect slave of her, with making her try on my doll\xe2\x80\x99s dress. Evening\r\nparties are severer work for me, because there\xe2\x80\x99s only a doorway for a\r\nfull view, and what with hobbling among the wheels of the carriages\r\nand the legs of the horses, I fully expect to be run over some night.\r\nHowever, there I have \xe2\x80\x98em, just the same. When they go bobbing into the\r\nhall from the carriage, and catch a glimpse of my little physiognomy\r\npoked out from behind a policeman\xe2\x80\x99s cape in the rain, I dare say they\r\nthink I am wondering and admiring with all my eyes and heart, but they\r\nlittle think they\xe2\x80\x99re only working for my dolls! There was Lady Belinda\r\nWhitrose. I made her do double duty in one night. I said when she came\r\nout of the carriage, \xe2\x80\x9cYOU\xe2\x80\x99ll do, my dear!\xe2\x80\x9d and I ran straight home and\r\ncut her out and basted her. Back I came again, and waited behind the men\r\nthat called the carriages. Very bad night too. At last, \xe2\x80\x9cLady Belinda\r\nWhitrose\xe2\x80\x99s carriage! Lady Belinda Whitrose coming down!\xe2\x80\x9d And I made her\r\ntry on--oh! and take pains about it too--before she got seated. That\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nLady Belinda hanging up by the waist, much too near the gaslight for a\r\nwax one, with her toes turned in.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWhen they had plodded on for some time nigh the river, Riah asked\r\nthe way to a certain tavern called the Six Jolly Fellowship Porters.\r\nFollowing the directions he received, they arrived, after two or three\r\npuzzled stoppages for consideration, and some uncertain looking about\r\nthem, at the door of Miss Abbey Potterson\xe2\x80\x99s dominions. A peep through\r\nthe glass portion of the door revealed to them the glories of the bar,\r\nand Miss Abbey herself seated in state on her snug throne, reading the\r\nnewspaper. To whom, with deference, they presented themselves.\r\n\r\nTaking her eyes off her newspaper, and pausing with a suspended\r\nexpression of countenance, as if she must finish the paragraph in hand\r\nbefore undertaking any other business whatever, Miss Abbey demanded,\r\nwith some slight asperity: \xe2\x80\x98Now then, what\xe2\x80\x99s for you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Could we see Miss Potterson?\xe2\x80\x99 asked the old man, uncovering his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You not only could, but you can and you do,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the hostess.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Might we speak with you, madam?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBy this time Miss Abbey\xe2\x80\x99s eyes had possessed themselves of the small\r\nfigure of Miss Jenny Wren. For the closer observation of which, Miss\r\nAbbey laid aside her newspaper, rose, and looked over the half-door of\r\nthe bar. The crutch-stick seemed to entreat for its owner leave to come\r\nin and rest by the fire; so, Miss Abbey opened the half-door, and said,\r\nas though replying to the crutch-stick:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, come in and rest by the fire.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My name is Riah,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old man, with courteous action, \xe2\x80\x98and my\r\navocation is in London city. This, my young companion--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stop a bit,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Miss Wren. \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll give the lady my card.\xe2\x80\x99 She\r\nproduced it from her pocket with an air, after struggling with the\r\ngigantic door-key which had got upon the top of it and kept it down.\r\nMiss Abbey, with manifest tokens of astonishment, took the diminutive\r\ndocument, and found it to run concisely thus:--\r\n\r\n\r\n\t\tMISS JENNY WREN\r\n\r\n\t       DOLLS\xe2\x80\x99 DRESSMAKER.\r\n\r\n\tDolls attended at their own residences.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lud!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Miss Potterson, staring. And dropped the card.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We take the liberty of coming, my young companion and I, madam,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nRiah, \xe2\x80\x98on behalf of Lizzie Hexam.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMiss Potterson was stooping to loosen the bonnet-strings of the dolls\xe2\x80\x99\r\ndressmaker. She looked round rather angrily, and said: \xe2\x80\x98Lizzie Hexam is\r\na very proud young woman.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She would be so proud,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Riah, dexterously, \xe2\x80\x98to stand well in\r\nyour good opinion, that before she quitted London for--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98For where, in the name of the Cape of Good Hope?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Miss Potterson,\r\nas though supposing her to have emigrated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98For the country,\xe2\x80\x99 was the cautious answer,--\xe2\x80\x98she made us promise to\r\ncome and show you a paper, which she left in our hands for that special\r\npurpose. I am an unserviceable friend of hers, who began to know her\r\nafter her departure from this neighbourhood. She has been for some time\r\nliving with my young companion, and has been a helpful and a comfortable\r\nfriend to her. Much needed, madam,\xe2\x80\x99 he added, in a lower voice. \xe2\x80\x98Believe\r\nme; if you knew all, much needed.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can believe that,\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Abbey, with a softening glance at the\r\nlittle creature.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And if it\xe2\x80\x99s proud to have a heart that never hardens, and a temper\r\nthat never tires, and a touch that never hurts,\xe2\x80\x99 Miss Jenny struck in,\r\nflushed, \xe2\x80\x98she is proud. And if it\xe2\x80\x99s not, she is NOT.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHer set purpose of contradicting Miss Abbey point blank, was so far from\r\noffending that dread authority, as to elicit a gracious smile. \xe2\x80\x98You do\r\nright, child,\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Abbey, \xe2\x80\x98to speak well of those who deserve well\r\nof you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Right or wrong,\xe2\x80\x99 muttered Miss Wren, inaudibly, with a visible hitch of\r\nher chin, \xe2\x80\x98I mean to do it, and you may make up your mind to THAT, old\r\nlady.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here is the paper, madam,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Jew, delivering into Miss\r\nPotterson\xe2\x80\x99s hands the original document drawn up by Rokesmith, and\r\nsigned by Riderhood. \xe2\x80\x98Will you please to read it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But first of all,\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Abbey, \xe2\x80\x98--did you ever taste shrub,\r\nchild?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMiss Wren shook her head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Should you like to?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Should if it\xe2\x80\x99s good,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Miss Wren.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You shall try. And, if you find it good, I\xe2\x80\x99ll mix some for you with hot\r\nwater. Put your poor little feet on the fender. It\xe2\x80\x99s a cold, cold night,\r\nand the fog clings so.\xe2\x80\x99 As Miss Abbey helped her to turn her chair, her\r\nloosened bonnet dropped on the floor. \xe2\x80\x98Why, what lovely hair!\xe2\x80\x99 cried\r\nMiss Abbey. \xe2\x80\x98And enough to make wigs for all the dolls in the world.\r\nWhat a quantity!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Call THAT a quantity?\xe2\x80\x99 returned Miss Wren. \xe2\x80\x98Poof! What do you say to\r\nthe rest of it?\xe2\x80\x99 As she spoke, she untied a band, and the golden stream\r\nfell over herself and over the chair, and flowed down to the ground.\r\nMiss Abbey\xe2\x80\x99s admiration seemed to increase her perplexity. She beckoned\r\nthe Jew towards her, as she reached down the shrub-bottle from its\r\nniche, and whispered:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Child, or woman?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Child in years,\xe2\x80\x99 was the answer; \xe2\x80\x98woman in self-reliance and trial.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are talking about Me, good people,\xe2\x80\x99 thought Miss Jenny, sitting in\r\nher golden bower, warming her feet. \xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t hear what you say, but I\r\nknow your tricks and your manners!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe shrub, when tasted from a spoon, perfectly harmonizing with Miss\r\nJenny\xe2\x80\x99s palate, a judicious amount was mixed by Miss Potterson\xe2\x80\x99s skilful\r\nhands, whereof Riah too partook. After this preliminary, Miss Abbey read\r\nthe document; and, as often as she raised her eyebrows in so doing,\r\nthe watchful Miss Jenny accompanied the action with an expressive and\r\nemphatic sip of the shrub and water.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As far as this goes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Abbey Potterson, when she had read it\r\nseveral times, and thought about it, \xe2\x80\x98it proves (what didn\xe2\x80\x99t much need\r\nproving) that Rogue Riderhood is a villain. I have my doubts whether he\r\nis not the villain who solely did the deed; but I have no expectation of\r\nthose doubts ever being cleared up now. I believe I did Lizzie\xe2\x80\x99s father\r\nwrong, but never Lizzie\xe2\x80\x99s self; because when things were at the worst I\r\ntrusted her, had perfect confidence in her, and tried to persuade her\r\nto come to me for a refuge. I am very sorry to have done a man wrong,\r\nparticularly when it can\xe2\x80\x99t be undone. Be kind enough to let Lizzie know\r\nwhat I say; not forgetting that if she will come to the Porters, after\r\nall, bygones being bygones, she will find a home at the Porters, and a\r\nfriend at the Porters. She knows Miss Abbey of old, remind her, and she\r\nknows what-like the home, and what-like the friend, is likely to turn\r\nout. I am generally short and sweet--or short and sour, according as it\r\nmay be and as opinions vary--\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Miss Abbey, \xe2\x80\x98and that\xe2\x80\x99s about\r\nall I have got to say, and enough too.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBut before the shrub and water was sipped out, Miss Abbey bethought\r\nherself that she would like to keep a copy of the paper by her. \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nnot long, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said she to Riah, \xe2\x80\x98and perhaps you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t mind just\r\njotting it down.\xe2\x80\x99 The old man willingly put on his spectacles, and,\r\nstanding at the little desk in the corner where Miss Abbey filed her\r\nreceipts and kept her sample phials (customers\xe2\x80\x99 scores were interdicted\r\nby the strict administration of the Porters), wrote out the copy in\r\na fair round character. As he stood there, doing his methodical\r\npenmanship, his ancient scribelike figure intent upon the work, and the\r\nlittle dolls\xe2\x80\x99 dressmaker sitting in her golden bower before the fire,\r\nMiss Abbey had her doubts whether she had not dreamed those two rare\r\nfigures into the bar of the Six Jolly Fellowships, and might not wake\r\nwith a nod next moment and find them gone.\r\n\r\nMiss Abbey had twice made the experiment of shutting her eyes and\r\nopening them again, still finding the figures there, when, dreamlike,\r\na confused hubbub arose in the public room. As she started up, and they\r\nall three looked at one another, it became a noise of clamouring voices\r\nand of the stir of feet; then all the windows were heard to be hastily\r\nthrown up, and shouts and cries came floating into the house from\r\nthe river. A moment more, and Bob Gliddery came clattering along the\r\npassage, with the noise of all the nails in his boots condensed into\r\nevery separate nail.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What is it?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Miss Abbey.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s summut run down in the fog, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Bob. \xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s ever so\r\nmany people in the river.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Tell \xe2\x80\x98em to put on all the kettles!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Miss Abbey. \xe2\x80\x98See that the\r\nboiler\xe2\x80\x99s full. Get a bath out. Hang some blankets to the fire. Heat some\r\nstone bottles. Have your senses about you, you girls down stairs, and\r\nuse \xe2\x80\x98em.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWhile Miss Abbey partly delivered these directions to Bob--whom she\r\nseized by the hair, and whose head she knocked against the wall, as a\r\ngeneral injunction to vigilance and presence of mind--and partly hailed\r\nthe kitchen with them--the company in the public room, jostling one\r\nanother, rushed out to the causeway, and the outer noise increased.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come and look,\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Abbey to her visitors. They all three hurried\r\nto the vacated public room, and passed by one of the windows into the\r\nwooden verandah overhanging the river.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Does anybody down there know what has happened?\xe2\x80\x99 demanded Miss Abbey,\r\nin her voice of authority.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s a steamer, Miss Abbey,\xe2\x80\x99 cried one blurred figure in the fog.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It always IS a steamer, Miss Abbey,\xe2\x80\x99 cried another.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Them\xe2\x80\x99s her lights, Miss Abbey, wot you see a-blinking yonder,\xe2\x80\x99 cried\r\nanother.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She\xe2\x80\x99s a-blowing off her steam, Miss Abbey, and that\xe2\x80\x99s what makes the\r\nfog and the noise worse, don\xe2\x80\x99t you see?\xe2\x80\x99 explained another.\r\n\r\nBoats were putting off, torches were lighting up, people were rushing\r\ntumultuously to the water\xe2\x80\x99s edge. Some man fell in with a splash, and\r\nwas pulled out again with a roar of laughter. The drags were called for.\r\nA cry for the life-buoy passed from mouth to mouth. It was impossible to\r\nmake out what was going on upon the river, for every boat that put off\r\nsculled into the fog and was lost to view at a boat\xe2\x80\x99s length. Nothing\r\nwas clear but that the unpopular steamer was assailed with reproaches\r\non all sides. She was the Murderer, bound for Gallows Bay; she was the\r\nManslaughterer, bound for Penal Settlement; her captain ought to be\r\ntried for his life; her crew ran down men in row-boats with a relish;\r\nshe mashed up Thames lightermen with her paddles; she fired property\r\nwith her funnels; she always was, and she always would be, wreaking\r\ndestruction upon somebody or something, after the manner of all her\r\nkind. The whole bulk of the fog teemed with such taunts, uttered in\r\ntones of universal hoarseness. All the while, the steamer\xe2\x80\x99s lights moved\r\nspectrally a very little, as she lay-to, waiting the upshot of whatever\r\naccident had happened. Now, she began burning blue-lights. These made a\r\nluminous patch about her, as if she had set the fog on fire, and in the\r\npatch--the cries changing their note, and becoming more fitful and more\r\nexcited--shadows of men and boats could be seen moving, while voices\r\nshouted: \xe2\x80\x98There!\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98There again!\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98A couple more strokes a-head!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hurrah!\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Look out!\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Hold on!\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Haul in!\xe2\x80\x99 and the like. Lastly, with\r\na few tumbling clots of blue fire, the night closed in dark again,\r\nthe wheels of the steamer were heard revolving, and her lights glided\r\nsmoothly away in the direction of the sea.\r\n\r\nIt appeared to Miss Abbey and her two companions that a considerable\r\ntime had been thus occupied. There was now as eager a set towards the\r\nshore beneath the house as there had been from it; and it was only\r\non the first boat of the rush coming in that it was known what had\r\noccurred.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If that\xe2\x80\x99s Tom Tootle,\xe2\x80\x99 Miss Abbey made proclamation, in her most\r\ncommanding tones, \xe2\x80\x98let him instantly come underneath here.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe submissive Tom complied, attended by a crowd.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What is it, Tootle?\xe2\x80\x99 demanded Miss Abbey.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s a foreign steamer, miss, run down a wherry.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How many in the wherry?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98One man, Miss Abbey.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Found?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. He\xe2\x80\x99s been under water a long time, Miss; but they\xe2\x80\x99ve grappled up\r\nthe body.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Let \xe2\x80\x98em bring it here. You, Bob Gliddery, shut the house-door and stand\r\nby it on the inside, and don\xe2\x80\x99t you open till I tell you. Any police down\r\nthere?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here, Miss Abbey,\xe2\x80\x99 was official rejoinder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98After they have brought the body in, keep the crowd out, will you? And\r\nhelp Bob Gliddery to shut \xe2\x80\x98em out.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98All right, Miss Abbey.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe autocratic landlady withdrew into the house with Riah and Miss\r\nJenny, and disposed those forces, one on either side of her, within the\r\nhalf-door of the bar, as behind a breastwork.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You two stand close here,\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Abbey, \xe2\x80\x98and you\xe2\x80\x99ll come to no\r\nhurt, and see it brought in. Bob, you stand by the door.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThat sentinel, smartly giving his rolled shirt-sleeves an extra and a\r\nfinal tuck on his shoulders, obeyed.\r\n\r\nSound of advancing voices, sound of advancing steps. Shuffle and talk\r\nwithout. Momentary pause. Two peculiarly blunt knocks or pokes at the\r\ndoor, as if the dead man arriving on his back were striking at it with\r\nthe soles of his motionless feet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s the stretcher, or the shutter, whichever of the two they are\r\ncarrying,\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Abbey, with experienced ear. \xe2\x80\x98Open, you Bob!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDoor opened. Heavy tread of laden men. A halt. A rush. Stoppage of rush.\r\nDoor shut. Baffled boots from the vexed souls of disappointed outsiders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come on, men!\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Abbey; for so potent was she with her subjects\r\nthat even then the bearers awaited her permission. \xe2\x80\x98First floor.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe entry being low, and the staircase being low, they so took up the\r\nburden they had set down, as to carry that low. The recumbent figure, in\r\npassing, lay hardly as high as the half door.\r\n\r\nMiss Abbey started back at sight of it. \xe2\x80\x98Why, good God!\xe2\x80\x99 said she,\r\nturning to her two companions, \xe2\x80\x98that\xe2\x80\x99s the very man who made the\r\ndeclaration we have just had in our hands. That\xe2\x80\x99s Riderhood!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 3\r\n\r\nTHE SAME RESPECTED FRIEND IN MORE ASPECTS THAN ONE\r\n\r\n\r\nIn sooth, it is Riderhood and no other, or it is the outer husk and\r\nshell of Riderhood and no other, that is borne into Miss Abbey\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfirst-floor bedroom. Supple to twist and turn as the Rogue has ever\r\nbeen, he is sufficiently rigid now; and not without much shuffling of\r\nattendant feet, and tilting of his bier this way and that way, and\r\nperil even of his sliding off it and being tumbled in a heap over the\r\nbalustrades, can he be got up stairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Fetch a doctor,\xe2\x80\x99 quoth Miss Abbey. And then, \xe2\x80\x98Fetch his daughter.\xe2\x80\x99 On\r\nboth of which errands, quick messengers depart.\r\n\r\nThe doctor-seeking messenger meets the doctor halfway, coming under\r\nconvoy of police. Doctor examines the dank carcase, and pronounces, not\r\nhopefully, that it is worth while trying to reanimate the same. All the\r\nbest means are at once in action, and everybody present lends a hand,\r\nand a heart and soul. No one has the least regard for the man; with them\r\nall, he has been an object of avoidance, suspicion, and aversion; but\r\nthe spark of life within him is curiously separable from himself now,\r\nand they have a deep interest in it, probably because it IS life, and\r\nthey are living and must die.\r\n\r\nIn answer to the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s inquiry how did it happen, and was anyone to\r\nblame, Tom Tootle gives in his verdict, unavoidable accident and no one\r\nto blame but the sufferer. \xe2\x80\x98He was slinking about in his boat,\xe2\x80\x99 says\r\nTom, \xe2\x80\x98which slinking were, not to speak ill of the dead, the manner of\r\nthe man, when he come right athwart the steamer\xe2\x80\x99s bows and she cut him\r\nin two.\xe2\x80\x99 Mr Tootle is so far figurative, touching the dismemberment, as\r\nthat he means the boat, and not the man. For, the man lies whole before\r\nthem.\r\n\r\nCaptain Joey, the bottle-nosed regular customer in the glazed hat, is a\r\npupil of the much-respected old school, and (having insinuated himself\r\ninto the chamber, in the execution of the important service of carrying\r\nthe drowned man\xe2\x80\x99s neck-kerchief) favours the doctor with a sagacious\r\nold-scholastic suggestion that the body should be hung up by the heels,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98sim\xe2\x80\x99lar\xe2\x80\x99, says Captain Joey, \xe2\x80\x98to mutton in a butcher\xe2\x80\x99s shop,\xe2\x80\x99 and\r\nshould then, as a particularly choice manoeuvre for promoting easy\r\nrespiration, be rolled upon casks. These scraps of the wisdom of the\r\ncaptain\xe2\x80\x99s ancestors are received with such speechless indignation by\r\nMiss Abbey, that she instantly seizes the Captain by the collar, and\r\nwithout a single word ejects him, not presuming to remonstrate, from the\r\nscene.\r\n\r\nThere then remain, to assist the doctor and Tom, only those three other\r\nregular customers, Bob Glamour, William Williams, and Jonathan (family\r\nname of the latter, if any, unknown to man-kind), who are quite enough.\r\nMiss Abbey having looked in to make sure that nothing is wanted,\r\ndescends to the bar, and there awaits the result, with the gentle Jew\r\nand Miss Jenny Wren.\r\n\r\nIf you are not gone for good, Mr Riderhood, it would be something to\r\nknow where you are hiding at present. This flabby lump of mortality that\r\nwe work so hard at with such patient perseverance, yields no sign of\r\nyou. If you are gone for good, Rogue, it is very solemn, and if you are\r\ncoming back, it is hardly less so. Nay, in the suspense and mystery of\r\nthe latter question, involving that of where you may be now, there is a\r\nsolemnity even added to that of death, making us who are in attendance\r\nalike afraid to look on you and to look off you, and making those below\r\nstart at the least sound of a creaking plank in the floor.\r\n\r\nStay! Did that eyelid tremble? So the doctor, breathing low, and closely\r\nwatching, asks himself.\r\n\r\nNo.\r\n\r\nDid that nostril twitch?\r\n\r\nNo.\r\n\r\nThis artificial respiration ceasing, do I feel any faint flutter under\r\nmy hand upon the chest?\r\n\r\nNo.\r\n\r\nOver and over again No. No. But try over and over again, nevertheless.\r\n\r\nSee! A token of life! An indubitable token of life! The spark may\r\nsmoulder and go out, or it may glow and expand, but see! The four\r\nrough fellows, seeing, shed tears. Neither Riderhood in this world, nor\r\nRiderhood in the other, could draw tears from them; but a striving human\r\nsoul between the two can do it easily.\r\n\r\nHe is struggling to come back. Now, he is almost here, now he is far\r\naway again. Now he is struggling harder to get back. And yet--like us\r\nall, when we swoon--like us all, every day of our lives when we wake--he\r\nis instinctively unwilling to be restored to the consciousness of this\r\nexistence, and would be left dormant, if he could.\r\n\r\nBob Gliddery returns with Pleasant Riderhood, who was out when sought\r\nfor, and hard to find. She has a shawl over her head, and her first\r\naction, when she takes it off weeping, and curtseys to Miss Abbey, is to\r\nwind her hair up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you, Miss Abbey, for having father here.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am bound to say, girl, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know who it was,\xe2\x80\x99 returns Miss Abbey;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98but I hope it would have been pretty much the same if I had known.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPoor Pleasant, fortified with a sip of brandy, is ushered into the\r\nfirst-floor chamber. She could not express much sentiment about her\r\nfather if she were called upon to pronounce his funeral oration, but she\r\nhas a greater tenderness for him than he ever had for her, and crying\r\nbitterly when she sees him stretched unconscious, asks the doctor, with\r\nclasped hands: \xe2\x80\x98Is there no hope, sir? O poor father!
