Is poor father\r\ndead?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nTo which the doctor, on one knee beside the body, busy and watchful,\r\nonly rejoins without looking round: \xe2\x80\x98Now, my girl, unless you have the\r\nself-command to be perfectly quiet, I cannot allow you to remain in the\r\nroom.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPleasant, consequently, wipes her eyes with her back-hair, which is in\r\nfresh need of being wound up, and having got it out of the way, watches\r\nwith terrified interest all that goes on. Her natural woman\xe2\x80\x99s aptitude\r\nsoon renders her able to give a little help. Anticipating the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwant of this or that, she quietly has it ready for him, and so by\r\ndegrees is intrusted with the charge of supporting her father\xe2\x80\x99s head\r\nupon her arm.\r\n\r\nIt is something so new to Pleasant to see her father an object of\r\nsympathy and interest, to find any one very willing to tolerate his\r\nsociety in this world, not to say pressingly and soothingly entreating\r\nhim to belong to it, that it gives her a sensation she never experienced\r\nbefore. Some hazy idea that if affairs could remain thus for a long time\r\nit would be a respectable change, floats in her mind. Also some vague\r\nidea that the old evil is drowned out of him, and that if he should\r\nhappily come back to resume his occupation of the empty form that lies\r\nupon the bed, his spirit will be altered. In which state of mind she\r\nkisses the stony lips, and quite believes that the impassive hand she\r\nchafes will revive a tender hand, if it revive ever.\r\n\r\nSweet delusion for Pleasant Riderhood. But they minister to him with\r\nsuch extraordinary interest, their anxiety is so keen, their vigilance\r\nis so great, their excited joy grows so intense as the signs of life\r\nstrengthen, that how can she resist it, poor thing! And now he begins\r\nto breathe naturally, and he stirs, and the doctor declares him to have\r\ncome back from that inexplicable journey where he stopped on the dark\r\nroad, and to be here.\r\n\r\nTom Tootle, who is nearest to the doctor when he says this, grasps\r\nthe doctor fervently by the hand. Bob Glamour, William Williams, and\r\nJonathan of the no surname, all shake hands with one another round, and\r\nwith the doctor too. Bob Glamour blows his nose, and Jonathan of the\r\nno surname is moved to do likewise, but lacking a pocket handkerchief\r\nabandons that outlet for his emotion. Pleasant sheds tears deserving her\r\nown name, and her sweet delusion is at its height.\r\n\r\nThere is intelligence in his eyes. He wants to ask a question. He\r\nwonders where he is. Tell him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Father, you were run down on the river, and are at Miss Abbey\r\nPotterson\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe stares at his daughter, stares all around him, closes his eyes, and\r\nlies slumbering on her arm.\r\n\r\nThe short-lived delusion begins to fade. The low, bad, unimpressible\r\nface is coming up from the depths of the river, or what other depths, to\r\nthe surface again. As he grows warm, the doctor and the four men cool.\r\nAs his lineaments soften with life, their faces and their hearts harden\r\nto him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He will do now,\xe2\x80\x99 says the doctor, washing his hands, and looking at the\r\npatient with growing disfavour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Many a better man,\xe2\x80\x99 moralizes Tom Tootle with a gloomy shake of the\r\nhead, \xe2\x80\x98ain\xe2\x80\x99t had his luck.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s to be hoped he\xe2\x80\x99ll make a better use of his life,\xe2\x80\x99 says Bob\r\nGlamour, \xe2\x80\x98than I expect he will.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Or than he done afore,\xe2\x80\x99 adds William Williams.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But no, not he!\xe2\x80\x99 says Jonathan of the no surname, clinching the\r\nquartette.\r\n\r\nThey speak in a low tone because of his daughter, but she sees that they\r\nhave all drawn off, and that they stand in a group at the other end of\r\nthe room, shunning him. It would be too much to suspect them of being\r\nsorry that he didn\xe2\x80\x99t die when he had done so much towards it, but they\r\nclearly wish that they had had a better subject to bestow their pains\r\non. Intelligence is conveyed to Miss Abbey in the bar, who reappears on\r\nthe scene, and contemplates from a distance, holding whispered discourse\r\nwith the doctor. The spark of life was deeply interesting while it was\r\nin abeyance, but now that it has got established in Mr Riderhood, there\r\nappears to be a general desire that circumstances had admitted of its\r\nbeing developed in anybody else, rather than that gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98However,\xe2\x80\x99 says Miss Abbey, cheering them up, \xe2\x80\x98you have done your duty\r\nlike good and true men, and you had better come down and take something\r\nat the expense of the Porters.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis they all do, leaving the daughter watching the father. To whom, in\r\ntheir absence, Bob Gliddery presents himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98His gills looks rum; don\xe2\x80\x99t they?\xe2\x80\x99 says Bob, after inspecting the\r\npatient.\r\n\r\nPleasant faintly nods.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98His gills\xe2\x80\x99ll look rummer when he wakes; won\xe2\x80\x99t they?\xe2\x80\x99 says Bob.\r\n\r\nPleasant hopes not. Why?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When he finds himself here, you know,\xe2\x80\x99 Bob explains. \xe2\x80\x98Cause Miss Abbey\r\nforbid him the house and ordered him out of it. But what you may call\r\nthe Fates ordered him into it again. Which is rumness; ain\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have come here of his own accord,\xe2\x80\x99 returns poor Pleasant,\r\nwith an effort at a little pride.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 retorts Bob. \xe2\x80\x98Nor he wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have been let in, if he had.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe short delusion is quite dispelled now. As plainly as she sees on her\r\narm the old father, unimproved, Pleasant sees that everybody there will\r\ncut him when he recovers consciousness. \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll take him away ever so soon\r\nas I can,\xe2\x80\x99 thinks Pleasant with a sigh; \xe2\x80\x98he\xe2\x80\x99s best at home.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPresently they all return, and wait for him to become conscious that\r\nthey will all be glad to get rid of him. Some clothes are got together\r\nfor him to wear, his own being saturated with water, and his present\r\ndress being composed of blankets.\r\n\r\nBecoming more and more uncomfortable, as though the prevalent dislike\r\nwere finding him out somewhere in his sleep and expressing itself to\r\nhim, the patient at last opens his eyes wide, and is assisted by his\r\ndaughter to sit up in bed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, Riderhood,\xe2\x80\x99 says the doctor, \xe2\x80\x98how do you feel?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe replies gruffly, \xe2\x80\x98Nothing to boast on.\xe2\x80\x99 Having, in fact, returned to\r\nlife in an uncommonly sulky state.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t mean to preach; but I hope,\xe2\x80\x99 says the doctor, gravely shaking\r\nhis head, \xe2\x80\x98that this escape may have a good effect upon you, Riderhood.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe patient\xe2\x80\x99s discontented growl of a reply is not intelligible; his\r\ndaughter, however, could interpret, if she would, that what he says is,\r\nhe \xe2\x80\x98don\xe2\x80\x99t want no Poll-Parroting\xe2\x80\x99.\r\n\r\nMr Riderhood next demands his shirt; and draws it on over his head (with\r\nhis daughter\xe2\x80\x99s help) exactly as if he had just had a Fight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Warn\xe2\x80\x99t it a steamer?\xe2\x80\x99 he pauses to ask her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, father.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll have the law on her, bust her! and make her pay for it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe then buttons his linen very moodily, twice or thrice stopping to\r\nexamine his arms and hands, as if to see what punishment he has received\r\nin the Fight. He then doggedly demands his other garments, and slowly\r\ngets them on, with an appearance of great malevolence towards his late\r\nopponent and all the spectators. He has an impression that his nose is\r\nbleeding, and several times draws the back of his hand across it, and\r\nlooks for the result, in a pugilistic manner, greatly strengthening that\r\nincongruous resemblance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where\xe2\x80\x99s my fur cap?\xe2\x80\x99 he asks in a surly voice, when he has shuffled his\r\nclothes on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In the river,\xe2\x80\x99 somebody rejoins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And warn\xe2\x80\x99t there no honest man to pick it up? O\xe2\x80\x99 course there was\r\nthough, and to cut off with it arterwards. You are a rare lot, all on\r\nyou!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThus, Mr Riderhood: taking from the hands of his daughter, with special\r\nill-will, a lent cap, and grumbling as he pulls it down over his ears.\r\nThen, getting on his unsteady legs, leaning heavily upon her, and\r\ngrowling, \xe2\x80\x98Hold still, can\xe2\x80\x99t you? What! You must be a staggering next,\r\nmust you?\xe2\x80\x99 he takes his departure out of the ring in which he has had\r\nthat little turn-up with Death.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 4\r\n\r\nA HAPPY RETURN OF THE DAY\r\n\r\n\r\nMr and Mrs Wilfer had seen a full quarter of a hundred more\r\nanniversaries of their wedding day than Mr and Mrs Lammle had seen of\r\ntheirs, but they still celebrated the occasion in the bosom of\r\ntheir family. Not that these celebrations ever resulted in anything\r\nparticularly agreeable, or that the family was ever disappointed by that\r\ncircumstance on account of having looked forward to the return of the\r\nauspicious day with sanguine anticipations of enjoyment. It was kept\r\nmorally, rather as a Fast than a Feast, enabling Mrs Wilfer to hold\r\na sombre darkling state, which exhibited that impressive woman in her\r\nchoicest colours.\r\n\r\nThe noble lady\xe2\x80\x99s condition on these delightful occasions was one\r\ncompounded of heroic endurance and heroic forgiveness. Lurid indications\r\nof the better marriages she might have made, shone athwart the awful\r\ngloom of her composure, and fitfully revealed the cherub as a little\r\nmonster unaccountably favoured by Heaven, who had possessed himself of a\r\nblessing for which many of his superiors had sued and contended in vain.\r\nSo firmly had this his position towards his treasure become established,\r\nthat when the anniversary arrived, it always found him in an apologetic\r\nstate. It is not impossible that his modest penitence may have even gone\r\nthe length of sometimes severely reproving him for that he ever took the\r\nliberty of making so exalted a character his wife.\r\n\r\nAs for the children of the union, their experience of these festivals\r\nhad been sufficiently uncomfortable to lead them annually to wish, when\r\nout of their tenderest years, either that Ma had married somebody else\r\ninstead of much-teased Pa, or that Pa had married somebody else instead\r\nof Ma. When there came to be but two sisters left at home, the daring\r\nmind of Bella on the next of these occasions scaled the height of\r\nwondering with droll vexation \xe2\x80\x98what on earth Pa ever could have seen in\r\nMa, to induce him to make such a little fool of himself as to ask her to\r\nhave him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe revolving year now bringing the day round in its orderly sequence,\r\nBella arrived in the Boffin chariot to assist at the celebration. It was\r\nthe family custom when the day recurred, to sacrifice a pair of fowls\r\non the altar of Hymen; and Bella had sent a note beforehand, to intimate\r\nthat she would bring the votive offering with her. So, Bella and the\r\nfowls, by the united energies of two horses, two men, four wheels, and a\r\nplum-pudding carriage dog with as uncomfortable a collar on as if he\r\nhad been George the Fourth, were deposited at the door of the parental\r\ndwelling. They were there received by Mrs Wilfer in person, whose\r\ndignity on this, as on most special occasions, was heightened by a\r\nmysterious toothache.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall not require the carriage at night,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella. \xe2\x80\x98I shall walk\r\nback.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe male domestic of Mrs Boffin touched his hat, and in the act of\r\ndeparture had an awful glare bestowed upon him by Mrs Wilfer, intended\r\nto carry deep into his audacious soul the assurance that, whatever his\r\nprivate suspicions might be, male domestics in livery were no rarity\r\nthere.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, dear Ma,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, \xe2\x80\x98and how do you do?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am as well, Bella,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mrs Wilfer, \xe2\x80\x98as can be expected.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dear me, Ma,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella; \xe2\x80\x98you talk as if one was just born!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s exactly what Ma has been doing,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Lavvy, over the\r\nmaternal shoulder, \xe2\x80\x98ever since we got up this morning. It\xe2\x80\x99s all very\r\nwell to laugh, Bella, but anything more exasperating it is impossible to\r\nconceive.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs Wilfer, with a look too full of majesty to be accompanied by any\r\nwords, attended both her daughters to the kitchen, where the sacrifice\r\nwas to be prepared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Rokesmith,\xe2\x80\x99 said she, resignedly, \xe2\x80\x98has been so polite as to place\r\nhis sitting-room at our disposal to-day. You will therefore, Bella, be\r\nentertained in the humble abode of your parents, so far in accordance\r\nwith your present style of living, that there will be a drawing-room for\r\nyour reception as well as a dining-room. Your papa invited Mr Rokesmith\r\nto partake of our lowly fare. In excusing himself on account of a\r\nparticular engagement, he offered the use of his apartment.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella happened to know that he had no engagement out of his own room at\r\nMr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s, but she approved of his staying away. \xe2\x80\x98We should only have\r\nput one another out of countenance,\xe2\x80\x99 she thought, \xe2\x80\x98and we do that quite\r\noften enough as it is.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nYet she had sufficient curiosity about his room, to run up to it with\r\nthe least possible delay, and make a close inspection of its contents.\r\nIt was tastefully though economically furnished, and very neatly\r\narranged. There were shelves and stands of books, English, French, and\r\nItalian; and in a portfolio on the writing-table there were sheets upon\r\nsheets of memoranda and calculations in figures, evidently referring to\r\nthe Boffin property. On that table also, carefully backed with canvas,\r\nvarnished, mounted, and rolled like a map, was the placard descriptive\r\nof the murdered man who had come from afar to be her husband. She shrank\r\nfrom this ghostly surprise, and felt quite frightened as she rolled and\r\ntied it up again. Peeping about here and there, she came upon a print, a\r\ngraceful head of a pretty woman, elegantly framed, hanging in the corner\r\nby the easy chair. \xe2\x80\x98Oh, indeed, sir!\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, after stopping to\r\nruminate before it. \xe2\x80\x98Oh, indeed, sir! I fancy I can guess whom you\r\nthink THAT\xe2\x80\x99S like. But I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you what it\xe2\x80\x99s much more like--your\r\nimpudence!\xe2\x80\x99 Having said which she decamped: not solely because she was\r\noffended, but because there was nothing else to look at.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, Ma,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, reappearing in the kitchen with some remains of a\r\nblush, \xe2\x80\x98you and Lavvy think magnificent me fit for nothing, but I intend\r\nto prove the contrary. I mean to be Cook today.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hold!\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined her majestic mother. \xe2\x80\x98I cannot permit it. Cook, in that\r\ndress!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As for my dress, Ma,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Bella, merrily searching in a\r\ndresser-drawer, \xe2\x80\x98I mean to apron it and towel it all over the front; and\r\nas to permission, I mean to do without.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98YOU cook?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Wilfer. \xe2\x80\x98YOU, who never cooked when you were at\r\nhome?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, Ma,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Bella; \xe2\x80\x98that is precisely the state of the case.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe girded herself with a white apron, and busily with knots and pins\r\ncontrived a bib to it, coming close and tight under her chin, as if it\r\nhad caught her round the neck to kiss her. Over this bib her dimples\r\nlooked delightful, and under it her pretty figure not less so. \xe2\x80\x98Now,\r\nMa,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, pushing back her hair from her temples with both hands,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98what\xe2\x80\x99s first?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98First,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mrs Wilfer solemnly, \xe2\x80\x98if you persist in what I cannot\r\nbut regard as conduct utterly incompatible with the equipage in which\r\nyou arrived--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n[\xe2\x80\x98Which I do, Ma.\xe2\x80\x99)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98First, then, you put the fowls down to the fire.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To--be--sure!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Bella; \xe2\x80\x98and flour them, and twirl them round, and\r\nthere they go!\xe2\x80\x99 sending them spinning at a great rate. \xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s next,\r\nMa?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Next,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Wilfer with a wave of her gloves, expressive of\r\nabdication under protest from the culinary throne, \xe2\x80\x98I would recommend\r\nexamination of the bacon in the saucepan on the fire, and also of the\r\npotatoes by the application of a fork. Preparation of the greens will\r\nfurther become necessary if you persist in this unseemly demeanour.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As of course I do, Ma.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPersisting, Bella gave her attention to one thing and forgot the\r\nother, and gave her attention to the other and forgot the third, and\r\nremembering the third was distracted by the fourth, and made amends\r\nwhenever she went wrong by giving the unfortunate fowls an extra spin,\r\nwhich made their chance of ever getting cooked exceedingly doubtful. But\r\nit was pleasant cookery too. Meantime Miss Lavinia, oscillating between\r\nthe kitchen and the opposite room, prepared the dining-table in the\r\nlatter chamber. This office she (always doing her household spiriting\r\nwith unwillingness) performed in a startling series of whisks and bumps;\r\nlaying the table-cloth as if she were raising the wind, putting down\r\nthe glasses and salt-cellars as if she were knocking at the door, and\r\nclashing the knives and forks in a skirmishing manner suggestive of\r\nhand-to-hand conflict.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Look at Ma,\xe2\x80\x99 whispered Lavinia to Bella when this was done, and they\r\nstood over the roasting fowls. \xe2\x80\x98If one was the most dutiful child in\r\nexistence (of course on the whole one hopes one is), isn\xe2\x80\x99t she enough\r\nto make one want to poke her with something wooden, sitting there bolt\r\nupright in a corner?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Only suppose,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Bella, \xe2\x80\x98that poor Pa was to sit bolt upright in\r\nanother corner.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear, he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t do it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lavvy. \xe2\x80\x98Pa would loll directly. But\r\nindeed I do not believe there ever was any human creature who could keep\r\nso bolt upright as Ma, \xe2\x80\x98or put such an amount of aggravation into one\r\nback! What\xe2\x80\x99s the matter, Ma? Ain\xe2\x80\x99t you well, Ma?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Doubtless I am very well,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mrs Wilfer, turning her eyes upon\r\nher youngest born, with scornful fortitude. \xe2\x80\x98What should be the matter\r\nwith Me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t seem very brisk, Ma,\xe2\x80\x99 retorted Lavvy the bold.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Brisk?\xe2\x80\x99 repeated her parent, \xe2\x80\x98Brisk? Whence the low expression,\r\nLavinia? If I am uncomplaining, if I am silently contented with my lot,\r\nlet that suffice for my family.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, Ma,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Lavvy, \xe2\x80\x98since you will force it out of me, I must\r\nrespectfully take leave to say that your family are no doubt under\r\nthe greatest obligations to you for having an annual toothache on your\r\nwedding day, and that it\xe2\x80\x99s very disinterested in you, and an immense\r\nblessing to them. Still, on the whole, it is possible to be too boastful\r\neven of that boon.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You incarnation of sauciness,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Wilfer, \xe2\x80\x98do you speak like that\r\nto me? On this day, of all days in the year? Pray do you know what\r\nwould have become of you, if I had not bestowed my hand upon R. W., your\r\nfather, on this day?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, Ma,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Lavvy, \xe2\x80\x98I really do not; and, with the greatest\r\nrespect for your abilities and information, I very much doubt if you do\r\neither.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWhether or no the sharp vigour of this sally on a weak point of Mrs\r\nWilfer\xe2\x80\x99s entrenchments might have routed that heroine for the time, is\r\nrendered uncertain by the arrival of a flag of truce in the person of\r\nMr George Sampson: bidden to the feast as a friend of the family, whose\r\naffections were now understood to be in course of transference from\r\nBella to Lavinia, and whom Lavinia kept--possibly in remembrance of his\r\nbad taste in having overlooked her in the first instance--under a course\r\nof stinging discipline.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I congratulate you, Mrs Wilfer,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr George Sampson, who had\r\nmeditated this neat address while coming along, \xe2\x80\x98on the day.\xe2\x80\x99 Mrs Wilfer\r\nthanked him with a magnanimous sigh, and again became an unresisting\r\nprey to that inscrutable toothache.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am surprised,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Sampson feebly, \xe2\x80\x98that Miss Bella condescends\r\nto cook.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHere Miss Lavinia descended on the ill-starred young gentleman with a\r\ncrushing supposition that at all events it was no business of his. This\r\ndisposed of Mr Sampson in a melancholy retirement of spirit, until the\r\ncherub arrived, whose amazement at the lovely woman\xe2\x80\x99s occupation was\r\ngreat.\r\n\r\nHowever, she persisted in dishing the dinner as well as cooking it, and\r\nthen sat down, bibless and apronless, to partake of it as an illustrious\r\nguest: Mrs Wilfer first responding to her husband\xe2\x80\x99s cheerful \xe2\x80\x98For what\r\nwe are about to receive--\xe2\x80\x99 with a sepulchral Amen, calculated to cast a\r\ndamp upon the stoutest appetite.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But what,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, as she watched the carving of the fowls, \xe2\x80\x98makes\r\nthem pink inside, I wonder, Pa! Is it the breed?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, I don\xe2\x80\x99t think it\xe2\x80\x99s the breed, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Pa. \xe2\x80\x98I rather\r\nthink it is because they are not done.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They ought to be,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, I am aware they ought to be, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined her father, \xe2\x80\x98but\r\nthey--ain\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSo, the gridiron was put in requisition, and the good-tempered cherub,\r\nwho was often as un-cherubically employed in his own family as if he had\r\nbeen in the employment of some of the Old Masters, undertook to grill\r\nthe fowls. Indeed, except in respect of staring about him (a branch of\r\nthe public service to which the pictorial cherub is much addicted), this\r\ndomestic cherub discharged as many odd functions as his prototype; with\r\nthe difference, say, that he performed with a blacking-brush on the\r\nfamily\xe2\x80\x99s boots, instead of performing on enormous wind instruments and\r\ndouble-basses, and that he conducted himself with cheerful alacrity to\r\nmuch useful purpose, instead of foreshortening himself in the air with\r\nthe vaguest intentions.\r\n\r\nBella helped him with his supplemental cookery, and made him very happy,\r\nbut put him in mortal terror too by asking him when they sat down at\r\ntable again, how he supposed they cooked fowls at the Greenwich dinners,\r\nand whether he believed they really were such pleasant dinners as people\r\nsaid? His secret winks and nods of remonstrance, in reply, made the\r\nmischievous Bella laugh until she choked, and then Lavinia was obliged\r\nto slap her on the back, and then she laughed the more.\r\n\r\nBut her mother was a fine corrective at the other end of the table; to\r\nwhom her father, in the innocence of his good-fellowship, at intervals\r\nappealed with: \xe2\x80\x98My dear, I am afraid you are not enjoying yourself?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why so, R. W.?\xe2\x80\x99 she would sonorously reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Because, my dear, you seem a little out of sorts.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not at all,\xe2\x80\x99 would be the rejoinder, in exactly the same tone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Would you take a merry-thought, my dear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you. I will take whatever you please, R. W.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, but my dear, do you like it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I like it as well as I like anything, R. W.\xe2\x80\x99 The stately woman would\r\nthen, with a meritorious appearance of devoting herself to the general\r\ngood, pursue her dinner as if she were feeding somebody else on high\r\npublic grounds.\r\n\r\nBella had brought dessert and two bottles of wine, thus shedding\r\nunprecedented splendour on the occasion. Mrs Wilfer did the honours of\r\nthe first glass by proclaiming: \xe2\x80\x98R. W. I drink to you.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you, my dear. And I to you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pa and Ma!\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Permit me,\xe2\x80\x99 Mrs Wilfer interposed, with outstretched glove. \xe2\x80\x98No. I\r\nthink not. I drank to your papa. If, however, you insist on including\r\nme, I can in gratitude offer no objection.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, Lor, Ma,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Lavvy the bold, \xe2\x80\x98isn\xe2\x80\x99t it the day that made\r\nyou and Pa one and the same? I have no patience!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98By whatever other circumstance the day may be marked, it is not the\r\nday, Lavinia, on which I will allow a child of mine to pounce upon me.\r\nI beg--nay, command!--that you will not pounce. R. W., it is appropriate\r\nto recall that it is for you to command and for me to obey. It is your\r\nhouse, and you are master at your own table. Both our healths!\xe2\x80\x99 Drinking\r\nthe toast with tremendous stiffness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I really am a little afraid, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 hinted the cherub meekly, \xe2\x80\x98that\r\nyou are not enjoying yourself?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98On the contrary,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mrs Wilfer, \xe2\x80\x98quite so. Why should I not?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I thought, my dear, that perhaps your face might--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My face might be a martyrdom, but what would that import, or who should\r\nknow it, if I smiled?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAnd she did smile; manifestly freezing the blood of Mr George Sampson\r\nby so doing. For that young gentleman, catching her smiling eye, was so\r\nvery much appalled by its expression as to cast about in his thoughts\r\nconcerning what he had done to bring it down upon himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The mind naturally falls,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Wilfer, \xe2\x80\x98shall I say into a\r\nreverie, or shall I say into a retrospect? on a day like this.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLavvy, sitting with defiantly folded arms, replied (but not audibly),\r\n\xe2\x80\x98For goodness\xe2\x80\x99 sake say whichever of the two you like best, Ma, and get\r\nit over.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The mind,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued Mrs Wilfer in an oratorical manner, \xe2\x80\x98naturally\r\nreverts to Papa and Mamma--I here allude to my parents--at a period\r\nbefore the earliest dawn of this day. I was considered tall; perhaps I\r\nwas. Papa and Mamma were unquestionably tall. I have rarely seen a finer\r\nwomen than my mother; never than my father.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe irrepressible Lavvy remarked aloud, \xe2\x80\x98Whatever grandpapa was, he\r\nwasn\xe2\x80\x99t a female.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your grandpapa,\xe2\x80\x99 retorted Mrs Wilfer, with an awful look, and in an\r\nawful tone, \xe2\x80\x98was what I describe him to have been, and would have struck\r\nany of his grandchildren to the earth who presumed to question it. It\r\nwas one of mamma\xe2\x80\x99s cherished hopes that I should become united to a\r\ntall member of society. It may have been a weakness, but if so, it was\r\nequally the weakness, I believe, of King Frederick of Prussia.\xe2\x80\x99 These\r\nremarks being offered to Mr George Sampson, who had not the courage to\r\ncome out for single combat, but lurked with his chest under the table\r\nand his eyes cast down, Mrs Wilfer proceeded, in a voice of increasing\r\nsternness and impressiveness, until she should force that skulker\r\nto give himself up. \xe2\x80\x98Mamma would appear to have had an indefinable\r\nforeboding of what afterwards happened, for she would frequently urge\r\nupon me, \xe2\x80\x9cNot a little man. Promise me, my child, not a little man.\r\nNever, never, never, marry a little man!\xe2\x80\x9d Papa also would remark to me\r\n(he possessed extraordinary humour), \xe2\x80\x9cthat a family of whales must not\r\nally themselves with sprats.\xe2\x80\x9d His company was eagerly sought, as may\r\nbe supposed, by the wits of the day, and our house was their continual\r\nresort. I have known as many as three copper-plate engravers exchanging\r\nthe most exquisite sallies and retorts there, at one time.\xe2\x80\x99 (Here Mr\r\nSampson delivered himself captive, and said, with an uneasy movement on\r\nhis chair, that three was a large number, and it must have been highly\r\nentertaining.) \xe2\x80\x98Among the most prominent members of that distinguished\r\ncircle, was a gentleman measuring six feet four in height. HE was NOT\r\nan engraver.\xe2\x80\x99 (Here Mr Sampson said, with no reason whatever, Of course\r\nnot.) \xe2\x80\x98This gentleman was so obliging as to honour me with attentions\r\nwhich I could not fail to understand.\xe2\x80\x99 (Here Mr Sampson murmured that\r\nwhen it came to that, you could always tell.) \xe2\x80\x98I immediately announced\r\nto both my parents that those attentions were misplaced, and that I\r\ncould not favour his suit. They inquired was he too tall? I replied it\r\nwas not the stature, but the intellect was too lofty. At our house,\r\nI said, the tone was too brilliant, the pressure was too high, to be\r\nmaintained by me, a mere woman, in every-day domestic life. I well\r\nremember mamma\xe2\x80\x99s clasping her hands, and exclaiming \xe2\x80\x9cThis will end in\r\na little man!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99 (Here Mr Sampson glanced at his host and shook his head\r\nwith despondency.) \xe2\x80\x98She afterwards went so far as to predict that it\r\nwould end in a little man whose mind would be below the average, but\r\nthat was in what I may denominate a paroxysm of maternal disappointment.\r\nWithin a month,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Wilfer, deepening her voice, as if she were\r\nrelating a terrible ghost story, \xe2\x80\x98within a-month, I first saw R. W. my\r\nhusband. Within a year, I married him. It is natural for the mind to\r\nrecall these dark coincidences on the present day.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Sampson at length released from the custody of Mrs Wilfer\xe2\x80\x99s eye, now\r\ndrew a long breath, and made the original and striking remark that there\r\nwas no accounting for these sort of presentiments. R. W. scratched his\r\nhead and looked apologetically all round the table until he came to his\r\nwife, when observing her as it were shrouded in a more sombre veil than\r\nbefore, he once more hinted, \xe2\x80\x98My dear, I am really afraid you are not\r\naltogether enjoying yourself?\xe2\x80\x99 To which she once more replied, \xe2\x80\x98On the\r\ncontrary, R. W. Quite so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe wretched Mr Sampson\xe2\x80\x99s position at this agreeable entertainment\r\nwas truly pitiable. For, not only was he exposed defenceless to the\r\nharangues of Mrs Wilfer, but he received the utmost contumely at the\r\nhands of Lavinia; who, partly to show Bella that she (Lavinia) could do\r\nwhat she liked with him, and partly to pay him off for still obviously\r\nadmiring Bella\xe2\x80\x99s beauty, led him the life of a dog. Illuminated on the\r\none hand by the stately graces of Mrs Wilfer\xe2\x80\x99s oratory, and shadowed\r\non the other by the checks and frowns of the young lady to whom he\r\nhad devoted himself in his destitution, the sufferings of this young\r\ngentleman were distressing to witness. If his mind for the moment reeled\r\nunder them, it may be urged, in extenuation of its weakness, that it\r\nwas constitutionally a knock-knee\xe2\x80\x99d mind and never very strong upon its\r\nlegs.\r\n\r\nThe rosy hours were thus beguiled until it was time for Bella to have\r\nPa\xe2\x80\x99s escort back. The dimples duly tied up in the bonnet-strings and the\r\nleave-taking done, they got out into the air, and the cherub drew a long\r\nbreath as if he found it refreshing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, dear Pa,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, \xe2\x80\x98the anniversary may be considered over.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the cherub, \xe2\x80\x98there\xe2\x80\x99s another of \xe2\x80\x98em gone.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella drew his arm closer through hers as they walked along, and gave it\r\na number of consolatory pats. \xe2\x80\x98Thank you, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, as if\r\nshe had spoken; \xe2\x80\x98I am all right, my dear. Well, and how do you get on,\r\nBella?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am not at all improved, Pa.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ain\xe2\x80\x99t you really though?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, Pa. On the contrary, I am worse.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lor!\xe2\x80\x99 said the cherub.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am worse, Pa. I make so many calculations how much a year I must have\r\nwhen I marry, and what is the least I can manage to do with, that I am\r\nbeginning to get wrinkles over my nose. Did you notice any wrinkles over\r\nmy nose this evening, Pa?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPa laughing at this, Bella gave him two or three shakes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You won\xe2\x80\x99t laugh, sir, when you see your lovely woman turning haggard.\r\nYou had better be prepared in time, I can tell you. I shall not be able\r\nto keep my greediness for money out of my eyes long, and when you see it\r\nthere you\xe2\x80\x99ll be sorry, and serve you right for not being warned in time.\r\nNow, sir, we entered into a bond of confidence. Have you anything to\r\nimpart?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I thought it was you who was to impart, my love.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh! did you indeed, sir? Then why didn\xe2\x80\x99t you ask me, the moment we came\r\nout? The confidences of lovely women are not to be slighted. However, I\r\nforgive you this once, and look here, Pa; that\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x99--Bella laid the\r\nlittle forefinger of her right glove on her lip, and then laid it on her\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s lip--\xe2\x80\x98that\xe2\x80\x99s a kiss for you. And now I am going seriously\r\nto tell you--let me see how many--four secrets. Mind! Serious, grave,\r\nweighty secrets. Strictly between ourselves.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Number one, my dear?\xe2\x80\x99 said her father, settling her arm comfortably and\r\nconfidentially.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Number one,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, \xe2\x80\x98will electrify you, Pa. Who do you think\r\nhas\xe2\x80\x99--she was confused here in spite of her merry way of beginning \xe2\x80\x98has\r\nmade an offer to me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPa looked in her face, and looked at the ground, and looked in her face\r\nagain, and declared he could never guess.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Rokesmith.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t tell me so, my dear!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mis--ter Roke--smith, Pa,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella separating the syllables for\r\nemphasis. \xe2\x80\x98What do you say to THAT?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPa answered quietly with the counter-question, \xe2\x80\x98What did YOU say to\r\nthat, my love?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I said No,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Bella sharply. \xe2\x80\x98Of course.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. Of course,\xe2\x80\x99 said her father, meditating.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And I told him why I thought it a betrayal of trust on his part, and an\r\naffront to me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. To be sure. I am astonished indeed. I wonder he committed himself\r\nwithout seeing more of his way first. Now I think of it, I suspect he\r\nalways has admired you though, my dear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A hackney coachman may admire me,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Bella, with a touch of her\r\nmother\xe2\x80\x99s loftiness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s highly probable, my love. Number two, my dear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Number two, Pa, is much to the same purpose, though not so\r\npreposterous. Mr Lightwood would propose to me, if I would let him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then I understand, my dear, that you don\xe2\x80\x99t intend to let him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella again saying, with her former emphasis, \xe2\x80\x98Why, of course not!\xe2\x80\x99 her\r\nfather felt himself bound to echo, \xe2\x80\x98Of course not.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t care for him,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s enough,\xe2\x80\x99 her father interposed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, Pa, it\xe2\x80\x99s NOT enough,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Bella, giving him another shake or\r\ntwo. \xe2\x80\x98Haven\xe2\x80\x99t I told you what a mercenary little wretch I am? It\r\nonly becomes enough when he has no money, and no clients, and no\r\nexpectations, and no anything but debts.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hah!\xe2\x80\x99 said the cherub, a little depressed. \xe2\x80\x98Number three, my dear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Number three, Pa, is a better thing. A generous thing, a noble thing, a\r\ndelightful thing. Mrs Boffin has herself told me, as a secret, with her\r\nown kind lips--and truer lips never opened or closed in this life, I am\r\nsure--that they wish to see me well married; and that when I marry with\r\ntheir consent they will portion me most handsomely.\xe2\x80\x99 Here the grateful\r\ngirl burst out crying very heartily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t cry, my darling,\xe2\x80\x99 said her father, with his hand to his eyes;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98it\xe2\x80\x99s excusable in me to be a little overcome when I find that my dear\r\nfavourite child is, after all disappointments, to be so provided for\r\nand so raised in the world; but don\xe2\x80\x99t YOU cry, don\xe2\x80\x99t YOU cry. I am very\r\nthankful. I congratulate you with all my heart, my dear.\xe2\x80\x99 The good soft\r\nlittle fellow, drying his eyes, here, Bella put her arms round his neck\r\nand tenderly kissed him on the high road, passionately telling him\r\nhe was the best of fathers and the best of friends, and that on her\r\nwedding-morning she would go down on her knees to him and beg his pardon\r\nfor having ever teased him or seemed insensible to the worth of such\r\na patient, sympathetic, genial, fresh young heart. At every one of her\r\nadjectives she redoubled her kisses, and finally kissed his hat off, and\r\nthen laughed immoderately when the wind took it and he ran after it.\r\n\r\nWhen he had recovered his hat and his breath, and they were going on\r\nagain once more, said her father then: \xe2\x80\x98Number four, my dear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella\xe2\x80\x99s countenance fell in the midst of her mirth. \xe2\x80\x98After all, perhaps\r\nI had better put off number four, Pa. Let me try once more, if for never\r\nso short a time, to hope that it may not really be so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe change in her, strengthened the cherub\xe2\x80\x99s interest in number four,\r\nand he said quietly: \xe2\x80\x98May not be so, my dear? May not be how, my dear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella looked at him pensively, and shook her head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And yet I know right well it is so, Pa. I know it only too well.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My love,\xe2\x80\x99 returned her father, \xe2\x80\x98you make me quite uncomfortable. Have\r\nyou said No to anybody else, my dear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, Pa.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes to anybody?\xe2\x80\x99 he suggested, lifting up his eyebrows.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, Pa.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is there anybody else who would take his chance between Yes and No, if\r\nyou would let him, my dear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not that I know of, Pa.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There can\xe2\x80\x99t be somebody who won\xe2\x80\x99t take his chance when you want him\r\nto?\xe2\x80\x99 said the cherub, as a last resource.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, of course not, Pa,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, giving him another shake or two.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, of course not,\xe2\x80\x99 he assented. \xe2\x80\x98Bella, my dear, I am afraid I must\r\neither have no sleep to-night, or I must press for number four.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, Pa, there is no good in number four! I am so sorry for it, I am so\r\nunwilling to believe it, I have tried so earnestly not to see it, that\r\nit is very hard to tell, even to you. But Mr Boffin is being spoilt by\r\nprosperity, and is changing every day.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear Bella, I hope and trust not.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have hoped and trusted not too, Pa; but every day he changes for\r\nthe worse, and for the worse. Not to me--he is always much the same\r\nto me--but to others about him. Before my eyes he grows suspicious,\r\ncapricious, hard, tyrannical, unjust. If ever a good man were ruined by\r\ngood fortune, it is my benefactor. And yet, Pa, think how terrible the\r\nfascination of money is! I see this, and hate this, and dread this, and\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t know but that money might make a much worse change in me. And yet\r\nI have money always in my thoughts and my desires; and the whole life I\r\nplace before myself is money, money, money, and what money can make of\r\nlife!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 5\r\n\r\nTHE GOLDEN DUSTMAN FALLS INTO BAD COMPANY\r\n\r\n\r\nWere Bella Wilfer\xe2\x80\x99s bright and ready little wits at fault, or was the\r\nGolden Dustman passing through the furnace of proof and coming out\r\ndross? Ill news travels fast. We shall know full soon.\r\n\r\nOn that very night of her return from the Happy Return, something\r\nchanced which Bella closely followed with her eyes and ears. There was\r\nan apartment at the side of the Boffin mansion, known as Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nroom. Far less grand than the rest of the house, it was far more\r\ncomfortable, being pervaded by a certain air of homely snugness, which\r\nupholstering despotism had banished to that spot when it inexorably set\r\nits face against Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s appeals for mercy in behalf of any other\r\nchamber. Thus, although a room of modest situation--for its windows gave\r\non Silas Wegg\xe2\x80\x99s old corner--and of no pretensions to velvet, satin, or\r\ngilding, it had got itself established in a domestic position analogous\r\nto that of an easy dressing-gown or pair of slippers; and whenever the\r\nfamily wanted to enjoy a particularly pleasant fireside evening, they\r\nenjoyed it, as an institution that must be, in Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s room.\r\n\r\nMr and Mrs Boffin were reported sitting in this room, when Bella got\r\nback. Entering it, she found the Secretary there too; in official\r\nattendance it would appear, for he was standing with some papers in his\r\nhand by a table with shaded candles on it, at which Mr Boffin was seated\r\nthrown back in his easy chair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are busy, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, hesitating at the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not at all, my dear, not at all. You\xe2\x80\x99re one of ourselves. We never\r\nmake company of you. Come in, come in. Here\xe2\x80\x99s the old lady in her usual\r\nplace.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs Boffin adding her nod and smile of welcome to Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s words,\r\nBella took her book to a chair in the fireside corner, by Mrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwork-table. Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s station was on the opposite side.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, Rokesmith,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Golden Dustman, so sharply rapping the table\r\nto bespeak his attention as Bella turned the leaves of her book, that\r\nshe started; \xe2\x80\x98where were we?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You were saying, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the Secretary, with an air of some\r\nreluctance and a glance towards those others who were present, \xe2\x80\x98that you\r\nconsidered the time had come for fixing my salary.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t be above calling it wages, man,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, testily. \xe2\x80\x98What\r\nthe deuce! I never talked of any salary when I was in service.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My wages,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Secretary, correcting himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Rokesmith, you are not proud, I hope?\xe2\x80\x99 observed Mr Boffin, eyeing him\r\naskance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope not, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Because I never was, when I was poor,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98Poverty and\r\npride don\xe2\x80\x99t go at all well together. Mind that. How can they go well\r\ntogether? Why it stands to reason. A man, being poor, has nothing to be\r\nproud of. It\xe2\x80\x99s nonsense.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith a slight inclination of his head, and a look of some surprise,\r\nthe Secretary seemed to assent by forming the syllables of the word\r\n\xe2\x80\x98nonsense\xe2\x80\x99 on his lips.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, concerning these same wages,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98Sit down.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe Secretary sat down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why didn\xe2\x80\x99t you sit down before?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mr Boffin, distrustfully. \xe2\x80\x98I\r\nhope that wasn\xe2\x80\x99t pride? But about these wages. Now, I\xe2\x80\x99ve gone into the\r\nmatter, and I say two hundred a year. What do you think of it? Do you\r\nthink it\xe2\x80\x99s enough?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you. It is a fair proposal.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t say, you know,\xe2\x80\x99 Mr Boffin stipulated, \xe2\x80\x98but what it may be more\r\nthan enough. And I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you why, Rokesmith. A man of property, like\r\nme, is bound to consider the market-price. At first I didn\xe2\x80\x99t enter into\r\nthat as much as I might have done; but I\xe2\x80\x99ve got acquainted with other\r\nmen of property since, and I\xe2\x80\x99ve got acquainted with the duties of\r\nproperty. I mustn\xe2\x80\x99t go putting the market-price up, because money may\r\nhappen not to be an object with me. A sheep is worth so much in the\r\nmarket, and I ought to give it and no more. A secretary is worth so much\r\nin the market, and I ought to give it and no more. However, I don\xe2\x80\x99t mind\r\nstretching a point with you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Boffin, you are very good,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the Secretary, with an effort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then we put the figure,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98at two hundred a year.\r\nThen the figure\xe2\x80\x99s disposed of. Now, there must be no misunderstanding\r\nregarding what I buy for two hundred a year. If I pay for a sheep, I buy\r\nit out and out. Similarly, if I pay for a secretary, I buy HIM out and\r\nout.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In other words, you purchase my whole time?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly I do. Look here,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98it ain\xe2\x80\x99t that I want to\r\noccupy your whole time; you can take up a book for a minute or two when\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ve nothing better to do, though I think you\xe2\x80\x99ll a\xe2\x80\x99most always find\r\nsomething useful to do. But I want to keep you in attendance. It\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nconvenient to have you at all times ready on the premises. Therefore,\r\nbetwixt your breakfast and your supper,--on the premises I expect to\r\nfind you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe Secretary bowed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In bygone days, when I was in service myself,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98I\r\ncouldn\xe2\x80\x99t go cutting about at my will and pleasure, and you won\xe2\x80\x99t expect\r\nto go cutting about at your will and pleasure. You\xe2\x80\x99ve rather got into\r\na habit of that, lately; but perhaps it was for want of a right\r\nspecification betwixt us. Now, let there be a right specification\r\nbetwixt us, and let it be this. If you want leave, ask for it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAgain the Secretary bowed. His manner was uneasy and astonished, and\r\nshowed a sense of humiliation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll have a bell,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98hung from this room to yours,\r\nand when I want you, I\xe2\x80\x99ll touch it. I don\xe2\x80\x99t call to mind that I have\r\nanything more to say at the present moment.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe Secretary rose, gathered up his papers, and withdrew. Bella\xe2\x80\x99s eyes\r\nfollowed him to the door, lighted on Mr Boffin complacently thrown back\r\nin his easy chair, and drooped over her book.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have let that chap, that young man of mine,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, taking a\r\ntrot up and down the room, \xe2\x80\x98get above his work. It won\xe2\x80\x99t do. I must have\r\nhim down a peg. A man of property owes a duty to other men of property,\r\nand must look sharp after his inferiors.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella felt that Mrs Boffin was not comfortable, and that the eyes of\r\nthat good creature sought to discover from her face what attention she\r\nhad given to this discourse, and what impression it had made upon her.\r\nFor which reason Bella\xe2\x80\x99s eyes drooped more engrossedly over her book,\r\nand she turned the page with an air of profound absorption in it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Noddy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Boffin, after thoughtfully pausing in her work.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the Golden Dustman, stopping short in his trot.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Excuse my putting it to you, Noddy, but now really! Haven\xe2\x80\x99t you been\r\na little strict with Mr Rokesmith to-night? Haven\xe2\x80\x99t you been a\r\nlittle--just a little little--not quite like your old self?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, old woman, I hope so,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mr Boffin, cheerfully, if not\r\nboastfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hope so, deary?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Our old selves wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t do here, old lady. Haven\xe2\x80\x99t you found that out\r\nyet? Our old selves would be fit for nothing here but to be robbed and\r\nimposed upon. Our old selves weren\xe2\x80\x99t people of fortune; our new selves\r\nare; it\xe2\x80\x99s a great difference.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Boffin, pausing in her work again, softly to draw a long\r\nbreath and to look at the fire. \xe2\x80\x98A great difference.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And we must be up to the difference,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued her husband; \xe2\x80\x98we must be\r\nequal to the change; that\xe2\x80\x99s what we must be. We\xe2\x80\x99ve got to hold our own\r\nnow, against everybody (for everybody\xe2\x80\x99s hand is stretched out to be\r\ndipped into our pockets), and we have got to recollect that money makes\r\nmoney, as well as makes everything else.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mentioning recollecting,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Boffin, with her work abandoned,\r\nher eyes upon the fire, and her chin upon her hand, \xe2\x80\x98do you recollect,\r\nNoddy, how you said to Mr Rokesmith when he first came to see us at the\r\nBower, and you engaged him--how you said to him that if it had pleased\r\nHeaven to send John Harmon to his fortune safe, we could have been\r\ncontent with the one Mound which was our legacy, and should never have\r\nwanted the rest?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ay, I remember, old lady. But we hadn\xe2\x80\x99t tried what it was to have the\r\nrest then. Our new shoes had come home, but we hadn\xe2\x80\x99t put \xe2\x80\x98em on. We\xe2\x80\x99re\r\nwearing \xe2\x80\x98em now, we\xe2\x80\x99re wearing \xe2\x80\x98em, and must step out accordingly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs Boffin took up her work again, and plied her needle in silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As to Rokesmith, that young man of mine,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, dropping\r\nhis voice and glancing towards the door with an apprehension of being\r\noverheard by some eavesdropper there, \xe2\x80\x98it\xe2\x80\x99s the same with him as with\r\nthe footmen. I have found out that you must either scrunch them, or let\r\nthem scrunch you. If you ain\xe2\x80\x99t imperious with \xe2\x80\x98em, they won\xe2\x80\x99t believe\r\nin your being any better than themselves, if as good, after the stories\r\n(lies mostly) that they have heard of your beginnings. There\xe2\x80\x99s nothing\r\nbetwixt stiffening yourself up, and throwing yourself away; take my word\r\nfor that, old lady.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella ventured for a moment to look stealthily towards him under her\r\neyelashes, and she saw a dark cloud of suspicion, covetousness, and\r\nconceit, overshadowing the once open face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hows\xe2\x80\x99ever,\xe2\x80\x99 said he, \xe2\x80\x98this isn\xe2\x80\x99t entertaining to Miss Bella. Is it,\r\nBella?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nA deceiving Bella she was, to look at him with that pensively abstracted\r\nair, as if her mind were full of her book, and she had not heard a\r\nsingle word!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hah! Better employed than to attend to it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nright, that\xe2\x80\x99s right. Especially as you have no call to be told how to\r\nvalue yourself, my dear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nColouring a little under this compliment, Bella returned, \xe2\x80\x98I hope sir,\r\nyou don\xe2\x80\x99t think me vain?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not a bit, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98But I think it\xe2\x80\x99s very creditable\r\nin you, at your age, to be so well up with the pace of the world, and to\r\nknow what to go in for. You are right. Go in for money, my love. Money\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nthe article. You\xe2\x80\x99ll make money of your good looks, and of the money Mrs\r\nBoffin and me will have the pleasure of settling upon you, and you\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nlive and die rich. That\xe2\x80\x99s the state to live and die in!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin,\r\nin an unctuous manner. \xe2\x80\x98R--r--rich!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere was an expression of distress in Mrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s face, as, after\r\nwatching her husband\xe2\x80\x99s, she turned to their adopted girl, and said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t mind him, Bella, my dear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Eh?\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98What! Not mind him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t mean that,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Boffin, with a worried look, \xe2\x80\x98but I mean,\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t believe him to be anything but good and generous, Bella, because\r\nhe is the best of men. No, I must say that much, Noddy. You are always\r\nthe best of men.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe made the declaration as if he were objecting to it: which assuredly\r\nhe was not in any way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And as to you, my dear Bella,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Boffin, still with that\r\ndistressed expression, \xe2\x80\x98he is so much attached to you, whatever he says,\r\nthat your own father has not a truer interest in you and can hardly like\r\nyou better than he does.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Says too!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98Whatever he says! Why, I say so, openly.\r\nGive me a kiss, my dear child, in saying Good Night, and let me confirm\r\nwhat my old lady tells you. I am very fond of you, my dear, and I am\r\nentirely of your mind, and you and I will take care that you shall be\r\nrich. These good looks of yours (which you have some right to be vain\r\nof; my dear, though you are not, you know) are worth money, and you\r\nshall make money of \xe2\x80\x98em. The money you will have, will be worth money,\r\nand you shall make money of that too. There\xe2\x80\x99s a golden ball at your\r\nfeet. Good night, my dear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSomehow, Bella was not so well pleased with this assurance and this\r\nprospect as she might have been. Somehow, when she put her arms\r\nround Mrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s neck and said Good Night, she derived a sense of\r\nunworthiness from the still anxious face of that good woman and her\r\nobvious wish to excuse her husband. \xe2\x80\x98Why, what need to excuse him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\nthought Bella, sitting down in her own room. \xe2\x80\x98What he said was very\r\nsensible, I am sure, and very true, I am sure. It is only what I often\r\nsay to myself. Don\xe2\x80\x99t I like it then? No, I don\xe2\x80\x99t like it, and, though\r\nhe is my liberal benefactor, I disparage him for it. Then pray,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nBella, sternly putting the question to herself in the looking-glass as\r\nusual, \xe2\x80\x98what do you mean by this, you inconsistent little Beast?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe looking-glass preserving a discreet ministerial silence when thus\r\ncalled upon for explanation, Bella went to bed with a weariness upon her\r\nspirit which was more than the weariness of want of sleep. And again\r\nin the morning, she looked for the cloud, and for the deepening of the\r\ncloud, upon the Golden Dustman\xe2\x80\x99s face.\r\n\r\nShe had begun by this time to be his frequent companion in his morning\r\nstrolls about the streets, and it was at this time that he made her a\r\nparty to his engaging in a curious pursuit. Having been hard at work in\r\none dull enclosure all his life, he had a child\xe2\x80\x99s delight in looking\r\nat shops. It had been one of the first novelties and pleasures of his\r\nfreedom, and was equally the delight of his wife. For many years their\r\nonly walks in London had been taken on Sundays when the shops were shut;\r\nand when every day in the week became their holiday, they derived an\r\nenjoyment from the variety and fancy and beauty of the display in the\r\nwindows, which seemed incapable of exhaustion. As if the principal\r\nstreets were a great Theatre and the play were childishly new to them,\r\nMr and Mrs Boffin, from the beginning of Bella\xe2\x80\x99s intimacy in their\r\nhouse, had been constantly in the front row, charmed with all they saw\r\nand applauding vigorously. But now, Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s interest began to centre\r\nin book-shops; and more than that--for that of itself would not have\r\nbeen much--in one exceptional kind of book.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Look in here, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 Mr Boffin would say, checking Bella\xe2\x80\x99s arm at a\r\nbookseller\xe2\x80\x99s window; \xe2\x80\x98you can read at sight, and your eyes are as sharp\r\nas they\xe2\x80\x99re bright. Now, look well about you, my dear, and tell me if you\r\nsee any book about a Miser.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIf Bella saw such a book, Mr Boffin would instantly dart in and buy\r\nit. And still, as if they had not found it, they would seek out another\r\nbook-shop, and Mr Boffin would say, \xe2\x80\x98Now, look well all round, my\r\ndear, for a Life of a Miser, or any book of that sort; any Lives of odd\r\ncharacters who may have been Misers.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella, thus directed, would examine the window with the greatest\r\nattention, while Mr Boffin would examine her face. The moment she\r\npointed out any book as being entitled Lives of eccentric personages,\r\nAnecdotes of strange characters, Records of remarkable individuals, or\r\nanything to that purpose, Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s countenance would light up, and\r\nhe would instantly dart in and buy it. Size, price, quality, were of no\r\naccount. Any book that seemed to promise a chance of miserly biography,\r\nMr Boffin purchased without a moment\xe2\x80\x99s delay and carried home. Happening\r\nto be informed by a bookseller that a portion of the Annual Register was\r\ndevoted to \xe2\x80\x98Characters\xe2\x80\x99, Mr Boffin at once bought a whole set of that\r\ningenious compilation, and began to carry it home piecemeal, confiding\r\na volume to Bella, and bearing three himself. The completion of this\r\nlabour occupied them about a fortnight. When the task was done, Mr\r\nBoffin, with his appetite for Misers whetted instead of satiated, began\r\nto look out again.\r\n\r\nIt very soon became unnecessary to tell Bella what to look for, and an\r\nunderstanding was established between her and Mr Boffin that she was\r\nalways to look for Lives of Misers. Morning after morning they roamed\r\nabout the town together, pursuing this singular research. Miserly\r\nliterature not being abundant, the proportion of failures to successes\r\nmay have been as a hundred to one; still Mr Boffin, never wearied,\r\nremained as avaricious for misers as he had been at the first onset. It\r\nwas curious that Bella never saw the books about the house, nor did she\r\never hear from Mr Boffin one word of reference to their contents. He\r\nseemed to save up his Misers as they had saved up their money. As they\r\nhad been greedy for it, and secret about it, and had hidden it, so he\r\nwas greedy for them, and secret about them, and hid them. But beyond all\r\ndoubt it was to be noticed, and was by Bella very clearly noticed, that,\r\nas he pursued the acquisition of those dismal records with the ardour of\r\nDon Quixote for his books of chivalry, he began to spend his money with\r\na more sparing hand. And often when he came out of a shop with some new\r\naccount of one of those wretched lunatics, she would almost shrink from\r\nthe sly dry chuckle with which he would take her arm again and trot\r\naway. It did not appear that Mrs Boffin knew of this taste. He made\r\nno allusion to it, except in the morning walks when he and Bella were\r\nalways alone; and Bella, partly under the impression that he took her\r\ninto his confidence by implication, and partly in remembrance of Mrs\r\nBoffin\xe2\x80\x99s anxious face that night, held the same reserve.\r\n\r\nWhile these occurrences were in progress, Mrs Lammle made the discovery\r\nthat Bella had a fascinating influence over her. The Lammles, originally\r\npresented by the dear Veneerings, visited the Boffins on all grand\r\noccasions, and Mrs Lammle had not previously found this out; but now the\r\nknowledge came upon her all at once. It was a most extraordinary thing\r\n(she said to Mrs Boffin); she was foolishly susceptible of the power of\r\nbeauty, but it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t altogether that; she never had been able to resist\r\na natural grace of manner, but it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t altogether that; it was more\r\nthan that, and there was no name for the indescribable extent and degree\r\nto which she was captivated by this charming girl.\r\n\r\nThis charming girl having the words repeated to her by Mrs Boffin (who\r\nwas proud of her being admired, and would have done anything to give her\r\npleasure), naturally recognized in Mrs Lammle a woman of penetration\r\nand taste. Responding to the sentiments, by being very gracious to Mrs\r\nLammle, she gave that lady the means of so improving her opportunity,\r\nas that the captivation became reciprocal, though always wearing an\r\nappearance of greater sobriety on Bella\xe2\x80\x99s part than on the enthusiastic\r\nSophronia\xe2\x80\x99s. Howbeit, they were so much together that, for a time, the\r\nBoffin chariot held Mrs Lammle oftener than Mrs Boffin: a preference\r\nof which the latter worthy soul was not in the least jealous, placidly\r\nremarking, \xe2\x80\x98Mrs Lammle is a younger companion for her than I am, and\r\nLor! she\xe2\x80\x99s more fashionable.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBut between Bella Wilfer and Georgiana Podsnap there was this one\r\ndifference, among many others, that Bella was in no danger of being\r\ncaptivated by Alfred. She distrusted and disliked him. Indeed, her\r\nperception was so quick, and her observation so sharp, that after all\r\nshe mistrusted his wife too, though with her giddy vanity and wilfulness\r\nshe squeezed the mistrust away into a corner of her mind, and blocked it\r\nup there.\r\n\r\nMrs Lammle took the friendliest interest in Bella\xe2\x80\x99s making a good match.\r\nMrs Lammle said, in a sportive way, she really must show her beautiful\r\nBella what kind of wealthy creatures she and Alfred had on hand, who\r\nwould as one man fall at her feet enslaved. Fitting occasion made,\r\nMrs Lammle accordingly produced the most passable of those feverish,\r\nboastful, and indefinably loose gentlemen who were always lounging in\r\nand out of the City on questions of the Bourse and Greek and Spanish and\r\nIndia and Mexican and par and premium and discount and three-quarters\r\nand seven-eighths. Who in their agreeable manner did homage to Bella\r\nas if she were a compound of fine girl, thorough-bred horse, well-built\r\ndrag, and remarkable pipe. But without the least effect, though even Mr\r\nFledgeby\xe2\x80\x99s attractions were cast into the scale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I fear, Bella dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Lammle one day in the chariot, \xe2\x80\x98that you\r\nwill be very hard to please.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t expect to be pleased, dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, with a languid turn of\r\nher eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Truly, my love,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Sophronia, shaking her head, and smiling\r\nher best smile, \xe2\x80\x98it would not be very easy to find a man worthy of your\r\nattractions.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The question is not a man, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, coolly, \xe2\x80\x98but an\r\nestablishment.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My love,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mrs Lammle, \xe2\x80\x98your prudence amazes me--where DID you\r\nstudy life so well!--you are right. In such a case as yours, the object\r\nis a fitting establishment. You could not descend to an inadequate one\r\nfrom Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s house, and even if your beauty alone could not command\r\nit, it is to be assumed that Mr and Mrs Boffin will--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh! they have already,\xe2\x80\x99 Bella interposed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No! Have they really?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nA little vexed by a suspicion that she had spoken precipitately, and\r\nwithal a little defiant of her own vexation, Bella determined not to\r\nretreat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That is to say,\xe2\x80\x99 she explained, \xe2\x80\x98they have told me they mean to portion\r\nme as their adopted child, if you mean that. But don\xe2\x80\x99t mention it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mention it!\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mrs Lammle, as if she were full of awakened\r\nfeeling at the suggestion of such an impossibility. \xe2\x80\x98Men-tion it!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t mind telling you, Mrs Lammle--\xe2\x80\x99 Bella began again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My love, say Sophronia, or I must not say Bella.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith a little short, petulant \xe2\x80\x98Oh!\xe2\x80\x99 Bella complied. \xe2\x80\x98Oh!--Sophronia\r\nthen--I don\xe2\x80\x99t mind telling you, Sophronia, that I am convinced I have\r\nno heart, as people call it; and that I think that sort of thing is\r\nnonsense.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Brave girl!\xe2\x80\x99 murmured Mrs Lammle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And so,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued Bella, \xe2\x80\x98as to seeking to please myself, I don\xe2\x80\x99t;\r\nexcept in the one respect I have mentioned. I am indifferent otherwise.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But you can\xe2\x80\x99t help pleasing, Bella,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Lammle, rallying her with\r\nan arch look and her best smile, \xe2\x80\x98you can\xe2\x80\x99t help making a proud and an\r\nadmiring husband. You may not care to please yourself, and you may not\r\ncare to please him, but you are not a free agent as to pleasing: you\r\nare forced to do that, in spite of yourself, my dear; so it may be a\r\nquestion whether you may not as well please yourself too, if you can.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nNow, the very grossness of this flattery put Bella upon proving that she\r\nactually did please in spite of herself. She had a misgiving that she\r\nwas doing wrong--though she had an indistinct foreshadowing that some\r\nharm might come of it thereafter, she little thought what consequences\r\nit would really bring about--but she went on with her confidence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t talk of pleasing in spite of one\xe2\x80\x99s self, dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella. \xe2\x80\x98I\r\nhave had enough of that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ay?\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mrs Lammle. \xe2\x80\x98Am I already corroborated, Bella?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Never mind, Sophronia, we will not speak of it any more. Don\xe2\x80\x99t ask me\r\nabout it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis plainly meaning Do ask me about it, Mrs Lammle did as she was\r\nrequested.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Tell me, Bella. Come, my dear. What provoking burr has been\r\ninconveniently attracted to the charming skirts, and with difficulty\r\nshaken off?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Provoking indeed,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, \xe2\x80\x98and no burr to boast of! But don\xe2\x80\x99t ask\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Shall I guess?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You would never guess. What would you say to our Secretary?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear! The hermit Secretary, who creeps up and down the back stairs,\r\nand is never seen!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know about his creeping up and down the back stairs,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nBella, rather contemptuously, \xe2\x80\x98further than knowing that he does no such\r\nthing; and as to his never being seen, I should be content never to have\r\nseen him, though he is quite as visible as you are. But I pleased HIM\r\n(for my sins) and he had the presumption to tell me so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The man never made a declaration to you, my dear Bella!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you sure of that, Sophronia?\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella. \xe2\x80\x98I am not. In fact, I am\r\nsure of the contrary.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The man must be mad,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Lammle, with a kind of resignation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He appeared to be in his senses,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Bella, tossing her head,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98and he had plenty to say for himself. I told him my opinion of his\r\ndeclaration and his conduct, and dismissed him. Of course this has all\r\nbeen very inconvenient to me, and very disagreeable. It has remained a\r\nsecret, however. That word reminds me to observe, Sophronia, that I have\r\nglided on into telling you the secret, and that I rely upon you never to\r\nmention it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mention it!\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Mrs Lammle with her former feeling. \xe2\x80\x98Men-tion\r\nit!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis time Sophronia was so much in earnest that she found it necessary\r\nto bend forward in the carriage and give Bella a kiss. A Judas order of\r\nkiss; for she thought, while she yet pressed Bella\xe2\x80\x99s hand after giving\r\nit, \xe2\x80\x98Upon your own showing, you vain heartless girl, puffed up by the\r\ndoting folly of a dustman, I need have no relenting towards YOU. If my\r\nhusband, who sends me here, should form any schemes for making YOU a\r\nvictim, I should certainly not cross him again.\xe2\x80\x99 In those very same\r\nmoments, Bella was thinking, \xe2\x80\x98Why am I always at war with myself? Why\r\nhave I told, as if upon compulsion, what I knew all along I ought to\r\nhave withheld? Why am I making a friend of this woman beside me, in\r\nspite of the whispers against her that I hear in my heart?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs usual, there was no answer in the looking-glass when she got home and\r\nreferred these questions to it. Perhaps if she had consulted some better\r\noracle, the result might have been more satisfactory; but she did not,\r\nand all things consequent marched the march before them.\r\n\r\nOn one point connected with the watch she kept on Mr Boffin, she felt\r\nvery inquisitive, and that was the question whether the Secretary\r\nwatched him too, and followed the sure and steady change in him, as she\r\ndid? Her very limited intercourse with Mr Rokesmith rendered this hard\r\nto find out. Their communication now, at no time extended beyond the\r\npreservation of commonplace appearances before Mr and Mrs Boffin; and if\r\nBella and the Secretary were ever left alone together by any chance,\r\nhe immediately withdrew. She consulted his face when she could do so\r\ncovertly, as she worked or read, and could make nothing of it. He looked\r\nsubdued; but he had acquired a strong command of feature, and, whenever\r\nMr Boffin spoke to him in Bella\xe2\x80\x99s presence, or whatever revelation of\r\nhimself Mr Boffin made, the Secretary\xe2\x80\x99s face changed no more than a\r\nwall. A slightly knitted brow, that expressed nothing but an almost\r\nmechanical attention, and a compression of the mouth, that might have\r\nbeen a guard against a scornful smile--these she saw from morning to\r\nnight, from day to day, from week to week, monotonous, unvarying, set,\r\nas in a piece of sculpture.\r\n\r\nThe worst of the matter was, that it thus fell out insensibly--and most\r\nprovokingly, as Bella complained to herself, in her impetuous little\r\nmanner--that her observation of Mr Boffin involved a continual\r\nobservation of Mr Rokesmith. \xe2\x80\x98Won\xe2\x80\x99t THAT extract a look from him?\xe2\x80\x99--\xe2\x80\x98Can\r\nit be possible THAT makes no impression on him?\xe2\x80\x99 Such questions Bella\r\nwould propose to herself, often as many times in a day as there were\r\nhours in it. Impossible to know. Always the same fixed face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Can he be so base as to sell his very nature for two hundred a year?\xe2\x80\x99\r\nBella would think. And then, \xe2\x80\x98But why not? It\xe2\x80\x99s a mere question of price\r\nwith others besides him. I suppose I would sell mine, if I could get\r\nenough for it.\xe2\x80\x99 And so she would come round again to the war with\r\nherself.\r\n\r\nA kind of illegibility, though a different kind, stole over Mr\r\nBoffin\xe2\x80\x99s face. Its old simplicity of expression got masked by a certain\r\ncraftiness that assimilated even his good-humour to itself. His very\r\nsmile was cunning, as if he had been studying smiles among the portraits\r\nof his misers. Saving an occasional burst of impatience, or coarse\r\nassertion of his mastery, his good-humour remained to him, but it had\r\nnow a sordid alloy of distrust; and though his eyes should twinkle and\r\nall his face should laugh, he would sit holding himself in his own\r\narms, as if he had an inclination to hoard himself up, and must always\r\ngrudgingly stand on the defensive.\r\n\r\nWhat with taking heed of these two faces, and what with feeling\r\nconscious that the stealthy occupation must set some mark on her own,\r\nBella soon began to think that there was not a candid or a natural face\r\namong them all but Mrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s. None the less because it was far less\r\nradiant than of yore, faithfully reflecting in its anxiety and regret\r\nevery line of change in the Golden Dustman\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Rokesmith,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin one evening when they were all in his room\r\nagain, and he and the Secretary had been going over some accounts, \xe2\x80\x98I\r\nam spending too much money. Or leastways, you are spending too much for\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are rich, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am not,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin.\r\n\r\nThe sharpness of the retort was next to telling the Secretary that he\r\nlied. But it brought no change of expression into the set face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I tell you I am not rich,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98and I won\xe2\x80\x99t have it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are not rich, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 repeated the Secretary, in measured words.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98if I am, that\xe2\x80\x99s my business. You wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t like it,\r\nif it was your money.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Even in that impossible case, sir, I--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hold your tongue!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98You oughtn\xe2\x80\x99t to like it in any\r\ncase.
