Don\xe2\x80\x99t hold your tongue. Only, don\xe2\x80\x99t contradict. Did you\r\never come across the life of Mr Elwes?\xe2\x80\x99 referring to his favourite\r\nsubject at last.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The miser?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, people called him a miser. People are always calling other people\r\nsomething. Did you ever read about him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He never owned to being rich, and yet he might have bought me twice\r\nover. Did you ever hear of Daniel Dancer?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Another miser? Yes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He was a good \xe2\x80\x98un,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98and he had a sister worthy of him.\r\nThey never called themselves rich neither. If they HAD called themselves\r\nrich, most likely they wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have been so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They lived and died very miserably. Did they not, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know that they did,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, curtly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then they are not the Misers I mean. Those abject wretches--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t call names, Rokesmith,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98--That exemplary brother and sister--lived and died in the foulest and\r\nfilthiest degradation.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They pleased themselves,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98and I suppose they could\r\nhave done no more if they had spent their money. But however, I ain\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ngoing to fling mine away. Keep the expenses down. The fact is, you ain\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nenough here, Rokesmith. It wants constant attention in the littlest\r\nthings. Some of us will be dying in a workhouse next.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As the persons you have cited,\xe2\x80\x99 quietly remarked the Secretary,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98thought they would, if I remember, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And very creditable in \xe2\x80\x98em too,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98Very independent in\r\n\xe2\x80\x98em! But never mind them just now. Have you given notice to quit your\r\nlodgings?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Under your direction, I have, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then I tell you what,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin; \xe2\x80\x98pay the quarter\xe2\x80\x99s rent--pay the\r\nquarter\xe2\x80\x99s rent, it\xe2\x80\x99ll be the cheapest thing in the end--and come here at\r\nonce, so that you may be always on the spot, day and night, and keep the\r\nexpenses down. You\xe2\x80\x99ll charge the quarter\xe2\x80\x99s rent to me, and we must try\r\nand save it somewhere. You\xe2\x80\x99ve got some lovely furniture; haven\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The furniture in my rooms is my own.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then we shan\xe2\x80\x99t have to buy any for you. In case you was to think it,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Mr Boffin, with a look of peculiar shrewdness, \xe2\x80\x98so honourably\r\nindependent in you as to make it a relief to your mind, to make that\r\nfurniture over to me in the light of a set-off against the quarter\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nrent, why ease your mind, ease your mind. I don\xe2\x80\x99t ask it, but I won\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nstand in your way if you should consider it due to yourself. As to your\r\nroom, choose any empty room at the top of the house.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Any empty room will do for me,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Secretary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You can take your pick,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98and it\xe2\x80\x99ll be as good as eight\r\nor ten shillings a week added to your income. I won\xe2\x80\x99t deduct for it; I\r\nlook to you to make it up handsomely by keeping the expenses down. Now,\r\nif you\xe2\x80\x99ll show a light, I\xe2\x80\x99ll come to your office-room and dispose of a\r\nletter or two.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nOn that clear, generous face of Mrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s, Bella had seen such traces\r\nof a pang at the heart while this dialogue was being held, that she\r\nhad not the courage to turn her eyes to it when they were left alone.\r\nFeigning to be intent on her embroidery, she sat plying her needle until\r\nher busy hand was stopped by Mrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s hand being lightly laid upon\r\nit. Yielding to the touch, she felt her hand carried to the good soul\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlips, and felt a tear fall on it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, my loved husband!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98This is hard to see and hear.\r\nBut my dear Bella, believe me that in spite of all the change in him, he\r\nis the best of men.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe came back, at the moment when Bella had taken the hand comfortingly\r\nbetween her own.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Eh?\xe2\x80\x99 said he, mistrustfully looking in at the door. \xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s she telling\r\nyou?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She is only praising you, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Praising me? You are sure? Not blaming me for standing on my own\r\ndefence against a crew of plunderers, who could suck me dry by driblets?\r\nNot blaming me for getting a little hoard together?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe came up to them, and his wife folded her hands upon his shoulder, and\r\nshook her head as she laid it on her hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There, there, there!\xe2\x80\x99 urged Mr Boffin, not unkindly. \xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t take on,\r\nold lady.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I can\xe2\x80\x99t bear to see you so, my dear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nonsense! Recollect we are not our old selves. Recollect, we must\r\nscrunch or be scrunched. Recollect, we must hold our own. Recollect,\r\nmoney makes money. Don\xe2\x80\x99t you be uneasy, Bella, my child; don\xe2\x80\x99t you be\r\ndoubtful. The more I save, the more you shall have.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella thought it was well for his wife that she was musing with her\r\naffectionate face on his shoulder; for there was a cunning light in\r\nhis eyes as he said all this, which seemed to cast a disagreeable\r\nillumination on the change in him, and make it morally uglier.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 6\r\n\r\nTHE GOLDEN DUSTMAN FALLS INTO WORSE COMPANY\r\n\r\n\r\nIt had come to pass that Mr Silas Wegg now rarely attended the minion of\r\nfortune and the worm of the hour, at his (the worm\xe2\x80\x99s and minion\xe2\x80\x99s) own\r\nhouse, but lay under general instructions to await him within a certain\r\nmargin of hours at the Bower. Mr Wegg took this arrangement in great\r\ndudgeon, because the appointed hours were evening hours, and those he\r\nconsidered precious to the progress of the friendly move. But it was\r\nquite in character, he bitterly remarked to Mr Venus, that the upstart\r\nwho had trampled on those eminent creatures, Miss Elizabeth, Master\r\nGeorge, Aunt Jane, and Uncle Parker, should oppress his literary man.\r\n\r\nThe Roman Empire having worked out its destruction, Mr Boffin next\r\nappeared in a cab with Rollin\xe2\x80\x99s Ancient History, which valuable work\r\nbeing found to possess lethargic properties, broke down, at about the\r\nperiod when the whole of the army of Alexander the Macedonian (at that\r\ntime about forty thousand strong) burst into tears simultaneously, on\r\nhis being taken with a shivering fit after bathing. The Wars of the\r\nJews, likewise languishing under Mr Wegg\xe2\x80\x99s generalship, Mr Boffin\r\narrived in another cab with Plutarch: whose Lives he found in the sequel\r\nextremely entertaining, though he hoped Plutarch might not expect him to\r\nbelieve them all. What to believe, in the course of his reading, was Mr\r\nBoffin\xe2\x80\x99s chief literary difficulty indeed; for some time he was divided\r\nin his mind between half, all, or none; at length, when he decided, as a\r\nmoderate man, to compound with half, the question still remained, which\r\nhalf? And that stumbling-block he never got over.\r\n\r\nOne evening, when Silas Wegg had grown accustomed to the arrival of\r\nhis patron in a cab, accompanied by some profane historian charged with\r\nunutterable names of incomprehensible peoples, of impossible descent,\r\nwaging wars any number of years and syllables long, and carrying\r\nillimitable hosts and riches about, with the greatest ease, beyond the\r\nconfines of geography--one evening the usual time passed by, and no\r\npatron appeared. After half an hour\xe2\x80\x99s grace, Mr Wegg proceeded to the\r\nouter gate, and there executed a whistle, conveying to Mr Venus,\r\nif perchance within hearing, the tidings of his being at home and\r\ndisengaged. Forth from the shelter of a neighbouring wall, Mr Venus then\r\nemerged.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Brother in arms,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Wegg, in excellent spirits, \xe2\x80\x98welcome!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIn return, Mr Venus gave him a rather dry good evening.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Walk in, brother,\xe2\x80\x99 said Silas, clapping him on the shoulder, \xe2\x80\x98and take\r\nyour seat in my chimley corner; for what says the ballad?\r\n\r\n     \xe2\x80\x9cNo malice to dread, sir,\r\n     And no falsehood to fear,\r\n     But truth to delight me, Mr Venus,\r\n     And I forgot what to cheer.\r\n     Li toddle de om dee.\r\n     And something to guide,\r\n     My ain fireside, sir,\r\n     My ain fireside.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith this quotation (depending for its neatness rather on the spirit\r\nthan the words), Mr Wegg conducted his guest to his hearth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And you come, brother,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Wegg, in a hospitable glow, \xe2\x80\x98you come\r\nlike I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what--exactly like it--I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t know you from\r\nit--shedding a halo all around you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What kind of halo?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mr Venus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x99Ope sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Silas. \xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s YOUR halo.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Venus appeared doubtful on the point, and looked rather\r\ndiscontentedly at the fire.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We\xe2\x80\x99ll devote the evening, brother,\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Wegg, \xe2\x80\x98to prosecute our\r\nfriendly move. And arterwards, crushing a flowing wine-cup--which I\r\nallude to brewing rum and water--we\xe2\x80\x99ll pledge one another. For what says\r\nthe Poet?\r\n\r\n     \xe2\x80\x9cAnd you needn\xe2\x80\x99t Mr Venus be your black bottle,\r\n     For surely I\xe2\x80\x99ll be mine,\r\n     And we\xe2\x80\x99ll take a glass with a slice of lemon in it to which\r\n     you\xe2\x80\x99re partial,\r\n     For auld lang syne.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis flow of quotation and hospitality in Wegg indicated his observation\r\nof some little querulousness on the part of Venus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, as to the friendly move,\xe2\x80\x99 observed the last-named gentleman,\r\nrubbing his knees peevishly, \xe2\x80\x98one of my objections to it is, that it\r\nDON\xe2\x80\x99T move.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Rome, brother,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Wegg: \xe2\x80\x98a city which (it may not be generally\r\nknown) originated in twins and a wolf; and ended in Imperial marble:\r\nwasn\xe2\x80\x99t built in a day.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did I say it was?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Venus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, you did not, brother. Well-inquired.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I do say,\xe2\x80\x99 proceeded Venus, \xe2\x80\x98that I am taken from among my trophies\r\nof anatomy, am called upon to exchange my human warious for mere\r\ncoal-ashes warious, and nothing comes of it. I think I must give up.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, sir!\xe2\x80\x99 remonstrated Wegg, enthusiastically. \xe2\x80\x98No, Sir!\r\n\r\n     \xe2\x80\x9cCharge, Chester, charge,\r\n     On, Mr Venus, on!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNever say die, sir! A man of your mark!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s not so much saying it that I object to,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mr Venus, \xe2\x80\x98as\r\ndoing it. And having got to do it whether or no, I can\xe2\x80\x99t afford to waste\r\nmy time on groping for nothing in cinders.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But think how little time you have given to the move, sir, after all,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nurged Wegg. \xe2\x80\x98Add the evenings so occupied together, and what do they\r\ncome to? And you, sir, harmonizer with myself in opinions, views, and\r\nfeelings, you with the patience to fit together on wires the whole\r\nframework of society--I allude to the human skelinton--you to give in so\r\nsoon!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t like it,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mr Venus moodily, as he put his head between\r\nhis knees and stuck up his dusty hair. \xe2\x80\x98And there\xe2\x80\x99s no encouragement to\r\ngo on.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not them Mounds without,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Wegg, extending his right hand with\r\nan air of solemn reasoning, \xe2\x80\x98encouragement? Not them Mounds now looking\r\ndown upon us?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They\xe2\x80\x99re too big,\xe2\x80\x99 grumbled Venus. \xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s a scratch here and a scrape\r\nthere, a poke in this place and a dig in the other, to them. Besides;\r\nwhat have we found?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What HAVE we found?\xe2\x80\x99 cried Wegg, delighted to be able to acquiesce.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! There I grant you, comrade. Nothing. Anything.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t like it,\xe2\x80\x99 pettishly returned Venus as before. \xe2\x80\x98I came into\r\nit without enough consideration. And besides again. Isn\xe2\x80\x99t your own Mr\r\nBoffin well acquainted with the Mounds? And wasn\xe2\x80\x99t he well acquainted\r\nwith the deceased and his ways? And has he ever showed any expectation\r\nof finding anything?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAt that moment wheels were heard.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, I should be loth,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Wegg, with an air of patient injury,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98to think so ill of him as to suppose him capable of coming at this time\r\nof night. And yet it sounds like him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nA ring at the yard bell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is him,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Wegg, \xe2\x80\x98and he is capable of it. I am sorry, because\r\nI could have wished to keep up a little lingering fragment of respect\r\nfor him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHere Mr Boffin was heard lustily calling at the yard gate, \xe2\x80\x98Halloa!\r\nWegg! Halloa!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Keep your seat, Mr Venus,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg. \xe2\x80\x98He may not stop.\xe2\x80\x99 And then\r\ncalled out, \xe2\x80\x98Halloa, sir! Halloa! I\xe2\x80\x99m with you directly, sir! Half a\r\nminute, Mr Boffin. Coming, sir, as fast as my leg will bring me!\xe2\x80\x99 And\r\nso with a show of much cheerful alacrity stumped out to the gate with\r\na light, and there, through the window of a cab, descried Mr Boffin\r\ninside, blocked up with books.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here! lend a hand, Wegg,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin excitedly, \xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t get out\r\ntill the way is cleared for me. This is the Annual Register, Wegg, in a\r\ncab-full of wollumes. Do you know him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Know the Animal Register, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 returned the Impostor, who had caught\r\nthe name imperfectly. \xe2\x80\x98For a trifling wager, I think I could find any\r\nAnimal in him, blindfold, Mr Boffin.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And here\xe2\x80\x99s Kirby\xe2\x80\x99s Wonderful Museum,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98and Caulfield\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nCharacters, and Wilson\xe2\x80\x99s. Such Characters, Wegg, such Characters! I must\r\nhave one or two of the best of \xe2\x80\x98em to-night. It\xe2\x80\x99s amazing what places\r\nthey used to put the guineas in, wrapped up in rags. Catch hold of that\r\npile of wollumes, Wegg, or it\xe2\x80\x99ll bulge out and burst into the mud. Is\r\nthere anyone about, to help?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s a friend of mine, sir, that had the intention of spending\r\nthe evening with me when I gave you up--much against my will--for the\r\nnight.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Call him out,\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mr Boffin in a bustle; \xe2\x80\x98get him to bear a hand.\r\nDon\xe2\x80\x99t drop that one under your arm. It\xe2\x80\x99s Dancer. Him and his sister made\r\npies of a dead sheep they found when they were out a walking. Where\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nyour friend? Oh, here\xe2\x80\x99s your friend. Would you be so good as help Wegg\r\nand myself with these books? But don\xe2\x80\x99t take Jemmy Taylor of Southwark,\r\nnor yet Jemmy Wood of Gloucester. These are the two Jemmys. I\xe2\x80\x99ll carry\r\nthem myself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nNot ceasing to talk and bustle, in a state of great excitement, Mr\r\nBoffin directed the removal and arrangement of the books, appearing\r\nto be in some sort beside himself until they were all deposited on the\r\nfloor, and the cab was dismissed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, gloating over them. \xe2\x80\x98There they are, like the\r\nfour-and-twenty fiddlers--all of a row. Get on your spectacles, Wegg;\r\nI know where to find the best of \xe2\x80\x98em, and we\xe2\x80\x99ll have a taste at once of\r\nwhat we have got before us. What\xe2\x80\x99s your friend\xe2\x80\x99s name?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Wegg presented his friend as Mr Venus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Eh?\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mr Boffin, catching at the name. \xe2\x80\x98Of Clerkenwell?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of Clerkenwell, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Venus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, I\xe2\x80\x99ve heard of you,\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98I heard of you in the\r\nold man\xe2\x80\x99s time. You knew him. Did you ever buy anything of him?\xe2\x80\x99 With\r\npiercing eagerness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Venus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But he showed you things; didn\xe2\x80\x99t he?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Venus, with a glance at his friend, replied in the affirmative.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What did he show you?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mr Boffin, putting his hands behind him,\r\nand eagerly advancing his head. \xe2\x80\x98Did he show you boxes, little cabinets,\r\npocket-books, parcels, anything locked or sealed, anything tied up?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Venus shook his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you a judge of china?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Venus again shook his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Because if he had ever showed you a teapot, I should be glad to know of\r\nit,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin. And then, with his right hand at his lips, repeated\r\nthoughtfully, \xe2\x80\x98a Teapot, a Teapot\xe2\x80\x99, and glanced over the books on the\r\nfloor, as if he knew there was something interesting connected with a\r\nteapot, somewhere among them.\r\n\r\nMr Wegg and Mr Venus looked at one another wonderingly: and Mr Wegg, in\r\nfitting on his spectacles, opened his eyes wide, over their rims, and\r\ntapped the side of his nose: as an admonition to Venus to keep himself\r\ngenerally wide awake.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A Teapot,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Mr Boffin, continuing to muse and survey the books;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98a Teapot, a Teapot. Are you ready, Wegg?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am at your service, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied that gentleman, taking his usual\r\nseat on the usual settle, and poking his wooden leg under the table\r\nbefore it. \xe2\x80\x98Mr Venus, would you make yourself useful, and take a seat\r\nbeside me, sir, for the conveniency of snuffing the candles?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nVenus complying with the invitation while it was yet being given, Silas\r\npegged at him with his wooden leg, to call his particular attention to\r\nMr Boffin standing musing before the fire, in the space between the two\r\nsettles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hem! Ahem!\xe2\x80\x99 coughed Mr Wegg to attract his employer\xe2\x80\x99s attention. \xe2\x80\x98Would\r\nyou wish to commence with an Animal, sir--from the Register?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98no, Wegg.\xe2\x80\x99 With that, producing a little book\r\nfrom his breast-pocket, he handed it with great care to the literary\r\ngentlemen, and inquired, \xe2\x80\x98What do you call that, Wegg?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Silas, adjusting his spectacles, and referring to\r\nthe title-page, \xe2\x80\x98is Merryweather\xe2\x80\x99s Lives and Anecdotes of Misers. Mr\r\nVenus, would you make yourself useful and draw the candles a little\r\nnearer, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 This to have a special opportunity of bestowing a stare\r\nupon his comrade.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Which of \xe2\x80\x98em have you got in that lot?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98Can you find\r\nout pretty easy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Silas, turning to the table of contents and slowly\r\nfluttering the leaves of the book, \xe2\x80\x98I should say they must be pretty\r\nwell all here, sir; here\xe2\x80\x99s a large assortment, sir; my eye catches John\r\nOvers, sir, John Little, sir, Dick Jarrel, John Elwes, the Reverend Mr\r\nJones of Blewbury, Vulture Hopkins, Daniel Dancer--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Give us Dancer, Wegg,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin.\r\n\r\nWith another stare at his comrade, Silas sought and found the place.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Page a hundred and nine, Mr Boffin. Chapter eight. Contents of chapter,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis birth and estate. His garments and outward appearance. Miss Dancer\r\nand her feminine graces. The Miser\xe2\x80\x99s Mansion. The finding of a treasure.\r\nThe Story of the Mutton Pies. A Miser\xe2\x80\x99s Idea of Death. Bob, the Miser\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncur. Griffiths and his Master. How to turn a penny. A substitute for a\r\nFire. The Advantages of keeping a Snuff-box. The Miser dies without a\r\nShirt. The Treasures of a Dunghill--\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Eh? What\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x99 demanded Mr Boffin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cThe Treasures,\xe2\x80\x9d sir,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Silas, reading very distinctly, \xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cof a\r\nDunghill.\xe2\x80\x9d Mr Venus, sir, would you obleege with the snuffers?\xe2\x80\x99 This, to\r\nsecure attention to his adding with his lips only, \xe2\x80\x98Mounds!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Boffin drew an arm-chair into the space where he stood, and said,\r\nseating himself and slyly rubbing his hands:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Give us Dancer.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Wegg pursued the biography of that eminent man through its various\r\nphases of avarice and dirt, through Miss Dancer\xe2\x80\x99s death on a sick\r\nregimen of cold dumpling, and through Mr Dancer\xe2\x80\x99s keeping his rags\r\ntogether with a hayband, and warming his dinner by sitting upon it, down\r\nto the consolatory incident of his dying naked in a sack. After which he\r\nread on as follows:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cThe house, or rather the heap of ruins, in which Mr Dancer lived, and\r\nwhich at his death devolved to the right of Captain Holmes, was a most\r\nmiserable, decayed building, for it had not been repaired for more than\r\nhalf a century.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n(Here Mr Wegg eyes his comrade and the room in which they sat: which had\r\nnot been repaired for a long time.)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cBut though poor in external structure, the ruinous fabric was very\r\nrich in the interior. It took many weeks to explore its whole contents;\r\nand Captain Holmes found it a very agreeable task to dive into the\r\nmiser\xe2\x80\x99s secret hoards.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n(Here Mr Wegg repeated \xe2\x80\x98secret hoards\xe2\x80\x99, and pegged his comrade again.)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cOne of Mr Dancer\xe2\x80\x99s richest escretoires was found to be a dungheap in\r\nthe cowhouse; a sum but little short of two thousand five hundred\r\npounds was contained in this rich piece of manure; and in an old jacket,\r\ncarefully tied, and strongly nailed down to the manger, in bank notes\r\nand gold were found five hundred pounds more.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n(Here Mr Wegg\xe2\x80\x99s wooden leg started forward under the table, and slowly\r\nelevated itself as he read on.)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cSeveral bowls were discovered filled with guineas and half-guineas;\r\nand at different times on searching the corners of the house they found\r\nvarious parcels of bank notes. Some were crammed into the crevices of\r\nthe wall\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99;\r\n\r\n(Here Mr Venus looked at the wall.)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cBundles were hid under the cushions and covers of the chairs\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99;\r\n\r\n(Here Mr Venus looked under himself on the settle.)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cSome were reposing snugly at the back of the drawers; and notes\r\namounting to six hundred pounds were found neatly doubled up in the\r\ninside of an old teapot. In the stable the Captain found jugs full of\r\nold dollars and shillings. The chimney was not left unsearched, and paid\r\nvery well for the trouble; for in nineteen different holes, all filled\r\nwith soot, were found various sums of money, amounting together to more\r\nthan two hundred pounds.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nOn the way to this crisis Mr Wegg\xe2\x80\x99s wooden leg had gradually elevated\r\nitself more and more, and he had nudged Mr Venus with his opposite\r\nelbow deeper and deeper, until at length the preservation of his balance\r\nbecame incompatible with the two actions, and he now dropped over\r\nsideways upon that gentleman, squeezing him against the settle\xe2\x80\x99s edge.\r\nNor did either of the two, for some few seconds, make any effort to\r\nrecover himself; both remaining in a kind of pecuniary swoon.\r\n\r\nBut the sight of Mr Boffin sitting in the arm-chair hugging himself,\r\nwith his eyes upon the fire, acted as a restorative. Counterfeiting a\r\nsneeze to cover their movements, Mr Wegg, with a spasmodic \xe2\x80\x98Tish-ho!\xe2\x80\x99\r\npulled himself and Mr Venus up in a masterly manner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Let\xe2\x80\x99s have some more,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, hungrily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98John Elwes is the next, sir. Is it your pleasure to take John Elwes?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98Let\xe2\x80\x99s hear what John did.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe did not appear to have hidden anything, so went off rather flatly.\r\nBut an exemplary lady named Wilcocks, who had stowed away gold and\r\nsilver in a pickle-pot in a clock-case, a canister-full of treasure in\r\na hole under her stairs, and a quantity of money in an old rat-trap,\r\nrevived the interest. To her succeeded another lady, claiming to be a\r\npauper, whose wealth was found wrapped up in little scraps of paper and\r\nold rag. To her, another lady, apple-woman by trade, who had saved a\r\nfortune of ten thousand pounds and hidden it \xe2\x80\x98here and there, in cracks\r\nand corners, behind bricks and under the flooring.\xe2\x80\x99 To her, a French\r\ngentleman, who had crammed up his chimney, rather to the detriment\r\nof its drawing powers, \xe2\x80\x98a leather valise, containing twenty thousand\r\nfrancs, gold coins, and a large quantity of precious stones,\xe2\x80\x99 as\r\ndiscovered by a chimneysweep after his death. By these steps Mr Wegg\r\narrived at a concluding instance of the human Magpie:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Many years ago, there lived at Cambridge a miserly old couple of the\r\nname of Jardine: they had two sons: the father was a perfect miser, and\r\nat his death one thousand guineas were discovered secreted in his bed.\r\nThe two sons grew up as parsimonious as their sire. When about twenty\r\nyears of age, they commenced business at Cambridge as drapers, and\r\nthey continued there until their death. The establishment of the Messrs\r\nJardine was the most dirty of all the shops in Cambridge. Customers\r\nseldom went in to purchase, except perhaps out of curiosity. The\r\nbrothers were most disreputable-looking beings; for, although surrounded\r\nwith gay apparel as their staple in trade, they wore the most filthy\r\nrags themselves. It is said that they had no bed, and, to save the\r\nexpense of one, always slept on a bundle of packing-cloths under the\r\ncounter. In their housekeeping they were penurious in the extreme. A\r\njoint of meat did not grace their board for twenty years. Yet when the\r\nfirst of the brothers died, the other, much to his surprise, found large\r\nsums of money which had been secreted even from him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98Even from him, you see! There was only two of\r\n\xe2\x80\x98em, and yet one of \xe2\x80\x98em hid from the other.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Venus, who since his introduction to the French gentleman, had been\r\nstooping to peer up the chimney, had his attention recalled by the last\r\nsentence, and took the liberty of repeating it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you like it?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mr Boffin, turning suddenly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I beg your pardon, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you like what Wegg\xe2\x80\x99s been a-reading?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Venus answered that he found it extremely interesting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then come again,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98and hear some more. Come when you\r\nlike; come the day after to-morrow, half an hour sooner. There\xe2\x80\x99s plenty\r\nmore; there\xe2\x80\x99s no end to it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Venus expressed his acknowledgments and accepted the invitation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s wonderful what\xe2\x80\x99s been hid, at one time and another,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr\r\nBoffin, ruminating; \xe2\x80\x98truly wonderful.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Meaning sir,\xe2\x80\x99 observed Wegg, with a propitiatory face to draw him out,\r\nand with another peg at his friend and brother, \xe2\x80\x98in the way of money?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Money,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98Ah! And papers.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Wegg, in a languid transport, again dropped over on Mr Venus, and\r\nagain recovering himself, masked his emotions with a sneeze.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Tish-ho! Did you say papers too, sir? Been hidden, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hidden and forgot,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98Why the bookseller that sold me\r\nthe Wonderful Museum--where\xe2\x80\x99s the Wonderful Museum?\xe2\x80\x99 He was on his knees\r\non the floor in a moment, groping eagerly among the books.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Can I assist you, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Wegg.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, I have got it; here it is,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, dusting it with the\r\nsleeve of his coat. \xe2\x80\x98Wollume four. I know it was the fourth wollume,\r\nthat the bookseller read it to me out of. Look for it, Wegg.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSilas took the book and turned the leaves.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Remarkable petrefaction, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, that\xe2\x80\x99s not it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98It can\xe2\x80\x99t have been a\r\npetrefaction.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Memoirs of General John Reid, commonly called The Walking Rushlight,\r\nsir? With portrait?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, nor yet him,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Remarkable case of a person who swallowed a crown-piece, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To hide it?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mr Boffin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, no, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Wegg, consulting the text, \xe2\x80\x98it appears to have\r\nbeen done by accident. Oh! This next must be it. \xe2\x80\x9cSingular discovery of\r\na will, lost twenty-one years.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s it!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98Read that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cA most extraordinary case,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99 read Silas Wegg aloud, \xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cwas tried at\r\nthe last Maryborough assizes in Ireland. It was briefly this. Robert\r\nBaldwin, in March 1782, made his will, in which he devised the lands now\r\nin question, to the children of his youngest son; soon after which his\r\nfaculties failed him, and he became altogether childish and died, above\r\neighty years old. The defendant, the eldest son, immediately afterwards\r\ngave out that his father had destroyed the will; and no will being\r\nfound, he entered into possession of the lands in question, and so\r\nmatters remained for twenty-one years, the whole family during all\r\nthat time believing that the father had died without a will. But after\r\ntwenty-one years the defendant\xe2\x80\x99s wife died, and he very soon afterwards,\r\nat the age of seventy-eight, married a very young woman: which caused\r\nsome anxiety to his two sons, whose poignant expressions of this feeling\r\nso exasperated their father, that he in his resentment executed a will\r\nto disinherit his eldest son, and in his fit of anger showed it to his\r\nsecond son, who instantly determined to get at it, and destroy it, in\r\norder to preserve the property to his brother. With this view, he broke\r\nopen his father\xe2\x80\x99s desk, where he found--not his father\xe2\x80\x99s will which he\r\nsought after, but the will of his grandfather, which was then altogether\r\nforgotten in the family.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98See what men put away and forget, or mean to\r\ndestroy, and don\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x99 He then added in a slow tone, \xe2\x80\x98As--ton--ish--ing!\xe2\x80\x99\r\nAnd as he rolled his eyes all round the room, Wegg and Venus likewise\r\nrolled their eyes all round the room. And then Wegg, singly, fixed his\r\neyes on Mr Boffin looking at the fire again; as if he had a mind to\r\nspring upon him and demand his thoughts or his life.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98However, time\xe2\x80\x99s up for to-night,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, waving his hand after\r\na silence. \xe2\x80\x98More, the day after to-morrow. Range the books upon the\r\nshelves, Wegg. I dare say Mr Venus will be so kind as help you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWhile speaking, he thrust his hand into the breast of his outer coat,\r\nand struggled with some object there that was too large to be got out\r\neasily. What was the stupefaction of the friendly movers when this\r\nobject at last emerging, proved to be a much-dilapidated dark lantern!\r\n\r\nWithout at all noticing the effect produced by this little instrument,\r\nMr Boffin stood it on his knee, and, producing a box of matches,\r\ndeliberately lighted the candle in the lantern, blew out the kindled\r\nmatch, and cast the end into the fire. \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m going, Wegg,\xe2\x80\x99 he then\r\nannounced, \xe2\x80\x98to take a turn about the place and round the yard. I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nwant you. Me and this same lantern have taken hundreds--thousands--of\r\nsuch turns in our time together.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t think, sir--not on any account, I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99--Wegg was\r\npolitely beginning, when Mr Boffin, who had risen and was going towards\r\nthe door, stopped:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have told you that I don\xe2\x80\x99t want you, Wegg.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWegg looked intelligently thoughtful, as if that had not occurred to his\r\nmind until he now brought it to bear on the circumstance. He had nothing\r\nfor it but to let Mr Boffin go out and shut the door behind him. But,\r\nthe instant he was on the other side of it, Wegg clutched Venus\r\nwith both hands, and said in a choking whisper, as if he were being\r\nstrangled:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Venus, he must be followed, he must be watched, he mustn\xe2\x80\x99t be lost\r\nsight of for a moment.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why mustn\xe2\x80\x99t he?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Venus, also strangling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Comrade, you might have noticed I was a little elewated in spirits when\r\nyou come in to-night. I\xe2\x80\x99ve found something.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What have you found?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Venus, clutching him with both hands, so\r\nthat they stood interlocked like a couple of preposterous gladiators.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s no time to tell you now. I think he must have gone to look for\r\nit. We must have an eye upon him instantly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nReleasing each other, they crept to the door, opened it softly, and\r\npeeped out. It was a cloudy night, and the black shadow of the Mounds\r\nmade the dark yard darker. \xe2\x80\x98If not a double swindler,\xe2\x80\x99 whispered Wegg,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98why a dark lantern? We could have seen what he was about, if he had\r\ncarried a light one. Softly, this way.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nCautiously along the path that was bordered by fragments of crockery set\r\nin ashes, the two stole after him. They could hear him at his peculiar\r\ntrot, crushing the loose cinders as he went. \xe2\x80\x98He knows the place by\r\nheart,\xe2\x80\x99 muttered Silas, \xe2\x80\x98and don\xe2\x80\x99t need to turn his lantern on, confound\r\nhim!\xe2\x80\x99 But he did turn it on, almost in that same instant, and flashed\r\nits light upon the first of the Mounds.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is that the spot?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Venus in a whisper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He\xe2\x80\x99s warm,\xe2\x80\x99 said Silas in the same tone. \xe2\x80\x98He\xe2\x80\x99s precious warm. He\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nclose. I think he must be going to look for it. What\xe2\x80\x99s that he\xe2\x80\x99s got in\r\nhis hand?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A shovel,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Venus. \xe2\x80\x98And he knows how to use it, remember, fifty\r\ntimes as well as either of us.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If he looks for it and misses it, partner,\xe2\x80\x99 suggested Wegg, \xe2\x80\x98what shall\r\nwe do?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98First of all, wait till he does,\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus.\r\n\r\nDiscreet advice too, for he darkened his lantern again, and the mound\r\nturned black. After a few seconds, he turned the light on once more, and\r\nwas seen standing at the foot of the second mound, slowly raising the\r\nlantern little by little until he held it up at arm\xe2\x80\x99s length, as if he\r\nwere examining the condition of the whole surface.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That can\xe2\x80\x99t be the spot too?\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg, \xe2\x80\x98he\xe2\x80\x99s getting cold.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It strikes me,\xe2\x80\x99 whispered Venus, \xe2\x80\x98that he wants to find out whether any\r\none has been groping about there.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hush!\xe2\x80\x99 returned Wegg, \xe2\x80\x98he\xe2\x80\x99s getting colder and colder.--Now he\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfreezing!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis exclamation was elicited by his having turned the lantern off\r\nagain, and on again, and being visible at the foot of the third mound.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, he\xe2\x80\x99s going up it!\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Shovel and all!\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg.\r\n\r\nAt a nimbler trot, as if the shovel over his shoulder stimulated him by\r\nreviving old associations, Mr Boffin ascended the \xe2\x80\x98serpentining walk\xe2\x80\x99,\r\nup the Mound which he had described to Silas Wegg on the occasion of\r\ntheir beginning to decline and fall. On striking into it he turned his\r\nlantern off. The two followed him, stooping low, so that their figures\r\nmight make no mark in relief against the sky when he should turn his\r\nlantern on again. Mr Venus took the lead, towing Mr Wegg, in order that\r\nhis refractory leg might be promptly extricated from any pitfalls it\r\nshould dig for itself. They could just make out that the Golden Dustman\r\nstopped to breathe. Of course they stopped too, instantly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is his own Mound,\xe2\x80\x99 whispered Wegg, as he recovered his wind, \xe2\x80\x98this\r\none.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why all three are his own,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Venus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So he thinks; but he\xe2\x80\x99s used to call this his own, because it\xe2\x80\x99s the one\r\nfirst left to him; the one that was his legacy when it was all he took\r\nunder the will.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When he shows his light,\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus, keeping watch upon his dusky\r\nfigure all the time, \xe2\x80\x98drop lower and keep closer.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe went on again, and they followed again. Gaining the top of the Mound,\r\nhe turned on his light--but only partially--and stood it on the ground.\r\nA bare lopsided weatherbeaten pole was planted in the ashes there,\r\nand had been there many a year. Hard by this pole, his lantern stood:\r\nlighting a few feet of the lower part of it and a little of the ashy\r\nsurface around, and then casting off a purposeless little clear trail of\r\nlight into the air.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He can never be going to dig up the pole!\xe2\x80\x99 whispered Venus as they\r\ndropped low and kept close.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Perhaps it\xe2\x80\x99s holler and full of something,\xe2\x80\x99 whispered Wegg.\r\n\r\nHe was going to dig, with whatsoever object, for he tucked up his cuffs\r\nand spat on his hands, and then went at it like an old digger as he\r\nwas. He had no design upon the pole, except that he measured a shovel\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlength from it before beginning, nor was it his purpose to dig deep.\r\nSome dozen or so of expert strokes sufficed. Then, he stopped, looked\r\ndown into the cavity, bent over it, and took out what appeared to be an\r\nordinary case-bottle: one of those squat, high-shouldered, short-necked\r\nglass bottles which the Dutchman is said to keep his Courage in. As soon\r\nas he had done this, he turned off his lantern, and they could hear that\r\nhe was filling up the hole in the dark. The ashes being easily moved by\r\na skilful hand, the spies took this as a hint to make off in good time.\r\nAccordingly, Mr Venus slipped past Mr Wegg and towed him down. But Mr\r\nWegg\xe2\x80\x99s descent was not accomplished without some personal inconvenience,\r\nfor his self-willed leg sticking into the ashes about half way down, and\r\ntime pressing, Mr Venus took the liberty of hauling him from his tether\r\nby the collar: which occasioned him to make the rest of the journey on\r\nhis back, with his head enveloped in the skirts of his coat, and his\r\nwooden leg coming last, like a drag. So flustered was Mr Wegg by this\r\nmode of travelling, that when he was set on the level ground with his\r\nintellectual developments uppermost, he was quite unconscious of his\r\nbearings, and had not the least idea where his place of residence was\r\nto be found, until Mr Venus shoved him into it. Even then he staggered\r\nround and round, weakly staring about him, until Mr Venus with a hard\r\nbrush brushed his senses into him and the dust out of him.\r\n\r\nMr Boffin came down leisurely, for this brushing process had been well\r\naccomplished, and Mr Venus had had time to take his breath, before he\r\nreappeared. That he had the bottle somewhere about him could not be\r\ndoubted; where, was not so clear. He wore a large rough coat, buttoned\r\nover, and it might be in any one of half a dozen pockets.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s the matter, Wegg?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98You are as pale as a\r\ncandle.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Wegg replied, with literal exactness, that he felt as if he had had a\r\nturn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bile,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, blowing out the light in the lantern, shutting\r\nit up, and stowing it away in the breast of his coat as before. \xe2\x80\x98Are you\r\nsubject to bile, Wegg?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Wegg again replied, with strict adherence to truth, that he didn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nthink he had ever had a similar sensation in his head, to anything like\r\nthe same extent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Physic yourself to-morrow, Wegg,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98to be in order\r\nfor next night. By-the-by, this neighbourhood is going to have a loss,\r\nWegg.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A loss, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Going to lose the Mounds.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe friendly movers made such an obvious effort not to look at one\r\nanother, that they might as well have stared at one another with all\r\ntheir might.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have you parted with them, Mr Boffin?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Silas.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes; they\xe2\x80\x99re going. Mine\xe2\x80\x99s as good as gone already.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You mean the little one of the three, with the pole atop, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, rubbing his ear in his old way, with that new\r\ntouch of craftiness added to it. \xe2\x80\x98It has fetched a penny. It\xe2\x80\x99ll begin to\r\nbe carted off to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have you been out to take leave of your old friend, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Silas,\r\njocosely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98What the devil put that in your head?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe was so sudden and rough, that Wegg, who had been hovering closer\r\nand closer to his skirts, despatching the back of his hand on exploring\r\nexpeditions in search of the bottle\xe2\x80\x99s surface, retired two or three\r\npaces.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No offence, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg, humbly. \xe2\x80\x98No offence.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Boffin eyed him as a dog might eye another dog who wanted his bone;\r\nand actually retorted with a low growl, as the dog might have retorted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good-night,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, after having sunk into a moody silence, with\r\nhis hands clasped behind him, and his eyes suspiciously wandering about\r\nWegg.--\xe2\x80\x98No! stop there. I know the way out, and I want no light.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAvarice, and the evening\xe2\x80\x99s legends of avarice, and the inflammatory\r\neffect of what he had seen, and perhaps the rush of his ill-conditioned\r\nblood to his brain in his descent, wrought Silas Wegg to such a pitch of\r\ninsatiable appetite, that when the door closed he made a swoop at it and\r\ndrew Venus along with him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He mustn\xe2\x80\x99t go,\xe2\x80\x99 he cried. \xe2\x80\x98We mustn\xe2\x80\x99t let him go? He has got that\r\nbottle about him. We must have that bottle.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t take it by force?\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus, restraining him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t I? Yes I would. I\xe2\x80\x99d take it by any force, I\xe2\x80\x99d have it at any\r\nprice! Are you so afraid of one old man as to let him go, you coward?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am so afraid of you, as not to let YOU go,\xe2\x80\x99 muttered Venus, sturdily,\r\nclasping him in his arms.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did you hear him?\xe2\x80\x99 retorted Wegg. \xe2\x80\x98Did you hear him say that he was\r\nresolved to disappoint us? Did you hear him say, you cur, that he was\r\ngoing to have the Mounds cleared off, when no doubt the whole place will\r\nbe rummaged? If you haven\xe2\x80\x99t the spirit of a mouse to defend your rights,\r\nI have. Let me go after him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs in his wildness he was making a strong struggle for it, Mr Venus\r\ndeemed it expedient to lift him, throw him, and fall with him; well\r\nknowing that, once down, he would not be up again easily with his wooden\r\nleg. So they both rolled on the floor, and, as they did so, Mr Boffin\r\nshut the gate.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 7\r\n\r\nTHE FRIENDLY MOVE TAKES UP A STRONG POSITION\r\n\r\n\r\nThe friendly movers sat upright on the floor, panting and eyeing one\r\nanother, after Mr Boffin had slammed the gate and gone away. In the weak\r\neyes of Venus, and in every reddish dust-coloured hair in his shock of\r\nhair, there was a marked distrust of Wegg and an alertness to fly at him\r\non perceiving the smallest occasion. In the hard-grained face of Wegg,\r\nand in his stiff knotty figure (he looked like a German wooden toy),\r\nthere was expressed a politic conciliation, which had no spontaneity in\r\nit. Both were flushed, flustered, and rumpled, by the late scuffle; and\r\nWegg, in coming to the ground, had received a humming knock on the back\r\nof his devoted head, which caused him still to rub it with an air of\r\nhaving been highly--but disagreeably--astonished. Each was silent for\r\nsome time, leaving it to the other to begin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Brother,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg, at length breaking the silence, \xe2\x80\x98you were right,\r\nand I was wrong. I forgot myself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Venus knowingly cocked his shock of hair, as rather thinking Mr Wegg\r\nhad remembered himself, in respect of appearing without any disguise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But comrade,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued Wegg, \xe2\x80\x98it was never your lot to know Miss\r\nElizabeth, Master George, Aunt Jane, nor Uncle Parker.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Venus admitted that he had never known those distinguished persons,\r\nand added, in effect, that he had never so much as desired the honour of\r\ntheir acquaintance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t say that, comrade!\xe2\x80\x99 retorted Wegg: \xe2\x80\x98No, don\xe2\x80\x99t say that! Because,\r\nwithout having known them, you never can fully know what it is to be\r\nstimilated to frenzy by the sight of the Usurper.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nOffering these excusatory words as if they reflected great credit on\r\nhimself, Mr Wegg impelled himself with his hands towards a chair in\r\na corner of the room, and there, after a variety of awkward gambols,\r\nattained a perpendicular position. Mr Venus also rose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Comrade,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg, \xe2\x80\x98take a seat. Comrade, what a speaking countenance\r\nis yours!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Venus involuntarily smoothed his countenance, and looked at his hand,\r\nas if to see whether any of its speaking properties came off.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98For clearly do I know, mark you,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued Wegg, pointing his words\r\nwith his forefinger, \xe2\x80\x98clearly do I know what question your expressive\r\nfeatures puts to me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What question?\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The question,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Wegg, with a sort of joyful affability, \xe2\x80\x98why\r\nI didn\xe2\x80\x99t mention sooner, that I had found something. Says your speaking\r\ncountenance to me: \xe2\x80\x9cWhy didn\xe2\x80\x99t you communicate that, when I first come\r\nin this evening? Why did you keep it back till you thought Mr Boffin had\r\ncome to look for the article?\xe2\x80\x9d Your speaking countenance,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98puts it plainer than language. Now, you can\xe2\x80\x99t read in my face what\r\nanswer I give?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, I can\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I knew it! And why not?\xe2\x80\x99 returned Wegg, with the same joyful candour.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Because I lay no claims to a speaking countenance. Because I am well\r\naware of my deficiencies. All men are not gifted alike. But I can answer\r\nin words. And in what words? These. I wanted to give you a delightful\r\nsap--pur--IZE!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHaving thus elongated and emphasized the word Surprise, Mr Wegg shook\r\nhis friend and brother by both hands, and then clapped him on both\r\nknees, like an affectionate patron who entreated him not to mention so\r\nsmall a service as that which it had been his happy privilege to render.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your speaking countenance,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg, \xe2\x80\x98being answered to its\r\nsatisfaction, only asks then, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat have you found?\xe2\x80\x9d Why, I hear it say\r\nthe words!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well?\xe2\x80\x99 retorted Venus snappishly, after waiting in vain. \xe2\x80\x98If you hear\r\nit say the words, why don\xe2\x80\x99t you answer it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hear me out!\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg. \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m a-going to. Hear me out! Man and brother,\r\npartner in feelings equally with undertakings and actions, I have found\r\na cash-box.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98--Hear me out!\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg. (He tried to reserve whatever he could, and,\r\nwhenever disclosure was forced upon him, broke into a radiant gush of\r\nHear me out.) \xe2\x80\x98On a certain day, sir--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When?\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus bluntly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98N--no,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Wegg, shaking his head at once observantly,\r\nthoughtfully, and playfully. \xe2\x80\x98No, sir! That\xe2\x80\x99s not your expressive\r\ncountenance which asks that question. That\xe2\x80\x99s your voice; merely your\r\nvoice. To proceed. On a certain day, sir, I happened to be walking in\r\nthe yard--taking my lonely round--for in the words of a friend of my own\r\nfamily, the author of All\xe2\x80\x99s Well arranged as a duett:\r\n\r\n     \xe2\x80\x9cDeserted, as you will remember Mr Venus, by the waning\r\n     moon,\r\n     When stars, it will occur to you before I mention it, proclaim\r\n     night\xe2\x80\x99s cheerless noon,\r\n     On tower, fort, or tented ground,\r\n     The sentry walks his lonely round,\r\n     The sentry walks:\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n--under those circumstances, sir, I happened to be walking in the yard\r\nearly one afternoon, and happened to have an iron rod in my hand, with\r\nwhich I have been sometimes accustomed to beguile the monotony of a\r\nliterary life, when I struck it against an object not necessary to\r\ntrouble you by naming--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is necessary. What object?\xe2\x80\x99 demanded Venus, in a wrathful tone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98--Hear me out!\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg. \xe2\x80\x98The Pump.--When I struck it against the\r\nPump, and found, not only that the top was loose and opened with a lid,\r\nbut that something in it rattled. That something, comrade, I discovered\r\nto be a small flat oblong cash-box. Shall I say it was disappointingly\r\nlight?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There were papers in it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There your expressive countenance speaks indeed!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Wegg. \xe2\x80\x98A\r\npaper. The box was locked, tied up, and sealed, and on the outside was\r\na parchment label, with the writing, \xe2\x80\x9cMY WILL, JOHN HARMON, TEMPORARILY\r\nDEPOSITED HERE.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We must know its contents,\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98--Hear me out!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Wegg. \xe2\x80\x98I said so, and I broke the box open.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Without coming to me!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Venus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Exactly so, sir!\xe2\x80\x99 returned Wegg, blandly and buoyantly. \xe2\x80\x98I see I take\r\nyou with me! Hear, hear, hear! Resolved, as your discriminating good\r\nsense perceives, that if you was to have a sap--pur--IZE, it should be\r\na complete one! Well, sir. And so, as you have honoured me by\r\nanticipating, I examined the document. Regularly executed, regularly\r\nwitnessed, very short. Inasmuch as he has never made friends, and has\r\never had a rebellious family, he, John Harmon, gives to Nicodemus Boffin\r\nthe Little Mound, which is quite enough for him, and gives the whole\r\nrest and residue of his property to the Crown.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The date of the will that has been proved, must be looked to,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked\r\nVenus. \xe2\x80\x98It may be later than this one.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98--Hear me out!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Wegg. \xe2\x80\x98I said so. I paid a shilling (never mind\r\nyour sixpence of it) to look up that will. Brother, that will is dated\r\nmonths before this will. And now, as a fellow-man, and as a partner in a\r\nfriendly move,\xe2\x80\x99 added Wegg, benignantly taking him by both hands again,\r\nand clapping him on both knees again, \xe2\x80\x98say have I completed my labour of\r\nlove to your perfect satisfaction, and are you sap--pur--IZED?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Venus contemplated his fellow-man and partner with doubting eyes, and\r\nthen rejoined stiffly:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is great news indeed, Mr Wegg. There\xe2\x80\x99s no denying it. But I could\r\nhave wished you had told it me before you got your fright to-night, and\r\nI could have wished you had ever asked me as your partner what we were\r\nto do, before you thought you were dividing a responsibility.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98--Hear me out!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Wegg. \xe2\x80\x98I knew you was a-going to say so. But\r\nalone I bore the anxiety, and alone I\xe2\x80\x99ll bear the blame!\xe2\x80\x99 This with an\r\nair of great magnanimity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus. \xe2\x80\x98Let\xe2\x80\x99s see this will and this box.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do I understand, brother,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Wegg with considerable reluctance,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98that it is your wish to see this will and this--?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Venus smote the table with his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98--Hear me out!\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg. \xe2\x80\x98Hear me out! I\xe2\x80\x99ll go and fetch \xe2\x80\x98em.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAfter being some time absent, as if in his covetousness he could hardly\r\nmake up his mind to produce the treasure to his partner, he returned\r\nwith an old leathern hat-box, into which he had put the other box,\r\nfor the better preservation of commonplace appearances, and for the\r\ndisarming of suspicion. \xe2\x80\x98But I don\xe2\x80\x99t half like opening it here,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nSilas in a low voice, looking around: \xe2\x80\x98he might come back, he may not be\r\ngone; we don\xe2\x80\x99t know what he may be up to, after what we\xe2\x80\x99ve seen.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s something in that,\xe2\x80\x99 assented Venus. \xe2\x80\x98Come to my place.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJealous of the custody of the box, and yet fearful of opening it under\r\nthe existing circumstances, Wegg hesitated. \xe2\x80\x98Come, I tell you,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated\r\nVenus, chafing, \xe2\x80\x98to my place.\xe2\x80\x99 Not very well seeing his way to a\r\nrefusal, Mr Wegg then rejoined in a gush, \xe2\x80\x98--Hear me out!--Certainly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\nSo he locked up the Bower and they set forth: Mr Venus taking his arm,\r\nand keeping it with remarkable tenacity.\r\n\r\nThey found the usual dim light burning in the window of Mr Venus\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nestablishment, imperfectly disclosing to the public the usual pair\r\nof preserved frogs, sword in hand, with their point of honour still\r\nunsettled. Mr Venus had closed his shop door on coming out, and now\r\nopened it with the key and shut it again as soon as they were within;\r\nbut not before he had put up and barred the shutters of the shop window.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No one can get in without being let in,\xe2\x80\x99 said he then, \xe2\x80\x98and we couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nbe more snug than here.\xe2\x80\x99 So he raked together the yet warm cinders in\r\nthe rusty grate, and made a fire, and trimmed the candle on the little\r\ncounter. As the fire cast its flickering gleams here and there upon the\r\ndark greasy walls; the Hindoo baby, the African baby, the articulated\r\nEnglish baby, the assortment of skulls, and the rest of the collection,\r\ncame starting to their various stations as if they had all been out,\r\nlike their master and were punctual in a general rendezvous to assist\r\nat the secret. The French gentleman had grown considerably since Mr Wegg\r\nlast saw him, being now accommodated with a pair of legs and a head,\r\nthough his arms were yet in abeyance. To whomsoever the head had\r\noriginally belonged, Silas Wegg would have regarded it as a personal\r\nfavour if he had not cut quite so many teeth.\r\n\r\nSilas took his seat in silence on the wooden box before the fire, and\r\nVenus dropping into his low chair produced from among his skeleton\r\nhands, his tea-tray and tea-cups, and put the kettle on. Silas inwardly\r\napproved of these preparations, trusting they might end in Mr Venus\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndiluting his intellect.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus, \xe2\x80\x98all is safe and quiet. Let us see this\r\ndiscovery.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith still reluctant hands, and not without several glances towards the\r\nskeleton hands, as if he mistrusted that a couple of them might spring\r\nforth and clutch the document, Wegg opened the hat-box and revealed the\r\ncash-box, opened the cash-box and revealed the will. He held a corner\r\nof it tight, while Venus, taking hold of another corner, searchingly and\r\nattentively read it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Was I correct in my account of it, partner?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Wegg at length.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Partner, you were,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Venus.\r\n\r\nMr Wegg thereupon made an easy, graceful movement, as though he would\r\nfold it up; but Mr Venus held on by his corner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Venus, winking his weak eyes and shaking his head.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, partner. The question is now brought up, who is going to take care\r\nof this. Do you know who is going to take care of this, partner?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh dear no, partner,\xe2\x80\x99 retorted Venus. \xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s a mistake. I am. Now look\r\nhere, Mr Wegg. I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to have any words with you, and still less\r\ndo I want to have any anatomical pursuits with you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you mean?\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg, quickly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I mean, partner,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Venus, slowly, \xe2\x80\x98that it\xe2\x80\x99s hardly possible\r\nfor a man to feel in a more amiable state towards another man than I\r\ndo towards you at this present moment. But I am on my own ground, I am\r\nsurrounded by the trophies of my art, and my tools is very handy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you mean, Mr Venus?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Wegg again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am surrounded, as I have observed,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Venus, placidly, \xe2\x80\x98by\r\nthe trophies of my art. They are numerous, my stock of human warious is\r\nlarge, the shop is pretty well crammed, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t just now want any\r\nmore trophies of my art. But I like my art, and I know how to exercise\r\nmy art.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No man better,\xe2\x80\x99 assented Mr Wegg, with a somewhat staggered air.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s the Miscellanies of several human specimens,\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98(though you mightn\xe2\x80\x99t think it) in the box on which you\xe2\x80\x99re sitting.\r\nThere\xe2\x80\x99s the Miscellanies of several human specimens, in the lovely\r\ncompo-one behind the door\xe2\x80\x99; with a nod towards the French gentleman. \xe2\x80\x98It\r\nstill wants a pair of arms. I DON\xe2\x80\x99T say that I\xe2\x80\x99m in any hurry for \xe2\x80\x98em.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You must be wandering in your mind, partner,\xe2\x80\x99 Silas remonstrated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99ll excuse me if I wander,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Venus; \xe2\x80\x98I am sometimes rather\r\nsubject to it. I like my art, and I know how to exercise my art, and I\r\nmean to have the keeping of this document.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But what has that got to do with your art, partner?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Wegg, in an\r\ninsinuating tone.\r\n\r\nMr Venus winked his chronically-fatigued eyes both at once, and\r\nadjusting the kettle on the fire, remarked to himself, in a hollow\r\nvoice, \xe2\x80\x98She\xe2\x80\x99ll bile in a couple of minutes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSilas Wegg glanced at the kettle, glanced at the shelves, glanced at the\r\nFrench gentleman behind the door, and shrank a little as he glanced at\r\nMr Venus winking his red eyes, and feeling in his waistcoat pocket--as\r\nfor a lancet, say--with his unoccupied hand. He and Venus were\r\nnecessarily seated close together, as each held a corner of the\r\ndocument, which was but a common sheet of paper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Partner,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg, even more insinuatingly than before, \xe2\x80\x98I propose\r\nthat we cut it in half, and each keep a half.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nVenus shook his shock of hair, as he replied, \xe2\x80\x98It wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t do to\r\nmutilate it, partner. It might seem to be cancelled.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Partner,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg, after a silence, during which they had\r\ncontemplated one another, \xe2\x80\x98don\xe2\x80\x99t your speaking countenance say that\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99re a-going to suggest a middle course?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nVenus shook his shock of hair as he replied, \xe2\x80\x98Partner, you have kept\r\nthis paper from me once. You shall never keep it from me again. I offer\r\nyou the box and the label to take care of, but I\xe2\x80\x99ll take care of the\r\npaper.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSilas hesitated a little longer, and then suddenly releasing his corner,\r\nand resuming his buoyant and benignant tone, exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s life\r\nwithout trustfulness! What\xe2\x80\x99s a fellow-man without honour! You\xe2\x80\x99re welcome\r\nto it, partner, in a spirit of trust and confidence.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nContinuing to wink his red eyes both together--but in a self-communing\r\nway, and without any show of triumph--Mr Venus folded the paper now left\r\nin his hand, and locked it in a drawer behind him, and pocketed the key.\r\nHe then proposed \xe2\x80\x98A cup of tea, partner?\xe2\x80\x99 To which Mr Wegg returned,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank\xe2\x80\x99ee, partner,\xe2\x80\x99 and the tea was made and poured out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Next,\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus, blowing at his tea in his saucer, and looking over\r\nit at his confidential friend, \xe2\x80\x98comes the question, What\xe2\x80\x99s the course to\r\nbe pursued?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nOn this head, Silas Wegg had much to say. Silas had to say That, he\r\nwould beg to remind his comrade, brother, and partner, of the impressive\r\npassages they had read that evening; of the evident parallel in Mr\r\nBoffin\xe2\x80\x99s mind between them and the late owner of the Bower, and the\r\npresent circumstances of the Bower; of the bottle; and of the box. That,\r\nthe fortunes of his brother and comrade, and of himself were evidently\r\nmade, inasmuch as they had but to put their price upon this document,\r\nand get that price from the minion of fortune and the worm of the hour:\r\nwho now appeared to be less of a minion and more of a worm than had been\r\npreviously supposed. That, he considered it plain that such price was\r\nstateable in a single expressive word, and that the word was, \xe2\x80\x98Halves!\xe2\x80\x99\r\nThat, the question then arose when \xe2\x80\x98Halves!\xe2\x80\x99 should be called. That,\r\nhere he had a plan of action to recommend, with a conditional clause.\r\nThat, the plan of action was that they should lie by with patience;\r\nthat, they should allow the Mounds to be gradually levelled and cleared\r\naway, while retaining to themselves their present opportunity of\r\nwatching the process--which would be, he conceived, to put the trouble\r\nand cost of daily digging and delving upon somebody else, while they\r\nmight nightly turn such complete disturbance of the dust to the account\r\nof their own private investigations--and that, when the Mounds were\r\ngone, and they had worked those chances for their own joint benefit\r\nsolely, they should then, and not before, explode on the minion and\r\nworm. But here came the conditional clause, and to this he entreated the\r\nspecial attention of his comrade, brother, and partner. It was not to\r\nbe borne that the minion and worm should carry off any of that property\r\nwhich was now to be regarded as their own property. When he, Mr Wegg,\r\nhad seen the minion surreptitiously making off with that bottle, and its\r\nprecious contents unknown, he had looked upon him in the light of a mere\r\nrobber, and, as such, would have despoiled him of his ill-gotten gain,\r\nbut for the judicious interference of his comrade, brother, and partner.\r\nTherefore, the conditional clause he proposed was, that, if the minion\r\nshould return in his late sneaking manner, and if, being closely\r\nwatched, he should be found to possess himself of anything, no matter\r\nwhat, the sharp sword impending over his head should be instantly shown\r\nhim, he should be strictly examined as to what he knew or suspected,\r\nshould be severely handled by them his masters, and should be kept in\r\na state of abject moral bondage and slavery until the time when they\r\nshould see fit to permit him to purchase his freedom at the price of\r\nhalf his possessions. If, said Mr Wegg by way of peroration, he had\r\nerred in saying only \xe2\x80\x98Halves!\xe2\x80\x99 he trusted to his comrade, brother, and\r\npartner not to hesitate to set him right, and to reprove his weakness.\r\nIt might be more according to the rights of things, to say\r\nTwo-thirds; it might be more according to the rights of things, to say\r\nThree-fourths. On those points he was ever open to correction.\r\n\r\nMr Venus, having wafted his attention to this discourse over three\r\nsuccessive saucers of tea, signified his concurrence in the views\r\nadvanced. Inspirited hereby, Mr Wegg extended his right hand, and\r\ndeclared it to be a hand which never yet. Without entering into more\r\nminute particulars. Mr Venus, sticking to his tea, briefly professed his\r\nbelief as polite forms required of him, that it WAS a hand which never\r\nyet. But contented himself with looking at it, and did not take it to\r\nhis bosom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Brother,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg, when this happy understanding was established, \xe2\x80\x98I\r\nshould like to ask you something. You remember the night when I first\r\nlooked in here, and found you floating your powerful mind in tea?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nStill swilling tea, Mr Venus nodded assent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And there you sit, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued Wegg with an air of thoughtful\r\nadmiration, \xe2\x80\x98as if you had never left off! There\r\nyou sit, sir, in the midst of your works, looking as if you\xe2\x80\x99d been\r\ncalled upon for Home, Sweet Home, and was obleeging the company!\r\n\r\n     \xe2\x80\x9cA exile from home splendour dazzles in vain,\r\n     O give you your lowly Preparations again,\r\n     The birds stuffed so sweetly that can\xe2\x80\x99t be expected to come at\r\n     your call,\r\n     Give you these with the peace of mind dearer than all.\r\n     Home, Home, Home, sweet Home!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n--Be it ever,\xe2\x80\x99 added Mr Wegg in prose as he glanced about the shop,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98ever so ghastly, all things considered there\xe2\x80\x99s no place like it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You said you\xe2\x80\x99d like to ask something; but you haven\xe2\x80\x99t asked it,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nremarked Venus, very unsympathetic in manner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your peace of mind,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg, offering condolence, \xe2\x80\x98your peace of\r\nmind was in a poor way that night. HOW\xe2\x80\x99S it going on? IS it looking up\r\nat all?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She does not wish,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr Venus with a comical mixture of\r\nindignant obstinacy and tender melancholy, \xe2\x80\x98to regard herself, nor yet\r\nto be regarded, in that particular light. There\xe2\x80\x99s no more to be said.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, dear me, dear me!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Wegg with a sigh, but eyeing him while\r\npretending to keep him company in eyeing the fire, \xe2\x80\x98such is Woman! And\r\nI remember you said that night, sitting there as I sat here--said that\r\nnight when your peace of mind was first laid low, that you had taken an\r\ninterest in these very affairs. Such is coincidence!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Her father,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Venus, and then stopped to swallow more tea, \xe2\x80\x98her\r\nfather was mixed up in them.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You didn\xe2\x80\x99t mention her name, sir, I think?\xe2\x80\x99 observed Wegg, pensively.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, you didn\xe2\x80\x99t mention her name that night.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pleasant Riderhood.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In--deed!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Wegg. \xe2\x80\x98Pleasant Riderhood. There\xe2\x80\x99s something moving in\r\nthe name. Pleasant. Dear me! Seems to express what she might have\r\nbeen, if she hadn\xe2\x80\x99t made that unpleasant remark--and what she ain\xe2\x80\x99t,\r\nin consequence of having made it. Would it at all pour balm into your\r\nwounds, Mr Venus, to inquire how you came acquainted with her?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I was down at the water-side,\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus, taking another gulp of\r\ntea and mournfully winking at the fire--\xe2\x80\x98looking for parrots\xe2\x80\x99--taking\r\nanother gulp and stopping.\r\n\r\nMr Wegg hinted, to jog his attention: \xe2\x80\x98You could hardly have been out\r\nparrot-shooting, in the British climate, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no, no,\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus fretfully. \xe2\x80\x98I was down at the water-side,\r\nlooking for parrots brought home by sailors, to buy for stuffing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ay, ay, ay, sir!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98--And looking for a nice pair of rattlesnakes, to articulate for a\r\nMuseum--when I was doomed to fall in with her and deal with her. It was\r\njust at the time of that discovery in the river. Her father had seen the\r\ndiscovery being towed in the river. I made the popularity of the subject\r\na reason for going back to improve the acquaintance, and I have never\r\nsince been the man I was. My very bones is rendered flabby by brooding\r\nover it. If they could be brought to me loose, to sort, I should hardly\r\nhave the face to claim \xe2\x80\x98em as mine. To such an extent have I fallen off\r\nunder it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Wegg, less interested than he had been, glanced at one particular\r\nshelf in the dark.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why I remember, Mr Venus,\xe2\x80\x99 he said in a tone of friendly commiseration\r\n\xe2\x80\x98(for I remember every word that falls from you, sir), I remember that\r\nyou said that night, you had got up there--and then your words was,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98--The parrot that I bought of her,\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus, with a despondent rise\r\nand fall of his eyes. \xe2\x80\x98Yes; there it lies on its side, dried up; except\r\nfor its plumage, very like myself. I\xe2\x80\x99ve never had the heart to prepare\r\nit, and I never shall have now.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith a disappointed face, Silas mentally consigned this parrot to\r\nregions more than tropical, and, seeming for the time to have lost\r\nhis power of assuming an interest in the woes of Mr Venus, fell to\r\ntightening his wooden leg as a preparation for departure: its gymnastic\r\nperformances of that evening having severely tried its constitution.\r\n\r\nAfter Silas had left the shop, hat-box in hand, and had left Mr Venus\r\nto lower himself to oblivion-point with the requisite weight of tea, it\r\ngreatly preyed on his ingenuous mind that he had taken this artist into\r\npartnership at all. He bitterly felt that he had overreached himself in\r\nthe beginning, by grasping at Mr Venus\xe2\x80\x99s mere straws of hints, now shown\r\nto be worthless for his purpose. Casting about for ways and means of\r\ndissolving the connexion without loss of money, reproaching himself for\r\nhaving been betrayed into an avowal of his secret, and complimenting\r\nhimself beyond measure on his purely accidental good luck, he beguiled\r\nthe distance between Clerkenwell and the mansion of the Golden Dustman.\r\n\r\nFor, Silas Wegg felt it to be quite out of the question that he could\r\nlay his head upon his pillow in peace, without first hovering over\r\nMr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s house in the superior character of its Evil Genius. Power\r\n(unless it be the power of intellect or virtue) has ever the greatest\r\nattraction for the lowest natures; and the mere defiance of the\r\nunconscious house-front, with his power to strip the roof off the\r\ninhabiting family like the roof of a house of cards, was a treat which\r\nhad a charm for Silas Wegg.\r\n\r\nAs he hovered on the opposite side of the street, exulting, the carriage\r\ndrove up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99ll shortly be an end of YOU,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg, threatening it with the\r\nhat-box. \xe2\x80\x98YOUR varnish is fading.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs Boffin descended and went in.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Look out for a fall, my Lady Dustwoman,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg.\r\n\r\nBella lightly descended, and ran in after her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How brisk we are!\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg. \xe2\x80\x98You won\xe2\x80\x99t run so gaily to your old\r\nshabby home, my girl. You\xe2\x80\x99ll have to go there, though.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nA little while, and the Secretary came out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I was passed over for you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg. \xe2\x80\x98But you had better provide\r\nyourself with another situation, young man.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s shadow passed upon the blinds of three large windows as he\r\ntrotted down the room, and passed again as he went back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yoop!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Wegg. \xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re there, are you? Where\xe2\x80\x99s the bottle? You\r\nwould give your bottle for my box, Dustman!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHaving now composed his mind for slumber, he turned homeward. Such\r\nwas the greed of the fellow, that his mind had shot beyond halves,\r\ntwo-thirds, three-fourths, and gone straight to spoliation of the whole.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Though that wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t quite do,\xe2\x80\x99 he considered, growing cooler as he got\r\naway. \xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s what would happen to him if he didn\xe2\x80\x99t buy us up. We should\r\nget nothing by that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWe so judge others by ourselves, that it had never come into his head\r\nbefore, that he might not buy us up, and might prove honest, and prefer\r\nto be poor. It caused him a slight tremor as it passed; but a very\r\nslight one, for the idle thought was gone directly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He\xe2\x80\x99s grown too fond of money for that,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg; \xe2\x80\x98he\xe2\x80\x99s grown too fond\r\nof money.\xe2\x80\x99 The burden fell into a strain or tune as he stumped along the\r\npavements.
