All the way home he stumped it out of the rattling streets,\r\nPIANO with his own foot, and FORTE with his wooden leg, \xe2\x80\x98He\xe2\x80\x99s GROWN too\r\nFOND of MONEY for THAT, he\xe2\x80\x99s GROWN too FOND of MONEY.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nEven next day Silas soothed himself with this melodious strain, when he\r\nwas called out of bed at daybreak, to set open the yard-gate and admit\r\nthe train of carts and horses that came to carry off the little Mound.\r\nAnd all day long, as he kept unwinking watch on the slow process which\r\npromised to protract itself through many days and weeks, whenever\r\n(to save himself from being choked with dust) he patrolled a little\r\ncinderous beat he established for the purpose, without taking his eyes\r\nfrom the diggers, he still stumped to the tune: He\xe2\x80\x99s GROWN too FOND of\r\nMONEY for THAT, he\xe2\x80\x99s GROWN too FOND of MONEY.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 8\r\n\r\nTHE END OF A LONG JOURNEY\r\n\r\n\r\nThe train of carts and horses came and went all day from dawn to\r\nnightfall, making little or no daily impression on the heap of ashes,\r\nthough, as the days passed on, the heap was seen to be slowly melting.\r\nMy lords and gentlemen and honourable boards, when you in the course\r\nof your dust-shovelling and cinder-raking have piled up a mountain of\r\npretentious failure, you must off with your honourable coats for the\r\nremoval of it, and fall to the work with the power of all the queen\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhorses and all the queen\xe2\x80\x99s men, or it will come rushing down and bury us\r\nalive.\r\n\r\nYes, verily, my lords and gentlemen and honourable boards, adapting your\r\nCatechism to the occasion, and by God\xe2\x80\x99s help so you must. For when we\r\nhave got things to the pass that with an enormous treasure at disposal\r\nto relieve the poor, the best of the poor detest our mercies, hide their\r\nheads from us, and shame us by starving to death in the midst of us, it\r\nis a pass impossible of prosperity, impossible of continuance. It may\r\nnot be so written in the Gospel according to Podsnappery; you may not\r\n\xe2\x80\x98find these words\xe2\x80\x99 for the text of a sermon, in the Returns of the Board\r\nof Trade; but they have been the truth since the foundations of the\r\nuniverse were laid, and they will be the truth until the foundations of\r\nthe universe are shaken by the Builder. This boastful handiwork of\r\nours, which fails in its terrors for the professional pauper, the sturdy\r\nbreaker of windows and the rampant tearer of clothes, strikes with a\r\ncruel and a wicked stab at the stricken sufferer, and is a horror to\r\nthe deserving and unfortunate. We must mend it, lords and gentlemen and\r\nhonourable boards, or in its own evil hour it will mar every one of us.\r\n\r\nOld Betty Higden fared upon her pilgrimage as many ruggedly honest\r\ncreatures, women and men, fare on their toiling way along the roads\r\nof life. Patiently to earn a spare bare living, and quietly to die,\r\nuntouched by workhouse hands--this was her highest sublunary hope.\r\n\r\nNothing had been heard of her at Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s house since she trudged\r\noff. The weather had been hard and the roads had been bad, and her\r\nspirit was up. A less stanch spirit might have been subdued by such\r\nadverse influences; but the loan for her little outfit was in no part\r\nrepaid, and it had gone worse with her than she had foreseen, and she\r\nwas put upon proving her case and maintaining her independence.\r\n\r\nFaithful soul! When she had spoken to the Secretary of that \xe2\x80\x98deadness\r\nthat steals over me at times\xe2\x80\x99, her fortitude had made too little of it.\r\nOftener and ever oftener, it came stealing over her; darker and ever\r\ndarker, like the shadow of advancing Death. That the shadow should\r\nbe deep as it came on, like the shadow of an actual presence, was in\r\naccordance with the laws of the physical world, for all the Light that\r\nshone on Betty Higden lay beyond Death.\r\n\r\nThe poor old creature had taken the upward course of the river Thames as\r\nher general track; it was the track in which her last home lay, and of\r\nwhich she had last had local love and knowledge. She had hovered for a\r\nlittle while in the near neighbourhood of her abandoned dwelling, and\r\nhad sold, and knitted and sold, and gone on. In the pleasant towns of\r\nChertsey, Walton, Kingston, and Staines, her figure came to be quite\r\nwell known for some short weeks, and then again passed on.\r\n\r\nShe would take her stand in market-places, where there were such things,\r\non market days; at other times, in the busiest (that was seldom very\r\nbusy) portion of the little quiet High Street; at still other times she\r\nwould explore the outlying roads for great houses, and would ask leave\r\nat the Lodge to pass in with her basket, and would not often get it. But\r\nladies in carriages would frequently make purchases from her trifling\r\nstock, and were usually pleased with her bright eyes and her hopeful\r\nspeech. In these and her clean dress originated a fable that she was\r\nwell to do in the world: one might say, for her station, rich. As making\r\na comfortable provision for its subject which costs nobody anything,\r\nthis class of fable has long been popular.\r\n\r\nIn those pleasant little towns on Thames, you may hear the fall of\r\nthe water over the weirs, or even, in still weather, the rustle of the\r\nrushes; and from the bridge you may see the young river, dimpled like a\r\nyoung child, playfully gliding away among the trees, unpolluted by the\r\ndefilements that lie in wait for it on its course, and as yet out of\r\nhearing of the deep summons of the sea. It were too much to pretend that\r\nBetty Higden made out such thoughts; no; but she heard the tender river\r\nwhispering to many like herself, \xe2\x80\x98Come to me, come to me! When the cruel\r\nshame and terror you have so long fled from, most beset you, come to me!\r\nI am the Relieving Officer appointed by eternal ordinance to do my work;\r\nI am not held in estimation according as I shirk it. My breast is softer\r\nthan the pauper-nurse\xe2\x80\x99s; death in my arms is peacefuller than among the\r\npauper-wards. Come to me!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere was abundant place for gentler fancies too, in her untutored mind.\r\nThose gentlefolks and their children inside those fine houses, could\r\nthey think, as they looked out at her, what it was to be really hungry,\r\nreally cold? Did they feel any of the wonder about her, that she felt\r\nabout them? Bless the dear laughing children! If they could have seen\r\nsick Johnny in her arms, would they have cried for pity? If they could\r\nhave seen dead Johnny on that little bed, would they have understood it?\r\nBless the dear children for his sake, anyhow! So with the humbler houses\r\nin the little street, the inner firelight shining on the panes as the\r\nouter twilight darkened. When the families gathered in-doors there, for\r\nthe night, it was only a foolish fancy to feel as if it were a little\r\nhard in them to close the shutter and blacken the flame. So with the\r\nlighted shops, and speculations whether their masters and mistresses\r\ntaking tea in a perspective of back-parlour--not so far within but that\r\nthe flavour of tea and toast came out, mingled with the glow of light,\r\ninto the street--ate or drank or wore what they sold, with the greater\r\nrelish because they dealt in it. So with the churchyard on a branch of\r\nthe solitary way to the night\xe2\x80\x99s sleeping-place. \xe2\x80\x98Ah me! The dead and\r\nI seem to have it pretty much to ourselves in the dark and in this\r\nweather! But so much the better for all who are warmly housed at home.\xe2\x80\x99\r\nThe poor soul envied no one in bitterness, and grudged no one anything.\r\n\r\nBut, the old abhorrence grew stronger on her as she grew weaker, and\r\nit found more sustaining food than she did in her wanderings. Now, she\r\nwould light upon the shameful spectacle of some desolate creature--or\r\nsome wretched ragged groups of either sex, or of both sexes, with\r\nchildren among them, huddled together like the smaller vermin for\r\na little warmth--lingering and lingering on a doorstep, while the\r\nappointed evader of the public trust did his dirty office of trying to\r\nweary them out and so get rid of them. Now, she would light upon some\r\npoor decent person, like herself, going afoot on a pilgrimage of\r\nmany weary miles to see some worn-out relative or friend who had been\r\ncharitably clutched off to a great blank barren Union House, as far from\r\nold home as the County Jail (the remoteness of which is always its worst\r\npunishment for small rural offenders), and in its dietary, and in\r\nits lodging, and in its tending of the sick, a much more penal\r\nestablishment. Sometimes she would hear a newspaper read out, and would\r\nlearn how the Registrar General cast up the units that had within the\r\nlast week died of want and of exposure to the weather: for which that\r\nRecording Angel seemed to have a regular fixed place in his sum, as if\r\nthey were its halfpence. All such things she would hear discussed, as\r\nwe, my lords and gentlemen and honourable boards, in our unapproachable\r\nmagnificence never hear them, and from all such things she would fly\r\nwith the wings of raging Despair.\r\n\r\nThis is not to be received as a figure of speech. Old Betty Higden\r\nhowever tired, however footsore, would start up and be driven away\r\nby her awakened horror of falling into the hands of Charity. It is a\r\nremarkable Christian improvement, to have made a pursuing Fury of the\r\nGood Samaritan; but it was so in this case, and it is a type of many,\r\nmany, many.\r\n\r\nTwo incidents united to intensify the old unreasoning\r\nabhorrence--granted in a previous place to be unreasoning, because the\r\npeople always are unreasoning, and invariably make a point of producing\r\nall their smoke without fire.\r\n\r\nOne day she was sitting in a market-place on a bench outside an inn,\r\nwith her little wares for sale, when the deadness that she strove\r\nagainst came over her so heavily that the scene departed from before\r\nher eyes; when it returned, she found herself on the ground, her head\r\nsupported by some good-natured market-women, and a little crowd about\r\nher.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you better now, mother?\xe2\x80\x99 asked one of the women. \xe2\x80\x98Do you think you\r\ncan do nicely now?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have I been ill then?\xe2\x80\x99 asked old Betty.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have had a faint like,\xe2\x80\x99 was the answer, \xe2\x80\x98or a fit. It ain\xe2\x80\x99t that\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ve been a-struggling, mother, but you\xe2\x80\x99ve been stiff and numbed.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah!\xe2\x80\x99 said Betty, recovering her memory. \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s the numbness. Yes. It\r\ncomes over me at times.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWas it gone? the women asked her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s gone now,\xe2\x80\x99 said Betty. \xe2\x80\x98I shall be stronger than I was afore.\r\nMany thanks to ye, my dears, and when you come to be as old as I am, may\r\nothers do as much for you!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey assisted her to rise, but she could not stand yet, and they\r\nsupported her when she sat down again upon the bench.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My head\xe2\x80\x99s a bit light, and my feet are a bit heavy,\xe2\x80\x99 said old Betty,\r\nleaning her face drowsily on the breast of the woman who had spoken\r\nbefore. \xe2\x80\x98They\xe2\x80\x99ll both come nat\xe2\x80\x99ral in a minute. There\xe2\x80\x99s nothing more the\r\nmatter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ask her,\xe2\x80\x99 said some farmers standing by, who had come out from their\r\nmarket-dinner, \xe2\x80\x98who belongs to her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are there any folks belonging to you, mother?\xe2\x80\x99 said the woman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes sure,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Betty. \xe2\x80\x98I heerd the gentleman say it, but I\r\ncouldn\xe2\x80\x99t answer quick enough. There\xe2\x80\x99s plenty belonging to me. Don\xe2\x80\x99t ye\r\nfear for me, my dear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But are any of \xe2\x80\x98em near here?\xe2\x80\x99 said the men\xe2\x80\x99s voices; the women\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nvoices chiming in when it was said, and prolonging the strain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Quite near enough,\xe2\x80\x99 said Betty, rousing herself. \xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t ye be afeard\r\nfor me, neighbours.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But you are not fit to travel. Where are you going?\xe2\x80\x99 was the next\r\ncompassionate chorus she heard.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m a going to London when I\xe2\x80\x99ve sold out all,\xe2\x80\x99 said Betty, rising with\r\ndifficulty. \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve right good friends in London. I want for nothing. I\r\nshall come to no harm. Thankye. Don\xe2\x80\x99t ye be afeard for me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nA well-meaning bystander, yellow-legginged and purple-faced, said\r\nhoarsely over his red comforter, as she rose to her feet, that she\r\n\xe2\x80\x98oughtn\xe2\x80\x99t to be let to go\xe2\x80\x99.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98For the Lord\xe2\x80\x99s love don\xe2\x80\x99t meddle with me!\xe2\x80\x99 cried old Betty, all her\r\nfears crowding on her. \xe2\x80\x98I am quite well now, and I must go this minute.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe caught up her basket as she spoke and was making an unsteady rush\r\naway from them, when the same bystander checked her with his hand on\r\nher sleeve, and urged her to come with him and see the parish-doctor.\r\nStrengthening herself by the utmost exercise of her resolution, the poor\r\ntrembling creature shook him off, almost fiercely, and took to flight.\r\nNor did she feel safe until she had set a mile or two of by-road between\r\nherself and the marketplace, and had crept into a copse, like a hunted\r\nanimal, to hide and recover breath. Not until then for the first time\r\ndid she venture to recall how she had looked over her shoulder before\r\nturning out of the town, and had seen the sign of the White Lion hanging\r\nacross the road, and the fluttering market booths, and the old grey\r\nchurch, and the little crowd gazing after her but not attempting to\r\nfollow her.\r\n\r\nThe second frightening incident was this. She had been again as bad, and\r\nhad been for some days better, and was travelling along by a part of\r\nthe road where it touched the river, and in wet seasons was so often\r\noverflowed by it that there were tall white posts set up to mark the\r\nway. A barge was being towed towards her, and she sat down on the bank\r\nto rest and watch it. As the tow-rope was slackened by a turn of the\r\nstream and dipped into the water, such a confusion stole into her\r\nmind that she thought she saw the forms of her dead children and dead\r\ngrandchildren peopling the barge, and waving their hands to her in\r\nsolemn measure; then, as the rope tightened and came up, dropping\r\ndiamonds, it seemed to vibrate into two parallel ropes and strike her,\r\nwith a twang, though it was far off. When she looked again, there was no\r\nbarge, no river, no daylight, and a man whom she had never before seen\r\nheld a candle close to her face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, Missis,\xe2\x80\x99 said he; \xe2\x80\x98where did you come from and where are you going\r\nto?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe poor soul confusedly asked the counter-question where she was?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am the Lock,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The Lock?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am the Deputy Lock, on job, and this is the Lock-house. (Lock or\r\nDeputy Lock, it\xe2\x80\x99s all one, while the t\xe2\x80\x99other man\xe2\x80\x99s in the hospital.)\r\nWhat\xe2\x80\x99s your Parish?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Parish!\xe2\x80\x99 She was up from the truckle-bed directly, wildly feeling about\r\nher for her basket, and gazing at him in affright.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99ll be asked the question down town,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man. \xe2\x80\x98They won\xe2\x80\x99t let\r\nyou be more than a Casual there. They\xe2\x80\x99ll pass you on to your settlement,\r\nMissis, with all speed. You\xe2\x80\x99re not in a state to be let come upon\r\nstrange parishes \xe2\x80\x98ceptin as a Casual.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x99Twas the deadness again!\xe2\x80\x99 murmured Betty Higden, with her hand to her\r\nhead.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was the deadness, there\xe2\x80\x99s not a doubt about it,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the man.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should have thought the deadness was a mild word for it, if it had\r\nbeen named to me when we brought you in. Have you got any friends,\r\nMissis?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The best of friends, Master.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should recommend your looking \xe2\x80\x98em up if you consider \xe2\x80\x98em game to do\r\nanything for you,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Deputy Lock. \xe2\x80\x98Have you got any money?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Just a morsel of money, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you want to keep it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sure I do!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, you know,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Deputy Lock, shrugging his shoulders with his\r\nhands in his pockets, and shaking his head in a sulkily ominous manner,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98the parish authorities down town will have it out of you, if you go on,\r\nyou may take your Alfred David.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then I\xe2\x80\x99ll not go on.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They\xe2\x80\x99ll make you pay, as fur as your money will go,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued the\r\nDeputy, \xe2\x80\x98for your relief as a Casual and for your being passed to your\r\nParish.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank ye kindly, Master, for your warning, thank ye for your shelter,\r\nand good night.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Stop a bit,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Deputy, striking in between her and the door.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why are you all of a shake, and what\xe2\x80\x99s your hurry, Missis?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, Master, Master,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Betty Higden, \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve fought against the\r\nParish and fled from it, all my life, and I want to die free of it!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Deputy, with deliberation, \xe2\x80\x98as I ought to let\r\nyou go. I\xe2\x80\x99m a honest man as gets my living by the sweat of my brow, and\r\nI may fall into trouble by letting you go. I\xe2\x80\x99ve fell into trouble afore\r\nnow, by George, and I know what it is, and it\xe2\x80\x99s made me careful. You\r\nmight be took with your deadness again, half a mile off--or half of half\r\na quarter, for the matter of that--and then it would be asked, Why did\r\nthat there honest Deputy Lock, let her go, instead of putting her safe\r\nwith the Parish? That\xe2\x80\x99s what a man of his character ought to have done,\r\nit would be argueyfied,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Deputy Lock, cunningly harping on the\r\nstrong string of her terror; \xe2\x80\x98he ought to have handed her over safe to\r\nthe Parish. That was to be expected of a man of his merits.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs he stood in the doorway, the poor old careworn wayworn woman burst\r\ninto tears, and clasped her hands, as if in a very agony she prayed to\r\nhim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As I\xe2\x80\x99ve told you, Master, I\xe2\x80\x99ve the best of friends. This letter will\r\nshow how true I spoke, and they will be thankful for me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe Deputy Lock opened the letter with a grave face, which underwent no\r\nchange as he eyed its contents. But it might have done, if he could have\r\nread them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What amount of small change, Missis,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, with an abstracted air,\r\nafter a little meditation, \xe2\x80\x98might you call a morsel of money?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHurriedly emptying her pocket, old Betty laid down on the table, a\r\nshilling, and two sixpenny pieces, and a few pence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If I was to let you go instead of handing you over safe to the Parish,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid the Deputy, counting the money with his eyes, \xe2\x80\x98might it be your own\r\nfree wish to leave that there behind you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Take it, Master, take it, and welcome and thankful!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m a man,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Deputy, giving her back the letter, and pocketing\r\nthe coins, one by one, \xe2\x80\x98as earns his living by the sweat of his brow;\xe2\x80\x99\r\nhere he drew his sleeve across his forehead, as if this particular\r\nportion of his humble gains were the result of sheer hard labour and\r\nvirtuous industry; \xe2\x80\x98and I won\xe2\x80\x99t stand in your way. Go where you like.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe was gone out of the Lock-house as soon as he gave her this\r\npermission, and her tottering steps were on the road again. But, afraid\r\nto go back and afraid to go forward; seeing what she fled from, in the\r\nsky-glare of the lights of the little town before her, and leaving a\r\nconfused horror of it everywhere behind her, as if she had escaped it\r\nin every stone of every market-place; she struck off by side ways, among\r\nwhich she got bewildered and lost. That night she took refuge from the\r\nSamaritan in his latest accredited form, under a farmer\xe2\x80\x99s rick; and\r\nif--worth thinking of, perhaps, my fellow-Christians--the Samaritan had\r\nin the lonely night, \xe2\x80\x98passed by on the other side\xe2\x80\x99, she would have most\r\ndevoutly thanked High Heaven for her escape from him.\r\n\r\nThe morning found her afoot again, but fast declining as to the\r\nclearness of her thoughts, though not as to the steadiness of her\r\npurpose. Comprehending that her strength was quitting her, and that the\r\nstruggle of her life was almost ended, she could neither reason out the\r\nmeans of getting back to her protectors, nor even form the idea. The\r\novermastering dread, and the proud stubborn resolution it engendered\r\nin her to die undegraded, were the two distinct impressions left in her\r\nfailing mind. Supported only by a sense that she was bent on conquering\r\nin her life-long fight, she went on.\r\n\r\nThe time was come, now, when the wants of this little life were passing\r\naway from her. She could not have swallowed food, though a table had\r\nbeen spread for her in the next field. The day was cold and wet, but\r\nshe scarcely knew it. She crept on, poor soul, like a criminal afraid of\r\nbeing taken, and felt little beyond the terror of falling down while it\r\nwas yet daylight, and being found alive. She had no fear that she would\r\nlive through another night.\r\n\r\nSewn in the breast of her gown, the money to pay for her burial was\r\nstill intact. If she could wear through the day, and then lie down to\r\ndie under cover of the darkness, she would die independent. If she were\r\ncaptured previously, the money would be taken from her as a pauper who\r\nhad no right to it, and she would be carried to the accursed workhouse.\r\nGaining her end, the letter would be found in her breast, along with\r\nthe money, and the gentlefolks would say when it was given back to them,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She prized it, did old Betty Higden; she was true to it; and while she\r\nlived, she would never let it be disgraced by falling into the hands\r\nof those that she held in horror.\xe2\x80\x99 Most illogical, inconsequential, and\r\nlight-headed, this; but travellers in the valley of the shadow of death\r\nare apt to be light-headed; and worn-out old people of low estate have\r\na trick of reasoning as indifferently as they live, and doubtless\r\nwould appreciate our Poor Law more philosophically on an income of ten\r\nthousand a year.\r\n\r\nSo, keeping to byways, and shunning human approach, this troublesome\r\nold woman hid herself, and fared on all through the dreary day. Yet so\r\nunlike was she to vagrant hiders in general, that sometimes, as the day\r\nadvanced, there was a bright fire in her eyes, and a quicker beating at\r\nher feeble heart, as though she said exultingly, \xe2\x80\x98The Lord will see me\r\nthrough it!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBy what visionary hands she was led along upon that journey of escape\r\nfrom the Samaritan; by what voices, hushed in the grave, she seemed\r\nto be addressed; how she fancied the dead child in her arms again, and\r\ntimes innumerable adjusted her shawl to keep it warm; what infinite\r\nvariety of forms of tower and roof and steeple the trees took; how many\r\nfurious horsemen rode at her, crying, \xe2\x80\x98There she goes! Stop! Stop,\r\nBetty Higden!\xe2\x80\x99 and melted away as they came close; be these things left\r\nuntold. Faring on and hiding, hiding and faring on, the poor harmless\r\ncreature, as though she were a Murderess and the whole country were up\r\nafter her, wore out the day, and gained the night.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Water-meadows, or such like,\xe2\x80\x99 she had sometimes murmured, on the day\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npilgrimage, when she had raised her head and taken any note of the real\r\nobjects about her. There now arose in the darkness, a great building,\r\nfull of lighted windows. Smoke was issuing from a high chimney in\r\nthe rear of it, and there was the sound of a water-wheel at the side.\r\nBetween her and the building, lay a piece of water, in which the lighted\r\nwindows were reflected, and on its nearest margin was a plantation of\r\ntrees. \xe2\x80\x98I humbly thank the Power and the Glory,\xe2\x80\x99 said Betty Higden,\r\nholding up her withered hands, \xe2\x80\x98that I have come to my journey\xe2\x80\x99s end!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe crept among the trees to the trunk of a tree whence she could see,\r\nbeyond some intervening trees and branches, the lighted windows, both in\r\ntheir reality and their reflection in the water. She placed her orderly\r\nlittle basket at her side, and sank upon the ground, supporting herself\r\nagainst the tree. It brought to her mind the foot of the Cross, and\r\nshe committed herself to Him who died upon it. Her strength held out to\r\nenable her to arrange the letter in her breast, so as that it could\r\nbe seen that she had a paper there. It had held out for this, and it\r\ndeparted when this was done.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am safe here,\xe2\x80\x99 was her last benumbed thought. \xe2\x80\x98When I am found dead\r\nat the foot of the Cross, it will be by some of my own sort; some of\r\nthe working people who work among the lights yonder. I cannot see the\r\nlighted windows now, but they are there. I am thankful for all!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\nThe darkness gone, and a face bending down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It cannot be the boofer lady?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t understand what you say. Let me wet your lips again with this\r\nbrandy. I have been away to fetch it. Did you think that I was long\r\ngone?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt is as the face of a woman, shaded by a quantity of rich dark hair.\r\nIt is the earnest face of a woman who is young and handsome. But all is\r\nover with me on earth, and this must be an Angel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have I been long dead?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t understand what you say. Let me wet your lips again. I hurried\r\nall I could, and brought no one back with me, lest you should die of the\r\nshock of strangers.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Am I not dead?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I cannot understand what you say. Your voice is so low and broken that\r\nI cannot hear you. Do you hear me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you mean Yes?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I was coming from my work just now, along the path outside (I was up\r\nwith the night-hands last night), and I heard a groan, and found you\r\nlying here.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What work, deary?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did you ask what work? At the paper-mill.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where is it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your face is turned up to the sky, and you can\xe2\x80\x99t see it. It is close\r\nby. You can see my face, here, between you and the sky?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dare I lift you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not yet.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not even lift your head to get it on my arm? I will do it by very\r\ngentle degrees. You shall hardly feel it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not yet. Paper. Letter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This paper in your breast?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bless ye!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Let me wet your lips again. Am I to open it? To read it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bless ye!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe reads it with surprise, and looks down with a new expression and an\r\nadded interest on the motionless face she kneels beside.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know these names. I have heard them often.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Will you send it, my dear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I cannot understand you. Let me wet your lips again, and your forehead.\r\nThere. O poor thing, poor thing!\xe2\x80\x99 These words through her fast-dropping\r\ntears. \xe2\x80\x98What was it that you asked me? Wait till I bring my ear quite\r\nclose.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Will you send it, my dear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Will I send it to the writers? Is that your wish? Yes, certainly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99ll not give it up to any one but them?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As you must grow old in time, and come to your dying hour, my dear,\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ll not give it up to any one but them?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No. Most solemnly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Never to the Parish!\xe2\x80\x99 with a convulsed struggle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No. Most solemnly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nor let the Parish touch me, not yet so much as look at me!\xe2\x80\x99 with\r\nanother struggle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No. Faithfully.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nA look of thankfulness and triumph lights the worn old face.\r\n\r\nThe eyes, which have been darkly fixed upon the sky, turn with meaning\r\nin them towards the compassionate face from which the tears are\r\ndropping, and a smile is on the aged lips as they ask:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What is your name, my dear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My name is Lizzie Hexam.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I must be sore disfigured. Are you afraid to kiss me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe answer is, the ready pressure of her lips upon the cold but smiling\r\nmouth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bless ye! NOW lift me, my love.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLizzie Hexam very softly raised the weather-stained grey head, and\r\nlifted her as high as Heaven.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 9\r\n\r\nSOMEBODY BECOMES THE SUBJECT OF A PREDICTION\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cWe give thee hearty thanks for that it hath pleased thee to deliver\r\nthis our sister out of the miseries of this sinful world.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99 So read the\r\nReverend Frank Milvey in a not untroubled voice, for his heart misgave\r\nhim that all was not quite right between us and our sister--or say our\r\nsister in Law--Poor Law--and that we sometimes read these words in an\r\nawful manner, over our Sister and our Brother too.\r\n\r\nAnd Sloppy--on whom the brave deceased had never turned her back until\r\nshe ran away from him, knowing that otherwise he would not be separated\r\nfrom her--Sloppy could not in his conscience as yet find the hearty\r\nthanks required of it. Selfish in Sloppy, and yet excusable, it may be\r\nhumbly hoped, because our sister had been more than his mother.\r\n\r\nThe words were read above the ashes of Betty Higden, in a corner of a\r\nchurchyard near the river; in a churchyard so obscure that there was\r\nnothing in it but grass-mounds, not so much as one single tombstone.\r\nIt might not be to do an unreasonably great deal for the diggers and\r\nhewers, in a registering age, if we ticketed their graves at the common\r\ncharge; so that a new generation might know which was which: so that the\r\nsoldier, sailor, emigrant, coming home, should be able to identify the\r\nresting-place of father, mother, playmate, or betrothed. For, we turn up\r\nour eyes and say that we are all alike in death, and we might turn\r\nthem down and work the saying out in this world, so far. It would\r\nbe sentimental, perhaps? But how say ye, my lords and gentleman and\r\nhonourable boards, shall we not find good standing-room left for a\r\nlittle sentiment, if we look into our crowds?\r\n\r\nNear unto the Reverend Frank Milvey as he read, stood his little wife,\r\nJohn Rokesmith the Secretary, and Bella Wilfer. These, over and above\r\nSloppy, were the mourners at the lowly grave. Not a penny had been\r\nadded to the money sewn in her dress: what her honest spirit had so long\r\nprojected, was fulfilled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve took it in my head,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sloppy, laying it, inconsolable, against\r\nthe church door, when all was done: \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve took it in my wretched head\r\nthat I might have sometimes turned a little harder for her, and it cuts\r\nme deep to think so now.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe Reverend Frank Milvey, comforting Sloppy, expounded to him how the\r\nbest of us were more or less remiss in our turnings at our respective\r\nMangles--some of us very much so--and how we were all a halting,\r\nfailing, feeble, and inconstant crew.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98SHE warn\xe2\x80\x99t, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Sloppy, taking this ghostly counsel rather ill,\r\nin behalf of his late benefactress. \xe2\x80\x98Let us speak for ourselves, sir.\r\nShe went through with whatever duty she had to do. She went through with\r\nme, she went through with the Minders, she went through with herself,\r\nshe went through with everythink. O Mrs Higden, Mrs Higden, you was a\r\nwoman and a mother and a mangler in a million million!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith those heartfelt words, Sloppy removed his dejected head from the\r\nchurch door, and took it back to the grave in the corner, and laid it\r\ndown there, and wept alone. \xe2\x80\x98Not a very poor grave,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Reverend\r\nFrank Milvey, brushing his hand across his eyes, \xe2\x80\x98when it has that\r\nhomely figure on it. Richer, I think, than it could be made by most of\r\nthe sculpture in Westminster Abbey!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey left him undisturbed, and passed out at the wicket-gate. The\r\nwater-wheel of the paper-mill was audible there, and seemed to have a\r\nsoftening influence on the bright wintry scene. They had arrived but a\r\nlittle while before, and Lizzie Hexam now told them the little she could\r\nadd to the letter in which she had enclosed Mr Rokesmith\xe2\x80\x99s letter and\r\nhad asked for their instructions. This was merely how she had heard the\r\ngroan, and what had afterwards passed, and how she had obtained leave\r\nfor the remains to be placed in that sweet, fresh, empty store-room of\r\nthe mill from which they had just accompanied them to the churchyard,\r\nand how the last requests had been religiously observed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I could not have done it all, or nearly all, of myself,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lizzie.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should not have wanted the will; but I should not have had the power,\r\nwithout our managing partner.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Surely not the Jew who received us?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Milvey.\r\n\r\n[\xe2\x80\x98My dear,\xe2\x80\x99 observed her husband in parenthesis, \xe2\x80\x98why not?\xe2\x80\x99)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The gentleman certainly is a Jew,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lizzie, \xe2\x80\x98and the lady, his\r\nwife, is a Jewess, and I was first brought to their notice by a Jew. But\r\nI think there cannot be kinder people in the world.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But suppose they try to convert you!\xe2\x80\x99 suggested Mrs Milvey, bristling\r\nin her good little way, as a clergyman\xe2\x80\x99s wife.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To do what, ma\xe2\x80\x99am?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Lizzie, with a modest smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To make you change your religion,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Milvey.\r\n\r\nLizzie shook her head, still smiling. \xe2\x80\x98They have never asked me what\r\nmy religion is. They asked me what my story was, and I told them. They\r\nasked me to be industrious and faithful, and I promised to be so.\r\nThey most willingly and cheerfully do their duty to all of us who are\r\nemployed here, and we try to do ours to them. Indeed they do much more\r\nthan their duty to us, for they are wonderfully mindful of us in many\r\nways.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is easy to see you\xe2\x80\x99re a favourite, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said little Mrs Milvey,\r\nnot quite pleased.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It would be very ungrateful in me to say I am not,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Lizzie,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98for I have been already raised to a place of confidence here. But that\r\nmakes no difference in their following their own religion and leaving\r\nall of us to ours. They never talk of theirs to us, and they never talk\r\nof ours to us. If I was the last in the mill, it would be just the same.\r\nThey never asked me what religion that poor thing had followed.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Milvey, aside to the Reverend Frank, \xe2\x80\x98I wish you\r\nwould talk to her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Reverend Frank aside to his good little wife, \xe2\x80\x98I\r\nthink I will leave it to somebody else. The circumstances are hardly\r\nfavourable. There are plenty of talkers going about, my love, and she\r\nwill soon find one.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWhile this discourse was interchanging, both Bella and the Secretary\r\nobserved Lizzie Hexam with great attention. Brought face to face for the\r\nfirst time with the daughter of his supposed murderer, it was natural\r\nthat John Harmon should have his own secret reasons for a careful\r\nscrutiny of her countenance and manner. Bella knew that Lizzie\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfather had been falsely accused of the crime which had had so great an\r\ninfluence on her own life and fortunes; and her interest, though it had\r\nno secret springs, like that of the Secretary, was equally natural. Both\r\nhad expected to see something very different from the real Lizzie Hexam,\r\nand thus it fell out that she became the unconscious means of bringing\r\nthem together.\r\n\r\nFor, when they had walked on with her to the little house in the clean\r\nvillage by the paper-mill, where Lizzie had a lodging with an elderly\r\ncouple employed in the establishment, and when Mrs Milvey and Bella\r\nhad been up to see her room and had come down, the mill bell rang.\r\nThis called Lizzie away for the time, and left the Secretary and Bella\r\nstanding rather awkwardly in the small street; Mrs Milvey being engaged\r\nin pursuing the village children, and her investigations whether they\r\nwere in danger of becoming children of Israel; and the Reverend Frank\r\nbeing engaged--to say the truth--in evading that branch of his spiritual\r\nfunctions, and getting out of sight surreptitiously.\r\n\r\nBella at length said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hadn\xe2\x80\x99t we better talk about the commission we have undertaken, Mr\r\nRokesmith?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98By all means,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Secretary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose,\xe2\x80\x99 faltered Bella, \xe2\x80\x98that we ARE both commissioned, or we\r\nshouldn\xe2\x80\x99t both be here?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose so,\xe2\x80\x99 was the Secretary\xe2\x80\x99s answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When I proposed to come with Mr and Mrs Milvey,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, \xe2\x80\x98Mrs\r\nBoffin urged me to do so, in order that I might give her my small\r\nreport--it\xe2\x80\x99s not worth anything, Mr Rokesmith, except for it\xe2\x80\x99s being\r\na woman\xe2\x80\x99s--which indeed with you may be a fresh reason for it\xe2\x80\x99s being\r\nworth nothing--of Lizzie Hexam.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Boffin,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Secretary, \xe2\x80\x98directed me to come for the same\r\npurpose.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs they spoke they were leaving the little street and emerging on the\r\nwooded landscape by the river.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You think well of her, Mr Rokesmith?\xe2\x80\x99 pursued Bella, conscious of\r\nmaking all the advances.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think highly of her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am so glad of that! Something quite refined in her beauty, is there\r\nnot?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Her appearance is very striking.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There is a shade of sadness upon her that is quite touching. At least\r\nI--I am not setting up my own poor opinion, you know, Mr Rokesmith,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Bella, excusing and explaining herself in a pretty shy way; \xe2\x80\x98I am\r\nconsulting you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I noticed that sadness. I hope it may not,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Secretary in\r\na lower voice, \xe2\x80\x98be the result of the false accusation which has been\r\nretracted.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWhen they had passed on a little further without speaking, Bella, after\r\nstealing a glance or two at the Secretary, suddenly said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, Mr Rokesmith, don\xe2\x80\x99t be hard with me, don\xe2\x80\x99t be stern with me; be\r\nmagnanimous! I want to talk with you on equal terms.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe Secretary as suddenly brightened, and returned: \xe2\x80\x98Upon my honour I\r\nhad no thought but for you. I forced myself to be constrained, lest you\r\nmight misinterpret my being more natural. There. It\xe2\x80\x99s gone.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, holding out her little hand. \xe2\x80\x98Forgive me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No!\xe2\x80\x99 cried the Secretary, eagerly. \xe2\x80\x98Forgive ME!\xe2\x80\x99 For there were tears\r\nin her eyes, and they were prettier in his sight (though they smote him\r\non the heart rather reproachfully too) than any other glitter in the\r\nworld.\r\n\r\nWhen they had walked a little further:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You were going to speak to me,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Secretary, with the shadow so\r\nlong on him quite thrown off and cast away, \xe2\x80\x98about Lizzie Hexam. So was\r\nI going to speak to you, if I could have begun.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now that you CAN begin, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Bella, with a look as if she\r\nitalicized the word by putting one of her dimples under it, \xe2\x80\x98what were\r\nyou going to say?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You remember, of course, that in her short letter to Mrs Boffin--short,\r\nbut containing everything to the purpose--she stipulated that either\r\nher name, or else her place of residence, must be kept strictly a secret\r\namong us.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella nodded Yes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is my duty to find out why she made that stipulation. I have it in\r\ncharge from Mr Boffin to discover, and I am very desirous for myself to\r\ndiscover, whether that retracted accusation still leaves any stain upon\r\nher. I mean whether it places her at any disadvantage towards any one,\r\neven towards herself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, nodding thoughtfully; \xe2\x80\x98I understand. That seems wise,\r\nand considerate.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You may not have noticed, Miss Wilfer, that she has the same kind of\r\ninterest in you, that you have in her. Just as you are attracted by her\r\nbeaut--by her appearance and manner, she is attracted by yours.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I certainly have NOT noticed it,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Bella, again italicizing\r\nwith the dimple, \xe2\x80\x98and I should have given her credit for--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe Secretary with a smile held up his hand, so plainly interposing \xe2\x80\x98not\r\nfor better taste\xe2\x80\x99, that Bella\xe2\x80\x99s colour deepened over the little piece of\r\ncoquetry she was checked in.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And so,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed the Secretary, \xe2\x80\x98if you would speak with her alone\r\nbefore we go away from here, I feel quite sure that a natural and easy\r\nconfidence would arise between you. Of course you would not be asked to\r\nbetray it; and of course you would not, if you were. But if you do not\r\nobject to put this question to her--to ascertain for us her own feeling\r\nin this one matter--you can do so at a far greater advantage than I or\r\nany else could. Mr Boffin is anxious on the subject. And I am,\xe2\x80\x99 added\r\nthe Secretary after a moment, \xe2\x80\x98for a special reason, very anxious.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall be happy, Mr Rokesmith,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Bella, \xe2\x80\x98to be of the least\r\nuse; for I feel, after the serious scene of to-day, that I am useless\r\nenough in this world.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t say that,\xe2\x80\x99 urged the Secretary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, but I mean that,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, raising her eyebrows.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No one is useless in this world,\xe2\x80\x99 retorted the Secretary, \xe2\x80\x98who lightens\r\nthe burden of it for any one else.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I assure you I DON\xe2\x80\x99T, Mr Rokesmith,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, half-crying.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not for your father?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dear, loving, self-forgetting, easily-satisfied Pa! Oh, yes! He thinks\r\nso.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is enough if he only thinks so,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Secretary. \xe2\x80\x98Excuse the\r\ninterruption: I don\xe2\x80\x99t like to hear you depreciate yourself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But YOU once depreciated ME, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 thought Bella, pouting, \xe2\x80\x98and I hope\r\nyou may be satisfied with the consequences you brought upon your head!\xe2\x80\x99\r\nHowever, she said nothing to that purpose; she even said something to a\r\ndifferent purpose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Rokesmith, it seems so long since we spoke together naturally, that\r\nI am embarrassed in approaching another subject. Mr Boffin. You know I\r\nam very grateful to him; don\xe2\x80\x99t you? You know I feel a true respect for\r\nhim, and am bound to him by the strong ties of his own generosity; now\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Unquestionably. And also that you are his favourite companion.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That makes it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, \xe2\x80\x98so very difficult to speak of him. But--.\r\nDoes he treat you well?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You see how he treats me,\xe2\x80\x99 the Secretary answered, with a patient and\r\nyet proud air.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, and I see it with pain,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, very energetically.\r\n\r\nThe Secretary gave her such a radiant look, that if he had thanked her a\r\nhundred times, he could not have said as much as the look said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I see it with pain,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Bella, \xe2\x80\x98and it often makes me miserable.\r\nMiserable, because I cannot bear to be supposed to approve of it, or\r\nhave any indirect share in it. Miserable, because I cannot bear to be\r\nforced to admit to myself that Fortune is spoiling Mr Boffin.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Miss Wilfer,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Secretary, with a beaming face, \xe2\x80\x98if you could\r\nknow with what delight I make the discovery that Fortune isn\xe2\x80\x99t spoiling\r\nYOU, you would know that it more than compensates me for any slight at\r\nany other hands.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, don\xe2\x80\x99t speak of ME,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, giving herself an impatient little\r\nslap with her glove. \xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t know me as well as--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As you know yourself?\xe2\x80\x99 suggested the Secretary, finding that she\r\nstopped. \xe2\x80\x98DO you know yourself?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know quite enough of myself,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, with a charming air of\r\nbeing inclined to give herself up as a bad job, \xe2\x80\x98and I don\xe2\x80\x99t improve\r\nupon acquaintance. But Mr Boffin.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s manner to me, or consideration for me, is not what it\r\nused to be,\xe2\x80\x99 observed the Secretary, \xe2\x80\x98must be admitted. It is too plain\r\nto be denied.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you disposed to deny it, Mr Rokesmith?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Bella, with a look of\r\nwonder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ought I not to be glad to do so, if I could: though it were only for my\r\nown sake?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Truly,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Bella, \xe2\x80\x98it must try you very much, and--you must\r\nplease promise me that you won\xe2\x80\x99t take ill what I am going to add, Mr\r\nRokesmith?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I promise it with all my heart.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98--And it must sometimes, I should think,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, hesitating, \xe2\x80\x98a\r\nlittle lower you in your own estimation?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAssenting with a movement of his head, though not at all looking as if\r\nit did, the Secretary replied:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have very strong reasons, Miss Wilfer, for bearing with the drawbacks\r\nof my position in the house we both inhabit. Believe that they are not\r\nall mercenary, although I have, through a series of strange fatalities,\r\nfaded out of my place in life. If what you see with such a gracious\r\nand good sympathy is calculated to rouse my pride, there are other\r\nconsiderations (and those you do not see) urging me to quiet endurance.\r\nThe latter are by far the stronger.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think I have noticed, Mr Rokesmith,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, looking at him with\r\ncuriosity, as not quite making him out, \xe2\x80\x98that you repress yourself, and\r\nforce yourself, to act a passive part.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are right. I repress myself and force myself to act a part. It is\r\nnot in tameness of spirit that I submit. I have a settled purpose.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And a good one, I hope,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And a good one, I hope,\xe2\x80\x99 he answered, looking steadily at her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sometimes I have fancied, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, turning away her eyes,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98that your great regard for Mrs Boffin is a very powerful motive with\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are right again; it is. I would do anything for her, bear anything\r\nfor her. There are no words to express how I esteem that good, good\r\nwoman.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As I do too! May I ask you one thing more, Mr Rokesmith?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Anything more.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course you see that she really suffers, when Mr Boffin shows how he\r\nis changing?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I see it, every day, as you see it, and am grieved to give her pain.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To give her pain?\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, repeating the phrase quickly, with her\r\neyebrows raised.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am generally the unfortunate cause of it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Perhaps she says to you, as she often says to me, that he is the best\r\nof men, in spite of all.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I often overhear her, in her honest and beautiful devotion to him,\r\nsaying so to you,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the Secretary, with the same steady look,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98but I cannot assert that she ever says so to me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella met the steady look for a moment with a wistful, musing little\r\nlook of her own, and then, nodding her pretty head several times, like\r\na dimpled philosopher (of the very best school) who was moralizing on\r\nLife, heaved a little sigh, and gave up things in general for a bad job,\r\nas she had previously been inclined to give up herself.\r\n\r\nBut, for all that, they had a very pleasant walk. The trees were bare of\r\nleaves, and the river was bare of water-lilies; but the sky was not bare\r\nof its beautiful blue, and the water reflected it, and a delicious\r\nwind ran with the stream, touching the surface crisply. Perhaps the old\r\nmirror was never yet made by human hands, which, if all the images it\r\nhas in its time reflected could pass across its surface again, would\r\nfail to reveal some scene of horror or distress. But the great serene\r\nmirror of the river seemed as if it might have reproduced all it had\r\never reflected between those placid banks, and brought nothing to the\r\nlight save what was peaceful, pastoral, and blooming.\r\n\r\nSo, they walked, speaking of the newly filled-up grave, and of Johnny,\r\nand of many things. So, on their return, they met brisk Mrs Milvey\r\ncoming to seek them, with the agreeable intelligence that there was no\r\nfear for the village children, there being a Christian school in the\r\nvillage, and no worse Judaical interference with it than to plant its\r\ngarden. So, they got back to the village as Lizzie Hexam was coming from\r\nthe paper-mill, and Bella detached herself to speak with her in her own\r\nhome.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am afraid it is a poor room for you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lizzie, with a smile of\r\nwelcome, as she offered the post of honour by the fireside.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not so poor as you think, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Bella, \xe2\x80\x98if you knew all.\xe2\x80\x99\r\nIndeed, though attained by some wonderful winding narrow stairs, which\r\nseemed to have been erected in a pure white chimney, and though very low\r\nin the ceiling, and very rugged in the floor, and rather blinking as\r\nto the proportions of its lattice window, it was a pleasanter room than\r\nthat despised chamber once at home, in which Bella had first bemoaned\r\nthe miseries of taking lodgers.\r\n\r\nThe day was closing as the two girls looked at one another by the\r\nfireside. The dusky room was lighted by the fire. The grate might have\r\nbeen the old brazier, and the glow might have been the old hollow down\r\nby the flare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s quite new to me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lizzie, \xe2\x80\x98to be visited by a lady so nearly\r\nof my own age, and so pretty, as you. It\xe2\x80\x99s a pleasure to me to look at\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have nothing left to begin with,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Bella, blushing, \xe2\x80\x98because\r\nI was going to say that it was a pleasure to me to look at you, Lizzie.\r\nBut we can begin without a beginning, can\xe2\x80\x99t we?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLizzie took the pretty little hand that was held out in as pretty a\r\nlittle frankness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, drawing her chair a little nearer, and taking\r\nLizzie\xe2\x80\x99s arm as if they were going out for a walk, \xe2\x80\x98I am commissioned\r\nwith something to say, and I dare say I shall say it wrong, but I\r\nwon\xe2\x80\x99t if I can help it. It is in reference to your letter to Mr and Mrs\r\nBoffin, and this is what it is. Let me see. Oh yes! This is what it is.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith this exordium, Bella set forth that request of Lizzie\xe2\x80\x99s touching\r\nsecrecy, and delicately spoke of that false accusation and its\r\nretraction, and asked might she beg to be informed whether it had any\r\nbearing, near or remote, on such request. \xe2\x80\x98I feel, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella,\r\nquite amazing herself by the business-like manner in which she was\r\ngetting on, \xe2\x80\x98that the subject must be a painful one to you, but I\r\nam mixed up in it also; for--I don\xe2\x80\x99t know whether you may know it or\r\nsuspect it--I am the willed-away girl who was to have been married to\r\nthe unfortunate gentleman, if he had been pleased to approve of me. So\r\nI was dragged into the subject without my consent, and you were dragged\r\ninto it without your consent, and there is very little to choose between\r\nus.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I had no doubt,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lizzie, \xe2\x80\x98that you were the Miss Wilfer I have\r\noften heard named. Can you tell me who my unknown friend is?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Unknown friend, my dear?\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who caused the charge against poor father to be contradicted, and sent\r\nme the written paper.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella had never heard of him. Had no notion who he was.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should have been glad to thank him,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Lizzie. \xe2\x80\x98He has done a\r\ngreat deal for me. I must hope that he will let me thank him some day.\r\nYou asked me has it anything to do--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It or the accusation itself,\xe2\x80\x99 Bella put in.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. Has either anything to do with my wishing to live quite secret and\r\nretired here? No.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs Lizzie Hexam shook her head in giving this reply and as her glance\r\nsought the fire, there was a quiet resolution in her folded hands, not\r\nlost on Bella\xe2\x80\x99s bright eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have you lived much alone?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Bella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. It\xe2\x80\x99s nothing new to me. I used to be always alone many hours\r\ntogether, in the day and in the night, when poor father was alive.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have a brother, I have been told?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have a brother, but he is not friendly with me. He is a very good\r\nboy though, and has raised himself by his industry. I don\xe2\x80\x99t complain of\r\nhim.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs she said it, with her eyes upon the fire-glow, there was an\r\ninstantaneous escape of distress into her face. Bella seized the moment\r\nto touch her hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lizzie, I wish you would tell me whether you have any friend of your\r\nown sex and age.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have lived that lonely kind of life, that I have never had one,\xe2\x80\x99 was\r\nthe answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nor I neither,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella. \xe2\x80\x98Not that my life has been lonely, for I\r\ncould have sometimes wished it lonelier, instead of having Ma going on\r\nlike the Tragic Muse with a face-ache in majestic corners, and Lavvy\r\nbeing spiteful--though of course I am very fond of them both. I wish\r\nyou could make a friend of me, Lizzie. Do you think you could? I have\r\nno more of what they call character, my dear, than a canary-bird, but I\r\nknow I am trustworthy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe wayward, playful, affectionate nature, giddy for want of the\r\nweight of some sustaining purpose, and capricious because it was always\r\nfluttering among little things, was yet a captivating one. To Lizzie it\r\nwas so new, so pretty, at once so womanly and so childish, that it won\r\nher completely. And when Bella said again, \xe2\x80\x98Do you think you could,\r\nLizzie?\xe2\x80\x99 with her eyebrows raised, her head inquiringly on one side,\r\nand an odd doubt about it in her own bosom, Lizzie showed beyond all\r\nquestion that she thought she could.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Tell me, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, \xe2\x80\x98what is the matter, and why you live\r\nlike this.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLizzie presently began, by way of prelude, \xe2\x80\x98You must have many lovers--\xe2\x80\x99\r\nwhen Bella checked her with a little scream of astonishment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear, I haven\xe2\x80\x99t one!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not one?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well! Perhaps one,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella. \xe2\x80\x98I am sure I don\xe2\x80\x99t know. I HAD one, but\r\nwhat he may think about it at the present time I can\xe2\x80\x99t say. Perhaps I\r\nhave half a one (of course I don\xe2\x80\x99t count that Idiot, George Sampson).\r\nHowever, never mind me. I want to hear about you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There is a certain man,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lizzie, \xe2\x80\x98a passionate and angry man, who\r\nsays he loves me, and who I must believe does love me. He is the friend\r\nof my brother. I shrank from him within myself when my brother first\r\nbrought him to me; but the last time I saw him he terrified me more than\r\nI can say.\xe2\x80\x99 There she stopped.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did you come here to escape from him, Lizzie?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I came here immediately after he so alarmed me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you afraid of him here?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am not timid generally, but I am always afraid of him. I am afraid\r\nto see a newspaper, or to hear a word spoken of what is done in London,\r\nlest he should have done some violence.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then you are not afraid of him for yourself, dear?\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, after\r\npondering on the words.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should be even that, if I met him about here. I look round for him\r\nalways, as I pass to and fro at night.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you afraid of anything he may do to himself in London, my dear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No. He might be fierce enough even to do some violence to himself, but\r\nI don\xe2\x80\x99t think of that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then it would almost seem, dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella quaintly, \xe2\x80\x98as if there\r\nmust be somebody else?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLizzie put her hands before her face for a moment before replying: \xe2\x80\x98The\r\nwords are always in my ears, and the blow he struck upon a stone wall as\r\nhe said them is always before my eyes. I have tried hard to think it\r\nnot worth remembering, but I cannot make so little of it. His hand was\r\ntrickling down with blood as he said to me, \xe2\x80\x9cThen I hope that I may\r\nnever kill him!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nRather startled, Bella made and clasped a girdle of her arms round\r\nLizzie\xe2\x80\x99s waist, and then asked quietly, in a soft voice, as they both\r\nlooked at the fire:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Kill him! Is this man so jealous, then?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of a gentleman,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lizzie. \xe2\x80\x98--I hardly know how to tell you--of a\r\ngentleman far above me and my way of life, who broke father\xe2\x80\x99s death to\r\nme, and has shown an interest in me since.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Does he love you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLizzie shook her head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Does he admire you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLizzie ceased to shake her head, and pressed her hand upon her living\r\ngirdle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is it through his influence that you came here?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O no! And of all the world I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have him know that I am here, or\r\nget the least clue where to find me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lizzie, dear! Why?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Bella, in amazement at this burst. But then\r\nquickly added, reading Lizzie\xe2\x80\x99s face: \xe2\x80\x98No. Don\xe2\x80\x99t say why. That was a\r\nfoolish question of mine. I see, I see.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere was silence between them. Lizzie, with a drooping head, glanced\r\ndown at the glow in the fire where her first fancies had been nursed,\r\nand her first escape made from the grim life out of which she had\r\nplucked her brother, foreseeing her reward.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You know all now,\xe2\x80\x99 she said, raising her eyes to Bella\xe2\x80\x99s. \xe2\x80\x98There is\r\nnothing left out. This is my reason for living secret here, with the aid\r\nof a good old man who is my true friend. For a short part of my life\r\nat home with father, I knew of things--don\xe2\x80\x99t ask me what--that I set my\r\nface against, and tried to better. I don\xe2\x80\x99t think I could have done more,\r\nthen, without letting my hold on father go; but they sometimes lie heavy\r\non my mind. By doing all for the best, I hope I may wear them out.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And wear out too,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella soothingly, \xe2\x80\x98this weakness, Lizzie, in\r\nfavour of one who is not worthy of it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No. I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to wear that out,\xe2\x80\x99 was the flushed reply, \xe2\x80\x98nor do I\r\nwant to believe, nor do I believe, that he is not worthy of it. What\r\nshould I gain by that, and how much should I lose!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella\xe2\x80\x99s expressive little eyebrows remonstrated with the fire for some\r\nshort time before she rejoined:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t think that I press you, Lizzie; but wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t you gain in peace,\r\nand hope, and even in freedom? Wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t it be better not to live a\r\nsecret life in hiding, and not to be shut out from your natural and\r\nwholesome prospects? Forgive my asking you, would that be no gain?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Does a woman\xe2\x80\x99s heart that--that has that weakness in it which you have\r\nspoken of,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Lizzie, \xe2\x80\x98seek to gain anything?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe question was so directly at variance with Bella\xe2\x80\x99s views in life, as\r\nset forth to her father, that she said internally, \xe2\x80\x98There, you little\r\nmercenary wretch! Do you hear that? Ain\xe2\x80\x99t you ashamed of your self?\xe2\x80\x99\r\nand unclasped the girdle of her arms, expressly to give herself a\r\npenitential poke in the side.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But you said, Lizzie,\xe2\x80\x99 observed Bella, returning to her subject when\r\nshe had administered this chastisement, \xe2\x80\x98that you would lose, besides.\r\nWould you mind telling me what you would lose, Lizzie?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should lose some of the best recollections, best encouragements,\r\nand best objects, that I carry through my daily life. I should lose my\r\nbelief that if I had been his equal, and he had loved me, I should have\r\ntried with all my might to make him better and happier, as he would have\r\nmade me. I should lose almost all the value that I put upon the little\r\nlearning I have, which is all owing to him, and which I conquered the\r\ndifficulties of, that he might not think it thrown away upon me. I\r\nshould lose a kind of picture of him--or of what he might have been,\r\nif I had been a lady, and he had loved me--which is always with me, and\r\nwhich I somehow feel that I could not do a mean or a wrong thing before.\r\nI should leave off prizing the remembrance that he has done me nothing\r\nbut good since I have known him, and that he has made a change within\r\nme, like--like the change in the grain of these hands, which were\r\ncoarse, and cracked, and hard, and brown when I rowed on the river with\r\nfather, and are softened and made supple by this new work as you see\r\nthem now.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey trembled, but with no weakness, as she showed them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Understand me, my dear;\xe2\x80\x99 thus she went on. \xe2\x80\x98I have never dreamed of\r\nthe possibility of his being anything to me on this earth but the\r\nkind picture that I know I could not make you understand, if the\r\nunderstanding was not in your own breast already. I have no more dreamed\r\nof the possibility of MY being his wife, than he ever has--and words\r\ncould not be stronger than that. And yet I love him. I love him so much,\r\nand so dearly, that when I sometimes think my life may be but a weary\r\none, I am proud of it and glad of it. I am proud and glad to suffer\r\nsomething for him, even though it is of no service to him, and he will\r\nnever know of it or care for it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella sat enchained by the deep, unselfish passion of this girl or woman\r\nof her own age, courageously revealing itself in the confidence of her\r\nsympathetic perception of its truth. And yet she had never experienced\r\nanything like it, or thought of the existence of anything like it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was late upon a wretched night,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lizzie, \xe2\x80\x98when his eyes first\r\nlooked at me in my old river-side home, very different from this. His\r\neyes may never look at me again. I would rather that they never did; I\r\nhope that they never may. But I would not have the light of them taken\r\nout of my life, for anything my life can give me. I have told you\r\neverything now, my dear. If it comes a little strange to me to have\r\nparted with it, I am not sorry. I had no thought of ever parting with a\r\nsingle word of it, a moment before you came in; but you came in, and my\r\nmind changed.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella kissed her on the cheek, and thanked her warmly for her\r\nconfidence. \xe2\x80\x98I only wish,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, \xe2\x80\x98I was more deserving of it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98More deserving of it?\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Lizzie, with an incredulous smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t mean in respect of keeping it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, \xe2\x80\x98because any\r\none should tear me to bits before getting at a syllable of it--though\r\nthere\xe2\x80\x99s no merit in that, for I am naturally as obstinate as a Pig. What\r\nI mean is, Lizzie, that I am a mere impertinent piece of conceit, and\r\nyou shame me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLizzie put up the pretty brown hair that came tumbling down, owing to\r\nthe energy with which Bella shook her head; and she remonstrated while\r\nthus engaged, \xe2\x80\x98My dear!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, it\xe2\x80\x99s all very well to call me your dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, with a\r\npettish whimper, \xe2\x80\x98and I am glad to be called so, though I have slight\r\nenough claim to be. But I AM such a nasty little thing!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear!\xe2\x80\x99 urged Lizzie again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Such a shallow, cold, worldly, Limited little brute!\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella,\r\nbringing out her last adjective with culminating force.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you think,\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Lizzie with her quiet smile, the hair being now\r\nsecured, \xe2\x80\x98that I don\xe2\x80\x99t know better?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98DO you know better though?\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella. \xe2\x80\x98Do you really believe you know\r\nbetter? Oh, I should be so glad if you did know better, but I am so very\r\nmuch afraid that I must know best!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLizzie asked her, laughing outright, whether she ever saw her own face\r\nor heard her own voice?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose so,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Bella; \xe2\x80\x98I look in the glass often enough, and I\r\nchatter like a Magpie.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have seen your face, and heard your voice, at any rate,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lizzie,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98and they have tempted me to say to you--with a certainty of not going\r\nwrong--what I thought I should never say to any one. Does that look\r\nill?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, I hope it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99 pouted Bella, stopping herself in something\r\nbetween a humoured laugh and a humoured sob.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I used once to see pictures in the fire,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lizzie playfully, \xe2\x80\x98to\r\nplease my brother. Shall I tell you what I see down there where the fire\r\nis glowing?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey had risen, and were standing on the hearth, the time being come for\r\nseparating; each had drawn an arm around the other to take leave.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Shall I tell you,\xe2\x80\x99 asked Lizzie, \xe2\x80\x98what I see down there?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Limited little b?\xe2\x80\x99 suggested Bella with her eyebrows raised.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A heart well worth winning, and well won. A heart that, once won, goes\r\nthrough fire and water for the winner, and never changes, and is never\r\ndaunted.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Girl\xe2\x80\x99s heart?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Bella, with accompanying eyebrows.\r\n\r\nLizzie nodded. \xe2\x80\x98And the figure to which it belongs--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is yours,\xe2\x80\x99 suggested Bella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No. Most clearly and distinctly yours.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSo the interview terminated with pleasant words on both sides, and with\r\nmany reminders on the part of Bella that they were friends, and pledges\r\nthat she would soon come down into that part of the country again. There\r\nwith Lizzie returned to her occupation, and Bella ran over to the little\r\ninn to rejoin her company.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You look rather serious, Miss Wilfer,\xe2\x80\x99 was the Secretary\xe2\x80\x99s first\r\nremark.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I feel rather serious,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Miss Wilfer.\r\n\r\nShe had nothing else to tell him but that Lizzie Hexam\xe2\x80\x99s secret had\r\nno reference whatever to the cruel charge, or its withdrawal. Oh yes\r\nthough! said Bella; she might as well mention one other thing; Lizzie\r\nwas very desirous to thank her unknown friend who had sent her the\r\nwritten retractation. Was she, indeed? observed the Secretary. Ah! Bella\r\nasked him, had he any notion who that unknown friend might be? He had no\r\nnotion whatever.\r\n\r\nThey were on the borders of Oxfordshire, so far had poor old Betty\r\nHigden strayed. They were to return by the train presently, and, the\r\nstation being near at hand, the Reverend Frank and Mrs Frank, and Sloppy\r\nand Bella and the Secretary, set out to walk to it. Few rustic paths are\r\nwide enough for five, and Bella and the Secretary dropped behind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Can you believe, Mr Rokesmith,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, \xe2\x80\x98that I feel as if whole\r\nyears had passed since I went into Lizzie Hexam\xe2\x80\x99s cottage?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We have crowded a good deal into the day,\xe2\x80\x99 he returned, \xe2\x80\x98and you were\r\nmuch affected in the churchyard. You are over-tired.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, I am not at all tired. I have not quite expressed what I mean. I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t mean that I feel as if a great space of time had gone by, but that\r\nI feel as if much had happened--to myself, you know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98For good, I hope?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope so,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are cold; I felt you tremble. Pray let me put this wrapper of mine\r\nabout you. May I fold it over this shoulder without injuring your dress?\r\nNow, it will be too heavy and too long. Let me carry this end over my\r\narm, as you have no arm to give me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nYes she had though. How she got it out, in her muffled state, Heaven\r\nknows; but she got it out somehow--there it was--and slipped it through\r\nthe Secretary\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have had a long and interesting talk with Lizzie, Mr Rokesmith, and\r\nshe gave me her full confidence.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She could not withhold it,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Secretary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wonder how you come,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, stopping short as she glanced at\r\nhim, \xe2\x80\x98to say to me just what she said about it!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I infer that it must be because I feel just as she felt about it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And how was that, do you mean to say, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Bella, moving again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That if you were inclined to win her confidence--anybody\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nconfidence--you were sure to do it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe railway, at this point, knowingly shutting a green eye and opening\r\na red one, they had to run for it. As Bella could not run easily so\r\nwrapped up, the Secretary had to help her. When she took her opposite\r\nplace in the carriage corner, the brightness in her face was so charming\r\nto behold, that on her exclaiming, \xe2\x80\x98What beautiful stars and what a\r\nglorious night!\xe2\x80\x99 the Secretary said \xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 but seemed to prefer to see\r\nthe night and the stars in the light of her lovely little countenance,\r\nto looking out of window.\r\n\r\nO boofer lady, fascinating boofer lady! If I were but legally executor\r\nof Johnny\xe2\x80\x99s will! If I had but the right to pay your legacy and to take\r\nyour receipt!--Something to this purpose surely mingled with the blast\r\nof the train as it cleared the stations, all knowingly shutting up their\r\ngreen eyes and opening their red ones when they prepared to let the\r\nboofer lady pass.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 10\r\n\r\nSCOUTS OUT\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And so, Miss Wren,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Eugene Wrayburn, \xe2\x80\x98I cannot persuade you to\r\ndress me a doll?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Miss Wren snappishly; \xe2\x80\x98if you want one, go and buy one at\r\nthe shop.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And my charming young goddaughter,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Wrayburn plaintively, \xe2\x80\x98down\r\nin Hertfordshire--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n[\xe2\x80\x98Humbugshire you mean, I think,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Miss Wren.)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98--is to be put upon the cold footing of the general public, and is\r\nto derive no advantage from my private acquaintance with the Court\r\nDressmaker?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If it\xe2\x80\x99s any advantage to your charming godchild--and oh, a precious\r\ngodfather she has got!\xe2\x80\x99--replied Miss Wren, pricking at him in the air\r\nwith her needle, \xe2\x80\x98to be informed that the Court Dressmaker knows\r\nyour tricks and your manners, you may tell her so by post, with my\r\ncompliments.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMiss Wren was busy at her work by candle-light, and Mr Wrayburn, half\r\namused and half vexed, and all idle and shiftless, stood by her bench\r\nlooking on. Miss Wren\xe2\x80\x99s troublesome child was in the corner in deep\r\ndisgrace, and exhibiting great wretchedness in the shivering stage of\r\nprostration from drink.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ugh, you disgraceful boy!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Miss Wren, attracted by the sound\r\nof his chattering teeth, \xe2\x80\x98I wish they\xe2\x80\x99d all drop down your throat and\r\nplay at dice in your stomach! Boh, wicked child! Bee-baa, black sheep!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nOn her accompanying each of these reproaches with a threatening stamp of\r\nthe foot, the wretched creature protested with a whine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pay five shillings for you indeed!\xe2\x80\x99 Miss Wren proceeded; \xe2\x80\x98how many\r\nhours do you suppose it costs me to earn five shillings, you infamous\r\nboy?--Don\xe2\x80\x99t cry like that, or I\xe2\x80\x99ll throw a doll at you. Pay five\r\nshillings fine for you indeed. Fine in more ways than one, I think! I\xe2\x80\x99d\r\ngive the dustman five shillings, to carry you off in the dust cart.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no,\xe2\x80\x99 pleaded the absurd creature. \xe2\x80\x98Please!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He\xe2\x80\x99s enough to break his mother\xe2\x80\x99s heart, is this boy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Wren,\r\nhalf appealing to Eugene. \xe2\x80\x98I wish I had never brought him up. He\xe2\x80\x99d be\r\nsharper than a serpent\xe2\x80\x99s tooth, if he wasn\xe2\x80\x99t as dull as ditch water.\r\nLook at him. There\xe2\x80\x99s a pretty object for a parent\xe2\x80\x99s eyes!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAssuredly, in his worse than swinish state (for swine at least fatten on\r\ntheir guzzling, and make themselves good to eat), he was a pretty object\r\nfor any eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A muddling and a swipey old child,\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Wren, rating him with\r\ngreat severity, \xe2\x80\x98fit for nothing but to be preserved in the liquor\r\nthat destroys him, and put in a great glass bottle as a sight for other\r\nswipey children of his own pattern,--if he has no consideration for his\r\nliver, has he none for his mother?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes.
