Deration, oh don\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x99 cried the subject of these angry remarks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh don\xe2\x80\x99t and oh don\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued Miss Wren. \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s oh do and oh do. And\r\nwhy do you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Won\xe2\x80\x99t do so any more. Won\xe2\x80\x99t indeed. Pray!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There!\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Wren, covering her eyes with her hand. \xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nbear to look at you. Go up stairs and get me my bonnet and shawl. Make\r\nyourself useful in some way, bad boy, and let me have your room instead\r\nof your company, for one half minute.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nObeying her, he shambled out, and Eugene Wrayburn saw the tears exude\r\nfrom between the little creature\xe2\x80\x99s fingers as she kept her hand before\r\nher eyes. He was sorry, but his sympathy did not move his carelessness\r\nto do anything but feel sorry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m going to the Italian Opera to try on,\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Wren, taking away\r\nher hand after a little while, and laughing satirically to hide that she\r\nhad been crying; \xe2\x80\x98I must see your back before I go, Mr Wrayburn. Let me\r\nfirst tell you, once for all, that it\xe2\x80\x99s of no use your paying visits\r\nto me. You wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t get what you want, of me, no, not if you brought\r\npincers with you to tear it out.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you so obstinate on the subject of a doll\xe2\x80\x99s dress for my godchild?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah!\xe2\x80\x99 returned Miss Wren with a hitch of her chin, \xe2\x80\x98I am so\r\nobstinate. And of course it\xe2\x80\x99s on the subject of a doll\xe2\x80\x99s dress--or\r\nADdress--whichever you like. Get along and give it up!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHer degraded charge had come back, and was standing behind her with the\r\nbonnet and shawl.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Give \xe2\x80\x98em to me and get back into your corner, you naughty old thing!\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Miss Wren, as she turned and espied him. \xe2\x80\x98No, no, I won\xe2\x80\x99t have your\r\nhelp. Go into your corner, this minute!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe miserable man, feebly rubbing the back of his faltering hands\r\ndownward from the wrists, shuffled on to his post of disgrace; but not\r\nwithout a curious glance at Eugene in passing him, accompanied with what\r\nseemed as if it might have been an action of his elbow, if any action of\r\nany limb or joint he had, would have answered truly to his will. Taking\r\nno more particular notice of him than instinctively falling away from\r\nthe disagreeable contact, Eugene, with a lazy compliment or so to Miss\r\nWren, begged leave to light his cigar, and departed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now you prodigal old son,\xe2\x80\x99 said Jenny, shaking her head and her\r\nemphatic little forefinger at her burden, \xe2\x80\x98you sit there till I come\r\nback. You dare to move out of your corner for a single instant while I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\ngone, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll know the reason why.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith this admonition, she blew her work candles out, leaving him to the\r\nlight of the fire, and, taking her big door-key in her pocket and her\r\ncrutch-stick in her hand, marched off.\r\n\r\nEugene lounged slowly towards the Temple, smoking his cigar, but saw\r\nno more of the dolls\xe2\x80\x99 dressmaker, through the accident of their taking\r\nopposite sides of the street. He lounged along moodily, and stopped at\r\nCharing Cross to look about him, with as little interest in the crowd\r\nas any man might take, and was lounging on again, when a most unexpected\r\nobject caught his eyes. No less an object than Jenny Wren\xe2\x80\x99s bad boy\r\ntrying to make up his mind to cross the road.\r\n\r\nA more ridiculous and feeble spectacle than this tottering wretch making\r\nunsteady sallies into the roadway, and as often staggering back again,\r\noppressed by terrors of vehicles that were a long way off or were\r\nnowhere, the streets could not have shown. Over and over again, when the\r\ncourse was perfectly clear, he set out, got half way, described a loop,\r\nturned, and went back again; when he might have crossed and re-crossed\r\nhalf a dozen times. Then, he would stand shivering on the edge of the\r\npavement, looking up the street and looking down, while scores of people\r\njostled him, and crossed, and went on. Stimulated in course of time\r\nby the sight of so many successes, he would make another sally, make\r\nanother loop, would all but have his foot on the opposite pavement,\r\nwould see or imagine something coming, and would stagger back again.\r\nThere, he would stand making spasmodic preparations as if for a great\r\nleap, and at last would decide on a start at precisely the wrong moment,\r\nand would be roared at by drivers, and would shrink back once more, and\r\nstand in the old spot shivering, with the whole of the proceedings to go\r\nthrough again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It strikes me,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Eugene coolly, after watching him for some\r\nminutes, \xe2\x80\x98that my friend is likely to be rather behind time if he has\r\nany appointment on hand.\xe2\x80\x99 With which remark he strolled on, and took no\r\nfurther thought of him.\r\n\r\nLightwood was at home when he got to the Chambers, and had dined alone\r\nthere. Eugene drew a chair to the fire by which he was having his wine\r\nand reading the evening paper, and brought a glass, and filled it for\r\ngood fellowship\xe2\x80\x99s sake.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear Mortimer, you are the express picture of contented industry,\r\nreposing (on credit) after the virtuous labours of the day.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear Eugene, you are the express picture of discontented idleness\r\nnot reposing at all. Where have you been?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have been,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Wrayburn, \xe2\x80\x98--about town. I have turned up at the\r\npresent juncture, with the intention of consulting my highly intelligent\r\nand respected solicitor on the position of my affairs.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your highly intelligent and respect solicitor is of opinion that your\r\naffairs are in a bad way, Eugene.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Though whether,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene thoughtfully, \xe2\x80\x98that can be intelligently\r\nsaid, now, of the affairs of a client who has nothing to lose and who\r\ncannot possibly be made to pay, may be open to question.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have fallen into the hands of the Jews, Eugene.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear boy,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the debtor, very composedly taking up his glass,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98having previously fallen into the hands of some of the Christians, I\r\ncan bear it with philosophy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have had an interview to-day, Eugene, with a Jew, who seems\r\ndetermined to press us hard. Quite a Shylock, and quite a Patriarch. A\r\npicturesque grey-headed and grey-bearded old Jew, in a shovel-hat and\r\ngaberdine.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, pausing in setting down his glass, \xe2\x80\x98surely not my\r\nworthy friend Mr Aaron?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He calls himself Mr Riah.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98By-the-by,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, \xe2\x80\x98it comes into my mind that--no doubt with an\r\ninstinctive desire to receive him into the bosom of our Church--I gave\r\nhim the name of Aaron!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Eugene, Eugene,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Lightwood, \xe2\x80\x98you are more ridiculous than\r\nusual. Say what you mean.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Merely, my dear fellow, that I have the honour and pleasure of a\r\nspeaking acquaintance with such a Patriarch as you describe, and that I\r\naddress him as Mr Aaron, because it appears to me Hebraic, expressive,\r\nappropriate, and complimentary. Notwithstanding which strong reasons for\r\nits being his name, it may not be his name.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I believe you are the absurdest man on the face of the earth,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nLightwood, laughing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not at all, I assure you. Did he mention that he knew me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He did not. He only said of you that he expected to be paid by you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Which looks,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Eugene with much gravity, \xe2\x80\x98like NOT knowing me.\r\nI hope it may not be my worthy friend Mr Aaron, for, to tell you the\r\ntruth, Mortimer, I doubt he may have a prepossession against me. I\r\nstrongly suspect him of having had a hand in spiriting away Lizzie.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Everything,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Lightwood impatiently, \xe2\x80\x98seems, by a fatality,\r\nto bring us round to Lizzie. \xe2\x80\x9cAbout town\xe2\x80\x9d meant about Lizzie, just now,\r\nEugene.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My solicitor, do you know,\xe2\x80\x99 observed Eugene, turning round to the\r\nfurniture, \xe2\x80\x98is a man of infinite discernment!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did it not, Eugene?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes it did, Mortimer.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And yet, Eugene, you know you do not really care for her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nEugene Wrayburn rose, and put his hands in his pockets, and stood with a\r\nfoot on the fender, indolently rocking his body and looking at the fire.\r\nAfter a prolonged pause, he replied: \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know that. See now! That\xe2\x80\x99s exactly what I am incapable of doing. How very\r\nacute you are, Mortimer, in finding my weak place! When we were at\r\nschool together, I got up my lessons at the last moment, day by day and\r\nbit by bit; now we are out in life together, I get up my lessons in the\r\nsame way. In the present task I have not got beyond this:--I am bent\r\non finding Lizzie, and I mean to find her, and I will take any means\r\nof finding her that offer themselves. Fair means or foul means, are all\r\nalike to me. I ask you--for information--what does that mean? When I\r\nhave found her I may ask you--also for information--what do I mean now?\r\nBut it would be premature in this stage, and it\xe2\x80\x99s not the character of\r\nmy mind.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLightwood was shaking his head over the air with which his friend held\r\nforth thus--an air so whimsically open and argumentative as almost to\r\ndeprive what he said of the appearance of evasion--when a shuffling was\r\nheard at the outer door, and then an undecided knock, as though\r\nsome hand were groping for the knocker. \xe2\x80\x98The frolicsome youth of the\r\nneighbourhood,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, \xe2\x80\x98whom I should be delighted to pitch from\r\nthis elevation into the churchyard below, without any intermediate\r\nceremonies, have probably turned the lamp out. The amiable occupation has been the solace of my life,\r\nsince I was baulked in the manner unnecessary to recall. I have derived\r\ninexpressible comfort from it. I do it thus: I stroll out after dark,\r\nstroll a little way, look in at a window and furtively look out for the\r\nschoolmaster. Sooner or later, I perceive the schoolmaster on the watch;\r\nsometimes accompanied by his hopeful pupil; oftener, pupil-less. Having\r\nmade sure of his watching me, I tempt him on, all over London. One\r\nnight I go east, another night north, in a few nights I go all round the\r\ncompass. Sometimes, I walk; sometimes, I proceed in cabs, draining the\r\npocket of the schoolmaster who then follows in cabs. I study and get\r\nup abstruse No Thoroughfares in the course of the day. With Venetian\r\nmystery I seek those No Thoroughfares at night, glide into them by means\r\nof dark courts, tempt the schoolmaster to follow, turn suddenly, and\r\ncatch him before he can retreat. Then we face one another, and I pass\r\nhim as unaware of his existence, and he undergoes grinding torments.\r\nSimilarly, I walk at a great pace down a short street, rapidly turn the\r\ncorner, and, getting out of his view, as rapidly turn back. I catch him\r\ncoming on post, again pass him as unaware of his existence, and again\r\nhe undergoes grinding torments. Night after night his disappointment is\r\nacute, but hope springs eternal in the scholastic breast, and he follows\r\nme again to-morrow. Thus I enjoy the pleasures of the chase, and derive\r\ngreat benefit from the healthful exercise. When I do not enjoy the\r\npleasures of the chase, for anything I know he watches at the Temple\r\nGate all night.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is an extraordinary story,\xe2\x80\x99 observed Lightwood, who had heard it\r\nout with serious attention. \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t like it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are a little hipped, dear fellow,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene; \xe2\x80\x98you have been too\r\nsedentary. It will do you good.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLightwood hesitated; but, yielding to his curiosity, rose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Bravo!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Eugene, rising too. \xe2\x80\x98Or, if Yoicks would be in better\r\nkeeping, consider that I said Yoicks. Look to your feet, Mortimer, for\r\nwe shall try your boots. When you are ready, I am--need I say with a Hey\r\nHo Chivey, and likewise with a Hark Forward, Hark Forward, Tantivy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Will nothing make you serious?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mortimer, laughing through his\r\ngravity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am always serious, but just now I am a little excited by the glorious\r\nfact that a southerly wind and a cloudy sky proclaim a hunting evening.\r\nReady? So. We turn out the lamp and shut the door, and take the field.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs the two friends passed out of the Temple into the public street,\r\nEugene demanded with a show of courteous patronage in which direction\r\nMortimer would you like the run to be? \xe2\x80\x98There is a rather difficult\r\ncountry about Bethnal Green,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, \xe2\x80\x98and we have not taken in\r\nthat direction lately. What is your opinion of Bethnal Green?\xe2\x80\x99 Mortimer\r\nassented to Bethnal Green, and they turned eastward. \xe2\x80\x98Now, when we come\r\nto St Paul\xe2\x80\x99s churchyard,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued Eugene, \xe2\x80\x98we\xe2\x80\x99ll loiter artfully, and\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll show you the schoolmaster.\xe2\x80\x99 But, they both saw him, before they got\r\nthere; alone, and stealing after them in the shadow of the houses, on\r\nthe opposite side of the way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Get your wind,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, \xe2\x80\x98for I am off directly. Does it occur\r\nto you that the boys of Merry England will begin to deteriorate in an\r\neducational light, if this lasts long? The schoolmaster can\xe2\x80\x99t attend to\r\nme and the boys too. Got your wind? I am off!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAt what a rate he went, to breathe the schoolmaster; and how he then\r\nlounged and loitered, to put his patience to another kind of wear;\r\nwhat preposterous ways he took, with no other object on earth than to\r\ndisappoint and punish him; and how he wore him out by every piece of\r\ningenuity that his eccentric humour could devise; all this Lightwood\r\nnoted, with a feeling of astonishment that so careless a man could be so\r\nwary, and that so idle a man could take so much trouble. At last, far on\r\nin the third hour of the pleasures of the chase, when he had brought the\r\npoor dogging wretch round again into the City, he twisted Mortimer up\r\na few dark entries, twisted him into a little square court, twisted him\r\nsharp round again, and they almost ran against Bradley Headstone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And you see, as I was saying, Mortimer,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Eugene aloud with\r\nthe utmost coolness, as though there were no one within hearing\r\nby themselves: \xe2\x80\x98and you see, as I was saying--undergoing grinding\r\ntorments.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt was not too strong a phrase for the occasion. Looking like the hunted\r\nand not the hunter, baffled, worn, with the exhaustion of deferred\r\nhope and consuming hate and anger in his face, white-lipped, wild-eyed,\r\ndraggle-haired, seamed with jealousy and anger, and torturing himself\r\nwith the conviction that he showed it all and they exulted in it, he\r\nwent by them in the dark, like a haggard head suspended in the air: so\r\ncompletely did the force of his expression cancel his figure.\r\n\r\nMortimer Lightwood was not an extraordinarily impressible man, but this\r\nface impressed him. He spoke of it more than once on the remainder of\r\nthe way home, and more than once when they got home.\r\n\r\nThey had been abed in their respective rooms two or three hours, when\r\nEugene was partly awakened by hearing a footstep going about, and was\r\nfully awakened by seeing Lightwood standing at his bedside.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing wrong, Mortimer?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What fancy takes you, then, for walking about in the night?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am horribly wakeful.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How comes that about, I wonder!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Eugene, I cannot lose sight of that fellow\xe2\x80\x99s face.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Odd!\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene with a light laugh, \xe2\x80\x98I can.\xe2\x80\x99 And turned over, and\r\nfell asleep again.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 11\r\n\r\nIN THE DARK\r\n\r\n\r\nThere was no sleep for Bradley Headstone on that night when Eugene\r\nWrayburn turned so easily in his bed; there was no sleep for little\r\nMiss Peecher. Bradley consumed the lonely hours, and consumed himself in\r\nhaunting the spot where his careless rival lay a dreaming; little Miss\r\nPeecher wore them away in listening for the return home of the master\r\nof her heart, and in sorrowfully presaging that much was amiss with him.\r\nYet more was amiss with him than Miss Peecher\xe2\x80\x99s simply arranged little\r\nwork-box of thoughts, fitted with no gloomy and dark recesses, could\r\nhold. For, the state of the man was murderous.\r\n\r\nThe state of the man was murderous, and he knew it. More; he irritated\r\nit, with a kind of perverse pleasure akin to that which a sick man\r\nsometimes has in irritating a wound upon his body. Tied up all day with\r\nhis disciplined show upon him, subdued to the performance of his routine\r\nof educational tricks, encircled by a gabbling crowd, he broke loose at\r\nnight like an ill-tamed wild animal. Under his daily restraint, it was\r\nhis compensation, not his trouble, to give a glance towards his state at\r\nnight, and to the freedom of its being indulged. If great criminals told\r\nthe truth--which, being great criminals, they do not--they would very\r\nrarely tell of their struggles against the crime. Their struggles are\r\ntowards it. They buffet with opposing waves, to gain the bloody shore,\r\nnot to recede from it. This man perfectly comprehended that he hated his\r\nrival with his strongest and worst forces, and that if he tracked him to\r\nLizzie Hexam, his so doing would never serve himself with her, or serve\r\nher. All his pains were taken, to the end that he might incense himself\r\nwith the sight of the detested figure in her company and favour, in her\r\nplace of concealment. And he knew as well what act of his would follow\r\nif he did, as he knew that his mother had borne him. Granted, that he\r\nmay not have held it necessary to make express mention to himself of the\r\none familiar truth any more than of the other.\r\n\r\nHe knew equally well that he fed his wrath and hatred, and that he\r\naccumulated provocation and self-justification, by being made the\r\nnightly sport of the reckless and insolent Eugene. Knowing all\r\nthis,--and still always going on with infinite endurance, pains, and\r\nperseverance, could his dark soul doubt whither he went?\r\n\r\nBaffled, exasperated, and weary, he lingered opposite the Temple gate\r\nwhen it closed on Wrayburn and Lightwood, debating with himself should\r\nhe go home for that time or should he watch longer. Possessed in his\r\njealousy by the fixed idea that Wrayburn was in the secret, if it were\r\nnot altogether of his contriving, Bradley was as confident of getting\r\nthe better of him at last by sullenly sticking to him, as he would have\r\nbeen--and often had been--of mastering any piece of study in the way\r\nof his vocation, by the like slow persistent process. A man of rapid\r\npassions and sluggish intelligence, it had served him often and should\r\nserve him again.\r\n\r\nThe suspicion crossed him as he rested in a doorway with his eyes upon\r\nthe Temple gate, that perhaps she was even concealed in that set of\r\nChambers. It would furnish another reason for Wrayburn\xe2\x80\x99s purposeless\r\nwalks, and it might be. He thought of it and thought of it, until\r\nhe resolved to steal up the stairs, if the gatekeeper would let him\r\nthrough, and listen. So, the haggard head suspended in the air flitted\r\nacross the road, like the spectre of one of the many heads erst hoisted\r\nupon neighbouring Temple Bar, and stopped before the watchman.\r\n\r\nThe watchman looked at it, and asked: \xe2\x80\x98Who for?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Wrayburn.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s very late.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He came back with Mr Lightwood, I know, near upon two hours ago. But if\r\nhe has gone to bed, I\xe2\x80\x99ll put a paper in his letter-box. I am expected.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe watchman said no more, but opened the gate, though rather\r\ndoubtfully. Seeing, however, that the visitor went straight and fast in\r\nthe right direction, he seemed satisfied.\r\n\r\nThe haggard head floated up the dark staircase, and softly descended\r\nnearer to the floor outside the outer door of the chambers. The doors\r\nof the rooms within, appeared to be standing open. There were rays of\r\ncandlelight from one of them, and there was the sound of a footstep\r\ngoing about. There were two voices. The words they uttered were not\r\ndistinguishable, but they were both the voices of men. In a few moments\r\nthe voices were silent, and there was no sound of footstep, and the\r\ninner light went out. If Lightwood could have seen the face which kept\r\nhim awake, staring and listening in the darkness outside the door as\r\nhe spoke of it, he might have been less disposed to sleep, through the\r\nremainder of the night.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not there,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bradley; \xe2\x80\x98but she might have been.\xe2\x80\x99 The head arose to\r\nits former height from the ground, floated down the stair-case again,\r\nand passed on to the gate. A man was standing there, in parley with the\r\nwatchman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh!\xe2\x80\x99 said the watchman. \xe2\x80\x98Here he is!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPerceiving himself to be the antecedent, Bradley looked from the\r\nwatchman to the man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This man is leaving a letter for Mr Lightwood,\xe2\x80\x99 the watchman explained,\r\nshowing it in his hand; \xe2\x80\x98and I was mentioning that a person had just\r\ngone up to Mr Lightwood\xe2\x80\x99s chambers. It might be the same business\r\nperhaps?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bradley, glancing at the man, who was a stranger to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 the man assented in a surly way; \xe2\x80\x98my letter--it\xe2\x80\x99s wrote by my\r\ndaughter, but it\xe2\x80\x99s mine--is about my business, and my business ain\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nnobody else\xe2\x80\x99s business.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs Bradley passed out at the gate with an undecided foot, he heard it\r\nshut behind him, and heard the footstep of the man coming after him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x99Scuse me,\xe2\x80\x99 said the man, who appeared to have been drinking and rather\r\nstumbled at him than touched him, to attract his attention: \xe2\x80\x98but might\r\nyou be acquainted with the T\xe2\x80\x99other Governor?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98With whom?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Bradley.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98With,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the man, pointing backward over his right shoulder with\r\nhis right thumb, \xe2\x80\x98the T\xe2\x80\x99other Governor?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what you mean.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why look here,\xe2\x80\x99 hooking his proposition on his left-hand fingers with\r\nthe forefinger of his right. \xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s two Governors, ain\xe2\x80\x99t there? One\r\nand one, two--Lawyer Lightwood, my first finger, he\xe2\x80\x99s one, ain\xe2\x80\x99t he?\r\nWell; might you be acquainted with my middle finger, the T\xe2\x80\x99other?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know quite as much of him,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bradley, with a frown and a distant\r\nlook before him, \xe2\x80\x98as I want to know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hooroar!\xe2\x80\x99 cried the man. \xe2\x80\x98Hooroar T\xe2\x80\x99other t\xe2\x80\x99other Governor. Hooroar\r\nT\xe2\x80\x99otherest Governor! I am of your way of thinkin\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t make such a noise at this dead hour of the night. What are you\r\ntalking about?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Look here, T\xe2\x80\x99otherest Governor,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the man, becoming hoarsely\r\nconfidential. \xe2\x80\x98The T\xe2\x80\x99other Governor he\xe2\x80\x99s always joked his jokes agin me,\r\nowing, as I believe, to my being a honest man as gets my living by the\r\nsweat of my brow. Which he ain\xe2\x80\x99t, and he don\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What is that to me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98T\xe2\x80\x99otherest Governor,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the man in a tone of injured innocence,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98if you don\xe2\x80\x99t care to hear no more, don\xe2\x80\x99t hear no more. You begun it.\r\nYou said, and likeways showed pretty plain, as you warn\xe2\x80\x99t by no means\r\nfriendly to him. But I don\xe2\x80\x99t seek to force my company nor yet my\r\nopinions on no man. I am a honest man, that\xe2\x80\x99s what I am. Put me in the\r\ndock anywhere--I don\xe2\x80\x99t care where--and I says, \xe2\x80\x9cMy Lord, I am a honest\r\nman.\xe2\x80\x9d Put me in the witness-box anywhere--I don\xe2\x80\x99t care where--and I\r\nsays the same to his lordship, and I kisses the book. I don\xe2\x80\x99t kiss my\r\ncoat-cuff; I kisses the book.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt was not so much in deference to these strong testimonials to\r\ncharacter, as in his restless casting about for any way or help towards\r\nthe discovery on which he was concentrated, that Bradley Headstone\r\nreplied: \xe2\x80\x98You needn\xe2\x80\x99t take offence. I didn\xe2\x80\x99t mean to stop you. You were\r\ntoo--loud in the open street; that was all.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x99Totherest Governor,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr Riderhood, mollified and mysterious,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know wot it is to be loud, and I know wot it is to be soft. Nat\xe2\x80\x99rally\r\nI do. It would be a wonder if I did not, being by the Chris\xe2\x80\x99en name of\r\nRoger, which took it arter my own father, which took it from his own\r\nfather, though which of our fam\xe2\x80\x99ly fust took it nat\xe2\x80\x99ral I will not in\r\nany ways mislead you by undertakin\xe2\x80\x99 to say. And wishing that your elth\r\nmay be better than your looks, which your inside must be bad indeed if\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s on the footing of your out.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nStartled by the implication that his face revealed too much of his mind,\r\nBradley made an effort to clear his brow. It might be worth knowing what\r\nthis strange man\xe2\x80\x99s business was with Lightwood, or Wrayburn, or both, at\r\nsuch an unseasonable hour. He set himself to find out, for the man might\r\nprove to be a messenger between those two.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You call at the Temple late,\xe2\x80\x99 he remarked, with a lumbering show of\r\nease.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wish I may die,\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mr Riderhood, with a hoarse laugh, \xe2\x80\x98if I warn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\na goin\xe2\x80\x99 to say the self-same words to you, T\xe2\x80\x99otherest Governor!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It chanced so with me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bradley, looking disconcertedly about him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And it chanced so with me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Riderhood. \xe2\x80\x98But I don\xe2\x80\x99t mind telling\r\nyou how. Why should I mind telling you? I\xe2\x80\x99m a Deputy Lock-keeper up the\r\nriver, and I was off duty yes\xe2\x80\x99day, and I shall be on to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, and I come to London to look arter my private affairs. My private\r\naffairs is to get appinted to the Lock as reg\xe2\x80\x99lar keeper at fust hand,\r\nand to have the law of a busted B\xe2\x80\x99low-Bridge steamer which drownded of\r\nme. I ain\xe2\x80\x99t a goin\xe2\x80\x99 to be drownded and not paid for it!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBradley looked at him, as though he were claiming to be a Ghost.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The steamer,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Riderhood, obstinately, \xe2\x80\x98run me down and drownded\r\nof me. Interference on the part of other parties brought me round; but\r\nI never asked \xe2\x80\x98em to bring me round, nor yet the steamer never asked \xe2\x80\x98em\r\nto it. I mean to be paid for the life as the steamer took.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Was that your business at Mr Lightwood\xe2\x80\x99s chambers in the middle of the\r\nnight?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Bradley, eyeing him with distrust.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That and to get a writing to be fust-hand Lock Keeper. A recommendation\r\nin writing being looked for, who else ought to give it to me? As I says\r\nin the letter in my daughter\xe2\x80\x99s hand, with my mark put to it to make it\r\ngood in law, Who but you, Lawyer Lightwood, ought to hand over this here\r\nstifficate, and who but you ought to go in for damages on my account\r\nagin the Steamer? For (as I says under my mark) I have had trouble\r\nenough along of you and your friend. If you, Lawyer Lightwood, had\r\nbacked me good and true, and if the T\xe2\x80\x99other Governor had took me down\r\ncorrect (I says under my mark), I should have been worth money at the\r\npresent time, instead of having a barge-load of bad names chucked at me,\r\nand being forced to eat my words, which is a unsatisfying sort of food\r\nwotever a man\xe2\x80\x99s appetite! And when you mention the middle of the night,\r\nT\xe2\x80\x99otherest Governor,\xe2\x80\x99 growled Mr Riderhood, winding up his monotonous\r\nsummary of his wrongs, \xe2\x80\x98throw your eye on this here bundle under my arm,\r\nand bear in mind that I\xe2\x80\x99m a walking back to my Lock, and that the Temple\r\nlaid upon my line of road.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBradley Headstone\xe2\x80\x99s face had changed during this latter recital, and he\r\nhad observed the speaker with a more sustained attention.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you know,\xe2\x80\x99 said he, after a pause, during which they walked on side\r\nby side, \xe2\x80\x98that I believe I could tell you your name, if I tried?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Prove your opinion,\xe2\x80\x99 was the answer, accompanied with a stop and a\r\nstare. \xe2\x80\x98Try.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your name is Riderhood.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m blest if it ain\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99 returned that gentleman. \xe2\x80\x98But I don\xe2\x80\x99t know\r\nyour\xe2\x80\x99n.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s quite another thing,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bradley. \xe2\x80\x98I never supposed you did.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs Bradley walked on meditating, the Rogue walked on at his side\r\nmuttering. The purport of the muttering was: \xe2\x80\x98that Rogue Riderhood, by\r\nGeorge! seemed to be made public property on, now, and that every man\r\nseemed to think himself free to handle his name as if it was a Street\r\nPump.\xe2\x80\x99 The purport of the meditating was: \xe2\x80\x98Here is an instrument. Can I\r\nuse it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey had walked along the Strand, and into Pall Mall, and had turned\r\nup-hill towards Hyde Park Corner; Bradley Headstone waiting on the pace\r\nand lead of Riderhood, and leaving him to indicate the course. So slow\r\nwere the schoolmaster\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts, and so indistinct his purposes when\r\nthey were but tributary to the one absorbing purpose or rather when,\r\nlike dark trees under a stormy sky, they only lined the long vista at\r\nthe end of which he saw those two figures of Wrayburn and Lizzie on\r\nwhich his eyes were fixed--that at least a good half-mile was traversed\r\nbefore he spoke again. Even then, it was only to ask:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where is your Lock?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Twenty mile and odd--call it five-and-twenty mile and odd, if you\r\nlike--up stream,\xe2\x80\x99 was the sullen reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How is it called?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Plashwater Weir Mill Lock.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Suppose I was to offer you five shillings; what then?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, then, I\xe2\x80\x99d take it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Riderhood.\r\n\r\nThe schoolmaster put his hand in his pocket, and produced two\r\nhalf-crowns, and placed them in Mr Riderhood\xe2\x80\x99s palm: who stopped at\r\na convenient doorstep to ring them both, before acknowledging their\r\nreceipt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s one thing about you, T\xe2\x80\x99otherest Governor,\xe2\x80\x99 said Riderhood,\r\nfaring on again, \xe2\x80\x98as looks well and goes fur. You\xe2\x80\x99re a ready money man.\r\nNow;\xe2\x80\x99 when he had carefully pocketed the coins on that side of himself\r\nwhich was furthest from his new friend; \xe2\x80\x98what\xe2\x80\x99s this for?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98For you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, o\xe2\x80\x99 course I know THAT,\xe2\x80\x99 said Riderhood, as arguing something that\r\nwas self-evident. \xe2\x80\x98O\xe2\x80\x99 course I know very well as no man in his right\r\nsenses would suppose as anythink would make me give it up agin when I\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nonce got it. But what do you want for it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know that I want anything for it. Or if I do want anything\r\nfor it, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what it is.\xe2\x80\x99 Bradley gave this answer in a stolid,\r\nvacant, and self-communing manner, which Mr Riderhood found very\r\nextraordinary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have no goodwill towards this Wrayburn,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bradley, coming to\r\nthe name in a reluctant and forced way, as if he were dragged to it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Neither have I.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nRiderhood nodded, and asked: \xe2\x80\x98Is it for that?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s as much for that as anything else. It\xe2\x80\x99s something to be agreed\r\nwith, on a subject that occupies so much of one\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It don\xe2\x80\x99t agree with YOU,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mr Riderhood, bluntly. \xe2\x80\x98No! It\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t, T\xe2\x80\x99otherest Governor, and it\xe2\x80\x99s no use a lookin\xe2\x80\x99 as if you wanted\r\nto make out that it did. I tell you it rankles in you. It rankles in\r\nyou, rusts in you, and pisons you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Say that it does so,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Bradley with quivering lips; \xe2\x80\x98is there\r\nno cause for it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Cause enough, I\xe2\x80\x99ll bet a pound!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mr Riderhood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Haven\xe2\x80\x99t you yourself declared that the fellow has heaped provocations,\r\ninsults, and affronts on you, or something to that effect? He has done\r\nthe same by me. He is made of venomous insults and affronts, from the\r\ncrown of his head to the sole of his foot. Are you so hopeful or so\r\nstupid, as not to know that he and the other will treat your application\r\nwith contempt, and light their cigars with it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t wonder if they did, by George!\xe2\x80\x99 said Riderhood, turning\r\nangry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If they did! They will. Let me ask you a question. I know something\r\nmore than your name about you; I knew something about Gaffer Hexam. When\r\ndid you last set eyes upon his daughter?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When did I last set eyes upon his daughter, T\xe2\x80\x99otherest Governor?\xe2\x80\x99\r\nrepeated Mr Riderhood, growing intentionally slower of comprehension as\r\nthe other quickened in his speech.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. Not to speak to her. To see her--anywhere?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe Rogue had got the clue he wanted, though he held it with a clumsy\r\nhand. Looking perplexedly at the passionate face, as if he were trying\r\nto work out a sum in his mind, he slowly answered:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I ain\xe2\x80\x99t set eyes upon her--never once--not since the day of Gaffer\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndeath.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You know her well, by sight?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should think I did! No one better.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And you know him as well?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who\xe2\x80\x99s him?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Riderhood, taking off his hat and rubbing his\r\nforehead, as he directed a dull look at his questioner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Curse the name! Is it so agreeable to you that you want to hear it\r\nagain?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh! HIM!\xe2\x80\x99 said Riderhood, who had craftily worked the schoolmaster into\r\nthis corner, that he might again take note of his face under its evil\r\npossession. \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99d know HIM among a thousand.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did you--\xe2\x80\x99 Bradley tried to ask it quietly; but, do what he might\r\nwith his voice, he could not subdue his face;--\xe2\x80\x98did you ever see them\r\ntogether?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n(The Rogue had got the clue in both hands now.)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I see \xe2\x80\x98em together, T\xe2\x80\x99otherest Governor, on the very day when Gaffer\r\nwas towed ashore.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBradley could have hidden a reserved piece of information from the sharp\r\neyes of a whole inquisitive class, but he could not veil from the eyes\r\nof the ignorant Riderhood the withheld question next in his breast.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You shall put it plain if you want it answered,\xe2\x80\x99 thought the Rogue,\r\ndoggedly; \xe2\x80\x98I ain\xe2\x80\x99t a-going a wolunteering.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well! was he insolent to her too?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Bradley after a struggle. \xe2\x80\x98Or\r\ndid he make a show of being kind to her?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He made a show of being most uncommon kind to her,\xe2\x80\x99 said Riderhood. \xe2\x80\x98By\r\nGeorge! now I--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHis flying off at a tangent was indisputably natural. Bradley looked at\r\nhim for the reason.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now I think of it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Riderhood, evasively, for he was\r\nsubstituting those words for \xe2\x80\x98Now I see you so jealous,\xe2\x80\x99 which was the\r\nphrase really in his mind; \xe2\x80\x98P\xe2\x80\x99r\xe2\x80\x99aps he went and took me down wrong, a\r\npurpose, on account o\xe2\x80\x99 being sweet upon her!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe baseness of confirming him in this suspicion or pretence of one (for\r\nhe could not have really entertained it), was a line\xe2\x80\x99s breadth beyond\r\nthe mark the schoolmaster had reached. The baseness of communing and\r\nintriguing with the fellow who would have set that stain upon her, and\r\nupon her brother too, was attained. The line\xe2\x80\x99s breadth further, lay\r\nbeyond. He made no reply, but walked on with a lowering face.\r\n\r\nWhat he might gain by this acquaintance, he could not work out in his\r\nslow and cumbrous thoughts. The man had an injury against the object of\r\nhis hatred, and that was something; though it was less than he supposed,\r\nfor there dwelt in the man no such deadly rage and resentment as burned\r\nin his own breast. The man knew her, and might by a fortunate chance see\r\nher, or hear of her; that was something, as enlisting one pair of eyes\r\nand ears the more. The man was a bad man, and willing enough to be in\r\nhis pay. That was something, for his own state and purpose were as\r\nbad as bad could be, and he seemed to derive a vague support from the\r\npossession of a congenial instrument, though it might never be used.\r\n\r\nSuddenly he stood still, and asked Riderhood point-blank if he knew\r\nwhere she was? Clearly, he did not know. He asked Riderhood if he would\r\nbe willing, in case any intelligence of her, or of Wrayburn as seeking\r\nher or associating with her, should fall in his way, to communicate it\r\nif it were paid for? He would be very willing indeed. He was \xe2\x80\x98agin \xe2\x80\x98em\r\nboth,\xe2\x80\x99 he said with an oath, and for why? \xe2\x80\x98Cause they had both stood\r\nbetwixt him and his getting his living by the sweat of his brow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It will not be long then,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bradley Headstone, after some more\r\ndiscourse to this effect, \xe2\x80\x98before we see one another again. Here is the\r\ncountry road, and here is the day. Both have come upon me by surprise.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But, T\xe2\x80\x99otherest Governor,\xe2\x80\x99 urged Mr Riderhood, \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know where to\r\nfind you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is of no consequence. I know where to find you, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll come to\r\nyour Lock.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But, T\xe2\x80\x99otherest Governor,\xe2\x80\x99 urged Mr Riderhood again, \xe2\x80\x98no luck never\r\ncome yet of a dry acquaintance. Let\xe2\x80\x99s wet it, in a mouth-fill of rum and\r\nmilk, T\xe2\x80\x99otherest Governor.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBradley assenting, went with him into an early public-house, haunted by\r\nunsavoury smells of musty hay and stale straw, where returning carts,\r\nfarmers\xe2\x80\x99 men, gaunt dogs, fowls of a beery breed, and certain human\r\nnightbirds fluttering home to roost, were solacing themselves after\r\ntheir several manners; and where not one of the nightbirds hovering\r\nabout the sloppy bar failed to discern at a glance in the passion-wasted\r\nnightbird with respectable feathers, the worst nightbird of all.\r\n\r\nAn inspiration of affection for a half-drunken carter going his way led\r\nto Mr Riderhood\xe2\x80\x99s being elevated on a high heap of baskets on a waggon,\r\nand pursuing his journey recumbent on his back with his head on his\r\nbundle. Bradley then turned to retrace his steps, and by-and-by struck\r\noff through little-traversed ways, and by-and-by reached school and\r\nhome. Up came the sun to find him washed and brushed, methodically\r\ndressed in decent black coat and waistcoat, decent formal black tie, and\r\npepper-and-salt pantaloons, with his decent silver watch in its pocket,\r\nand its decent hair-guard round his neck: a scholastic huntsman clad for\r\nthe field, with his fresh pack yelping and barking around him.\r\n\r\nYet more really bewitched than the miserable creatures of the\r\nmuch-lamented times, who accused themselves of impossibilities under a\r\ncontagion of horror and the strongly suggestive influences of Torture,\r\nhe had been ridden hard by Evil Spirits in the night that was newly\r\ngone. He had been spurred and whipped and heavily sweated. If a record\r\nof the sport had usurped the places of the peaceful texts from Scripture\r\non the wall, the most advanced of the scholars might have taken fright\r\nand run away from the master.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 12\r\n\r\nMEANING MISCHIEF\r\n\r\n\r\nUp came the sun, streaming all over London, and in its glorious\r\nimpartiality even condescending to make prismatic sparkles in the\r\nwhiskers of Mr Alfred Lammle as he sat at breakfast. In need of some\r\nbrightening from without, was Mr Alfred Lammle, for he had the air of\r\nbeing dull enough within, and looked grievously discontented.\r\n\r\nMrs Alfred Lammle faced her lord. The happy pair of swindlers, with\r\nthe comfortable tie between them that each had swindled the other, sat\r\nmoodily observant of the tablecloth. Things looked so gloomy in the\r\nbreakfast-room, albeit on the sunny side of Sackville Street, that any\r\nof the family tradespeople glancing through the blinds might have taken\r\nthe hint to send in his account and press for it. But this, indeed, most\r\nof the family tradespeople had already done, without the hint.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It seems to me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Lammle, \xe2\x80\x98that you have had no money at all,\r\never since we have been married.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What seems to you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Lammle, \xe2\x80\x98to have been the case, may\r\npossibly have been the case. It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t matter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWas it the speciality of Mr and Mrs Lammle, or does it ever obtain\r\nwith other loving couples? In these matrimonial dialogues they never\r\naddressed each other, but always some invisible presence that appeared\r\nto take a station about midway between them. Perhaps the skeleton in the\r\ncupboard comes out to be talked to, on such domestic occasions?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have never seen any money in the house,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Lammle to the\r\nskeleton, \xe2\x80\x98except my own annuity. That I swear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You needn\xe2\x80\x99t take the trouble of swearing,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Lammle to the\r\nskeleton; \xe2\x80\x98once more, it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t matter. You never turned your annuity\r\nto so good an account.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good an account! In what way?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mrs Lammle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In the way of getting credit, and living well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Lammle. Perhaps\r\nthe skeleton laughed scornfully on being intrusted with this question\r\nand this answer; certainly Mrs Lammle did, and Mr Lammle did.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And what is to happen next?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mrs Lammle of the skeleton.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Smash is to happen next,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Lammle to the same authority.\r\n\r\nAfter this, Mrs Lammle looked disdainfully at the skeleton--but without\r\ncarrying the look on to Mr Lammle--and drooped her eyes. After that, Mr\r\nLammle did exactly the same thing, and drooped HIS eyes. A servant then\r\nentering with toast, the skeleton retired into the closet, and shut\r\nitself up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sophronia,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Lammle, when the servant had withdrawn. And then,\r\nvery much louder: \xe2\x80\x98Sophronia!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Attend to me, if you please.\xe2\x80\x99 He eyed her sternly until she did attend,\r\nand then went on. \xe2\x80\x98I want to take counsel with you. Come, come; no more\r\ntrifling. You know our league and covenant. We are to work together for\r\nour joint interest, and you are as knowing a hand as I am. We shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nbe together, if you were not. What\xe2\x80\x99s to be done? We are hemmed into a\r\ncorner. What shall we do?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have you no scheme on foot that will bring in anything?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Lammle plunged into his whiskers for reflection, and came out\r\nhopeless: \xe2\x80\x98No; as adventurers we are obliged to play rash games for\r\nchances of high winnings, and there has been a run of luck against us.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe was resuming, \xe2\x80\x98Have you nothing--\xe2\x80\x99 when he stopped her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We, Sophronia. We, we, we.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have we nothing to sell?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Deuce a bit. I have given a Jew a bill of sale on this furniture, and\r\nhe could take it to-morrow, to-day, now. He would have taken it before\r\nnow, I believe, but for Fledgeby.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What has Fledgeby to do with him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Knew him. Cautioned me against him before I got into his claws.\r\nCouldn\xe2\x80\x99t persuade him then, in behalf of somebody else.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you mean that Fledgeby has at all softened him towards you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Us, Sophronia. Us, us, us.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Towards us?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I mean that the Jew has not yet done what he might have done, and that\r\nFledgeby takes the credit of having got him to hold his hand.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you believe Fledgeby?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sophronia, I never believe anybody. I never have, my dear, since I\r\nbelieved you. But it looks like it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHaving given her this back-handed reminder of her mutinous observations\r\nto the skeleton, Mr Lammle rose from table--perhaps, the better to\r\nconceal a smile, and a white dint or two about his nose--and took a turn\r\non the carpet and came to the hearthrug.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If we could have packed the brute off with Georgiana;--but however;\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s spilled milk.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs Lammle, standing gathering up the skirts of his dressing-gown with\r\nhis back to the fire, said this, looking down at his wife, she turned\r\npale and looked down at the ground. With a sense of disloyalty upon\r\nher, and perhaps with a sense of personal danger--for she was afraid of\r\nhim--even afraid of his hand and afraid of his foot, though he had never\r\ndone her violence--she hastened to put herself right in his eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If we could borrow money, Alfred--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Beg money, borrow money, or steal money. It would be all one to us,\r\nSophronia,\xe2\x80\x99 her husband struck in.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98--Then, we could weather this?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No doubt. To offer another original and undeniable remark, Sophronia,\r\ntwo and two make four.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBut, seeing that she was turning something in her mind, he gathered up\r\nthe skirts of his dressing-gown again, and, tucking them under one arm,\r\nand collecting his ample whiskers in his other hand, kept his eye upon\r\nher, silently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is natural, Alfred,\xe2\x80\x99 she said, looking up with some timidity into\r\nhis face, \xe2\x80\x98to think in such an emergency of the richest people we know,\r\nand the simplest.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Just so, Sophronia.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The Boffins.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Just so, Sophronia.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is there nothing to be done with them?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What is there to be done with them, Sophronia?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe cast about in her thoughts again, and he kept his eye upon her as\r\nbefore.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course I have repeatedly thought of the Boffins, Sophronia,\xe2\x80\x99 he\r\nresumed, after a fruitless silence; \xe2\x80\x98but I have seen my way to nothing.\r\nThey are well guarded. That infernal Secretary stands between them\r\nand--people of merit.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If he could be got rid of?\xe2\x80\x99 said she, brightening a little, after more\r\ncasting about.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Take time, Sophronia,\xe2\x80\x99 observed her watchful husband, in a patronizing\r\nmanner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If working him out of the way could be presented in the light of a\r\nservice to Mr Boffin?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Take time, Sophronia.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We have remarked lately, Alfred, that the old man is turning very\r\nsuspicious and distrustful.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Miserly too, my dear; which is far the most unpromising for us.\r\nNevertheless, take time, Sophronia, take time.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe took time and then said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Suppose we should address ourselves to that tendency in him of which we\r\nhave made ourselves quite sure. Suppose my conscience--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And we know what a conscience it is, my soul. Yes?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Suppose my conscience should not allow me to keep to myself any\r\nlonger what that upstart girl told me of the Secretary\xe2\x80\x99s having made a\r\ndeclaration to her. Suppose my conscience should oblige me to repeat it\r\nto Mr Boffin.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I rather like that,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lammle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Suppose I so repeated it to Mr Boffin, as to insinuate that my\r\nsensitive delicacy and honour--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very good words, Sophronia.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98--As to insinuate that OUR sensitive delicacy and honour,\xe2\x80\x99 she resumed,\r\nwith a bitter stress upon the phrase, \xe2\x80\x98would not allow us to be silent\r\nparties to so mercenary and designing a speculation on the Secretary\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npart, and so gross a breach of faith towards his confiding employer.\r\nSuppose I had imparted my virtuous uneasiness to my excellent husband,\r\nand he had said, in his integrity, \xe2\x80\x9cSophronia, you must immediately\r\ndisclose this to Mr Boffin.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Once more, Sophronia,\xe2\x80\x99 observed Lammle, changing the leg on which he\r\nstood, \xe2\x80\x98I rather like that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You remark that he is well guarded,\xe2\x80\x99 she pursued. \xe2\x80\x98I think so too. But\r\nif this should lead to his discharging his Secretary, there would be a\r\nweak place made.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Go on expounding, Sophronia. I begin to like this very much.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Having, in our unimpeachable rectitude, done him the service of opening\r\nhis eyes to the treachery of the person he trusted, we shall have\r\nestablished a claim upon him and a confidence with him. Whether it\r\ncan be made much of, or little of, we must wait--because we can\xe2\x80\x99t help\r\nit--to see. Probably we shall make the most of it that is to be made.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Probably,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lammle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you think it impossible,\xe2\x80\x99 she asked, in the same cold plotting way,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98that you might replace the Secretary?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not impossible, Sophronia. It might be brought about. At any rate it\r\nmight be skilfully led up to.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe nodded her understanding of the hint, as she looked at the fire. \xe2\x80\x98Mr\r\nLammle,\xe2\x80\x99 she said, musingly: not without a slight ironical touch: \xe2\x80\x98Mr\r\nLammle would be so delighted to do anything in his power. Mr Lammle,\r\nhimself a man of business as well as a capitalist. Mr Lammle, accustomed\r\nto be intrusted with the most delicate affairs. Mr Lammle, who has\r\nmanaged my own little fortune so admirably, but who, to be sure, began\r\nto make his reputation with the advantage of being a man of property,\r\nabove temptation, and beyond suspicion.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Lammle smiled, and even patted her on the head. In his sinister\r\nrelish of the scheme, as he stood above her, making it the subject of\r\nhis cogitations, he seemed to have twice as much nose on his face as he\r\nhad ever had in his life.\r\n\r\nHe stood pondering, and she sat looking at the dusty fire without\r\nmoving, for some time. But, the moment he began to speak again she\r\nlooked up with a wince and attended to him, as if that double-dealing of\r\nhers had been in her mind, and the fear were revived in her of his hand\r\nor his foot.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It appears to me, Sophronia, that you have omitted one branch of the\r\nsubject. Perhaps not, for women understand women. We might oust the girl\r\nherself?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs Lammle shook her head. \xe2\x80\x98She has an immensely strong hold upon them\r\nboth, Alfred. Not to be compared with that of a paid secretary.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But the dear child,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lammle, with a crooked smile, \xe2\x80\x98ought to have\r\nbeen open with her benefactor and benefactress. The darling love\r\nought to have reposed unbounded confidence in her benefactor and\r\nbenefactress.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSophronia shook her head again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well! Women understand women,\xe2\x80\x99 said her husband, rather disappointed.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t press it. It might be the making of our fortune to make a\r\nclean sweep of them both. With me to manage the property, and my wife to\r\nmanage the people--Whew!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAgain shaking her head, she returned: \xe2\x80\x98They will never quarrel with the\r\ngirl. They will never punish the girl. We must accept the girl, rely\r\nupon it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Lammle, shrugging his shoulders, \xe2\x80\x98so be it: only always\r\nremember that we don\xe2\x80\x99t want her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, the sole remaining question is,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Lammle, \xe2\x80\x98when shall I\r\nbegin?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You cannot begin too soon, Sophronia. As I have told you, the condition\r\nof our affairs is desperate, and may be blown upon at any moment.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I must secure Mr Boffin alone, Alfred. If his wife was present, she\r\nwould throw oil upon the waters. I know I should fail to move him to an\r\nangry outburst, if his wife was there. And as to the girl herself--as I\r\nam going to betray her confidence, she is equally out of the question.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t do to write for an appointment?\xe2\x80\x99 said Lammle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, certainly not. They would wonder among themselves why I wrote, and\r\nI want to have him wholly unprepared.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Call, and ask to see him alone?\xe2\x80\x99 suggested Lammle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I would rather not do that either. Leave it to me. Spare me the little\r\ncarriage for to-day, and for to-morrow (if I don\xe2\x80\x99t succeed to-day), and\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll lie in wait for him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt was barely settled when a manly form was seen to pass the windows\r\nand heard to knock and ring. \xe2\x80\x98Here\xe2\x80\x99s Fledgeby,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lammle. \xe2\x80\x98He admires\r\nyou, and has a high opinion of you. I\xe2\x80\x99ll be out. Coax him to use his\r\ninfluence with the Jew. His name is Riah, of the House of Pubsey and\r\nCo.\xe2\x80\x99 Adding these words under his breath, lest he should be audible\r\nin the erect ears of Mr Fledgeby, through two keyholes and the hall,\r\nLammle, making signals of discretion to his servant, went softly up\r\nstairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Fledgeby,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Lammle, giving him a very gracious reception,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98so glad to see you! My poor dear Alfred, who is greatly worried just\r\nnow about his affairs, went out rather early. Dear Mr Fledgeby, do sit\r\ndown.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDear Mr Fledgeby did sit down, and satisfied himself (or, judging from\r\nthe expression of his countenance, DISsatisfied himself) that nothing\r\nnew had occurred in the way of whisker-sprout since he came round the\r\ncorner from the Albany.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dear Mr Fledgeby, it was needless to mention to you that my poor dear\r\nAlfred is much worried about his affairs at present, for he has told me\r\nwhat a comfort you are to him in his temporary difficulties, and what a\r\ngreat service you have rendered him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Fledgeby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Lammle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Mr Fledgeby, trying a new part of his chair,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98but that Lammle might be reserved about his affairs.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not to me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Lammle, with deep feeling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, indeed?\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not to me, dear Mr Fledgeby. Pubsey\r\nand Co.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh yes!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mrs Lammle, clasping her hands with a certain\r\ngushing wildness. \xe2\x80\x98Pubsey and Co.!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The pleading of the feminine--\xe2\x80\x99 Mr Fledgeby began, and there stuck so\r\nlong for a word to get on with, that Mrs Lammle offered him sweetly,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Heart?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Fledgeby, \xe2\x80\x98Gender--is ever what a man is bound to listen\r\nto, and I wish it rested with myself. They might have taken up their station\r\nin his breast, too, for he was blithe and merry. There was quite a fresh\r\ntrill in his voice, when, arriving at the counting-house in St Mary Axe,\r\nand finding it for the moment empty, he trolled forth at the foot of the\r\nstaircase: \xe2\x80\x98Now, Judah, what are you up to there?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe old man appeared, with his accustomed deference.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Halloa!\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby, falling back, with a wink. \xe2\x80\x98You mean mischief,\r\nJerusalem!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe old man raised his eyes inquiringly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes you do,\xe2\x80\x99 said Fledgeby. \xe2\x80\x98Oh, you sinner! Toddle, Judah!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 13\r\n\r\nGIVE A DOG A BAD NAME, AND HANG HIM\r\n\r\n\r\nFascination Fledgeby, left alone in the counting-house, strolled about\r\nwith his hat on one side, whistling, and investigating the drawers, and\r\nprying here and there for any small evidences of his being cheated,\r\nbut could find none. \xe2\x80\x98Not his merit that he don\xe2\x80\x99t cheat me,\xe2\x80\x99 was Mr\r\nFledgeby\xe2\x80\x99s commentary delivered with a wink, \xe2\x80\x98but my precaution.\xe2\x80\x99 He\r\nthen with a lazy grandeur asserted his rights as lord of Pubsey and\r\nCo. by poking his cane at the stools and boxes, and spitting in the\r\nfireplace, and so loitered royally to the window and looked out into the\r\nnarrow street, with his small eyes just peering over the top of Pubsey\r\nand Co.\xe2\x80\x99s blind. As a blind in more senses than one, it reminded him\r\nthat he was alone in the counting-house with the front door open. He was\r\nmoving away to shut it, lest he should be injudiciously identified with\r\nthe establishment, when he was stopped by some one coming to the door.\r\n\r\nThis some one was the dolls\xe2\x80\x99 dressmaker, with a little basket on her\r\narm, and her crutch stick in her hand. Her keen eyes had espied Mr\r\nFledgeby before Mr Fledgeby had espied her, and he was paralysed in his\r\npurpose of shutting her out, not so much by her approaching the door, as\r\nby her favouring him with a shower of nods, the instant he saw her. This\r\nadvantage she improved by hobbling up the steps with such despatch that\r\nbefore Mr Fledgeby could take measures for her finding nobody at home,\r\nshe was face to face with him in the counting-house.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hope I see you well, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Wren. \xe2\x80\x98Mr Riah in?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nFledgeby had dropped into a chair, in the attitude of one waiting\r\nwearily. \xe2\x80\x98I suppose he will be back soon,\xe2\x80\x99 he replied; \xe2\x80\x98he has cut\r\nout and left me expecting him back, in an odd way. I\r\nremember. Fledgeby taking no notice, the door was at length softly\r\nopened, and the dried face of a mild little elderly gentleman looked in.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Riah?\xe2\x80\x99 said this visitor, very politely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am waiting for him, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mr Fledgeby. \xe2\x80\x98He went out and left\r\nme here. Perhaps you had better take a\r\nchair.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe gentleman took a chair, and put his hand to his forehead, as if\r\nhe were in a melancholy frame of mind. Then he started,\r\nand said: \xe2\x80\x98I beg your pardon, sir. I fear you spoke to me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I said,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Fledgeby, a little louder than before, \xe2\x80\x98it was a fine\r\nday.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I beg your pardon. Mr Fledgeby sat on a stool with a foot on the rail of another\r\nstool, and his hat on. Mr Twemlow had uncovered on looking in at the\r\ndoor, and remained so. Now the conscientious Twemlow, knowing what he\r\nhad done to thwart the gracious Fledgeby, was particularly disconcerted\r\nby this encounter. He was as ill at ease as a gentleman well could be.\r\nHe felt himself bound to conduct himself stiffly towards Fledgeby,\r\nand he made him a distant bow. Fledgeby made his small eyes smaller\r\nin taking special note of his manner. I have always found him the bitingest and\r\ntightest screw in London.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Twemlow acknowledged the remark with a little distant bow. Sell her her waste,\r\nplease, and give her good measure if you can make up your mind to do the\r\nliberal thing for once.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe looked on for a time, as the Jew filled her little basket with such\r\nscraps as she was used to buy; but, his merry vein coming on again, he\r\nwas obliged to turn round to the window once more, and lean his arms on\r\nthe blind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There, my Cinderella dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said the old man in a whisper, and with a\r\nworn-out look, \xe2\x80\x98the basket\xe2\x80\x99s full now. Bless you! And get you gone!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t call me your Cinderella dear,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Miss Wren. \xe2\x80\x98O you cruel\r\ngodmother!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe shook that emphatic little forefinger of hers in his face at\r\nparting, as earnestly and reproachfully as she had ever shaken it at her\r\ngrim old child at home.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are not the godmother at all!\xe2\x80\x99 said she. \xe2\x80\x98You are the Wolf in\r\nthe Forest, the wicked Wolf! And if ever my dear Lizzie is sold and\r\nbetrayed, I shall know who sold and betrayed her!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 14\r\n\r\nMR WEGG PREPARES A GRINDSTONE FOR MR BOFFIN\xe2\x80\x99S NOSE\r\n\r\n\r\nHaving assisted at a few more expositions of the lives of Misers, Mr\r\nVenus became almost indispensable to the evenings at the Bower. The\r\ncircumstance of having another listener to the wonders unfolded by\r\nWegg, or, as it were, another calculator to cast up the guineas found in\r\nteapots, chimneys, racks and mangers, and other such banks of deposit,\r\nseemed greatly to heighten Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s enjoyment; while Silas Wegg, for\r\nhis part, though of a jealous temperament which might under ordinary\r\ncircumstances have resented the anatomist\xe2\x80\x99s getting into favour, was\r\nso very anxious to keep his eye on that gentleman--lest, being too\r\nmuch left to himself, he should be tempted to play any tricks with the\r\nprecious document in his keeping--that he never lost an opportunity of\r\ncommending him to Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s notice as a third party whose company was\r\nmuch to be desired. Another friendly demonstration towards him Mr Wegg\r\nnow regularly gratified. After each sitting was over, and the patron\r\nhad departed, Mr Wegg invariably saw Mr Venus home. To be sure, he as\r\ninvariably requested to be refreshed with a sight of the paper in which\r\nhe was a joint proprietor; but he never failed to remark that it was the\r\ngreat pleasure he derived from Mr Venus\xe2\x80\x99s improving society which had\r\ninsensibly lured him round to Clerkenwell again, and that, finding\r\nhimself once more attracted to the spot by the social powers of Mr V.,\r\nhe would beg leave to go through that little incidental procedure, as a\r\nmatter of form. \xe2\x80\x98For well I know, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 Mr Wegg would add, \xe2\x80\x98that a\r\nman of your delicate mind would wish to be checked off whenever the\r\nopportunity arises, and it is not for me to baulk your feelings.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nA certain rustiness in Mr Venus, which never became so lubricated by\r\nthe oil of Mr Wegg but that he turned under the screw in a creaking and\r\nstiff manner, was very noticeable at about this period. While assisting\r\nat the literary evenings, he even went so far, on two or three\r\noccasions, as to correct Mr Wegg when he grossly mispronounced a word,\r\nor made nonsense of a passage; insomuch that Mr Wegg took to surveying\r\nhis course in the day, and to making arrangements for getting round\r\nrocks at night instead of running straight upon them. Of the slightest\r\nanatomical reference he became particularly shy, and, if he saw a bone\r\nahead, would go any distance out of his way rather than mention it by\r\nname.\r\n\r\nThe adverse destinies ordained that one evening Mr Wegg\xe2\x80\x99s labouring\r\nbark became beset by polysyllables, and embarrassed among a perfect\r\narchipelago of hard words. It being necessary to take soundings every\r\nminute, and to feel the way with the greatest caution, Mr Wegg\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nattention was fully employed. Advantage was taken of this dilemma by\r\nMr Venus, to pass a scrap of paper into Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s hand, and lay his\r\nfinger on his own lip.\r\n\r\nWhen Mr Boffin got home at night he found that the paper contained Mr\r\nVenus\xe2\x80\x99s card and these words: \xe2\x80\x98Should be glad to be honoured with a call\r\nrespecting business of your own, about dusk on an early evening.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe very next evening saw Mr Boffin peeping in at the preserved frogs\r\nin Mr Venus\xe2\x80\x99s shop-window, and saw Mr Venus espying Mr Boffin with the\r\nreadiness of one on the alert, and beckoning that gentleman into his\r\ninterior. Responding, Mr Boffin was invited to seat himself on the box\r\nof human miscellanies before the fire, and did so, looking round the\r\nplace with admiring eyes. The fire being low and fitful, and the dusk\r\ngloomy, the whole stock seemed to be winking and blinking with both\r\neyes, as Mr Venus did. The French gentleman, though he had no eyes, was\r\nnot at all behind-hand, but appeared, as the flame rose and fell, to\r\nopen and shut his no eyes, with the regularity of the glass-eyed dogs\r\nand ducks and birds. The big-headed babies were equally obliging in\r\nlending their grotesque aid to the general effect.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You see, Mr Venus, I\xe2\x80\x99ve lost no time,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98Here I am.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Here you are, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 assented Mr Venus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t like secrecy,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued Mr Boffin--\xe2\x80\x98at least, not in a general\r\nway I don\xe2\x80\x99t--but I dare say you\xe2\x80\x99ll show me good reason for being secret\r\nso far.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think I shall, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Venus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t expect Wegg, I take it for granted?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, sir. I expect no one but the present company.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Boffin glanced about him, as accepting under that inclusive\r\ndenomination the French gentleman and the circle in which he didn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nmove, and repeated, \xe2\x80\x98The present company.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Venus, \xe2\x80\x98before entering upon business, I shall have to\r\nask you for your word and honour that we are in confidence.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Let\xe2\x80\x99s wait a bit and understand what the expression means,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Mr\r\nBoffin. \xe2\x80\x98In confidence for how long? In confidence for ever and a day?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I take your hint, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus; \xe2\x80\x98you think you might consider the\r\nbusiness, when you came to know it, to be of a nature incompatible with\r\nconfidence on your part?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I might,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin with a cautious look.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98True, sir. Well, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 observed Venus, after clutching at his dusty\r\nhair, to brighten his ideas, \xe2\x80\x98let us put it another way. I open the\r\nbusiness with you, relying upon your honour not to do anything in it,\r\nand not to mention me in it, without my knowledge.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That sounds fair,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98I agree to that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have your word and honour, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My good fellow,\xe2\x80\x99 retorted Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98you have my word; and how you\r\ncan have that, without my honour too, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know. I\xe2\x80\x99ve sorted a lot\r\nof dust in my time, but I never knew the two things go into separate\r\nheaps.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis remark seemed rather to abash Mr Venus. He hesitated, and said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very true, sir;\xe2\x80\x99 and again, \xe2\x80\x98Very true, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 before resuming the\r\nthread of his discourse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Boffin, if I confess to you that I fell into a proposal of which you\r\nwere the subject, and of which you oughtn\xe2\x80\x99t to have been the subject,\r\nyou will allow me to mention, and will please take into favourable\r\nconsideration, that I was in a crushed state of mind at the time.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe Golden Dustman, with his hands folded on the top of his stout\r\nstick, with his chin resting upon them, and with something leering and\r\nwhimsical in his eyes, gave a nod, and said, \xe2\x80\x98Quite so, Venus.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That proposal, sir, was a conspiring breach of your confidence, to\r\nsuch an extent, that I ought at once to have made it known to you. But I\r\ndidn\xe2\x80\x99t, Mr Boffin, and I fell into it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWithout moving eye or finger, Mr Boffin gave another nod, and placidly\r\nrepeated, \xe2\x80\x98Quite so, Venus.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not that I was ever hearty in it, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 the penitent anatomist went\r\non, \xe2\x80\x98or that I ever viewed myself with anything but reproach for having\r\nturned out of the paths of science into the paths of--\xe2\x80\x99 he was going\r\nto say \xe2\x80\x98villany,\xe2\x80\x99 but, unwilling to press too hard upon himself,\r\nsubstituted with great emphasis--\xe2\x80\x98Weggery.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPlacid and whimsical of look as ever, Mr Boffin answered:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Quite so, Venus.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And now, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus, \xe2\x80\x98having prepared your mind in the rough, I\r\nwill articulate the details.\xe2\x80\x99 With which brief professional exordium, he\r\nentered on the history of the friendly move, and truly recounted it. One\r\nmight have thought that it would have extracted some show of surprise or\r\nanger, or other emotion, from Mr Boffin, but it extracted nothing beyond\r\nhis former comment:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Quite so, Venus.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have astonished you, sir, I believe?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Venus, pausing\r\ndubiously.\r\n\r\nMr Boffin simply answered as aforesaid: \xe2\x80\x98Quite so, Venus.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBy this time the astonishment was all on the other side. It did not,\r\nhowever, so continue. For, when Venus passed to Wegg\xe2\x80\x99s discovery, and\r\nfrom that to their having both seen Mr Boffin dig up the Dutch bottle,\r\nthat gentleman changed colour, changed his attitude, became extremely\r\nrestless, and ended (when Venus ended) by being in a state of manifest\r\nanxiety, trepidation, and confusion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus, finishing off; \xe2\x80\x98you best know what was in that\r\nDutch bottle, and why you dug it up, and took it away. I don\xe2\x80\x99t pretend\r\nto know anything more about it than I saw. All I know is this: I am\r\nproud of my calling after all (though it has been attended by one\r\ndreadful drawback which has told upon my heart, and almost equally upon\r\nmy skeleton), and I mean to live by my calling. Putting the same meaning\r\ninto other words, I do not mean to turn a single dishonest penny by this\r\naffair. As the best amends I can make you for having ever gone into it,\r\nI make known to you, as a warning, what Wegg has found out. My opinion\r\nis, that Wegg is not to be silenced at a modest price, and I build that\r\nopinion on his beginning to dispose of your property the moment he knew\r\nhis power. Whether it\xe2\x80\x99s worth your while to silence him at any price,\r\nyou will decide for yourself, and take your measures accordingly. As\r\nfar as I am concerned, I have no price. If I am ever called upon for\r\nthe truth, I tell it, but I want to do no more than I have now done and\r\nended.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank\xe2\x80\x99ee, Venus!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, with a hearty grip of his hand;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98thank\xe2\x80\x99ee, Venus, thank\xe2\x80\x99ee, Venus!\xe2\x80\x99 And then walked up and down the\r\nlittle shop in great agitation. \xe2\x80\x98But look here, Venus,\xe2\x80\x99 he by-and-by\r\nresumed, nervously sitting down again; \xe2\x80\x98if I have to buy Wegg up, I\r\nshan\xe2\x80\x99t buy him any cheaper for your being out of it. Instead of his\r\nhaving half the money--it was to have been half, I suppose? Share and\r\nshare alike?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was to have been half, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Venus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Instead of that, he\xe2\x80\x99ll now have all. I shall pay the same, if not more.\r\nFor you tell me he\xe2\x80\x99s an unconscionable dog, a ravenous rascal.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He is,\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you think, Venus,\xe2\x80\x99 insinuated Mr Boffin, after looking at the\r\nfire for a while--\xe2\x80\x98don\xe2\x80\x99t you feel as if--you might like to pretend to be\r\nin it till Wegg was bought up, and then ease your mind by handing over\r\nto me what you had made believe to pocket?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No I don\xe2\x80\x99t, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Venus, very positively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not to make amends?\xe2\x80\x99 insinuated Mr Boffin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, sir. Dusty Boffin. That foxey old grunter and grinder, sir, turns\r\ninto the yard this morning, to meddle with our property, a menial tool\r\nof his own, a young man by the name of Sloppy. Ecod, when I say to him,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want here, young man? Give him an inch, and he\xe2\x80\x99ll take an ell. Let him\r\nalone this time, and what\xe2\x80\x99ll he do with our property next? I tell you\r\nwhat, Mr Venus; it comes to this; I must be overbearing with Boffin, or\r\nI shall fly into several pieces. I can\xe2\x80\x99t contain myself when I look\r\nat him.
