A wooden\r\nleg can\xe2\x80\x99t bear it!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But, Mr Wegg,\xe2\x80\x99 urged Venus, \xe2\x80\x98it was your own idea that he should not be\r\nexploded upon, till the Mounds were carted away.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But it was likewise my idea, Mr Venus,\xe2\x80\x99 retorted Wegg, \xe2\x80\x98that if he came\r\nsneaking and sniffing about the property, he should be threatened, given\r\nto understand that he has no right to it, and be made our slave. Wasn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nthat my idea, Mr Venus?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It certainly was, Mr Wegg.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It certainly was, as you say, partner,\xe2\x80\x99 assented Wegg, put into\r\na better humour by the ready admission. \xe2\x80\x98Very well. I consider his\r\nplanting one of his menial tools in the yard, an act of sneaking and\r\nsniffing. And his nose shall be put to the grindstone for it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was not your fault, Mr Wegg, I must admit,\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus, \xe2\x80\x98that he got\r\noff with the Dutch bottle that night.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As you handsomely say again, partner! No, it was not my fault. I\xe2\x80\x99d have\r\nhad that bottle out of him. Was it to be borne that he should come, like\r\na thief in the dark, digging among stuff that was far more ours than his\r\n(seeing that we could deprive him of every grain of it, if he didn\xe2\x80\x99t buy\r\nus at our own figure), and carrying off treasure from its bowels? No,\r\nit was not to be borne. And for that, too, his nose shall be put to the\r\ngrindstone.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How do you propose to do it, Mr Wegg?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To put his nose to the grindstone? I propose,\xe2\x80\x99 returned that estimable\r\nman, \xe2\x80\x98to insult him openly. And, if looking into this eye of mine, he\r\ndares to offer a word in answer, to retort upon him before he can take\r\nhis breath, \xe2\x80\x9cAdd another word to that, you dusty old dog, and you\xe2\x80\x99re a\r\nbeggar.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Suppose he says nothing, Mr Wegg?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Wegg, \xe2\x80\x98we shall have come to an understanding with very\r\nlittle trouble, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll break him and drive him, Mr Venus. I\xe2\x80\x99ll put\r\nhim in harness, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll bear him up tight, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll break him and drive\r\nhim. The harder the old Dust is driven, sir, the higher he\xe2\x80\x99ll pay. And I\r\nmean to be paid high, Mr Venus, I promise you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You speak quite revengefully, Mr Wegg.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Revengefully, sir? Is it for him that I have declined and falled,\r\nnight after night? Is it for his pleasure that I\xe2\x80\x99ve waited at home of an\r\nevening, like a set of skittles, to be set up and knocked over, set up\r\nand knocked over, by whatever balls--or books--he chose to bring against\r\nme? Why, I\xe2\x80\x99m a hundred times the man he is, sir; five hundred times!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPerhaps it was with the malicious intent of urging him on to his worst\r\nthat Mr Venus looked as if he doubted that.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What? Was it outside the house at present ockypied, to its disgrace,\r\nby that minion of fortune and worm of the hour,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg, falling back\r\nupon his strongest terms of reprobation, and slapping the counter,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98that I, Silas Wegg, five hundred times the man he ever was, sat in all\r\nweathers, waiting for a errand or a customer? Was it outside that very\r\nhouse as I first set eyes upon him, rolling in the lap of luxury, when I\r\nwas selling halfpenny ballads there for a living? And am I to grovel in\r\nthe dust for HIM to walk over? No!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere was a grin upon the ghastly countenance of the French gentleman\r\nunder the influence of the firelight, as if he were computing how many\r\nthousand slanderers and traitors array themselves against the fortunate,\r\non premises exactly answering to those of Mr Wegg. One might have\r\nfancied that the big-headed babies were toppling over with their\r\nhydrocephalic attempts to reckon up the children of men who transform\r\ntheir benefactors into their injurers by the same process. The yard or\r\ntwo of smile on the part of the alligator might have been invested with\r\nthe meaning, \xe2\x80\x98All about this was quite familiar knowledge down in the\r\ndepths of the slime, ages ago.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But,\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg, possibly with some slight perception to the foregoing\r\neffect, \xe2\x80\x98your speaking countenance remarks, Mr Venus, that I\xe2\x80\x99m duller\r\nand savager than usual. Perhaps I HAVE allowed myself to brood too much.\r\nBegone, dull Care! \xe2\x80\x98Tis gone, sir. I\xe2\x80\x99ve looked in upon you, and empire\r\nresumes her sway. For, as the song says--subject to your correction,\r\nsir--\r\n\r\n     \xe2\x80\x9cWhen the heart of a man is depressed with cares,\r\n     The mist is dispelled if Venus appears.\r\n     Like the notes of a fiddle, you sweetly, sir, sweetly,\r\n     Raises our spirits and charms our ears.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGood-night, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall have a word or two to say to you, Mr Wegg, before long,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nremarked Venus, \xe2\x80\x98respecting my share in the project we\xe2\x80\x99ve been speaking\r\nof.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My time, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Wegg, \xe2\x80\x98is yours. In the meanwhile let it be\r\nfully understood that I shall not neglect bringing the grindstone to\r\nbear, nor yet bringing Dusty Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s nose to it. His nose once brought\r\nto it, shall be held to it by these hands, Mr Venus, till the sparks\r\nflies out in showers.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith this agreeable promise Wegg stumped out, and shut the shop-door\r\nafter him. \xe2\x80\x98Wait till I light a candle, Mr Boffin,\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus, \xe2\x80\x98and\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ll come out more comfortable.\xe2\x80\x99 So, he lighting a candle and holding\r\nit up at arm\xe2\x80\x99s length, Mr Boffin disengaged himself from behind the\r\nalligator\xe2\x80\x99s smile, with an expression of countenance so very downcast\r\nthat it not only appeared as if the alligator had the whole of the joke\r\nto himself, but further as if it had been conceived and executed at Mr\r\nBoffin\xe2\x80\x99s expense.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s a treacherous fellow,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, dusting his arms and legs\r\nas he came forth, the alligator having been but musty company. \xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\ndreadful fellow.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The alligator, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, Venus, no. The Serpent.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99ll have the goodness to notice, Mr Boffin,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Venus, \xe2\x80\x98that I\r\nsaid nothing to him about my going out of the affair altogether, because\r\nI didn\xe2\x80\x99t wish to take you anyways by surprise. But I can\xe2\x80\x99t be too soon\r\nout of it for my satisfaction, Mr Boffin, and I now put it to you when\r\nit will suit your views for me to retire?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank\xe2\x80\x99ee, Venus, thank\xe2\x80\x99ee, Venus; but I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what to say,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nreturned Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what to do. He\xe2\x80\x99ll drop down on me any\r\nway. He seems fully determined to drop down; don\xe2\x80\x99t he?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Venus opined that such was clearly his intention.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You might be a sort of protection for me, if you remained in it,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nMr Boffin; \xe2\x80\x98you might stand betwixt him and me, and take the edge off\r\nhim. Don\xe2\x80\x99t you feel as if you could make a show of remaining in it,\r\nVenus, till I had time to turn myself round?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nVenus naturally inquired how long Mr Boffin thought it might take him to\r\nturn himself round?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am sure I don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x99 was the answer, given quite at a loss.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Everything is so at sixes and sevens. If I had never come into the\r\nproperty, I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have minded. But being in it, it would be very\r\ntrying to be turned out; now, don\xe2\x80\x99t you acknowledge that it would,\r\nVenus?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Venus preferred, he said, to leave Mr Boffin to arrive at his own\r\nconclusions on that delicate question.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am sure I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what to do,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98If I ask advice of\r\nany one else, it\xe2\x80\x99s only letting in another person to be bought out, and\r\nthen I shall be ruined that way, and might as well have given up the\r\nproperty and gone slap to the workhouse. If I was to take advice of my\r\nyoung man, Rokesmith, I should have to buy HIM out. Sooner or later, of\r\ncourse, he\xe2\x80\x99d drop down upon me, like Wegg. I was brought into the world\r\nto be dropped down upon, it appears to me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Venus listened to these lamentations in silence, while Mr Boffin\r\njogged to and fro, holding his pockets as if he had a pain in them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98After all, you haven\xe2\x80\x99t said what you mean to do yourself, Venus. When\r\nyou do go out of it, how do you mean to go?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nVenus replied that as Wegg had found the document and handed it to him,\r\nit was his intention to hand it back to Wegg, with the declaration that\r\nhe himself would have nothing to say to it, or do with it, and that Wegg\r\nmust act as he chose, and take the consequences.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And then he drops down with his whole weight upon ME!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mr Boffin,\r\nruefully. \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99d sooner be dropped upon by you than by him, or even by you\r\njintly, than by him alone!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Venus could only repeat that it was his fixed intention to betake\r\nhimself to the paths of science, and to walk in the same all the days\r\nof his life; not dropping down upon his fellow-creatures until they were\r\ndeceased, and then only to articulate them to the best of his humble\r\nability.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How long could you be persuaded to keep up the appearance of remaining\r\nin it?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mr Boffin, retiring on his other idea. \xe2\x80\x98Could you be got\r\nto do so, till the Mounds are gone?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nNo. That would protract the mental uneasiness of Mr Venus too long, he\r\nsaid.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not if I was to show you reason now?\xe2\x80\x99 demanded Mr Boffin; \xe2\x80\x98not if I was\r\nto show you good and sufficient reason?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIf by good and sufficient reason Mr Boffin meant honest and\r\nunimpeachable reason, that might weigh with Mr Venus against his\r\npersonal wishes and convenience. But he must add that he saw no opening\r\nto the possibility of such reason being shown him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come and see me, Venus,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98at my house.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is the reason there, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mr Venus, with an incredulous smile\r\nand blink.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It may be, or may not be,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98just as you view it. But\r\nin the meantime don\xe2\x80\x99t go out of the matter. Look here. Do this. Give me\r\nyour word that you won\xe2\x80\x99t take any steps with Wegg, without my knowledge,\r\njust as I have given you my word that I won\xe2\x80\x99t without yours.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Done, Mr Boffin!\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus, after brief consideration.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank\xe2\x80\x99ee, Venus, thank\xe2\x80\x99ee, Venus! Done!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When shall I come to see you, Mr Boffin.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When you like. The sooner the better. I must be going now. Good-night,\r\nVenus.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good-night, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And good-night to the rest of the present company,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin,\r\nglancing round the shop. \xe2\x80\x98They make a queer show, Venus, and I should\r\nlike to be better acquainted with them some day. Good-night, Venus,\r\ngood-night! Thankee, Venus, thankee, Venus!\xe2\x80\x99 With that he jogged out\r\ninto the street, and jogged upon his homeward way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, I wonder,\xe2\x80\x99 he meditated as he went along, nursing his stick,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98whether it can be, that Venus is setting himself to get the better of\r\nWegg? Whether it can be, that he means, when I have bought Wegg out, to\r\nhave me all to himself and to pick me clean to the bones!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt was a cunning and suspicious idea, quite in the way of his school\r\nof Misers, and he looked very cunning and suspicious as he went jogging\r\nthrough the streets. More than once or twice, more than twice or thrice,\r\nsay half a dozen times, he took his stick from the arm on which he\r\nnursed it, and hit a straight sharp rap at the air with its head.\r\nPossibly the wooden countenance of Mr Silas Wegg was incorporeally\r\nbefore him at those moments, for he hit with intense satisfaction.\r\n\r\nHe was within a few streets of his own house, when a little private\r\ncarriage, coming in the contrary direction, passed him, turned round,\r\nand passed him again. It was a little carriage of eccentric movement,\r\nfor again he heard it stop behind him and turn round, and again he saw\r\nit pass him. Then it stopped, and then went on, out of sight. But, not\r\nfar out of sight, for, when he came to the corner of his own street,\r\nthere it stood again.\r\n\r\nThere was a lady\xe2\x80\x99s face at the window as he came up with this carriage,\r\nand he was passing it when the lady softly called to him by his name.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I beg your pardon, Ma\xe2\x80\x99am?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, coming to a stop.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is Mrs Lammle,\xe2\x80\x99 said the lady.\r\n\r\nMr Boffin went up to the window, and hoped Mrs Lammle was well.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not very well, dear Mr Boffin; I have fluttered myself by\r\nbeing--perhaps foolishly--uneasy and anxious. I have been waiting for\r\nyou some time. Can I speak to you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Boffin proposed that Mrs Lammle should drive on to his house, a few\r\nhundred yards further.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I would rather not, Mr Boffin, unless you particularly wish it. I feel\r\nthe difficulty and delicacy of the matter so much that I would rather\r\navoid speaking to you at your own home. You must think this very\r\nstrange?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Boffin said no, but meant yes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is because I am so grateful for the good opinion of all my\r\nfriends, and am so touched by it, that I cannot bear to run the risk of\r\nforfeiting it in any case, even in the cause of duty. I have asked my\r\nhusband (my dear Alfred, Mr Boffin) whether it is the cause of duty,\r\nand he has most emphatically said Yes. I wish I had asked him sooner. It\r\nwould have spared me much distress.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n[\xe2\x80\x98Can this be more dropping down upon me!\xe2\x80\x99 thought Mr Boffin, quite\r\nbewildered.)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was Alfred who sent me to you, Mr Boffin. Alfred said, \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ncome back, Sophronia, until you have seen Mr Boffin, and told him all.\r\nWhatever he may think of it, he ought certainly to know it.\xe2\x80\x9d Would you\r\nmind coming into the carriage?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Boffin answered, \xe2\x80\x98Not at all,\xe2\x80\x99 and took his seat at Mrs Lammle\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nside.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Drive slowly anywhere,\xe2\x80\x99 Mrs Lammle called to her coachman, \xe2\x80\x98and don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nlet the carriage rattle.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It MUST be more dropping down, I think,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin to himself.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What next?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 15\r\n\r\nTHE GOLDEN DUSTMAN AT HIS WORST\r\n\r\n\r\nThe breakfast table at Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s was usually a very pleasant one, and\r\nwas always presided over by Bella. As though he began each new day in\r\nhis healthy natural character, and some waking hours were necessary to\r\nhis relapse into the corrupting influences of his wealth, the face and\r\nthe demeanour of the Golden Dustman were generally unclouded at that\r\nmeal. It would have been easy to believe then, that there was no change\r\nin him. It was as the day went on that the clouds gathered, and the\r\nbrightness of the morning became obscured. One might have said that the\r\nshadows of avarice and distrust lengthened as his own shadow lengthened,\r\nand that the night closed around him gradually.\r\n\r\nBut, one morning long afterwards to be remembered, it was black midnight\r\nwith the Golden Dustman when he first appeared. His altered character\r\nhad never been so grossly marked. His bearing towards his Secretary was\r\nso charged with insolent distrust and arrogance, that the latter rose\r\nand left the table before breakfast was half done. The look he directed\r\nat the Secretary\xe2\x80\x99s retiring figure was so cunningly malignant, that\r\nBella would have sat astounded and indignant, even though he had not\r\ngone the length of secretly threatening Rokesmith with his clenched\r\nfist as he closed the door. This unlucky morning, of all mornings in the\r\nyear, was the morning next after Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s interview with Mrs Lammle\r\nin her little carriage.\r\n\r\nBella looked to Mrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s face for comment on, or explanation of,\r\nthis stormy humour in her husband, but none was there. An anxious and\r\na distressed observation of her own face was all she could read in it.\r\nWhen they were left alone together--which was not until noon, for Mr\r\nBoffin sat long in his easy-chair, by turns jogging up and down\r\nthe breakfast-room, clenching his fist and muttering--Bella, in\r\nconsternation, asked her what had happened, what was wrong? \xe2\x80\x98I am\r\nforbidden to speak to you about it, Bella dear; I mustn\xe2\x80\x99t tell you,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nwas all the answer she could get. And still, whenever, in her wonder and\r\ndismay, she raised her eyes to Mrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s face, she saw in it the same\r\nanxious and distressed observation of her own.\r\n\r\nOppressed by her sense that trouble was impending, and lost in\r\nspeculations why Mrs Boffin should look at her as if she had any part in\r\nit, Bella found the day long and dreary. It was far on in the afternoon\r\nwhen, she being in her own room, a servant brought her a message from Mr\r\nBoffin begging her to come to his.\r\n\r\nMrs Boffin was there, seated on a sofa, and Mr Boffin was jogging up and\r\ndown. On seeing Bella he stopped, beckoned her to him, and drew her arm\r\nthrough his. \xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t be alarmed, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, gently; \xe2\x80\x98I am not\r\nangry with you. Why you actually tremble! Don\xe2\x80\x99t be alarmed, Bella my\r\ndear. I\xe2\x80\x99ll see you righted.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98See me righted?\xe2\x80\x99 thought Bella. And then repeated aloud in a tone of\r\nastonishment: \xe2\x80\x98see me righted, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ay, ay!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98See you righted. Send Mr Rokesmith here, you\r\nsir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella would have been lost in perplexity if there had been pause\r\nenough; but the servant found Mr Rokesmith near at hand, and he almost\r\nimmediately presented himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Shut the door, sir!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98I have got something to say to\r\nyou which I fancy you\xe2\x80\x99ll not be pleased to hear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am sorry to reply, Mr Boffin,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the Secretary, as, having\r\nclosed the door, he turned and faced him, \xe2\x80\x98that I think that very\r\nlikely.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you mean?\xe2\x80\x99 blustered Mr Boffin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I mean that it has become no novelty to me to hear from your lips what\r\nI would rather not hear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh! Perhaps we shall change that,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin with a threatening\r\nroll of his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope so,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the Secretary. He was quiet and respectful; but\r\nstood, as Bella thought (and was glad to think), on his manhood too.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98look at this young lady on my arm.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella involuntarily raising her eyes, when this sudden reference was\r\nmade to herself, met those of Mr Rokesmith. He was pale and seemed\r\nagitated. Then her eyes passed on to Mrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s, and she met the look\r\nagain. In a flash it enlightened her, and she began to understand what\r\nshe had done.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I say to you, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 Mr Boffin repeated, \xe2\x80\x98look at this young lady on my\r\narm.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I do so,\xe2\x80\x99 returned the Secretary.\r\n\r\nAs his glance rested again on Bella for a moment, she thought there was\r\nreproach in it. But it is possible that the reproach was within herself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How dare you, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98tamper, unknown to me, with this\r\nyoung lady? Then I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you what it is, Rokesmith; I\xe2\x80\x99ll answer for you.\r\nThere are two sides to this matter, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll take \xe2\x80\x98em separately. The\r\nfirst side is, sheer Insolence. That\xe2\x80\x99s the first side.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe Secretary smiled with some bitterness, as though he would have said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So I see and hear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was sheer Insolence in you, I tell you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98even to\r\nthink of this young lady. This young lady was far above YOU. This young\r\nlady was no match for YOU. This young lady was lying in wait (as she was\r\nqualified to do) for money, and you had no money.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella hung her head and seemed to shrink a little from Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nprotecting arm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What are you, I should like to know,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98that you were\r\nto have the audacity to follow up this young lady? Mew,\r\nQuack-quack, Bow-wow!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJohn Rokesmith stared at him in his outburst, as if with some faint idea\r\nthat he had gone mad.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What is due to this young lady,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98is Money, and this\r\nyoung lady right well knows it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You slander the young lady.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98YOU slander the young lady; you with your affections and hearts and\r\ntrumpery,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s of a piece with the rest of your\r\nbehaviour. I heard of these doings of yours only last night, or you\r\nshould have heard of \xe2\x80\x98em from me, sooner, take your oath of it. I heard\r\nof \xe2\x80\x98em from a lady with as good a headpiece as the best, and she knows\r\nthis young lady, and I know this young lady, and we all three know that\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s Money she makes a stand for--money, money, money--and that you and\r\nyour affections and hearts are a Lie, sir!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mrs Boffin,\xe2\x80\x99 said Rokesmith, quietly turning to her, \xe2\x80\x98for your delicate\r\nand unvarying kindness I thank you with the warmest gratitude. Good-bye!\r\nMiss Wilfer, good-bye!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And now, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, laying his hand on Bella\xe2\x80\x99s head\r\nagain, \xe2\x80\x98you may begin to make yourself quite comfortable, and I hope you\r\nfeel that you\xe2\x80\x99ve been righted.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBut, Bella was so far from appearing to feel it, that she shrank from\r\nhis hand and from the chair, and, starting up in an incoherent passion\r\nof tears, and stretching out her arms, cried, \xe2\x80\x98O Mr Rokesmith, before\r\nyou go, if you could but make me poor again! O! Make me poor again,\r\nSomebody, I beg and pray, or my heart will break if this goes on! Pa,\r\ndear, make me poor again and take me home! I was bad enough there, but\r\nI have been so much worse here. Don\xe2\x80\x99t give me money, Mr Boffin, I won\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nhave money. Keep it away from me, and only let me speak to good little\r\nPa, and lay my head upon his shoulder, and tell him all my griefs.\r\nNobody else can understand me, nobody else can comfort me, nobody else\r\nknows how unworthy I am, and yet can love me like a little child. I am\r\nbetter with Pa than any one--more innocent, more sorry, more glad!\xe2\x80\x99 So,\r\ncrying out in a wild way that she could not bear this, Bella drooped her\r\nhead on Mrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s ready breast.\r\n\r\nJohn Rokesmith from his place in the room, and Mr Boffin from his,\r\nlooked on at her in silence until she was silent herself. Then Mr Boffin\r\nobserved in a soothing and comfortable tone, \xe2\x80\x98There, my dear, there; you\r\nare righted now, and it\xe2\x80\x99s ALL right. I don\xe2\x80\x99t wonder, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure, at your\r\nbeing a little flurried by having a scene with this fellow, but it\xe2\x80\x99s all\r\nover, my dear, and you\xe2\x80\x99re righted, and it\xe2\x80\x99s--and it\xe2\x80\x99s ALL right!\xe2\x80\x99 Which\r\nMr Boffin repeated with a highly satisfied air of completeness and\r\nfinality.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hate you!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Bella, turning suddenly upon him, with a stamp of\r\nher little foot--\xe2\x80\x98at least, I can\xe2\x80\x99t hate you, but I don\xe2\x80\x99t like you!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98HUL--LO!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Mr Boffin in an amazed under-tone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re a scolding, unjust, abusive, aggravating, bad old creature!\xe2\x80\x99\r\ncried Bella. \xe2\x80\x98I am angry with my ungrateful self for calling you names;\r\nbut you are, you are; you know you are!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Boffin stared here, and stared there, as misdoubting that he must be\r\nin some sort of fit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have heard you with shame,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella. \xe2\x80\x98With shame for myself, and\r\nwith shame for you. You ought to be above the base tale-bearing of a\r\ntime-serving woman; but you are above nothing now.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Boffin, seeming to become convinced that this was a fit, rolled his\r\neyes and loosened his neckcloth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When I came here, I respected you and honoured you, and I soon loved\r\nyou,\xe2\x80\x99 cried Bella. \xe2\x80\x98And now I can\xe2\x80\x99t bear the sight of you. At least, I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t know that I ought to go so far as that--only you\xe2\x80\x99re a--you\xe2\x80\x99re a\r\nMonster!\xe2\x80\x99 Having shot this bolt out with a great expenditure of force,\r\nBella hysterically laughed and cried together.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The best wish I can wish you is,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, returning to the charge,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98that you had not one single farthing in the world. If any true friend\r\nand well-wisher could make you a bankrupt, you would be a Duck; but as a\r\nman of property you are a Demon!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAfter despatching this second bolt with a still greater expenditure of\r\nforce, Bella laughed and cried still more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Rokesmith, pray stay one moment. Pray hear one word from me before\r\nyou go! I am deeply sorry for the reproaches you have borne on my\r\naccount. Out of the depths of my heart I earnestly and truly beg your\r\npardon.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs she stepped towards him, he met her. As she gave him her hand, he put\r\nit to his lips, and said, \xe2\x80\x98God bless you!\xe2\x80\x99 No laughing was mixed with\r\nBella\xe2\x80\x99s crying then; her tears were pure and fervent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There is not an ungenerous word that I have heard addressed to\r\nyou--heard with scorn and indignation, Mr Rokesmith--but it has wounded\r\nme far more than you, for I have deserved it, and you never have. Mr\r\nRokesmith, it is to me you owe this perverted account of what passed\r\nbetween us that night. I parted with the secret, even while I was angry\r\nwith myself for doing so. It was very bad in me, but indeed it was not\r\nwicked. I did it in a moment of conceit and folly--one of my many such\r\nmoments--one of my many such hours--years. As I am punished for it\r\nseverely, try to forgive it!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I do with all my soul.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you. O thank you! Don\xe2\x80\x99t part from me till I have said one other\r\nword, to do you justice. The only fault you can be truly charged with,\r\nin having spoken to me as you did that night--with how much delicacy\r\nand how much forbearance no one but I can know or be grateful to you\r\nfor--is, that you laid yourself open to be slighted by a worldly shallow\r\ngirl whose head was turned, and who was quite unable to rise to the\r\nworth of what you offered her. Mr Rokesmith, that girl has often seen\r\nherself in a pitiful and poor light since, but never in so pitiful\r\nand poor a light as now, when the mean tone in which she answered\r\nyou--sordid and vain girl that she was--has been echoed in her ears by\r\nMr Boffin.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe kissed her hand again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s speeches were detestable to me, shocking to me,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nBella, startling that gentleman with another stamp of her little\r\nfoot. \xe2\x80\x98It is quite true that there was a time, and very lately, when I\r\ndeserved to be so \xe2\x80\x9crighted,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr Rokesmith; but I hope that I shall never\r\ndeserve it again!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe once more put her hand to his lips, and then relinquished it, and\r\nleft the room. Bella was hurrying back to the chair in which she had\r\nhidden her face so long, when, catching sight of Mrs Boffin by the\r\nway, she stopped at her. \xe2\x80\x98He is gone,\xe2\x80\x99 sobbed Bella indignantly,\r\ndespairingly, in fifty ways at once, with her arms round Mrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nneck. \xe2\x80\x98He has been most shamefully abused, and most unjustly and most\r\nbasely driven away, and I am the cause of it!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAll this time, Mr Boffin had been rolling his eyes over his loosened\r\nneckerchief, as if his fit were still upon him. Appearing now to think\r\nthat he was coming to, he stared straight before him for a while, tied\r\nhis neckerchief again, took several long inspirations, swallowed several\r\ntimes, and ultimately exclaimed with a deep sigh, as if he felt himself\r\non the whole better: \xe2\x80\x98Well!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nNo word, good or bad, did Mrs Boffin say; but she tenderly took care of\r\nBella, and glanced at her husband as if for orders. Mr Boffin, without\r\nimparting any, took his seat on a chair over against them, and there\r\nsat leaning forward, with a fixed countenance, his legs apart, a hand on\r\neach knee, and his elbows squared, until Bella should dry her eyes and\r\nraise her head, which in the fulness of time she did.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I must go home,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, rising hurriedly. \xe2\x80\x98I am very grateful to\r\nyou for all you have done for me, but I can\xe2\x80\x99t stay here.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My darling girl!\xe2\x80\x99 remonstrated Mrs Boffin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, I can\xe2\x80\x99t stay here,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella; \xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t indeed.--Ugh! you vicious\r\nold thing!\xe2\x80\x99 (This to Mr Boffin.)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t be rash, my love,\xe2\x80\x99 urged Mrs Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98Think well of what you do.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, you had better think well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall never more think well of YOU,\xe2\x80\x99 cried Bella, cutting him\r\nshort, with intense defiance in her expressive little eyebrows, and\r\nchampionship of the late Secretary in every dimple. \xe2\x80\x98No! Never again!\r\nYour money has changed you to marble. You are a hard-hearted Miser. You\r\nare worse than Dancer, worse than Hopkins, worse than Blackberry Jones,\r\nworse than any of the wretches. And more!\xe2\x80\x99 proceeded Bella, breaking\r\ninto tears again, \xe2\x80\x98you were wholly undeserving of the Gentleman you have\r\nlost.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, you don\xe2\x80\x99t mean to say, Miss Bella,\xe2\x80\x99 the Golden Dustman slowly\r\nremonstrated, \xe2\x80\x98that you set up Rokesmith against me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I do!\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella. \xe2\x80\x98He is worth a Million of you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nVery pretty she looked, though very angry, as she made herself as\r\ntall as she possibly could (which was not extremely tall), and utterly\r\nrenounced her patron with a lofty toss of her rich brown head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I would rather he thought well of me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, \xe2\x80\x98though he swept the\r\nstreet for bread, than that you did, though you splashed the mud upon\r\nhim from the wheels of a chariot of pure gold.--There!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well I\xe2\x80\x99m sure!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mr Boffin, staring.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And for a long time past, when you have thought you set yourself above\r\nhim, I have only seen you under his feet,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella--\xe2\x80\x98There! And\r\nthroughout I saw in him the master, and I saw in you the man--There! And\r\nwhen you used him shamefully, I took his part and loved him--There! I\r\nboast of it!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAfter which strong avowal Bella underwent reaction, and cried to any\r\nextent, with her face on the back of her chair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, look here,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, as soon as he could find an opening\r\nfor breaking the silence and striking in. \xe2\x80\x98Give me your attention,\r\nBella. I am not angry.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I AM!\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I say,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed the Golden Dustman, \xe2\x80\x98I am not angry, and I mean kindly\r\nto you, and I want to overlook this. So you\xe2\x80\x99ll stay where you are, and\r\nwe\xe2\x80\x99ll agree to say no more about it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, I can\xe2\x80\x99t stay here,\xe2\x80\x99 cried Bella, rising hurriedly again; \xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nthink of staying here. I must go home for good.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, don\xe2\x80\x99t be silly,\xe2\x80\x99 Mr Boffin reasoned. \xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t do what you can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nundo; don\xe2\x80\x99t do what you\xe2\x80\x99re sure to be sorry for.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall never be sorry for it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella; \xe2\x80\x98and I should always be\r\nsorry, and should every minute of my life despise myself if I remained\r\nhere after what has happened.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98At least, Bella,\xe2\x80\x99 argued Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98let there be no mistake about it.\r\nLook before you leap, you know. Stay where you are, and all\xe2\x80\x99s well, and\r\nall\xe2\x80\x99s as it was to be. Go away, and you can never come back.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know that I can never come back, and that\xe2\x80\x99s what I mean,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You mustn\xe2\x80\x99t expect,\xe2\x80\x99 Mr Boffin pursued, \xe2\x80\x98that I\xe2\x80\x99m a-going to settle\r\nmoney on you, if you leave us like this, because I am not. No, Bella! Be\r\ncareful! Not one brass farthing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Expect!\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, haughtily. \xe2\x80\x98Do you think that any power on earth\r\ncould make me take it, if you did, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBut there was Mrs Boffin to part from, and, in the full flush of her\r\ndignity, the impressible little soul collapsed again. Down upon her\r\nknees before that good woman, she rocked herself upon her breast, and\r\ncried, and sobbed, and folded her in her arms with all her might.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re a dear, a dear, the best of dears!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Bella. \xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re the\r\nbest of human creatures. I can never be thankful enough to you, and I\r\ncan never forget you. If I should live to be blind and deaf I know I\r\nshall see and hear you, in my fancy, to the last of my dim old days!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs Boffin wept most heartily, and embraced her with all fondness; but\r\nsaid not one single word except that she was her dear girl. She said\r\nthat often enough, to be sure, for she said it over and over again; but\r\nnot one word else.\r\n\r\nBella broke from her at length, and was going weeping out of the room,\r\nwhen in her own little queer affectionate way, she half relented towards\r\nMr Boffin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am very glad,\xe2\x80\x99 sobbed Bella, \xe2\x80\x98that I called you names, sir, because\r\nyou richly deserved it. But I am very sorry that I called you names,\r\nbecause you used to be so different. Say good-bye!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good-bye,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, shortly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If I knew which of your hands was the least spoilt, I would ask you\r\nto let me touch it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, \xe2\x80\x98for the last time. But not because I\r\nrepent of what I have said to you. For I don\xe2\x80\x99t. It\xe2\x80\x99s true!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Try the left hand,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, holding it out in a stolid manner;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98it\xe2\x80\x99s the least used.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have been wonderfully good and kind to me,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, \xe2\x80\x98and I kiss\r\nit for that. You have been as bad as bad could be to Mr Rokesmith, and I\r\nthrow it away for that. Thank you for myself, and good-bye!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good-bye,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin as before.\r\n\r\nBella caught him round the neck and kissed him, and ran out for ever.\r\n\r\nShe ran up-stairs, and sat down on the floor in her own room, and cried\r\nabundantly. But the day was declining and she had no time to lose. She\r\nopened all the places where she kept her dresses; selected only those\r\nshe had brought with her, leaving all the rest; and made a great\r\nmisshapen bundle of them, to be sent for afterwards.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I won\xe2\x80\x99t take one of the others,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, tying the knots of the\r\nbundle very tight, in the severity of her resolution. \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll leave all\r\nthe presents behind, and begin again entirely on my own account.\xe2\x80\x99 That\r\nthe resolution might be thoroughly carried into practice, she even\r\nchanged the dress she wore, for that in which she had come to the grand\r\nmansion. Even the bonnet she put on, was the bonnet that had mounted\r\ninto the Boffin chariot at Holloway.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, I am complete,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella. \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s a little trying, but I have\r\nsteeped my eyes in cold water, and I won\xe2\x80\x99t cry any more. You have been\r\na pleasant room to me, dear room. Adieu! We shall never see each other\r\nagain.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith a parting kiss of her fingers to it, she softly closed the door and\r\nwent with a light foot down the great staircase, pausing and listening\r\nas she went, that she might meet none of the household. No one chanced\r\nto be about, and she got down to the hall in quiet. The door of the late\r\nSecretary\xe2\x80\x99s room stood open. She peeped in as she passed, and divined\r\nfrom the emptiness of his table, and the general appearance of things,\r\nthat he was already gone. Softly opening the great hall door, and\r\nsoftly closing it upon herself, she turned and kissed it on the\r\noutside--insensible old combination of wood and iron that it\r\nwas!--before she ran away from the house at a swift pace.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That was well done!\xe2\x80\x99 panted Bella, slackening in the next street, and\r\nsubsiding into a walk. \xe2\x80\x98If I had left myself any breath to cry with, I\r\nshould have cried again. Now poor dear darling little Pa, you are going\r\nto see your lovely woman unexpectedly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 16\r\n\r\nTHE FEAST OF THE THREE HOBGOBLINS\r\n\r\n\r\nThe City looked unpromising enough, as Bella made her way along its\r\ngritty streets. Most of its money-mills were slackening sail, or had\r\nleft off grinding for the day. The master-millers had already departed,\r\nand the journeymen were departing. There was a jaded aspect on\r\nthe business lanes and courts, and the very pavements had a weary\r\nappearance, confused by the tread of a million of feet. There must be\r\nhours of night to temper down the day\xe2\x80\x99s distraction of so feverish a\r\nplace. As yet the worry of the newly-stopped whirling and grinding on\r\nthe part of the money-mills seemed to linger in the air, and the quiet\r\nwas more like the prostration of a spent giant than the repose of one\r\nwho was renewing his strength.\r\n\r\nIf Bella thought, as she glanced at the mighty Bank, how agreeable it\r\nwould be to have an hour\xe2\x80\x99s gardening there, with a bright copper shovel,\r\namong the money, still she was not in an avaricious vein. Much improved\r\nin that respect, and with certain half-formed images which had little\r\ngold in their composition, dancing before her bright eyes, she arrived\r\nin the drug-flavoured region of Mincing Lane, with the sensation of\r\nhaving just opened a drawer in a chemist\xe2\x80\x99s shop.\r\n\r\nThe counting-house of Chicksey, Veneering, and Stobbles was pointed out\r\nby an elderly female accustomed to the care of offices, who dropped upon\r\nBella out of a public-house, wiping her mouth, and accounted for its\r\nhumidity on natural principles well known to the physical sciences, by\r\nexplaining that she had looked in at the door to see what o\xe2\x80\x99clock it\r\nwas. The counting-house was a wall-eyed ground floor by a dark gateway,\r\nand Bella was considering, as she approached it, could there be any\r\nprecedent in the City for her going in and asking for R. Wilfer, when\r\nwhom should she see, sitting at one of the windows with the plate-glass\r\nsash raised, but R. Wilfer himself, preparing to take a slight\r\nrefection.\r\n\r\nOn approaching nearer, Bella discerned that the refection had\r\nthe appearance of a small cottage-loaf and a pennyworth of milk.\r\nSimultaneously with this discovery on her part, her father discovered\r\nher, and invoked the echoes of Mincing Lane to exclaim \xe2\x80\x98My gracious me!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe then came cherubically flying out without a hat, and embraced her,\r\nand handed her in. \xe2\x80\x98For it\xe2\x80\x99s after hours and I am all alone, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nhe explained, \xe2\x80\x98and am having--as I sometimes do when they are all\r\ngone--a quiet tea.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLooking round the office, as if her father were a captive and this his\r\ncell, Bella hugged him and choked him to her heart\xe2\x80\x99s content.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I never was so surprised, my dear!\xe2\x80\x99 said her father. \xe2\x80\x98I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nbelieve my eyes. Upon my life, I thought they had taken to lying! The\r\nidea of your coming down the Lane yourself! Why didn\xe2\x80\x99t you send the\r\nfootman down the Lane, my dear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have brought no footman with me, Pa.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh indeed! Yes to the first question, and Certainly\r\nNot to the second. Respecting the quiet tea, my dear, why you see the\r\noccupations of the day are sometimes a little wearing; and if there\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nnothing interposed between the day and your mother, why SHE is sometimes\r\na little wearing, too.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know, Pa.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, my dear. You see that little desk in the corner?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In the dark corner, furthest both from the light and from the\r\nfireplace? The shabbiest desk of all the desks?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, does it really strike you in that point of view, my dear?\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nher father, surveying it artistically with his head on one side: \xe2\x80\x98that\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmine. That\xe2\x80\x99s called Rumty\xe2\x80\x99s Perch.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Whose Perch?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Bella with great indignation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Rumty\xe2\x80\x99s. Three times and away, Pa!\xe2\x80\x99 Off she skimmed, bearing\r\nthe cherub along, nor ever stopped, nor suffered him to stop, until she\r\nhad pulled at the bell. \xe2\x80\x98Now, dear Pa,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, taking him by both\r\nears as if he were a pitcher, and conveying his face to her rosy lips,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98we are in for it!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMiss Lavvy came out to open the gate, waited on by that attentive\r\ncavalier and friend of the family, Mr George Sampson. \xe2\x80\x98Why, it\xe2\x80\x99s never\r\nBella!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Miss Lavvy starting back at the sight. And then\r\nbawled, \xe2\x80\x98Ma! Here\xe2\x80\x99s Bella!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis produced, before they could get into the house, Mrs Wilfer. Who,\r\nstanding in the portal, received them with ghostly gloom, and all her\r\nother appliances of ceremony.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My child is welcome, though unlooked for,\xe2\x80\x99 said she, at the time\r\npresenting her cheek as if it were a cool slate for visitors to enrol\r\nthemselves upon. \xe2\x80\x98You too, R. W., are welcome, though late. Does the\r\nmale domestic of Mrs Boffin hear me there?\xe2\x80\x99 This deep-toned inquiry was\r\ncast forth into the night, for response from the menial in question.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There is no one waiting, Ma, dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There is no one waiting?\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Mrs Wilfer in majestic accents.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, Ma, dear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nA dignified shiver pervaded Mrs Wilfer\xe2\x80\x99s shoulders and gloves, as\r\nwho should say, \xe2\x80\x98An Enigma!\xe2\x80\x99 and then she marched at the head of the\r\nprocession to the family keeping-room, where she observed:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Unless, R. W.\xe2\x80\x99: who started on being solemnly turned upon: \xe2\x80\x98you have\r\ntaken the precaution of making some addition to our frugal supper on\r\nyour way home, it will prove but a distasteful one to Bella. Cold neck\r\nof mutton and a lettuce can ill compete with the luxuries of Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nboard.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pray don\xe2\x80\x99t talk like that, Ma dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella; \xe2\x80\x98Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s board is\r\nnothing to me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBut, here Miss Lavinia, who had been intently eyeing Bella\xe2\x80\x99s bonnet,\r\nstruck in with \xe2\x80\x98Why, Bella!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, Lavvy, I know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe Irrepressible lowered her eyes to Bella\xe2\x80\x99s dress, and stooped to look\r\nat it, exclaiming again: \xe2\x80\x98Why, Bella!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, Lavvy, I know what I have got on. I was going to tell Ma when you\r\ninterrupted. I have left Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s house for good, Ma, and I have come\r\nhome again.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs Wilfer spake no word, but, having glared at her offspring for a\r\nminute or two in an awful silence, retired into her corner of state\r\nbackward, and sat down: like a frozen article on sale in a Russian\r\nmarket.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In short, dear Ma,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, taking off the depreciated bonnet and\r\nshaking out her hair, \xe2\x80\x98I have had a very serious difference with Mr\r\nBoffin on the subject of his treatment of a member of his household, and\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s a final difference, and there\xe2\x80\x99s an end of all.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And I am bound to tell you, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 added R. W., submissively, \xe2\x80\x98that\r\nBella has acted in a truly brave spirit, and with a truly right feeling.\r\nAnd therefore I hope, my dear, you\xe2\x80\x99ll not allow yourself to be greatly\r\ndisappointed.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98George!\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Lavvy, in a sepulchral, warning voice, founded on\r\nher mother\xe2\x80\x99s; \xe2\x80\x98George Sampson, speak! What did I tell you about those\r\nBoffins?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Sampson perceiving his frail bark to be labouring among shoals and\r\nbreakers, thought it safest not to refer back to any particular thing\r\nthat he had been told, lest he should refer back to the wrong thing.\r\nWith admirable seamanship he got his bark into deep water by murmuring\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes indeed.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes! I told George Sampson, as George Sampson tells you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss\r\nLavvy, \xe2\x80\x98that those hateful Boffins would pick a quarrel with Bella, as\r\nsoon as her novelty had worn off. Have they done it, or have they not?\r\nWas I right, or was I wrong? And what do you say to us, Bella, of your\r\nBoffins now?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lavvy and Ma,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, \xe2\x80\x98I say of Mr and Mrs Boffin what I always\r\nhave said; and I always shall say of them what I always have said. But\r\nnothing will induce me to quarrel with any one to-night. I hope you\r\nare not sorry to see me, Ma dear,\xe2\x80\x99 kissing her; \xe2\x80\x98and I hope you are not\r\nsorry to see me, Lavvy,\xe2\x80\x99 kissing her too; \xe2\x80\x98and as I notice the lettuce\r\nMa mentioned, on the table, I\xe2\x80\x99ll make the salad.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella playfully setting herself about the task, Mrs Wilfer\xe2\x80\x99s impressive\r\ncountenance followed her with glaring eyes, presenting a combination\r\nof the once popular sign of the Saracen\xe2\x80\x99s Head, with a piece of\r\nDutch clock-work, and suggesting to an imaginative mind that from the\r\ncomposition of the salad, her daughter might prudently omit the vinegar.\r\nBut no word issued from the majestic matron\xe2\x80\x99s lips. And this was more\r\nterrific to her husband (as perhaps she knew) than any flow of eloquence\r\nwith which she could have edified the company.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, Ma dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella in due course, \xe2\x80\x98the salad\xe2\x80\x99s ready, and it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npast supper-time.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs Wilfer rose, but remained speechless. \xe2\x80\x98George!\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Lavinia\r\nin her voice of warning, \xe2\x80\x98Ma\xe2\x80\x99s chair!\xe2\x80\x99 Mr Sampson flew to the excellent\r\nlady\xe2\x80\x99s back, and followed her up close chair in hand, as she stalked\r\nto the banquet. Arrived at the table, she took her rigid seat, after\r\nfavouring Mr Sampson with a glare for himself, which caused the young\r\ngentleman to retire to his place in much confusion.\r\n\r\nThe cherub not presuming to address so tremendous an object, transacted\r\nher supper through the agency of a third person, as \xe2\x80\x98Mutton to your Ma,\r\nBella, my dear\xe2\x80\x99; and \xe2\x80\x98Lavvy, I dare say your Ma would take some lettuce\r\nif you were to put it on her plate.\xe2\x80\x99 Mrs Wilfer\xe2\x80\x99s manner of receiving\r\nthose viands was marked by petrified absence of mind; in which state,\r\nlikewise, she partook of them, occasionally laying down her knife and\r\nfork, as saying within her own spirit, \xe2\x80\x98What is this I am doing?\xe2\x80\x99 and\r\nglaring at one or other of the party, as if in indignant search of\r\ninformation. A magnetic result of such glaring was, that the person\r\nglared at could not by any means successfully pretend to be ignorant of\r\nthe fact: so that a bystander, without beholding Mrs Wilfer at all, must\r\nhave known at whom she was glaring, by seeing her refracted from the\r\ncountenance of the beglared one.\r\n\r\nMiss Lavinia was extremely affable to Mr Sampson on this special\r\noccasion, and took the opportunity of informing her sister why.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was not worth troubling you about, Bella, when you were in a sphere\r\nso far removed from your family as to make it a matter in which you\r\ncould be expected to take very little interest,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lavinia with a\r\ntoss of her chin; \xe2\x80\x98but George Sampson is paying his addresses to me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella was glad to hear it. Mr Sampson became thoughtfully red, and\r\nfelt called upon to encircle Miss Lavinia\xe2\x80\x99s waist with his arm; but,\r\nencountering a large pin in the young lady\xe2\x80\x99s belt, scarified a finger,\r\nuttered a sharp exclamation, and attracted the lightning of Mrs Wilfer\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nglare.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98George is getting on very well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Lavinia which might not have\r\nbeen supposed at the moment--\xe2\x80\x98and I dare say we shall be married, one of\r\nthese days. I didn\xe2\x80\x99t care to mention it when you were with your Bof--\xe2\x80\x99\r\nhere Miss Lavinia checked herself in a bounce, and added more placidly,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98when you were with Mr and Mrs Boffin; but now I think it sisterly to\r\nname the circumstance.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you, Lavvy dear. I congratulate you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you, Bella. The truth is, George and I did discuss whether\r\nI should tell you; but I said to George that you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be much\r\ninterested in so paltry an affair, and that it was far more likely you\r\nwould rather detach yourself from us altogether, than have him added to\r\nthe rest of us.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That was a mistake, dear Lavvy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It turns out to be,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Miss Lavinia; \xe2\x80\x98but circumstances have\r\nchanged, you know, my dear. I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have had the courage to tell\r\nyou so yesterday, when you would have thought his prospects poor, and\r\nnot worth notice; but I feel quite bold tonight.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When did you begin to feel timid, Lavvy?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Bella, with a smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I didn\xe2\x80\x99t say that I ever felt timid, Bella,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the Irrepressible.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But perhaps I might have said, if I had not been restrained by delicacy\r\ntowards a sister\xe2\x80\x99s feelings, that I have for some time felt independent;\r\ntoo independent, my dear, to subject myself to have my intended match\r\n(you\xe2\x80\x99ll prick yourself again, George) looked down upon. It is not that I\r\ncould have blamed you for looking down upon it, when you were looking up\r\nto a rich and great match, Bella; it is only that I was independent.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWhether the Irrepressible felt slighted by Bella\xe2\x80\x99s declaration that she\r\nwould not quarrel, or whether her spitefulness was evoked by Bella\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nreturn to the sphere of Mr George Sampson\xe2\x80\x99s courtship, or whether it was\r\na necessary fillip to her spirits that she should come into collision\r\nwith somebody on the present occasion,--anyhow she made a dash at her\r\nstately parent now, with the greatest impetuosity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ma, pray don\xe2\x80\x99t sit staring at me in that intensely aggravating manner!\r\nIf you see a black on my nose, tell me so; if you don\xe2\x80\x99t, leave me\r\nalone.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you address Me in those words?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Wilfer. \xe2\x80\x98Do you presume?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t talk about presuming, Ma, for goodness\xe2\x80\x99 sake. A girl who is old\r\nenough to be engaged, is quite old enough to object to be stared at as\r\nif she was a Clock.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Audacious one!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Wilfer. \xe2\x80\x98Your grandmamma, if so addressed by\r\none of her daughters, at any age, would have insisted on her retiring to\r\na dark apartment.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My grandmamma,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Lavvy, folding her arms and leaning back\r\nin her chair, \xe2\x80\x98wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have sat staring people out of countenance, I\r\nthink.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She would!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Wilfer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then it\xe2\x80\x99s a pity she didn\xe2\x80\x99t know better,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lavvy. \xe2\x80\x98And if my\r\ngrandmamma wasn\xe2\x80\x99t in her dotage when she took to insisting on people\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nretiring to dark apartments, she ought to have been. A pretty exhibition\r\nmy grandmamma must have made of herself! I wonder whether she ever\r\ninsisted on people\xe2\x80\x99s retiring into the ball of St Paul\xe2\x80\x99s; and if she\r\ndid, how she got them there!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Silence!\xe2\x80\x99 proclaimed Mrs Wilfer. \xe2\x80\x98I command silence!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have not the slightest intention of being silent, Ma,\xe2\x80\x99 returned\r\nLavinia coolly, \xe2\x80\x98but quite the contrary. If Pa thinks proper to be eyed as if HE had come from\r\nthe Boffins also, well and good. I don\xe2\x80\x99t choose to. And I won\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLavinia\xe2\x80\x99s engineering having made this crooked opening at Bella, Mrs\r\nWilfer strode into it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You rebellious spirit! I have had a tiring day, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll go to bed.\xe2\x80\x99 This\r\nbroke up the agreeable party. Mr George Sampson shortly afterwards took\r\nhis leave, accompanied by Miss Lavinia with a candle as far as the hall,\r\nand without a candle as far as the garden gate; Mrs Wilfer, washing her\r\nhands of the Boffins, went to bed after the manner of Lady Macbeth; and\r\nR. W. was left alone among the dilapidations of the supper table, in a\r\nmelancholy attitude.\r\n\r\nBut, a light footstep roused him from his meditations, and it was\r\nBella\xe2\x80\x99s. Her pretty hair was hanging all about her, and she had tripped\r\ndown softly, brush in hand, and barefoot, to say good-night to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear, you most unquestionably ARE a lovely woman,\xe2\x80\x99 said the cherub,\r\ntaking up a tress in his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Look here, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella; \xe2\x80\x98when your lovely woman marries, you shall\r\nhave that piece if you like, and she\xe2\x80\x99ll make you a chain of it. Would\r\nyou prize that remembrance of the dear creature?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, my precious.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then you shall have it if you\xe2\x80\x99re good, sir. I am very, very sorry,\r\ndearest Pa, to have brought home all this trouble.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My pet,\xe2\x80\x99 returned her father, in the simplest good faith, \xe2\x80\x98don\xe2\x80\x99t make\r\nyourself uneasy about that. It really is not worth mentioning, because\r\nthings at home would have taken pretty much the same turn any way. If\r\nyour mother and sister don\xe2\x80\x99t find one subject to get at times a little\r\nwearing on, they find another. We\xe2\x80\x99re never out of a wearing subject,\r\nmy dear, I assure you. I am afraid you find your old room with Lavvy,\r\ndreadfully inconvenient, Bella?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No I don\xe2\x80\x99t, Pa; I don\xe2\x80\x99t mind. Why don\xe2\x80\x99t I mind, do you think, Pa?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, my child, you used to complain of it when it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t such a\r\ncontrast as it must be now.
