If the Golden Dustman\xe2\x80\x99s riches had\r\nbeen his to stake, he would have staked them to the last farthing on the\r\nfidelity through good and evil of her affectionate and trusting heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, I\xe2\x80\x99ll go down to, and go away with, Mr Lightwood,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella,\r\nspringing up. \xe2\x80\x98You are the most creasing and tumbling Clumsy-Boots of a\r\npacker, John, that ever was; but if you\xe2\x80\x99re quite good, and will promise\r\nnever to do so any more (though I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what you have done!) you\r\nmay pack me a little bag for a night, while I get my bonnet on.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe gaily complied, and she tied her dimpled chin up, and shook her head\r\ninto her bonnet, and pulled out the bows of her bonnet-strings, and\r\ngot her gloves on, finger by finger, and finally got them on her\r\nlittle plump hands, and bade him good-bye and went down. Mr Lightwood\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nimpatience was much relieved when he found her dressed for departure.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Rokesmith goes with us?\xe2\x80\x99 he said, hesitating, with a look towards\r\nthe door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, I forgot!\xe2\x80\x99 replied Bella. \xe2\x80\x98His best compliments. His face is\r\nswollen to the size of two faces, and he is to go to bed directly, poor\r\nfellow, to wait for the doctor, who is coming to lance him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is curious,\xe2\x80\x99 observed Lightwood, \xe2\x80\x98that I have never yet seen Mr\r\nRokesmith, though we have been engaged in the same affairs.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Really?\xe2\x80\x99 said the unblushing Bella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I begin to think,\xe2\x80\x99 observed Lightwood, \xe2\x80\x98that I never shall see him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98These things happen so oddly sometimes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella with a steady\r\ncountenance, \xe2\x80\x98that there seems a kind of fatality in them. But I am\r\nquite ready, Mr Lightwood.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey started directly, in a little carriage that Lightwood had brought\r\nwith him from never-to-be-forgotten Greenwich; and from Greenwich they\r\nstarted directly for London; and in London they waited at a railway\r\nstation until such time as the Reverend Frank Milvey, and Margaretta\r\nhis wife, with whom Mortimer Lightwood had been already in conference,\r\nshould come and join them.\r\n\r\nThat worthy couple were delayed by a portentous old parishioner of the\r\nfemale gender, who was one of the plagues of their lives, and with whom\r\nthey bore with most exemplary sweetness and good-humour, notwithstanding\r\nher having an infection of absurdity about her, that communicated itself\r\nto everything with which, and everybody with whom, she came in contact.\r\nShe was a member of the Reverend Frank\xe2\x80\x99s congregation, and made a point\r\nof distinguishing herself in that body, by conspicuously weeping at\r\neverything, however cheering, said by the Reverend Frank in his public\r\nministration; also by applying to herself the various lamentations of\r\nDavid, and complaining in a personally injured manner (much in arrear of\r\nthe clerk and the rest of the respondents) that her enemies were digging\r\npit-falls about her, and breaking her with rods of iron. Indeed, this\r\nold widow discharged herself of that portion of the Morning and Evening\r\nService as if she were lodging a complaint on oath and applying for\r\na warrant before a magistrate. But this was not her most inconvenient\r\ncharacteristic, for that took the form of an impression, usually\r\nrecurring in inclement weather and at about daybreak, that she had\r\nsomething on her mind and stood in immediate need of the Reverend Frank\r\nto come and take it off. Many a time had that kind creature got up, and\r\ngone out to Mrs Sprodgkin (such was the disciple\xe2\x80\x99s name), suppressing\r\na strong sense of her comicality by his strong sense of duty, and\r\nperfectly knowing that nothing but a cold would come of it. However,\r\nbeyond themselves, the Reverend Frank Milvey and Mrs Milvey seldom\r\nhinted that Mrs Sprodgkin was hardly worth the trouble she gave; but\r\nboth made the best of her, as they did of all their troubles.\r\n\r\nThis very exacting member of the fold appeared to be endowed with a\r\nsixth sense, in regard of knowing when the Reverend Frank Milvey least\r\ndesired her company, and with promptitude appearing in his little hall.\r\nConsequently, when the Reverend Frank had willingly engaged that he and\r\nhis wife would accompany Lightwood back, he said, as a matter of course:\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We must make haste to get out, Margaretta, my dear, or we shall be\r\ndescended on by Mrs Sprodgkin.\xe2\x80\x99 To which Mrs Milvey replied, in her\r\npleasantly emphatic way, \xe2\x80\x98Oh YES, for she IS such a marplot, Frank, and\r\nDOES worry so!\xe2\x80\x99 Words that were scarcely uttered when their theme\r\nwas announced as in faithful attendance below, desiring counsel on a\r\nspiritual matter. The points on which Mrs Sprodgkin sought elucidation\r\nbeing seldom of a pressing nature (as Who begat Whom, or some\r\ninformation concerning the Amorites), Mrs Milvey on this special\r\noccasion resorted to the device of buying her off with a present of tea\r\nand sugar, and a loaf and butter. These gifts Mrs Sprodgkin accepted,\r\nbut still insisted on dutifully remaining in the hall, to curtsey to the\r\nReverend Frank as he came forth. Who, incautiously saying in his genial\r\nmanner, \xe2\x80\x98Well, Sally, there you are!\xe2\x80\x99 involved himself in a discursive\r\naddress from Mrs Sprodgkin, revolving around the result that she\r\nregarded tea and sugar in the light of myrrh and frankincense, and\r\nconsidered bread and butter identical with locusts and wild honey.\r\nHaving communicated this edifying piece of information, Mrs Sprodgkin\r\nwas left still unadjourned in the hall, and Mr and Mrs Milvey hurried in\r\na heated condition to the railway station. All of which is here recorded\r\nto the honour of that good Christian pair, representatives of hundreds\r\nof other good Christian pairs as conscientious and as useful, who merge\r\nthe smallness of their work in its greatness, and feel in no danger of\r\nlosing dignity when they adapt themselves to incomprehensible humbugs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Detained at the last moment by one who had a claim upon me,\xe2\x80\x99 was the\r\nReverend Frank\xe2\x80\x99s apology to Lightwood, taking no thought of himself.\r\nTo which Mrs Milvey added, taking thought for him, like the championing\r\nlittle wife she was; \xe2\x80\x98Oh yes, detained at the last moment. But AS to\r\nthe claim, Frank, I MUST say that I DO think you are OVER-considerate\r\nsometimes, and allow THAT to be a LITTLE abused.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella felt conscious, in spite of her late pledge for herself, that her\r\nhusband\xe2\x80\x99s absence would give disagreeable occasion for surprise to the\r\nMilveys. Nor could she appear quite at her ease when Mrs Milvey asked:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98HOW is Mr Rokesmith, and IS he gone before us, or DOES he follow us?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt becoming necessary, upon this, to send him to bed again and hold him\r\nin waiting to be lanced again, Bella did it. But not half as well on\r\nthe second occasion as on the first; for, a twice-told white one seems\r\nalmost to become a black one, when you are not used to it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh DEAR!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Milvey, \xe2\x80\x98I am SO sorry! Mr Rokesmith took SUCH an\r\ninterest in Lizzie Hexam, when we were there before. And if we had ONLY\r\nknown of his face, we COULD have given him something that would have\r\nkept it down long enough for so SHORT a purpose.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBy way of making the white one whiter, Bella hastened to stipulate that\r\nhe was not in pain. Mrs Milvey was SO glad of it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know HOW it is,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Milvey, \xe2\x80\x98and I am SURE you don\xe2\x80\x99t,\r\nFrank, but the clergy and their wives seem to CAUSE swelled faces.\r\nWhenever I take notice of a child in the school, it seems to me as if\r\nits face swelled INSTANTLY. Frank NEVER makes acquaintance with a new\r\nold woman, but she gets the face-ache. And another thing is, we DO make\r\nthe poor children sniff so. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know HOW we do it, and I should\r\nbe so glad not to; but the MORE we take notice of them, the MORE they\r\nsniff. Just as they do when the text is given out.--Frank, that\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nschoolmaster. I have seen him somewhere.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe reference was to a young man of reserved appearance, in a coat and\r\nwaistcoat of black, and pantaloons of pepper and salt. He had come\r\ninto the office of the station, from its interior, in an unsettled way,\r\nimmediately after Lightwood had gone out to the train; and he had been\r\nhurriedly reading the printed bills and notices on the wall. He had had\r\na wandering interest in what was said among the people waiting there\r\nand passing to and fro. He had drawn nearer, at about the time when\r\nMrs Milvey mentioned Lizzie Hexam, and had remained near, since: though\r\nalways glancing towards the door by which Lightwood had gone out. He\r\nstood with his back towards them, and his gloved hands clasped behind\r\nhim. There was now so evident a faltering upon him, expressive of\r\nindecision whether or no he should express his having heard himself\r\nreferred to, that Mr Milvey spoke to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I cannot recall your name,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, \xe2\x80\x98but I remember to have seen you\r\nin your school.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My name is Bradley Headstone, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 he replied, backing into a more\r\nretired place.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I ought to have remembered it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Milvey, giving him his hand. \xe2\x80\x98I\r\nhope you are well? A little overworked, I am afraid?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, I am overworked just at present, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Had no play in your last holiday time?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98All work and no play, Mr Headstone, will not make dulness, in your\r\ncase, I dare say; but it will make dyspepsia, if you don\xe2\x80\x99t take care.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I will endeavour to take care, sir. Might I beg leave to speak to you,\r\noutside, a moment?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98By all means.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt was evening, and the office was well lighted. The schoolmaster, who\r\nhad never remitted his watch on Lightwood\xe2\x80\x99s door, now moved by another\r\ndoor to a corner without, where there was more shadow than light; and\r\nsaid, plucking at his gloves:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98One of your ladies, sir, mentioned within my hearing a name that I am\r\nacquainted with; I may say, well acquainted with. The name of the sister\r\nof an old pupil of mine. He was my pupil for a long time, and has got on\r\nand gone upward rapidly. The name of Hexam. The name of Lizzie Hexam.\xe2\x80\x99\r\nHe seemed to be a shy man, struggling against nervousness, and spoke in\r\na very constrained way. The break he set between his last two sentences\r\nwas quite embarrassing to his hearer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mr Milvey. \xe2\x80\x98We are going down to see her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I gathered as much, sir. I hope there is nothing amiss with the sister\r\nof my old pupil? I hope no bereavement has befallen her. I hope she is\r\nin no affliction? Has lost no--relation?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Milvey thought this a man with a very odd manner, and a dark downward\r\nlook; but he answered in his usual open way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am glad to tell you, Mr Headstone, that the sister of your old pupil\r\nhas not sustained any such loss. You thought I might be going down to\r\nbury some one?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That may have been the connexion of ideas, sir, with your clerical\r\ncharacter, but I was not conscious of it.--Then you are not, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nA man with a very odd manner indeed, and with a lurking look that was\r\nquite oppressive.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No. In fact,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Milvey, \xe2\x80\x98since you are so interested in the\r\nsister of your old pupil, I may as well tell you that I am going down to\r\nmarry her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe schoolmaster started back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not to marry her, myself,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Milvey, with a smile, \xe2\x80\x98because I\r\nhave a wife already. To perform the marriage service at her wedding.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBradley Headstone caught hold of a pillar behind him. If Mr Milvey knew\r\nan ashy face when he saw it, he saw it then.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are quite ill, Mr Headstone!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is not much, sir. It will pass over very soon. I am accustomed to be\r\nseized with giddiness. Don\xe2\x80\x99t let me detain you, sir; I stand in need\r\nof no assistance, I thank you. Much obliged by your sparing me these\r\nminutes of your time.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAs Mr Milvey, who had no more minutes to spare, made a suitable reply\r\nand turned back into the office, he observed the schoolmaster to\r\nlean against the pillar with his hat in his hand, and to pull at his\r\nneckcloth as if he were trying to tear it off. The Reverend Frank\r\naccordingly directed the notice of one of the attendants to him, by\r\nsaying: \xe2\x80\x98There is a person outside who seems to be really ill, and to\r\nrequire some help, though he says he does not.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLightwood had by this time secured their places, and the departure-bell\r\nwas about to be rung. They took their seats, and were beginning to\r\nmove out of the station, when the same attendant came running along the\r\nplatform, looking into all the carriages.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh! You are here, sir!\xe2\x80\x99 he said, springing on the step, and holding\r\nthe window-frame by his elbow, as the carriage moved. \xe2\x80\x98That person you\r\npointed out to me is in a fit.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I infer from what he told me that he is subject to such attacks. He\r\nwill come to, in the air, in a little while.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe was took very bad to be sure, and was biting and knocking about him\r\n(the man said) furiously. Would the gentleman give him his card, as he\r\nhad seen him first? The gentleman did so, with the explanation that\r\nhe knew no more of the man attacked than that he was a man of a very\r\nrespectable occupation, who had said he was out of health, as his\r\nappearance would of itself have indicated. The attendant received the\r\ncard, watched his opportunity for sliding down, slid down, and so it\r\nended.\r\n\r\nThen, the train rattled among the house-tops, and among the ragged sides\r\nof houses torn down to make way for it, and over the swarming streets,\r\nand under the fruitful earth, until it shot across the river: bursting\r\nover the quiet surface like a bomb-shell, and gone again as if it had\r\nexploded in the rush of smoke and steam and glare. A little more, and\r\nagain it roared across the river, a great rocket: spurning the watery\r\nturnings and doublings with ineffable contempt, and going straight to\r\nits end, as Father Time goes to his. To whom it is no matter what living\r\nwaters run high or low, reflect the heavenly lights and darknesses,\r\nproduce their little growth of weeds and flowers, turn here, turn there,\r\nare noisy or still, are troubled or at rest, for their course has one\r\nsure termination, though their sources and devices are many.\r\n\r\nThen, a carriage ride succeeded, near the solemn river, stealing away\r\nby night, as all things steal away, by night and by day, so quietly\r\nyielding to the attraction of the loadstone rock of Eternity; and the\r\nnearer they drew to the chamber where Eugene lay, the more they feared\r\nthat they might find his wanderings done. At last they saw its dim light\r\nshining out, and it gave them hope: though Lightwood faltered as he\r\nthought: \xe2\x80\x98If he were gone, she would still be sitting by him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBut he lay quiet, half in stupor, half in sleep. Bella, entering with\r\na raised admonitory finger, kissed Lizzie softly, but said not a word.\r\nNeither did any of them speak, but all sat down at the foot of the bed,\r\nsilently waiting. And now, in this night-watch, mingling with the flow\r\nof the river and with the rush of the train, came the questions into\r\nBella\xe2\x80\x99s mind again: What could be in the depths of that mystery of\r\nJohn\xe2\x80\x99s? Why was it that he had never been seen by Mr Lightwood, whom he\r\nstill avoided? When would that trial come, through which her faith\r\nin, and her duty to, her dear husband, was to carry her, rendering him\r\ntriumphant? For, that had been his term. Her passing through the trial\r\nwas to make the man she loved with all her heart, triumphant. Term not\r\nto sink out of sight in Bella\xe2\x80\x99s breast.\r\n\r\nFar on in the night, Eugene opened his eyes. He was sensible, and said\r\nat once: \xe2\x80\x98How does the time go? Has our Mortimer come back?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLightwood was there immediately, to answer for himself. \xe2\x80\x98Yes, Eugene,\r\nand all is ready.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dear boy!\xe2\x80\x99 returned Eugene with a smile, \xe2\x80\x98we both thank you heartily.\r\nLizzie, tell them how welcome they are, and that I would be eloquent if\r\nI could.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There is no need,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Milvey. \xe2\x80\x98We know it. Are you better, Mr\r\nWrayburn?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am much happier,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Much better too, I hope?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nEugene turned his eyes towards Lizzie, as if to spare her, and answered\r\nnothing.\r\n\r\nThen, they all stood around the bed, and Mr Milvey, opening his book,\r\nbegan the service; so rarely associated with the shadow of death; so\r\ninseparable in the mind from a flush of life and gaiety and hope and\r\nhealth and joy. Bella thought how different from her own sunny little\r\nwedding, and wept. Mrs Milvey overflowed with pity, and wept too. The\r\ndolls\xe2\x80\x99 dressmaker, with her hands before her face, wept in her golden\r\nbower. Reading in a low clear voice, and bending over Eugene, who kept\r\nhis eyes upon him, Mr Milvey did his office with suitable simplicity.\r\nAs the bridegroom could not move his hand, they touched his fingers with\r\nthe ring, and so put it on the bride. When the two plighted their troth,\r\nshe laid her hand on his and kept it there. When the ceremony was done,\r\nand all the rest departed from the room, she drew her arm under his\r\nhead, and laid her own head down upon the pillow by his side.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Undraw the curtains, my dear girl,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, after a while, \xe2\x80\x98and\r\nlet us see our wedding-day.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe sun was rising, and his first rays struck into the room, as she came\r\nback, and put her lips to his. \xe2\x80\x98I bless the day!\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene. \xe2\x80\x98I bless\r\nthe day!\xe2\x80\x99 said Lizzie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have made a poor marriage of it, my sweet wife,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene. \xe2\x80\x98A\r\nshattered graceless fellow, stretched at his length here, and next to\r\nnothing for you when you are a young widow.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have made the marriage that I would have given all the world to dare\r\nto hope for,\xe2\x80\x99 she replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have thrown yourself away,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, shaking his head. \xe2\x80\x98But you\r\nhave followed the treasure of your heart. My justification is, that you\r\nhad thrown that away first, dear girl!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No. I had given it to you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The same thing, my poor Lizzie!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Hush! hush! A very different thing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere were tears in his eyes, and she besought him to close them. \xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Eugene, again shaking his head; \xe2\x80\x98let me look at you, Lizzie, while\r\nI can. You brave devoted girl! You heroine!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHer own eyes filled under his praises. And when he mustered strength to\r\nmove his wounded head a very little way, and lay it on her bosom, the\r\ntears of both fell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lizzie,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, after a silence: \xe2\x80\x98when you see me wandering away\r\nfrom this refuge that I have so ill deserved, speak to me by my name,\r\nand I think I shall come back.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, dear Eugene.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There!\xe2\x80\x99 he exclaimed, smiling. \xe2\x80\x98I should have gone then, but for that!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nA little while afterwards, when he appeared to be sinking into\r\ninsensibility, she said, in a calm loving voice: \xe2\x80\x98Eugene, my dear\r\nhusband!\xe2\x80\x99 He immediately answered: \xe2\x80\x98There again! You see how you can\r\nrecall me!\xe2\x80\x99 And afterwards, when he could not speak, he still answered\r\nby a slight movement of his head upon her bosom.\r\n\r\nThe sun was high in the sky, when she gently disengaged herself to give\r\nhim the stimulants and nourishment he required. The utter helplessness\r\nof the wreck of him that lay cast ashore there, now alarmed her, but he\r\nhimself appeared a little more hopeful.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, my beloved Lizzie!\xe2\x80\x99 he said, faintly. \xe2\x80\x98How shall I ever pay all I\r\nowe you, if I recover!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t be ashamed of me,\xe2\x80\x99 she replied, \xe2\x80\x98and you will have more than paid\r\nall.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It would require a life, Lizzie, to pay all; more than a life.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Live for that, then; live for me, Eugene; live to see how hard I will\r\ntry to improve myself, and never to discredit you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My darling girl,\xe2\x80\x99 he replied, rallying more of his old manner than\r\nhe had ever yet got together. \xe2\x80\x98On the contrary, I have been thinking\r\nwhether it is not the best thing I can do, to die.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The best thing you can do, to leave me with a broken heart?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t mean that, my dear girl. I was not thinking of that. What I was\r\nthinking of was this. Out of your compassion for me, in this maimed and\r\nbroken state, you make so much of me--you think so well of me--you love\r\nme so dearly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Heaven knows I love you dearly!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And Heaven knows I prize it! Well. If I live, you\xe2\x80\x99ll find me out.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall find out that my husband has a mine of purpose and energy, and\r\nwill turn it to the best account?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope so, dearest Lizzie,\xe2\x80\x99 said Eugene, wistfully, and yet somewhat\r\nwhimsically. \xe2\x80\x98I hope so. But I can\xe2\x80\x99t summon the vanity to think so. How\r\ncan I think so, looking back on such a trifling wasted youth as mine! I\r\nhumbly hope it; but I daren\xe2\x80\x99t believe it. There is a sharp misgiving\r\nin my conscience that if I were to live, I should disappoint your good\r\nopinion and my own--and that I ought to die, my dear!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 12\r\n\r\nTHE PASSING SHADOW\r\n\r\n\r\nThe winds and tides rose and fell a certain number of times, the earth\r\nmoved round the sun a certain number of times, the ship upon the ocean\r\nmade her voyage safely, and brought a baby-Bella home. Then who so blest\r\nand happy as Mrs John Rokesmith, saving and excepting Mr John Rokesmith!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Would you not like to be rich NOW, my darling?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How can you ask me such a question, John dear? Am I not rich?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThese were among the first words spoken near the baby Bella as she lay\r\nasleep. She soon proved to be a baby of wonderful intelligence,\r\nevincing the strongest objection to her grandmother\xe2\x80\x99s society, and\r\nbeing invariably seized with a painful acidity of the stomach when that\r\ndignified lady honoured her with any attention.\r\n\r\nIt was charming to see Bella contemplating this baby, and finding out\r\nher own dimples in that tiny reflection, as if she were looking in the\r\nglass without personal vanity. Her cherubic father justly remarked\r\nto her husband that the baby seemed to make her younger than before,\r\nreminding him of the days when she had a pet doll and used to talk to it\r\nas she carried it about. The world might have been challenged to produce\r\nanother baby who had such a store of pleasant nonsense said and sung\r\nto it, as Bella said and sung to this baby; or who was dressed and\r\nundressed as often in four-and-twenty hours as Bella dressed and\r\nundressed this baby; or who was held behind doors and poked out to stop\r\nits father\xe2\x80\x99s way when he came home, as this baby was; or, in a word, who\r\ndid half the number of baby things, through the lively invention of a\r\ngay and proud young mother, that this inexhaustible baby did.\r\n\r\nThe inexhaustible baby was two or three months old, when Bella began to\r\nnotice a cloud upon her husband\xe2\x80\x99s brow. Watching it, she saw a gathering\r\nand deepening anxiety there, which caused her great disquiet. More than\r\nonce, she awoke him muttering in his sleep; and, though he muttered\r\nnothing worse than her own name, it was plain to her that his\r\nrestlessness originated in some load of care. Therefore, Bella at length\r\nput in her claim to divide this load, and hear her half of it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You know, John dear,\xe2\x80\x99 she said, cheerily reverting to their former\r\nconversation, \xe2\x80\x98that I hope I may safely be trusted in great things. And\r\nit surely cannot be a little thing that causes you so much uneasiness.\r\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s very considerate of you to try to hide from me that you are\r\nuncomfortable about something, but it\xe2\x80\x99s quite impossible to be done,\r\nJohn love.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I admit that I am rather uneasy, my own.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then please to tell me what about, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBut no, he evaded that. \xe2\x80\x98Never mind!\xe2\x80\x99 thought Bella, resolutely.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98John requires me to put perfect faith in him, and he shall not be\r\ndisappointed.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe went up to London one day, to meet him, in order that they might\r\nmake some purchases. She found him waiting for her at her journey\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nend, and they walked away together through the streets. He was in gay\r\nspirits, though still harping on that notion of their being rich; and\r\nhe said, now let them make believe that yonder fine carriage was theirs,\r\nand that it was waiting to take them home to a fine house they had; what\r\nwould Bella, in that case, best like to find in the house? Well! Bella\r\ndidn\xe2\x80\x99t know: already having everything she wanted, she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t say.\r\nBut, by degrees she was led on to confess that she would like to have\r\nfor the inexhaustible baby such a nursery as never was seen. It was\r\nto be \xe2\x80\x98a very rainbow for colours\xe2\x80\x99, as she was quite sure baby noticed\r\ncolours; and the staircase was to be adorned with the most exquisite\r\nflowers, as she was absolutely certain baby noticed flowers; and there\r\nwas to be an aviary somewhere, of the loveliest little birds, as there\r\nwas not the smallest doubt in the world that baby noticed birds.\r\nWas there nothing else? No, John dear. The predilections of the\r\ninexhaustible baby being provided for, Bella could think of nothing\r\nelse.\r\n\r\nThey were chatting on in this way, and John had suggested, \xe2\x80\x98No jewels\r\nfor your own wear, for instance?\xe2\x80\x99 and Bella had replied laughing. O! if\r\nhe came to that, yes, there might be a beautiful ivory case of jewels\r\non her dressing-table; when these pictures were in a moment darkened and\r\nblotted out.\r\n\r\nThey turned a corner, and met Mr Lightwood.\r\n\r\nHe stopped as if he were petrified by the sight of Bella\xe2\x80\x99s husband, who\r\nin the same moment had changed colour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Lightwood and I have met before,\xe2\x80\x99 he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Met before, John?\xe2\x80\x99 Bella repeated in a tone of wonder. \xe2\x80\x98Mr Lightwood\r\ntold me he had never seen you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I did not then know that I had,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lightwood, discomposed on her\r\naccount. \xe2\x80\x98I believed that I had only heard of--Mr Rokesmith.\xe2\x80\x99 With an\r\nemphasis on the name.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When Mr Lightwood saw me, my love,\xe2\x80\x99 observed her husband, not avoiding\r\nhis eye, but looking at him, \xe2\x80\x98my name was Julius Handford.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJulius Handford! The name that Bella had so often seen in old\r\nnewspapers, when she was an inmate of Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s house! Julius\r\nHandford, who had been publicly entreated to appear, and for\r\nintelligence of whom a reward had been publicly offered!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I would have avoided mentioning it in your presence,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lightwood to\r\nBella, delicately; \xe2\x80\x98but since your husband mentions it himself, I must\r\nconfirm his strange admission. I saw him as Mr Julius Handford, and I\r\nafterwards (unquestionably to his knowledge) took great pains to trace\r\nhim out.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Quite true. But it was not my object or my interest,\xe2\x80\x99 said Rokesmith,\r\nquietly, \xe2\x80\x98to be traced out.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella looked from the one to the other, in amazement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Lightwood,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued her husband, \xe2\x80\x98as chance has brought us face to\r\nface at last--which is not to be wondered at, for the wonder is, that,\r\nin spite of all my pains to the contrary, chance has not confronted\r\nus together sooner--I have only to remind you that you have been at my\r\nhouse, and to add that I have not changed my residence.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sir\xe2\x80\x99 returned Lightwood, with a meaning glance towards Bella, \xe2\x80\x98my\r\nposition is a truly painful one. I hope that no complicity in a very\r\ndark transaction may attach to you, but you cannot fail to know that\r\nyour own extraordinary conduct has laid you under suspicion.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know it has,\xe2\x80\x99 was all the reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My professional duty,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lightwood hesitating, with another glance\r\ntowards Bella, \xe2\x80\x98is greatly at variance with my personal inclination; but\r\nI doubt, Mr Handford, or Mr Rokesmith, whether I am justified in taking\r\nleave of you here, with your whole course unexplained.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella caught her husband by the hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t be alarmed, my darling. Mr Lightwood will find that he is quite\r\njustified in taking leave of me here. At all events,\xe2\x80\x99 added Rokesmith,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98he will find that I mean to take leave of him here.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Lightwood, \xe2\x80\x98you can scarcely deny that when I came\r\nto your house on the occasion to which you have referred, you avoided me\r\nof a set purpose.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Lightwood, I assure you I have no disposition to deny it, or\r\nintention to deny it. I should have continued to avoid you, in pursuance\r\nof the same set purpose, for a short time longer, if we had not met now.\r\nI am going straight home, and shall remain at home to-morrow until noon.\r\nHereafter, I hope we may be better acquainted. Good-day.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLightwood stood irresolute, but Bella\xe2\x80\x99s husband passed him in the\r\nsteadiest manner, with Bella on his arm; and they went home without\r\nencountering any further remonstrance or molestation from any one.\r\n\r\nWhen they had dined and were alone, John Rokesmith said to his wife, who\r\nhad preserved her cheerfulness: \xe2\x80\x98And you don\xe2\x80\x99t ask me, my dear, why I\r\nbore that name?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, John love. I should dearly like to know, of course;\xe2\x80\x99 (which her\r\nanxious face confirmed;) \xe2\x80\x98but I wait until you can tell me of your own\r\nfree will. You asked me if I could have perfect faith in you, and I said\r\nyes, and I meant it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt did not escape Bella\xe2\x80\x99s notice that he began to look triumphant. She\r\nwanted no strengthening in her firmness; but if she had had need of any,\r\nshe would have derived it from his kindling face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You cannot have been prepared, my dearest, for such a discovery as that\r\nthis mysterious Mr Handford was identical with your husband?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, John dear, of course not. But you told me to prepare to be tried,\r\nand I prepared myself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe drew her to nestle closer to him, and told her it would soon be over,\r\nand the truth would soon appear. \xe2\x80\x98And now,\xe2\x80\x99 he went on, \xe2\x80\x98lay stress,\r\nmy dear, on these words that I am going to add. I stand in no kind of\r\nperil, and I can by possibility be hurt at no one\xe2\x80\x99s hand.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are quite, quite sure of that, John dear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not a hair of my head! Moreover, I have done no wrong, and have injured\r\nno man. Shall I swear it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, John!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Bella, laying her hand upon his lips, with a proud\r\nlook. \xe2\x80\x98Never to me!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But circumstances,\xe2\x80\x99 he went on \xe2\x80\x98--I can, and I will, disperse them in\r\na moment--have surrounded me with one of the strangest suspicions ever\r\nknown. You heard Mr Lightwood speak of a dark transaction?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, John.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are prepared to hear explicitly what he meant?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, John.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My life, he meant the murder of John Harmon, your allotted husband.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith a fast palpitating heart, Bella grasped him by the arm. \xe2\x80\x98You cannot\r\nbe suspected, John?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dear love, I can be--for I am!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere was silence between them, as she sat looking in his face, with the\r\ncolour quite gone from her own face and lips. \xe2\x80\x98How dare they!\xe2\x80\x99 she cried\r\nat length, in a burst of generous indignation. \xe2\x80\x98My beloved husband, how\r\ndare they!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe caught her in his arms as she opened hers, and held her to his heart.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Even knowing this, you can trust me, Bella?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can trust you, John dear, with all my soul. If I could not trust you,\r\nI should fall dead at your feet.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe kindling triumph in his face was bright indeed, as he looked up and\r\nrapturously exclaimed, what had he done to deserve the blessing of this\r\ndear confiding creature\xe2\x80\x99s heart! Again she put her hand upon his lips,\r\nsaying, \xe2\x80\x98Hush!\xe2\x80\x99 and then told him, in her own little natural pathetic\r\nway, that if all the world were against him, she would be for him; that\r\nif all the world repudiated him, she would believe him; that if he were\r\ninfamous in other eyes, he would be honoured in hers; and that, under\r\nthe worst unmerited suspicion, she could devote her life to consoling\r\nhim, and imparting her own faith in him to their little child.\r\n\r\nA twilight calm of happiness then succeeding to their radiant noon, they\r\nremained at peace, until a strange voice in the room startled them both.\r\nThe room being by that time dark, the voice said, \xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t let the lady\r\nbe alarmed by my striking a light,\xe2\x80\x99 and immediately a match rattled, and\r\nglimmered in a hand. The hand and the match and the voice were then seen\r\nby John Rokesmith to belong to Mr Inspector, once meditatively active in\r\nthis chronicle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I take the liberty,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector, in a business-like manner, \xe2\x80\x98to\r\nbring myself to the recollection of Mr Julius Handford, who gave me his\r\nname and address down at our place a considerable time ago. Would the\r\nlady object to my lighting the pair of candles on the chimneypiece, to\r\nthrow a further light upon the subject? No? Thank you, ma\xe2\x80\x99am. Now, we\r\nlook cheerful.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Inspector, in a dark-blue buttoned-up frock coat and pantaloons,\r\npresented a serviceable, half-pay, Royal Arms kind of appearance, as he\r\napplied his pocket handkerchief to his nose and bowed to the lady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You favoured me, Mr Handford,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector, \xe2\x80\x98by writing down your\r\nname and address, and I produce the piece of paper on which you wrote\r\nit. Comparing the same with the writing on the fly-leaf of this book on\r\nthe table--and a sweet pretty volume it is--I find the writing of the\r\nentry, \xe2\x80\x9cMrs John Rokesmith. From her husband on her birthday\xe2\x80\x9d--and very\r\ngratifying to the feelings such memorials are--to correspond exactly.\r\nCan I have a word with you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly. Here, if you please,\xe2\x80\x99 was the reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why,\xe2\x80\x99 retorted Mr Inspector, again using his pocket handkerchief,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98though there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing for the lady to be at all alarmed at, still,\r\nladies are apt to take alarm at matters of business--being of that\r\nfragile sex that they\xe2\x80\x99re not accustomed to them when not of a strictly\r\ndomestic character--and I do generally make it a rule to propose\r\nretirement from the presence of ladies, before entering upon business\r\ntopics. Or perhaps,\xe2\x80\x99 Mr Inspector hinted, \xe2\x80\x98if the lady was to step\r\nup-stairs, and take a look at baby now!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mrs Rokesmith,\xe2\x80\x99--her husband was beginning; when Mr Inspector,\r\nregarding the words as an introduction, said, \xe2\x80\x98Happy I am sure, to have\r\nthe honour.\xe2\x80\x99 And bowed, with gallantry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mrs Rokesmith,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed her husband, \xe2\x80\x98is satisfied that she can have no\r\nreason for being alarmed, whatever the business is.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Really? Is that so?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector. \xe2\x80\x98But it\xe2\x80\x99s a sex to live and\r\nlearn from, and there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing a lady can\xe2\x80\x99t accomplish when she once\r\nfully gives her mind to it. It\xe2\x80\x99s the case with my own wife. Well, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\r\nthis good gentleman of yours has given rise to a rather large amount\r\nof trouble which might have been avoided if he had come forward and\r\nexplained himself. Well you see! He DIDN\xe2\x80\x99T come forward and explain\r\nhimself. Consequently, now that we meet, him and me, you\xe2\x80\x99ll say--and say\r\nright--that there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing to be alarmed at, in my proposing to him\r\nTO come forward--or, putting the same meaning in another form, to come\r\nalong with me--and explain himself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWhen Mr Inspector put it in that other form, \xe2\x80\x98to come along with me,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nthere was a relishing roll in his voice, and his eye beamed with an\r\nofficial lustre.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you propose to take me into custody?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired John Rokesmith, very\r\ncoolly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why argue?\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mr Inspector in a comfortable sort of\r\nremonstrance; \xe2\x80\x98ain\xe2\x80\x99t it enough that I propose that you shall come along\r\nwith me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98For what reason?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lord bless my soul and body!\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mr Inspector, \xe2\x80\x98I wonder at it in\r\na man of your education. Why argue?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you charge against me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wonder at you before a lady,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector, shaking his head\r\nreproachfully: \xe2\x80\x98I wonder, brought up as you have been, you haven\xe2\x80\x99t a\r\nmore delicate mind! I charge you, then, with being some way concerned\r\nin the Harmon Murder. I don\xe2\x80\x99t say whether before, or in, or after, the\r\nfact. I don\xe2\x80\x99t say whether with having some knowledge of it that hasn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ncome out.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t surprise me. I foresaw your visit this afternoon.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector. \xe2\x80\x98Why, why argue? It\xe2\x80\x99s my duty to inform you\r\nthat whatever you say, will be used against you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t think it will.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I tell you it will,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector. \xe2\x80\x98Now, having received the\r\ncaution, do you still say that you foresaw my visit this afternoon?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. And I will say something more, if you will step with me into the\r\nnext room.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith a reassuring kiss on the lips of the frightened Bella, her husband\r\n(to whom Mr Inspector obligingly offered his arm), took up a candle, and\r\nwithdrew with that gentleman. They were a full half-hour in conference.\r\nWhen they returned, Mr Inspector looked considerably astonished.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have invited this worthy officer, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said John, \xe2\x80\x98to make a\r\nshort excursion with me in which you shall be a sharer. He will take\r\nsomething to eat and drink, I dare say, on your invitation, while you\r\nare getting your bonnet on.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Inspector declined eating, but assented to the proposal of a glass of\r\nbrandy and water. Mixing this cold, and pensively consuming it, he broke\r\nat intervals into such soliloquies as that he never did know such a\r\nmove, that he never had been so gravelled, and that what a game was\r\nthis to try the sort of stuff a man\xe2\x80\x99s opinion of himself was made\r\nof! Concurrently with these comments, he more than once burst out a\r\nlaughing, with the half-enjoying and half-piqued air of a man, who\r\nhad given up a good conundrum, after much guessing, and been told the\r\nanswer. Bella was so timid of him, that she noted these things in a\r\nhalf-shrinking, half-perceptive way, and similarly noted that there was\r\na great change in his manner towards John. That coming-along-with-him\r\ndeportment was now lost in long musing looks at John and at herself and\r\nsometimes in slow heavy rubs of his hand across his forehead, as if he\r\nwere ironing cut the creases which his deep pondering made there. He had\r\nhad some coughing and whistling satellites secretly gravitating towards\r\nhim about the premises, but they were now dismissed, and he eyed John as\r\nif he had meant to do him a public service, but had unfortunately been\r\nanticipated. Whether Bella might have noted anything more, if she\r\nhad been less afraid of him, she could not determine; but it was all\r\ninexplicable to her, and not the faintest flash of the real state of the\r\ncase broke in upon her mind. Mr Inspector\xe2\x80\x99s increased notice of herself\r\nand knowing way of raising his eyebrows when their eyes by any chance\r\nmet, as if he put the question \xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you see?\xe2\x80\x99 augmented her timidity,\r\nand, consequently, her perplexity. For all these reasons, when he\r\nand she and John, at towards nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock of a winter evening went to\r\nLondon, and began driving from London Bridge, among low-lying water-side\r\nwharves and docks and strange places, Bella was in the state of a\r\ndreamer; perfectly unable to account for her being there, perfectly\r\nunable to forecast what would happen next, or whither she was going, or\r\nwhy; certain of nothing in the immediate present, but that she confided\r\nin John, and that John seemed somehow to be getting more triumphant. But\r\nwhat a certainty was that!\r\n\r\nThey alighted at last at the corner of a court, where there was a\r\nbuilding with a bright lamp and wicket gate. Its orderly appearance was\r\nvery unlike that of the surrounding neighbourhood, and was explained by\r\nthe inscription POLICE STATION.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We are not going in here, John?\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, clinging to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, my dear; but of our own accord. We shall come out again as easily,\r\nnever fear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe whitewashed room was pure white as of old, the methodical\r\nbook-keeping was in peaceful progress as of old, and some distant howler\r\nwas banging against a cell door as of old. The sanctuary was not a\r\npermanent abiding-place, but a kind of criminal Pickford\xe2\x80\x99s. The lower\r\npassions and vices were regularly ticked off in the books, warehoused in\r\nthe cells, carted away as per accompanying invoice, and left little mark\r\nupon it.\r\n\r\nMr Inspector placed two chairs for his visitors, before the fire, and\r\ncommuned in a low voice with a brother of his order (also of a half-pay,\r\nand Royal Arms aspect), who, judged only by his occupation at the\r\nmoment, might have been a writing-master, setting copies. Their\r\nconference done, Mr Inspector returned to the fireplace, and, having\r\nobserved that he would step round to the Fellowships and see how matters\r\nstood, went out. He soon came back again, saying, \xe2\x80\x98Nothing could be\r\nbetter, for they\xe2\x80\x99re at supper with Miss Abbey in the bar;\xe2\x80\x99 and then they\r\nall three went out together.\r\n\r\nStill, as in a dream, Bella found herself entering a snug old-fashioned\r\npublic-house, and found herself smuggled into a little three-cornered\r\nroom nearly opposite the bar of that establishment. Mr Inspector\r\nachieved the smuggling of herself and John into this queer room, called\r\nCosy in an inscription on the door, by entering in the narrow passage\r\nfirst in order, and suddenly turning round upon them with extended arms,\r\nas if they had been two sheep. The room was lighted for their reception.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Inspector to John, turning the gas lower; \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll mix with\r\n\xe2\x80\x98em in a casual way, and when I say Identification, perhaps you\xe2\x80\x99ll show\r\nyourself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJohn nodded, and Mr Inspector went alone to the half-door of the bar.\r\nFrom the dim doorway of Cosy, within which Bella and her husband stood,\r\nthey could see a comfortable little party of three persons sitting at\r\nsupper in the bar, and could hear everything that was said.\r\n\r\nThe three persons were Miss Abbey and two male guests. To whom\r\ncollectively, Mr Inspector remarked that the weather was getting sharp\r\nfor the time of year.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It need be sharp to suit your wits, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Abbey. \xe2\x80\x98What have\r\nyou got in hand now?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thanking you for your compliment: not much, Miss Abbey,\xe2\x80\x99 was Mr\r\nInspector\xe2\x80\x99s rejoinder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who have you got in Cosy?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Miss Abbey.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Only a gentleman and his wife, Miss.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And who are they? If one may ask it without detriment to your deep\r\nplans in the interests of the honest public?\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Abbey, proud of\r\nMr Inspector as an administrative genius.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They are strangers in this part of the town, Miss Abbey. They are\r\nwaiting till I shall want the gentleman to show himself somewhere, for\r\nhalf a moment.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98While they\xe2\x80\x99re waiting,\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Abbey, \xe2\x80\x98couldn\xe2\x80\x99t you join us?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Inspector immediately slipped into the bar, and sat down at the side\r\nof the half-door, with his back towards the passage, and directly facing\r\nthe two guests. \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t take my supper till later in the night,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nhe, \xe2\x80\x98and therefore I won\xe2\x80\x99t disturb the compactness of the table. But\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll take a glass of flip, if that\xe2\x80\x99s flip in the jug in the fender.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s flip,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Miss Abbey, \xe2\x80\x98and it\xe2\x80\x99s my making, and if even you\r\ncan find out better, I shall be glad to know where.\xe2\x80\x99 Filling him, with\r\nhospitable hands, a steaming tumbler, Miss Abbey replaced the jug by\r\nthe fire; the company not having yet arrived at the flip-stage of their\r\nsupper, but being as yet skirmishing with strong ale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah--h!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mr Inspector. \xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s the smack! There\xe2\x80\x99s not a Detective\r\nin the Force, Miss Abbey, that could find out better stuff than that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Glad to hear you say so,\xe2\x80\x99 rejoined Miss Abbey. \xe2\x80\x98You ought to know, if\r\nanybody does.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Job Potterson,\xe2\x80\x99 Mr Inspector continued, \xe2\x80\x98I drink your health. Mr\r\nJacob Kibble, I drink yours. Hope you have made a prosperous voyage\r\nhome, gentlemen both.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Kibble, an unctuous broad man of few words and many mouthfuls, said,\r\nmore briefly than pointedly, raising his ale to his lips: \xe2\x80\x98Same to you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\nMr Job Potterson, a semi-seafaring man of obliging demeanour, said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Lord bless my soul and body!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mr Inspector. \xe2\x80\x98Talk of trades, Miss\r\nAbbey, and the way they set their marks on men\xe2\x80\x99 (a subject which nobody\r\nhad approached); \xe2\x80\x98who wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t know your brother to be a Steward!\r\nThere\xe2\x80\x99s a bright and ready twinkle in his eye, there\xe2\x80\x99s a neatness in his\r\naction, there\xe2\x80\x99s a smartness in his figure, there\xe2\x80\x99s an air of reliability\r\nabout him in case you wanted a basin, which points out the steward! Welcome to your house and home, my deary!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 13\r\n\r\nSHOWING HOW THE GOLDEN DUSTMAN HELPED TO SCATTER DUST\r\n\r\n\r\nIn all the first bewilderment of her wonder, the most bewilderingly\r\nwonderful thing to Bella was the shining countenance of Mr Boffin. These two, whom I come to life to disappoint and dispossess,\r\ncry for joy!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella looked at him confusedly, and looked again at Mrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s radiant\r\nface.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s right, my dear, don\xe2\x80\x99t you mind him,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98stick\r\nto me. John, he tells us how he is despairing in his mind on\r\naccounts of a certain fair young person, and how, if I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t found him\r\nout, he was going away to seek his fortune far and wide, and had fully\r\nmeant never to come to life, but to leave the property as our wrongful\r\ninheritance for ever and a day. At which you never see a man so\r\nfrightened as my Noddy was. For to think that he should have come into\r\nthe property wrongful, however innocent, and--more than that--might have\r\ngone on keeping it to his dying day, turned him whiter than chalk.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And you too,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you mind him, neither, my deary,\xe2\x80\x99 resumed Mrs Boffin; \xe2\x80\x98stick\r\nto me. This brings up a confabulation regarding the certain fair young\r\nperson; when Noddy he gives it as his opinion that she is a deary\r\ncreetur. \xe2\x80\x9cShe may be a leetle spoilt, and nat\xe2\x80\x99rally spoilt,\xe2\x80\x9d he says,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cby circumstances, but that\xe2\x80\x99s only the surface, and I lay my life,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsays, \xe2\x80\x9cthat she\xe2\x80\x99s the true golden gold at heart.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So did you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you mind him a single morsel, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 proceeded Mrs Boffin,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98but stick to me. Then says John, O, if he could but prove so! Then we\r\nboth of us ups and says, that minute, \xe2\x80\x9cProve so!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith a start, Bella directed a hurried glance towards Mr Boffin. But,\r\nhe was sitting thoughtfully smiling at that broad brown hand of his, and\r\neither didn\xe2\x80\x99t see it, or would take no notice of it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cProve it, John!\xe2\x80\x9d we says,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Mrs Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cProve it and\r\novercome your doubts with triumph, and be happy for the first time in\r\nyour life, and for the rest of your life.\xe2\x80\x9d This puts John in a state,\r\nto be sure. Then we says, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat will content you? If she was to stand up\r\nfor you when you was slighted, if she was to show herself of a generous\r\nmind when you was oppressed, if she was to be truest to you when you was\r\npoorest and friendliest, and all this against her own seeming interest,\r\nhow would that do?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cDo?\xe2\x80\x9d says John, \xe2\x80\x9cit would raise me to the skies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n \xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d says my Noddy, \xe2\x80\x9cmake your preparations for the ascent, John, it\r\nbeing my firm belief that up you go!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella caught Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s twinkling eye for half an instant; but he got\r\nit away from her, and restored it to his broad brown hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98From the first, you was always a special favourite of Noddy\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nMrs Boffin, shaking her head. \xe2\x80\x98O you were! And if I had been inclined\r\nto be jealous, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what I mightn\xe2\x80\x99t have done to you. But the horses is coming round the\r\ncorner. Well! Then says my Noddy, shaking his sides till he was fit to\r\nmake \xe2\x80\x98em ache again: \xe2\x80\x9cLook out for being slighted and oppressed, John,\r\nfor if ever a man had a hard master, you shall find me from this present\r\ntime to be such to you.\xe2\x80\x9d And then he began!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mrs Boffin, in an\r\necstacy of admiration. \xe2\x80\x98Lord bless you, then he began! And how he DID\r\nbegin; didn\xe2\x80\x99t he!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella looked half frightened, and yet half laughed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But, bless you,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued Mrs Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98if you could have seen him of a\r\nnight, at that time of it! The way he\xe2\x80\x99d sit and chuckle over himself!\r\nThe way he\xe2\x80\x99d say \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been a regular brown bear to-day,\xe2\x80\x9d and take\r\nhimself in his arms and hug himself at the thoughts of the brute he had\r\npretended. I\r\nmust wait a little longer.\xe2\x80\x9d Then, when baby was expected, he says, \xe2\x80\x9cShe\r\nis such a cheerful, glorious housewife that I can\xe2\x80\x99t afford to be rich\r\nyet. I must wait a little longer.\xe2\x80\x9d And so he goes on and on, till I says\r\noutright, \xe2\x80\x9cNow, John, if you don\xe2\x80\x99t fix a time for setting her up in her\r\nown house and home, and letting us walk out of it, I\xe2\x80\x99ll turn Informer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n Then he says he\xe2\x80\x99ll only wait to triumph beyond what we ever thought\r\npossible, and to show her to us better than even we ever supposed; and\r\nhe says, \xe2\x80\x9cShe shall see me under suspicion of having murdered myself,\r\nand YOU shall see how trusting and how true she\xe2\x80\x99ll be.\xe2\x80\x9d Well! Noddy and\r\nme agreed to that, and he was right, and here you are, and the horses is\r\nin, and the story is done, and God bless you my Beauty, and God bless us\r\nall!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe pile of hands dispersed, and Bella and Mrs Boffin took a good long\r\nhug of one another: to the apparent peril of the inexhaustible baby,\r\nlying staring in Bella\xe2\x80\x99s lap.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But IS the story done?\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, pondering. \xe2\x80\x98Is there no more of\r\nit?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What more of it should there be, deary?\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mrs Boffin, full of\r\nglee.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you sure you have left nothing out of it?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Bella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t think I have,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Boffin, archly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98John dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, \xe2\x80\x98you\xe2\x80\x99re a good nurse; will you please hold\r\nbaby?\xe2\x80\x99 Having deposited the Inexhaustible in his arms with those words,\r\nBella looked hard at Mr Boffin, who had moved to a table where he was\r\nleaning his head upon his hand with his face turned away, and, quietly\r\nsettling herself on her knees at his side, and drawing one arm over his\r\nshoulder, said: \xe2\x80\x98Please I beg your pardon, and I made a small mistake of\r\na word when I took leave of you last. Please I think you are better (not\r\nworse) than Hopkins, better (not worse) than Dancer, better (not worse)\r\nthan Blackberry Jones, better (not worse) than any of them! Please\r\nsomething more!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Bella, with an exultant ringing laugh as she\r\nstruggled with him and forced him to turn his delighted face to hers.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Please I have found out something not yet mentioned. Please I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nbelieve you are a hard-hearted miser at all, and please I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe\r\nyou ever for one single minute were!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAt this, Mrs Boffin fairly screamed with rapture, and sat beating her\r\nfeet upon the floor, clapping her hands, and bobbing herself backwards\r\nand forwards, like a demented member of some Mandarin\xe2\x80\x99s family.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O, I understand you now, sir!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Bella. \xe2\x80\x98I want neither you nor any\r\none else to tell me the rest of the story. I can tell it to YOU, now, if\r\nyou would like to hear it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Can you, my dear?\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin. \xe2\x80\x98Tell it then.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What?\xe2\x80\x99 cried Bella, holding him prisoner by the coat with both hands.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When you saw what a greedy little wretch you were the patron of, you\r\ndetermined to show her how much misused and misprized riches could\r\ndo, and often had done, to spoil people; did you? Not caring what she\r\nthought of you (and Goodness knows THAT was of no consequence!) you\r\nshowed her, in yourself, the most detestable sides of wealth, saying in\r\nyour own mind, \xe2\x80\x9cThis shallow creature would never work the truth out of\r\nher own weak soul, if she had a hundred years to do it in; but a glaring\r\ninstance kept before her may open even her eyes and set her thinking.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n That was what you said to yourself, was it, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I never said anything of the sort,\xe2\x80\x99 Mr Boffin declared in a state of\r\nthe highest enjoyment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then you ought to have said it, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Bella, giving him two\r\npulls and one kiss, \xe2\x80\x98for you must have thought and meant it. You saw\r\nthat good fortune was turning my stupid head and hardening my silly\r\nheart--was making me grasping, calculating, insolent, insufferable--and\r\nyou took the pains to be the dearest and kindest fingerpost that ever\r\nwas set up anywhere, pointing out the road that I was taking and the end\r\nit led to. Confess instantly!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98John,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, one broad piece of sunshine from head to foot,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wish you\xe2\x80\x99d help me out of this.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You can\xe2\x80\x99t be heard by counsel, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Bella. \xe2\x80\x98You must speak\r\nfor yourself. Confess instantly!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98the truth is, that when we did go in\r\nfor the little scheme that my old lady has pinted out, I did put it to\r\nJohn, what did he think of going in for some such general scheme as YOU\r\nhave pinted out? But I didn\xe2\x80\x99t in any way so word it, because I didn\xe2\x80\x99t in\r\nany way so mean it. I only said to John, wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t it be more consistent,\r\nme going in for being a reg\xe2\x80\x99lar brown bear respecting him, to go in as a\r\nreg\xe2\x80\x99lar brown bear all round?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Confess this minute, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, \xe2\x80\x98that you did it to correct and\r\namend me!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly, my dear child,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98I didn\xe2\x80\x99t do it to harm you;\r\nyou may be sure of that. And I did hope it might just hint a caution.\r\nStill, it ought to be mentioned that no sooner had my old lady found out\r\nJohn, than John made known to her and me that he had had his eye upon a\r\nthankless person by the name of Silas Wegg. Partly for the punishment of\r\nwhich Wegg, by leading him on in a very unhandsome and underhanded\r\ngame that he was playing, them books that you and me bought so many\r\nof together (and, by-the-by, my dear, he wasn\xe2\x80\x99t Blackberry Jones, but\r\nBlewberry) was read aloud to me by that person of the name of Silas Wegg\r\naforesaid.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBella, who was still on her knees at Mr Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s feet, gradually sank\r\ndown into a sitting posture on the ground, as she meditated more and\r\nmore thoughtfully, with her eyes upon his beaming face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Still,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella, after this meditative pause, \xe2\x80\x98there remain two\r\nthings that I cannot understand. Mrs Boffin never supposed any part of\r\nthe change in Mr Boffin to be real; did she?--You never did; did you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\nasked Bella, turning to her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No!\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mrs Boffin, with a most rotund and glowing negative.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And yet you took it very much to heart,\xe2\x80\x99 said Bella. \xe2\x80\x98I remember its\r\nmaking you very uneasy, indeed.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ecod, you see Mrs John has a sharp eye, John!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mr Boffin, shaking\r\nhis head with an admiring air. \xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re right, my dear. The old lady\r\nnearly blowed us into shivers and smithers, many times.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Bella. \xe2\x80\x98How did that happen, when she was in your secret?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, it was a weakness in the old lady,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin; \xe2\x80\x98and yet, to\r\ntell you the whole truth and nothing but the truth, I\xe2\x80\x99m rather proud of\r\nit. My dear, the old lady thinks so high of me that she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t abear\r\nto see and hear me coming out as a reg\xe2\x80\x99lar brown one. Couldn\xe2\x80\x99t abear\r\nto make-believe as I meant it! In consequence of which, we was\r\neverlastingly in danger with her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs Boffin laughed heartily at herself; but a certain glistening in her\r\nhonest eyes revealed that she was by no means cured of that dangerous\r\npropensity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I assure you, my dear,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Boffin, \xe2\x80\x98that on the celebrated\r\nday when I made what has since been agreed upon to be my grandest\r\ndemonstration--I allude to Mew says the cat, Quack quack says the\r\nduck, and Bow-wow-wow says the dog--I assure you, my dear, that on that\r\ncelebrated day, them flinty and unbelieving words hit my old lady so hard\r\non my account, that I had to hold her, to prevent her running out after\r\nyou, and defending me by saying I was playing a part.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs Boffin laughed heartily again, and her eyes glistened again, and\r\nit then appeared, not only that in that burst of sarcastic eloquence\r\nMr Boffin was considered by his two fellow-conspirators to have outdone\r\nhimself, but that in his own opinion it was a remarkable achievement.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Never thought of it afore the moment, my dear!\xe2\x80\x99 he observed to Bella.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When John said, if he had been so happy as to win your affections and\r\npossess your heart, it come into my head to turn round upon him with\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWin her affections and possess her heart! Mew says the cat, Quack quack\r\nsays the duck, and Bow-wow-wow says the dog.\xe2\x80\x9d I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t tell you how\r\nit come into my head or where from, but it had so much the sound of a\r\nrasper that I own to you it astonished myself. I was awful nigh bursting\r\nout a laughing though, when it made John stare!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You said, my pretty,\xe2\x80\x99 Mrs Boffin reminded Bella, \xe2\x80\x98that there was one\r\nother thing you couldn\xe2\x80\x99t understand.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O yes!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Bella, covering her face with her hands; \xe2\x80\x98but that I\r\nnever shall be able to understand as long as I live. It is, how John\r\ncould love me so when I so little deserved it, and how you, Mr and Mrs\r\nBoffin, could be so forgetful of yourselves, and take such pains and\r\ntrouble, to make me a little better, and after all to help him to so\r\nunworthy a wife. But I am very very grateful.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt was John Harmon\xe2\x80\x99s turn then--John Harmon now for good, and John\r\nRokesmith for nevermore--to plead with her (quite unnecessarily) in\r\nbehalf of his deception, and to tell her, over and over again, that it\r\nhad been prolonged by her own winning graces in her supposed station of\r\nlife. This led on to many interchanges of endearment and enjoyment\r\non all sides, in the midst of which the Inexhaustible being observed\r\nstaring, in a most imbecile manner, on Mrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s breast, was\r\npronounced to be supernaturally intelligent as to the whole transaction,\r\nand was made to declare to the ladies and gemplemorums, with a wave of\r\nthe speckled fist (with difficulty detached from an exceedingly short\r\nwaist), \xe2\x80\x98I have already informed my venerable Ma that I know all about\r\nit!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThen, said John Harmon, would Mrs John Harmon come and see her house?\r\nAnd a dainty house it was, and a tastefully beautiful; and they went\r\nthrough it in procession; the Inexhaustible on Mrs Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s bosom (still\r\nstaring) occupying the middle station, and Mr Boffin bringing up the\r\nrear. And on Bella\xe2\x80\x99s exquisite toilette table was an ivory casket, and\r\nin the casket were jewels the like of which she had never dreamed of,\r\nand aloft on an upper floor was a nursery garnished as with rainbows;\r\n\xe2\x80\x98though we were hard put to it,\xe2\x80\x99 said John Harmon, \xe2\x80\x98to get it done in so\r\nshort a time.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe house inspected, emissaries removed the Inexhaustible, who was\r\nshortly afterwards heard screaming among the rainbows; whereupon Bella\r\nwithdrew herself from the presence and knowledge of gemplemorums, and\r\nthe screaming ceased, and smiling Peace associated herself with that\r\nyoung olive branch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come and look in, Noddy!\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Boffin to Mr Boffin.\r\n\r\nMr Boffin, submitting to be led on tiptoe to the nursery door, looked in\r\nwith immense satisfaction, although there was nothing to see but Bella\r\nin a musing state of happiness, seated in a little low chair upon the\r\nhearth, with her child in her fair young arms, and her soft eyelashes\r\nshading her eyes from the fire.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It looks as if the old man\xe2\x80\x99s spirit had found rest at last; don\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Mrs Boffin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, old lady.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And as if his money had turned bright again, after a long long rust in\r\nthe dark, and was at last a beginning to sparkle in the sunlight?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, old lady.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And it makes a pretty and a promising picter; don\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, old lady.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBut, aware at the instant of a fine opening for a point, Mr Boffin\r\nquenched that observation in this--delivered in the grisliest growling\r\nof the regular brown bear. \xe2\x80\x98A pretty and a hopeful picter? Mew,\r\nQuack quack, Bow-wow!\xe2\x80\x99 And then trotted silently downstairs, with his\r\nshoulders in a state of the liveliest commotion.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter 14\r\n\r\nCHECKMATE TO THE FRIENDLY MOVE\r\n\r\n\r\nMr and Mrs John Harmon had so timed their taking possession of their\r\nrightful name and their London house, that the event befel on the very\r\nday when the last waggon-load of the last Mound was driven out at the\r\ngates of Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s Bower. As it jolted away, Mr Wegg felt that the\r\nlast load was correspondingly removed from his mind, and hailed the\r\nauspicious season when that black sheep, Boffin, was to be closely\r\nsheared.\r\n\r\nOver the whole slow process of levelling the Mounds, Silas had kept\r\nwatch with rapacious eyes. But, eyes no less rapacious had watched the\r\ngrowth of the Mounds in years bygone, and had vigilantly sifted the dust\r\nof which they were composed. No valuables turned up. How should there\r\nbe any, seeing that the old hard jailer of Harmony Jail had coined every\r\nwaif and stray into money, long before?\r\n\r\nThough disappointed by this bare result, Mr Wegg felt too sensibly\r\nrelieved by the close of the labour, to grumble to any great extent.\r\nA foreman-representative of the dust contractors, purchasers of the\r\nMounds, had worn Mr Wegg down to skin and bone. This supervisor of the\r\nproceedings, asserting his employers\xe2\x80\x99 rights to cart off by daylight,\r\nnightlight, torchlight, when they would, must have been the death of\r\nSilas if the work had lasted much longer. Seeming never to need sleep\r\nhimself, he would reappear, with a tied-up broken head, in fantail hat\r\nand velveteen smalls, like an accursed goblin, at the most unholy and\r\nuntimely hours. Tired out by keeping close ward over a long day\xe2\x80\x99s work\r\nin fog and rain, Silas would have just crawled to bed and be dozing,\r\nwhen a horrid shake and rumble under his pillow would announce an\r\napproaching train of carts, escorted by this Demon of Unrest, to fall to\r\nwork again. At another time, he would be rumbled up out of his soundest\r\nsleep, in the dead of the night; at another, would be kept at his post\r\neight-and-forty hours on end. The more his persecutor besought him not\r\nto trouble himself to turn out, the more suspicious was the crafty Wegg\r\nthat indications had been observed of something hidden somewhere, and\r\nthat attempts were on foot to circumvent him. So continually broken was\r\nhis rest through these means, that he led the life of having wagered\r\nto keep ten thousand dog-watches in ten thousand hours, and looked\r\npiteously upon himself as always getting up and yet never going to bed.\r\nSo gaunt and haggard had he grown at last, that his wooden leg showed\r\ndisproportionate, and presented a thriving appearance in contrast\r\nwith the rest of his plagued body, which might almost have been termed\r\nchubby.\r\n\r\nHowever, Wegg\xe2\x80\x99s comfort was, that all his disagreeables were now over,\r\nand that he was immediately coming into his property. Of late, the\r\ngrindstone did undoubtedly appear to have been whirling at his own nose\r\nrather than Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s, but Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s nose was now to be sharpened fine.\r\nThus far, Mr Wegg had let his dusty friend off lightly, having been\r\nbaulked in that amiable design of frequently dining with him, by the\r\nmachinations of the sleepless dustman. He had been constrained to depute\r\nMr Venus to keep their dusty friend, Boffin, under inspection, while he\r\nhimself turned lank and lean at the Bower.\r\n\r\nTo Mr Venus\xe2\x80\x99s museum Mr Wegg repaired when at length the Mounds\r\nwere down and gone. It being evening, he found that gentleman, as he\r\nexpected, seated over his fire; but did not find him, as he expected,\r\nfloating his powerful mind in tea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, you smell rather comfortable here!\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg, seeming to take it\r\nill, and stopping and sniffing as he entered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I AM rather comfortable, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t use lemon in your business, do you?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Wegg, sniffing\r\nagain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, Mr Wegg,\xe2\x80\x99 said Venus. \xe2\x80\x98When I use it at all, I mostly use it in\r\ncobblers\xe2\x80\x99 punch.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you call cobblers\xe2\x80\x99 punch?\xe2\x80\x99 demanded Wegg, in a worse humour\r\nthan before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s difficult to impart the receipt for it, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Venus,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98because, however particular you may be in allotting your materials,\r\nso much will still depend upon the individual gifts, and there being a\r\nfeeling thrown into it. But the groundwork is gin.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In a Dutch bottle?\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg gloomily, as he sat himself down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very good, sir, very good!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Venus. \xe2\x80\x98Will you partake, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Will I partake?\xe2\x80\x99 returned Wegg very surlily. \xe2\x80\x98Why, of course I will!\r\nWILL a man partake, as has been tormented out of his five senses by\r\nan everlasting dustman with his head tied up! WILL he, too! As if he\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t let it put you out, Mr Wegg. You don\xe2\x80\x99t seem in your usual\r\nspirits.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If you come to that, you don\xe2\x80\x99t seem in your usual spirits,\xe2\x80\x99 growled\r\nWegg. \xe2\x80\x98You seem to be setting up for lively.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis circumstance appeared, in his then state of mind, to give Mr Wegg\r\nuncommon offence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And you\xe2\x80\x99ve been having your hair cut!\xe2\x80\x99 said Wegg, missing the usual\r\ndusty shock.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, Mr Wegg. There are strings that must not be played\r\nupon. No sir! Not sounded, unless in the most respectful and tuneful\r\nmanner. At a certain point of the\r\nroad between Clerkenwell and Boffin\xe2\x80\x99s house (Mr Wegg expressly insisted\r\nthat there should be no prefix to the Golden Dustman\xe2\x80\x99s name) the\r\npartners separated for the night.\r\n\r\nIt was a very bad night; to which succeeded a very bad morning. The\r\nstreets were so unusually slushy, muddy, and miserable, in the morning,\r\nthat Wegg rode to the scene of action; arguing that a man who was, as\r\nit were, going to the Bank to draw out a handsome property, could well\r\nafford that trifling expense.\r\n\r\nVenus was punctual, and Wegg undertook to knock at the door, and conduct\r\nthe conference. Door knocked at.
